1. Standard deviations...
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 22:40:48 -0000


Someone posted a curious average a few weeks ago (was it Joël?).
I may get very small standard deviations too. I think it happens when
you maintain a constant concentration level, and when the importance
of luck is reduced.
But tonight, I got this average: 14,75 14,7 20,66 18,39 18,85 16,95
21,89 16,56 16,75 14,91 11,19 20,41.
Standard deviation > 3 ! Sometimes I can reach good times, and
suddenly loose focus, even if I really try to keep it.
By the way, I noticed I often get 17.89 as individual times or
averages. I can explain this, it's the year of the french revolution.
And you, what are your weirdest averages, standard deviations or series?

Gilles.








2. Re: Equation!
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 23:49:49 -0000

Option 1) Answer "You say you know it. How do you know? Go ask the person who told you that." Option 2) Answer "How can an equation solve the cube? How does it even twist it? " Option 3) Answer "What do you mean?". If they still don't shut up, go to option 2 before trying anything else. Let them at least tell you what they mean/want. Option 4) Provide a short version of God's algorithm, e.g.: a) neighbours of a state are the states reachable in 1 move b) distance( solved state ) = 0 c) for all states s, distance( s ) = 1 + Min(over all neighbours n of s) distance( n ) Ok so it's not a single equation but several. Also, neighbours could/should be defined with equations as well. And it's not a solution but then again saying "equation that solves the cube" is pretty nonsense (see option 2 above). It can be used to solve the cube with the instruction "always do a move that results in a state with smaller distance value". Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > Hey, > > Does anybody have a good response for when they are asked: > > "I know there is a mathematical equation that solves the cube. What is > it?" > > I get asked this on a regular basis and I haven't been able to come up > with any clever reply for it. > > ~Bob
3. Re: [Speed cubing group] Standard deviations...
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 10 Apr 2005 18:55:58 -0500

Well, I've somehow managed to get <1 standard deviation averages using both a Fridrich 4 look LL method and with the Roux method. Of course, that only happens when I'm concentrating considerably, and it seems I'm another practitioner of Gille's religion: laziness. Also, I've been learning so many new methods and so much lately my averages have gone way down hill, but I expect with a healthy amount of shut-in practice, they should get back in shape. -Mike Bennett [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>

My standard deviations are always all over the place and often several seconds. However, I did once get a standard deviation on the Rubik's Magic of .03 seconds :) ~Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > Someone posted a curious average a few weeks ago (was it Joël?). > I may get very small standard deviations too. Sometimes I can reach good times, and > suddenly loose focus, even if I really try to keep it. > By the way, I noticed I often get 17.89 as individual times or > averages. 5. Layers solver needs help teaching a corners first solver
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 06:14:24 -0000


Hey everyone,

I posted this message on the corners first group already, but since it
has been quiet there lately, and I would really need a response by
Thursday this week in order to help me, I decided to post here too in
case any of you corners first solvers read this group too.

--------------

I post a lot at the international forum but haven't posted here
before, and I have a corners first specific quesiton.

I'm studying at college and it turns out that one of the guys on my
hall is a corners first cuber. He recently asked me about where to
start to learn more about cubing/speedcubing, specifically about the
layer by layer method. I told him, though, that since he is already
comfortable and used to corners first solving that there is no reason
he should switch to layer by layer.

>From what he's told me about how he solves I get the impression that
he uses a beginner/intermediate approach. What I'm going to do is to
show him ways to make his current steps more efficient. The problem
with this is that I am a diehard layers solver.

I already know that for solving the last 4 corners he only uses 1 or 2
algorithms, so that step needs work. Also I was going to point him to
the algorithms on speedcubing.com about solving the last edge (the 8th
edge, such that only the middle layer is left unsolved) and also
orient the middle layer edges.

I have messed around with corners first solving before and came up
with my own version of a probably fairly widely used approach. I
average about 50 seconds with this method.

What I do is this:
1) solve the first 4 corners intuitively
2) solve the last 4 in one alg using COLL (NOT CLL, I use COLL simply
because I know them from layers solving. If this guy gets interested
in learning more algs I would point him towards CLL and _not_ COLL)
3) solve the 8 top and bottom layer edges, making sure to try to
insert two at a time whenever possible. I insert the last two at the
same time.
4) permute the middle layer edges
5) orient the LL edges in one alg

I personally am not very fast with this method, but does it seem that
it could be made fairly fast with practice? Should I teach the guy on
my hall this method? For step 2 I would show him how to orient and
then permute the corners using 9 algs (7 to orient and 2 to permute)
rather than say "learn CLL, it's only 40 algs".

Should I tell him to look at the algs for inserting the 8th edge
(completing the two opposite layers) while also orienting the middle
layer edges? It seems like there are only 8, since the 4 middle layer
edge orientations have 8 different possibilites. Of course I haven't
learned them, so I don't know if that is true in practice.

Anyway I would appreciate some help. This guy sounds interested in
learning more about cubing, and I really don't want to make him a
Fridrich clone. Since he is already comfortable with corners first
solving, I'd rather show him an intermediate/advanced corners first
approach.

Thanks,
Chris





6. Re: [Speed cubing group] Layers solver needs help teaching a corners first solver
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 01:45:38 -0500

Hey there, Chris. In an attempt not to become a Fridrich clone myself, I've been experimenting with various methods recently. My primary method is now the Roux method, which I use to average around 34. I started toying with my own corners first method recently, though, and have used it to teach a few friends, with minimal effort and a heck of a lot less memorization than the 40 COLL algs you suggested. It's not an advanced method by any means, but I feel it has merit because it's upgradable without having to abandon. Here's an attempt at an explanation. If you decide you'd like to know more, let me know and I'll elaborate. 1) Solve bottom corners intuitively. Usually takes somewhere around 7 or 8 moves. 2) U layer corners in two looks. Algorithms, including reflections: 9 3) D layer edges. 5 incredibly simple (no more than 4 moves) cases covers all possibilities, including reflections. 4) Insert middle layer edges, controlling as much orientation as possible: 2 cases (edge 3 cycle and mirror). 5) Orient U layer edges. 3 algorithms cover all cases in a maximum of 2 steps. 6) Permute U layer edges. 3 cases. Using this method, which requires minimal memorization (the second step is easily solvable using a grand total of a corner swapping algorithm and Sune/antiSune but I use a few extras from my Fridrich method) I am able to solve the cube in under 45 seconds on average and around 75-80 moves. I've managed a single sub 30, but I got fairly lucky. My usual faster times are in the low and mid 30's with it. I'm sure if I worked on the method and practiced a little sub 35 averages would be attainable without major upgrading. I'm curious to see what you think. Let me know and I'll give you a list of sequences, though I'm sure you already know all of them already. =) -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: cmhardw<mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Monday, April 11, 2005 1:14 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Layers solver needs help teaching a corners first solver Hey everyone, I posted this message on the corners first group already, but since it has been quiet there lately, and I would really need a response by Thursday this week in order to help me, I decided to post here too in case any of you corners first solvers read this group too. -------------- I post a lot at the international forum but haven't posted here before, and I have a corners first specific quesiton. I'm studying at college and it turns out that one of the guys on my hall is a corners first cuber. He recently asked me about where to start to learn more about cubing/speedcubing, specifically about the layer by layer method. I told him, though, that since he is already comfortable and used to corners first solving that there is no reason he should switch to layer by layer. From what he's told me about how he solves I get the impression that he uses a beginner/intermediate approach. What I'm going to do is to show him ways to make his current steps more efficient. The problem with this is that I am a diehard layers solver. I already know that for solving the last 4 corners he only uses 1 or 2 algorithms, so that step needs work. Also I was going to point him to the algorithms on speedcubing.com about solving the last edge (the 8th edge, such that only the middle layer is left unsolved) and also orient the middle layer edges. I have messed around with corners first solving before and came up with my own version of a probably fairly widely used approach. I average about 50 seconds with this method. What I do is this: 1) solve the first 4 corners intuitively 2) solve the last 4 in one alg using COLL (NOT CLL, I use COLL simply because I know them from layers solving. If this guy gets interested in learning more algs I would point him towards CLL and _not_ COLL) 3) solve the 8 top and bottom layer edges, making sure to try to insert two at a time whenever possible. I insert the last two at the same time. 4) permute the middle layer edges 5) orient the LL edges in one alg I personally am not very fast with this method, but does it seem that it could be made fairly fast with practice? Should I teach the guy on my hall this method? For step 2 I would show him how to orient and then permute the corners using 9 algs (7 to orient and 2 to permute) rather than say "learn CLL, it's only 40 algs". Should I tell him to look at the algs for inserting the 8th edge (completing the two opposite layers) while also orienting the middle layer edges? It seems like there are only 8, since the 4 middle layer edge orientations have 8 different possibilites. Of course I haven't learned them, so I don't know if that is true in practice. Anyway I would appreciate some help. This guy sounds interested in learning more about cubing, and I really don't want to make him a Fridrich clone. Since he is already comfortable with corners first solving, I'd rather show him an intermediate/advanced corners first approach. Thanks, Chris ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Yahoo! Groups Links a.. 7. Memorizing Algs
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 06:46:09 -0000


I tried my hand at a memorization tutorial. I hope someone finds use
with it. If you have any ideas/hints for this tutorial, please let me
know.

http://www.geocities.com/rubiks_galaxia/alg_memo_richy.htm


Happy Cubing!

-Richard





8. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Starting Color
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 08:16:51 +0100

When I cubed in the 80s and then again when I restarted I just chose the colour that looked easiest. But the consensus here seemed to be that it was faster to always start with the same colour so I switched. I've been cubing with the same colour for quite a few months now and probably agree that its faster. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Sunday, April 10, 2005 6:22 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Starting Color > > > I begin with white. When I first started, it was easiest to recognize > because of its brightness. Of course, it is true that the starting > color is practically irrelevant once you get used to starting with a > specific color. Is there anybody out there that starts with the color > that looks like it will be easiest to begin with? > > ~Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, metgorubiks > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Just curious, what color do most of you do the cross with, I used > > green, from watching solving videos it seems like most people do > white. > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > >

About the "single trick to solve the cube" thing. I guess if someone was taught, and really understood, about conjugates they would be able to solve and would consider that to be a "trick". Thats the way I first figured it out! 11. [Speed cubing group] Re: Starting Color
From: portoseb <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 08:45:02 -0000


I use the Lars Petrus method with fixed coulours. I decided not to
always use the same colour since I can get really nasty positions for a
2x2x2. But I always go for the same 2x2x3, that is the yellow-gree one,
so at the begining I can choose between two different 2x2x2's. I do
that because after that I'm left with white and blue colours as the two-
generator colours, which have the biggest contrast on the cube so
seeing the bad edges happens almost instantly. Then I usually try to
leave white as LL because of your reasons: it's bright. I also think
that using the same colour for LL helps memorising the positions much
faster.

Sebastian





12. Re: Layers solver needs help teaching a corners first solver
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 09:02:33 -0000

If you need a pure corners-first approach for your guy, he can try: - 4 + 4 (but not CLL sequences, Waterman's for example or shorter/faster). - Gaétan's or even easier: - http://www.ai.sri.com/~cheyer/rubiks/rubiks.html - http://rubikscube.info/ortega.html But I feel that keeping all the edges unsolved is less efficient, because with a same number of pieces, it's faster to recognize them if they belong to 2 distinct categories. A good compromise (not strictly corners-first) between speed and complexity could be: - Solve L face minus 1 edge (Waterman's way, 1x2x3 + 2 corners, etc). - Solve the last 4 corners. - Solve 3 R-edges + 1 L/R-edge. - Solve the last L/R-edge while orienting M-edges. - Permute M-edges. Thierry Gagnaire says he was sub-19 with it, I'm very confident that sub-18 is possible. Have fun, Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I posted this message on the corners first group already, but since it > has been quiet there lately, and I would really need a response by > Thursday this week in order to help me, I decided to post here too in > case any of you corners first solvers read this group too. > > -------------- > > I post a lot at the international forum but haven't posted here > before, and I have a corners first specific quesiton. > > I'm studying at college and it turns out that one of the guys on my > hall is a corners first cuber. He recently asked me about where to > start to learn more about cubing/speedcubing, specifically about the > layer by layer method. I told him, though, that since he is already > comfortable and used to corners first solving that there is no reason > he should switch to layer by layer. > > From what he's told me about how he solves I get the impression that > he uses a beginner/intermediate approach. What I'm going to do is to > show him ways to make his current steps more efficient. The problem > with this is that I am a diehard layers solver. > > I already know that for solving the last 4 corners he only uses 1 or 2 > algorithms, so that step needs work. Also I was going to point him to > the algorithms on speedcubing.com about solving the last edge (the 8th > edge, such that only the middle layer is left unsolved) and also > orient the middle layer edges. > > I have messed around with corners first solving before and came up > with my own version of a probably fairly widely used approach. I > average about 50 seconds with this method. > > What I do is this: > 1) solve the first 4 corners intuitively > 2) solve the last 4 in one alg using COLL (NOT CLL, I use COLL simply > because I know them from layers solving. If this guy gets interested > in learning more algs I would point him towards CLL and _not_ COLL) > 3) solve the 8 top and bottom layer edges, making sure to try to > insert two at a time whenever possible. I insert the last two at the > same time. > 4) permute the middle layer edges > 5) orient the LL edges in one alg > > I personally am not very fast with this method, but does it seem that > it could be made fairly fast with practice? Should I teach the guy on > my hall this method? For step 2 I would show him how to orient and > then permute the corners using 9 algs (7 to orient and 2 to permute) > rather than say "learn CLL, it's only 40 algs". > > Should I tell him to look at the algs for inserting the 8th edge > (completing the two opposite layers) while also orienting the middle > layer edges? It seems like there are only 8, since the 4 middle layer > edge orientations have 8 different possibilites. Of course I haven't > learned them, so I don't know if that is true in practice. > > Anyway I would appreciate some help. This guy sounds interested in > learning more about cubing, and I really don't want to make him a > Fridrich clone. Since he is already comfortable with corners first > solving, I'd rather show him an intermediate/advanced corners first > approach. > > Thanks, > Chris
13. Re: Layers solver needs help teaching a corners first solver
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 09:25:26 -0000


Hey :-)

> I have messed around with corners first solving before and came up
> with my own version of a probably fairly widely used approach. I
> average about 50 seconds with this method.
>
> What I do is this:
> 1) solve the first 4 corners intuitively
> 2) solve the last 4 in one alg using COLL (NOT CLL, I use COLL
simply
> because I know them from layers solving. If this guy gets
interested
> in learning more algs I would point him towards CLL and _not_ COLL)
> 3) solve the 8 top and bottom layer edges, making sure to try to
> insert two at a time whenever possible. I insert the last two at
the
> same time.
> 4) permute the middle layer edges
> 5) orient the LL edges in one alg
>
> I personally am not very fast with this method, but does it seem
that
> it could be made fairly fast with practice? Should I teach the
guy on
> my hall this method?

Yes this seems like an okay intermediate corners first method. Yo, i
wish u'd stick to that method chris. Then i could beat u ;-) Even if
i use that method also. Im about 35-40 secs with such a method.

One suggestion though, complete first layer before doing last 4
corners. Yes i know it's then not longer a pure corners first
approach. Inserting edges into bottom layer (first solved layer
remains at top when i do this approach) is easy with an alg like
this : R' E R2 E R' or R E' R2 E' R (first one backwards). A more
advanced approach will orient the middle edges while doing the edges
on the bottom layer. Or one could learn all the cases for edges on
the middle layers. I once worked out all those algs. It's not all
that many. Orient edges then position them is also not that bad.
(This is opposite order of what u suggested chris!) There are a few
bad cases for that when all edges need be flipped. Those are better
dealt with by simply doing 2 edge-cycles. Ie diverting from the
orient/permute pattern.

> Thanks,
> Chris

Happy cubing!

-Per





14. Another Method Idea...
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 10:20:14 -0000


Yes, another method idea :P The one I'm about to describe has been
inspired by a variety of different methods. While I'm sure it's been
explored, I have yet to see it discussed.

Step 1: Solve [D] layer except for one corner slot
Step 2: Orient and Permute LL edges using the empty corner slot
Step 3: Orient and Permute Middle Layer
Step 4: Solve remaining corners


This is a simplified version of the idea. I haven't persued learning
it yet because I'm not sure if it's worth the trouble. Let me know
what you think!

-Richard





15. Re: Equation!
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 13:54:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > Option 4) > Provide a short version of God's algorithm, e.g.: Or simply give them one of the Devil's Algorithm formulae discussed here a few months ago. That should keep them quiet for a while. ;) Mike
16. Re: Memorizing Algs
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 14:18:34 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > I tried my hand at a memorization tutorial. I hope someone finds use > with it. Oh, I like that -- I've been discovering some of these ideas for myself recently. It is easy to say that much of it is common sense, but (to take one example) most of the sequences I use were learnt without the use of triggers, and the learning process was definitely harder then. Idea from a non-expert: in cases where the inverse of a sequence A is useful, learn both at the same time, if you can. To practice, start with a solved cube and apply A (once) then A' (twice) then A (twice), and so on. That way you regularly get to see the cases that A and A' apply to, and you get equal amounts of practice on each. Mike
17. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Starting Color
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 10:29:10 -0400

I start with orange. I used to solve with cubes that had different
color arrangements (RO/BG/WY vs. RO/BW/GY). Red and orange were the
only opposite colors that were the same with the two arrangements, and
orange is a lot brighter (especially with the Rubik's Studio cubes).


18. Re: Layers solver needs help teaching a corners first solver
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 16:03:31 -0000

Thanks for the help everybody, I guess mainly what I am looking for is a way to show this guy how to improve his method without saying to just learn lots of algs. I'm not sure how into speedcubing he is, but I assume since he seemed willing to learn a whole new method that he is fairly dedicated. I guess for now I'll show him the 9 algs necessary to do the last four corners relatively quickly (since he only uses I think 2 now), as well as point him to the algs for inserting the 8th edge (such that only the middle layer is left) and also orient all middle layer edges at the same time. That is 17 algs, or I guess 25 if you count reflections, which seems like a reasonable amount given that I think he is fairly dedicated. Am I correct that there are only 8 (16 with reflections) algs necessary for inserting the 8th edge and flipping the middle layer edges? I don't want to tell him to learn that step but it turn out to be a huge number of algs. I figure this method is scalable if he gets into speedcubing since the 9 algs for the last 4 corners are all useful CLL algs, leaving only 31 if he decides to learn that. Also the algs to insert that last edge and flip the middle layer edges seem to be mentioned a lot on corners first sites and for corners first solving, so it seems like a useful set of algs to know, even if just for special cases in more advanced methods. I figure I'll also learn those edge algs along with this guy. I think it would be cool to expand my corners first knowledge, so this is also partially a selfish pursuit in that it is a convenient opportuity for me to learn about corners first solving. If anyone else has any more ideas for beginner/intermediate corners first adaptations please keep posting! Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hey :-) > > > I have messed around with corners first solving before and came up > > with my own version of a probably fairly widely used approach. I > > average about 50 seconds with this method. > > > > What I do is this: > > 1) solve the first 4 corners intuitively > > 2) solve the last 4 in one alg using COLL (NOT CLL, I use COLL > simply > > because I know them from layers solving. If this guy gets > interested > > in learning more algs I would point him towards CLL and _not_ COLL) > > 3) solve the 8 top and bottom layer edges, making sure to try to > > insert two at a time whenever possible. I insert the last two at > the > > same time. > > 4) permute the middle layer edges > > 5) orient the LL edges in one alg > > > > I personally am not very fast with this method, but does it seem > that > > it could be made fairly fast with practice? Should I teach the > guy on > > my hall this method? > > Yes this seems like an okay intermediate corners first method. Yo, i > wish u'd stick to that method chris. Then i could beat u ;-) Even if > i use that method also. Im about 35-40 secs with such a method. > > One suggestion though, complete first layer before doing last 4 > corners. Yes i know it's then not longer a pure corners first > approach. Inserting edges into bottom layer (first solved layer > remains at top when i do this approach) is easy with an alg like > this : R' E R2 E R' or R E' R2 E' R (first one backwards). A more > advanced approach will orient the middle edges while doing the edges > on the bottom layer. Or one could learn all the cases for edges on > the middle layers. I once worked out all those algs. It's not all > that many. Orient edges then position them is also not that bad. > (This is opposite order of what u suggested chris!) There are a few > bad cases for that when all edges need be flipped. Those are better > dealt with by simply doing 2 edge-cycles. Ie diverting from the > orient/permute pattern. > > > Thanks, > > Chris > > Happy cubing! > > -Per
19. Re: Layers solver needs help teaching a corners first solver
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 16:40:45 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > [...] > I guess for now I'll show him the 9 algs necessary to do the last > four corners relatively quickly (since he only uses I think 2 now), Learning 7 orientation sequences is quite easy: - Sune, Anti-Sune, Double-Sune - FRUR'U'F' and the doubled version: FRUR'U'RUR'U'F' - Another you like and it's "anti" for the last 2 cases. That's only 3 basic sequences to figure out. > [...] > Am I correct that there are only 8 (16 with reflections) algs > necessary for inserting the 8th edge and flipping the middle layer > edges? I don't want to tell him to learn that step but it turn out > to be a huge number of algs. See http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Step_4.html , Step 4-1b. If you simplify 2 cases and take care of symetries, there are only 4 sequences left to learn. BUT there's more than this when the last edge is already in place, twisted or not. > [...] > I figure I'll also learn those edge algs along with this guy. I > think it would be cool to expand my corners first knowledge, so this > is also partially a selfish pursuit in that it is a convenient > opportuity for me to learn about corners first solving. > Nice, M (or E) is going to become your best friend :-) And don't miss my above link ( http://rubikscube.info/ortega.html ), it allows you to solve the corners faster than using a 2-stage CLL for about the same number of sequences! (+color neutral method) Gilles
20. 2 > 3
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 18:13:33 -0000


On the box for the Rubik's 4x4x4, it says that the 4x4x4 is not harder than the
3x3x3. It just requires a different approach.

I don't think this is true at all.
1. The 4x4x4 has way more combinations than the 3x3x3
2. The most popular method is to unite the edges and centers, then solve like a
3x3x3.
3. The world record time for the 4x4x4 is at least 5 times as much as the 3x3x3.





21. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Starting Color
From: Crispy <redivre@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 11:28:11 -0700 (PDT)

I start with Red --- Bob Burton <bob@...> wrote: > > I begin with white. When I first started, it was > easiest to recognize > because of its brightness. Of course, it is true > that the starting > color is practically irrelevant once you get used to > starting with a > specific color. Is there anybody out there that > starts with the color > that looks like it will be easiest to begin with? > > ~Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > metgorubiks > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Just curious, what color do most of you do the > cross with, I used > > green, from watching solving videos it seems like > most people do > white. > > > > Philia, Crispy __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? Yahoo! Small Business - Try our new resources site! http://smallbusiness.yahoo.com/resources/
22. Re: 2 > 3
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 19:16:26 -0000


> On the box for the Rubik's 4x4x4, it says that the 4x4x4 is not
harder than the
> 3x3x3. It just requires a different approach.
>
> I don't think this is true at all.

Though I agree with you, I'm not sure I agree with your arguments.

> 1. The 4x4x4 has way more combinations than the 3x3x3

The 5x5x5 has way more combinations than the 4x4x4, but I would
consider it "easier" because of the lack of parities. The megaminx has
more combinations than the 4x4x4, but I would consider it easier, too,
because it can be solved almost exactly like the 3x3x3. The 2x2x2 has
more combinations than a pyraminx, but I consider the pyraminx to be
MUCH easier to solve...Difficulty of puzzles can be very opinionated.

> 2. The most popular method is to unite the edges and centers, then
solve like a
> 3x3x3.

Perhaps that's not the "easiest" method to use for solving a 4x4x4.
There are certainly other ways to solve it. Maybe some of the other
ways of solving a 4x4x4 are easier? You say it requires a "different
approach, so maybe the approach that is mentioned is easier than that
off a 3x3x3 (note: I don't agree with this, but it is possible).

> 3. The world record time for the 4x4x4 is at least 5 times as much as
the 3x3x3.

The world record time for blindsolving a 3x3x3 is nearly twice as fast
as solving a 3x3x3 with feet, but surely it's not easier to solve it
blindfolded (only faster :P). Speed and difficulty don't necessarily
correlate to each other.

~Bob

28. Question for Chris
From: "grsbmd" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 06:38:34 -0000


Just wondering, do you think learning ZB will improve your times on
bigger cubes at all?





29. Re: Question for Chris
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Apr 2005 01:59:34 -0000

> Just wondering, do you think learning ZB will improve your times on > bigger cubes at all? Hey, Yes I think it will. I've already experimented with doing ZBF2L on the 4x4x4 and had positive results, and once I am comfortable with all the ZBF2L algs on the 3x3x3 I am going to start relearning them for one-handed solving since I think it will help for that too. I mentioned a little bit about my 4x4x4 ZBF2L solving on my ZB progress page http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/myzb.html Once I am completely comfortable with using ZBF2L on the 3x3x3 normally I'll start working on the other categories. I think ZBLL is a bad idea for the 4x4x4 since it is possible to have two corners switched (which can be tricky to recognize and cause problems sometimes), so my 4x4x4 strategy will most likely be just ZBF2L / COLL / PLL. Also on a side note I'm getting lots of sub-20 ZBF2L averages, and I set a non-lucky 12 second solve already using ZB techniques! I'm improving slowly but steadily. I think I'll go sub-19 fairly soon, maybe in a week or two. I still don't know if ZB will compare to Fridrich or Gilles' method, but I am of course trying to see how well I do when I have practiced the system more. Of course I'm curious if the method will help me improve my times, and I'd be happy if it would, but I'm just having fun learning a new method right now. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "grsbmd" <grsbmd@y...> wrote: > > Just wondering, do you think learning ZB will improve your times on > bigger cubes at all?
30. edge-swapping alg?
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Apr 2005 03:27:11 -0000


does anybody have an algorithm that swaps the front and right edges of
the bottom layer with each other AND the front & right edges of the top
layer with each other? (ie - FU <-> RU & FD <-> RD)

~Bob





31. Re: [Speed cubing group] edge-swapping alg?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 22:32:55 -0500

Make it into a simple commutator. Using simple setup moves (D2 B2 and then either R2 or L2) twist the bottom layer around and turn the bottom layer edges in question so they're on the top. Then apply your Z permutation algorithm. I'll work on a shorter solution, but that's a good way to start. -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: Bob Burton<mailto:bob@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Monday, April 11, 2005 10:27 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] edge-swapping alg? does anybody have an algorithm that swaps the front and right edges of the bottom layer with each other AND the front & right edges of the top layer with each other? (ie - FU <-> RU & FD <-> RD) ~Bob [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
32. Re: [Speed cubing group] edge-swapping alg?
From: Doug Reed <dougreed@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 2005 21:43:45 -0500

Hi Bob,

This might be what you're looking for. Just figured it out.

(D R2 D') F2 R2 F2 R2 F2 R2 (D R2 D')

Doug

Bob Burton wrote:

>does anybody have an algorithm that swaps the front and right edges of
>the bottom layer with each other AND the front & right edges of the top
>layer with each other? (ie - FU <-> RU & FD <-> RD)
>
>~Bob
>
>
>
>
>
>
>Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

34. Re: edge-swapping alg?
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Apr 2005 04:05:07 -0000

I use R E B' U2 M2 U2 M2 B E' R' for that case. Or also R E B' M2 U2 M2 U2 B E' R' works as well, whichever is faster. I would probably use the second one. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > does anybody have an algorithm that swaps the front and right edges of > the bottom layer with each other AND the front & right edges of the top > layer with each other? (ie - FU <-> RU & FD <-> RD) > > ~Bob

44. Re: [Speed cubing group] begginer..
From: Dennis Webb <dhwebb@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Apr 2005 09:47:17 -0500

I think a minute is pretty good for a beginner. Obviously a good,
properly lubed cube helps a lot. Also doing the fancy fingerwork
helps also. I use the Lars method which is nice and simple to start
with. I think the Friedrich is the most common though.


45. Re: begginer..
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Apr 2005 15:18:42 -0000

Hey, Well, there are many speedcubing methods that you could learn, but the Fridrich method is the most common. If you are interested in learning it, try to learn to do the first two layers (F2L) intuitively so that you can place corner-edge pairs into their proper slots simultaneously. Then I would recommend learning PLL algorithms, and then the orientations. There are plenty of websites to learn these things from. Good luck, Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, souzamusic <souzamusic@i...> wrote: > hey guys, where do I begin for speedcubing? Can anyone tell me the most used > methods? I can do it in 1 minute, but I'd like to learn a method to get the > 20 seconds or less..any help? > > > Thanks a lot! > > =) > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
46. Re: Macky's New Average

Hi Per, At the Caltech Winter Tournament 2004 Tyson held a "Champion's solve." I thought that Macky might try it on a Deluxe so I loaned him one of mine. He solved it in less than 13 seconds. There was a bit of a mix up, and before he tried the "Champion's" scramble on the Deluxe he solved that scramble on another cube, though it turned out that he had solved it differently on the Deluxe. When I got home I discovered that I had accidently loaned Macky the wrong cube, he had done that solve on an older Deluxe which wasn't lubed. There used to be a video of the (12 point something) solve on Dan Henage's page, but it's not there right now. 49. Re: begginer..
From: "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Apr 2005 19:56:31 -0000

Hi, I think that Fridrich is also a good method for beginner. I started cubing seriously in February and I have a personnal best time of 24.77 and a best average of 36.66 with that method. You really should try to do the F2L steps first by searching yourself (or ask someone to explain you the general idea) then optimize your moves with the solutions you can find nearly evrywhere. But before that, I recommend you to learn the OLL and at least both the U and A PLL's (U changes 3 edges and A changes 3 corners) because they enable you to solve any situation on the top layer. Then learn some other (for example : 2 opposite edges).. and with work you should see your times being improved. ;-) Good Luck ! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > Hey, > > Well, there are many speedcubing methods that you could learn, but the > Fridrich method is the most common. If you are interested in learning > it, try to learn to do the first two layers (F2L) intuitively so that > you can place corner-edge pairs into their proper slots simultaneously. > Then I would recommend learning PLL algorithms, and then the > orientations. There are plenty of websites to learn these things from. > > Good luck, > Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, souzamusic > <souzamusic@i...> wrote: > > hey guys, where do I begin for speedcubing? Can anyone tell me the > most used > > methods? I can do it in 1 minute, but I'd like to learn a method to > get the > > 20 seconds or less..any help? > > > > > > Thanks a lot! > > > > =) > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
50. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: begginer..
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 12 Apr 2005 15:08:26 -0500

If a beginner wants to seriously optimize their times without extreme and outrageous amounts of memorization, they should check out Andy Camann's site. His explanation of the working corner method explanation is fantastic. Using that method, low 30's averages are possible, and from there, F2L is much easier to understand once you decide to upgrade. One needs not learn all of the OLL or even the PLL in order to average sub-30. Improving first two layers time is the way to improvement for beginners. Otherwise, I recommend using either the Petrus method or looking into corners first solutions. They often require minimal memorization and result in great times and fewer moves on average. http://rubikscube.info<http://rubikscube.info/> is a fantastic site for such solutions. Whatever method you choose, good luck and happy cubing. -Mike Bennett [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

54. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Memorizing Algs
From: Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Apr 2005 16:14:58 -0700 (PDT)

I'll take your advice on that :) Practice with algs that share an inverse is definetly a plus. I've also received a few more ideas via personal email. I'll update the tutorial this weekend. If anyone else has some ideas please let me know! :P -Richard --- mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > "richy_jr_2000" > <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > > I tried my hand at a memorization tutorial. I > hope someone finds use > > with it. > > Oh, I like that -- I've been discovering some of > these ideas for myself > recently. It is easy to say that much of it is > common sense, but (to > take one example) most of the sequences I use were > learnt without the > use of triggers, and the learning process was > definitely harder then. > > Idea from a non-expert: in cases where the inverse > of a sequence A is > useful, learn both at the same time, if you can. To > practice, start > with a solved cube and apply A (once) then A' > (twice) then A (twice), > and so on. That way you regularly get to see the > cases that A and A' > apply to, and you get equal amounts of practice on > each. > > Mike > > > > __________________________________________________ Do You Yahoo!? 58. [Speed cubing group] Re: Memorizing Algs
From: "dwarmaj" <Dwarmaj@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Apr 2005 23:52:29 -0000

Yes, I've memorized the different algoritms (mirrors and inverses). But have only memorized the cases for a couple (A, B, and F configurations). Right now I cheat by turning the C-G configurations into a B which can be done with one Sune. Then I solve B. Learning the different cases for each configuration should lower my LL from ~23 moves to closer to 15. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > Recognizing different cases you mean? It also has algorithms for a 4 look last layer. And if any of it doesn't make sence, just ask me and I'll do my best to explain. 60. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Memorizing Algs
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 02:56:31 +0200

At the moment I'm trying a thing recommeded to me regarding memorizing algs and their cases. I've printed out each case (using imagecube, size 200) on a sqaure piece of paper (I actually printed several on the same paper and them cut them into squares :). At first I lay them out on the table, doing all the separate algs over and over, until the cube is restored. When I feel a bit more confident, I draw random alg-papers and do the algs. Thereby learning the alg and learning to recognize the case. Seems to work pretty good so far. /Gustav dwarmaj skrev: >Yes, I've memorized the different algoritms (mirrors and inverses). >But have only memorized the cases for a couple (A, B, and F >configurations). > >Right now I cheat by turning the C-G configurations into a B which >can be done with one Sune. Then I solve B. > >Learning the different cases for each configuration should lower my >LL from ~23 moves to closer to 15. > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Richard Patterson ><richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > > >>Recognizing different cases you mean? 61. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Macky's New Average
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>

Date: Tue, 12 Apr 2005 21:26:32 -0700 (PDT)

well lets just say from what i know, macky knows a lot. he pretty much learned how to solve the cube using corner method, fridrich, and also a bunch of other methods including ring method. he can pretty much solve the cube with the other methods in about 30sec. in a case like this, its true that learning lots about the cube, not only the fridrich can really lend a helping hand by making you really understand the way the cube pieces moves, and from experience, you can do many other nifty algs and tricks even while using the fridrich method. sincerely, John BTW: rumours about macky learnt all the ZB aint true. i heard it from him myself. --- d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...> wrote: > > Hi Per, > > At the Caltech Winter Tournament 2004 Tyson held > a "Champion's > solve." 62. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Memorizing Algs
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 05:33:21 +0100

My way of memorising. I order the cases. Then I memorise each algroithm in order in my head - just the moves. I dont always even touch a cube at this stage although sometimes it helps especially if I'm choosing between two possible algs. once they are memorised in my head then I start to practice with them. Its slow at first because I have to recognise a case, then where it appears in my ordering, then translate the moves in my head into real moves on the cube. The benefit is that I can start using the algs much sooner. and without having to carry pieces of paper around too much. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Gustav Fredell" <gufr5747@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, April 13, 2005 1:56 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Memorizing Algs > > At the moment I'm trying a thing recommeded to me regarding memorizing > algs and their cases. > > I've printed out each case (using imagecube, size 200) on a sqaure piece > of paper (I actually printed several on the same paper and them cut them > into squares :). 63. Question about cube group (yay math!)
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 05:10:03 -0000


Hey all you math people,

We haven't had an interesting discussion lately, so I figured I would
post a question I've been thinking about. I hope it hasn't been asked
before, but here goes.

I visited my cousin not too long ago and was cubing a little bit, he
can't solve the cube yet but is interested to learn how. I was giving
him some puzzles to solve (6 move patterns such as R2 U2 R2 L2 U2 L2)
to get him started before I start showing him the full solution.

Anyway he gave me a puzzle and told me to make a position such that no
two stickers of the same color are touching on any face. I started
from a solved cube and did the superflip, but then he said that the
diagonal X's on the faces count as two like colored stickers touching
since they share a corner. He also said that I should do this so that
diagonally across an edge should count too. So that would mean that
the F sticker of UF is adjacent to the U stickers of both ULF and URF.
I had a hard time thinking of a way to do this, but I found one.

Switch every corner with it's opposite across the body diagonal of the
cube (4 transpositions), then do the superflip and viola!

My question is though, is this the only position where this works?
The puzzle is to find a (of course legal) position on the cube such
that no two adjacent stickers (either horizontally, vertically, or
diagonally if on the same face - or horizontally or diagonally across
an edge of the cube) are the same color.

My alg to set this case up is a bit long, 2 permutations and then the
superflip, but I used Cube Explorer to find a shorter move: D' U F2 .
B L R D' B2 R2 D' B F' R B2 R' F2 R' (perform on a solved cube).

Is this the only possible position? By that I mean this type of
position performed on any of the 24 possible rotations of the cube.

Chris





64. Re: Question about cube group (yay math!)
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 05:15:31 -0000


> Is this the only possible position? By that I mean this type of
> position performed on any of the 24 possible rotations of the cube.

In my last post I forgot to mention this also includes all possible
rotations of the corners. So switching every corner with its body
diagonally opposite corner, then doing the superflip, then allowing
the corners to have all 3^7 possible orientations gives 2187 different
positions such that the puzzle my cousin gave me is satisfied. I
meant, is there a different permutation of the pieces that, given you
fix the orientations correctly, still satisifes the puzzle?

Chris





65. Re: Macky's New Average
From: "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 05:38:19 -0000

Hi Per, Hmm...would you please tell me where on earth people talk about me (or anyone!) having learned all of ZB? =) My method is Fridrich with the following: - extended cross when possible - other block approaches to F2L when appropriate - F2L using empty slots with cross on bottom or left - multiple algs memorized for most c-e pairs used in such a way that there is minimum pause (_not_ to control edge orientation) - avoiding 4 wrong LL edges when fixing the fourth slot (but only when it flows nicely from the rest of the F2L) - the nicer patterns from COLL when all LL edges are correct (if it's not a nice COLL, I just use the normal OLL pattern but still know what corner permutation it's going to end up with.) - PLL recognition by blocks of same colors; AUF at end or beginning, never both - slamming down the cube pretty quickly ;) I know several algorithms for each F2L, but I haven't actually sit down and memorized their effects on edge orientation. Like Ron (read the comments on his new record!), I'm doubting the theoretical benefits of ZB. The number of moves in ZB is very appealing, but I find that F2L is much faster without it. Of course, maybe it'll all be very smooth once you master ZBF2L. I used a new 25th anniversary cube (best of the 20 purchased) to set the new average. The cube is pretty lubed right now...I thought until now that stiff (but soft) cubes work better for me (because I'm not very fast at LL), but this cube is very nice. It is true that I used a Deluxe at one point. It was with a Deluxe that I came very near to the 15 sec barrier. The only reason I haven't touched it recently is because it's not tuned, and that takes longer than buying new cubes. I have to thank David for the Deluxe, of course. I plan to work much more with it once it's adjusted. =) I don't think that I will ever work too much with the 5-by. I'm finding it much harder to pair up the edges for this size than it is for the 4-by. I've never even had a sub-3 min solve! Macky --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hmmm ... > > Another option to stop Macky is to make a soft cushioned pillow- cube > thing and write Macky on it. And then stick lots of needles into > it ... Woodoo ... lol ... just kidding :-P > > Btw Macky, on the serious side. There are lots of rumours about what > kind of cube and what method u use. Some have claimed that u do ur > best averages on a Deluxe cube and that u already know and use all > the zb stuff. What is the truth? Probably u have all the answers to > this at ur site, but it's nice to see it here in the group as well. > > Many congratz on ur new avg Macky !!!! **fanfare** > > When will u seriously pick up speedcubing the 5x5x5? I know that u > have done sone awesome times on the 4x4x4 so it's not really much > new to learn to step up to 5x5x5. > > Cheers!! > > -Per >

69. Re: Question about cube group (yay math!)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 10:07:56 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > Is this the only possible position? By that I mean this type of > > position performed on any of the 24 possible rotations of the cube. Hi Chris If I understand you correctly, the position generated by F R L2 U' R2 L' U' D2 R2 F D B D F2 U' R' D' F2 D2 L2 also solves the problem. I found it myself, but because the position has a lot of symmetry, you can find the optimal generator on Jaap's pages on symmetrical patterns: http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/symmetr1.htm It is pattern 3g: supertwist+superflip+pons-asinorum. I haven't tried to find any other solutions... Mike
70. Re: Macky's New Average
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 10:16:37 -0000

Hi Macky! Or u prefer ppl call u Shotaro? Well, most simply call u Macky so i just follow suite :-) The rumour about that u know all zb stuff (or at least a large part of it) i cant really recall where it comes from. It's something i heard almost a yr ago now. Which means u must have learnt it really quickly since it was very new at that time ;-) So indeed i was sceptical about it. And yes i agree with u that a "simple" method can be just as fast or faster than a more sophisticated method. Cause fewer cases to distinguish and u get less time lost in recognition, better flow and better lookahead. Even if u should learn optimised fingertricks for 700 algs it won't help u much if u need 1 sec to recognize a case :- o 3 steps is then 3 lost secs ... What is the difference between the 25th anniversary cube and the diy- kit? I mean also the geometry of the cubies, not only the assembly/tuning. Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > Hi Per, > > Hmm...would you please tell me where on earth people talk about me > (or anyone!) having learned all of ZB? =) > > My method is Fridrich with the following: > - extended cross when possible > - other block approaches to F2L when appropriate > - F2L using empty slots with cross on bottom or left > - multiple algs memorized for most c-e pairs used in such a way that > there is minimum pause (_not_ to control edge orientation) > - avoiding 4 wrong LL edges when fixing the fourth slot (but only > when it flows nicely from the rest of the F2L) > - the nicer patterns from COLL when all LL edges are correct (if it's > not a nice COLL, I just use the normal OLL pattern but still know > what corner permutation it's going to end up with.) > - PLL recognition by blocks of same colors; AUF at end or beginning, > never both > - slamming down the cube pretty quickly ;) > > I know several algorithms for each F2L, but I haven't actually sit > down and memorized their effects on edge orientation. > > Like Ron (read the comments on his new record!), I'm doubting the > theoretical benefits of ZB. The number of moves in ZB is very > appealing, but I find that F2L is much faster without it. Of course, > maybe it'll all be very smooth once you master ZBF2L. > > I used a new 25th anniversary cube (best of the 20 purchased) to set > the new average. The cube is pretty lubed right now...I thought until > now that stiff (but soft) cubes work better for me (because I'm not > very fast at LL), but this cube is very nice. It is true that I used > a Deluxe at one point. It was with a Deluxe that I came very near to > the 15 sec barrier. The only reason I haven't touched it recently is > because it's not tuned, and that takes longer than buying new cubes. > I have to thank David for the Deluxe, of course. I plan to work much > more with it once it's adjusted. =) > > I don't think that I will ever work too much with the 5-by. I'm > finding it much harder to pair up the edges for this size than it is > for the 4-by. I've never even had a sub-3 min solve! > > Macky > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Hmmm ... > > > > Another option to stop Macky is to make a soft cushioned pillow- > cube > > thing and write Macky on it. And then stick lots of needles into > > it ... Woodoo ... lol ... just kidding :-P > > > > Btw Macky, on the serious side. There are lots of rumours about > what > > kind of cube and what method u use. Some have claimed that u do ur > > best averages on a Deluxe cube and that u already know and use all > > the zb stuff. What is the truth? Probably u have all the answers to > > this at ur site, but it's nice to see it here in the group as well. > > > > Many congratz on ur new avg Macky !!!! **fanfare** > > > > When will u seriously pick up speedcubing the 5x5x5? I know that u > > have done sone awesome times on the 4x4x4 so it's not really much > > new to learn to step up to 5x5x5. > > > > Cheers!! > > > > -Per > >
71. Re: Question about cube group (yay math!) another...
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 10:50:56 -0000


Here's another one, with the same symmetry but a different piece
permutation, which doesn't involve swapping pieces with their opposite
numbers:

U' F2 D' L U F D2 L2 F' U' L2 D R2 U2 R B U L F U

It's pattern 3j on Jaap's page.

Perhaps there are a lot of solutions! Really must stop now.

Mike

74. Re: Looks like Rubiks DIY kits are finally back in stock
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 12:41:04 -0000


> Yes, I manage to pop it once in a while.. I think that is because I
> put my srews in in such a way that the cube is very loose.. I am
> used to that, and it works fine for me. But I am pretty sure that I
> can do more than 100 solves without popping. It's good enough to use
> it in a competition.

I also manage to pop from time to time. Usually the piece just pops
out (doesn't get shot out onto the table or anything like that), so I
just push it back in and continue. This is rare, and it's only
happened about 3 or 4 times since January 1.

~ Bob





75. BLD solve
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 14:00:39 -0000


I finally solved a 3x3 blindfolded! (took 6 tries!) :) 9 minutes to
memorize, 4 minutes to review, 5 1/2 minutes to solve. It's been an
exciting day already! :-D

~ Bob





76. Re: BLD solve
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 14:33:05 -0000

(took 6 tries!) :) 9 minutes to > memorize, 4 minutes to review, 5 1/2 minutes to solve. Congratulations! Your account of the first attempt was interesting, and the fact that it didn't work out completely has got me interested in trying this: admitting a bit of fallibility somehow made it seem more (not less) possible. Mike
77. Re: BLD solve
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 14:38:55 -0000


> Congratulations! Your account of the first attempt was interesting,
> and the fact that it didn't work out completely has got me interested
> in trying this: admitting a bit of fallibility somehow made it seem
> more (not less) possible.

Thanks. I'm glad it sparked some interest. :-) It's really a lot of
fun, though it gets a bit frustrating when you fail a few times. It
just made me want to solve it that much more every time I failed. I
was determined to spend as many attempts as it would take this morning
to solve it, so I'm glad it took only one. :-) You should definitely
give it a try, though. It's quite addicting!

~ Bob

80. Re: Question about cube group (yay math!) another...
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 15:03:06 -0000

Hey Mike, those are some interesting solutions to this puzzle. I guess it wasn't as difficult of a puzzle as I had previously thought :) I liked that one position where the edges were all switched in pairs and then flipped, that was a cool way to do it. So given 2187 ways to flip corners for each of these solutions it seems we have found a few ways to solve it :) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Here's another one, with the same symmetry but a different piece > permutation, which doesn't involve swapping pieces with their opposite > numbers: > > U' F2 D' L U F D2 L2 F' U' L2 D R2 U2 R B U L F U > > It's pattern 3j on Jaap's page. > > Perhaps there are a lot of solutions! Really must stop now. > > Mike
81. Re: BLD solve
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 15:07:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Now, something I didn't understand (either from your account or from > Stefan's page) is how you associate orientations (3 possibiities) with > your 2-colour object mnemonics for the corners. How does that work? Do > you have three objects to choose from for each corner, for example? I actually had to ask him about that, too. You only have to remember the first two colors, going clockwise. For example, if you look at a solved cube and hold yellow on top, right in front, then the URF cubie is (with my color scheme) YGR. Note that there are no other corners that have green next to yellow in the clockwise direction. Thus, you can identify it instead just by yellow green (what I would memorize as Sprite :-D). It takes a little bit of extra thinking at first, but it is easy to check by visualizing where that piece goes. Does this clear things up? ~ Bob
82. Re: Question about cube group (yay math!) another...
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 15:20:00 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I guess it > wasn't as difficult of a puzzle as I had previously thought :) Well, the first one did only take a minute or two, constructing by analogy with your own corner-permuted example. The second one wasn't really "constructed", but I noticed it when I used Cube Explorer 3.56 to generate all the other positions with the same symmetry as the first. (I hadn't got as far as "3j" when looking up the other pattern on Jaap's page!) > So given 2187 ways to flip corners for each of these solutions it > seems we have found a few ways to solve it :) Not quite that many: the corners can't have every possible orientation, because their facelets mustn't match the centres. ;) Mike
83. Re: BLD solve
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 15:21:34 -0000


A-ha! Thanks a lot!

Mike





84. Re: Question about cube group (yay math!) another...
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 18:56:56 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > I guess it > > wasn't as difficult of a puzzle as I had previously thought :) > > Well, the first one did only take a minute or two, constructing by > analogy with your own corner-permuted example. The second one wasn't > really "constructed", but I noticed it when I used Cube Explorer 3.56 > to generate all the other positions with the same symmetry as the > first. (I hadn't got as far as "3j" when looking up the other pattern > on Jaap's page!) > > > So given 2187 ways to flip corners for each of these solutions it > > seems we have found a few ways to solve it :) > > Not quite that many: the corners can't have every possible orientation, > because their facelets mustn't match the centres. ;) They can't because the corners were opposite their correct positions so the 3 colours on the corner are all distinct from the 3 colours of the adjacent centres. > > Mike

86. Re: Question about cube group (yay math!) another...

That's right for Chris's example, but not for mine -- in which only the edges are permuted. Mike

88. amazing one-handed cubing by patricio
From: "bmcgaugh49" <bmcgaugh49@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 21:29:27 -0000


Ryan Patricio and I decided to meet at lunch this week to
practice some cubing together before the Caltech tourney...I figured
I might be able to compete
with him if I use two hands versus his one hand.

Well...

Yesterday, we had a mini-competition...5 cubes, computer scrambles on
the Stackmat...15 seconds pre-inspection, etc...Ryan did
32.93, 31.35, 27.35, 30.06, 35.10...one handed. I choked ;-) best
of 29.10 for me.

Today, Ryan came in and started doing 29's, scrambling for himself.
I decided to quit being lazy and "officiate him" on another set of
five computer scrambles...His times:

25.02, 28.48, 32.39, 24.24, 28.74

average of 5, throwing out high and low: 27.41

He then did two more cubes, which was all he could get in before the
bell to his next class... 32.73, 30.37

The average for the 12 "official" solves over the last two days:
29.942...it can't really count for anything...but each solve is
amazing to me.

None of the solves were officially lucky, but he said the 24 and 25's
were easy cases for him...I didn't save all of the scrambles, but
I did write down the scramble for the 24.24, and gave it to him.

His dexterity and finger speed is incredible.

My hope for myself is to be more competitive with him, with two hands
(versus his one hand).

Oh, he also did some 16's and 18's two handed... ;-)

Bill







89. Huge optimal solver
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 21:29:49 -0000



What is the minimum amount of memory needed to run this thing? I know
it's supposed to be over 1 GB, but is 1.5 GB enough for instance?

91. Sub-19!
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 23:49:46 -0000


Sub-19 with ZBF2L / COLL / PLL !!! :

18.10 16.68 20.96 18.56 17.44 18.85 16.87 (24.59) 18.70 23.69 18.35
(15.72) = 18.82

Aiming for sub-18 now. I still stutter on the ZBF2L cases a lot, so I
imagine with more practice I can get sub-18 more regularly. I think
sub-18 will take knowing the cases well enough to not stutter, or to
stutter only once in 12 solves obviously.

Chris





92. Re: [Speed cubing group] Sub-19!
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 18:55:21 -0500

Congratulations, Chris! I, too, managed my best average with a new method. I put in some practice last night and it payed off with a personal best time of 22.19 and an average of 29.31 a few hours ago. I've still managed a slightly faster average with my Fridrich 4 Look, but I don't expect that to last. Keep up the good work. 96. my poor bank account
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 18:25:30 -0700

Under my bed sits 80 pounds of cubes.

And another 80 pounds is due to come in tomorrow.

And there's a $1700 hole in my bank account.

Thought you guys might find this somewhat amusing that I sleep in a sea
of cubes now.

At least until Saturday.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

100. record breaking?
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 02:33:18 -0000


Why are so many people breaking records for the 3x3x3 average lately?
In the last month, there have been five changes to the list and if you
go back a few days further, you Gilles Roux for six?
Is this just average breaking season because we're all practicing for
competitions or is it just a coincidence?





101. Re: record breaking?
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 02:45:38 -0000


> Why are so many people breaking records for the 3x3x3 average lately?
> In the last month, there have been five changes to the list and if
you
> go back a few days further, you Gilles Roux for six?
> Is this just average breaking season because we're all practicing for
> competitions or is it just a coincidence?

The magical times fairy has been good to everybody lately :-P

Actually, I think it has partially to do with people practicing more
than usual, and partially to do with coincidence. The position of the
stars might have something to do with it, too...

~ Bob





102. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: record breaking?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 21:54:45 -0500

As near as I can tell, it's partly to do with people 'cramming' for the upcoming tournaments, but partly to do with the general trend of faster times. People have refined methods and timing, they have optimized algorithms for number of moves, cases, and speed. And part of it has to do with Macky and our yellow Sun... ----- Original Message ----- From: Bob Burton<mailto:bob@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, April 13, 2005 9:45 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: record breaking? The magical times fairy has been good to everybody lately :-P Actually, I think it has partially to do with people practicing more than usual, and partially to do with coincidence. The position of the stars might have something to do with it, too... ~ Bob [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
103. Sub-18 with ZBF2L!!!!!!
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 02:59:44 -0000


Oh wow!!!

I really apologize for all these posts, but I had no idea this would
happen as soon as it did!

I just did a sub-18 average using ZBF2L!!!! In this average I only
stuttered on a ZBF2L case once, the 26 second time below. All the
other times were just solves where I recognized the ZBF2L case in a
relatively decent amount of time.

17.30 17.42 18.08 (16.30) 18.96 (26.16) 16.46 16.47 18.71 17.69 17.83
19.74 = 17.87

I did ZBF2L / COLL / PLL on every solve. The 17.42 had a PLL skip
after the COLL alg. I'm aiming for sub-17 next! :-D

Chris

106. [Speed cubing group] Re: Sub-18 with ZBF2L!!!!!!
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 03:27:45 -0000

Hey Mike, I think you should learn the 1 look corners and other special cases for your method if you are interested. It sucks to spend so much time learning and not taking averages, but the payoff later is so nice. I'm starting to be of the opinion that the more algs you know for the last, non-intuitive, steps of your method the better off you are. Look at all the sub-15 cubers - they all know tons of algs and/or useful tricks and can do all kinds of cool special case solves at the end. Also, I'm sorry to get on my soapbox but everyone seems to seriously doubt ZB lately. I definitely do not, and the averages I've been doing lately are definitely making me think ZB will be a useful speedcubing system. I had to _really_ work with Fridrich to get sub-18, and to get sub-18 with ZBF2L I only had to get my first average where I only screw up once (since the slowest is eliminated). I can't wait till I know all these algs really well and have moved them to my subconcious. I don't know if ZB will ever be sub-15 or anything crazy like that, but I think I can beat my own personal best Fridrich average using ZBF2L and that at least is motivation enough for me to keep learning it. But Mike, I definitely think that you should learn the special case algs for your method. I guarantee that you won't regret it. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Showoff. ; ) I suppose this is just more motivation for the group of us who are trailing a bit. I guess I've found my motivation to finally learn 1 look corners and special cases for my method. > > -Mike Bennett > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>, cmhardw > <no_reply@y<mailto:no_reply@y>...> wrote: > > > > Oh wow!!! > > > > I really apologize for all these posts, but I had no idea this > would > > happen as soon as it did! > > > > I just did a sub-18 average using ZBF2L!!!! In this average I only > > stuttered on a ZBF2L case once, the 26 second time below. All the > > other times were just solves where I recognized the ZBF2L case in a > > relatively decent amount of time. > > > > 17.30 17.42 18.08 (16.30) 18.96 (26.16) 16.46 16.47 18.71 17.69 > 17.83 > > 19.74 = 17.87 > > > > I did ZBF2L / COLL / PLL on every solve. The 17.42 had a PLL skip > > after the COLL alg. I'm aiming for sub-17 next! :-D > > > > Chris > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

108. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Sub-18 with ZBF2L!!!!!!
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 22:36:11 -0500

I wholeheartedly agree, I'm just tragically lazy. I've managed to average in the 28's with a 4 look layer method, 29.31 today with the Roux method (which I think I can safely call my primary method now), and 45 or below with a few others. The past week and a half I decided to learn other methods, and because of those I feel like I better understand how the cube works. It's caused me to look ahead more, instead of flying through the early parts of my solves. I've also found I can switch between solving styles incredibly easily. The only one I have trouble seeing right away is Petrus style. I think I'm going to start trying that with a 3/4 cross to start. I'm also interested in learning how to improve on my corners first method. It seems to work well for the few beginners I've taught it to, but I want to figure out how to speed it up and get it on par with my other methods. Anywho, I suppose I've rambled enough. Off to Gille's site...May the force be with me. -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: cmhardw<mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, April 13, 2005 10:27 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Sub-18 with ZBF2L!!!!!! Hey Mike, I think you should learn the 1 look corners and other special cases for your method if you are interested. It sucks to spend so much time learning and not taking averages, but the payoff later is so nice. I'm starting to be of the opinion that the more algs you know for the last, non-intuitive, steps of your method the better off you are. Look at all the sub-15 cubers - they all know tons of algs and/or useful tricks and can do all kinds of cool special case solves at the end. Also, I'm sorry to get on my soapbox but everyone seems to seriously doubt ZB lately. I definitely do not, and the averages I've been doing lately are definitely making me think ZB will be a useful speedcubing system. I had to _really_ work with Fridrich to get sub-18, and to get sub-18 with ZBF2L I only had to get my first average where I only screw up once (since the slowest is eliminated). I can't wait till I know all these algs really well and have moved them to my subconcious. I don't know if ZB will ever be sub-15 or anything crazy like that, but I think I can beat my own personal best Fridrich average using ZBF2L and that at least is motivation enough for me to keep learning it. But Mike, I definitely think that you should learn the special case algs for your method. I guarantee that you won't regret it. Chris [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
