112. Re: Macky's New Average
From: "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 07:39:27 -0000


> And yes i agree with u that a "simple" method can be just as fast
or
> faster than a more sophisticated method. Cause fewer cases to
> distinguish and u get less time lost in recognition, better flow
and
> better lookahead. Even if u should learn optimised fingertricks for
> 700 algs it won't help u much if u need 1 sec to recognize a case :-
> o 3 steps is then 3 lost secs ...

My point exactly. =)

> What is the difference between the 25th anniversary cube and the
diy-
> kit? I mean also the geometry of the cubies, not only the
> assembly/tuning.
>
> Cheers!
>
> -Per

You can't take off the center caps from 25th anniversary cubes, so
you can't tune them. They have arched centers, bad stickers, very
noticeable imperfections of plastic on the legs of corners....
Quality varies from as bad as Chris recently described to as amazing
as my new cube. A lot of them have a bump on the core that makes one
layer click with every 90 degree rotation...I can't tell you about
DIY because I don't have one, but I've tried a few, and they can be
pretty amazing. DIY>25th.

In my opinion, the main problem with normal cubes is that you have to
buy a few before you can get a good one. Studios are all very nice,
but not any nicer than the best Oddzon cube.

You can call me whatever you want to as long as I know who you're
talking about. =)

Macky





113. Re: Huge optimal solver
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 07:48:35 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > What is the minimum amount of memory needed to run this thing? I > know > > it's supposed to be over 1 GB, but is 1.5 GB enough for instance? > > Depends on the puzzle and the algorithm. Without that info, it's > impossible to answer. (Will also depend on your operating system.) But Stefan, the puzzle is the 3x3x3 -- this is the Huge Optimal Solver in the later versions of Cube Explorer, so we know pretty accurately what the algorithm is, too. My own experience of various puzzle programs that push the limits of available memory is that the amount needed at startup can be 50% greater (or even worse) than what it settles down to later. Sorry, GameOfDeath, but I have only 512MB on this machine, so haven't been able to try H.O.S. myself, but would like to -- surely someone here has used it? Mike
114. Re: Huge optimal solver
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 09:12:30 -0000

Hey! I have run the HOS of the Cube Explorer. I have "only" 1 GB of RAM so that was obviously enough for me. Im sure it helps to close down all other applications before running it. Internet Explorer or Microsoft Office could steal 100's of MB of RAM without u noticing that anything is slow. So when u run the HOS it's better to close all other apps on ur computer. As for the algorithm it's of course just the same 2-phase algorithm, but with a much larger pruning table. That's indeed why u need so much RAM, to have the table loaded in memory ;-) And also the sourcecode for the Cube Explorer is freely available. Im not sure if u are allowed to modify it in any way. And it could also be that u have quite a task at hand installing external packages into the Delphi IDE. Cause i haven't tried it out yet ... Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > What is the minimum amount of memory needed to run this thing? I > > know > > > it's supposed to be over 1 GB, but is 1.5 GB enough for instance? > > > > Depends on the puzzle and the algorithm. Without that info, it's > > impossible to answer. > > (Will also depend on your operating system.) > > But Stefan, the puzzle is the 3x3x3 -- this is the Huge Optimal > Solver in the later versions of Cube Explorer, so we know pretty > accurately what the algorithm is, too. My own experience of various > puzzle programs that push the limits of available memory is that the > amount needed at startup can be 50% greater (or even worse) than what > it settles down to later. > > Sorry, GameOfDeath, but I have only 512MB on this machine, so haven't > been able to try H.O.S. myself, but would like to -- surely someone > here has used it? > > Mike
115. Re: record breaking?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 09:23:36 -0000

Hey! Everyone is just trying to consolidate their position in the list, so they are frantically pulling off 30 averages pr day in order to get a good one :-P Just kidding of course. Probably just a coincidence i guess :-) Have fun cubing :-) -Per PS! It could also be that ppl have better cubes, or benefit on the occasional solve from having learnt more stuff :D > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ben King" <grsbmd@y...> wrote: > > Why are so many people breaking records for the 3x3x3 average lately? > In the last month, there have been five changes to the list and if you > go back a few days further, you Gilles Roux for six? > Is this just average breaking season because we're all practicing for > competitions or is it just a coincidence?

121. [Speed cubing group] Re: school vs. cubing
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 13:52:27 -0000

I still turn in all the really big assignments ;-) In all seriousness though, I'd probably be a better student if I never discovered speedcubing, but I try to keep a good balance of coursework and cubing practice. I hardly practice on days where I have a paper due the next day, or if I have a big test the next morning. But, on a light day for coursework I cube a lot to make up for my lighter practicing days. So I'm balanced I guess. Plus Caltech _is_ a better school than UNC, so I imagine that my coursework and homework load isn't as much or as difficult as yours. :-) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > ZB and ZBF2L and sub-whatever all sounds good... but isn't there such a > thing as 'school work'? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology

127. Re: Huge optimal solver
From: h_kociemba <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 17:14:07 -0000

Hi, all! I recently had a look in this group and though I do no speedcubing I saw that there are quite a few questions concerning my progam. So I joined this group now. Concerning the huge optimal solver: 1. You should definitely have 1 GB of RAM to run it. It will not run with 512 MB because the big table alone needs about 800 MB. 2. You should use a fresh rebooted system to run it then because Windows tends to steal much memory for other purposes (file buffering etc. ...). 3. It does not use the 2-phase algorithm because it is an *optimal* solver. 4. I removed the source code of the last versions from my homepage because it tends to become more and more ugly with all this additional stuff about web-cam, symmetry editor etc., but I will send the source code of version 2.25 which contains the essential algorithms to everyone who is interested in it. 5. My provider t-online will shut down his old server, so the old link to my homepage will become invalid within the next two months. Please update your link to http://www.kociemba.homepage.t-online.de/cube.htm Herbert --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > I have run the HOS of the Cube Explorer. I have "only" 1 GB of RAM > so that was obviously enough for me. Im sure it helps to close down > all other applications before running it. Internet Explorer or > Microsoft Office could steal 100's of MB of RAM without u noticing > that anything is slow. So when u run the HOS it's better to close > all other apps on ur computer. As for the algorithm it's of course > just the same 2-phase algorithm, but with a much larger pruning > table. That's indeed why u need so much RAM, to have the table > loaded in memory ;-) And also the sourcecode for the Cube Explorer > is freely available. Im not sure if u are allowed to modify it in > any way. And it could also be that u have quite a task at hand > installing external packages into the Delphi IDE. Cause i haven't > tried it out yet ... >
128. Re: Macky's New Average
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 19:29:05 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > - PLL recognition by blocks of same colors; AUF at end or beginning, > never both I've started using this now, too. So far I've always done AUF first to solve two corners (usually ULF and ULB), then with a second look recognize the PLL fully. Now I've drawn pictures of all the PLLs and their blocks and from some first experiences with it I must say I like it a lot. One question, though: Do you really define blocks that strictly? For example, consider case n3 and n9. According to your definition, they're equivalent. Both only have a triple-block of a corner and its two adjacent edges. But n3 has another "non-adjacent block", two corners which share the same color on one side but the edge between them has a different color. But they're still easy to identify as a "non-adjacent block". Do you use this or do you differentiate them a different way? I think I've heard of the block-approach before, but never thought about it much. What recognition methods do the other top (PLL) cubers use? And a question for top F2L cross on bottom cubers: When you for example do (R U' R' U R U' R'), do you prefer using right thumb to push or using left index finger to pull the U'? I noticed I've been using the thumb but the index finger seems to do a much better job. Cheers! Stefan
129. Re: Macky's New Average
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 19:34:36 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" > <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > > > - PLL recognition by blocks of same colors; AUF at end or beginning, > > never both > > I've started using this now, too. Oh, and one more question for Macky: You say - "in PLL you need to AUF before you can see which pieces need to be permuted" - about even "better" methods: "eliminating the need for any AUF" This sounds like you have to do AUF for the block recognition approach, which I think is exactly wrong. Can you clarify this? Also, here's the shortcut for anyone interested: http://cubefreak.hp.infoseek.co.jp/PLL.html Cheers! Stefan
130. Re: Macky's New Average
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 19:45:06 -0000


> I think I've heard of the block-approach before, but never thought
> about it much. What recognition methods do the other top (PLL) cubers
> use?

I'm not a top cuber, but I'll answer anyway :-P I actually recognize
the blocks and start to AUF. During the AUF, I recognize the PLL alg I
will have to do.

> And a question for top F2L cross on bottom cubers: When you for
> example do (R U' R' U R U' R'), do you prefer using right thumb to
> push or using left index finger to pull the U'? I noticed I've been
> using the thumb but the index finger seems to do a much better job.

Again, I'm a top cuber, but I use my thumb. I find the left index to
be too awkward to use in that situation. It just doesn't feel right.

~ Bob

133. Re: Macky's New Average
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 20:25:51 -0000



> I think I've heard of the block-approach before, but never thought
> about it much. What recognition methods do the other top (PLL)
cubers
> use?

Hi Stefan,

I never actually learned any methods or tricks for recognising the PLL
cases. But I saw Macky's 'block' approach, and I must say it looks
quite like what I have always been doing. I just look at what pieces
have the same colours on the same side... But I can also recognize
some cases without seeing a block, just because I have seen it 100s of
times :D.

Btw, I am looking forward to see you again, Stefan ;), bye!!

Joël.

P.S.: What does AUF mean? All I can guess is 'Align U layer First'...
Is that what it means?
> And a question for top F2L cross on bottom cubers: When you for
> example do (R U' R' U R U' R'), do you prefer using right thumb to
> push or using left index finger to pull the U'? I noticed I've been
> using the thumb but the index finger seems to do a much better job.
>
> Cheers!
> Stefan

135. Re: Huge optimal solver
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 21:47:49 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Mailer_Daemon <perscription_death@y...> wrote: > where/what program is this, i don't have all the old > posts? i would like to use it, or help out with the > use of it, i have a pretty powerful desktop, i would > have no problem devoting my massive ram to something > of the sort, let me know if i can help in anyway, > maybe we can team up on the project, or at least lemme > know where i can get a copy, if its available The program is CubeExplorer by Herbert Kociemba. The project is a multi-stage project, it's the advanced blindfold method - "Blindfold Cubing For Seriously Sad Savants", a sequel to the intermediate method "Blindfold Cubing For The Seriously Sad", which is a follow up to the basic method which is available on the web. The intermediate method is probably more advanced than most people would care to try to learn, although it is possible to get useful sub-methods from it. The advanced method is part of a bigger project, but I need to get that finished first. The current stage of the project is the optimization of the orientation algorithms (in HTM - I may be mistaken but I think Cube Explorer doesn't optimize in QTM). I was able to obtain some time ago that this subgroup has diameter 20 (that is, that 20 moves is always sufficient and that 20 moves is sometimes necessary (the necessity was already well-known as witnessed by the superflip)). Originally, of the 94.518 isomorphism classes in the orientation group, I didn't have better than 20 move algorithms for over 90,000 of them (that's partly because I stopped optimizing and went on to get the diameter first). Now I am reducing that number. Currently it is a little under 2,400 (plus 11 which are definitely optimal at 20) and I've got about several of those running on Cube Explorer now to try to shorten their paths to less than 20 before optimizing - clearly if the optimum is say 19 moves then reducing 20 to 19 and then optimizing means that one would only have to search through 18 (but not wade for ages through 19). Of course, some are quite probably going to take 20 moves and therefore will not be reduced by this method. Then I will have to optimize them (most likely by checking that all the (isomorphim classes of) neighbours need at least 19 moves - this is equivalent but can be done in stages and therefore takes less resources)). > > intel mb 865gbf > intel p4 @3.2 ghz w/ ht > 2 gb ddr400 ram > > --- GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > > h_kociemba > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hi, all! > > > > > > I recently had a look in this group and though I > > do no speedcubing I > > > saw that there are quite a few questions > > concerning my progam. So I > > > joined this group now. > > > > > > Concerning the huge optimal solver: > > > > > > 1. You should definitely have 1 GB of RAM to run > > it. It will not run > > > with 512 MB because the big table alone needs > > about 800 MB. > > > > Thanks - I was wondering if I bought a Windows > > machine whether I > > should get one with 2GB but I guess that won't be > > necessary. Optimal > > is good - I have lots of potential 20 move positions > > to try to optimize. > > > > Thanks. > > > > > > > > 2. You should use a fresh rebooted system to run > > it then because > > > Windows tends to steal much memory for other > > purposes (file buffering > > > etc. ...). > > > > > > 3. It does not use the 2-phase algorithm because > > it is an *optimal* > > > solver. > > > > > > 4. I removed the source code of the last versions > > from my homepage > > > because it tends to become more and more ugly with > > all this > > > additional stuff about web-cam, symmetry editor > > etc., but I will send > > > the source code of version 2.25 which contains the > > essential > > > algorithms to everyone who is interested in it. > > > > > > 5. My provider t-online will shut down his old > > server, so the old > > > link to my homepage will become invalid within the > > next two months. > > > Please update your link to > > > http://www.kociemba.homepage.t-online.de/cube.htm > > > > > > > > > Herbert > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > > "Per Kristen Fredlund" > > > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > I have run the HOS of the Cube Explorer. I have > > "only" 1 GB of RAM > > > > so that was obviously enough for me. Im sure it > > helps to close down > > > > all other applications before running it. > > Internet Explorer or > > > > Microsoft Office could steal 100's of MB of RAM > > without u noticing > > > > that anything is slow. So when u run the HOS > > it's better to close > > > > all other apps on ur computer. As for the > > algorithm it's of course > > > > just the same 2-phase algorithm, but with a much > > larger pruning > > > > table. That's indeed why u need so much RAM, to > > have the table > > > > loaded in memory ;-) And also the sourcecode for > > the Cube Explorer > > > > is freely available. Im not sure if u are > > allowed to modify it in > > > > any way. And it could also be that u have quite > > a task at hand > > > > installing external packages into the Delphi > > IDE. Cause i haven't > > > > tried it out yet ... > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > __________________________________ > Do you Yahoo!? > Make Yahoo! your home page > http://www.yahoo.com/r/hs
136. [Speed cubing group] Re: Huge optimal solver
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 2005 22:06:20 -0000



Here are some algorithms which I suspect might be optimal:

L2 F2 R2 D2 B2 U2 L' B2 U B2 L R' D' F' R' U2 F' D' F' R2 (20f) //3;1346
D2 L2 U2 B F' U2 F' L B2 D' F2 L2 F2 D F2 D2 U2 R' F' U2 (20f) // 3;1366
U L2 B2 U' B2 D2 R2 F U2 L' D' R2 D' B U R2 D2 R' F2 R' (20f) //3;1445

F2 U2 R2 D2 L U2 L F2 U2 R' D' B R' F' R B L' F' R2 U (20f) //90;1187
R2 B2 F' L2 B D2 L2 R' D2 B F' L2 U R2 B D2 U2 L2 F' R2 (20f) //90;1832

He's a hobby lover and has done some cool stuff like card throwing...of course, I taught him to cube, too. It's pretty funny that we all started pen spinning at around the same time! I've always been interested in different kinds of manipulation, mostly because there are workshops on zippo, cards, poker chips, and even butterfly knife manipulation in some juggling festivals I go to. I know several jugglers who are serious about cubing, too. 141. Re: Macky's New Average
From: "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 15 Apr 2005 07:50:53 -0000


Hi Stefan,

>One question, though: Do you really define blocks that strictly? For
>example, consider case n3 and n9. According to your definition,
>they're equivalent. Both only have a triple-block of a corner and its
>two adjacent edges. But n3 has another "non-adjacent block", two
>corners which share the same color on one side but the edge between
>them has a different color. But they're still easy to identify as a
>"non-adjacent block". Do you use this or do you differentiate them a
>different way?

Good point. I differentiate those two by looking at whether the
corner opposite the triple-block is permuted correctly (or rather,
whether those two corners share a same color). I like your definition
of "non-adjacent block"...that's essentially what I use to decide
which of the 4 G permutations I have. For now, I'm going to be lazy
and place a link on my page to this discussion.

>Oh, and one more question for Macky: You say
>
>- "in PLL you need to AUF before you can see which pieces need to be
>permuted"
>- about even "better" methods: "eliminating the need for any AUF"
>
>This sounds like you have to do AUF for the block recognition
>approach, which I think is exactly wrong. Can you clarify this?

Right, my fault. What I should have said was that there's never a
need to look behind the cube...but I'm not sure that having to do
this with the block approach makes you any slower. I find it much
more intuitive and easier, anyways.
(By the way, do we have different definitions for AUF? I thought that
both methods have AUF, either before or after the permutation
algorithm itself.)

>And a question for top F2L cross on bottom cubers: When you for
>example do (R U' R' U R U' R'), do you prefer using right thumb to
>push or using left index finger to pull the U'? I noticed I've been
>using the thumb but the index finger seems to do a much better job.
>
>Cheers!
>Stefan

Index works much better for me as well!

Macky

do, I can do :)'.

143. 3-colour FMC special results, and challenge 81
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 15 Apr 2005 14:35:46 +0100

Hi everyone!

The results for the 3-colour Fewest Moves Challenge are now available on my website - www.cubestation.co.uk - and are definitely worth a look!

This week we will have a normal challenge, and I would like to get as many people involved in Fewest Moves Solving as possible. It's becoming a very popular solving exercise, maybe one day people will be as enthusiastic about it as speedcubing! Maybe.

There are lots of experts now, who I am sure would be willing to help out and answer any questions, and you can definitely learn from them by browsing their solutions to previous week's scrambles using the FMC archive.

There is a lot of skill, lots of techniques, and a bit of luck involved in creating a winning solution, and it's a great puzzling exercise for the mind!

I hope you will all decide to try it out this week, and if so, Best Of Luck!

Dan Harris - www.cubestation.co.uk



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Heh heh, I also have picked up pen spinning, but only to a very minor extent probably compared to you guys. I can do the forward and reverse thumb spin on both left and right hands, and I'm working on twirling the pen through all 4 fingers (Kam does it briefly in his video, I guess it's the most basic manipulation). I can keep up the illusion of constant flow for a few seconds sometimes, but most of the time as I transfer from my pinky finger to the index again I have a quick jerk in the pen's motion which doesn't look so cool :( One of the guys in my cube club in high school was an extremely good pen spinner. He wasn't as good as Kam, but watching him do a lot of the tricks he did did look kinda like Kam's videos. I think he's been pen spinning for about 4 years, so he's had a lot of practice though. 146. Re: Macky's New Average
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 15 Apr 2005 17:38:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > (By the way, do we have different definitions for AUF? I thought that > both methods have AUF, either before or after the permutation > algorithm itself.) Thanks for the clarifications... Hmm, don't know about you but for me "AUF" just means "adjust U face" (or layer) in a very general way and sometimes I do it twice before PLL. Until now after OLL I did this: 1) Find two "non-adjacent" but "connected" corners (if any) 2) AUF so that these two corners are solved (or so that two diagonally opposite corners are solved) and rotate the cube so that these two corners are on the left side. 3) Recognize PLL case 4) Sometimes: AUF again (in case of corner 3-cycle) 5) Rotate the cube 6) Apply PLL algorithm Wow, now that I write it down this detailed, it looks like a terribly long list. Let's see what I hope it'll look like with the block approach: 1) Find the blocks, in other words: recognize the PLL case 2) AUF and rotate the cube 3) Apply the PLL algorithm Stefan

Wayne

156. Re: [Speed cubing group] Skillz Videos - pen spinning
From: Gaétan Guimond <rubiks99ca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Apr 2005 21:15:00 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > > I've always been interested in different kinds of manipulation, mostly > because there are workshops on zippo, cards, poker chips, and even > butterfly knife manipulation in some juggling festivals I go to. I know > several jugglers who are serious about cubing, too. > Hi Macky -1-January 2004 ( my chat with your friend) makimoto2000us (05:19:50): Thanks. for your linking to my site. I will link to you sooner or later. I never see my link:)) -2- Macky the cube freak webmaster.................. "Gaetan Guimond's Corner Method " "An extremely fast orientation-first method for the corners" But where is my link at your webmaster ?:)) You do not ask why I have not had upgrad my website for one year and half. If not I would have added many link! --3- Imagine, Gilles Roux is a FRENCH people and he don't link for me! I don't had a minimum cuber. What it would have been on a deserted island. EX: Petrus, Guss and several others. The simple ideas can be excellent but some will not underline or will see only the facility or none:)) I invent a corner first PURE method and I'm a first big cheater in the world. I repeat I don't pretend the better but I will never die! I wish my link but I don't real wait. I like Andy too but I suppose many more his beautifull webmaster sub20 (same link same method:)) than me:)) Anyway I add coming soon the link cubefreak & cubestation for the différence The cube game is not a chess game, welcome to my circus, look my official Guinness paper message (on file) 15398. The silencer Gaétan

165. [Speed cubing group] Re: Memorizing Algs
From: "Mikael" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 17 Apr 2005 10:32:20 -0000


Hello!

When I started learning when to use which alg (I´m talking about
Petrus also) I first started to learn the Complete Step 6+7 index. The
way I did it was to look for "color-pairs" (if a edge and a corner
share the same color on one face (not U-face) they are a color-pair).
Then I made a table with all the 8 different configurations. I divided
the different cases by the number of color-pairs and learned which alg
belongs to which case. This way I made block so small I could learn
all the cases in one block in on sitting. Some configurations were
easy to learn because of symmetry and few cases where as other took
lots of time.
After that I started with the Complete Step 5+6 index. At this point I
used most of the algs in the index. I only had to learn a few new ones
and it is quite easy to reconize which alg to use where when you know
which corners it flips.

I definetly think I did it in the wrong order. I should have started
with the Step 5+6 index because that way I can avoid getting in most
positions in the other index.
I still know most of Step 6+7 index so If I can skip Step 5 I still
know what alg to choose.

I´m sure there are way better ways of learning these things but this
was how I did it.

Hope it helps,
Mikael

> Any tips on memorizing when to use the algorithms?
>
> For the method I use (Petrus) there are 12 cases for each
> configuration. What's the best way to learn when to use what
algorithm?





166. WC2005
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 17 Apr 2005 19:13:50 -0000


There is a poll on Rubiks.com and it is as follows:

The 2005 Rubik's World Championships will be held in November. Will
the current 20 second world record be broken?

The current results are:

Yes (66%)
No (29%)
Tied (5%)

I found this a bit amusing. :)

~ Bob





167. still experimenting...
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 17 Apr 2005 20:00:17 -0000


Hey everyone,

I'm still experimenting with new methods and here are some tips I put
on my page of things that have helped me to improve. I know some
people do intuitive stuff to flip edges while doing the last c/e pair,
and I know some people are learning a handful of the algs as well. I
tried to write these tips for both groups, but of course I can relate
more to the learning algs aspect of it.

Anyway, in case anyone is interested here are some of my thoughts on
the method.

http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/zbtips.html

170. Re: good cubes for speed cubing...
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 03:34:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, souzamusic <souzamusic@i...> wrote: > Hey guys, I' d like to ask u what is the best cube for speed cubing..I've > heard u all telling about the DIY kit from rubiks.com...is this the one?! The answer to your question is based solely on opinion. Personally, I have found the Rubik's DIY kits to be better than all other speed cubes I have tried. I would not buy any other cube to prepare for speedcubing. I also spend hours when I get them to make sure they are exactly how I want them. :) I'm sure others have different opinions... ~ Bob
171. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: good cubes for speed cubing...
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 17 Apr 2005 22:43:54 -0500

My only suitable speedcube at the moment is a normal cube from Wal-Mart. My girlfriend uses a pair of cubes from Target. They're the best cubes I've ever tried. Part of finding the perfect cube is a subjective quality based upon your particular solving method and style. I must say that I've heard enough good things about the DIY cubes that I caved and ordered one last week, though. I'll let you know what I think when I get it. -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: Bob Burton<mailto:bob@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Sunday, April 17, 2005 10:34 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: good cubes for speed cubing... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>, souzamusic <souzamusic@i<mailto:souzamusic@i>...> wrote: > Hey guys, I' d like to ask u what is the best cube for speed cubing..I've > heard u all telling about the DIY kit from rubiks.com...is this the one?! 172. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: good cubes for speed cubing...
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 17 Apr 2005 20:48:17 -0700

The normal 25th Anniversary cubes vary a lot in quality. Macky bought 20 from me and found the best ones and seriously, you could get like, your normal averages, maybe +1 second on these cubes. Then you put some lube in and you're just fine. Some of the most amazing cubes I've seen in the last few weeks have been straight out of the box 25th Anniversary cubes. The 25th Anniversary cubes in my opinion are just fine. It is of my opinion that cubes may all start off at different places, but a bad cube can be worked in to become good. Of course, not many of us are willing to wait that long. Just don't be the guy that says that you are too good for any speedcube because your fingers and arms are too strong so you pop everything. I met him yesterday. It was fun. I'm sorry, I don't take things very well. You'll probably notice my small or not so small jabs here and there for a bit. 173. foot cubing
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, caltechrubiks@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 17 Apr 2005 23:44:38 -0700

Hey Everyone,

As you may know, Will Arnold absolutely shattered the foot-cubing
record at the tournament last Saturday. I met Will and he's actually
very new to speed cubing and the method he uses right now is very
elementary and inefficient. I was hoping the community would help him
come up with a method that would allow him to solve faster and of
course, we'd have to optimize it for his feet.

What do the current foot-cubers use? I think it would be interesting
to compare your methods and his and actually more specifically, your
technique. This was the first time I've seen foot-cubing so I have no
idea what the different styles are. However, I am lead to believe that
the other foot-cubers out there do daily life activities such as
opening and closing doors with their hands instead so they do not
practice their toe dexterity on a day-to-day basis. What I'm saying
is, Will right now can make about 1 turn per second meaning if he knew
Fridrich like I knew it, he would get sub-60 solves all the time. With
our help and maybe some ingenious toe tricks, Maybe we can see some
sub-40s?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

175. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: still experimenting...
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 01:56:22 -0700

I'm still fuming a little bit of last Saturday but I think I've calmed down to the point of sanity now. Basically, I had a run-in with a guy who claimed that he didn't use any method to solve the cube and that he could solve the cube intuitively in under 20 seconds. Later, he claimed that it was almost time to reveal his ultra-secret and amazing method. The whole thing about this guy is that he comes to my tournament from a very far place, doesn't compete, and then proceeds to insult everyone, not just me, not just the tournament, but people in practically every country, including Mr. Ernö Rubik himself, and then... doesn't compete and his excuse is that no cube is good enough for him because his arms and fingers are so strong that he pops everything. If you say you can solve a cube in under 20 seconds, show me. Get up on that stage with the timer, and solve for us. It's that simple. Solve it in under 25 and I'll believe you. Seriously... and saying that Mr. Rubik is lazy because he doesn't go to the tournaments? Doesn't he have cancer or something? I'd challenge him to crush my fingers with a handshake grip. I'd be willing to wager my fingers... and I was a musician before I even learned to cube. 177. Re: foot cubing
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 13:12:57 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > What I'm saying > is, Will right now can make about 1 turn per second meaning if he knew > Fridrich like I knew it, he would get sub-60 solves all the time. With > our help and maybe some ingenious toe tricks, Maybe we can see some > sub-40s? Since his average in 3 attempts was about 265 seconds, does that mean his current methods needs around 265 turns? Cheers! Stefan
178. Re: [Speed cubing group] still experimenting...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 13:14:55 -0000

Tyson, I'm quite sure I know (and knew) what you were talking about. But do you understood me? Please notice how I wrote "Him". Meant to say you're surely talking about God, since He's the only one who could do that as far as I convinced. Well, He probably doesn't even need a method because He can peel off all stickers in a split second. Or let them peel off themselves and fly to their correct spots. Ok, a little more seriously: I do believe one could solve the cube sub20 with a completely "intuitive method". Just not without a method in the intuition. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Haha, you know, I read that two ways. I thought you meant, in a > sarcastic tone, show him respect and don't call him "a guy" because > he's not worthy of being a human being. Then I reread your post and I > guess you didn't realize what I was talking about. But I'm sure now > you do. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Apr 17, 2005, at 4:05 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i.. .> > > wrote: > >> Oooh! 179. Re: [Speed cubing group] still experimenting...
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 13:41:47 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Tyson, > > I'm quite sure I know (and knew) what you were talking about. But do > you understood me? Please notice how I wrote "Him". Meant to say > you're surely talking about God, since He's the only one who could do > that as far as I convinced. > > Well, He probably doesn't even need a method because He can peel off > all stickers in a split second. Or let them peel off themselves and > fly to their correct spots. > > Ok, a little more seriously: I do believe one could solve the cube > sub20 with a completely "intuitive method". Just not without a method > in the intuition. > Speedcubing with logical thinking and reasoning is impossible. All good cubers use intuition only, it's a synonym for immediate cognition. Making more or less sophisticated things intuitive (thanks clever or dumb techniques - rehearsed sequences, case recognition and so on) is the art of speedcubing. Gilles.
180. Re: still experimenting...
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 14:24:54 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > Speedcubing with logical thinking and reasoning is impossible. > All good cubers use intuition only, it's a synonym for immediate > cognition. > Making more or less sophisticated things intuitive (thanks clever or > dumb techniques - rehearsed sequences, case recognition and so on) is > the art of speedcubing. Just noticed a curious contradiction: this (alleged) sub-20 fellow has "no method" but promises to reveal his wonderful method to the world at a later date. :) Perhaps he means a method whose individual steps could be understood using only a small amount of logical thinking and reasoning, like the "Fridrich" F2L or the early phases of most other methods, such as your own. Later steps, too, if you used simple commutators & conjugates. Of course, as you suggest, learning to apply it at speed would eliminate even that small amount of thinking & reasoning. All right, I could believe in the existence of such a method after all. Let's hope we see it someday. Mike
181. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: still experimenting...
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 15:53:49 +0100

Intuition - wish I knew what it was. Here is a Cambridge Dictionary defnition "the feeling that you know something without being able to explain why". With most sophisticated things when people say it is "intuitively obvious" they have either worked on similar things so long that, by analogy, they are confident that know how to do them (and could almost certainly explain why), or they are wrong (which is why they can't explain why). I don't think speedcubing fits this definition anyway! I remember at University that I struggled for months to understand some things that I would blythely say were inutitively obvious 2 years later! Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "mike_go_uk" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Monday, April 18, 2005 3:24 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: still experimenting... > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > Speedcubing with logical thinking and reasoning is impossible. > > All good cubers use intuition only, it's a synonym for immediate > > cognition. > > Making more or less sophisticated things intuitive (thanks clever or > > dumb techniques - rehearsed sequences, case recognition and so on) > is > > the art of speedcubing. > > Just noticed a curious contradiction: this (alleged) sub-20 fellow > has "no method" but promises to reveal his wonderful method to the > world at a later date. :) > > Perhaps he means a method whose individual steps could be understood > using only a small amount of logical thinking and reasoning, like > the "Fridrich" F2L or the early phases of most other methods, such as > your own. Later steps, too, if you used simple commutators & > conjugates. Of course, as you suggest, learning to apply it at speed > would eliminate even that small amount of thinking & reasoning. > > All right, I could believe in the existence of such a method after > all. Let's hope we see it someday. > > Mike > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > >

183. [Speed cubing group] Re: still experimenting...
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 16:28:36 -0000


Cubing is starting to gain a real measure of popularity, and it is
spreading. As with any hobby, (especially with one as intellectual
as ours), we are going to have to do deal with critics and phonies.
So far in the cubing community, most of the people here are nice, and
well mannered, but the larger we grow, and the more people we
encompass, the more likely it is that people will not necessarily all
be as respectful. This guy, sounds like a phony to me, somebody who
showed up, did a little research on cubing, so that he knows what he
is talking about, but is just talking. I don't know who it is, and
I'm not exactly sure what happened, but this is just my impression.

In my experience, most of the people that I've talked to in the
cubing community have been helpful and responsive. I think that is
something that we should emphasize, maybe as core values of being a
cuber. I think that for us, being a cuber, sure it's about being
fast, but there is also a sub-culture of support for everyone else
here. I'd like to see that continue. Don't let this one person
taint all the good things we have going on, and all the growth and
potential that we have in our sport.

To me, this sounds like a phony. One of the better measures of
strength and integrity, is doing something while having restraint.
You know like all the movies where the bad guy just goes around
killing people, but the good guy could kill people, but chooses not
to, even though it is a more difficult choice. I know that doesn't
really directly apply, but whatever. A good speedcube helps, but
most of the fastest solving is because of the brain being ahead of
the hands. You could still try to solve it. He could have gotten a
mid-20 or something, and then blame it on the cube...and if that was
the case, why didn't he bring his own?

I'm not convinced this was the case, but there was a kid at high
school that I went to, and he was a chronic liar. He lied about
everything, telling people that he was going to a really great
college, and doing great things. The only person he was hurting, was
himself.

Best of luck to everyone, (hoping to see some of you at the new york
tournament with Ian).

Happy Cubing,
Joe Spadafora





184. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: foot cubing
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 10:15:40 -0700

Probably. It involves putting up a cross on the yellow face by putting each edge to its corresponding center instead of putting all 4 in the right place in relation to each other and then connecting them all. Then it's first layer corners, middle layer edges. After that, it's position last layer corners, orient last layer corners, then use M' D M D2 M' D M to try and position all the edges and then some really long algorithm to fix whatever two edges are flipped. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Apr 18, 2005, at 6:12 AM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: >> What I'm saying >> is, Will right now can make about 1 turn per second meaning if he > knew >> Fridrich like I knew it, he would get sub-60 solves all the time. > With >> our help and maybe some ingenious toe tricks, Maybe we can see some >> sub-40s? > > Since his average in 3 attempts was about 265 seconds, does that mean > his current methods needs around 265 turns? > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >
185. Re: [Speed cubing group] New scientist
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 18:53:33 +0100

I went to London last Saturday on the train, and as usual bought my "train" magazine, the New Scientist.

I also noticed the cube (hard to miss!)... and when I got home I fired off an email straight away to the magazine, hoping that they would be able to tell me how to get hold of one. Imagine my disappointment when:

"Dear Daniel,
I'm afraid it was a computer generated image, so it woud be rather hard to send you one.

Eregarsd, John Hoyland (Letters)"

It looked so real though, especially the picture of it in pieces. One a side note, notice his really bad spelling... maybe I'm too good for Science... ;)



Dan Harris :)



----- Original Message -----
From: Duncan Dicks
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, April 16, 2005 1:42 PM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] New scientist


A cube sighting in today's (16th April) New Scientist. Check out the
picture in the article on superatoms (pp30-33).

For those in the UK sad enough to have seen the new Ask the Family series I
noticed a cube flying past in the opening sequences too!

Duncan

188. [Speed cubing group] Re: foot cubing
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 18:54:06 -0000


Lemme try it, but with hands ;-)

> Probably. It involves putting up a cross on the yellow face by
putting
> each edge to its corresponding center instead of putting all 4 in
the
> right place in relation to each other and then connecting them all.

==> 11 moves

> Then it's first layer corners,

==> 19 moves

> middle layer edges.

==> 45 moves

> After that, it's position last layer corners,

==> 8 moves

> orient last layer corners,

==> 14 moves

> then use M' D M D2 M' D M to try and position all the edges

==> 22 moves

> and then some really long
> algorithm to fix whatever two edges are flipped.

==> Since I had no clue what the algorithm is, I didn't do this step.
But it should take 265-11-19-45-8-14-22=146 moves, right? Wow, that
must really be a long algorithm... Btw, I tried to not look ahead
during F2L and even made a mistake or two (*not* on purpose ;-). Can
you ask him about the number of moves he usually needs?

Cheers!
Stefan





189. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: foot cubing
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 12:02:53 -0700

Well, also a lot of pauses. Let me try myself...

Yeah, 240 moves does seem like quite a bit. I guess between 120-130 is
more reasonable. I think the time is lost due to searching for pieces
like when you switch corners, I've definitely got to search for about 3
or 4 seconds at least. (Which is why I stopped using Petrus.)

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

190. Re: foot cubing
From: portoseb <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 19:10:47 -0000


> > After that, it's position last layer corners,
>
> ==> 8 moves
>

Using the alg that I first learnt from an old book, it would take 18
moves (it's a commutator: 8+1+8+1) for cycling three corners.

> > orient last layer corners,
>
> ==> 14 moves
>

Using algs from the same source, orienting two corners would take
another 18 moves. So 36 moves for 3 wrong corners.

> > then use M' D M D2 M' D M to try and position all the edges
>
> ==> 22 moves
>

used say 3 or 4 times, once for each edge.

> > and then some really long
> > algorithm to fix whatever two edges are flipped.
>
> ==> Since I had no clue what the algorithm is, I didn't do this
>step.
> But it should take 265-11-19-45-8-14-22=146 moves, right? Wow,
>that
> must really be a long algorithm...

My alg, considering slice moves as two moves (I wonder how you can
do slice moves with feet), is 26 moves for two wrong edges.

> Btw, I tried to not look ahead
> during F2L and even made a mistake or two (*not* on purpose ;-).
>Can
> you ask him about the number of moves he usually needs?
>
> Cheers!
> Stefan

So if you want, you can get a solution in 246 moves and more. But I
wouldn't expect you Stefan to be able to get such a solution without
trying really hard ;)

Sebastian

PS. The number of my classmates who can now solve the cube is 10.
One of them, when he was a beginner, used to need around 5 Sunes in
order to solve the corners. So it's not impossible to need many
moves, if you're a beginner.

192. 13.92!!!!

Chris

Groups Links > > > > > > > > > >
197. Re: foot cubing
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 23:10:51 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, portoseb <no_reply@y... > wrote: > > > After that, it's position last layer corners, > > ==> 8 moves > > Using the alg that I first learnt from an old book, it would take 18 > moves (it's a commutator: 8+1+8+1) for cycling three corners. That's terrible. I used a commutator, too. Does yours preserve orientation? Notice it doesn't have to. > > > orient last layer corners, > > ==> 14 moves > > Using algs from the same source, orienting two corners would take > another 18 moves. So 36 moves for 3 wrong corners. No, I applied the Sune *twice* already! Notice you'll never need more than two Sunes and it's probably the easiest and most well-known alg for this. > > > then use M' D M D2 M' D M to try and position all the edges > > ==> 22 moves > > used say 3 or 4 times, once for each edge. No, I already applied it twice. And I did count slice moves as two moves. And you never need do it more than twice. > So if you want, you can get a solution in 246 moves and more. But I > wouldn't expect you Stefan to be able to get such a solution without > trying really hard ;) Yes, I would've had to try *even harder* than I *already did*. Notice I only used a very small set of algs, didn't look ahead (e.g. planning two edges of the cross at the same time and other sophisticated stuff like that ;-). And there were damn *two* middle-layer edges correctly placed but flipped which I solved very naively which is why I used 45 (!) moves for those four middle layer edges alone (I think that can be called a very unlucky case??). Had I just tried to follow the steps but used the algs/techniques I know, then it would've been far less moves of course. Actually I feel insulted now that you think I can't do better than that! Just kidding ;-) Cheers! Stefan
198. Re: foot cubing
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 23:23:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > Using algs from the same source, orienting two corners would take > > another 18 moves. So 36 moves for 3 wrong corners. > > No, I applied the Sune *twice* already! Notice you'll never need more > than two Sunes and it's probably the easiest and most well-known alg > for this. Ok I misread, sorry. But in case he uses such a crappy (sorry ;-) method he should really learn the Sune instead... Btw, forgot my point: I believed he doesn't average 1 move per second for the whole solve. Neither do I average 8 moves per second though I can do that with two or three PLL algs. One is the T-perm and the other two are 3-edge-cycles. Using solely these for PLL I think solves 62.5% of the PLLs in at most 2 looks. That was my PLL method a while ago (btw, today I learned the remaining two PLLs :-). So I was turning the PLL very fast most of the time. But now that I use more algorithms it's not only harder to recognize but also harder to execute fast. I guess Will uses only very few algs and he has practiced them a lot and they're probably well-suited for it (e.g. mostly twisting <U,F,R> maybe). So I don't think it will scale as nicely as Tyson suggested first. Cheers! Stefan
199. Re: foot cubing
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 23:23:33 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > And there were damn *two* > middle-layer edges correctly placed but flipped which I solved very > naively which is why I used 45 (!) moves for those four middle layer > edges alone (I think that can be called a very unlucky case??). In the solution/hints booklet that I received with my first cube, I believe (not completely sure) that the algorithm they included for solving middle edges was TWELVE moves long! 4*12 + 2*12 (for flipping) = 72 moves + any moves between edges = ~ 75 edges, depending on the efficiency of the middle-layer edges algorithm. :) Still, I admit this is a very unlucky (and unlikely) case. ~ Bob
200. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: foot cubing
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 2005 16:24:58 -0700

Sorry, what I was trying to say is that when he moves the cube, he can easily do 1 move/second. However, there are delay times due to looking for the placement of certain pieces which makes to total moves/second slower but the manipulation alone can easily be 1 move/sec and maybe better with practice. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Apr 18, 2005, at 4:23 PM, Bob Burton wrote: > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: >> And there were damn *two* >> middle-layer edges correctly placed but flipped which I solved very >> naively which is why I used 45 (!) moves for those four middle layer >> edges alone (I think that can be called a very unlucky case??). > > In the solution/hints booklet that I received with my first cube, I > believe (not completely sure) that the algorithm they included for > solving middle edges was TWELVE moves long! 4*12 + 2*12 (for > flipping) = 72 moves + any moves between edges = ~ 75 edges, depending > on the efficiency of the middle-layer edges algorithm. :) Still, I > admit this is a very unlucky (and unlikely) case. > > ~ Bob > > > > > > > Yahoo! Date: Tue, 19 Apr 2005 01:00:10 -0000

This may only apply to those who don't use their own algorithms. David J

205. [Speed cubing group] Re: foot cubing
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 19 Apr 2005 08:23:41 -0000

What about an F2L approach with cross on back during F2L? This would allow for the pairs to be solved into DR and DL, using mainly {D,R} or {D,L} moves. The cube could be rotated with z turns to move empty slots into DR or DL. Also {U,R} {U,L} turns might also be fairly fast for foot cubing. There is also the option of doing cross on left, which would also use a lot of {D,R} turns. The LL could be done with F2L on the B and LL as the F face. This would make for lots of z (seems like it may be fast) and {U,R,L,D} turns for the alg. Also, some algs could be recognized with LL as F and then rotate the cube so that LL will be on D and the alg will then have lots of D moves, plus recognitition won't be a factor since PLL is the last step. Just trying to throw out some ideas. I guess if cube rotations in the x direction aren't too hard then a cross on left startegy would work (or cross on right) and if z rotations aren't bad then cross on B might work. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Sorry, what I was trying to say is that when he moves the cube, he can > easily do 1 move/second. However, there are delay times due to looking > for the placement of certain pieces which makes to total moves/second > slower but the manipulation alone can easily be 1 move/sec and maybe > better with practice. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Apr 18, 2005, at 4:23 PM, Bob Burton wrote:
206. Re: foot cubing
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 19 Apr 2005 11:49:33 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > In the solution/hints booklet that I received with my first cube, I > believe (not completely sure) that the algorithm they included for > solving middle edges was TWELVE moves long! That must be some record ;-) Well, I only knoww the two 7-move algs and this 9-move one: R' U' R' U' R' U R U R. There are of course others and maybe some are even faster 2-gen algs but I wouldn't imagine them in a beginner's solution... Maybe there should be a SCC record category for "worst middle layer edge alg". Reminds me I want to submit my record for "Rubik's Magic: assembling to solved state" (this one I actually will submit). Cheers! Stefan

214. Re: Macky's New Average
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Apr 2005 14:29:16 -0000

This thread actually inspired me to write a bit about how I recognize the PLL cases. I wrote a couple short paragraphs on my PLL page (www.cubewhiz.com and click "permutations") describing EXACTLY how I recognize each case and setup to perform it. Any feedback would be greatly appreciated. :-) I hope somebody can find this helpful. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" > <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > > > (By the way, do we have different definitions for AUF? I thought > that > > both methods have AUF, either before or after the permutation > > algorithm itself.) > > Thanks for the clarifications... > > Hmm, don't know about you but for me "AUF" just means "adjust U face" > (or layer) in a very general way and sometimes I do it twice before > PLL. Until now after OLL I did this: > > 1) Find two "non-adjacent" but "connected" corners (if any) > 2) AUF so that these two corners are solved (or so that two diagonally > opposite corners are solved) and rotate the cube so that these two > corners are on the left side. > 3) Recognize PLL case > 4) Sometimes: AUF again (in case of corner 3-cycle) > 5) Rotate the cube > 6) Apply PLL algorithm > > Wow, now that I write it down this detailed, it looks like a terribly > long list. Let's see what I hope it'll look like with the block > approach: > > 1) Find the blocks, in other words: recognize the PLL case > 2) AUF and rotate the cube > 3) Apply the PLL algorithm > > Stefan
215. Re: Macky's New Average
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Apr 2005 15:31:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > This thread actually inspired me to write a bit about how I > recognize the PLL cases. I wrote a couple short paragraphs on my > PLL page (www.cubewhiz.com and click "permutations") describing > EXACTLY how I recognize each case and setup to perform it. Any > feedback would be greatly appreciated. :-) I hope somebody can find > this helpful. Mmh, I'm a bit confused. In the introduction you seem to say you recognize the case by always just looking at two adjacent sides. But the detailed descriptions seem to disagree. For example "Corners Only" starts with "In these cases, I first AUF until the edges are already permuted." and then describes how you recognize the case after that AUF. Question: How do you recognize that the edges are permuted correctly relative to each other? And after the AUF, haven't you looked at at least three sides now? Cheers! Stefan
216. Re: Macky's New Average
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Apr 2005 16:08:59 -0000


> Mmh, I'm a bit confused. In the introduction you seem to say you
> recognize the case by always just looking at two adjacent sides. But
> the detailed descriptions seem to disagree.

Hrmm...yes, sorry. I forgot to update the introduction after I wrote
the rest of the page.

> For example "Corners Only" starts with "In these cases, I first AUF
> until the edges are already permuted." and then describes how you
> recognize the case after that AUF. Question: How do you recognize
that
> the edges are permuted correctly relative to each other? And after
the
> AUF, haven't you looked at at least three sides now?

Good point, that isn't really clear. I have fixed that so that it is
hopefully more clear, now.

Thanks,
~ Bob





217. Re: Macky's New Average
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Apr 2005 18:41:59 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > > For example "Corners Only" starts with "In these cases, I first AUF > > until the edges are already permuted." and then describes how you > > recognize the case after that AUF. Question: How do you recognize > that > > the edges are permuted correctly relative to each other? And after > the > > AUF, haven't you looked at at least three sides now? > > Good point, that isn't really clear. I have fixed that so that it is > hopefully more clear, now. Yes, I think it's better. So I guess you might look at up to all four sides as well, for example to find that "corner block", right? For case #02, I like how you pull D2 with your middle and ring finger, gotta try that (the videos show case #1, though ;-) I love the block recognition method. Not only did it motivate me to learn those darn final two PLLs that I've been wanting to learn for months, but I think it will allow me to get faster. Right now I'm still slower with it but hey I've only been doing it for a few days. The Y-permutation is my favourite. I see its two blocks and BOOM I immediately know what it is. Only the two double-edge-swaps are similarly easy for me to recognize. Cheers! Stefan
218. Re: Macky's New Average
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Apr 2005 19:16:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > This thread actually inspired me to write a bit about how I > recognize the PLL cases. I wrote a couple short paragraphs on my > PLL page (www.cubewhiz.com and click "permutations") describing > EXACTLY how I recognize each case and setup to perform it. Any > feedback would be greatly appreciated. :-) I hope somebody can find > this helpful. About your PLL 18: You don't need to hate that case, not even the algorithm. Only the cube rotation ;-) I use the same algorithm but do that rotation differently: http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/foo/pll18.wmv (medium speed execution) Cheers! Stefan
219. Re: Macky's New Average
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Apr 2005 21:58:25 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > Yes, I think it's better. So I guess you might look at up to all four > sides as well, for example to find that "corner block", right? Yes, that is possible. > For case #02, I like how you pull D2 with your middle and ring finger, > gotta try that (the videos show case #1, though ;-) Hehe, that's what 3 years of solving LL on bottom will do ;) I switched the videos for case #01 and #02--didn't notice that they were wrong. thanks. > I love the block recognition method. Not only did it motivate me to > learn those darn final two PLLs that I've been wanting to learn for > months, but I think it will allow me to get faster. Right now I'm > still slower with it but hey I've only been doing it for a few days. Yeah, I like it too. I think that it's a very natural way to recognize the PLL cases (it is how my mind decided it would recognize cases without anybody showing me how), so I find that as another advantage to it. > The Y-permutation is my favourite. I see its two blocks and BOOM I > immediately know what it is. Only the two double-edge-swaps are > similarly easy for me to recognize. I love both of those permutations. I think the double-edge-swaps (especially the cross swap) are still easier for me to recognize, though :-D Thanks for the feedback/corrections/etc. ~ Bob

222. 4x4x4 Rubik's Revenge Speedsolving method

Just wondering what are some of the fast speedsolving methods for the
4x4x4 and what are the websites for them?

Thanks.





223. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 Rubik's Revenge Speedsolving method
From: Chun Hei Uwe Wong <lilbeyond@...>

Date: Wed, 20 Apr 2005 18:17:12 -0700 (PDT)

224. By far my coolest ever pop
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 21 Apr 2005 03:49:52 -0000


Hey everyone,

I had a really interesting pop today. I was solving at my computer
and had a pop, a 3x1 group (2 corners and an edge) came out. I was
able to find two of the pieces pretty quickly, but I could have sworn
the other had disappeared in some quantum tunneling vortex or something.

After about 10 minutes I gave up and just surfed the internet for
about an hour before class, which by the way is a great way to spend
time when you should be doing homework ;-) When it was time to go to
class I grabbed my bag, one of those shoulder strap computer bags, and
felt a weird lump where the strap was as I put it on. I figured the
shoulder strap was twisted, but it turns out that the other popped
piece had landed in my shirt pocket, *AND* had been there for the
entire hour I was at my computer without my noticing!

I feel kinda slow lol, but I thought it was somewhat interesting :)

Chris





225. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 Rubik's Revenge Speedsolving method
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 21 Apr 2005 03:57:07 -0000

I know I keep saying this, but eventually I want to add my 4x4 speed solution on my site. The solution on my site I consider to be beginner/intermediate. I was able to get to about 1:50-1:55 on average with that method. The only changes for speed solving are: 1) Solve two opposite centers 2) solve two adjacent centers 3) finish the last two 4) Solve the edges using one of the more common pair up methods (either 2, 4, or 6). 5) Solve as a 3x3 The only changes are that the second and third pairs of centers are solved as adjacent pairs. Also solving the edges is much more structured as I mention on my site, so that you don't have to spend any time looking ahead. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Chun Hei Uwe Wong <lilbeyond@y...> wrote: > sup darereck, > this should be the easiest and quite fast solution for 4x4x4 http://speedcubing.com/chris/4-solution.html i personally can solve the cube under 2 minutes. > > darereck <darereck@g...> wrote: > > Just wondering what are some of the fast speedsolving methods for the > 4x4x4 and what are the websites for them? > > Thanks. > > > > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! Groups Links > > To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > __________________________________________________ > Do You Yahoo!? > Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around > http://mail.yahoo.com > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

227. [Speed cubing group] A little Roux advice, please.
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 20 Apr 2005 23:35:37 -0500

I've finally resigned to learn the 1 step LL corner algorithms for the Roux method, in pursuit of the elusive sub 20. I've dabbled with some of the PLL algs and somewhat understand the theory behind recognization.

Unfortunately, with this method, there are no blocks, no helpful side pieces, or anything I've been able to figure out in order to identify cases quickly. It's making the learning process incredibly slow and difficult for me. There are only a small few I've learned I can see quickly enough to execute and achieve decent times with, and most of those are when either the corners are either oriented or permuted correctly.

Any advice anyone could offer would be most appreciated. I have a lot of time to spend in a hospital waiting over the next week with my trusty page of cube notes to pour over. Thanks in advance.

-Mike Bennett


P.S. If anyone has any advice about recognizing special cases for Step 4, that would most certainly not go unwelcome.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

231. Re: By far my coolest ever pop
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 21 Apr 2005 11:40:16 -0000

I've recently had a similar experience, though not caused by a pop. I was preparing a 2cm 3x3 cube for speedsolving and its center caps are smaller than the stickers above them so I had to peel those stickers off. I've had missing parts maybe 4 or 5 times. Stupid me was working on the floor (grey carpet), imagine searching for a spring that's maybe 2-3mm long. At one point the orange sticker was missing. I was looking for it everywhere. All around me. Even on myself, especially I remember rolling out the left sleeve of my sweater because I had a feeling it could be there. I even took out a few keys of my notebook keyboard because I thought the stickers might have gotten under them. Nothing. Nowhere. I found it later on the *right* sleeve of the sweater. Argh. Cheers! Stefan P.S. The cube turned out great, got a 35s average-of-10 with it. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I had a really interesting pop today. I was solving at my computer > and had a pop, a 3x1 group (2 corners and an edge) came out. I was > able to find two of the pieces pretty quickly, but I could have sworn > the other had disappeared in some quantum tunneling vortex or something. > > After about 10 minutes I gave up and just surfed the internet for > about an hour before class, which by the way is a great way to spend > time when you should be doing homework ;-) When it was time to go to > class I grabbed my bag, one of those shoulder strap computer bags, and > felt a weird lump where the strap was as I put it on. 233. Re: [Speed cubing group] A little Roux advice, please.
From: "Wayne" <mylib_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 21 Apr 2005 14:56:38 -0000

Check out Speedcubing.com's site for the LL corners. Ron explains howo to recognize the orientation/permutation algs for corners. I learned from there and after practice you can "instantly" recognize the situation. the center caps was loose. so out of curiousity i wanted to see if my
cube had rivets or screws. Unfortunely it had rivets. Anything i could
do to loosen the rivets without ruining my new cube? Also, more
importantly, whats an easy way to make the center cap stay on?





235. RE: [Speed cubing group] COLL w/o affecting edges
From: ~Erwaman~ <erwaman@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 21 Apr 2005 19:13:57 -0400 (GMT-04:00)

I believe Lars Petrus's Step 5 + 6 index is the same thing as COLL. http://lar5.com/cube/yMain.html
I'm planning on learning them, too, some time...

~Erwaman~

Yea it is, but it affects edges permutations. I should have been more clear, I need Ryan Heise step 4 only with the same way to recognize as coll. I'm messing around with various techniques for finishing off the cube. On a similar note, does anyone think this method could be viable? 1) F2l except one c/e pair (7+7*3=28) 2) insert edge/solve edges (the ones I've got so far average around 6-7?) 3) Insert corner/ orient at least one corner (no clue how many moves this takes...yet) 4) RH step 4 (12.48) I'm wondering if I could do something more efficient with inserting the corner without too many algs... _____ From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of ~Erwaman~ Sent: Thursday, April 21, 2005 4:14 PM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: RE: [Speed cubing group] COLL w/o affecting edges I believe Lars Petrus's Step 5 + 6 index is the same thing as COLL. http://lar5.com/cube/yMain.html I'm planning on learning them, too, some time... ~Erwaman~ -----Original Message----- From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]On Behalf Of James Stuber Sent: Wednesday, April 20, 2005 7:15 PM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] COLL w/o affecting edges Does anyone have the algs for COLL w/o affecting edges with the same recognition system as COLL? I was going to make a page on this for myself, but if someone already has this I don't want to bother :-P _____ Yahoo! 239. [Speed cubing group] Square-1 algorithm
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 22 Apr 2005 00:21:36 -0400

I don't know how, but I somehow managed to solve my Square-1 up to the point where I have every piece perfectly correct except for a three-cycle of the thin wedges on the top row. I use no algorithms, so I don't know how I managed...

Anyway, does anyone have an algorithm to flip the pieces? (It would also help me a lot if you could explain how the Square-1 notation works too...)

--qqwref

240. Re: [Speed cubing group] A little Roux advice, please.
From: "erik_jernqvist" <erik_jernqvist@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 22 Apr 2005 06:32:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > I've finally resigned to learn the 1 step LL corner algorithms for >the Roux method, in pursuit of the elusive sub 20. I've dabbled with >some of the PLL algs and somewhat understand the theory behind >recognization. Masayuki Akimoto has written page on this: http://rokumentai.akimoto3.com/GRSM-e3.htm
241. Average number of moves for ZB will probably be 45
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 22 Apr 2005 10:27:05 -0000


Hey everyone,

I am under the impression that at least some people find this info
about the ZB method interesting. If that isn't the case, let me know
and I'll stop posting.

-----------------------

I just did a 100 cube average, only instead of times I was counting
the number of moves.

I took note of when I got a ZBLL solve, and when I had a COLL/PLL solve.

I also counted the average number of moves for ZBF2L, as well as the
LL given whichever type of solve it was.

Here were the total counts:

Average number of moves for ZBF2L: 33.37

Average number of moves for COLL/PLL finish: 21.29 (54.66 if combined
with ZBF2L)

Average number of moves for ZBLL finish: 12.19 (45.66 if combined with
ZBF2L)

Average number of moves with my hybrid (VH + 10% ZBLL) system: 53.84

I had 9 ZBLL solves, 4 of which were unintentional PLL skips after COLL.

Interesting to notice, is that the ZBLL solves took on average 45.56
moves total. So it seems that ZB might have a move average of 45. I
personally still think the benefits of ZB are good, despite the move
count being a bit higher. I think the move count is higher because I
don't think an average of 18 moves for the ZBF2L is reasonable while
speedsolving (perhaps while fewest moves solving).

Out of all 100 solves my shortest ZBF2L solve was 26 moves, which I
only was able to do 3 times.

So anyway, I still think ZB is a worthwhile system, but the average
number of moves appears that it might be 45 instead of 40.

45 moves done at 3.5 moves per second is 12.86, so I think sub-13 is a
reasonable goal for ZB once you know all the algs and have completely
mastered the system.

Also my worst COLL/PLL solves were three 62's and my best ZBLL solve
was a 37. 37 at 3.5 moves per second could have been 10.57 for
someone who had this system completely mastered.

Well, I guess I am shooting for sub-13 in 10 years or less ;-)

Chris





242. Re: [Speed cubing group] Average number of moves for ZB will probably be 45
From: sachin shirwalkar <sachin_civilian@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 22 Apr 2005 13:24:56 +0100 (BST)

Groups Links To visit your group on the web, go to: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo!
