India Matrimony: Find your life partner online Go to: http://yahoo.shaadi.com/india-matrimony
243. Re: [Speed cubing group] Square-1 algorithm
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 22 Apr 2005 16:09:44 -0000

Well, Square 1 has one feature that makes it nicer than the 3x3x3 to solve. You can swap two edges or two corners without moving any other pieces. So, the easiest way to break down a three cycle is into two swaps of two edge pieces. Now let me talk a bit about notation. Jaap manages to do a good job of describing (that's also where the algorithms are from). I'll try to paraphrase. There are only two axes on which the square 1 can move. You can turn the top or the bottom or you can do a twist diagonally across the cube. The twist is denoted as a "/". Turning the top and the bottom is denoted like this: (x, y) Where x is the number of 30 degree clockwise turns on the top (30 degrees is one edge and 60 degrees is one corner). y is the same thing for the bottom. x and y can be negative numbers, indicating that the face should go counterclockwise that many degrees. Now, the algorithm for swapping two edges, UF and UL, is (1,0)/(-3,0)/ (-1,-1)/(3,0)/(1,1)/(-3,0)/(-1,-1)/(4,1)/(-1,0) This will also swap DF and DR, but after you do the second swap, this will return itself to normal. You also could just get a three cycle algorithm. To Cycle UF->UB->UR do (1,0)/(-1,2)/(-5,1)/(0,3)/(-3,0)/(5,2)/(-5,4)/(-4,0) And to go the opposite direction, you can just do this algorithm backwards. -Ben. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@v...> wrote: > I don't know how, but I somehow managed to solve my Square-1 up to the point where I have every piece perfectly correct except for a three-cycle of the thin wedges on the top row.
244. Re: [Speed cubing group] Average number of moves for ZB will probably be 45
From: Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 22 Apr 2005 10:58:31 -0700 (PDT)

The ZB method is an interesting process. I'm happy with it just doing ZBF2L->OLL->PLL As my recognition for orientations is almost instant. My average number of turns wouldn't be affected though unless I started learning ZBLL, as I average about 55 turns a solve anyway. At the very least everyone should learn the most basic cases for ZBF2L. They're easy to recognize, and many are very fast. -Richard --- cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I am under the impression that at least some people > find this info > about the ZB method interesting. If that isn't the > case, let me know > and I'll stop posting. > > ----------------------- > > I just did a 100 cube average, only instead of times > I was counting > the number of moves. > > I took note of when I got a ZBLL solve, and when I > had a COLL/PLL solve. > > I also counted the average number of moves for > ZBF2L, as well as the > LL given whichever type of solve it was. > > Here were the total counts: > > Average number of moves for ZBF2L: 33.37 > > Average number of moves for COLL/PLL finish: 21.29 > (54.66 if combined > with ZBF2L) > > Average number of moves for ZBLL finish: 12.19 > (45.66 if combined with > ZBF2L) > > Average number of moves with my hybrid (VH + 10% > ZBLL) system: 53.84 > > I had 9 ZBLL solves, 4 of which were unintentional > PLL skips after COLL. > > Interesting to notice, is that the ZBLL solves took > on average 45.56 > moves total. I think the move count is > higher because I > don't think an average of 18 moves for the ZBF2L is > reasonable while > speedsolving (perhaps while fewest moves solving). > > Out of all 100 solves my shortest ZBF2L solve was 26 > moves, which I > only was able to do 3 times. > > So anyway, I still think ZB is a worthwhile system, > but the average > number of moves appears that it might be 45 instead > of 40. > > 45 moves done at 3.5 moves per second is 12.86, so I > think sub-13 is a > reasonable goal for ZB once you know all the algs > and have completely > mastered the system. > > Also my worst COLL/PLL solves were three 62's and my > best ZBLL solve > was a 37. 37 at 3.5 moves per second could have > been 10.57 for > someone who had this system completely mastered. > > Well, I guess I am shooting for sub-13 in 10 years > or less ;-) > > Chris > > > > __________________________________________________ Do You Yahoo!? 251. ===Newest Rubik's Cube Solving Robot===
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 23 Apr 2005 03:04:42 -0000

It's been awhile since I've been around these parts, but I am still a someone active cuber... Here's proof. Today I (with a couple friends) finished making (the first version) of my take on a Rubik's Cube Solving Robot. It takes a while to load, cuz the file is so large. There is a long pause when it's *thinking*. <http://www-personal.umich.edu/~dlli/Cubebot_DivX.avi> Recorded Friday April, 22, 2005 for a demo to the professors of an "Microprocessor-Based Embedded-Systems Design" Course I was taking as a final project. (It solves in a little under 38 seconds from one measurement I took. That my not be the case in this video.) It starts off by reading in the 6 faces by perfoming a 360 on each face. Then it takes about 27 seconds to *think*, that video was taken without the I-Cache or D-Cashe turned on (if you know what that means) or with millisecond interrupts turned off during that processing, so it could have been much faster (<8 sec). It was running at 20Mhz Bus Speed and off a Motorola Power PC chip (the MPC823, very ancient). It's an embedded systems design, meaning it can be easily made to be portable. (It does *NOT* rely on an computer for processing.) It goes counterclockwise always, and overshoots... a protocol the same (or opposite) to what the DeepCube people used. We just wanted to get it working..., I can go in a modify it now that we know it is precise enough not to lock-up more then say 1% of the time... though I would put in an "anti-lock-up" protocal that detects-and-reverses. It is applying a breath-first search for the cross..., does the 4 c/e-pairs, CLL, and then ELL. (The LL according to my personal algorithms.) This was pretty close to a method I used to use, before moving onto something much more insane. It is essentially what Guus R. Schultz and/or Akimoto uses/used as well. It does c/e-pairing in a fairly sophisticated manner different from what is usually seen in stage-based solver programs I have seen before. Averages 69.1 quarter turns (i.e. QTM) in an average of 100,000 runs. Though counter-clockwise is currently executed as a 270 rotation. It never does more then 270 on a face during solving. All these figures can be readily optimized now that everything else is reliable. And yes, it is dangling a few inches from the table due to us having to wire it up in a rush not using any ties to the frame. It can stand on 3 points of the frame as well. Just simple aluminum frame and some precise whelding. Oh, and that is NOT the standard color scheme, it is my own. BTW, if tHe bandwidth gets terrible, feel free to mirror the file elsewhere..., say on speedcubing.com. -Doug Li (Happy Cubing)
252. assembly help
From: "abarnhart2000" <abarnhart2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 23 Apr 2005 03:17:27 -0000


I just got my first rubiks.com assembly cubes today. The bags say the
instructions are online, and online there is a link to a
speedcubing.com page. The page has no intsructions on it at all, as
far as i can tell. The only thing i need to know is the purpose of
the small black rings, mine has 13 with it.

I seem to remember someone posted a diagram of theirs step by step,
but i could be wrong.

Thanks,
Andrew





253. Re: [Speed cubing group] ===Newest Rubik's Cube Solving Robot===
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 22 Apr 2005 22:35:09 -0700

Wow, competition ;-) you know, I hate to tell you this because you will probably end up beating me, but mike reid (sp) has a very nice implementation of the kociemba algorithm in C, that is what I currently have deepcube using. I am very curious though on how you got the cameras to work, as I have been having lots of trouble with color recognition, maybe shoot me an email sometime, or if you have aim my screen name is Gates Evan M while on a somewhat similar topic, I just got back from the Los Angeles county science and engineering fair with deepcube as a year two project, placed first in my category :-) and ended up winning the sweepstakes, meaning first out of all the first place projects :-D I'm in a very good mood right now, just thought I'd share ;-) good luck with the new robot, I'll have to get serious again ;-) -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On 4/22/05, d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > It's been awhile since I've been around these parts, but I am still > a someone active cuber... 256. Re: [Speed cubing group] ===Newest Rubik's Cube Solving Robot===
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 23 Apr 2005 13:36:43 +0100

Thats great. This may be a stupid question but does it effectively solve blindfold? That is: is the solve worked out from beginning to end before it does the first move, or is it rescanning the cube continually, or once it has scanned once is it calculating the new position while its moving? Or is there another option of which I haven't thought! Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "d_funny007" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Saturday, April 23, 2005 4:04 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] ===Newest Rubik's Cube Solving Robot=== > > > It's been awhile since I've been around these parts, but I am still > a someone active cuber... Here's proof. > > Today I (with a couple friends) finished making (the first version) > of my take on a Rubik's Cube Solving Robot. > > It takes a while to load, cuz the file is so large. There is a long > pause when it's *thinking*. > > > <http://www-personal.umich.edu/~dlli/Cubebot_DivX.avi> > > > Recorded Friday April, 22, 2005 for a demo to the professors of > an "Microprocessor-Based Embedded-Systems Design" Course I was > taking as a final project. (It solves in a little under 38 seconds > from one measurement I took. That my not be the case in this video.) > > It starts off by reading in the 6 faces by perfoming a 360 on each > face. Then it takes about 27 seconds to *think*, that video was > taken without the I-Cache or D-Cashe turned on (if you know what > that means) or with millisecond interrupts turned off during that > processing, so it could have been much faster (<8 sec). It was > running at 20Mhz Bus Speed and off a Motorola Power PC chip (the > MPC823, very ancient). > > It's an embedded systems design, meaning it can be easily made to be > portable. (It does *NOT* rely on an computer for processing.) > > It goes counterclockwise always, and overshoots... a protocol the > same (or opposite) to what the DeepCube people used. We just wanted > to get it working..., I can go in a modify it now that we know it is > precise enough not to lock-up more then say 1% of the time... though > I would put in an "anti-lock-up" protocal that detects-and-reverses. > > It is applying a breath-first search for the cross..., does the 4 > c/e-pairs, CLL, and then ELL. (The LL according to my personal > algorithms.) This was pretty close to a method I used to use, before > moving onto something much more insane. It is essentially what Guus > R. Schultz and/or Akimoto uses/used as well. > > It does c/e-pairing in a fairly sophisticated manner different from > what is usually seen in stage-based solver programs I have seen > before. > > Averages 69.1 quarter turns (i.e. QTM) in an average of 100,000 > runs. Though counter-clockwise is currently executed as a 270 > rotation. It never does more then 270 on a face during solving. All > these figures can be readily optimized now that everything else is > reliable. > > And yes, it is dangling a few inches from the table due to us having > to wire it up in a rush not using any ties to the frame. It can > stand on 3 points of the frame as well. Just simple aluminum frame > and some precise whelding. > > Oh, and that is NOT the standard color scheme, it is my own. > > BTW, if tHe bandwidth gets terrible, feel free to mirror the file > elsewhere..., say on speedcubing.com. > > > -Doug Li (Happy Cubing) > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > >

258. Poor quality Rubik's Professor 5x5x5
From: "jello33" <jellomods@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 23 Apr 2005 15:44:07 -0000


I've gone through 3 new Rubik's 5x5x5 and they all suck. The first one
wasn't too bad but was very hard to turn, even after lubing and
playing with it for a month. I recently bought 2 more hoping for a
good one but these are worst.

>From the first turn of the cube pieces just wanted to start twisting
out. The molding of the plastic is very poor. The cube looks lumpy and
out of square. I contacted customer services, but just got the ship it
back response.

Now I'll be out shipping and have to pray that the replacements are
usable.

I've purchased and used all the available 5x5's on the market and
these are by far the worst.

Chris Licciardi
jellomods@...





259. Re: [Speed cubing group] ===Newest Rubik's Cube Solving Robot===
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 23 Apr 2005 08:54:52 -0700

Well, on deepcube, After the scramble, and any other moves that people do on it (as I now have a nice GUI with which a user can do any moves that he/she likes ;-)), the moves are stored in a file. When someone presses solve, the computer does those moves on a virtual cube, so that it knows the state of the cube. It then passes this state to the solver (slightly modified version of mike reid's solver) and passes the solution to a file. This solution is then converted to motor commands, and output at the right times. So in essence, yes, it does blindfold. One more question for Doug, how well does the visual feedback work for the motors? I was thinking of trying something like that, but the motors that I currently do not support it in any simple fashion. -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On 4/23/05, Duncan Dicks <duncan@...> wrote: > Thats great. This may be a stupid question but does it effectively solve > blindfold? That is: is the solve worked out from beginning to end before it > does the first move, or is it rescanning the cube continually, or once it > has scanned once is it calculating the new position while its moving? Or is > there another option of which I haven't thought! > > Duncan > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "d_funny007" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Saturday, April 23, 2005 4:04 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] ===Newest Rubik's Cube Solving Robot=== > > > > > > > > It's been awhile since I've been around these parts, but I am still > > a someone active cuber... Here's proof. > > > > Today I (with a couple friends) finished making (the first version) > > of my take on a Rubik's Cube Solving Robot. > > > > It takes a while to load, cuz the file is so large. There is a long > > pause when it's *thinking*. > > > > > > <http://www-personal.umich.edu/~dlli/Cubebot_DivX.avi> > > > > > > Recorded Friday April, 22, 2005 for a demo to the professors of > > an "Microprocessor-Based Embedded-Systems Design" Course I was > > taking as a final project. (It solves in a little under 38 seconds > > from one measurement I took. That my not be the case in this video.) > > > > It starts off by reading in the 6 faces by perfoming a 360 on each > > face. Then it takes about 27 seconds to *think*, that video was > > taken without the I-Cache or D-Cashe turned on (if you know what > > that means) or with millisecond interrupts turned off during that > > processing, so it could have been much faster (<8 sec). It was > > running at 20Mhz Bus Speed and off a Motorola Power PC chip (the > > MPC823, very ancient). > > > > It's an embedded systems design, meaning it can be easily made to be > > portable. (It does *NOT* rely on an computer for processing.) > > > > It goes counterclockwise always, and overshoots... a protocol the > > same (or opposite) to what the DeepCube people used. We just wanted > > to get it working..., I can go in a modify it now that we know it is > > precise enough not to lock-up more then say 1% of the time... though > > I would put in an "anti-lock-up" protocal that detects-and-reverses. > > > > It is applying a breath-first search for the cross..., does the 4 > > c/e-pairs, CLL, and then ELL. (The LL according to my personal > > algorithms.) This was pretty close to a method I used to use, before > > moving onto something much more insane. It is essentially what Guus > > R. Schultz and/or Akimoto uses/used as well. > > > > It does c/e-pairing in a fairly sophisticated manner different from > > what is usually seen in stage-based solver programs I have seen > > before. > > > > Averages 69.1 quarter turns (i.e. QTM) in an average of 100,000 > > runs. Though counter-clockwise is currently executed as a 270 > > rotation. It never does more then 270 on a face during solving. All > > these figures can be readily optimized now that everything else is > > reliable. > > > > And yes, it is dangling a few inches from the table due to us having > > to wire it up in a rush not using any ties to the frame. It can > > stand on 3 points of the frame as well. Just simple aluminum frame > > and some precise whelding. > > > > Oh, and that is NOT the standard color scheme, it is my own. > > > > BTW, if tHe bandwidth gets terrible, feel free to mirror the file > > elsewhere..., say on speedcubing.com. > > > > > > -Doug Li (Happy Cubing) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > ________________________________ > Yahoo! Groups Links > > To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.
260. Re: By far my coolest ever pop
From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 23 Apr 2005 16:26:15 -0000

hahahah, that's hilarious! something similar has happened to me, it was very interesting. about five cubies popped, which is quite a lot, and because of the way I was holding the cube, I dropped it. AND because of the poor quality/age of the cube I was using, it more or less exploded on impact with the floor. I found about 12 pieces, but I didn't find the rest of the pieces OR the central axle, which is the weirdest bit of all. a couple weeks later, I was cleaning my room (finally) and found that it had bounced inside of a rolled up poster on my floor.... > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > > > Hey everyone, > > > > I had a really interesting pop today. I was solving at my computer > > and had a pop, a 3x1 group (2 corners and an edge) came out. I was > > able to find two of the pieces pretty quickly, but I could have > sworn > > the other had disappeared in some quantum tunneling vortex or > something. > > > > After about 10 minutes I gave up and just surfed the internet for > > about an hour before class, which by the way is a great way to spend > > time when you should be doing homework ;-) When it was time to go > to > > class I grabbed my bag, one of those shoulder strap computer bags, > and > > felt a weird lump where the strap was as I put it on. I figured the > > shoulder strap was twisted, but it turns out that the other popped > > piece had landed in my shirt pocket, *AND* had been there for the > > entire hour I was at my computer without my noticing! > > > > I feel kinda slow lol, but I thought it was somewhat interesting :) > > > > Chris

That is: is the solve worked out from beginning to end before it > does the first move, or is it rescanning the cube continually, or once it > has scanned once is it calculating the new position while its moving? Or is > there another option of which I haven't thought! > > Duncan > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "d_funny007" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Saturday, April 23, 2005 4:04 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] ===Newest Rubik's Cube Solving Robot=== > > > > > > > > It's been awhile since I've been around these parts, but I am still > > a someone active cuber... Here's proof. > > > > Today I (with a couple friends) finished making (the first version) > > of my take on a Rubik's Cube Solving Robot. > > > > It takes a while to load, cuz the file is so large. There is a long > > pause when it's *thinking*. > > > > > > <http://www-personal.umich.edu/~dlli/Cubebot_DivX.avi> > > > > > > Recorded Friday April, 22, 2005 for a demo to the professors of > > an "Microprocessor-Based Embedded-Systems Design" Course I was > > taking as a final project. (It solves in a little under 38 seconds > > from one measurement I took. That my not be the case in this video.) > > > > It starts off by reading in the 6 faces by perfoming a 360 on each > > face. Then it takes about 27 seconds to *think*, that video was > > taken without the I-Cache or D-Cashe turned on (if you know what > > that means) or with millisecond interrupts turned off during that > > processing, so it could have been much faster (<8 sec). It was > > running at 20Mhz Bus Speed and off a Motorola Power PC chip (the > > MPC823, very ancient). > > > > It's an embedded systems design, meaning it can be easily made to be > > portable. (It does *NOT* rely on an computer for processing.) > > > > It goes counterclockwise always, and overshoots... a protocol the > > same (or opposite) to what the DeepCube people used. We just wanted > > to get it working..., I can go in a modify it now that we know it is > > precise enough not to lock-up more then say 1% of the time... though > > I would put in an "anti-lock-up" protocal that detects-and- reverses. > > > > It is applying a breath-first search for the cross..., does the 4 > > c/e-pairs, CLL, and then ELL. (The LL according to my personal > > algorithms.) This was pretty close to a method I used to use, before > > moving onto something much more insane. It is essentially what Guus > > R. Schultz and/or Akimoto uses/used as well. > > > > It does c/e-pairing in a fairly sophisticated manner different from > > what is usually seen in stage-based solver programs I have seen > > before. > > > > Averages 69.1 quarter turns (i.e. QTM) in an average of 100,000 > > runs. Though counter-clockwise is currently executed as a 270 > > rotation. It never does more then 270 on a face during solving. All > > these figures can be readily optimized now that everything else is > > reliable. > > > > And yes, it is dangling a few inches from the table due to us having > > to wire it up in a rush not using any ties to the frame. It can > > stand on 3 points of the frame as well. Just simple aluminum frame > > and some precise whelding. > > > > Oh, and that is NOT the standard color scheme, it is my own. > > > > BTW, if tHe bandwidth gets terrible, feel free to mirror the file > > elsewhere..., say on speedcubing.com. > > > > > > -Doug Li (Happy Cubing) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

267. Hi everyone.
From: "vic_jang" <vic.jang@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 24 Apr 2005 08:35:30 -0000


Hi everybody.

I am a speedcuber from Taiwan.

where the 2x2 4x4 5x5 cube manufacturer Eastsheen is located.

it's great to join this forum since there are very few people in
Taiwan who speedcube.

And it's also very difficult to get Rubik Studio cubes(well I don't
even have one.) and rubiks.com Cube from Taiwan, we can only get
them through internet and wait for the long long shipping trip from
North America to Asia.


This speed timer is made by one of my friends in the Rubik's Cube
Club in my university. Hope this may help.

http://nctuyoyo.twbbs.org/~file/tool/speedtimer/

please tell me if you found any problem using the timer.

btw, it's already known that it's not working correctly through the
browser Firefox :(

I will make another one with Java in a few weeks(exams are coming
right now), which will be able to record the timers and calculate
average and will display the time in larger font.


Nice to meet you all. :)

Just a little message to let you all know that I had a great time at
the German Open yesterday! It was very nice too meet all those cubers
again! The ambiance was really great.

I was glad I could realize some of my goals, but as usual, I could not
realize all of them.. I should really find a way to master those
nerves :).

Congratulationswith the new records everybody, especially Stefan
(megaminx!!) and Lars (some ER's). And DanH, with the new UK
record.. ;)

Cheers! ;)

Joël.





270. Blindfold Team Solving
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 24 Apr 2005 15:24:19 -0000


Raul Garcia and I are the unofficial record holders in the Blindfold
Team Solve (BTS) category (one person holds the cube but never looks
at it...the second person sees the cube and tells the first person
what moves/algs to do but the second person can't touch the cube).
We'd like to see more people in this category but that means having
two speedcubers who live near eachother.

Last night, Chris Hardwick and I tried a version of the BTS that two
cubers can try even if they don't live close together. Chris would
mix up his cube, hold the cube in front of his webcam, and close his
eyes. I watched his webcam and told him (over the phone) what
moves/algs to do. We even tried ZBF2L on some of the solves. Our
best average of 10 solves was about 2:20 and our single best solve
was 1:27.

We use a bunch of codes that Raul and I adapted from Katsui's F2L
page. Chris will post them soon in case anyone is interested in
learning them. Raul and I generally do a 3-look last layer and
we've got names for each of the edge orientation, corner
orientation, and PLL cases. We'll probably do some demonstrations
at the New York tournament next month.

I'm not sure what the limits are for the BTS over a webcam but I'm
hoping some of you will try it out. One thing that slowed us down
was a poor refresh rate for the cam (only about 1 frame per second
and a half) which means I couldn't look ahead at all.

In summary: BTS is a lot of fun and you only need a webcam (or two)
and a phone (a microphone might be better and cheaper). Give it a
shot!

Ian







271. My Hungarian Globe puzzle can't be solved!
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 24 Apr 2005 15:31:27 -0000


Hi all do-it-yourself guys!
I've got a Hungrian Globe which I received as a gift. The one like that
pictured on http://isacisco.free.fr/casserubiks.htm . It was mixed and
I thought that it had to be a piece of cake for me to solve it. I was
proved wrong! One piece is turned 120 degrees clockwise. You wonder how
can a square piece be turned 120 degrees? Right, it's the triangle
shaped piece of South America that is actually fixed in the body of the
globe.
Does anybody know how I can remove the piece and place it back
correctly without destroying the whole puzzle?
Mirek





272. Re: [Speed cubing group] German Open / Cube Day 2005
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 24 Apr 2005 16:57:55 +0100

Hey everyone,

Just to build on what Joel said, I would also like to congratulate everyone for their great performances at German Cube Day, it was a real privilege to be there and watch the masters in action :)

I would like to say thank you to Joel for his hospitality, and the rest of the Dutch gang + Lars for making me feel so welcome and a part of their group during the weekend. Also a great thank you to Patrick Bellenbaum for hosting the event, you did a great job :)

Hope to see you all again soon at Dutch Cube Day in October... and perhaps even in the UK if there will be an event this year, it wuld be very cool!

I will post my experience on my webpage (cubestation.co.uk) very soon, with pictures and movies and results. I would be really grateful to everybody there who was taking pictures if they could maybe send me the pictures to my email (danh@...), or perhaps just send me an email to tell me where I can find them? I would like to build a comprehensive collection of media from the event :D

See you guys!

Dan H :)

274. Re: [Speed cubing group] German Open / Cube Day 2005
From: a_ooms75 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 24 Apr 2005 19:50:09 -0000

Hello everybody, It was the first time that i have come to a compation and meet all the cubers. I did have a great time there. And same as Joël the nevers was braking me with the clocks and the kubus in the semifinal i hope i can get over that :) Someone did video my record on the mastermagic sorry i did not cast you name :( I hope you will react on this forum to stay in contact. see you all at the next event :) greets Alexander --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > Just to build on what Joel said, I would also like to congratulate everyone for their great performances at German Cube Day, it was a real privilege to be there and watch the masters in action :) > > I would like to say thank you to Joel for his hospitality, and the rest of the Dutch gang + Lars for making me feel so welcome and a part of their group during the weekend. Also a great thank you to Patrick Bellenbaum for hosting the event, you did a great job :) > > Hope to see you all again soon at Dutch Cube Day in October... and perhaps even in the UK if there will be an event this year, it wuld be very cool! > > I will post my experience on my webpage (cubestation.co.uk) very soon, with pictures and movies and results. I would be really grateful to everybody there who was taking pictures if they could maybe send me the pictures to my email (danh@c...), or perhaps just send me an email to tell me where I can find them? I would like to build a comprehensive collection of media from the event :D > > See you guys! > > Dan H :) > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Joël van Noort > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Sunday, April 24, 2005 4:20 PM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] German Open / Cube Day 2005 > > > > Hey everybody, > > Just a little message to let you all know that I had a great time at > the German Open yesterday! It was very nice too meet all those cubers > again! The ambiance was really great. > > I was glad I could realize some of my goals, but as usual, I could not > realize all of them.. I should really find a way to master those > nerves :). > > Congratulationswith the new records everybody, especially Stefan > (megaminx!!) and Lars (some ER's). 275. Re: [Speed cubing group] German Open / Cube Day 2005
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 24 Apr 2005 23:53:42 -0000


Hi all,

I also had a great time! Thanks a lot to everyone for making it
exciting two days, especially Patrick, who organized the whole time
and didn't compete!

Alexander, sorry, not sure who recorded your record. It was a German
(I think Michael), I'll try to find out and let you know (I don't
think the guys follow this group too closely). Btw, today I practiced
a bit with your modification and it's so great. I just got a 3.68
seconds solve, so don't feel too safe ;-)

I'll also write some report with pictures in the next few days.

Cheers!
Stefan






276. Re: [Speed cubing group] ===Newest Rubik's Cube Solving Robot===
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Apr 2005 07:10:57 -0000

I pretty much built every part from scratch... a lot of whelding had to be done, and I managed to do all the soldering myself. I suppose I could implement a Kocimba's algorithm..., but I'd rather just keep adding various human speedsolving methods. I would like it to illistrate different methodologies rather then just solve it as fast as possible. I think I can take it down to under 15s if I want to go for speed, which I'll probabily do just to demponsrate it's abilities. If it locks up for a few minutes, I can go up to it and fix the lock- up and it goes on it's merry way without loss of memory/state. HECK, if you turn it OFF, and turn it back on a few minutes later it will continue mid-solve. It currently has a 20MHz IBM embedded processor in it, I can upgrade that. Such a chip can be aquired for $15 or a free sample request. It worked out to be about $200 of parts. So fairly cheap. There was about $70 spent on **white** LEDs :(. It cost $50 for the material for the frame: aluminum chasis, steel-shafts, high-quality ball- bearings. I'm thinking $60 for motors. And $20 for other odd stuff. The image processing is mostly done in hardware. There is no software processing it much, except to shift some values for different lighting backgrounds..., chack ranges that RGB values fall in. The motor control is done with some black posterboard wheels with lines on them. They are read by an IR-emitter/IR-sensor pair that I put on the underside of the motors. Currently, there are 16 regions on each disk, the other side has 32 regions equally spaced, so a value can be changed in the software and the disks flipped to double the precision. The motors themselves took several hours to hack and mod for the proper calibration, torque, speed and stuff. It was an inital demo for the professors, better stuff is yet to come. hopefully I have time with two final exams left, one in Galois theory and one in Probability theory. I want to get it doing in both directions in one week, instead of always going clockwise to avoid lock-ups. Right now I have to prepare a presentation, report, and website for it. That'll be due Monday midnight. *sigh* Note that once the program is uploaded into the processor the computer can be dis-connected and the CubeBot is fully functional, able to do manual control, say from an old 8-bit Nintendo Controller (this hasn't been put in yet, current manual control is done with some DIP switches and button presses on thh board). It does the solve by first scanning the cube stickers in and then taking say 7.6seconds to *think*. It does some searchs and uses look-up tables..., it trys different paths and selects the optimal among them, etc. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Evan Gates <evan.gates@g...> wrote: > Well, on deepcube, > > After the scramble, and any other moves that people do on it (as I now > have a nice GUI with which a user can do any moves that he/she likes > ;-)), the moves are stored in a file. When someone presses solve, the > computer does those moves on a virtual cube, so that it knows the > state of the cube. It then passes this state to the solver (slightly > modified version of mike reid's solver) and passes the solution to a > file. This solution is then converted to motor commands, and output > at the right times. So in essence, yes, it does blindfold. > > One more question for Doug, how well does the visual feedback work for > the motors? I was thinking of trying something like that, but the > motors that I currently do not support it in any simple fashion. > > -Evan > > Until next time, Happy Cubing > http://www.deepcube.tk > > On 4/23/05, Duncan Dicks <duncan@d...> wrote: > > Thats great. This may be a stupid question but does it effectively solve > > blindfold? That is: is the solve worked out from beginning to end before it > > does the first move, or is it rescanning the cube continually, or once it > > has scanned once is it calculating the new position while its moving? Or is > > there another option of which I haven't thought! > > > > Duncan > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "d_funny007" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> > > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > > Sent: Saturday, April 23, 2005 4:04 AM > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] ===Newest Rubik's Cube Solving Robot=== > > > > > > > > > > > > > It's been awhile since I've been around these parts, but I am still > > > a someone active cuber... Here's proof. > > > > > > Today I (with a couple friends) finished making (the first version) > > > of my take on a Rubik's Cube Solving Robot. > > > > > > It takes a while to load, cuz the file is so large. There is a long > > > pause when it's *thinking*. > > > > > > > > > <http://www-personal.umich.edu/~dlli/Cubebot_DivX.avi> > > > > > > > > > Recorded Friday April, 22, 2005 for a demo to the professors of > > > an "Microprocessor-Based Embedded-Systems Design" Course I was > > > taking as a final project. (It solves in a little under 38 seconds > > > from one measurement I took. That my not be the case in this video.) > > > > > > It starts off by reading in the 6 faces by perfoming a 360 on each > > > face. Then it takes about 27 seconds to *think*, that video was > > > taken without the I-Cache or D-Cashe turned on (if you know what > > > that means) or with millisecond interrupts turned off during that > > > processing, so it could have been much faster (<8 sec). It was > > > running at 20Mhz Bus Speed and off a Motorola Power PC chip (the > > > MPC823, very ancient). > > > > > > It's an embedded systems design, meaning it can be easily made to be > > > portable. (It does *NOT* rely on an computer for processing.) > > > > > > It goes counterclockwise always, and overshoots... a protocol the > > > same (or opposite) to what the DeepCube people used. We just wanted > > > to get it working..., I can go in a modify it now that we know it is > > > precise enough not to lock-up more then say 1% of the time... though > > > I would put in an "anti-lock-up" protocal that detects-and- reverses. > > > > > > It is applying a breath-first search for the cross..., does the 4 > > > c/e-pairs, CLL, and then ELL. (The LL according to my personal > > > algorithms.) This was pretty close to a method I used to use, before > > > moving onto something much more insane. It is essentially what Guus > > > R. Schultz and/or Akimoto uses/used as well. > > > > > > It does c/e-pairing in a fairly sophisticated manner different from > > > what is usually seen in stage-based solver programs I have seen > > > before. > > > > > > Averages 69.1 quarter turns (i.e. QTM) in an average of 100,000 > > > runs. Though counter-clockwise is currently executed as a 270 > > > rotation. It never does more then 270 on a face during solving. All > > > these figures can be readily optimized now that everything else is > > > reliable. > > > > > > And yes, it is dangling a few inches from the table due to us having > > > to wire it up in a rush not using any ties to the frame. It can > > > stand on 3 points of the frame as well. Just simple aluminum frame > > > and some precise whelding. > > > > > > Oh, and that is NOT the standard color scheme, it is my own. > > > > > > BTW, if tHe bandwidth gets terrible, feel free to mirror the file > > > elsewhere..., say on speedcubing.com. > > > > > > > > > -Doug Li (Happy Cubing) > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > ________________________________ > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > To visit your group on the web, go to: > > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.

After this school year is over, I'll be exporting one of my products
back to the UK. A girl is here at Caltech on an exchange program for a
year. Yeah, taught her how to cube :-) I'm going to try to get her to
learn blindfolded too :-P

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

280. Connecting speedstack timer to PC ???
From: pbellenbaum <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Apr 2005 09:39:32 -0000


Hi,

a technical question:

Did anyone of you already tried/managed to connect the speedstacks
timer to a PC (via the output that is used by the competition timer
display)?

My goal would be to have the time that is displayed on the timer itself
also available at the PC (for further use in excel, etc.)

Any ideas and/or experience welcome, all the best, Patrick

287. Re: My Hungarian Globe puzzle can't be solved!
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Apr 2005 17:53:56 -0000

Hmm Mirek :-? That is indeed impossible cause opposite piece will always move in "parallell", so in that case u should expect 2 wrongly oriented pieces. In fact the orientations should be 0 (modulo 4). -Per >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" <goljan@s...> wrote: > > Hi all do-it-yourself guys! > I've got a Hungrian Globe which I received as a gift. The one like that > pictured on http://isacisco.free.fr/casserubiks.htm . It was mixed and > I thought that it had to be a piece of cake for me to solve it. I was > proved wrong! One piece is turned 120 degrees clockwise. You wonder how > can a square piece be turned 120 degrees? Right, it's the triangle > shaped piece of South America that is actually fixed in the body of the > globe. > Does anybody know how I can remove the piece and place it back > correctly without destroying the whole puzzle? > Mirek
288. Re: Huge optimal solver
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Apr 2005 18:45:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > Here are some algorithms which I suspect might be optimal: > > L2 F2 R2 D2 B2 U2 L' B2 U B2 L R' D' F' R' U2 F' D' F' R2 (20f) //3;1346 > D2 L2 U2 B F' U2 F' L B2 D' F2 L2 F2 D F2 D2 U2 R' F' U2 (20f) // 3;1366 > U L2 B2 U' B2 D2 R2 F U2 L' D' R2 D' B U R2 D2 R' F2 R' (20f) //3;1445 > > F2 U2 R2 D2 L U2 L F2 U2 R' D' B R' F' R B L' F' R2 U (20f) //90;1187 > R2 B2 F' L2 B D2 L2 R' D2 B F' L2 U R2 B D2 U2 L2 F' R2 (20f) //90;1832 Actually 90;1832 above is not optimal (optimal is 19 moves).

The Winning Moves ones should be in most of the > stores, especially in bigger towns and cities and there are some clues to > look out for; namely that the logo is much brighter print due to the new > stickers and there will be a stand included. later in the year (in time for > Christmas) will be a 25th Anniversary cube for 2005 with special logo (for > next year only) and different packaging (silver, hexagonal) All of these > will be to the new higher standard. > The cube kit on rubiks.com is the new design, you don't have to use the > rivets on this and can put in screws instead. > Hope that helps. > Dave > Seven Towns.

302. Cubing Exercises
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Apr 2005 17:52:49 -0000


A question for all the skilled cubists out there: do you have any
exercises that you perform to enhance your cubing abilities? I know I
can figure this stuff out, but I guess I am looking to see if there is
some advice or experience that can help speed the trial and error
process up. I am looking for things that will help me concentrate on
changing the position of one's grip fluidly; increasing the average
turns per minute; see the cube better; etc.

I could just perform a single algorithm over and over until it is
down, but I was hoping there was something that could give an overall
improvement, and not just on a per algorithm basis. Perhaps this does
not exist in speedcubing, but in other skills people perform drills
that increase ability before getting to the actual game.

Any advice or suggestions would be appreciated.






303. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cubing Exercises
From: Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Apr 2005 10:59:33 -0700 (PDT)

I would practice on a very "unlubed" stiff cube... And once you try a smooth/lubed cube after that, it seems as if it's magic... There are other things, but practice is the key. -Brent thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: A question for all the skilled cubists out there: do you have any exercises that you perform to enhance your cubing abilities? I know I can figure this stuff out, but I guess I am looking to see if there is some advice or experience that can help speed the trial and error process up. I am looking for things that will help me concentrate on changing the position of one's grip fluidly; increasing the average turns per minute; see the cube better; etc. I could just perform a single algorithm over and over until it is down, but I was hoping there was something that could give an overall improvement, and not just on a per algorithm basis. Perhaps this does not exist in speedcubing, but in other skills people perform drills that increase ability before getting to the actual game. Any advice or suggestions would be appreciated. --------------------------------- Yahoo! Mmh, I don't do this, but maybe it would help you to practice finger tricks? 305. MasterMagic design
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Apr 2005 18:18:10 -0000


I've just printed the pictures for the MasterMagic that rubiks.com
offers for download:
http://www.rubiks.
com/images/lvl4/produc/template/free_downloads/pdf/12panelmagic.pdf

I printed pages 1 and 3 on both sides of one sheet. Then I noticed the
back side (page 3) looks very different from the old MasterMagics I
have. Could someone with a new MasterMagic please tell me whether it
looks the same as the downloadable design? I'm not talking about
colors but about where the pieces of the rings are.

I guess I'll have to print it on two separate sheets...

Thanks,
Stefan






306. Re: MasterMagic design
From: "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Apr 2005 23:32:50 -0000

It looks like you can print it on one sheet, it's just that the pages on the download are oriented goofy, at least it is for me. I have an old Master Magic and I made one from the download and my pictures are identical. If you take page one's picture on the left, it's bottom left tile is opposite from page three's picture on the right's top left tile. Page one's picture on the right, its tile in the top right is opposite page three's left picture's tile in the bottom right. It's like page three is upside down. If your old Master Magic is like mine, the front and backside tiles that have Rubik's signature are the same tiles on the download that say Rubik's Magic. I hope this is what you're asking. I confused myself on all those lefts and rights. Matt --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I've just printed the pictures for the MasterMagic that rubiks.com > offers for download: > http://www.rubiks. > com/images/lvl4/produc/template/free_downloads/pdf/12panelmagic.pdf > > I printed pages 1 and 3 on both sides of one sheet. Then I noticed the > back side (page 3) looks very different from the old MasterMagics I > have. Could someone with a new MasterMagic please tell me whether it > looks the same as the downloadable design? I'm not talking about > colors but about where the pieces of the rings are. > > I guess I'll have to print it on two separate sheets... > > Thanks, > Stefan
307. Re: MasterMagic design
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Apr 2005 00:01:55 -0000

Thanks a lot! I looked at it again and indeed it seems to be basically correct but something's systematically wrong. I think the easiest way to fix it would be to swap the left and right parts of either page 1 or 3. Will tell rubiks.com about it. Also it would be nice if the rings on page 1 could be truly connected instead of just overlapping. If they can't fix it, I might print one page, cut it in half, swap the halves and glue them together, then print the other page. Sigh... Cheers! 308. Wrong cube pictures
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Apr 2005 00:30:11 -0000


Prove that the following item shows an impossible state (i.e. stickers
need to be peeled off). Slightly harder than usual because the top can
be rotated.

http://i7.ebayimg.com/03/i/03/f1/fc/ad_1_b.JPG

Only cubers, not designers (unless they're cubers), should be allowed
to design cube pictures.

Cheers!
Stefan






309. Re: Wrong cube pictures
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Apr 2005 01:24:28 -0000

Sorry, couldn't help jumping on this one :-) Rotate the top either once clockwise or once counterclockwise and place it back down (since right now the cube is obviously not a normal cube, some pieces have two stickers the same color). Call the faces that we can see U, R, F, going counterclockwise and starting from the top face. The corner in UFL has stickers for blue and orange after the top rotation, and would need to belong in the DFR spot to be solved. However the other corner with Blue-orange is in UFR and would need to be rotated clockwise to be solved. This puts the third sticker of that corner, yellow, in the top layer, but the top layer sticker of UFR needs to be light blue when that piece is solved :-) Silly cube personal storage container makers :) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Prove that the following item shows an impossible state (i.e. stickers > need to be peeled off). Slightly harder than usual because the top can > be rotated. > > http://i7.ebayimg.com/03/i/03/f1/fc/ad_1_b.JPG > > Only cubers, not designers (unless they're cubers), should be allowed > to design cube pictures. > > Cheers! > Stefan

311. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Wrong cube pictures
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Apr 2005 00:38:14 -0400

Note that, neglecting corners, the top can only be in one position, because otherwise either you have two red-white edges or a white-white one.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



312. Re: Wrong cube pictures - interesting puzzle
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Apr 2005 05:40:35 -0000

This brings up an interesting question, how many positions have one face symmetrical enough that you can have a container like this, such that all 4 orientations of the top create a solvable cube? All 4 corners would have to be the same color, since you can't create corners with in correct color combinations. Even if you could switch the U sticker of a corner with that sticker's opposite color, the two side colors on the corner would now be in the incorrect positions for a solvable cube. It seems that the edges could potentially not all have to be the same color, as long as any rotation of the top face created 4 actual edges for that cube, and seemingly only did a double transposition of them since you can't change the parity without changing the corner parity. Also, if the edges appear to flip at all, you can only flip an even number. So let's say that all the corner stickers on the loose face (the one we can take off) are orange say. Obviously if all the edge stickers are the same then there are no problems, but that's boring :-) Also, as I'll show you can have some top configurations that don't have that. Below the edges are written such that they belong in the spots (in the same order as written below) UB UR UF UL and the first color shows what is the top layer sticker, and the second shows what is the bottom layer sticker. White-Green Yellow-Orange White-Orange Yellow-Green So the top layer is somewhat symmetrical, and only has 2 possible states. By turning the top once clockwise or counterclockwise you perform the cycle (UB UL) (UR UF) which is an even permutation (you haven't changed the corner permutation since all the top layer stickers for the corners are the same color. Also, no edges flip so we're good there too. I'm currently taking a break from writing a big paper due tomorrow :-D, but I wanted to post that one example to show it was possible. Are there any others that work too? You'll notice that the pattern of the top layer stickers in my example form a plus sign, and each line of the plus is one solid color. Is that a necessary condition? Are there other ways to do this besides the obvious all corners one color and all edges some other color? Having all the corners one color is a requirement of course, but what other cool things can be done with the edges, if any? One last thing, notice that if you use a certain edge sticker color in the top layer, that you can't have its opposite color, or same color, in the side layer of the edges. This is because any rotation of the top must be possible, so you have to avoid creating say a red-red or red-orange edge. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@v...> wrote: > Note that, neglecting corners, the top can only be in one position, because otherwise either you have two red-white edges or a white-white one. > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
313. Re: [Speed cubing group] Animal Planet
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Apr 2005 09:49:49 +0200

Thanks, that was quite interesting. Shotaro was as always mighty impressive.

/Gustav

316. Re: Wrong cube pictures - interesting puzzle
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Apr 2005 14:42:49 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > This brings up an interesting question, how many positions have one > face symmetrical enough that you can have a container like this, such > that all 4 orientations of the top create a solvable cube? Hi Chris, nice riddle :-) I think you've found the only non-boring solution. Imagine a color (say red) only appears once in either the top four edges of the side four. Because we don't want a red-red edge it the other four can't be red. Since that red needs a certain partner, for rotation the whole other group needs to be that partner color. If the top four are that monocolor group, then it's valid but boring. If the side four are that monocolor group, then the top four colors need to be all different. But then a quarter turn is an odd permutation, making it invalid. So every color needs to appear at least twice (and in the same group of four). It can't be three because this would force another color to be alone. So every color appears either 2 or 4 times (and in the same group of four) and 4 is boring. Thus, all colors should appear twice and we have four colors, just like in your solution. There are only two patterns: Cross and Adjacent. We can't have the same pattern in both groups, this would lead to duplicate edges. Cross on top and Adjacent on sides works, that's your solution. The other way around doesn't work (easy to check). Cheers! Stefan

325. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Wrong cube pictures - interesting puzzle
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Apr 2005 00:22:30 -0400

I'm not following all of the discussion, but suppose this (Y/W, B/G, R/O):
Up face: all corner colors are same, edges are R, O, B, G (in any order).
UF/UR edges: on the F and R sides they are, say, Y and W.
So the edges can't clash, and the corners have no effect.
I hope you didn't already mention this.
--qqwref


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

very fast with very strong springs.

Tolerance for >> this parameter is (+-)15%(indicative)." >> :-D >> François >> --- François Sechet <frsechet@y...> wrote: >> --------------------------------- >> We do use k in France too... if that's what he meant. >> But, eh, Gilles, everyone knows you're a very old man >> now and R was probably the way it was called back in >> the 30'es :-P >> just kidding...no, seriously, were does the R come >> from? >> François >> --- Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: >> --------------------------------- >> The R value? Is this just the spring constant? 333. Re: [Speed cubing group] Springs
From: sachin shirwalkar <sachin_civilian@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Apr 2005 13:34:11 +0100 (BST)

ya the best way would be to use a water pan as a weight. since water has density of 1gm/cc and volume measuring instruments are much more accesible, this will make the measurements more accurate. and if u really want to be accurate use verniers;) --- Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote: --------------------------------- Haha... man, if I were a TA for the physics lab classes... I'd totally make them do it! What... just find some different weights, and plot the spring displacement and find the slope. I hate physics at 2 AM in the morning btw. 336. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Springs
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Apr 2005 11:35:21 -0700

Oh, the day when they'll come out with super premium cubes. The plastic will be nice and perfectly smooth, carefully molded so there are no bumps. The springs will be hand-selected to ensure equal tension in all the springs, and the stickers... the stickers won't peel and will provide an amazing fit. And before any cube leaves the store, it will be speed solved by Macky, and only the ones solved below 15 seconds will be considered for resale. 337. Re: Wrong cube pictures
From: portoseb <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Apr 2005 20:19:56 -0000

I did a cube medal from clay as an assignment for our art course. I
took two photos of it (they are uploaded in the photos section of the
group, the folder named Sebastian). To paint it more easily I
scrambled my cube and copied the position. So it's a legal position.

There's a poster in a classroom in our school which shows a timeline
with some stuff about the EU. In the 80's there's a drawing of the
cube, and it's impossible for the same reason: two corners with the
same clockwise order of colours.

On Dan's Cubestation there are four cubes on the lefthand side of the
page, showing the 4 steps of the Fridrich method. The cube next
to "Orient last layer" shows an impossible position again for the same
reason. So cubers sometimes make this mistake too!

Sebastian

From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 28 Apr 2005 22:46:01 +0100

Hi everyone

I have posted my full report from German Cube Day 2005 on my website. You can access it from the news page by clicking on the link.

Dan :)

P.S. I am shocked to hear that one of the cubes on my website is of the "unsolvable" type. I think what happened is that when I was drawing the cube some pieces popped out and I must have drawn them back in wrong. :)

340. [Speed cubing group] Re: Springs
From: "lkyawkyaw" <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Apr 2005 03:00:39 -0000

Find the right spring. 1. final work done on stretched spring = potential energy 1/2K(Xsquare) = mgX where x=distance moved. if you measuare the distance from central axle to center of cube g = gravity acceleration K = spring constant calculate spring constant: K = root(2mg/x) If they sell springs by their K value then you should be able to get a good one for the cube. a small mass is good :P --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Oh, the day when they'll come out with super premium cubes. The > plastic will be nice and perfectly smooth, carefully molded so there > are no bumps. The springs will be hand-selected to ensure equal > tension in all the springs, and the stickers... the stickers won't peel > and will provide an amazing fit. And before any cube leaves the store, > it will be speed solved by Macky, and only the ones solved below 15 > seconds will be considered for resale. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Apr 28, 2005, at 11:28 AM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > >> > >> http://www.vanel.com/compression.php? > > lang=english&sessionid=1935646144270993de57eb5102316167321632316285 > >> > >> Please help me find the R value for a 3x3x3 spring. > >> I'd like to validate my theory that says an old smooth cube would be > >> very fast with very strong springs. > >> > >> Gilles. > > > > Haha, that's funny. 343. Record pages
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Apr 2005 14:46:10 -0000


We're all reading record pages on http://www.speedcubing.com (times,
events, national records and so on).
But I wonder what kind of technology makes it possible (databases,
serverside programs or scripting, etc). And I suppose everything's not
automatic.

Could the webmasters tell us a bit more about it? I'm sure people
would be interested in hearing about who is doing what and how.

Gilles.






344. Re: [Speed cubing group] Record pages
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 29 Apr 2005 17:05:47 +0200

Hi Gilles, Thanks for the interest. :-) At the moment the world rankings are in Excel. The hard work is getting all results in the same format..... The unofficial world records are either in Excel (for the popular categories) or in the HTML files. Updating every days takes me quite some time.... It is taking me more time than I actually like. :-( For both we are working on good programs. World rankings in PHP, so that people can generate personal profiles. UWR in MS Access, so that it is easier to do daily updates. Have fun, Ron ----- Original Message ----- From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Friday, April 29, 2005 4:46 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Record pages > > We're all reading record pages on http://www.speedcubing.com (times, > events, national records and so on). > But I wonder what kind of technology makes it possible (databases, > serverside programs or scripting, etc). And I suppose everything's not > automatic. > > Could the webmasters tell us a bit more about it? I'm sure people > would be interested in hearing about who is doing what and how. > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
345. Rubic solve page?
From: "r_detzel" <god@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Apr 2005 16:21:33 -0000

Hey, probably a year ago or so I found a page online that shows you
how to solve the cube like this with pictures and everything but now I
can't find it, can anyone help me out?

Solve top first and get the sides of the top all the same. The you
have solid on top and each side has the top of a T . Next you solved
the middle layer for each color and then the bottom line. No idea what
it's called and I can't find this, it was the best solution and I
really want to learn to solve this cube again.

cube.

(I've never been to any competition but I'm thinking about the Dutch
Open in october.)

I've tried to imagine how we could cheat with a cube but I didn't find
anything except that it's possible to make it turn while another cube
would block (for exemple : R'U badly executed).

Thx :-)

361. Re: cube checked before a competition
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Apr 2005 16:45:19 -0000

Well.. The only thing I can think of, is that you should not be able to see what colour any stickers on the back sids have (when you look at the front), by painting it, or making your stickers in a weird way... Or, for BLD cubers, you can't have damaged stickers, because that might enable you to feel where certain stickers are. I did not notice any 'official' checks on my cube btw, but maybe the organizer inspected them a little while scrambling. -Joel. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@y...> wrote: > Hi, > > I've read the report of the german Open by Dan Harris and he mentioned > that the cubes were checked before the competition. > > I find this completely normal but I'm wondering what is checked on the > cube. > > (I've never been to any competition but I'm thinking about the Dutch > Open in october.) > > I've tried to imagine how we could cheat with a cube but I didn't find > anything except that it's possible to make it turn while another cube > would block (for exemple : R'U badly executed). > > Thx :-) > Gilles.
362. Re: cube checked before a competition (BLD)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Apr 2005 18:04:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > for BLD cubers, you can't have damaged stickers, because > that might enable you to feel where certain stickers are. I think you just have to trust people, at least until the next $1,000,000 BLD event. In fact, you don't even have to modify/damage the cube first to get some info about the cube position. For example, I can feel the edge orientations of my Studio cube without even wanting to: every edge piece has a slight depression on one facelet. Imagine what might be possible after you've sandpapered your fingertips, just a little... Uh... shouldn't I have kept my big mouth shut there? Mike

366. commutators, 4x4x4 and 5x5x5
From: "Evan" <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Apr 2005 21:50:31 -0000

so i know i asked about commutators a while ago, and i got a pretty
nice explanation, and i got it to work some of the time, but im
running into problems now.

so i want to do three cycles of edge peies on either a 4x4x4 or a
5x5x5, and i know the general idea behind a commutator. the only
problem is, almost every time i try it, i end up just doing like the
dot pattern, M E'M'E on a 3x3x3 (hope i used the correct notation
there), affecting a single center on all 6 sides, instead of just the
three i want to switch. So i was wondering if someone could possibly
explain it again, or send me to a page that has a good explanation,
maybe it will click this time, who knows

thank you in advanced
-Evan

Until next time, Happy Cubing
http://www.deepcube.tk

368. New Method
From: "James Stuber" <jestuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 30 Apr 2005 15:25:02 -0700



I've been messing around with new methods for awhile that have less
algorithms than zb but average less than fridrich. Here's the most viable
option I've found so far:

1) f2l minus one c/e pair 7+7*3=28

2) pair up last c/e pair 3.5

3) insert c/e pair and solve edges. (I've found about half of the algorithms
and so far avg. is 7.7)

4) solve corners 12.5

It needs 276 algorithms (including reflections and symmetries) and averages
51.7 moves (that might change when I find all the algs for step 3) which is
4 moves less than fridrich. My question is, does anyone think it would
actually be any faster? I think with practice, step 3 and 4 recognition
would be as fast as or faster than recognizing oll/pll.

On my page I have almost half of the algs for step 3 and recognition of step
3, but step 4 is not up yet.

http://www.stubers.org/jamesstuff/intro.htm



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



369. [Speed cubing group] Re: cube checked before a competition (BLD)
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Apr 2005 22:35:21 -0000

Hi Guys, I like the braille idea, but why stop there? Solving it by sound could get really annoying, and I'm not sure I would even want to try solving it by taste. But why not solve it my smell? White could smell like vanilla, Blue could smell like coffee, Yellow could smell like honeysuckle, Green could smell like mint, Orange could smell like Chocolate, and Red could smell like cinnamon. Thank you, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Dear Mr Jones, > > I was quite interested in the new white plastic DIY cubes. > > Going by the post below I ordered 2 of the new white plastic DIY > cubes from Rubiks.com, however when they arrived I was disappointed to > find the they didn't have arched centers. 376. [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4, 5x5x5 patterns?
From: Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Apr 2005 22:47:01 -0400

There aren't really any good sites for patterns on higher-order cubes, unfortunately. I have a personal database of a few cool 5x5x5 ones, although you guys can't use them because they use my notation (where f = turn two front layers). One of them for the 5x5x5 is 214 moves or so and I can't figure out how to get it better. I could, of course, solve it and get about 170 moves... How many moves do you guys usually take, excluding the 3x3x3 step if there is one? And do you have any ideas for patterns?

--MZRG

377. Did a speed solve for an 80's dance
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 01 May 2005 05:35:49 -0000

Hey everyone,

I just got back from an 80's dance at a really popular local band
scene near my school. It's called Cat's Cradle and from rumors I've
heard Dave Matthews band as well as Squirrel Nut Zippers used to play
there before they hit it really big.

Anyway they held an 80's dance tonight, and I went as Axel Rose,
wearing a red bandana, a plaid shirt and jeans (of course with long
hair too :-)

They had me get up on stage a couple hours in and do a solve. The
crowd loved it - there were maybe 200-300 people there so it was
pretty cool.

I wasn't able to time the solve, but I know for sure it wasn't sub-20.
I think it was a low twenty though (20-22), which was good for me for
low light and about 1.5 seconds of inspection :)

Anyway I had a blast, and of course it being a crowd of 80's
enthusiasts they loved it.

Just wanted to share in case anyone was interested :)

Chris

I know when I do this after getting a good time, it's partly because I want to be sure myself that I don't write down or remember a wrong time. 381. ELL, then CLL?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 01 May 2005 13:49:37 -0000

I solve the last layer of the megaminx by first solving edges and then
corners. That's because corners move much more freely than edges,
they're part of three layers. Also, no nice "middle layer" twists are
possible. So I do corners last.

I've been wondering whether the same is true for the 3x3 cube. The
algorithms section of SCC has algs for CLL first, ELL second. This
seems bad for me now. Why not try it the other way around? ELL first,
CLL second. Did someone try this already? Also, is there a comparison
between the two possibilities, e.g. average number of moves?

Cheers!
Stefan






382. Re: ELL, then CLL?
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 01 May 2005 14:10:06 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > The > algorithms section of SCC has algs for CLL first, ELL second. This > seems bad for me now. Why not try it the other way around? ELL first, > CLL second. Did someone try this already? Also, is there a comparison > between the two possibilities, e.g. average number of moves? I think what you need is in Bernard Helmstetter's pages: http://www.ai.univ-paris8.fr/~bh/cube/ He lists: CLL (25 configurations, average:9.18), then ELL (19 configurations, average:11.27). ELL (13 configurations, average:7.87), then CLL (42 configurations, average:11.73) (His numbers include the solved cases.) So there are fewer (distinct) cases for CLL-then-ELL than for ELL-then-CLL, but the average is indeed a little better in the latter case. Mike
383. Re: ELL, then CLL?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 01 May 2005 16:33:36 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > > I think what you need is in Bernard Helmstetter's pages: > > http://www.ai.univ-paris8.fr/~bh/cube/ > > He lists: > > CLL (25 configurations, average:9.18), > then ELL (19 configurations, average:11.27). > > ELL (13 configurations, average:7.87), > then CLL (42 configurations, average:11.73) > > (His numbers include the solved cases.) So there are fewer (distinct) > cases for CLL-then-ELL than for ELL-then-CLL, but the average is > indeed a little better in the latter case. Thanks, that's really nice. I'm sure I've seen it before, but obviously I forgot about it... Do you know whether his move averages are weighted averages? I.e. is it the average over all 42 "distinct" configurations or over all 12*27=324 configurations? I have a feeling it's the former, and I'd like the latter. I summed up the number of moves of all 42 shortest algs for "then CLL" and reached 491, resulting in a 491/42=11.69 average, not 11.73. So maybe it *is* weighted... Stefan

385. Re: 11.52 seconds
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 01 May 2005 20:41:47 -0000

!!#&+*#&& !!!!!! I just had a sub-10 solve (well scrambled, but very lucky in the end of course), and my video camera was not working...GGGGRRRR... Putain de bon dieu de bordel de merde! :-) Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > > But why do I always have to see the timer afterwards.. I will > believe > > you anyway, trust me :). > > I know when I do this after getting a good time, it's partly because I > want to be sure myself that I don't write down or remember a wrong > time. I don't always trust myself ;-) > > It's also good for when people in some forum post your video or > directly link to it. > > Cheers! > Stefan

388. 2x2x2 question
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 May 2005 02:52:28 -0000

Hey everyone,

I recently have gotten very interested in bettering my 2x2x2 times. I
had a question about one strategy that I think would help for those
who do a "first layer first" strategy (not Gaetan's method).

Here's is an example,
Do this scramble on your 2x2x2
F' R2 U R2 U F2 U' F R' U' F'

What if instead of solving one layer, you noticed that doing an R2
will solve two 2x1 blocks, effectively solving one layer.

So do R2 on this scramble.

The bottom "layer" can now be treated as one layer, and you can do a
CLL alg on the top, solving the last 4. So do B U2 B' U' B U' B'

Then you just have to solve all the 2x1 blocks that you've formed, in
this example it is B2.

So if you combine the whole solve you get a very, very short solve of
R2 B U2 B' U' B U' B

This strategy would probably only really work when the two 2x1 blocks
you can form have opposite colors as the 2 part. Notice how in that
example the blocks were opposite colors, making it easy to still spot
the CLL case, given that you know to convert the stickers on the
"wrong" corners to their opposite counterparts.

I imagine this would be very difficult to do for two 2x1 blocks that
weren't opposite colors, but of course the strategy would work the
same way.

Has anyone ever messed around with a strategy like this? Does it work
well?

Chris






389. Re: 2x2x2 question
From: cubacca1972 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 May 2005 03:13:20 -0000

Hi Chris This is a rather quirky event. It seems similar to solving one side with one move. I think that trying to figure out the correct CLL alg with a mix of U and D layer corners might cause severe headaches. At the very least, you might lose too much time thinking of the correct alg. There might be some benefit in a FMC type of event if you could recognize and exploit these cases. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I recently have gotten very interested in bettering my 2x2x2 times. I > had a question about one strategy that I think would help for those > who do a "first layer first" strategy (not Gaetan's method). > > Here's is an example, > Do this scramble on your 2x2x2 > F' R2 U R2 U F2 U' F R' U' F' > > What if instead of solving one layer, you noticed that doing an R2 > will solve two 2x1 blocks, effectively solving one layer. > > So do R2 on this scramble. > > The bottom "layer" can now be treated as one layer, and you can do a > CLL alg on the top, solving the last 4. So do B U2 B' U' B U' B' > > Then you just have to solve all the 2x1 blocks that you've formed, in > this example it is B2. > > So if you combine the whole solve you get a very, very short solve of > R2 B U2 B' U' B U' B > > This strategy would probably only really work when the two 2x1 blocks > you can form have opposite colors as the 2 part. Notice how in that > example the blocks were opposite colors, making it easy to still spot > the CLL case, given that you know to convert the stickers on the > "wrong" corners to their opposite counterparts. > > I imagine this would be very difficult to do for two 2x1 blocks that > weren't opposite colors, but of course the strategy would work the > same way. > > Has anyone ever messed around with a strategy like this? Does it work > well? > > Chris
390. Advanced F2L Algorithms
From: "Ben Marx" <godsalgorithm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 May 2005 03:56:11 -0000

Does anyone know of any good sites that have some advanced F2L
(corner-edge pair) algorithms beyond the 41 Fridrich ones?
The algs on this page are great, but incomplete.

http://www.geocities.com/rubiks_galaxia/offsetprintable.html

Thanks.
