394. Re: 2x2x2 question
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 May 2005 08:36:20 -0000

Hey Lucas, and all following this thread. I had my first success in using this offset 2x1 groups as the first layer approach. I just got a 5.90 second solve (pretty good for me) by building two 2x1 groups of opposite colors as my first "layer" and then solving the last "layer" with a CLL alg. I was able to read what the orientation case would be during inspection, and during the solve I was able to identify the CLL case. The last part to solve the four 2x1 groups into a solved 2x2x2 wasn't hard. I think this method will be difficult to use for the harder to recognize CLL cases, but what helpful cool trick isn't hard to learn? ;-) I'm going to rehearse this and try to use it when it comes up. It makes for an easy, fast solve if you can do it correctly. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cubacca1972 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hi Chris > > This is a rather quirky event. It seems similar to solving one side > with one move. > > I think that trying to figure out the correct CLL alg with a mix of U > and D layer corners might cause severe headaches. At the very least, > you might lose too much time thinking of the correct alg. > > There might be some benefit in a FMC type of event if you could > recognize and exploit these cases. > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > > > I recently have gotten very interested in bettering my 2x2x2 times. I > > had a question about one strategy that I think would help for those > > who do a "first layer first" strategy (not Gaetan's method). > > > > Here's is an example, > > Do this scramble on your 2x2x2 > > F' R2 U R2 U F2 U' F R' U' F' > > > > What if instead of solving one layer, you noticed that doing an R2 > > will solve two 2x1 blocks, effectively solving one layer. > > > > So do R2 on this scramble. > > > > The bottom "layer" can now be treated as one layer, and you can do a > > CLL alg on the top, solving the last 4. So do B U2 B' U' B U' B' > > > > Then you just have to solve all the 2x1 blocks that you've formed, in > > this example it is B2. > > > > So if you combine the whole solve you get a very, very short solve of > > R2 B U2 B' U' B U' B > > > > This strategy would probably only really work when the two 2x1 blocks > > you can form have opposite colors as the 2 part. Notice how in that > > example the blocks were opposite colors, making it easy to still spot > > the CLL case, given that you know to convert the stickers on the > > "wrong" corners to their opposite counterparts. > > > > I imagine this would be very difficult to do for two 2x1 blocks that > > weren't opposite colors, but of course the strategy would work the > > same way. > > > > Has anyone ever messed around with a strategy like this? I.e. is > it the average over all 42 "distinct" configurations or over all Hi Stefan, Almost certain they are weighted, as the figures for "Fridrich" are the usual ones. Why do you need the unweighted? (Just nosy!) Either way it is too many new sequences to learn.] Mike

397. Re: 2x2x2 question
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 May 2005 09:44:33 -0000

Hello Chris, I think that managing opposite colors during CLL as you proposed (and as I proposed before, and Ryan even before ;-) ) should not be a big problem. I can do it rather fast, but I try to avoid it when I want to be really fast. I'll even be more optimistic than you. This strategy could work without the need for opposite colors. You just have to learn to recognize more CLL configurations, in a different way. See http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Step_3.html (Possible improvement) Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I recently have gotten very interested in bettering my 2x2x2 times. So do B U2 B' U' B U' B' > > Then you just have to solve all the 2x1 blocks that you've formed, in > this example it is B2. > > So if you combine the whole solve you get a very, very short solve of > R2 B U2 B' U' B U' B > > This strategy would probably only really work when the two 2x1 blocks > you can form have opposite colors as the 2 part. Notice how in that > example the blocks were opposite colors, making it easy to still spot > the CLL case, given that you know to convert the stickers on the > "wrong" corners to their opposite counterparts. > > I imagine this would be very difficult to do for two 2x1 blocks that > weren't opposite colors, but of course the strategy would work the > same way. > > Has anyone ever messed around with a strategy like this? 402. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4, 5x5x5 patterns?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 May 2005 12:39:36 -0000

Hi Michael! There's a few sticker-swapping "patterns" at Stefan Pochmann's site. (http://www.stefan- pochmann.de/spocc/other_stuff/4x4_5x5_algs/#ColorSchemeModifiers) And of course any 3x3x3 pattern will carry over to 4x4x4 and larger cubes n^3. Some do carry over with natural extensions like "cube-in- cube". U can make "cube-in-cube-in-cube-.....-in-cube" and so on. Like wise with spot patterns u can make new spots inside the "3x3x3 kind spots". Could u pls post ur pattern collection or give us a link to a webpage? I'd be very interested in finding shorter solution for ur terribly long sequence pattern. Im sure some algorithm with reasonable length can be worked out somehow (using commutators or whatever to move the various parts around without having to resort to the normal pairing-up 3x3x3 approach.) Have a look at this really simple pattern that i posted before sometime : (on a 5x5x5 is nicest) r l f b r' l' f' b' Quite neat, right? Cheers! -Per K > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Michael Zener Riggs Gottlieb <mzrg@v...> wrote: > There aren't really any good sites for patterns on higher-order cubes, unfortunately. I have a personal database of a few cool 5x5x5 ones, although you guys can't use them because they use my notation (where f = turn two front layers). One of them for the 5x5x5 is 214 moves or so and I can't figure out how to get it better. I could, of course, solve it and get about 170 moves... How many moves do you guys usually take, excluding the 3x3x3 step if there is one? And do you have any ideas for patterns? > > --MZRG > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

405. Re: 2x2x2 question
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>

Date: Mon, 02 May 2005 13:24:44 -0000

Hi Chris.. It is an interesting strategy... But recognition is a bit of a problem.. However, when Fridrich published her method, some people thought recognizing F2L pairs would be difficult too :) (I read this somewhere). So maybe with practice, who knows? I should first learn CLL for this, though. -Joel. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I recently have gotten very interested in bettering my 2x2x2 times. I > had a question about one strategy that I think would help for those > who do a "first layer first" strategy (not Gaetan's method). > > Here's is an example, > Do this scramble on your 2x2x2 > F' R2 U R2 U F2 U' F R' U' F' > > What if instead of solving one layer, you noticed that doing an R2 > will solve two 2x1 blocks, effectively solving one layer. > > So do R2 on this scramble. > > The bottom "layer" can now be treated as one layer, and you can do a > CLL alg on the top, solving the last 4. So do B U2 B' U' B U' B' > > Then you just have to solve all the 2x1 blocks that you've formed, in > this example it is B2. > > So if you combine the whole solve you get a very, very short solve of > R2 B U2 B' U' B U' B > > This strategy would probably only really work when the two 2x1 blocks > you can form have opposite colors as the 2 part. Notice how in that > example the blocks were opposite colors, making it easy to still spot > the CLL case, given that you know to convert the stickers on the > "wrong" corners to their opposite counterparts. > > I imagine this would be very difficult to do for two 2x1 blocks that > weren't opposite colors, but of course the strategy would work the > same way. > > Has anyone ever messed around with a strategy like this? Does it work > well? > > Chris

So i compressed it to a reasonable size > > and uploaded to the group :-) I guess it's the olympicube in it's > > 6x6x6 incarnation, since Ron said a greek guy had sent it to him ;-) > > Great to see that video at last, but if it is olympicube, the inventor > has specifically requested (on twistypuzzles.com) that the video *NOT* > be made available yet! > > Mike

413. Re: 2x2x2 question
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 May 2005 19:11:47 -0000

Wow! Joel congrats on the new 5.90 average! That's awesome! I've decided to optimize my method with actual CLL algs wherever my COLL alg is just too long or too slow, so it may take me a while to improve again but I'll definitely try to take you up on your offer of catching up ;-) You've definitely got me really interested in learning Gaetan's method. I guess I'm so layers-entrenced that I just figured I'd go straight for the CLL approach when I started with the 2x2x2. Seeing that you can get 3's with Gaetan's method defnitely makes me want to learn it though. Good luck with CLL if you decide to learn it, I'm learning it for the first time myself actually, since I use COLL right now. I'm only 0.50 seconds behind you with COLL, so I hope learning CLL can make up the difference :) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > >...So maybe with practice, who knows? 414. Re: 2x2x2 question
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 May 2005 19:23:36 -0000

Actually, I kinda use a mix of Geatan's and the 'CFOP' aproach that I use for the 3x3. Sometimes, I first make one face, then do OLL on the other, and then permute both layers (PBL?). Geatan's algs are pretty easy. There are not that many of them, and they will enable you to see a way to orient all pieces very quickly. I can see the first two steps pretty often like that. Combined with C(O)LL, 2x2 can be solved very fast :). Not sure about continuing learning COLL, though.. I now know about 7 or 8 cases, but some of them really suck... Good luck with 2x2-ing! Joel. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Wow! Joel congrats on the new 5.90 average! That's awesome! I've > decided to optimize my method with actual CLL algs wherever my COLL > alg is just too long or too slow, so it may take me a while to improve > again but I'll definitely try to take you up on your offer of catching > up ;-) > > You've definitely got me really interested in learning Gaetan's > method. I guess I'm so layers-entrenced that I just figured I'd go > straight for the CLL approach when I started with the 2x2x2. Seeing > that you can get 3's with Gaetan's method defnitely makes me want to > learn it though. > > Good luck with CLL if you decide to learn it, I'm learning it for the > first time myself actually, since I use COLL right now. I'm only 0.50 > seconds behind you with COLL, so I hope learning CLL can make up the > difference :) > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > >...So maybe with practice, who knows? I should first learn > > > CLL for this, though. > > > > Although I an not sure if I can beat my new record with CLL :). You > > motivated me to give the 2x2 a go again today... 415. Re: 2x2x2 question
From: "azinj05ieipih" <azinj05ieipih@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 May 2005 23:13:40 -0000

Hi Chris, I have actually thought about this before the competition. Of course not as advanced to CLL. I think sub 6 average is possible using the way that I solve the 2x2: 1)Shortest amount of moves to complete on layer (solution founded during inspection period) (sub 2) 2)OLL (sub 1) 3)PLL (sub 2) Total:5 seconds+looking between each step Of course, the times that I got at the last competition didn't show - _-"~ ~Joseph http://jliao.tk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I recently have gotten very interested in bettering my 2x2x2 times. I > had a question about one strategy that I think would help for those > who do a "first layer first" strategy (not Gaetan's method). > > Here's is an example, > Do this scramble on your 2x2x2 > F' R2 U R2 U F2 U' F R' U' F' > > What if instead of solving one layer, you noticed that doing an R2 > will solve two 2x1 blocks, effectively solving one layer. > > So do R2 on this scramble. > > The bottom "layer" can now be treated as one layer, and you can do a > CLL alg on the top, solving the last 4. So do B U2 B' U' B U' B' > > Then you just have to solve all the 2x1 blocks that you've formed, in > this example it is B2. > > So if you combine the whole solve you get a very, very short solve of > R2 B U2 B' U' B U' B > > This strategy would probably only really work when the two 2x1 blocks > you can form have opposite colors as the 2 part. Notice how in that > example the blocks were opposite colors, making it easy to still spot > the CLL case, given that you know to convert the stickers on the > "wrong" corners to their opposite counterparts. > > I imagine this would be very difficult to do for two 2x1 blocks that > weren't opposite colors, but of course the strategy would work the > same way. > > Has anyone ever messed around with a strategy like this? Does it work > well? > > Chris
416. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: ELL, then CLL?
From: "James Stuber" <jestuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 02 May 2005 18:47:35 -0700

The Problem with ELL CLL is that CLL can't be recognized by the 4 stickers you would look at for CLL/ELL alone, you also have to take into account where in relation to the edges one of the corners is. _____ From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of mike_go_uk Sent: Monday, May 02, 2005 2:20 AM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: ELL, then CLL? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > Do you know whether his move averages are weighted averages? I.e. is > it the average over all 42 "distinct" configurations or over all Hi Stefan, Almost certain they are weighted, as the figures for "Fridrich" are the usual ones. Why do you need the unweighted? (Just nosy!) [Btw, I had looked into ELL+CLL because it would be the obvious way to cut my current 3-look LL to 2 looks; though PLL-then-OLL (ugh) would be possible instead. Either way it is too many new sequences to learn.] Mike _____ Yahoo! 419. airplane tickets
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 2 May 2005 21:13:58 -0700

Not cube related, but kind of cube related. What are good websites for
me to book a flight? I want to get from either Burbank, CA or LAX to
La Guardia... :-)

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology




420. Re: airplane tickets
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 03 May 2005 04:53:31 -0000

I usually fly united. they're usually one of the cheapest anyway. continental is pretty cheap, too. one thing i've done is use travelocity or expedia or cheaptickets, etc. and then gone to the website of whatever airline has the cheapest flight. sometimes, it is even cheaper if you get the ticket directly from the airline. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hey Everyone, > > Not cube related, but kind of cube related. What are good websites for > me to book a flight? I want to get from either Burbank, CA or LAX to > La Guardia... :-) > > is expedia.com any good? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology
421. Re: airplane tickets
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 03 May 2005 05:30:34 -0000

I agree with these tips--we usually check expedia or travelocity, then go directly to the airline's site. But you should also check some other airlines that are not in the databases of expedia etc. Jetblue, for example, flies out of both Long Beach and Burbank non- stop to NY [though they go to JFK, not La Guardia]. Compared to LAX, Long Beach is a dream to get through; coming from Caltech I don't think it's that much farther to Long Beach vs. LAX. Southwest is also not in those databases, but don't think they go non-stop to NY. Happy travels Kirk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > I usually fly united. they're usually one of the cheapest anyway. > continental is pretty cheap, too. one thing i've done is use > travelocity or expedia or cheaptickets, etc. and then gone to the > website of whatever airline has the cheapest flight. sometimes, it is > even cheaper if you get the ticket directly from the airline. > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > Hey Everyone, > > > > Not cube related, but kind of cube related. 422. Re: ELL, then CLL?
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 03 May 2005 09:18:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "James Stuber" <jestuber@v...> wrote: > The Problem with ELL CLL is that CLL can't be recognized by the 4 stickers > you would look at for CLL/ELL alone, you also have to take into account > where in relation to the edges one of the corners is. Too true -- the recognition problem is difficult. You'd certainly want to keep track of a couple of pieces during the preceding step. But a 2-look LL is not a realistic goal for me, anyway, regardless of the system: I would never be able to spend enough time practising it. Mike

426. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing Exercises
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 3 May 2005 19:39:41 +0100

Resuscitating an old thread I know but I recently started doing something new and my times and confidence have improved as a result. I have picked a typical solve and then repeated it over and over. For example the first one I picked I did a pretty slow 37 seconds the first time I solved it but as I learned the solve I got it down to 17 seconds (I'm pretty sure I can go faster). I didn't really do it as an exercise - I was just amazed by two things recently - one was Chris estimating a solve time if he turns at 3.5 moves a second and the other was that 11.52 video. I just didn't believe that I could turn the cube that smoothly and quickly even if I knew the solve. Now I know I can and also I know what it feels like to solve that quickly. I have found that in my normal solves I am looking ahead better and turning more accurately and quickly. I remember that someone suggested this some time ago as a way of working out how fast your method could be if you got really good at it. Anyway for those of us who think sub 20 seconds is a dream then I'd recommend trying it. Good luck Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "thewetdog" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, April 27, 2005 7:04 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing Exercises --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@y...> wrote: > I would practice on a very "unlubed" stiff cube... And once you try > a smooth/lubed cube after that, it seems as if it's magic... I use two cubes currently, one is really smooth as it is a few months old, and another is new and not as smooth. I can see that doing this suggestion could be advantageous, but sometimes I get used to turning harder on the less slick cube, so when I go back to the smooth cube I over shoot sometimes. I guess there is an adjustment period involved. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > . maybe it would help you to practice finger > tricks? When Dan Knight's website was still there he showed several > finger tricks and explained the Z-permutation as a combination of > finger tricks. I agree. I definitely need to master more finger tricks. It sounds like Dan Knight's page would have been ideal. However, since I have been interested in cubing the site has not existed. Does anyone have any data from the site, or can someone provide me with a site that has good VIDEO demonstrations for a variety of finger tricks? I have seen ASCII explanations on finger tricks (speedcubing.com comes to mind) but they are not as effective as having the ability to view the finger trick (at a reasonable speed). Better still, all the skilled cubists that record video of a fast solve or algorithms, how about taking the time to offer up some videos on finger tricks? Yahoo! Groups Links
427. [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing Exercises
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 03 May 2005 19:00:03 -0000

Hey Duncan, just to throw in my two cents, I think that is a really good cubing exercise to do, it especially helps show at which steps you tend to delay. I never got as fast as some of the others I saw who posted averages like that on here, but I remember getting 14-15 second averages by doing the same solve for each solve of the average :-) Also, in my defense I did mention that I think it would be possible to average really really fast with ZB at roughly 3.5 turns per second (which seems reasonable based on the level of cubers out there right now), but that implies possibly years of practice, or at least solves where your recognition is phenomenally fast. I don't forsee a non-lucky 10-11 second solve anywhere in my near future with ZB, though I hope to get there one day ;-) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > Resuscitating an old thread I know but I recently started doing something > new and my times and confidence have improved as a result. > I have picked a typical solve and then repeated it over and over. For > example the first one I picked I did a pretty slow 37 seconds the first time > I solved it but as I learned the solve I got it down to 17 seconds (I'm > pretty sure I can go faster). > > I didn't really do it as an exercise - I was just amazed by two things > recently - one was Chris estimating a solve time if he turns at 3.5 moves a > second and the other was that 11.52 video. I just didn't believe that I > could turn the cube that smoothly and quickly even if I knew the solve. Now > I know I can and also I know what it feels like to solve that quickly. > > I have found that in my normal solves I am looking ahead better and turning > more accurately and quickly. I remember that someone suggested this some > time ago as a way of working out how fast your method could be if you got > really good at it. > > Anyway for those of us who think sub 20 seconds is a dream then I'd > recommend trying it. > > Good luck > > Duncan
428. Re: [Speed cubing group] Using drugs/medication during competition.
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 3 May 2005 12:59:23 -0700

We have not written any rules about substance abuse and performance
enhancing drugs in speed cubing. If people start using steroids or
other narcotics, it would not be hard to write a rule.

Actually, I was thinking about this as well. Bug Selig, the
Commissioner of baseball here in the United States, wants to make
harsher penalties for steroid use in baseball. I hate steroids a lot
but what if there's a false positive? If there's a false positive and
someone gets 10 days, it's not so bad. But if it's a false positive
and they get 50 day suspension, that's kind of bad isn't it?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On May 3, 2005, at 8:20 AM, Joël van Noort wrote:

> Hey,
>
> I don't have any plans to do this, but I am just curious if there are
> any rules about using drungs/medication to help you relax and
> concentrate during competition... Does anyone know more about this?
>
> Joel.

429. Re: Using drugs/medication during competition.
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 03 May 2005 20:19:11 -0000

Hey! AFAIK there is no mention about this in the WCA rules. So in short it's allowed :-) This reminds me that using headphones was also discussed in the past. I can't recall if anything useful came out of that discussion :-) Using earplugs is certainly also possible. As long as u can hear the judge or read his body language ... hehe ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > Hey, > > I don't have any plans to do this, but I am just curious if there are > any rules about using drungs/medication to help you relax and > concentrate during competition... Does anyone know more about this? > > Joel.
430. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Using drugs/medication during competition.
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 3 May 2005 13:24:01 -0700

If you use ear plugs and you get disqualified because you don't hear the judge, then it's your fault. Same with head phones. The WCA naturally does not support the use of performance enhancing drugs and if it does become a problem, then we will deal with it as we can. Unfortunately, it would easily mean raising fees to cover the expense of testing. The way I see it now though, drug testing is silly and unnecessary. Perhaps in the future some drugs will actually help people in speed cubing but for now, I can only see it as a detriment. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On May 3, 2005, at 1:19 PM, Per Kristen Fredlund wrote: > Hey! > > AFAIK there is no mention about this in the WCA rules. So in short > it's allowed :-) This reminds me that using headphones was also > discussed in the past. I can't recall if anything useful came out of > that discussion :-) Using earplugs is certainly also possible. As > long as u can hear the judge or read his body language ... hehe ;-) > > Cheers! > > -Per > >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: >> Hey, >> >> I don't have any plans to do this, but I am just curious if there > are >> any rules about using drungs/medication to help you relax and >> concentrate during competition... Does anyone know more about this? >> >> Joel. > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >

Was just wondering if anyone is thinking of mixing the new black and white cubes together.

If someone were to do thi, would the mixed cube be allowed in a contest?

Just some thoughts I had as I am awaiting delivery of my white DIY kit.

432. Re: [Speed cubing group] Using drugs/medication during competition.
From: Gillian Buchanan <gmb@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 03 May 2005 23:02:41 +0100

ere in the United States, wants to make
> harsher penalties for steroid use in baseball. I hate steroids a lot
> but what if there's a false positive? If there's a false positive and
> someone gets 10 days, it's not so bad. But if it's a false positive
> and they get 50 day suspension

There's another aspect to using drugs. There are plenty of beneficial
medications which can affect performance, especially the medications
prescribed for mental health difficulties. I work as a medical
secretary in a community mental health team and there are lots of
different reasons there where someone might be on medication which could
affect their cubing performance.

Also there are steroidal medications which could give a false positive
and which are prescribed for a good medical reason - I have severe ear
problems and have in the past been prescribed aural steroidal
medications when antibiotics would not work - and it would be necessary
to ask people if they were on any medication and what it was if you were
going to make that sort of rule. Then you would have the implications
around issues of confidentiality. Bearing in mind recent changes in US
law around confidentiality I think you would have to be very careful. I
am in the UK and don't know exactly what these changes are myself for
that reason, but you would need to seek advice.

Gillian
--
Gillian Buchanan
Tatting Editor at Bella Online
http://www.bellaonline.com/site/tatting
http://www.craftsnlace.net

Seriously everyone, don't take drugs for cubing. I will personally
come smack you if you cheat in any way.

Tyson Mao

California Institute of Technology

435. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Using drugs/medication during competition.
From: François Sechet <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 4 May 2005 00:20:23 +0200 (CEST)

just throwing in my thoughts on the ear plugs debate... I did use ear plugs during the French Champs to help me relax, twice during the 1st roud, it didn't pay, because i did a wonderful 22.22 and a great 28.xx on these solves (yeah i know, shut up everyone) and at least 3 times during the 2nd and final round. It did help me then: 15.54 on the first solve, then I forgot my discman during the next 2 solves (3 solves actually, I poped one inbetween) and got a 17 and an 18 on the last 2 solves w/ headphones. I don't think i missed something the judge said, the music wasn't too loud anyway. Shostakovich, preludes and fugues op.87 :-P. There was even a bit of me focusing with the headphones on French TV lol... something like, eh, see how much stress there is in a speedcubing event lol. F. --- Tyson Mao <tmao@...> a ï¿½crit: --------------------------------- If you use ear plugs and you get disqualified because you don't hear the judge, then it's your fault. Same with head phones. The WCA naturally does not support the use of performance enhancing drugs and if it does become a problem, then we will deal with it as we can. Unfortunately, it would easily mean raising fees to cover the expense of testing. The way I see it now though, drug testing is silly and unnecessary. Perhaps in the future some drugs will actually help people in speed cubing but for now, I can only see it as a detriment. 437. [Speed cubing group] Re: Using drugs/medication during competition.
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 May 2005 03:43:59 -0000

The only drugs that would probably help, might be some stimulants, or the kind of you would find in herbal teas. I can't really see how steroids would be an issue, or that they would provide an advantage anyway. It'd be like using steroids to win a chess match. Most of the top cubers are limited not by twisting speed, but by how well you can follow the state of teh cube. Robin Williams Live on Broadway, "They took away his olympic medal from the candian skier, because he tested positive for Marijuana, which is kind of redundant anyway. They called it a performance enhancing drug. Now, marijuana enhances many things, feelings, colors, sensations, but you're certainly not f***ing empowered. Not unless there's a huge f***ing hershey bar at the end of the run" --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > If you use ear plugs and you get disqualified because you don't hear > the judge, then it's your fault. 440. JNetCube larger puzzle scramble fix
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 May 2005 05:09:42 -0000

Chris found a bug in JNetCube where the first three moves of either a
4x4x4 or 5x5x5 scramble may have two moves that *cancel* each other
out, effectively making the scramble one move shorter then it should
be. It turns out I had an 'AND' where there should have been an 'OR'.
An honest mistake. :)

So anyone who uses 4x4x4 or 5x5x5 scrambles from JNetCube should
download the latest version from:

http://www.plu.edu/~huntca

-Chris




441. Re: world championships 2005
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 May 2005 05:14:49 -0000

It is to help the organizers get an idea of how many people are coming and what they are interested in. Is this correct? Registration is still required in Florida, so I would assume the webpage-registration is for informational perposes only. -Chris

443. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: world championships 2005
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 4 May 2005 07:42:49 +0200 (CEST)

Hi friends, Yes, registration is still required in Florida, but that is to know that you are there, check the events that you want to compete in and receive your badge and goodie. You really have to register before the championship! Depending on the number of registrations we may need to close registration for some events. Of course we won't send you home if you come from far without registering. :-) We do expect many competitors, so without preregistration we cannot make a good time schedule. It is going to be fun!!!! Don't miss it! >From Amsterdam I found tickets to Orlando for 300 euro. Hotel rooms for $69 is pretty cheap, and you can share hotel rooms (probably 3 people per room). You can use this forum to find people to share a room with. :-) Have fun, Ron > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "h4m573r1" > <h4m573r1@y...> wrote: >> Along with Evan's question, I'd like to add that I noticed on >> Rubiks.com's registration page, you needed to be a club member to >> register for WC 2005. 445. Re: [Speed cubing group] Black and White cubes mixed
From: _jaap <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 May 2005 09:48:18 -0000

I wouldn't see anything wrong with a hybrid white/black cube in a competition either, provided that all the corners had the same colour plastic, and all the edges the same colour. Otherwise you could get an advantage if you made for example all F2L pairs white and the rest black. Jaap --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > I think it should be fine. I would approve such a cube if it were at > my tournament. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On May 3, 2005, at 2:22 PM, Peter Douthwright wrote: > > > Was just wondering if anyone is thinking of mixing the new black and > > white cubes together. > > > > If someone were to do thi, would the mixed cube be allowed in a > > contest? > > > > Just some thoughts I had as I am awaiting delivery of my white DIY kit. > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
446. black and white cube mix
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 4 May 2005 03:20:56 -0700

Hey Peter,

It has been brought to my attention that a black and white cube mix
would provide an unfair advantage to the solver because you would have
an advantage of recognizing certain pieces. Therefore, the plastic of
your cubes needs to all be the same color.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology




447. Re: [Speed cubing group] Black and White cubes mixed
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 4 May 2005 03:28:28 -0700

Yeah sorry, I over looked that fact. I think it is reasonable that we mandate that the plastic color is all the same for the puzzles. Nico




451. New Speedcube Timer
From: "one_eyed_blindcat" <dhwebb@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 May 2005 14:29:00 -0000

I had written this timer about a month ago for my personal timer.
About a week ago Leyan in the blindsolving group asked about a timer
that would keep up with the stages of his blindfold solves. I
volunteered to take that up. This version doesn't include that yet
but is in the works. The current version generates shuffles for 2x2x2
through the 5x5x5. It stores all data in an access database. I have
generated a few reports that will give you some statistical data. The
file is slightly large, 8 Meg, due to the use of Crystal Reports for
statistical data. It can be be found at my site at
www.rubikspuzzles.com. It will be listed on the right under the Files
heading.

Also, don't laugh at my slow solve videos. I'm old and not a super
speedcuber like a lot of you.

453. [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing Exercises
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 May 2005 20:05:28 -0000

Duncan, thank you very much for the input, though, is seven days
really "resuscitating" and old thread? I think this idea sounds
like an excellent exercise. You sound like you are at a similar
progress point as I. I, too, am amazed by the speed at which others
solve the cube and doubt my ability to ever achieve the same level
of skill.

I understand that getting sub 20 does not occur overnight. I just
get anxious and want to be competitive with everyone that frequents
this community; perhaps it is an inferiority complex. I will
definitely try this suggestion out on the weekend, if not before. I
will let you know if I experience the same type of results, but
solving it in 17 seconds seems improbable, even if it is the same
scramble.

So thank you Duncan (and Chris for the confirmation of the idea),
and thank you to everyone else that provides me with the inspiration
to become a faster cuber, and for letting me know I am not the only
hooked on the cube.

-Dave





454. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing Exercises
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 4 May 2005 15:34:41 -0500

Hi there. Using a layer approach with a 4 look last layer, I managed a pair of 30 second solves to start with. It wasn't particularly easy, but I employed a trick I know to permute and orient the corners at the same time. I average a tad under 30 like this, so I wasn't too impressed with how I solved it. My third time was a 24. Not bad, I thought. By the time I'd finished an average with that scramble, I'd managed a solve under 17. I kept going like this for a while, enjoying seeing 1X.XX on the timer. Eventually I got curious and solved a new scramble. I got my personal fastest time of 21.16. If I could reach, Duncan, I'd give you a hug. I'll check back in after some more of this practicing. -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: thewetdog<mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, May 04, 2005 3:05 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing Exercises Duncan, thank you very much for the input, though, is seven days really "resuscitating" and old thread? I think this idea sounds like an excellent exercise. You sound like you are at a similar progress point as I. I, too, am amazed by the speed at which others solve the cube and doubt my ability to ever achieve the same level of skill. I understand that getting sub 20 does not occur overnight. I just get anxious and want to be competitive with everyone that frequents this community; perhaps it is an inferiority complex. I will definitely try this suggestion out on the weekend, if not before. I will let you know if I experience the same type of results, but solving it in 17 seconds seems improbable, even if it is the same scramble. So thank you Duncan (and Chris for the confirmation of the idea), and thank you to everyone else that provides me with the inspiration to become a faster cuber, and for letting me know I am not the only hooked on the cube. -Dave ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Yahoo! 458. Re: [Speed cubing group] Black and White cubes mixed
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 4 May 2005 21:38:03 -0500

The way I see it, people do this already. If you have stickers that have worn, you can tell where they are by feeling. If you have tiles on your cube, you're already guilty. They overlap the sides to the point you can see around the edges of pieces. If you're going to disqualify cubes with mixed pieces, it's unfair to allow cubes with anything other than perfect stickers and uniformly tensioned sides, and that seems unnecessary. The last time I checked, WCA rules stipulated something about no modifications to the basic shape or mechanism of the puzzle, but nothing was mentioned of the pieces' colors. I think mixed should be allowed. It would lead to an advantage, possibly, but so does learning COLL for those who are crazy enough =). Just my two cents. -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: Peter Douthwright<mailto:pdouthwright0513@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, May 04, 2005 8:36 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Black and White cubes mixed This is what I thought. But Does not everyone have this same chance to do this. So if I can do this, why not everyone. no real advantage. But I am just asking. I am actually thinking of doing this just to learn f2l. ----- Original Message ----- From: Tyson Mao To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, May 04, 2005 6:28 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Black and White cubes mixed Yeah sorry, I over looked that fact. I think it is reasonable that we mandate that the plastic color is all the same for the puzzles. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On May 4, 2005, at 2:48 AM, _jaap wrote: > > I wouldn't see anything wrong with a hybrid white/black cube in a > competition either, provided that all the corners had the same colour > plastic, and all the edges the same colour. Otherwise you could get > an advantage if you made for example all F2L pairs white and the rest > black. > Jaap > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: >> I think it should be fine. I would approve such a cube if it were > at >> my tournament. >> >> Tyson Mao >> MSC #631 >> California Institute of Technology [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
459. Re: [Speed cubing group] Black and White cubes mixed
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 05 May 2005 02:46:09 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > The way I see it, people do this already. If you have stickers that have worn, you can tell where they are by feeling. Not if you're speedsolving I'd claim ;-) > If you have tiles on your cube, you're already guilty. Hmm, "guilty" makes it sound illegal. Note the WCA rules explicitly allow tiles. Cheers! Stefan

461. Re: [Speed cubing group] Black and White cubes mixed
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 4 May 2005 22:35:36 -0500

> Hmm, "guilty" makes it sound illegal. Note the WCA rules explicitly allow tiles. =) My point was that if those are allowed, and they allow ease of identification by seeing around edges of pieces, it doesn't follow logically to disallow mixed color cubes. That's like outlawing OLL+PLL for allowing fewer steps, but allowing ELL+CLL. Non-sequiturs make my brain hurt. > Not if you're speedsolving I'd claim ;-) And my orange stickers were so worn at one point that I could instantly tell when I was touching one, which was handy for cases when the piece was on the back side and I needed to see which way it was oriented. It's not a big difference, but neither would mixed cubes be. -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: Stefan Pochmann<mailto:pochmann@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, May 04, 2005 9:46 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Black and White cubes mixed --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h<mailto:mikebennett_one@h>...> wrote: > > The way I see it, people do this already. If you have stickers that have worn, you can tell where they are by feeling. Not if you're speedsolving I'd claim ;-) > If you have tiles on your cube, you're already guilty. Hmm, "guilty" makes it sound illegal. Note the WCA rules explicitly allow tiles. Cheers! Stefan ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Yahoo! Groups Links a.. 466. Re: black and white cube mix
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 05 May 2005 21:23:44 -0000

Hi Tyson, I think you over-reacted, changing your mind so quickly. Four reasons: 1.) I have been thinking that a cube with black centers and corners and white edges, and vice versa, would look really cool. It wouldn't give an advantage either. 2.) I also thought of having all the LL cubies white, because it would look cool. I have no problem recognising LL positions and the white wouldn't be an advantage to me, but if it enabled other cubers to recognise positions with ease I would have no problem with that. 3.) I thought of having certain specific cubies white and the rest of the cube black. That might give enable me to see some F2L things better, but not be an advantage over others because others don't solve the F2L like I do. :) 4.) Eventually we all may have cubes tailored to our tastes with no stickers or tiles but the plastic itself colored. (I am suggesting here a new line for Rubik's.com to pursue.) Anyway, please reconsider, if only for one of the reasons stated. Thanks, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hey Peter, > > It has been brought to my attention that a black and white cube mix > would provide an unfair advantage to the solver because you would have > an advantage of recognizing certain pieces. Therefore, the plastic of > your cubes needs to all be the same color. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology I think it should be fine. I would approve such a cube if it were at my tournament. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On May 3, 2005, at 2:22 PM, Peter Douthwright wrote: > Was just wondering if anyone is thinking of mixing the new black and > white cubes together. > > If someone were to do thi, would the mixed cube be allowed in a > contest? > > Just some thoughts I had as I am awaiting delivery of my white DIY kit.

468. Re: New Speedcube Timer
From: "one_eyed_blindcat" <dhwebb@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 05 May 2005 23:53:13 -0000

> G'day, I haven't ported on here since I signed up but anyway..
> I tried download your timer but it didn't work, all I've managed to
> do is save the page that comes up when I clicked on the link for it.
> What do I do next?

I just posted the MSI which is a windows installer file. You should
have windows installer already but if not goto
http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?displaylang=en&FamilyID=CEBBACD8-C094-4255-B702-DE3BB768148F
and download it there. It's for 95-ME. 2000 and XP should have
everything you need included.

If you still have issues, I will look into making a setup.exe instead.




469. Re: New Speedcube Timer
From: "one_eyed_blindcat" <dhwebb@...>

Date: Thu, 05 May 2005 23:54:50 -0000

No problem, will do. Scramble makes more sense. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joï¿½l van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > Hey, man! I really like your timer so far! It works fine... > > Just two things: Maybe it's a better idea to call the 'shuffle' > a 'scramble', since this is the term most of us use. Second, I would > like to request a feature: maybe it would be nice to have an: 'add > time' button, so I can use it in combination with my stackmat. Or > maybe even a "countdown+add time" option, because my stackmat won't do > the countdown for me :). > > Tnx a lot, > > Joel.
470. Re: black and white cube mix
From: "Ben Marx" <godsalgorithm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 05 May 2005 23:57:52 -0000

I do think mixed cubes would give some people an advantage. One of my
methods I use the "first layer minus working corner method" for F2L,
and I know that making all the first layer cubies white, or the
middle layer edges white, would definitely give me an advantage for
recognition.

As far as everyone being open to the same advantage I guess that
true. But it's still a little unfair. Not everyone has access to the
internet to get the white cubes, or is old enough to buy something
online without help from a parent, or whatever.

As far as feeling damaged stickers go, that's harder to control, but
has always been a part of tournaments. The white-cubie thing is new.
And there's no reason to nip the problem in the bud right away. And
besides don't tournaments often provide new stickers to resticker
your cube if you want to?

But aside from all that I think there's a more important reason to
not allow mixed cubes.

It changes solving the cube on a small but fundamental level.

As the cubies exist now, they're black with colored stickers.
Recognition is done by the sticker color alone. Adding certain cubies
with different colors now makes two types of cubie recognition. A
small, but I think significant, differance in the existing cube-
solving process. The line has to be drawn SOMEWHERE. It might as well
be here, while it's still an easy line to be drawn.

473. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: black and white cube mix
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 6 May 2005 08:27:01 +0200

Hi friends, I think article 3 of the WCA regulations (see http://www.speedcubing.com/events ) prohibits this. "No modifications are allowed that enhance the basic concept of the puzzle. Puzzles may not have any textures or markings that distinguish one piece from another." And I think it is a good thing, that it is not allowed. You could have a 5 color cube, where each corner edge pair has different color of the two pieces. It is also not allowed to have small stickers at the edge of each piece, to see what color is on the other side of that piece. Our goal is to have fun in tournaments, and to make sure the best cuber in competition conditions wins. Our goal is not to go faster by changing rules in our favor. Apart from the rules, I think if we would be on tv, people would consider us cheating. They expect to see normal cubes. I am purist. And proud of it. Normal cubes rule! Have fun, Ron ----- Original Message ----- From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Thursday, May 05, 2005 11:23 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: black and white cube mix > Hi Tyson, > > I think you over-reacted, changing your mind so quickly. Four reasons: > > 1.) I have been thinking that a cube with black centers and corners > and white edges, and vice versa, would look really cool. It wouldn't > give an advantage either. > > 2.) I also thought of having all the LL cubies white, because it would > look cool. I have no problem recognising LL positions and the white > wouldn't be an advantage to me, but if it enabled other cubers to > recognise positions with ease I would have no problem with that. > > 3.) I thought of having certain specific cubies white and the rest of > the cube black. That might give enable me to see some F2L things > better, but not be an advantage over others because others don't solve > the F2L like I do. :) > > 4.) Eventually we all may have cubes tailored to our tastes with no > stickers or tiles but the plastic itself colored. (I am suggesting > here a new line for Rubik's.com to pursue.) > > Anyway, please reconsider, if only for one of the reasons stated. > > Thanks, > > David J > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: >> Hey Peter, >> >> It has been brought to my attention that a black and white cube mix >> would provide an unfair advantage to the solver because you would have >> an advantage of recognizing certain pieces. Therefore, the plastic of >> your cubes needs to all be the same color. >> >> Tyson Mao >> MSC #631 >> California Institute of Technology > > I think it should be fine. I would approve such a cube if it were at > my tournament. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On May 3, 2005, at 2:22 PM, Peter Douthwright wrote: > >> Was just wondering if anyone is thinking of mixing the new black and >> white cubes together. >> >> If someone were to do thi, would the mixed cube be allowed in a >> contest? >> >> Just some thoughts I had as I am awaiting delivery of my white DIY kit. > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > >
474. Re: black and white cube mix
From: "Mikael" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 06 May 2005 08:00:53 -0000

Hello!

I´ve been following this thread from the start and there have been
good arguments both ways.

I agree that a cube with different color cubies would make recognition
easier, but on the other hand a two color-cubie cube (that sounded fun
=D) would look cool.

So why not make yourself this modified cube to have as a cool new toy
and use it for practice. With time recognition would become so natural
that the different colored cubies wouldn´t be needed anymore.

As Ron already stated the rules, if read carefully, already prohibit
the use of such a cube in competition. This is the way I think it
should be in the future also. After all the competition is much more
than just fast times. What is more important is to meet fellow cubers
and have fun.

Keep cubing,
Mikael

476. Re: black and white cube mix
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 06 May 2005 12:38:34 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ben Marx" <godsalgorithm@g...> wrote: > > As far as everyone being open to the same advantage I guess that > true. But it's still a little unfair. Not everyone has access to the > internet to get the white cubes, or is old enough to buy something > online without help from a parent, or whatever. Don't forget blind people or people with less than two hands or babies or those elderly who can't even hold a cube at all yet/anymore. Speedcubing in general is so unfair to these people. We should have rules that allow them to win tournaments, too. For a bonus, I want rules that allow them to beat Macky, Lars and Edouard. Please let's seriously do this. Stefan
477. Re: black and white cube mix
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 06 May 2005 12:48:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mikael" <stobe_98@h... > wrote: > > So why not make yourself this modified cube to have as a cool new toy > and use it for practice. With time recognition would become so natural > that the different colored cubies wouldn´t be needed anymore. I'd rather suggest not to. I think it will actually be bad for you. When you learn to rely on this aid and in competition it's not there, that'll hurt you. The environment for learning/practicing should optimally be the same as the one where it matters. Makes sense intuitively and psychology research supports it, too (for example the scuba diver experiment of Godden and Baddeley). Cheers! Stefan

479. Re: David Allen Method?
From: "Wayne" <mylib_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 06 May 2005 13:41:29 -0000

I wish there was a website about this method but I haven't heard of one. I have seen a video of Dave Allen and Gene Means(same method) solving at the Toronto WC. They appear to place all corners first and then solve left and right edges in pairs. They apparently have a very efficient way of solving the edges to be able to manage sub-20 times. I can avg 22-23 by using a similar method except I solve top and bottom edges instead of left and right. Wayne --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "darereck" <darereck@g...> wrote: > Is anyone here familar with David Allen's method? Is there a website > that has information about it?
480. Rubik's Cube Essay
From: "Evan" <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 06 May 2005 13:46:23 -0000

So I just applied for what is called highschool summer college at
stanford. It needs this entire application with an essay and all
that fun stuff. The essay prompt was "Tell us about a significant
event in your life. How did this event change you, or make you view
your life in a different light?" Of course, I wrote an essay about
the Rubik's cube. So here it is for anyone who would like to read.


Life Lessons^3
The following began on the night of November 19th 2003. I
was at my grandmother's house for my cousin's 17th birthday. The
atmosphere was cheery; the room was loud, as it often is when the
whole family is together. Getting distracted from the event at
hand, I decided to take part in a little sibling rivalry. My
brother and I took turns on my grandmother's stationary bike,
watching the RPM, seeing who could go faster. When we got to the
hands only category (as the bike had moving handlebars which could
be used in place of the pedals) my brother pushed and pulled his way
to 73 RPM. Then it was my turn. I hopped on and started up. As my
arms pumped like pistons, the RPM meter rose. The speed shot up to
20, 30, 40, 50 RPM and continued to rise up past 60, 70, 80 RPM. At
93 RPM, disaster struck. Due to the torque of my upper body as I
fought with the handles, my bare right foot slipped, and fell into
the path of the pedal. The pedal struck my heel and violently
jammed my toes into the foot peg.
A trip to the emergency room revealed a broken foot, and
broken hopes of playing football any more that season. To the
untrained observer, this event may seem to be an act of stupidity
followed by the deserved punishment. But in actuality this event
started me on my most intriguing journey to date.
A day or two later, while surfing the web and chatting with
friends, I came across a video of someone not only solving the
Rubik's cube, but doing so in under 20 seconds. I have a profound
interest in mathematics and computer science, so the idea of the
world's greatest puzzle intrigued me, and I followed up by getting a
Rubik's cube of my own. Sadly, I followed the path of most first
time cubists, and got fed up with the cube after a couple of days.
After a quick search on Google, I found a couple simple and a couple
not-so-simple solutions to the Rubik's cube online. I added the
sites to my favorites, and then went to sleep for the night.
The next day was a school football game. Because I was
confined to the bench for the rest of the season, I brought my cube
along for the twelve hour journey. During this time I began to
understand the basics of the Rubik's cube. I became highly
proficient at following the directions on how to solve the cube.
After a day or two more, I was solving the cube without the aid of
an instruction sheet, taking about three minutes to do so. The
addiction had begun.
From that day until the present I have been on a never
ending quest for speed, learning more algorithms (sets of moves
which produce a desired effect on the Rubik's cube) and different
solutions, working my way up. I have attended several official
Rubik's cube competitions, including the 2004 US national
championships, in which I placed 15th out of the 47 cubists who
attended. Currently my personal best time is 17.63 seconds.
Now as if one time and life consuming hobby isn't enough
fun, try combining it with another. This was the basic theory
behind my 2004 science project. I'm fanatical about the Rubik's
cube, passionate about programming, and fervent about robotics. So
what type of diabolical scheme can you come up with that combines
all three? That's right, the world's fastest Rubik's cube solving
robot. My inspiration came from another video I had recently seen.
Originally, I was planning on building a robot with the same basic
design as in the video, but I wasn't content with the speed, or lack
thereof, at which this design solved the Rubik's cube; I didn't want
to be able to beat my own robot. So I went about designing
something radically different and ended up with an 18 inch Plexiglas
cube that looks like something out of Star Trek. The robot
controlled my life for about two months, over the course of which I
wrote the code for it, built it, and tuned it into a lean mean cube
solving machine. It can now beat the current world record holder
and averages only 11.46 seconds per solve. The robot took me to the
California State Science Fair, and is unofficially the fastest cube
solving robot in the world, as there has not yet been an official
event for robots.
In the end, I was able to turn a negative experience into a
positive one. I set a goal for myself, pursued it, and enjoyed the
journey as well as the destination. Although I have not become the
fastest in the world, my robot has, and I can solve the Rubik's cube
more quickly than I ever thought possible. Parents always preach
persistence, hard work, dedication, and never using gym equipment
without shoes. But until you experience the reward, until you
understand the satisfaction that comes with the long hard hours of
determination, you cannot truly appreciate these lessons. That is
what this experience did for me. I now know how to go about solving
a problem. I now understand what it feels like to take on something
of this magnitude. And furthermore, I know how it feels to
accomplish a daunting task, and it is that feeling that drives me.





481. Re: black and white cube mix
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 06 May 2005 14:05:39 -0000

It could be that u are ironic ;-) Handicapped tournaments for ppl who can cube normally are easy to set up. One can compare times achieved with that persons normal (best) average and work out according to some simple mathematical formula. I know that dutch cubers have practised with those kinda friendly tournaments :-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ben Marx" > <godsalgorithm@g...> wrote: > > > > As far as everyone being open to the same advantage I guess that > > true. 489. Re: Rubik's Cube Essay
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 06 May 2005 17:27:52 -0000

Uh, yeah, I'd say you're in. great essay. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Evan" <evan.gates@g...> wrote: > So I just applied for what is called highschool summer college at > stanford. It needs this entire application with an essay and all > that fun stuff. The essay prompt was "Tell us about a significant > event in your life. So here it is for anyone who would like to read. > > > Life Lessons^3 > The following began on the night of November 19th 2003. I > was at my grandmother's house for my cousin's 17th birthday. The > atmosphere was cheery; the room was loud, as it often is when the > whole family is together. Getting distracted from the event at > hand, I decided to take part in a little sibling rivalry. My > brother and I took turns on my grandmother's stationary bike, > watching the RPM, seeing who could go faster. When we got to the > hands only category (as the bike had moving handlebars which could > be used in place of the pedals) my brother pushed and pulled his way > to 73 RPM. Then it was my turn. I hopped on and started up. As my > arms pumped like pistons, the RPM meter rose. The speed shot up to > 20, 30, 40, 50 RPM and continued to rise up past 60, 70, 80 RPM. At > 93 RPM, disaster struck. Due to the torque of my upper body as I > fought with the handles, my bare right foot slipped, and fell into > the path of the pedal. The pedal struck my heel and violently > jammed my toes into the foot peg. > A trip to the emergency room revealed a broken foot, and > broken hopes of playing football any more that season. To the > untrained observer, this event may seem to be an act of stupidity > followed by the deserved punishment. But in actuality this event > started me on my most intriguing journey to date. > A day or two later, while surfing the web and chatting with > friends, I came across a video of someone not only solving the > Rubik's cube, but doing so in under 20 seconds. I have a profound > interest in mathematics and computer science, so the idea of the > world's greatest puzzle intrigued me, and I followed up by getting a > Rubik's cube of my own. Sadly, I followed the path of most first > time cubists, and got fed up with the cube after a couple of days. > After a quick search on Google, I found a couple simple and a couple > not-so-simple solutions to the Rubik's cube online. I added the > sites to my favorites, and then went to sleep for the night. > The next day was a school football game. Because I was > confined to the bench for the rest of the season, I brought my cube > along for the twelve hour journey. During this time I began to > understand the basics of the Rubik's cube. I became highly > proficient at following the directions on how to solve the cube. > After a day or two more, I was solving the cube without the aid of > an instruction sheet, taking about three minutes to do so. The > addiction had begun. > From that day until the present I have been on a never > ending quest for speed, learning more algorithms (sets of moves > which produce a desired effect on the Rubik's cube) and different > solutions, working my way up. I have attended several official > Rubik's cube competitions, including the 2004 US national > championships, in which I placed 15th out of the 47 cubists who > attended. Currently my personal best time is 17.63 seconds. > Now as if one time and life consuming hobby isn't enough > fun, try combining it with another. This was the basic theory > behind my 2004 science project. I'm fanatical about the Rubik's > cube, passionate about programming, and fervent about robotics. So > what type of diabolical scheme can you come up with that combines > all three? That's right, the world's fastest Rubik's cube solving > robot. My inspiration came from another video I had recently seen. > Originally, I was planning on building a robot with the same basic > design as in the video, but I wasn't content with the speed, or lack > thereof, at which this design solved the Rubik's cube; I didn't want > to be able to beat my own robot. So I went about designing > something radically different and ended up with an 18 inch Plexiglas > cube that looks like something out of Star Trek. The robot > controlled my life for about two months, over the course of which I > wrote the code for it, built it, and tuned it into a lean mean cube > solving machine. It can now beat the current world record holder > and averages only 11.46 seconds per solve. The robot took me to the > California State Science Fair, and is unofficially the fastest cube > solving robot in the world, as there has not yet been an official > event for robots. > In the end, I was able to turn a negative experience into a > positive one. I set a goal for myself, pursued it, and enjoyed the > journey as well as the destination. Although I have not become the > fastest in the world, my robot has, and I can solve the Rubik's cube > more quickly than I ever thought possible. Parents always preach > persistence, hard work, dedication, and never using gym equipment > without shoes. But until you experience the reward, until you > understand the satisfaction that comes with the long hard hours of > determination, you cannot truly appreciate these lessons. That is > what this experience did for me. I now know how to go about solving > a problem. I now understand what it feels like to take on something > of this magnitude. And furthermore, I know how it feels to > accomplish a daunting task, and it is that feeling that drives me.

491. [Speed cubing group] Re: New Speedcube Timer
From: "one_eyed_blindcat" <dhwebb@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 06 May 2005 18:24:35 -0000

Only problem with it is the grid control control I had to purchase and had a license key which means nobody else could compile without the same control. I might convert that the the microsoft data grid though so that won't be an issue. Other problem is I have written most of it on the fly and the source needs to be cleaned up a lot before I could post it. Also, to the guy wondering about the best of 12, you have to do all 12 solves in a single session. Also, thanks for the compliments. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "alejandro_lamas" <alejandro_lamas@y...> wrote: > something like an > > open source timer! > > That would be a great idea!!! > > Maybe a SourceForge project. > > Thanks > Jan
492. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4, 5x5x5 patterns?
From: a_ooms75 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 06 May 2005 20:02:17 -0000

This is what i came up with: 1. (U2 R2 D2) *2 2. (U2 R2 D2) *2 F2 B2 = 4 O's 3. (U2 (Rr)2 D2) *2 = 2/3 1/4 lines? 4. ((Uu)2 (Rr)2 (Dd)2) *2 = 4 lines 5. 3 + 4 = 4 one lines 6. (u2 d2 b2 f2 r2) *2 (u2 d2 b2) *2 = 4 dots 7. M2 S2 E2 = kinda + sign 8. l2 r2 u2 d2 b2 f2 = schakerboard 9. 6 + 7 = sqaure with dot 10. 6 + 8 = # signs maybe this kinda standard stuff but its something :) greets Alexander --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hi Michael! > > There's a few sticker-swapping "patterns" at Stefan Pochmann's site. > > (http://www.stefan- > pochmann.de/spocc/other_stuff/4x4_5x5_algs/#ColorSchemeModifiers) > > And of course any 3x3x3 pattern will carry over to 4x4x4 and larger > cubes n^3. Some do carry over with natural extensions like "cube- in- > cube". U can make "cube-in-cube-in-cube-.....-in-cube" and so on. Like > wise with spot patterns u can make new spots inside the "3x3x3 kind > spots". > > Could u pls post ur pattern collection or give us a link to a webpage? > I'd be very interested in finding shorter solution for ur terribly > long sequence pattern. Im sure some algorithm with reasonable length > can be worked out somehow (using commutators or whatever to move the > various parts around without having to resort to the normal pairing-up > 3x3x3 approach.) > > Have a look at this really simple pattern that i posted before > sometime : > > (on a 5x5x5 is nicest) r l f b r' l' f' b' > > Quite neat, right? > > Cheers! > > -Per K > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Michael Zener Riggs > Gottlieb <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > There aren't really any good sites for patterns on higher-order > cubes, unfortunately. I have a personal database of a few cool 5x5x5 > ones, although you guys can't use them because they use my notation > (where f = turn two front layers). One of them for the 5x5x5 is 214 > moves or so and I can't figure out how to get it better. I could, of > course, solve it and get about 170 moves... How many moves do you guys > usually take, excluding the 3x3x3 step if there is one? And do you > have any ideas for patterns? > > > > --MZRG > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
493. [Speed cubing group] Re: black and white cube mix
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 06 May 2005 20:03:03 -0000

Hi Ron, The black plastic DIY cubes have arched centers and don't pop and are adjustable. The white plastic cubes have slicker plastic and look cool, however they have flat centers and pop a lot. So if I want an adjustable white cube that doesn't pop I *have* to have a black plastic center piece. I was displeased that the white DIY cubes I got were from the older model. I complained but no response. So I sent off for 2 black DIY kits so I could have arched centers on the whte cubes, and have good fast white cube which doesn't pop... ...and now you and Tyson tell me that cube is illegal. Thanks, but no thanks. Of course if a certain company made white plastic arched centers there'd be no problem. But that's not very likely seeing that I got *no* positive response to my complaint. David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > Hi friends, > > I think article 3 of the WCA regulations (see > http://www.speedcubing.com/events ) prohibits this. > "No modifications are allowed that enhance the basic concept of the puzzle. > Puzzles may not have any textures or markings that distinguish one piece > from another." > And I think it is a good thing, that it is not allowed. > You could have a 5 color cube, where each corner edge pair has different > color of the two pieces. > It is also not allowed to have small stickers at the edge of each piece, to > see what color is on the other side of that piece. > > Our goal is to have fun in tournaments, and to make sure the best cuber in > competition conditions wins. > Our goal is not to go faster by changing rules in our favor. > > Apart from the rules, I think if we would be on tv, people would consider us > cheating. They expect to see normal cubes. > > I am purist. And proud of it. > Normal cubes rule! > > Have fun, > > Ron > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Thursday, May 05, 2005 11:23 PM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: black and white cube mix > > > > Hi Tyson, > > > > I think you over-reacted, changing your mind so quickly. Four reasons: > > > > 1.) I have been thinking that a cube with black centers and corners > > and white edges, and vice versa, would look really cool. It wouldn't > > give an advantage either. > > > > 2.) I also thought of having all the LL cubies white, because it would > > look cool. I have no problem recognising LL positions and the white > > wouldn't be an advantage to me, but if it enabled other cubers to > > recognise positions with ease I would have no problem with that. > > > > 3.) I thought of having certain specific cubies white and the rest of > > the cube black. That might give enable me to see some F2L things > > better, but not be an advantage over others because others don't solve > > the F2L like I do. :) > > > > 4.) Eventually we all may have cubes tailored to our tastes with no > > stickers or tiles but the plastic itself colored. (I am suggesting > > here a new line for Rubik's.com to pursue.) > > > > Anyway, please reconsider, if only for one of the reasons stated. > > > > Thanks, > > > > David J [snip]
494. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: black and white cube mix
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 6 May 2005 13:20:30 -0700

I don't think you should be so quick to blame the cube. There are two factors that go into popping. The first is, yes, the cube. Certain cubes pop more easily than others. However, the second factor is the cuber. If you're accurate with your turns, then you can turn it as hard as you want and you won't pop. This principle is illustrated when I was cubing in front of Macky and jamming on a bunch of turns. Macky turns to me, says, "You need to work on your accuracy," grabs my cube, and then proceeds to make a billion turns on the cube smoothly without jamming at all. If the purpose of the white plastic cube is just to look cube and it has a negative impact on your cubing performance, why don't you just go with a black cube? Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On May 6, 2005, at 1:03 PM, d_j_salvia wrote: > Hi Ron, > > The black plastic DIY cubes have arched centers and don't pop and > are adjustable. The white plastic cubes have slicker plastic and look > cool, however they have flat centers and pop a lot. So if I want an > adjustable white cube that doesn't pop I *have* to have a black > plastic center piece. > > I was displeased that the white DIY cubes I got were from the older > model. I complained but no response. So I sent off for 2 black DIY > kits so I could have arched centers on the whte cubes, and have good > fast white cube which doesn't pop... > > ...and now you and Tyson tell me that cube is illegal. > > Thanks, but no thanks. > > Of course if a certain company made white plastic arched centers > there'd be no problem. But that's not very likely seeing that I got > *no* positive response to my complaint. > > David J > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" > <ron@s...> wrote: >> Hi friends, >> >> I think article 3 of the WCA regulations (see >> http://www.speedcubing.com/events ) prohibits this. >> "No modifications are allowed that enhance the basic concept of the > puzzle. >> Puzzles may not have any textures or markings that distinguish one > piece >> from another." >> And I think it is a good thing, that it is not allowed. >> You could have a 5 color cube, where each corner edge pair has > different >> color of the two pieces. >> It is also not allowed to have small stickers at the edge of each > piece, to >> see what color is on the other side of that piece. >> >> Our goal is to have fun in tournaments, and to make sure the best > cuber in >> competition conditions wins. >> Our goal is not to go faster by changing rules in our favor. >> >> Apart from the rules, I think if we would be on tv, people would > consider us >> cheating.
