496. New York Tournament
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 07 May 2005 13:04:03 -0000

Hi folks,

The tournament at Horace Mann School in Riverdale, New York is
coming up on Saturday, May 28th. We've got some really fast people
coming (Macky, Chris H, Ryan Patricio, Tyson) and we're doing a
bunch of different events (2x2, 3x3, 4x4, magic, rainbow cube,
square-1, blindfold, one-handed, and maybe fewest moves). The
tournament is an official one so we might have some new records at
day's end!

After the tournament, everyone is invited to a barbecue (BBQube?) at
my house which is 10 minutes from the venue.

The school is only 3 blocks from the subway and that Monday is
Memorial Day so if you ever needed an excuse to visit New York City
and do some sightseeing, this is it!

I've been looking around for some suitable hotels and I've found a
couple that are relatively cheap and are only a 10 minute drive from
the venue. If you won't have a car, a taxi ride shouldn't be too
expensive.

Holiday Inn
(914) 476-3800
125 Tuckahoe Rd
Yonkers, NY 10710

Royal Regency Hotel
914-476-6200
165 Tuckahoe Rd
Yonkers, NY 10710

E-mail me (iwinoky@...) if you have any questions or if you
want to register. There's info about the venue at

http://home.manhattan.edu/~ian.winokur/CubeTournament.html

I hope to see a bunch of you there!

Ian Winokur





497. Re: David Allen Method?
From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 07 May 2005 14:35:43 -0000

David is, as far as I know, quite secretive about his method. The only thing he's said about it is that it's a corners first method. He started out with the method in the book 'Conquer the Cube' and then evolved it to suit himself and to speed it up a bit (a lot). --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "darereck" <darereck@g...> wrote: > Is anyone here familar with David Allen's method? Is there a website > that has information about it?
498. [Speed cubing group] Re: black and white cube mix
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 07 May 2005 19:34:03 -0000

Hi! I think this can be resolved quite easily. Use the black arched centers, but use the centercaps from the white diy cube. Nobody will be able to tell that the cube ain't "all white". Well unless someone disassembles it. And even do noone can claim u have a color advantage from it. Just a trivially easy idea ;-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > Hi Ron, > > The black plastic DIY cubes have arched centers and don't pop and > are adjustable. 500. Re: Poor quality Rubik's Professor 5x5x5
From: "jello33" <jellomods@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 May 2005 02:52:10 -0000

Hello,

7 Towns contacted me about my problem with the 5x5x5. I have since
received a direct replacement, and it works very nice. It's not as
free moving as my Mefferts tiled prof. but it is very nice.

I'm happy to say that they took care of me well. The email responses
were fast, and a replacement showed up in 7 days.

Chris

502. [Speed cubing group] Re: New Speedcube Timer
From: "one_eyed_blindcat" <dhwebb@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 May 2005 06:02:39 -0000

Ok I have made most of the requested changes and there is an updated
version on my site, www.rubikspuzzles.com. I changed quite a bit and
added a few files so you will have to redownload the entire setup
application again. Hopefully after this I can just update the EXE.

Here are the requests that I received below

> just a small thing : would it be possible to have a different sound
> when the timer start ?

Done

> maybe for future updates for the cube size option:
> square1(cube21)
> megamix
> pyramix
> rubiks clock's
> or an option to add puzzles the use would like the times to be
> put in a database.

I added a lot more puzzles to the list. Didn't have time yet to allow
users to add their own puzzles.

> Maybe it's a better idea to call the 'shuffle' a 'scramble'

Done

> it would be nice to have an: 'add time' button, so I can use it
> in combination with my stackmat. Or maybe even a
> "countdown+add time" option, because my stackmat won't do the
> countdown for me :).

Both Done

Now what would be to add to the stackmat feature would be to read the
time directly from the stackmat. There was a post just a few days ago
about this.




503. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New Speedcube Timer
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 May 2005 14:04:45 +0200

Hi,

Your timer is my new favourite and I like it a lot. Here are some
suggestions on further improvements though:

*Delete/Change time without the need of MS Access
*Add 2 sec penalty option/button
*Some additional statistics like standard deviation and median
*Be able to show times over time as line graph in progression. Would be
nice to have both for solve times and averages, and maybe also one where
only improved averages are shown. (my first average made on 2005-05-08
and new points in the line graph are only added for better averages.)

Thank you
/Gustav

504. [Speed cubing group] Re: New Speedcube Timer
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 May 2005 14:15:53 -0000

Thanks a lot, mate! I don't have time to check it out right now, but I will do so later. Bye! Joël. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@...m, "one_eyed_blindcat" <dhwebb@g...> wrote: > Ok I have made most of the requested changes and there is an updated > version on my site, www.rubikspuzzles.com. I changed quite a bit and > added a few files so you will have to redownload the entire setup > application again. Hopefully after this I can just update the EXE. > > Here are the requests that I received below > > > just a small thing : would it be possible to have a different sound > > when the timer start ? > > Done > > > maybe for future updates for the cube size option: > > square1(cube21) > > megamix > > pyramix > > rubiks clock's > > or an option to add puzzles the use would like the times to be > > put in a database. > > I added a lot more puzzles to the list. Didn't have time yet to allow > users to add their own puzzles. > > > Maybe it's a better idea to call the 'shuffle' a 'scramble' > > Done > > > it would be nice to have an: 'add time' button, so I can use it > > in combination with my stackmat. Or maybe even a > > "countdown+add time" option, because my stackmat won't do the > > countdown for me :). > > Both Done > > Now what would be to add to the stackmat feature would be to read the > time directly from the stackmat. There was a post just a few days ago > about this.
505. Re: Poor quality Rubik's Professor 5x5x5
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 May 2005 15:54:08 -0000

Hmmm ... Why don't they simply offer a 5x5x5 diy-kit with some spare parts and a choice of rivets or screws, just like they have for the 3x3x3. Shouldn't be much of a problem to do that. And to be honest i think they would see the sales of the professor cube increase quite a bit. Many prefer the mefferts variant or eastsheen due to it's well known initial stiffness. A 5x5x5 rubiks.com diy-kit seems like a perfect idea to me :-) As a sidenote a 4x4x4 diy-kit does not seem to be much point. The only reason would be if we could glue those core parts together ourselves. That is kinda risky, but at least one can avoid some of the bad cores that i have seen with skewness and/or elevation. An almost perfect core is highly essential for a good 4x4x4 for speeding. -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "jello33" <jellomods@h...> wrote: > Hello, > > 7 Towns contacted me about my problem with the 5x5x5. I have since > received a direct replacement, and it works very nice. It's not as > free moving as my Mefferts tiled prof. but it is very nice. > > I'm happy to say that they took care of me well. The email responses > were fast, and a replacement showed up in 7 days. > > Chris
506. F2L help! :)
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 May 2005 16:09:12 -0000

Hey everybody,

I am not sure if this post will be usefull for my, but I'll try
anyway :).

I think I have found a pretty nice area of improvement for me. When
DanH was visiting me a few weeks ago, we had a few (a lot, actually)
of races, and he would sometimes say when he finished the cross, 1st
pair, 2nd pair, etc., and I noticed that he was much faster during
the F2L, but I would usually catch up during the LL phase.. Both
ending with about the same time. (sometimes, when he was solving F2L
really fast, I thought, 'oh well, he's just saying that :)',
remember Dan? ;)). Anyway, today, I timed my F2L and LL (without OLL
regognition) seperately, and I think I barely average sub 10 for the
F2L. Maybe around 11 seconds, but around 6 seconds for the last
layer (just estimating, I didnt make notes yet.. maybe I should).

Do any cubers here have tips to really speed up that F2L? I think I
know most shortcuts, but maybe I have to cut out some cube rotations
that I do automatically. But how can I train this? Does anyone else
here recognize the same 'weak spot'?

-Joël.




507. Re: F2L help! :)
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 May 2005 16:23:39 -0000

> I am not sure if this post will be usefull for my, but I'll try
> anyway :).

*my = me... duh?! :)




508. [Speed cubing group] Re: New Speedcube Timer
From: "one_eyed_blindcat" <dhwebb@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 May 2005 16:57:11 -0000

I had a report that somebody lost their previous records when they
upgraded. This should not happen. To be safe, make a copy of the
speedcube.mdb file in the program directory when upgrading just to be
safe. If you do lose your previous information, copying this file
back into the program directory after the upgrade will restore them.

Let me know your results from this via my email: dhwebb@...

From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>

Date: Sun, 08 May 2005 18:35:01 -0000

My washer story so far:
http://www.twistypuzzles.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=3723





510. Re: [Speed cubing group] F2L help! :)

Really would appreciate if anyone gives some tips for speeding that up. Maybe these times could be in part due to a very bad cube that i get here, but i think my technique is also bad. 511. Self-Scrambling LED cube...
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 May 2005 20:53:07 -0000

OK. So I went back and read the two threads "rubiks with lights?",
from 2002, and "Pretty Crazy Cube Idea", from 2004, and it got me
thinking ;)

I have to do a Computer Sciece capstone in about two years and,
instead of making a cube-solving robot ;) , I want to make the cube
that Evan and some other people were talking about in earlier threads.
My brother, dad, and I are doing some research right now to try and
figure out the best components to use for this thing. We have already
dropped the idea of using wires and are considering possible metal
contacts between cubies. I'm not sure how difficult this is going to
be...but it CAN BE DONE!! ;)

For those of you who haven't read the above threads, the main idea
here is to make a rubik's cube that uses lights (LEDs?), instead of
stickers, for color. Since the whole cube is electric, it will also be
able to scramble itself via a button on some center face or something
like that. I might build it using a 'large' 3x3x3 first, but maybe
not. The hardest part about this project is going to be the hardware
engineering. I'm pretty sure the software will be easy to write.

Let me know if any one of you bright engineers have ideas for getting
this done. I have two years ;)

-Chris




512. Re: [Speed cubing group] Self-Scrambling LED cube...
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 8 May 2005 13:59:54 -0700

I have a friend who's an EE here at Caltech who came across this idea
awhile ago. I think Glenn George, a professor at Caltech, thought it
was possible as well. Anyway, this e-mail is being CCed to him as
well. We kind of wanted to build something like this for Ditch Day
next year.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

513. Re: [Speed cubing group] Self-Scrambling LED cube...
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 May 2005 21:10:55 -0000

Hey! I think the basic feature which is needed is simply MEMORY. Ie the robot must do it's thinking not solely based on current state of it's sensors but also past history of the sensors. A few intermediate sensors btw one cubestate and the next (while doing a faceturn) would help identify what has happened to the cube and will correctly identify the next current state. Well something like this anyway. Haven't thought about it much yet. And though this would be cool my personal opinion is that is's much cooler to have a robot twist a normal cube like Evan's robot does. That way "computerworld" and real world combines to a great effect!! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > I have a friend who's an EE here at Caltech who came across this idea > awhile ago. 515. Re: [Speed cubing group] Self-Scrambling LED cube...
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 May 2005 21:58:00 -0000

Hey! No i didn't miss the point. It's already far too late and im here at uni. OK a robot is not necessarily a physical robot like in Robocop or like Evan's cube solving robot. Knowing which state the cube/program/robot (whatever!) is in will make sure that the correct LED's are lit up at each external cubie face. The state-space is obviously too large for somthing like a neural net. Well anyway it's too late to explain exactly what i mean ... zzzz ... More tomorrow :-) Cheers! --Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hey! > > > > I think the basic feature which is needed is simply MEMORY. 516. Re: [Speed cubing group] Self-Scrambling LED cube...
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 May 2005 22:04:03 -0000

<aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hey! > > I think the basic feature which is needed is simply MEMORY. Ie the > robot must do it's thinking not solely based on current state of > it's sensors but also past history of the sensors. I'm afraid I don't understand what you mean by "robot". This is a design where the cube is still solved as normal, by a human, but the colors of each cubie are displayed with LEDs rather then stickers. The only 'thinking' would take place when the cube randomly changes the LED colors to make a valid scramble.
517. Re: F2L help! :)
From: "darereck" <darereck@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 May 2005 22:17:58 -0000

well i wouldn't say that i am a fast cuber and all (about 18 seconds for f2l) but noticed a few improvements when i solve it. i solve f2l with a cross on the bottom and most of the f2l algorithms requires you to do a U2 turn and usually i take two moves U, U. i think i could improve my f2l times if i could eliminate the two moves and do one. so i tried to solve the f2l on the side.. at first it was kinda awkward... but it seems like i could move the U2 face into on move since it was now used for my right hand.. i think trying out side f2l maybe slightly easier for me, only because i take two moves for the U2. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, sachin shirwalkar <sachin_civilian@y...> wrote: > Ya I also have the same problem, albeit on a much > larger scale. Maybe > these times could be in part due to a very bad cube > that i get here, but i think my technique is also bad. > > Someday i will reach sub-60 :) > > --- Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > --------------------------------- > Hey everybody, > > I am not sure if this post will be usefull for my, but > I'll try > anyway :). > > I think I have found a pretty nice area of improvement > for me. 519. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: F2L help! :)
From: "James Stuber" <jestuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 08 May 2005 15:30:07 -0700

>well i wouldn't say that i am a fast cuber and all (about 18 seconds >for f2l) but noticed a few improvements when i solve it. i solve f2l >with a cross on the bottom and most of the f2l algorithms requires you >to do a U2 turn and usually i take two moves U, U. i think i could >improve my f2l times if i could eliminate the two moves and do one. so >i tried to solve the f2l on the side.. at first it was kinda >awkward... but it seems like i could move the U2 face into on move >since it was now used for my right hand.. i think trying out side f2l >maybe slightly easier for me, only because i take two moves for the U2. I can perform U2 just as fast as R2, and I think f2l on bottom is the best for looking ahead. Instead of using cube rotations, most of the time using d or d or d2 will do the same thing and get one U move closer at the same time. _____ From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of darereck Sent: Sunday, May 08, 2005 3:18 PM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: F2L help! :) well i wouldn't say that i am a fast cuber and all (about 18 seconds for f2l) but noticed a few improvements when i solve it. i solve f2l with a cross on the bottom and most of the f2l algorithms requires you to do a U2 turn and usually i take two moves U, U. i think i could improve my f2l times if i could eliminate the two moves and do one. so i tried to solve the f2l on the side.. at first it was kinda awkward... but it seems like i could move the U2 face into on move since it was now used for my right hand.. i think trying out side f2l maybe slightly easier for me, only because i take two moves for the U2. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, sachin shirwalkar <sachin_civilian@y...> wrote: > Ya I also have the same problem, albeit on a much > larger scale. 520. 25th Anv. Cube
From: "Peter Douthwright" <pdouthwright0513@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 8 May 2005 17:07:36 -0700

Has anyone actually played with this cube.

Wanted to know how it moves. Is it better then the normal?

Heard claims that is was the most superior working cube ever produced. Is this true?

Thanks

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



521. Re: 25th Anv. Cube
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 May 2005 02:33:57 -0000

No it's not true. I ordered 2 through rubiks.com a few weeks ago and am not too happy with them. I just got a regular cube at Meijer today and like it. I believe new cubes shouldn't be so loose. Stiffer smoother cubes will produce better results in the end once they are worn in. Speaking of which, I haven't had a good speedcube for a long time. (Keep losing them on the bus.) I am wondering if there's someone out there who is willing to make me one. I'm of course willing to spend $100-$200 for a good speedcube. It would have to be severly modded to my liking though... putting in special washers, perfect tension, solid stickers, a different color scheme,...., etc. The 25th aniversary cubes came packaged very nicely, but they had the old style of stickers that peeled very easily. It took me about 1-2 weeks to wear-out the stickers as usual. Solving 300 times a day might do that.... -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Peter Douthwright" <pdouthwright0513@r...> wrote: > Has anyone actually played with this cube. > > Wanted to know how it moves. Is it better then the normal? > > Heard claims that is was the most superior working cube ever produced. Is this true? > > Thanks > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
522. Re: 25th Anv. Cube
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 May 2005 11:35:02 -0000

Hi! I really recommend the rubiks.com diy kit. After adjusting mine on the day i got it i haven't had to do anything since. It's turning really well for me. Some say that it's a good idea to chenge the springs on them. I wouldn't know cause i never tried it. Anyway with screws instead of rivets it's fairly easy to adjust to ur own liking. U can also make a hybrid diy (i haven't tried it) with cubies from the white diy and the arched centers from black diy. Then put the white centercaps on the centers instead of the black ones. U will need to glue the centercaps on so dun use too much glue and complete ur tension adjustments before gluing!! Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > No it's not true. I ordered 2 through rubiks.com a few weeks ago and > am not too happy with them. I just got a regular cube at Meijer today > and like it. > > I believe new cubes shouldn't be so loose. Stiffer smoother cubes will > produce better results in the end once they are worn in. > > Speaking of which, I haven't had a good speedcube for a long time. > (Keep losing them on the bus.) I am wondering if there's someone out > there who is willing to make me one. I'm of course willing to spend > $100-$200 for a good speedcube. It would have to be severly modded to > my liking though... putting in special washers, perfect tension, solid > stickers, a different color scheme,...., etc. > > The 25th aniversary cubes came packaged very nicely, but they had the > old style of stickers that peeled very easily. It took me about 1- 2 > weeks to wear-out the stickers as usual. Solving 300 times a day might > do that.... > > > -Doug > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Peter Douthwright" > <pdouthwright0513@r...> wrote: > > Has anyone actually played with this cube. > > > > Wanted to know how it moves. Is it better then the normal? > > > > Heard claims that is was the most superior working cube ever > produced. Is this true? > > > > Thanks > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
523. Re: 25th Anv. Cube
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 May 2005 13:54:46 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hi! > > I really recommend the rubiks.com diy kit. After adjusting mine on > the day i got it i haven't had to do anything since. It's turning > really well for me. Some say that it's a good idea to chenge the > springs on them. I hope you don't mean me :-) These DIYs are actually ok, they do have washers, their spring length/strength are ok (could be slightly softer but not necessary), the spring ends are somewhat ground (not perfect, but at least a bit) and perhaps most importantly their screws are great. The thread is only near the end, i.e. the upper part is flat and thus can't lock up with the spring. And most importantly the screw head has a large diameter, larger than the center hole. This way, how far you can pull a center from the kernel spider is not limited by the spring compressed to maximum (where it reaches maximum strength), but by the screw head, and the spring is not compressed fully and thus appears to be less strong. I haven't tried the white DIYs with their original springs (instead I immediately used others) but I'd guess they're ok, too, because of the large screw head. Cheers! Stefan
524. Re: 25th Anv. Cube (springs/washers)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 May 2005 15:44:38 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > The thread is only near the end, i.e. the upper part is flat > and thus can't lock up with the spring. And most importantly the screw > head has a large diameter, larger than the center hole. This way, how > far you can pull a center from the kernel spider is not limited by the > spring compressed to maximum (where it reaches maximum strength), but > by the screw head, and the spring is not compressed fully and thus > appears to be less strong. Interesting. Have you tried to achieve this same limiting effect with a large washer between (small) screwhead and spring? (Am looking for a quick fix, as the only spare springs I have are as strong as those already in the Studio cube.) In fact it ought to be possible to get any tension you want by combining with washers at the opposite end of the spring. Might try it anyway... Mike

526. [Speed cubing group] Re: black and white cube mix
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 May 2005 16:36:34 -0000

Hi Tyson, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > I don't think you should be so quick to blame the cube. I blame Seven Towns. They know very well that the flat centers pop, and to have them pop less they need to be adjusted too tightly. Those are the very reasons why they went to arches for their main production runs. They know as well as I do that the flat centers are no treat for speedcubers. > There are two > factors that go into popping. The first is, yes, the cube. Certain > cubes pop more easily than others. However, the second factor is the > cuber. If you're accurate with your turns, then you can turn it as > hard as you want and you won't pop. This principle is illustrated when > I was cubing in front of Macky and jamming on a bunch of turns. Macky > turns to me, says, "You need to work on your accuracy," grabs my cube, > and then proceeds to make a billion turns on the cube smoothly without > jamming at all. Do you remember that I had several cubes with me at last years Nationals? Yes, I used two flat center cubes during the 10 cube no-inspection solves and solved them without popping, but they slowed me down. I agree that accuracy helps, but not entirely, not even with Macky. And at one point that day Macky tried my best flat center speedcube and it literally exploded all over the place on about his tenth turn. > If the purpose of the white plastic cube is just to look cube and it > has a negative impact on your cubing performance, why don't you just go > with a black cube? The purpose isn't just to look good - the white plastic is slicker. Regards, David J > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On May 6, 2005, at 1:03 PM, d_j_salvia wrote: > > > Hi Ron, > > > > The black plastic DIY cubes have arched centers and don't pop and > > are adjustable. The white plastic cubes have slicker plastic and look > > cool, however they have flat centers and pop a lot. So if I want an > > adjustable white cube that doesn't pop I *have* to have a black > > plastic center piece. > > > > I was displeased that the white DIY cubes I got were from the older > > model. 528. Sticker Web Site Now Up.
From: "jello33" <jellomods@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 May 2005 19:06:04 -0000

Hello All,

I've been making replacement cube stickers for a little bit, and sold
some to a few people on this board, Thanks. I have a site up now to
simplify the ordering process, and help keep track of everything.

I've got sets available for most cube puzzles, as well as a Supercube
5x5x5, and am going to be adding new sets as I can.

I think my next standard puzzle set will be for the Megaminx, I just
need to get a few more colors first.

Anyway, check it out.

Thanks
Chris

531. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: black and white cube mix
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 9 May 2005 13:33:01 -0700

I personally am a big fan of the flat centers because it reduces
jamming. Macky popped on your cube because he wasn't used to it, not
because it was chronically prone to popping. As a scrambler for these
tournaments, you very quickly find out whose cubes are the loosest and
most easy popping. Frank Chang's cube, for example, is absolutely
ridiculous and I popped slightly even when scrambling at a slow speed.
However, Frank can solve that cube in under 20 seconds. I believe that
with proper control and accuracy, even the loosest cube will not pop.
Of course, some cubes may actually pop, but I highly doubt this would
be the case for a new cube that hasn't been worn in.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On May 9, 2005, at 9:36 AM, d_j_salvia wrote:

> I blame Seven Towns. They know very well that the flat centers pop,
> and to have them pop less they need to be adjusted too tightly. Those
> are the very reasons why they went to arches for their main production
> runs. They know as well as I do that the flat centers are no treat for
> speedcubers.
>
> Do you remember that I had several cubes with me at last years
> Nationals? Yes, I used two flat center cubes during the 10 cube
> no-inspection solves and solved them without popping, but they slowed
> me down. I agree that accuracy helps, but not entirely, not even with
> Macky.
> And at one point that day Macky tried my best flat center speedcube
> and it literally exploded all over the place on about his tenth turn.

534. Re: 25th Anv. Cube (springs/washers)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 May 2005 21:41:34 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > > Interesting. Have you tried to achieve this same limiting effect with a > large washer between (small) screwhead and spring? (Am looking for a > quick fix, as the only spare springs I have are as strong as those > already in the Studio cube.) Yes, I've already done that and with very good success, but thanks anyway :-) The problem is that this means I can't screw in the screw very much, about 2mm less than usual, and the screws keep getting unscrewed during play. I could probably fix this with glue but I'd hate to use glue. Also, I like the screw to be deep inside the kernel spider to have bigger stability. That's why I've ordered very weak springs today, so that they're soft even when they're almost completely compressed, and then when they're fully compressed they suddenly block, achieving the effect I want: Small interval for movement but very soft in this interval. I've also started to look for screws yesterday. I noticed that the Studio cubes use the same screws as those from the early 80s so there's got to be a standard. I'd like to get the same screw thread, but only for the lower half of the screw, and flat above. Also the screw should be 1.5-2mm longer and it should have a large head (or I'd use a large washer again but I'd like to use nylon and I don't know how strong it is and I have to take care about screw head vs center cap). I've recently prepared some "wonderful puzzler" cubes (I think) and they already have perfect screws. That's why I was able to turn them into very good cubes easily just by replacing their too strong springs (and adding some washers). Cheers! Stefan
535. Re: 25th Anv. Cube (springs/washers)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 May 2005 22:10:29 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I've recently prepared some "wonderful puzzler" cubes (I think) and > they already have perfect screws. That's why I was able to turn them > into very good cubes easily just by replacing their too strong springs > (and adding some washers). Oh well, of course I also cleaned/lubed the pieces. But replacing the springs played a major part. The old ones have wire diameter 0.6mm or maybe even a bit more and the ends are not ground. Now I use 0.5mm springs with ends ground. It makes a huge difference. The springs I've now ordered have 0.32mm wire diameter, I hope that'll be weak enough. General question: Did anyone study the effects of different springs/washers/etc before? If so, I'd like to know anything that's known already (springs are much much more expensive than washers ;-) Cheers! Stefan

538. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: F2L help! :)
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 9 May 2005 22:12:25 -0500

even though it's been said a billion times... sllooooow down during the f2l. like practice trying to go without stopping ,even if you have to go really slow at first. try to look ahead and just don't go too fast even if you are tempted to go fast. anyways, hope that helps. On 5/8/05, James Stuber <jestuber@...> wrote: > > >well i wouldn't say that i am a fast cuber and all (about 18 seconds > >for f2l) but noticed a few improvements when i solve it. i solve f2l > >with a cross on the bottom and most of the f2l algorithms requires you > > >to do a U2 turn and usually i take two moves U, U. i think i could > > >improve my f2l times if i could eliminate the two moves and do one. so > >i tried to solve the f2l on the side.. at first it was kinda > >awkward... but it seems like i could move the U2 face into on move > >since it was now used for my right hand.. i think trying out side f2l > >maybe slightly easier for me, only because i take two moves for the U2. > > I can perform U2 just as fast as R2, and I think f2l on bottom is the best > for looking ahead. Instead of using cube rotations, most of the time using > d > or d' or d2 will do the same thing and get one U move closer at the same > time. > > _____ > > From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of darereck > Sent: Sunday, May 08, 2005 3:18 PM > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: F2L help! :) > > > well i wouldn't say that i am a fast cuber and all (about 18 seconds > for f2l) but noticed a few improvements when i solve it. i solve f2l > with a cross on the bottom and most of the f2l algorithms requires you > to do a U2 turn and usually i take two moves U, U. i think i could > improve my f2l times if i could eliminate the two moves and do one. so > i tried to solve the f2l on the side.. at first it was kinda > awkward... but it seems like i could move the U2 face into on move > since it was now used for my right hand.. i think trying out side f2l > maybe slightly easier for me, only because i take two moves for the U2. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, sachin shirwalkar > <sachin_civilian@y...> wrote: > > Ya I also have the same problem, albeit on a much > > larger scale. Really would appreciate > > if anyone gives some tips for speeding that up. Both > > ending with about the same time. (sometimes, when he > > was solving F2L > > really fast, I thought, 'oh well, he's just saying > > that :)', > > remember Dan? ;)). Anyway, today, I timed my F2L and > > LL (without OLL > > regognition) seperately, and I think I barely average > > sub 10 for the > > F2L. Maybe around 11 seconds, but around 6 seconds for > > the last > > layer (just estimating, I didnt make notes yet.. maybe > > I should). > > > > Do any cubers here have tips to really speed up that > > F2L? I think I > > know most shortcuts, but maybe I have to cut out some > > cube rotations > > that I do automatically. 542. [Speed cubing group] Re: 25th Anv. Cube (springs/washers)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 May 2005 11:40:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Chun Hei Uwe Wong <lilbeyond@y...> wrote: > how can u take a spring from a 25th Anv. Cube and replace them with some 80's spring??? u can take the riverts out?? Uh, sorry... maybe we should've continued under a completely separate thread. No, I probably can't do this with a 25th Anv. Cube, I recently tried to get the rivets out of a "normal" cube and did not succeed at all, I only hurt myself. But I don't think it would be a big improvement, just like with the DIYs. You could of course use a saw to destroy the kernel spider and get the rivets out, then replace the spider/rivets with spider/screws from a $1 clone cube. Haven't actually done so, but it could work. It's like a DIYDIY, build your own DIY kit... Cheers! Stefan
543. [Speed cubing group] Re: 25th Anv. Cube (springs/washers)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 May 2005 11:42:49 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Chun Hei Uwe Wong <lilbeyond@y...> wrote: > how can u take a spring from a 25th Anv. Cube and replace them with some 80's spring??? u can take the riverts out?? Oh, there's also some confusion. I would not want to replace them with 80s springs since those (among others) are the ones I'm complaining about. Cheers! Stefan
544. [Speed cubing group] Re: 25th Anv. Cube (springs/washers)
From: nascarjon2001 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 May 2005 14:21:07 -0000

> You could of course use a saw to destroy the kernel spider and get
the
> rivets out, then replace the spider/rivets with spider/screws from a
> $1 clone cube. Haven't actually done so, but it could work. It's
like
> a DIYDIY, build your own DIY kit...


That is what I did. When the arched center cubes first came out last
year I bought one from a local department store. It was terrible.
Some rivets were too tight and others were too loose. So I used a
power drill to drill the heads off of the rivets and replaced the
kernel with one from a cube from a 90's Rubik's Cube. Now the cube is
the best one in my fleet. I was planning on trying this again with
another old kernel that I have from a 4th dimension cube. But I never
got around to it.


Jon
www.geocities.com/nascarjon2001




545. [Speed cubing group] Re: F2L help! :)
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 May 2005 17:52:27 -0000

Whahah... I almost thought you were talking to me.. because I started this topic :)... I think I have found a good balance between speed and fluency now.. So I am afraid slowing down will not do the trick for me anymore :(.. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@g...> wrote: > even though it's been said a billion times... > > sllooooow down during the f2l. like practice trying to go without stopping > ,even if you have to go really slow at first. try to look ahead and just > don't go too fast even if you are tempted to go fast. > > anyways, hope that helps. > > On 5/8/05, James Stuber <jestuber@v...> wrote: > > > > >well i wouldn't say that i am a fast cuber and all (about 18 seconds > > >for f2l) but noticed a few improvements when i solve it. i solve f2l > > >with a cross on the bottom and most of the f2l algorithms requires you > > > > >to do a U2 turn and usually i take two moves U, U. i think i could > > > > >improve my f2l times if i could eliminate the two moves and do one. so > > >i tried to solve the f2l on the side.. at first it was kinda > > >awkward... but it seems like i could move the U2 face into on move > > >since it was now used for my right hand.. i think trying out side f2l > > >maybe slightly easier for me, only because i take two moves for the U2. > > > > I can perform U2 just as fast as R2, and I think f2l on bottom is the best > > for looking ahead. Instead of using cube rotations, most of the time using > > d > > or d' or d2 will do the same thing and get one U move closer at the same > > time. > > > > _____ > > > > From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of darereck > > Sent: Sunday, May 08, 2005 3:18 PM > > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: F2L help! :) > > > > > > well i wouldn't say that i am a fast cuber and all (about 18 seconds > > for f2l) but noticed a few improvements when i solve it. i solve f2l > > with a cross on the bottom and most of the f2l algorithms requires you > > to do a U2 turn and usually i take two moves U, U. i think i could > > improve my f2l times if i could eliminate the two moves and do one. so > > i tried to solve the f2l on the side.. at first it was kinda > > awkward... but it seems like i could move the U2 face into on move > > since it was now used for my right hand.. i think trying out side f2l > > maybe slightly easier for me, only because i take two moves for the U2. > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, sachin shirwalkar > > <sachin_civilian@y...> wrote: > > > Ya I also have the same problem, albeit on a much > > > larger scale. Usually my times for F2L are around 45 - > > > 60 seconds. And I also see a lot of improvement > > > possible in this area for me. Really would appreciate > > > if anyone gives some tips for speeding that up. Maybe > > > these times could be in part due to a very bad cube > > > that i get here, but i think my technique is also bad. > > > > > > Someday i will reach sub-60 :) > > > > > > --- Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > --------------------------------- > > > Hey everybody, > > > > > > I am not sure if this post will be usefull for my, but > > > I'll try > > > anyway :). > > > > > > I think I have found a pretty nice area of improvement > > > for me. When > > > DanH was visiting me a few weeks ago, we had a few (a > > > lot, actually) > > > of races, and he would sometimes say when he finished > > > the cross, 1st > > > pair, 2nd pair, etc., and I noticed that he was much > > > faster during > > > the F2L, but I would usually catch up during the LL > > > phase.. Both > > > ending with about the same time. (sometimes, when he > > > was solving F2L > > > really fast, I thought, 'oh well, he's just saying > > > that :)', > > > remember Dan? ;)). Anyway, today, I timed my F2L and > > > LL (without OLL > > > regognition) seperately, and I think I barely average > > > sub 10 for the > > > F2L. Maybe around 11 seconds, but around 6 seconds for > > > the last > > > layer (just estimating, I didnt make notes yet.. maybe > > > I should). > > > > > > Do any cubers here have tips to really speed up that > > > F2L? I think I > > > know most shortcuts, but maybe I have to cut out some > > > cube rotations > > > that I do automatically. 546. Accuracy WAS: black and white cube mix
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 May 2005 18:18:38 -0000

Hi Tyson, OK. We know each others preference. I'd like to turn this thread into one about accuracy. You know those crappy stickers? The ones that most everybody complains about? I've used them daily on an arched cube for nearly two years and they only show a little wear. When I got the cube I found that the edges of the stickers catch on my fingers, so I quit hitting the edge of the stickers with my fingers and the wear pretty much stopped. If you practice on several different kinds of cubes, including ones you dread like arched- or flat-center ones, too tight or too loose ones, etc. it can help with accuracy. Cheers, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > I personally am a big fan of the flat centers because it reduces > jamming. Macky popped on your cube because he wasn't used to it, not > because it was chronically prone to popping. As a scrambler for these > tournaments, you very quickly find out whose cubes are the loosest and > most easy popping. Frank Chang's cube, for example, is absolutely > ridiculous and I popped slightly even when scrambling at a slow speed. > However, Frank can solve that cube in under 20 seconds. I believe that > with proper control and accuracy, even the loosest cube will not pop. > Of course, some cubes may actually pop, but I highly doubt this would > be the case for a new cube that hasn't been worn in. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On May 9, 2005, at 9:36 AM, d_j_salvia wrote: > > > I blame Seven Towns. They know very well that the flat centers pop, > > and to have them pop less they need to be adjusted too tightly. Those > > are the very reasons why they went to arches for their main production > > runs. They know as well as I do that the flat centers are no treat for > > speedcubers. > > > > Do you remember that I had several cubes with me at last years > > Nationals? Yes, I used two flat center cubes during the 10 cube > > no-inspection solves and solved them without popping, but they slowed > > me down. I agree that accuracy helps, but not entirely, not even with > > Macky. > > And at one point that day Macky tried my best flat center speedcube > > and it literally exploded all over the place on about his tenth turn.
547. Re: [Speed cubing group] Accuracy WAS: black and white cube mix
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 May 2005 11:23:23 -0700

Hi David, You know, the same applies with pianos as well. Some people who never practice on a piano other than their own have difficultly in adjust when it comes time for a performance. The 'crappy sticker' issue also depends on cubing style. I use my entire thumb on certain algorithms and unfortunately, I have developed a rough callous for writing (yes, I occasionally go to class =) ) which is usually want contributes to the wear on those paper stickers. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On May 10, 2005, at 11:18 AM, d_j_salvia wrote: > Hi Tyson, > > OK. We know each others preference. Macky popped on your cube because he wasn't used to it, not >> because it was chronically prone to popping. As a scrambler for these >> tournaments, you very quickly find out whose cubes are the loosest and >> most easy popping. Frank Chang's cube, for example, is absolutely >> ridiculous and I popped slightly even when scrambling at a slow speed. >> However, Frank can solve that cube in under 20 seconds. I believe >> that >> with proper control and accuracy, even the loosest cube will not pop. >> Of course, some cubes may actually pop, but I highly doubt this would >> be the case for a new cube that hasn't been worn in. >> >> Tyson Mao >> MSC #631 >> California Institute of Technology >> >> On May 9, 2005, at 9:36 AM, d_j_salvia wrote: >> >>> I blame Seven Towns. 548. Re: Sticker Web Site Now Up.
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 May 2005 20:21:40 -0000

Bryan, I got some of the tiles from Chris about a week ago. he said they were made from a clear Lexan. Whatever they are, they fit great on any normal 3x3x3 cube and they are much, much thinner than I thought they would be--when I got them I thought at first glance that they were another set of stickers because all six colors combined were about the thickness of a quarter [and that included the little paper backing that you peel off to stick them on]. truly no real noticeable difference in thickness vs. the ordinary stickers. definitely recommend them. --Kirk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "bryanosaurus" <bmytko@o...> wrote: > What exactly are the 'replacement tiles' - more specifically what are > they made of, and can they be put on a regular 3x3x3 cube? > > bryan
549. My stickers changed color!!!
From: "Mikael" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 May 2005 21:41:08 -0000

Okey, this is bizzare...

Yesterday, I was working on a solution to this weeks FMC and left the
cube (Rubiks Studio) in a partly solved state in my room. I then had
other things to do so the cube remained untouched most of the day. In
the evening when I picked it up again all orange facelets had turned
red (it's almost impossible to differ between red and orange now,
speedcubing is totally impossible).

First I suspected that I had left it in the sun and the stickers had
bleached but now I doubt the theory for two reasons. First of all, I
have had left the cube in the same spot ever since I got it in January
and nothing has happened.
Second, the cube was not solved with orange facing up but only partly
solved with orange stickers on several faces.

Has this happened to anyone else or can someone give me a resonable
explenation to this phenomena?
I´m starting to develope a paranoia. I suspect there is some evil
cube-hating force that tries to destroy my cubes to prevent me from
cubing ever again (my girlfriend´s Rubiks.com cube [with arched
centers] has popped on its own and disassembled itself in her bag).

I´m very puzzled and really can´t understand what happened. In my
opinion this is at least slightly funny so I thought I´d share.

May the force be with you, fellow cubers, and don´t let the dark side
touch your cube,
Mikael




550. Re: My stickers changed color!!!
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 May 2005 21:56:30 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mikael" <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > Okey, this is bizzare... > > Yesterday, I was working on a solution to this weeks FMC and left the > cube (Rubiks Studio) in a partly solved state in my room. I then had > other things to do so the cube remained untouched most of the day. In > the evening when I picked it up again all orange facelets had turned > red (it's almost impossible to differ between red and orange now, > speedcubing is totally impossible). > > First I suspected that I had left it in the sun and the stickers had > bleached but now I doubt the theory for two reasons. First of all, I > have had left the cube in the same spot ever since I got it in January > and nothing has happened. > Second, the cube was not solved with orange facing up but only partly > solved with orange stickers on several faces. Well, if someone who has eaten a lot of beans and happens to be in the vicinity and ... > Has this happened to anyone else or can someone give me a resonable > explenation to this phenomena? > I´m starting to develope a paranoia. I suspect there is some evil > cube-hating force that tries to destroy my cubes to prevent me from > cubing ever again (my girlfriend´s Rubiks.com cube [with arched > centers] has popped on its own and disassembled itself in her bag). Since those cubes not only don't pop but are hard to disassemble I'd say someone was playing with your head. > > I´m very puzzled and really can´t understand what happened. In my > opinion this is at least slightly funny so I thought I´d share. > > May the force be with you, fellow cubers, and don´t let the dark side > touch your cube, As an Irish friend of mine says, Beware the dark side of the farce. > Mikael Cheers DJ P.S. Actually I left a scrambled cube, with about half of the orange stickers exposed, in direct sun for about 20 minutes and about those exposed ones turned darker for a while. They went back to normal, but I forget how long it took. It wouldn't be too hard for another cubist to memorize a position, stick the orange side in the sun for a bit and return it to the state it was in before.
551. Re: F2L help! :)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 May 2005 22:13:54 -0000

Hi Joel, maybe you should have a look at Pedro's "Magical F2L Tricks". Also, why don't you start analyzing what you already know? You know a specific cuber who's faster than you, so try to find out why *he* is faster. Maybe compare the number of twists and the number of cube turns for a start (I'd also be interested in these numbers). Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > Hey everybody, > > I am not sure if this post will be usefull for my, but I'll try > anyway :). > > I think I have found a pretty nice area of improvement for me. When > DanH was visiting me a few weeks ago, we had a few (a lot, actually) > of races, and he would sometimes say when he finished the cross, 1st > pair, 2nd pair, etc., and I noticed that he was much faster during > the F2L, but I would usually catch up during the LL phase.. Both > ending with about the same time. (sometimes, when he was solving F2L > really fast, I thought, 'oh well, he's just saying that :)', > remember Dan? ;)). Anyway, today, I timed my F2L and LL (without OLL > regognition) seperately, and I think I barely average sub 10 for the > F2L. Maybe around 11 seconds, but around 6 seconds for the last > layer (just estimating, I didnt make notes yet.. maybe I should). > > Do any cubers here have tips to really speed up that F2L? I think I > know most shortcuts, but maybe I have to cut out some cube rotations > that I do automatically. But how can I train this? Does anyone else > here recognize the same 'weak spot'? > > -Joël.
552. Re: My stickers changed color!!!
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

I left my cube in the car for a few hours and when I returned all the
orange stickers were dark red. The stickers never returned back to
their normal color. I assumed at the time it must have been the sun.

-Chris




553. Re: My stickers changed color!!!
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 00:58:24 -0000

I'm used to my orange stickers fading into white, not red. Usually the ink on the paper stickers rubs away first, and I'm left with white on two sides. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mikael" <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > Okey, this is bizzare... > > Yesterday, I was working on a solution to this weeks FMC and left the > cube (Rubiks Studio) in a partly solved state in my room. 554. Re: My stickers changed color!!!
From: "Rob Butler" <futuese@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 01:11:20 -0000

Hi Mikael, A similar thing actually did happen to me - at least partially. Again with orange turning to red and on a high quality studio cube (from Ton - my favourite cube). Only for me it was very confusing because it only happened to 2 corners and one edge piece. I had taken my cube apart to lube it and then when I went to reassemble it I couldn't find the OWB corner - in fact all of my white corners now had red stickers. IF you look VERY VERY closly you can tell the difference but it is useless for sppedcubing and I had to steal a couple of orange stickers off an inferior cube to keep my good one running. At the time I blamed the transformation on the lube and figured that I had been careless while spraying some of the pieces and that was why it only happened to 3 of the 8 orange stickers - now I'm no so sure what to think. Rob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mikael" <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > Okey, this is bizzare... > > Yesterday, I was working on a solution to this weeks FMC and left the > cube (Rubiks Studio) in a partly solved state in my room. I then had > other things to do so the cube remained untouched most of the day. In > the evening when I picked it up again all orange facelets had turned > red (it's almost impossible to differ between red and orange now, > speedcubing is totally impossible). > > First I suspected that I had left it in the sun and the stickers had > bleached but now I doubt the theory for two reasons. First of all, I > have had left the cube in the same spot ever since I got it in January > and nothing has happened. > Second, the cube was not solved with orange facing up but only partly > solved with orange stickers on several faces. > > Has this happened to anyone else or can someone give me a resonable > explenation to this phenomena? > I´m starting to develope a paranoia. I suspect there is some evil > cube-hating force that tries to destroy my cubes to prevent me from > cubing ever again (my girlfriend´s Rubiks.com cube [with arched > centers] has popped on its own and disassembled itself in her bag). > > I´m very puzzled and really can´t understand what happened. In my > opinion this is at least slightly funny so I thought I´d share. > > May the force be with you, fellow cubers, and don´t let the dark side > touch your cube, > Mikael
555. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: F2L help! :)
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 May 2005 20:20:57 -0500

ahh, sorry for the confusion. yea sometimes slowing down doesnt help.. and in those cases im not quite sure what to do (im not quite there yet either),but if you spend a lot of time searching for the pair, well then it's a great idea to slow down. and when slowing down look forward. and whatnot. and i second the thing on f2l tricks. On 5/10/05, Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> wrote: > > Hi Joel, > > maybe you should have a look at Pedro's "Magical F2L Tricks". > > Also, why don't you start analyzing what you already know? When > > DanH was visiting me a few weeks ago, we had a few (a lot, actually) > > of races, and he would sometimes say when he finished the cross, 1st > > pair, 2nd pair, etc., and I noticed that he was much faster during > > the F2L, but I would usually catch up during the LL phase.. Both > > ending with about the same time. (sometimes, when he was solving F2L > > really fast, I thought, 'oh well, he's just saying that :)', > > remember Dan? ;)). 556. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: F2L help! :)
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 May 2005 19:59:45 -0700 (PDT)

hmm idk but i think its just me. i find that i can track pieces better if i hold the cube not with the front face facing me, but a little bit moved about 30 degrees to your left or right as you solve, you can see and track some pieces quiet efficiently. so basically its like holding the side of the cube facing you :P just like in those java applets. laterz!!! --- Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...> wrote: > ahh, sorry for the confusion. > > yea sometimes slowing down doesnt help.. and in > those cases im not quite > sure what to do (im not quite there yet either),but > if you spend a lot of > time searching for the pair, well then it's a great > idea to slow down. and > when slowing down look forward. and whatnot. > > and i second the thing on f2l tricks. > > On 5/10/05, Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> wrote: > > > > Hi Joel, > > > > maybe you should have a look at Pedro's "Magical > F2L Tricks". > > > > Also, why don't you start analyzing what you > already know? 559. Re: My stickers changed color!!!
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 07:25:33 -0000

Same problem -- Studio cube. I tried household bleach, which possibly
lightened the colour a little (sorry, no "control" in the experiment),
but not enough. In the end I made new stickers from paper labels and
protected with acrylic varnish (never use this, btw -- it takes weeks
for acrylic to cure properly).

Anyway, it sounds like a good time for you to visit Jello33's sticker
shop...

Mike




560. Re: My stickers changed color!!!
From: "jello33" <jellomods@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 07:44:34 -0000

Was the orange originaly a fluorescent color? I know that the
fluorescent materials are only rated to keep there color for 6 months
outdoors. Some pigments can fade very quickly in sunlight. It seems
that once the color starts to break down it does so very fast.

Chris
www.cubesmith.com






561. Re: My stickers changed color!!!
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 09:54:11 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "jello33" <jellomods@h...> wrote: > Was the orange originaly a fluorescent color? I believe so. Disturbingly bright, anyway. > Some pigments can fade very quickly in sunlight. It seems > that once the color starts to break down it does so very fast. I actually don't know how long my own cube was sitting in the blazing sunshine of Manchester, but one person has reported on twistypuzzles.com that the orange on his Studio cube darkened after just 5-10 min. Mike
562. The world Championship In Florida
From: "Peter Douthwright" <pdouthwright0513@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 06:29:50 -0400

Will Eastsheen cubes be allowed in the wc2005 in Florida?

Are they allowed in other "official" competitions?

Was considering buying a 4X4X4 & a 5X5X5, but did not want to if they are not allowed into officials contests.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



563. Re: The world Championship In Florida
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 11:51:04 -0000

Hey :-) This is a recurring topic ;-) Short and sad answer is : NO! Reason is that the wc2005 will be sponsored by Seventowns. They will not allow any Eastsheen or other unbranded puzzles for the competitions. In theory any cheap cloned knock-off 3x3x3 is therefore not allowed. But it's real hard to identify those with any great certainty. So the ban by and large is concerned with the Eastsheen kinda 4x4x4 and 5x5x5. So my advise is either to buy official rubiks.com 4x4x4/5x5x5 or borrow some that u can practise with. If u solely practise the Eastsheen and borrow official ones in Orlando u will not be used to them and hence u have a large handicap. The 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 won't have to be brand new rubiks.com of course. They could be old Arxon or Mefferts or any other which have the same mechanism as the current rubiks.com ones. Tiled ones are also allowed as long as each face has tiles of a distinct color. And also the color of all cubies (the plastic pieces) should be same so as not to give any recognition advantage ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Peter Douthwright" <pdouthwright0513@r...> wrote: > Will Eastsheen cubes be allowed in the wc2005 in Florida? > > Are they allowed in other "official" competitions? > > Was considering buying a 4X4X4 & a 5X5X5, but did not want to if they are not allowed into officials contests. > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
564. Re: The world Championship In Florida
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 12:38:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Short and sad answer is : NO! How do you know? I've already searched on rubiks.com for puzzle restrictions and haven't found any. Besides organizational rules they only refer to the WCA rules which don't restrict puzzle brands at all. > The 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 won't have to be brand new rubiks.com of course. > They could be old Arxon or Mefferts or any other which have the same > mechanism as the current rubiks.com ones. Tiled ones are also allowed > as long as each face has tiles of a distinct color. And also the color > of all cubies (the plastic pieces) should be same so as not to give > any recognition advantage ;-) I sure hope so, I'd like to use a tiled Meffert 5x5 if I can't use my Eastsheen (I might want to use it anyway, it could become better than my Eastsheen once it is lubed). Cheers! Stefan

Joel. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > Hi Joel, > > maybe you should have a look at Pedro's "Magical F2L Tricks". > > Also, why don't you start analyzing what you already know? You know a > specific cuber who's faster than you, so try to find out why *he* is > faster. Maybe compare the number of twists and the number of cube > turns for a start (I'd also be interested in these numbers). > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > Hey everybody, > > > > I am not sure if this post will be usefull for my, but I'll try > > anyway :). > > > > I think I have found a pretty nice area of improvement for me. When > > DanH was visiting me a few weeks ago, we had a few (a lot, actually) > > of races, and he would sometimes say when he finished the cross, 1st > > pair, 2nd pair, etc., and I noticed that he was much faster during > > the F2L, but I would usually catch up during the LL phase.. Both > > ending with about the same time. (sometimes, when he was solving F2L > > really fast, I thought, 'oh well, he's just saying that :)', > > remember Dan? ;)). Anyway, today, I timed my F2L and LL (without OLL > > regognition) seperately, and I think I barely average sub 10 for the > > F2L. Maybe around 11 seconds, but around 6 seconds for the last > > layer (just estimating, I didnt make notes yet.. maybe I should). > > > > Do any cubers here have tips to really speed up that F2L? I think I > > know most shortcuts, but maybe I have to cut out some cube rotations > > that I do automatically. But how can I train this? Does anyone else > > here recognize the same 'weak spot'? > > > > -Joël.

speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

575. Sub-2 Second E-Permutation?
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 22:21:53 -0000

For those of you who don't know what the E permutation is (not to
insult anyone of course), it switches UFR<->UFL corners, and UBR<-
>UBL corners. This case has troubled me for quite some time, mostly
because my previous algorithm took ~2.4 seconds to execute. In the
overall scheme of things that's not bad execution time, but my
desire to have all my permutations under 2 seconds has prevented any
level of contentment. (sorry I'm rambling so much guys/girls) I've
found an alg after some playing around, and it's a great improvement
to my previous one. Here it is:

x'(U'R U L'U'R'U)(r2 U R')(U'L'U R U')

I'm not sure whether someone else has found this alg previously, but
it's very fluid after some practice. My times for executing this
case are ~2.1 seconds, but I think it will be sub2 after I 'master'
it.

Anyway, I'm sorry for such the long post regarding just a single LL
case, but I was so excited to find it I couldn't help myself.

Happy Cubing!

-Richard





576. stackmat re-build
From: "lilbeyond" <lilbeyond@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 22:52:19 -0000

i really want to get the 2nd generation of stackmat because u can carry
the timer itself everywhere. anyone every try to separate the mat and
the timer for the original generation stackmat? if yes can u please
show me how to do that, cause i dont wanna spend money to get a new
timer.

uwe




577. Re: [Speed cubing group] Sub-2 Second E-Permutation?
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 16:10:42 -0700 (PDT)

hehe nice i use something similiar except i hold it in a different way. visit www.planet-puzzle.com and go to the PLL evolution page. and do the n7: (r') R U'R'D - R U R'U'w U'w - R'U R D - R'U'R my best time for it was 1.96 :P. only problem is since you do a D turn you must be good with your pinky or the finger b4 it LATERZ! --- richy_jr_2000 <richy_jr_2000@...> wrote: > For those of you who don't know what the E > permutation is (not to > insult anyone of course), it switches UFR<->UFL > corners, and UBR<- > >UBL corners. This case has troubled me for quite > some time, mostly > because my previous algorithm took ~2.4 seconds to > execute. In the > overall scheme of things that's not bad execution > time, but my > desire to have all my permutations under 2 seconds > has prevented any > level of contentment. (sorry I'm rambling so much > guys/girls) I've > found an alg after some playing around, and it's a > great improvement > to my previous one. Here it is: > > x'(U'R U L'U'R'U)(r2 U R')(U'L'U R U') > > I'm not sure whether someone else has found this alg > previously, but > it's very fluid after some practice. My times for > executing this > case are ~2.1 seconds, but I think it will be sub2 > after I 'master' > it. > > Anyway, I'm sorry for such the long post regarding > just a single LL > case, but I was so excited to find it I couldn't > help myself. > > Happy Cubing! > > -Richard > > > > __________________________________ Yahoo! Mail Mobile Take Yahoo! Mail with you! Check email on your mobile phone. http://mobile.yahoo.com/learn/mail
578. Re: Sub-2 Second E-Permutation?
From: metgorubiks <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 23:19:49 -0000

For that PLL I use F R' F' L F R F' L2' x' U' R U L U' R' U http://geocities.com/metgorubiks/pll_73.mpeg Here is a video of how I do it. I can do this one some what fast. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > For those of you who don't know what the E permutation is (not to > insult anyone of course), it switches UFR<->UFL corners, and UBR<- > >UBL corners. This case has troubled me for quite some time, mostly > because my previous algorithm took ~2.4 seconds to execute. In the > overall scheme of things that's not bad execution time, but my > desire to have all my permutations under 2 seconds has prevented any > level of contentment. (sorry I'm rambling so much guys/girls) I've > found an alg after some playing around, and it's a great improvement > to my previous one. Here it is: > > x'(U'R U L'U'R'U)(r2 U R')(U'L'U R U') > > I'm not sure whether someone else has found this alg previously, but > it's very fluid after some practice. My times for executing this > case are ~2.1 seconds, but I think it will be sub2 after I 'master' > it. > > Anyway, I'm sorry for such the long post regarding just a single LL > case, but I was so excited to find it I couldn't help myself. > > Happy Cubing! > > -Richard
579. Re: Sub-2 Second E-Permutation?
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 23:46:47 -0000

Hi Richard, Congratulations! Very good. I found it in the form of B L' B' R B L B' R2 F' L F R F' L' F. David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > For those of you who don't know what the E permutation is (not to > insult anyone of course), it switches UFR<->UFL corners, and UBR<- > >UBL corners. This case has troubled me for quite some time, mostly > because my previous algorithm took ~2.4 seconds to execute. In the > overall scheme of things that's not bad execution time, but my > desire to have all my permutations under 2 seconds has prevented any > level of contentment. (sorry I'm rambling so much guys/girls) I've > found an alg after some playing around, and it's a great improvement > to my previous one. Here it is: > > x'(U'R U L'U'R'U)(r2 U R')(U'L'U R U') > > I'm not sure whether someone else has found this alg previously, but > it's very fluid after some practice. My times for executing this > case are ~2.1 seconds, but I think it will be sub2 after I 'master' > it. > > Anyway, I'm sorry for such the long post regarding just a single LL > case, but I was so excited to find it I couldn't help myself. > > Happy Cubing! > > -Richard
580. New Game
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 May 2005 23:53:05 -0000

Hi All,

I got a new game:
start the time
close your eyes
mix the cube 25 moves
open your eyes
solve the cube
stop the timer.

DJ

591. new record idea
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 May 2005 20:55:17 -0000

Since it takes more than one person to get a new category on
speedcubing's record page I was thinking I'd post my idea here.

Generate a 25 move scramble.
Start the timer.
Do the scramble as fast as possible.
Stop the timer.
Verify it (maybe see if doing it backwards solves it)

Cubists with more experience in scrambling cubes should be able to do
better.




592. Re: Sub-2 Second E-Permutation?
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 May 2005 21:48:38 -0000

I also "discovered" a very very similar algorithm, and the only effort required was to log on to www.cubezone.be and check out Lars V's E permutation that everyone was shouting about not so long ago. Perhaps you missed it ;) DanH :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > For those of you who don't know what the E permutation is (not to > insult anyone of course), it switches UFR<->UFL corners, and UBR<- > >UBL corners. This case has troubled me for quite some time, mostly > because my previous algorithm took ~2.4 seconds to execute. In the > overall scheme of things that's not bad execution time, but my > desire to have all my permutations under 2 seconds has prevented any > level of contentment. (sorry I'm rambling so much guys/girls) I've > found an alg after some playing around, and it's a great improvement > to my previous one. Here it is: > > x'(U'R U L'U'R'U)(r2 U R')(U'L'U R U') > > I'm not sure whether someone else has found this alg previously, but > it's very fluid after some practice. My times for executing this > case are ~2.1 seconds, but I think it will be sub2 after I 'master' > it. > > Anyway, I'm sorry for such the long post regarding just a single LL > case, but I was so excited to find it I couldn't help myself. > > Happy Cubing! > > -Richard
593. Re: new record idea
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 May 2005 21:50:55 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ben King" <grsbmd@y... > wrote: > Since it takes more than one person to get a new category on > speedcubing's record page I was thinking I'd post my idea here. > > Generate a 25 move scramble. > Start the timer. > Do the scramble as fast as possible. > Stop the timer. > Verify it (maybe see if doing it backwards solves it) > > Cubists with more experience in scrambling cubes should be able to do > better. That would be interesting. On videos I've seen some guys scramble quite fast using a scramble algorithm and I've been wondering how fast they are. You can easily verify using this page: http://thearufam.brinkster.net/cube/wrapplet.asp Cheers! Stefan
594. Re: F2L help! :)
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 May 2005 21:52:45 -0000

To Joel: Yes I remember, I think you thought I was saying it so fast to intimidate you or wind you up, but it didn't work ;) BUt I was actually finding the pairs that fast ;) I was imagining chasing Macky ;) On the cross... I heard some guy has a fantastic cross page on his website, with examples and rules and everything. Maybe you could try that out :) Dan :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > Hi Joel, > > maybe you should have a look at Pedro's "Magical F2L Tricks". > > Also, why don't you start analyzing what you already know? You know a > specific cuber who's faster than you, so try to find out why *he* is > faster. Maybe compare the number of twists and the number of cube > turns for a start (I'd also be interested in these numbers). > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > Hey everybody, > > > > I am not sure if this post will be usefull for my, but I'll try > > anyway :). > > > > I think I have found a pretty nice area of improvement for me. When > > DanH was visiting me a few weeks ago, we had a few (a lot, actually) > > of races, and he would sometimes say when he finished the cross, 1st > > pair, 2nd pair, etc., and I noticed that he was much faster during > > the F2L, but I would usually catch up during the LL phase.. Both > > ending with about the same time. (sometimes, when he was solving F2L > > really fast, I thought, 'oh well, he's just saying that :)', > > remember Dan? ;)). Anyway, today, I timed my F2L and LL (without OLL > > regognition) seperately, and I think I barely average sub 10 for the > > F2L. Maybe around 11 seconds, but around 6 seconds for the last > > layer (just estimating, I didnt make notes yet.. maybe I should). > > > > Do any cubers here have tips to really speed up that F2L? I think I > > know most shortcuts, but maybe I have to cut out some cube rotations > > that I do automatically. But how can I train this? Does anyone else > > here recognize the same 'weak spot'? > > > > -Joël.

602. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Sub-2 Second E-Permutation?
From: Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 May 2005 18:32:31 -0700 (PDT)

I'm kind of set back that I overlooked it! I've looked at Lars' PLL page quite a few times. Regardless, I'm hoping I can get this case under two seconds. It would bring my total sub2 second cases to 16/21. I feel like the remaining 5 cases will be nearly impossible to bring to sub2 seconds. I've decided to focus more on improving my OLL now. Is it reasonable to shoot for having most orientations under 1.5 seconds? I'm not sure where orientations should be on average. -Richard --- Dan <dan_j_harris@...> wrote: > I also "discovered" a very very similar algorithm, > and the only > effort required was to log on to www.cubezone.be and > check out Lars > V's E permutation that everyone was shouting about > not so long ago. > Perhaps you missed it ;) > > > DanH :) > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > "richy_jr_2000" > <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > > For those of you who don't know what the E > permutation is (not to > > insult anyone of course), it switches UFR<->UFL > corners, and UBR<- > > >UBL corners. This case has troubled me for quite > some time, > mostly > > because my previous algorithm took ~2.4 seconds to > execute. In the > > overall scheme of things that's not bad execution > time, but my > > desire to have all my permutations under 2 seconds > has prevented > any > > level of contentment. (sorry I'm rambling so much > guys/girls) > I've > > found an alg after some playing around, and it's a > great > improvement > > to my previous one. Here it is: > > > > x'(U'R U L'U'R'U)(r2 U R')(U'L'U R U') > > > > I'm not sure whether someone else has found this > alg previously, > but > > it's very fluid after some practice. My times for > executing this > > case are ~2.1 seconds, but I think it will be sub2 > after I 'master' > > it. > > > > Anyway, I'm sorry for such the long post regarding > just a single LL > > case, but I was so excited to find it I couldn't > help myself. > > > > Happy Cubing! > > > > -Richard > > > Discover Yahoo! Have fun online with music videos, cool games, IM and more. Check it out! http://discover.yahoo.com/online.html

or are these two being mass produced as two versions?
