605. what should i do after i am done with the F2L, OLL and PLL algorithms????
From: James Benedict Caares <ben41sbr2@...>
To: speedsolving rubikscube <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 12 May 2005 23:40:21 -0700 (PDT)

ei everybody,

i am almost done with the OLLs, only 8 algorithms to go, i am done with the F2L and PLL..........what should i do after all of this???? will this improve my sub35 seconds average???.................help me!!!!

J.B.



---------------------------------
Yahoo! Mail
Stay connected, organized, and protected. Take the tour

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



606. Re: [Speed cubing group] what should i do after i am done with the F2L, OLL and PLL algorithms????
From: François Sechet <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 08:51:03 +0200 (CEST)

practice will do... I'm at 16.85 best average, and i didn't even bother to learn the OLLs yet. I think by the time I was at 35s, I still did 1st layer then middle layer then 2 OLLs and that's where I started doing 2 PLLs instead of 4-5 :-P. Anyway, just practice, the OLLs are no miracle solution, if you can do the OLL in say 3-4s but it takes you 5s to recognize the LL case (and find the alg you have to use there)... Execution time is not the key, recognition is. It'll never take you more than 4-5s to do the alg (unless... well... you know what I mean) but if it takes you, say, 4s to recognize the OLL, 2s to see the PLL, plus the 20s to do the F2L, that's where you'll be losing most of your time. Just practice, i bet in one month of regular (not even freaky 5hours/day) practice you'll already be at 25 something, maybe even better. Franï¿½ois --- James Benedict Caares <ben41sbr2@...> a ï¿½crit: --------------------------------- ei everybody, i am almost done with the OLLs, only 8 algorithms to go, i am done with the F2L and PLL..........what should i do after all of this???? will this improve my sub35 seconds average???.................help me!!!! J.B. --------------------------------- Yahoo! Mail Stay connected, organized, and protected. Take the tour [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] --------------------------------- Yahoo! 607. Re: [Speed cubing group] what should i do after i am done with the F2L, OLL and PLL algorithms????
From: Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 01:06:54 -0700 (PDT)

Francois made excellent points here. At best learning OLL improved my LL by 1.5 seconds. The easiest way to improve your times from this point is to focus on the f2l. And the amount of algs you have to learn to improve on this is 0 anyway. Work on minimizing cube rotations, and solving your f2l fluidly without stalls. -Richard --- Fran���ois Sechet <frsechet@...> wrote: > practice will do... I'm at 16.85 best average, and i > didn't even bother to learn the OLLs yet. I think by > the time I was at 35s, I still did 1st layer then > middle layer then 2 OLLs and that's where I started > doing 2 PLLs instead of 4-5 :-P. Anyway, just > practice, the OLLs are no miracle solution, if you > can > do the OLL in say 3-4s but it takes you 5s to > recognize the LL case (and find the alg you have to > use there)... Execution time is not the key, > recognition is. 608. Very fast cubes?
From: "bryanosaurus" <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 08:25:44 -0000

I'm relatively new to speedcubing, and my cube is pretty fast.
However, after watching some videos I've noticed cubes that are so
loose that a tap sends that side spinning - any suggestions on how to
get my cube to move faster? I have two cubes, one is a white DIY
without arched centers and the other is a regular Rubiks model with
arched centers. I have used Rubik's cube lube and also tried silicon
spray. I've loosened the screws on my white cube but it pops all the
time.

thanks

bryan




609. Re: what should i do after i am done with the F2L, OLL and PLL algorithms????
From: "Ben Marx" <godsalgorithm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 08:38:09 -0000

Hey. I'm in almost the exact same boat as you are. I know all the 41 F2L algs, the 21 PLL, and all the two-step OLL algs. I'm currently averaging in the mid to low 30's. Aside from my own fears that i've reached the limit of my own dexterity, I've realized that by far my biggest weakness is the F2L. I believe this is the hardest part for most cubers to improve. I've just begun to try to spot a first-layer corner on the U-layer AS i'm placing a pair. I think this is a good step in working on spotting the pairs quicker. I use all triggerized versions of the F2L pair algs, which (for me at least) can be executed faster, even though each alg average about 1 move longer than the algs that Fridrich uses. Problem is I find algs that are done just by me left hand, are significantly slower. So strengthening your week hand might do some good as well. Just a couple ideas. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, James Benedict Caares <ben41sbr2@y...> wrote: > ei everybody, > > i am almost done with the OLLs, only 8 algorithms to go, i am done with the F2L and PLL..........what should i do after all of this???? will this improve my sub35 seconds average???.................help me!!!! > > J.B. > > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! Mail > Stay connected, organized, and protected. Take the tour > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
610. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: what should i do after i am done with the F2L, OLL and PLL algorithms????
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 03:45:52 -0500

I think another useful thing to try would be experimenting with a Petrus or block style F2L. The more you know about things like that, the more lucky cases you can take advantage of. Another good tip I rarely hear mentioned is to use working corners. When a corner or an edge is already placed correctly, assuming it's not part of the last pair, you can insert it using a different open corner. That's an easy way to often save a couple of moves. Just remembering to do that when I see it has helped with my recent several second average improvement. Another things is to make sure you know all of your algs and can recognize them from multiple angles and quickly. My biggest problem is still large delays between pairs and looks. Minimal stopping is the key to fast times. That, and being named Shotaro... -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: Ben Marx<mailto:godsalgorithm@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Friday, May 13, 2005 3:38 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: what should i do after i am done with the F2L, OLL and PLL algorithms???? Hey. I'm in almost the exact same boat as you are. I know all the 41 F2L algs, the 21 PLL, and all the two-step OLL algs. I'm currently averaging in the mid to low 30's. Aside from my own fears that i've reached the limit of my own dexterity, I've realized that by far my biggest weakness is the F2L. I believe this is the hardest part for most cubers to improve. I've just begun to try to spot a first-layer corner on the U-layer AS i'm placing a pair. I think this is a good step in working on spotting the pairs quicker. I use all triggerized versions of the F2L pair algs, which (for me at least) can be executed faster, even though each alg average about 1 move longer than the algs that Fridrich uses. Problem is I find algs that are done just by me left hand, are significantly slower. So strengthening your week hand might do some good as well. Just a couple ideas. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, James Benedict Caares <ben41sbr2@y...> wrote: > ei everybody, > > i am almost done with the OLLs, only 8 algorithms to go, i am done with the F2L and PLL..........what should i do after all of this???? will this improve my sub35 seconds average???.................help me!!!! > > J.B. > > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! 611. [Speed cubing group] Re: new record idea
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 08:59:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bill MCGAUGH" <bmcgaugh49@m...> wrote: > Another thing is fun, in a warped sort of way, is to take a tournament > scramble, and > solve it with cube explorer...and then use the solution to "solve" the > cube...and see if you > can beat macky's times ;-) I barely can ;-) If Chris can do a 25 move scramble alg in 8 seconds then he should do a 20 move one in 6.4 seconds, so he'd beat Macky (assuming 15s) by a factor of 2.34 which means if you have a record average of 2.34*16.75s = 39.26s or better you should have a good chance to beat Macky this way. Btw, I'd suggest to directly produce random scrambles with Cube Explorer instead. They're not only a bit shorter but also actually more uniformly distributed. Cheers! Stefan
612. Re: new record idea
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 09:03:38 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > If we do start this category I'd like to try it. I wonder if we get > 15 seconds to examine the algorithm and try to plan out how we will > execute it? :) > > Chris > > P.S. No I really am serious about the inspection time ;-) Nah, scrambling itself isn't that interesting. It's a dull boring annoying activity to scramble the cube, only solving is fun (note to the non-cubers out there: yes, I know for you it's the other way around). So I'm only interested in how to spend less time for scrambling and then why would I add any time for "inspection"? If scrambling were an interesting activity itself than I'd agree with inspection, but... Cheers! Stefan
613. [Speed cubing group] Re: what should i do after i am done with the F2L, OLL and PLL algorithms????
From: "Ben Marx" <godsalgorithm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 09:04:20 -0000

"When a corner or an edge is already placed correctly, assuming it's not part of the last pair, you can insert it using a different open corner. That's an easy way to often save a couple of moves." Ah, very good advice. My old method was a working corner method to solve the entire F2L, and i didn't even think of doing that when I swtiched over to the pairs. That should definitely help. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > I think another useful thing to try would be experimenting with a Petrus or block style F2L. When a corner or an edge is already placed correctly, assuming it's not part of the last pair, you can insert it using a different open corner. That's an easy way to often save a couple of moves. Just remembering to do that when I see it has helped with my recent several second average improvement. Another things is to make sure you know all of your algs and can recognize them from multiple angles and quickly. My biggest problem is still large delays between pairs and looks. Minimal stopping is the key to fast times. That, and being named Shotaro... > > -Mike Bennett > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Ben Marx<mailto:godsalgorithm@g...> > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@y ahoogroups.com> > Sent: Friday, May 13, 2005 3:38 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: what should i do after i am done with the F2L, OLL and PLL algorithms???? > > > Hey. 614. Re: what should i do after i am done with the F2L, OLL and PLL algorithms????
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 10:57:18 -0000

Well.. First of all, if there are still any cases (F2L, OLL or PLL) that you don't like, then I suggest you should try to find other versions of those algoritms that you do like. (It took me quite some time to get to the point where I like all my LL algs). For almost each algorithms, there are alternatives. I send some e-mails a couple of days ago to another speedcuber who also has about the same times as you... If you are interested, I can forward them to you... They might be usefull for you as well.. :). Good luck! - Joël. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, James Benedict Caares <ben41sbr2@y...> wrote: > ei everybody, > > i am almost done with the OLLs, only 8 algorithms to go, i am done with the F2L and PLL..........what should i do after all of this???? will this improve my sub35 seconds average???.................help me!!!! > > J.B. > > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! Mail > Stay connected, organized, and protected. Take the tour > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
615. [Speed cubing group] Re: Sub-2 Second E-Permutation?
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 10:59:37 -0000

Hey Richard... How do you time yourself when you time things you do in 2 seconds? Do you do this on the stackmat? - Joël. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > I'm kind of set back that I overlooked it! I've > looked at Lars' PLL page quite a few times. > Regardless, I'm hoping I can get this case under two > seconds. It would bring my total sub2 second cases to > 16/21. I feel like the remaining 5 cases will be > nearly impossible to bring to sub2 seconds. > > I've decided to focus more on improving my OLL now. > Is it reasonable to shoot for having most orientations > under 1.5 seconds? I'm not sure where orientations > should be on average. > > -Richard > --- Dan <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > I also "discovered" a very very similar algorithm, > > and the only > > effort required was to log on to www.cubezone.be and > > check out Lars > > V's E permutation that everyone was shouting about > > not so long ago. > > Perhaps you missed it ;) > > > > > > DanH :) > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > > "richy_jr_2000" > > <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > > > For those of you who don't know what the E > > permutation is (not to > > > insult anyone of course), it switches UFR<->UFL > > corners, and UBR<- > > > >UBL corners. This case has troubled me for quite > > some time, > > mostly > > > because my previous algorithm took ~2.4 seconds to > > execute. In the > > > overall scheme of things that's not bad execution > > time, but my > > > desire to have all my permutations under 2 seconds > > has prevented > > any > > > level of contentment. (sorry I'm rambling so much > > guys/girls) > > I've > > > found an alg after some playing around, and it's a > > great > > improvement > > > to my previous one. Here it is: > > > > > > x'(U'R U L'U'R'U)(r2 U R')(U'L'U R U') > > > > > > I'm not sure whether someone else has found this > > alg previously, > > but > > > it's very fluid after some practice. My times for > > executing this > > > case are ~2.1 seconds, but I think it will be sub2 > > after I 'master' > > > it. > > > > > > Anyway, I'm sorry for such the long post regarding > > just a single LL > > > case, but I was so excited to find it I couldn't > > help myself. > > > > > > Happy Cubing! > > > > > > -Richard > > > > > > > > > > Discover Yahoo! > Have fun online with music videos, cool games, IM and more. Check it out! > http://discover.yahoo.com/online.html
616. SV: [Speed cubing group] Re: Sub-2 Second E-Permutation?
From: "Terje Kristensen" <terje.kristensen@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 13:07:44 +0200

Do the same permutations 10 or 20 times in a row, time it and divide the time by 10 or 20 ... gives you a good idea of your avg speed :) Terje -----Opprinnelig melding----- Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Joël van Noort Sendt: 13. mai 2005 13:00 Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Emne: [Speed cubing group] Re: Sub-2 Second E-Permutation? This case has troubled me for quite > > some time, > > mostly > > > because my previous algorithm took ~2.4 seconds to > > execute. 617. Re: [Speed cubing group] what should i do after i am done with the F2L, OLL and PLL algorithms????
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 11:06:57 -0000

Hmm.. I am not really sure if 'practice will do'... :S I think for LL, yes, practice will do after you have found algorithms that you like to execute... For F2L, I don't think practicing with a timer and all will do. I think it's very important to solve the cube without timing yourself, while actively thinking about the steps that you make, and try to find all the F2L shortcuts yourself. Joël. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, François Sechet <frsechet@y...> wrote: > practice will do... I'm at 16.85 best average, and i > didn't even bother to learn the OLLs yet. I think by > the time I was at 35s, I still did 1st layer then > middle layer then 2 OLLs and that's where I started > doing 2 PLLs instead of 4-5 :-P. Anyway, just > practice, the OLLs are no miracle solution, if you can > do the OLL in say 3-4s but it takes you 5s to > recognize the LL case (and find the alg you have to > use there)... Execution time is not the key, > recognition is. It'll never take you more than 4-5s to > do the alg (unless... well... you know what I mean) > but if it takes you, say, 4s to recognize the OLL, 2s > to see the PLL, plus the 20s to do the F2L, that's > where you'll be losing most of your time. Just > practice, i bet in one month of regular (not even > freaky 5hours/day) practice you'll already be at 25 > something, maybe even better. > François > --- James Benedict Caares <ben41sbr2@y...> a > écrit: > --------------------------------- > ei everybody, > > i am almost done with the OLLs, only 8 algorithms to > go, i am done with the F2L and PLL..........what > should i do after all of this???? will this improve my > sub35 seconds average???.................help me!!!! > > J.B. > > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! Mail > Stay connected, organized, and protected. Take the > tour > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! Groups Links > > To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! > Terms of Service. > > > > > > > _____________________________________________________________________ ________ > Découvrez le nouveau Yahoo! Mail : 1 Go d'espace de stockage pour vos mails, photos et vidéos ! > Créez votre Yahoo! Mail sur http://fr.mail.yahoo.com
618. SV: [Speed cubing group] Re: Sub-2 Second E-Permutation?
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 11:59:39 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Terje Kristensen" <terje.kristensen@w...> wrote: > Do the same permutations 10 or 20 times in a row, time it and divide the > time by 10 or 20 ... gives you a good idea of your avg speed :) > > Terje Don't forget to bring your cube bask to normal orientation and restore your grip between 2 tries, you'll have an even better idea of the cost in speedcubing conditions. Gilles.
619. SV: [Speed cubing group] Re: Sub-2 Second E-Permutation?
From: "Terje Kristensen" <terje.kristensen@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 14:59:06 +0200

Sorry, but i just figured that he wasnt actually timing a single solve, but multiple solves, and used the average. If you do 20 solves in a row, the time you would save / loose depending on your timer mecanism would not make a huge impact on the time. I might be wrong on this point though. Terje -----Opprinnelig melding----- Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@...m [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Joël van Noort Sendt: 13. mai 2005 14:46 Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Emne: SV: [Speed cubing group] Re: Sub-2 Second E-Permutation? Yeah.. The the question was, what kind of timer he uses. With these 2sec algorithms, you can't really compare unless you use the same timing method. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Terje Kristensen" <terje.kristensen@w...> wrote: > Do the same permutations 10 or 20 times in a row, time it and divide the > time by 10 or 20 ... gives you a good idea of your avg speed :) > > Terje > > -----Opprinnelig melding----- > Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Joël van > Noort > Sendt: 13. mai 2005 13:00 > Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Emne: [Speed cubing group] Re: Sub-2 Second E-Permutation? > > Hey Richard... > > How do you time yourself when you time things you do in 2 seconds? > Do you do this on the stackmat? > > - Joël. > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Richard Patterson > <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > > I'm kind of set back that I overlooked it! I've > > looked at Lars' PLL page quite a few times. > > Regardless, I'm hoping I can get this case under two > > seconds. It would bring my total sub2 second cases to > > 16/21. I feel like the remaining 5 cases will be > > nearly impossible to bring to sub2 seconds. > > > > I've decided to focus more on improving my OLL now. > > Is it reasonable to shoot for having most orientations > > under 1.5 seconds? I'm not sure where orientations > > should be on average. > > > > -Richard > > --- Dan <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > > I also "discovered" a very very similar algorithm, > > > and the only > > > effort required was to log on to www.cubezone.be and > > > check out Lars > > > V's E permutation that everyone was shouting about > > > not so long ago. > > > Perhaps you missed it ;) > > > > > > > > > DanH :) > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > > > "richy_jr_2000" > > > <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > > > > For those of you who don't know what the E > > > permutation is (not to > > > > insult anyone of course), it switches UFR<->UFL > > > corners, and UBR<- > > > > >UBL corners. This case has troubled me for quite > > > some time, > > > mostly > > > > because my previous algorithm took ~2.4 seconds to > > > execute. In the > > > > overall scheme of things that's not bad execution > > > time, but my > > > > desire to have all my permutations under 2 seconds > > > has prevented > > > any > > > > level of contentment. (sorry I'm rambling so much > > > guys/girls) > > > I've > > > > found an alg after some playing around, and it's a > > > great > > > improvement > > > > to my previous one. Here it is: > > > > > > > > x'(U'R U L'U'R'U)(r2 U R')(U'L'U R U') > > > > > > > > I'm not sure whether someone else has found this > > > alg previously, > > > but > > > > it's very fluid after some practice. My times for > > > executing this > > > > case are ~2.1 seconds, but I think it will be sub2 > > > after I 'master' > > > > it. > > > > > > > > Anyway, I'm sorry for such the long post regarding > > > just a single LL > > > > case, but I was so excited to find it I couldn't > > > help myself. > > > > > > > > Happy Cubing! > > > > > > > > -Richard > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Discover Yahoo! > > Have fun online with music videos, cool games, IM and more. Check > it out! > > http://discover.yahoo.com/online.html > > > > > _____ > > Yahoo! 620. Re: [Speed cubing group] what should i do after i am done with the F2L, OLL and PLL algorithms????
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 13:23:41 -0000

I am in no position to be giving advice, which is not what I am here to do. But I wanted to offer some first hand experience. This idea that Joel suggested, about not timing yourself for a bit and just concentrating on going slowly and looking ahead during the F2L is sound. I had read people offer the advice before, but it is difficult to comprehend when you are first starting. You see other cubers flying through the F2L and feel you need to go as fast as you can to try and keep pace (which you won't anyway). Since Joel was nice enough to offer me some good tips, I took him seriously and did exactly that for most of this week  didn't time myself, and only concentrated on solving the F2L without stopping, no matter how slowly it felt I was going. After only 3 days of doing that, I could feel I was finding the pieces better. So I did an average last night, and I already dropped nearly 2 seconds from my average. Sub 30 here I come! So listen to these guys, they know their stuff. (And thanks again!!) -Dave --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > Hmm.. I am not really sure if 'practice will do'... :S > > I think for LL, yes, practice will do after you have found > algorithms that you like to execute... For F2L, I don't think > practicing with a timer and all will do. I think it's very important > to solve the cube without timing yourself, while actively thinking > about the steps that you make, and try to find all the F2L shortcuts > yourself. > > Joël.

Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 06:31:28 -0700

After you've done F2L, OLL, PLL, personally, I'd go for some ice cream. 622. Re: SV: [Speed cubing group] Re: Sub-2 Second E-Permutation?
From: Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 12:05:42 -0700 (PDT)

Hi all, There are a few ways I've tried timing my algs. I guess the most common way, is probably similar to what Terje is describing. Starting from a computer timer, repeating the alg 5-10 times, and just find my average from there. I hope to get a webcam soon for recording videos, and I can be completely accurate in knowing my times. -Richard --- Terje Kristensen <terje.kristensen@...> wrote: > Sorry, but i just figured that he wasnt actually > timing a single solve, > but multiple solves, and used the average. 625. TurkZeka 2005/2 Puzzle Competition wil start at 14 May 2005 22:00:00 GMT.
From: "yilmazekici2002" <bilgi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 22:26:18 -0000

TurkZeka 2005/2 Puzzle Competition wil start at 14 May 2005
22:00:00 GMT.

This year, each competition (total 4 times in a year-this one is
second competition) is going to have 10 puzzles and these puzzle
competitions are open to all country.

Competitions will be published in only Turkish, English and
Japanese.

You will have exactly 7 days to submit the answers of the puzzles
via "Answer" form page, beginning from the puzzle's publishing date.


You should read information about answer format in puzzle text
carefully before answering. Each correct answer is 100 points and
additionally there are two types of bonus points.

One of the bonus points are given to the first 3 competitors who
give the correct answer (30, 20 and 10 point) and the other bonus
points are given depending on answering day, beginning from current
puzzle's publishing date (30, 25, 20, 15, 10 and 5 point).


Correct answers and solutions will be given when the next puzzle is
published. Your score will be updated when you post your answer. You
can see whether your answer is correct or not on the "Score Anlayze
Table". To compete, you have to sign up to the site and log in.


Please tell friends who are interested in puzzles about these
competitions and the site.


Our web address : http://www.turkzeka.com

---------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------

Aim : The site TurkZeka.Com was established with a purpose of
helping puzzle fans improve their ability of imaging, thinking,
finding winding key, heading conclusion, finding out the hidden
properties etc. and having nice and useful time at the same time.


Nonograms :

Total 5 new nonograms are published every day.

Nonograms' sizes : 10x10 - 15x15 - 20x20 - 25x25 - 30x30


New types of puzzles will posted coming soon. (Diamond, Mines...)


Just Solve & Enjoy...

626. Re: Huge optimal solver
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 May 2005 23:07:46 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Here are some algorithms which I suspect might be optimal: > > > > L2 F2 R2 D2 B2 U2 L' B2 U B2 L R' D' F' R' U2 F' D' F' R2 (20f) //3;1346 > > D2 L2 U2 B F' U2 F' L B2 D' F2 L2 F2 D F2 D2 U2 R' F' U2 (20f) // 3;1366 > > U L2 B2 U' B2 D2 R2 F U2 L' D' R2 D' B U R2 D2 R' F2 R' (20f) //3;1445 > > > > F2 U2 R2 D2 L U2 L F2 U2 R' D' B R' F' R B L' F' R2 U (20f) //90;1187 > > R2 B2 F' L2 B D2 L2 R' D2 B F' L2 U R2 B D2 U2 L2 F' R2 (20f) //90;1832 > > Actually 90;1832 above is not optimal (optimal is 19 moves). 3;1445 isn't optimal either - that one's optimal in 19 moves too.
627. Re: what should i do after i am done with the F2L, OLL and PLL algorithms????
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 14 May 2005 09:26:27 -0000

Hey! Just a little remark. U cannot refer to one of the cases for OLL/PLL as an _algorithm_. An algorithm is how u do something, not what is to be done. A case is like a task. So another version of an algorithm doesn't make sense. Or it might possible mean u find another way to perform it. Likewise u can't say another sequence for an algorithm, cause then it's a different algorithm!! Sequence and algorithm is the same. At least when it comes to talking bout cube cases. So what u should have said was to find an algorithm/sequence and a way to perform it that suits u for _each_ of the cases in OLL/PLL ... Well this is how i understand it anyway. If im wrong please let me know :D Most ppl will still understand what is meant. But some might get confused when the terminology is not used consistently ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > Well.. First of all, if there are still any cases (F2L, OLL or PLL) > that you don't like, then I suggest you should try to find other > versions of those algoritms that you do like. (It took me quite some > time to get to the point where I like all my LL algs). For almost > each algorithms, there are alternatives. > > I send some e-mails a couple of days ago to another speedcuber who > also has about the same times as you... If you are interested, I can > forward them to you... They might be usefull for you as well.. :). > > Good luck! > > - Joël. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, James Benedict Caares > <ben41sbr2@y...> wrote: > > ei everybody, > > > > i am almost done with the OLLs, only 8 algorithms to go, i am done > with the F2L and PLL..........what should i do after all of this???? > will this improve my sub35 seconds average???.................help > me!!!! > > > > J.B. > > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > > Yahoo! Mail > > Stay connected, organized, and protected. Take the tour > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

629. Newbie
From: "pentium6700" <pentium6700@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 15 May 2005 05:53:51 -0000

I'm relatively new to speed cubing, definetly new to this group, but I
think I'm pretty good and I want an opinion. Rather than using web
sites, friends, books, or java applets, I developed my own system a
week after laying my hands on the cube. It's been about three months
and I've refined it to the point where my average is a minute and a
half, and my non-lucky record is fifty five seconds. What does
everybody think?




630. Re: [Speed cubing group] Newbie
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 15 May 2005 00:58:02 -0500

I'd be much more interested in finding out how many moves it actually takes you on average, how many steps and how efficient they are, and how easy the recognition of your steps is. These will give you a much better estimate of whether or not your method is viable for serious speedcubing in comparison with the other widely used systems. An average of under 60 moves and easy recognition will put you near the other systems, assuming you know your method well. -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: pentium6700<mailto:pentium6700@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Sunday, May 15, 2005 12:53 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Newbie I'm relatively new to speed cubing, definetly new to this group, but I think I'm pretty good and I want an opinion. Rather than using web sites, friends, books, or java applets, I developed my own system a week after laying my hands on the cube. It's been about three months and I've refined it to the point where my average is a minute and a half, and my non-lucky record is fifty five seconds. What does everybody think? ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Yahoo! Groups Links a.. 631. Re: [Speed cubing group] Newbie
From: "pentium6700" <pentium6700@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 15 May 2005 06:09:48 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > I'd be much more interested in finding out how many moves it actually takes you on average, how many steps and how efficient they are, and how easy the recognition of your steps is. These will give you a much better estimate of whether or not your method is viable for serious speedcubing in comparison with the other widely used systems. An average of under 60 moves and easy recognition will put you near the other systems, assuming you know your method well. > > -Mike Bennett Well, I feel ridiculous now. I just counted a few tries... if you count turning a face twice (half way around) and turning opposite faces simultaneously as TWO moves, not one, (for example (LR') is two moves and so is (F2)), it's about 115 moves. I guess I need to find some shortcuts...
632. Re: [Speed cubing group] Newbie
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 15 May 2005 01:20:58 -0500

Actually, I solve with the Roux method, and it uses lots of slice turns, and seeing as half turns are generally accepted as single moves outside of the fewest moves community (in which there is a roaring debate about this as we type), I think it's safe to measure those with Slice Turn Metric. The moves you described are both counted as single moves in this metric. Using quarter turn metric, most of even the top solvers would count more than 60 or even 65 moves, in my estimatation. That would still most likely leave you with a number around 100 or so, which is all well and good for a beginner, especially homemade solution, but you should still look for ways to optimize it, even if it's only a few moves here and there. Try to minimize moves that cancel eachother out when possible, like the ends of certain algorithms when you realize you'll have to turn around and undo them at the beginning of the next. Anywho, would you care to describe your method? You've piqued my late night curiosity. =) -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: pentium6700<mailto:pentium6700@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Sunday, May 15, 2005 1:09 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Newbie --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h<mailto:mikebennett_one@h>...> wrote: > I'd be much more interested in finding out how many moves it actually takes you on average, how many steps and how efficient they are, and how easy the recognition of your steps is. These will give you a much better estimate of whether or not your method is viable for serious speedcubing in comparison with the other widely used systems. An average of under 60 moves and easy recognition will put you near the other systems, assuming you know your method well. > > -Mike Bennett Well, I feel ridiculous now. I just counted a few tries... if you count turning a face twice (half way around) and turning opposite faces simultaneously as TWO moves, not one, (for example (LR') is two moves and so is (F2)), it's about 115 moves. I guess I need to find some shortcuts... ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Yahoo! Groups Links a.. 633. My Method
From: "pentium6700" <pentium6700@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 15 May 2005 06:32:27 -0000

I'm guessing that if I count the double moves as one the total will go
down to about 80 because I use A LOT of doubles at the end. My method
goes in layers, and I hear many of them do but have yet to research
that. I may not at all. I like making my own, and call those who
used the booklet that comes with the cube to solve it cheaters.
Anyway, I do the top edges, then corners, then middle edges. All of
those are just kind of... done. I don't have "steps" in my mind, I
just see and do what is necessary. Then I have a move that switches
two adjacent bottom corners and a move that switches both pairs of
adjacent bottom corners. Next, I have a single move that re-orients
three corners, but not necessarily correctly the first time I use it.
I may have to re-orient the cube itself, then do the sequence two or
three more times. Then, I have a move that shuffles three bottom
edges around. Finally, I finish up with any of three sequences that
solve the three possible situations at that point.

week. I HATE IT!!! They get really bad and need to be taped down
after a week and a half... Any ideas about what to do? Theories
about why it's ALWAYS THE STUPID ORANGE ONES?!??!??

637. Re: [Speed cubing group] My Method
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 15 May 2005 02:04:42 -0500

I highly recommend not necessarily learning a bunch of algorithms for the first two layers, but at least looking at sites that explain it. The more you understand how and why the pieces you're moving around behave like they do, the easier you can see how to move them around the way you want to. First two layers is key for decreasing your times. Using a very beginner last layer method with fewer algorithms to learn than yours, I've managed times in the low and mid 20's. That method involved a sequence and its inverse to flip edges, one to swap two corners sometimes done twice, one and its reflection to to orient corners in also sometimes done twice, and another and its inverse to rotate three edges. The approach you're taking is closer to a 4 look CLL+ELL (Corners last layer+Edges last layer). There are fewer distinct cases to learn than OLL+PLL, and it's easier to recognize, in my opinion. Anyway, good luck with your method and remember to slow down and concentrate on your first two layers and minimizing delays. As always, happy cubing. -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: pentium6700<mailto:pentium6700@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Sunday, May 15, 2005 1:32 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] My Method I'm guessing that if I count the double moves as one the total will go down to about 80 because I use A LOT of doubles at the end. My method goes in layers, and I hear many of them do but have yet to research that. I may not at all. I like making my own, and call those who used the booklet that comes with the cube to solve it cheaters. Anyway, I do the top edges, then corners, then middle edges. All of those are just kind of... done. I don't have "steps" in my mind, I just see and do what is necessary. Then I have a move that switches two adjacent bottom corners and a move that switches both pairs of adjacent bottom corners. Next, I have a single move that re-orients three corners, but not necessarily correctly the first time I use it. I may have to re-orient the cube itself, then do the sequence two or three more times. Then, I have a move that shuffles three bottom edges around. Finally, I finish up with any of three sequences that solve the three possible situations at that point. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Yahoo! Groups Links a.. To visit your group on the web, go to: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/<http://groups.yahoocom/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/> b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscribe> c.. 639. Re: [Speed cubing group] My Method
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 15 May 2005 02:29:35 -0500

The number of looks refers to the number of steps you use to solve the last layer. 3 looks=3 steps. They're called looks because generally, you're solving with a memorized sequence, so you're recognizing a case and performing an algorithm. While you're performing it, you should be looking ahead to the the state your cube will be in so as to minimize delays. When you orient pieces, that means they're flipped to face the direction they're supposed to face, though they're not necessarily in the correct spots. When you permute them, you're moving the pieces to their correct places, or at least to specific places you want them to go, and not necessarily conserving their orientation. CLL+ELL stands for Corners Last Layer+Edges Last Layer in much the same way OLL+PLL represents Orient and Permute Last Layer. CLL means you orient and permute the corners in one step (or two shorter steps). ELL is the same, but with edges. OLL is when you orient all of your last layer corners and edges at the same time. PLL is where you permute them all. -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: Bryan Mytko<mailto:bmytko@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Sunday, May 15, 2005 2:18 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] My Method I'm kinda new to speedcubing and I'm not sure about the terminology when people say "# look". What exactly does say, 4 look CLL+ELL mean? thanks bryan Mike Bennett wrote: > I highly recommend not necessarily learning a bunch of algorithms for > the first two layers, but at least looking at sites that explain it. > The more you understand how and why the pieces you're moving around > behave like they do, the easier you can see how to move them around > the way you want to. First two layers is key for decreasing your times. > > Using a very beginner last layer method with fewer algorithms to learn > than yours, I've managed times in the low and mid 20's. That method > involved a sequence and its inverse to flip edges, one to swap two > corners sometimes done twice, one and its reflection to to orient > corners in also sometimes done twice, and another and its inverse to > rotate three edges. > > The approach you're taking is closer to a 4 look CLL+ELL (Corners last > layer+Edges last layer). There are fewer distinct cases to learn than > OLL+PLL, and it's easier to recognize, in my opinion. Anyway, good > luck with your method and remember to slow down and concentrate on > your first two layers and minimizing delays. As always, happy cubing. > > -Mike Bennett > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: pentium6700<mailto:pentium6700@...> > To: > speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > > Sent: Sunday, May 15, 2005 1:32 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] My Method > > > I'm guessing that if I count the double moves as one the total will go > down to about 80 because I use A LOT of doubles at the end. My method > goes in layers, and I hear many of them do but have yet to research > that. I may not at all. I like making my own, and call those who > used the booklet that comes with the cube to solve it cheaters. > Anyway, I do the top edges, then corners, then middle edges. All of > those are just kind of... done. I don't have "steps" in my mind, I > just see and do what is necessary. Then I have a move that switches > two adjacent bottom corners and a move that switches both pairs of > adjacent bottom corners. 640. Re: My Method
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 15 May 2005 08:00:16 -0000

To give you an idea, though I am a self-proclaimed "cheater" :) you should be able to do the first two layers in 35 moves or less on average with *LOTS* of practice (the real pros use around 32 moves or less on average). Though many of us spent times learning lots of sequences, they can all be discovered with intuition and time/practice. A lot of people never look up anything about the first two layers, and come up with the optimal sequences. I would say to not worry about your last layer technique just yet, but to really practice decreasing the number of moves it takes you to solve the first two layers. This doesn't mean time yourself, it means to just sit down with a cube for 5 minutes or more and solve the first two layers in as few moves as possible. This helps you to see new things. One of my main "drills" when I practice is to count the number of moves it takes me to solve the cube, taking as much time as I feel like taking. I don't do any "fewest moves" tricks, just my normal system, but with any helpful tricks I see. I personally regret being a "cheater" a little bit, so if you can keep your non-cheater status and figure out first two layers stuff on your own, that would be awesome! One thing to realize though, last layer algorithms are to speed cubing as opening lines are to chess. You can try to discover them yourself, but why reinvent the wheel when it would take you months to do so, and you still may not find the optimal sequences? Eventually you'll reach a point where you have to learn more last layer algorithms to speed up. Just realize that memorizing algs for the last layer is just a necessity of speedcubing (unless you are an *incredible* prodigy IHMO). Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pentium6700" <pentium6700@y...> wrote: > I'm guessing that if I count the double moves as one the total will go > down to about 80 because I use A LOT of doubles at the end. My method > goes in layers, and I hear many of them do but have yet to research > that. I may not at all. I like making my own, and call those who > used the booklet that comes with the cube to solve it cheaters. > Anyway, I do the top edges, then corners, then middle edges. All of > those are just kind of... done. I don't have "steps" in my mind, I > just see and do what is necessary. Then I have a move that switches > two adjacent bottom corners and a move that switches both pairs of > adjacent bottom corners. Next, I have a single move that re-orients > three corners, but not necessarily correctly the first time I use it. > I may have to re-orient the cube itself, then do the sequence two or > three more times. Then, I have a move that shuffles three bottom > edges around. Finally, I finish up with any of three sequences that > solve the three possible situations at that point.
641. Sunday Contest
From: nascarjon2001 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 15 May 2005 14:27:33 -0000

Since we haven't been getting very many contestants over the last
couple of weeks I figured I'd plug the contest this week. Come on
and
compete with us... http://www.geocities.com/nascarjon2001


Jon

the times were

643. Product Reviews: White DIY, Magic, stickers, 25th aniversary, 4x4,...
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 15 May 2005 19:39:28 -0000

Alright folks, so I've lost all my speedcubes and given away a few
4x4s and stuff.

But lately I've been trying to amass a large fleet of cubes. I
ordered over $150 worth of cubing materials and have finished
preliminary evaluations.

***Items***
Rubiks.com:
Harry Potter Magic, two 25th Aniversary cubes, offical lube, offical
sets of stickers, print-your-own-design stickers, White DIY,
standard 4x4

CubeSmith.com:
8 sets of 3x3 stickers

Skiffy.com:
1000 cube-sized washers



So last night I was sitting here tinkering with the Magic and 2 hrs
flew by! The wires are holding up well, but one of my links seem to
be noticably offset, perhaps someone here can help with that. It
could be that I was doing a set of moves repeatedly and gradually
moved the wires to an *unhappy place*.

Long story short, the 25th Aniversary cubes are crap! I took out a
mechanism and did some sanding, put on pieces from my mediocre cube
(off-the-shelf Hasbro aged 9 months) (my best speedcube at the time
sadly enough), and put on a set of the official stickers.

Those stickers didn't last... Why? They were the out-dated laminated
crap that we always warn you about. Those would have held up for
about 10 days in [my] normal cubing conditions. I took off the
center caps to the mechnism to see that..., yup no screws, hurray!
Bleh.... It was good for one thing... placing in my cube robot. Then
I found out that the stickers were overly reflective for my RGB
sensors and so replaced them with oversized, colored
electrical/plastic tape.

The offical cube lube worked beautifully on my robot's cube. I am
starting to really love this citrus smelling milky cube wax they
offer. So that cube now happens to be donated (or indedefinate loan)
to the computer engineering department after the conclusion of my
project. (I will try to bring it back for some one credit
independent study, 400-lvl control systems course, or just join an
undergrad lab and get some office space to work on it in my spare
time.)

So then the remaining kernal was mated with the remaining pieces. So
the twenty 25th Aniversary pieces on a half-worn-in Hasbro
mechanism. That became my "best" speedcube for a few weeks, but I
use the term "best" very loosely here.

I am now finding the arched centers a terrible thing to have. (Not
necessarily in general, but this case has already made up my mind it
seems.)

So I took out the other 25th Anniversary cube out of it's shiny
hexagonal-prism box since I was lacking cubes. I haven't done
anythig to it for the past 6 weeks I've had it. I feel it's not
worth saving. I don't think there is much I can do for it and the
amount of work I put into it will have severly deminishing returns.

Ok so the main problem is that it came too loose, it's lacking the
desired springy-ness, the plastic seems to be harder, when you turn
a face it sounds like something is dying in there. In this case
lubing of any form didn't help. In fact it made the slipping problem
worst. It locks up as much as the disasterous Meffert's Assembly,
lol.

So that's just going to sit pretty on it's lovely hexagonal base on
top of my monitor for the time being. On to the exciting stuff.

I followed StefanP.'s washer idea on "twisty". You can find it here:
http://twistypuzzles.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=3723&highlight=washers
I am still waiting for the order to arrive however. They are proving
a cool little utility set. I mainly want it for the knife. Ordering
from Europe would have been just $6.50 or so. But in the states,
there is an extra $13 shippping fee which took me ages to decide on
paying. More about the washers next week.

I got a bunch of 3x3 stickers from Jello33/cubesmith. They arrived
either yesterday or the day before, and I am very impressed with the
service. It only took them like 2 days. I would like to place an
order for other stuff like Eastsheen 2x2, 4x4, Oddzon 4x4, 5x5, 5x5
supercubing, and pyraminx... oh but wait, he doesn't sell any non-
sqaure stickers. Hem... and also the 5x5 superset are done in the
standard color-scheme and not made to my liking. (I'm sure the
stickers are quality, just that I use this bizzare color-scheme.)

So to that, I hope taht in the future cubesmith.com will be a more
central shopping hub for our community. Surely, I see it's potential
to be. It would be great if he can provide other types of stickers
(megaminx?), injectable cube lube (I mean wax, since it's the new
hip thing to do now), and DIY kits... I would like it if we could
rally enough support as a community and push for a bulk order of
these DIY kits and sell them at discounted rates at cubesmith.com,
where by discounted I mainly refer to the shipping costs that
rubik.com is a bit hefty on for my budget. Jello33 is THE MAN!!!

While I try to pick enough things to get my total over the $10 mark
to avoid the extra shipping costs, lets talk about the DIY kits.

I got the white one a few days ago along with a brand-spankin' 4x4.
(To replace the 4x4 my frined took to Bombay as a graduation/parting
gift.) Now my old one was never schemed to my liking, and was a bit
on hte stiff side requiring obnoxiously frequent lubrication
(silicone spray, I still recommend it a couple weeks AFTER an
injection wax treatment, if you can afford it.)

The one I have been using has this terrible purple side, you know
what I'm talking about... the little Eastsheen one. It fits my hands
beautifully (I have small girlish hands, as I found out when
comparing to other cometitors at Toronto, and when I say other
competitiors I am thining about that 7 year old Polish girl, lol)

That one locks up and slips too much. There ARE a LOT of moving
parts in there. (I think euqual or worst then the standard 5x5 the
last time I counted.) I am afraid to re-scheme my Eastsheen
cubes...., Ah! but wait we have cubesmith now.... rescued again :)!

The Meffert's 4x4 still lies broken in my room, been like that for
over two years, cuz every time I fix a fragil center piece it breaks
again in a week or two along with another center :(. Ya, I recommend
against Meffert's 4x4s (this doesn't count the Eastsheen ones. You
see, they are not manufactured to good control standards I believe,
or at least wasn't at the time of my purchese 4 years ago. Bubbles
in the plactic underneth the stickers, tons of internal
imperfections. Had to spend days to sand out properly. Though the
kernal is dismantel-able unlike standard ones that are superglued in
on top of the 9 screws.

So THIS new 4x4 came 3 days after I placed my order! Very expedicant
service, I'm quite pleased. I applied the usual techniques I do for
4x4's, then an injection of wax, then a reschemeing. Referencing
Stefan's page on how to minimally rescheme a 4x4, I found that none
of those algorithms applied directly to my situation, my color-
scheme is the devil..., it's as far away from standard as possible.
It requies some 4-cycle of sticker faces. I managed to do it in 14
moves though! This required one twist of a corner piece which may be
considered "cheating" to some purists.

Anyhow, all that took up no more then a half hour and my cube was
PERFECT! I would say a bit on the loose side though, and that's in
accordance with MY style... I have a very loose/shifty/rapid
movement style. It's borderline to the point where I perform starts
AND *stops* of my turns. So the final note, I have a marvolously
loose 4x4 sppedcube. It came that way, better then if it was too
tight. but I'll eventually have to figure out how to tighten one of
those things.

Best of all is the White DIY 3x3 kit I recidved in the same shipment
as the 4x4. Put it together in about 2-3 hours. I was going to hold
out for the washers but, it's doing pretty well without it for the
time being. WHITE, dang that looks freaky! Ihave very high standards
when it comes to preparing a cube and some say that I have been
quite spoiled with the quality of my speedcubes. (Those who have
tested them at competitions.) Yet I lost them all on the bus over
the past year, *sigh*. WHY, OH LORD WHY HAVE THEY FORSAKEN ME, lol.

But the white one is fantastic. Only took about 3rhs to produce a
magnificent speedcube! It surpassed my standards. No real need to
wear it in. I'm going to have to tighten it further though after I
use it's loose state to practice my "accuracy" as Tyson, Macky, and
others have advocated.

I think I'm going to order a FLEET (a word I adapted from JonM) of
these. Get a dozen identical speedcubes suited up for Sunday
contests and stuff would be great.

So this was the story of how a cuber in speedcubing-proverty, is
rising to speedcube-wealth. More to come I hope; catch you on the
flip side!


-Doug






644. Re: Product Reviews: White DIY, Magic, stickers, 25th aniversary, 4x4,...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 15 May 2005 20:53:55 -0000

Hi Doug,

nice extensive review, thanks :-) Some comments...

> So last night I was sitting here tinkering with the Magic and 2 hrs
> flew by! The wires are holding up well, but one of my links seem to
> be noticably offset, perhaps someone here can help with that.

I have a few of these, too, and I can tell you they come this way. I'm
not at all happy with them in mint condition. I got them in order to
build new magics, e.g. a master magic. So I take out the strings, cut
holes in the sides of the paper where they should be, and insert the
strings again, but differently. A bit hard to explain, though, and if
you only have one it's maybe a bit risky...
> Ok so the main problem is that it came too loose, it's lacking the
> desired springy-ness, the plastic seems to be harder, when you turn
> a face it sounds like something is dying in there. In this case
> lubing of any form didn't help. In fact it made the slipping problem
> worst. It locks up as much as the disasterous Meffert's Assembly,
> lol.

When it's too loose you might be able to fix it even though they have
rivets instead of screws. They're pretty much impossible to pull out
but you might be able to push them in deeper. Have a closeup look at a
rivet (that I got with a black DIY, I assume this is what's in your
cube, too):
http://stefan-pochmann.de/foo/diy_rivet.jpg

> I followed StefanP.'s washer idea on "twisty". You can find it here:
> http://twistypuzzles.com/forum/viewtopic.php?
t=3723&highlight=washers
> I am still waiting for the order to arrive however. They are proving
> a cool little utility set. I mainly want it for the knife. Ordering
> from Europe would have been just $6.50 or so. But in the states,
> there is an extra $13 shippping fee which took me ages to decide on
> paying. More about the washers next week.

Uh, I do hope you'll get the tool. I didn't know this and I was
surprised when I got it. They say it's a welcome present for ordering
online, apparently sort of an appetizer also mentioned in the printed
catalog (which I don't have). I don't like the knife that much, I was
mainly interested in the washers, so for me it was just a nice extra.

> I got a bunch of 3x3 stickers from Jello33/cubesmith. They arrived
> either yesterday or the day before, and I am very impressed with the
> service. It only took them like 2 days. I would like to place an
> order for other stuff like Eastsheen 2x2, 4x4, Oddzon 4x4, 5x5, 5x5
> supercubing, and pyraminx... oh but wait, he doesn't sell any non-
> sqaure stickers.

Not true, look at the square-1 stickers :-) He'll probably have
Megaminx stickers very soon, too. I've never seen a Pyraminx with bad
stickers so I don't know whether that'd make sense ;-)

> It requies some 4-cycle of sticker faces. I managed to do it in 14
> moves though!

Can you tell those 14 moves? Even though the resulting scheme might
not be interesting for anyone but you (;-) such a short algorithm
sounds nice. How many stickers did you need to peel off?

> Best of all is the White DIY 3x3 kit I recidved in the same shipment
> as the 4x4. Put it together in about 2-3 hours. I was going to hold
> out for the washers but, it's doing pretty well without it for the
> time being.

Yes, washers won't make a big difference here. The screw head is large
enough to be the limit for how far you can pull out the center, so the
spring is not almost fully compressed like with smaller screw heads.
This and the somewhat ground spring ends prevent major scratching. I'd
however suggest to try adding washers *outside* of the centers,
between center and the kernel spider. This should stabilize the
centers which I think is good, it might work against pops.

Cheers!
Stefan

I made a beginner method for my webpage. It's a working corner method. Check

Any tips to make it better? Input is appreciated.

647. Re: Product Reviews: White DIY, Magic, stickers, 25th aniversary, 4x4,...
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 15 May 2005 23:30:39 -0000

Oh what I meant was 14 sticker moves... the actual number of turns was probably quite large since I was brute forcing it bit by bit. My scheme is: U=white, F=blue, R=red, L=yellow, B=orange, and D=green. To get it there I only needed to cycle 3 "pairs" of edge stickers and move around 8 corner stickers..., one on each conrer. I like your washer idea. -Doug (currently trying to break 2mins on the 4x4) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > Hi Doug, > > nice extensive review, thanks :-) Some comments... > > > So last night I was sitting here tinkering with the Magic and 2 hrs > > flew by! 648. How do you tighten a 4x4?
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Mon, 16 May 2005 01:49:09 -0000

My new Hasbro 4x4 is poping quite frequently and is getting really
loose. It's only been a day or two since I got it too.

Any ideas on how to tighten them? I'm sure someone here has tried to
do this before.


-Doug




649. Re: My Method
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 May 2005 02:46:42 -0000

welcome to the group I used to use a method that sounds very similar to what you describe, also self-taught over months of trial and error practice one summer before 7th grade when the cube first exploded on the scene--long before you could just look up these algs on the internet. I used that method until just the past few months when I started to learn Fridrich. I definitely see value in trying to figure it out on your own, but if you're serious about getting really fast, you'll almost certainly have to learn some algs that are already out there everywhere on the Net. my times with that old method were just over a minute, with an occasional sub 60. Just since March, my average has dropped to 47 seconds, and I very rarely have a solve over 60 [only when I get a brain cramp]. And my times are slowly but steadily dropping literally every week as I add new algs and get faster on the others. I definitely still need a lot more work on the F2L, though. agree that that's a huge part of getting faster times. good luck! Kirk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > To give you an idea, though I am a self-proclaimed "cheater" :) you > should be able to do the first two layers in 35 moves or less on > average with *LOTS* of practice (the real pros use around 32 moves or > less on average). > > Though many of us spent times learning lots of sequences, they can all > be discovered with intuition and time/practice. A lot of people never > look up anything about the first two layers, and come up with the > optimal sequences. > > I would say to not worry about your last layer technique just yet, but > to really practice decreasing the number of moves it takes you to > solve the first two layers. This doesn't mean time yourself, it means > to just sit down with a cube for 5 minutes or more and solve the first > two layers in as few moves as possible. This helps you to see new things. > > One of my main "drills" when I practice is to count the number of > moves it takes me to solve the cube, taking as much time as I feel > like taking. I don't do any "fewest moves" tricks, just my normal > system, but with any helpful tricks I see. > > I personally regret being a "cheater" a little bit, so if you can keep > your non-cheater status and figure out first two layers stuff on your > own, that would be awesome! > > One thing to realize though, last layer algorithms are to speed cubing > as opening lines are to chess. You can try to discover them yourself, > but why reinvent the wheel when it would take you months to do so, and > you still may not find the optimal sequences? Eventually you'll reach > a point where you have to learn more last layer algorithms to speed > up. Just realize that memorizing algs for the last layer is just a > necessity of speedcubing (unless you are an *incredible* prodigy IHMO). > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pentium6700" > <pentium6700@y...> wrote: > > I'm guessing that if I count the double moves as one the total will go > > down to about 80 because I use A LOT of doubles at the end. My method > > goes in layers, and I hear many of them do but have yet to research > > that. I may not at all. I like making my own, and call those who > > used the booklet that comes with the cube to solve it cheaters. > > Anyway, I do the top edges, then corners, then middle edges. All of > > those are just kind of... done. I don't have "steps" in my mind, I > > just see and do what is necessary. Then I have a move that switches > > two adjacent bottom corners and a move that switches both pairs of > > adjacent bottom corners. Next, I have a single move that re- orients > > three corners, but not necessarily correctly the first time I use it. > > I may have to re-orient the cube itself, then do the sequence two or > > three more times. Then, I have a move that shuffles three bottom > > edges around. Finally, I finish up with any of three sequences that > > solve the three possible situations at that point.
650. Is 100% silicone spray flammable?
From: Mark Longridge <mark@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 May 2005 03:29:25 -0400

It seems there is no way to order silicone spray
through the mail in Canada. I'm wondering if it's
on the restricted items list for Canada Post.
No Canadian sellers of silicone spray on ebay either.

I tried to order the Castle brand of spray and they
only ship within the Continental United States.

What brands of silicone spray are Canadians using
and where can I buy it? Thanks a bunch.

Mark

http://www.geocities.com/the3dcube




653. Re: Is 100% silicone spray flammable?
From: "Mike G" <m.godfrey@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 May 2005 09:01:32 -0000

Can't help with the stockists, but, yes, the propellant can be highly
flammable. You should be able to buy it in non-spray form, though (I
get it in a tube).

Mike

657. Re: Is 100% silicone spray flammable?
From: "Rob Butler" <futuese@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 May 2005 16:45:12 -0000

Hi Mark, I just take the easy way out and use "Motomaster Silicone Spray". It is easy to find in the automotive section of any Canadian Tire I've been to in either Ontario or Manitoba - presumably available from coast to coast. It comes in an aerosol can with an orange/reddish lid (they have several different types of lubes in the same section so do be careful which one you pick up). It is cheap and easy to find. It seems to work quite well on my cubes but since it is the only brand I have ever used I cannot rate its performance against other brands. I usually take my cubes apart, spray the silicone on all the cubies, and wait for the pieces to dry before reassembling. If I do this the cube is ready to go as soon as it is reassembled. Rob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Mark Longridge <mark@c...> wrote: > It seems there is no way to order silicone spray > through the mail in Canada. I'm wondering if it's > on the restricted items list for Canada Post. > No Canadian sellers of silicone spray on ebay either. > > I tried to order the Castle brand of spray and they > only ship within the Continental United States. > > What brands of silicone spray are Canadians using > and where can I buy it? Thanks a bunch. > > Mark
658. Vinyl sticker logo question
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: "cube" <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 16 May 2005 12:23:27 -0500

I recently purchased several sets of vinyl stickers for my 3x3x3's from Chris. The only real downside to them is the lack of a logo, without which my cube just looks a bit off. I intend to make my own logo on the white center cubie, but I don't know what I can use that won't rub right off the vinyl. I have permanent markers, paint, fabric paint, nailpolish, and other sets of stickers at my disposal. Has anyone else tried to make their own?

-Mike Bennett

659. Re: [Speed cubing group] Is 100% silicone spray flammable?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 May 2005 17:44:54 -0000

Hi! I was stupid enough to bring 2 cans of silicone spray to the 2nd GCD in Gütersloh. The stupid thing is that i brought it in my rucksack thinking it was much safer there than in my suitcase. Had it been there it would have been fine. But after a security scan of my rucksack they confiscated both cans (this was on my way out), and there was no way i could get them back later. One can did indeed say flammable on it, and the other even said _highly flammable_. So even if it should not really be flammable it will say so on the can, and may cause u trouble trying to transport in onboard aircrafts, at least as part of ur hand luggage ... *ugh* Luckily silicone spray is cheap ;-) There are actually some types of silicone sprays that are no legal here in Norway anymore, due to toxicity probably. Amongst others the black 3M spray is impossible to get hold of here. Same with Chestertone. And since it seems kinda impossible to get spray from one country to another in any legal way it's tough luck if u live in a restrictive country. Cubing was easier back in early 80's ;-) Slick cubing! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@n...> wrote: > It's been 8 hours. > > I guess if we never hear from Tyson again, the answer is "yes". > > /Lars > > On May 16, 2005, at 0:32, Tyson Mao wrote: > > > I'll get back to you on the subject of your post after I find a > > lighter. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On May 16, 2005, at 12:29 AM, Mark Longridge wrote: > > > >> It seems there is no way to order silicone spray > >> through the mail in Canada. I'm wondering if it's > >> on the restricted items list for Canada Post. > >> No Canadian sellers of silicone spray on ebay either. > >> > >> I tried to order the Castle brand of spray and they > >> only ship within the Continental United States. > >> > >> What brands of silicone spray are Canadians using > >> and where can I buy it? Thanks a bunch. > >> > >> Mark > > - - - - - - - - - - - - > "The mind is like a parachute. It doesn't work unless it's open." > --- Frank Zappa > > Lars Petrus - lars@l... http://lar5.com
660. TurkZeka 2005/2 Puzzle Competition
From: "yilmazekici2002" <bilgi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 May 2005 20:34:05 -0000

TurkZeka 2005/2 Puzzle Competition started on 14 May 2005 at
22:00:00 GMT.

This year, each competition (total 4 times in a year-this one is
second competition) is going to have 10 puzzles and these puzzle
competitions are open to all country.

Competitions will be published in only Turkish, English and
Japanese.

You will have exactly 7 days to submit the answers of the puzzles
via "Answer" form page, beginning from the puzzle's publishing date.


You should read information about answer format in puzzle text
carefully before answering. Each correct answer is 100 points and
additionally there are two types of bonus points.

One of the bonus points are given to the first 3 competitors who
give the correct answer (30, 20 and 10 point) and the other bonus
points are given depending on answering day, beginning from current
puzzle's publishing date (30, 25, 20, 15, 10 and 5 point).


Correct answers and solutions will be given when the next puzzle is
published. Your score will be updated when you post your answer. You
can see whether your answer is correct or not on the "Score Anlayze
Table". To compete, you have to sign up to the site and log in.


Please tell friends who are interested in puzzles about these
competitions and the site.


Our web address : http://www.turkzeka.com

---------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------

Aim : The site TurkZeka.Com was established with a purpose of
helping puzzle fans improve their ability of imaging, thinking,
finding winding key, heading conclusion, finding out the hidden
properties etc. and having nice and useful time at the same time.


Nonograms :

Total 5 new nonograms are published every day.

Nonograms' sizes : 10x10 - 15x15 - 20x20 - 25x25 - 30x30


New types of puzzles will posted coming soon. (Diamond, Mines...)


Just Solve & Enjoy...

--------------------------------------------------------------------
----------------------------------------

Yilmaz Ekici

(Owner & Administrator of TURKZEKA)



Our Editors :

ISMAIL TURK : Project & Software

OZTURK YILDIRIM : Category Puzzles

CENGIZHAN TEKIN : Statistics

TOMOAKI TOKUNAGA : Japanese Pages Translator

--------------------------------------------------------------------
-----------------------

web : http://www.turkzeka.com

e-mail : turkzeka@...





661. Re: Product Reviews: White DIY, Magic, stickers, 25th aniversary, 4x4,...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 May 2005 20:51:24 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > Oh what I meant was 14 sticker moves... the actual number of turns > was probably quite large since I was brute forcing it bit by bit. > > My scheme is: U=white, F=blue, R=red, L=yellow, B=orange, and > D=green. > > To get it there I only needed to cycle 3 "pairs" of edge stickers > and move around 8 corner stickers..., one on each conrer. Man, it took me forever to accomplish this. Centers were of course trivial, edges were easy but centers were quite hard. Now I also have 6 edge and 8 corner stickers wrong if I rotate a corner. How did you get it? Some sort of strategy or more or less random guessing? The latter was my master plan ;-) Cheers! Stefan

663. Re: Product Reviews: White DIY, Magic, stickers, 25th aniversary, 4x4,...
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 May 2005 22:12:13 -0000

Well I just had to think about it... I know that the centers are free to move around due to the availiblity of a 3 center piece cycle algorithm I know, and since you can cycle say (XXY) it will look like a two cycle. Thus no center stickers need to be chnaged. I noticed that there are only 3 edge-pairs that will not exist in the new scheme so that means that 6 edge stickers need to be moved. I know that none of the corners can be preserved since none of them exist on the new scheme. I checked each corner and noticed that there are two stickers that can belong to the new corners and thought that a minimal 8 might be possible. Then it took some guess work to see which corner should go where, with the knowledge that you can have two-corner cycles on the 4x4 without effecting other pieces. I quickly reduced the problem down to that of a 2x2, and since I already knew from experience that 8 is minimal on a 2x2, I knew everything would work out. Now to generate an optimal sequence for this.... what programs do this? -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y. > ..> wrote: > > Oh what I meant was 14 sticker moves... the actual number of turns > > was probably quite large since I was brute forcing it bit by bit. > > > > My scheme is: U=white, F=blue, R=red, L=yellow, B=orange, and > > D=green. > > > > To get it there I only needed to cycle 3 "pairs" of edge stickers > > and move around 8 corner stickers..., one on each conrer. > > Man, it took me forever to accomplish this. Centers were of course > trivial, edges were easy but centers were quite hard. Now I also have > 6 edge and 8 corner stickers wrong if I rotate a corner. How did you > get it? Some sort of strategy or more or less random guessing? The > latter was my master plan ;-) > > Cheers! > Stefan

669. [Speed cubing group] Re: Huge optimal solver
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Tue, 17 May 2005 15:32:39 -0000
