It might be the number of a particular case in one of his blindfold-solving systems, see http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/9589 On the other hand, it might be something else. ;) I really wish that in these irregular posts Richard would link to a web page (or even an earlier posting here) informing us (or reminding us) of what he is doing. No doubt it is very interesting -- a single case he mentioned a while back was intriguing because of its symmetry and depth. Mike
670. Re: Huge optimal solver
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 May 2005 18:47:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > Hi, > > I am new to the speedcubing, but I am trying to learn as much as possible. > > Can anyone tell me what 3;1346 (and all the others like that) mean? > > Thanks a lot. This is an element of the orientation subgroup. 3 denotes the edges to be flipped, in this case UF & UB, 1346 denotes the corners to be twisted convert to base 3 (21211212, of length 7 plus a filler (0, 1 or 2) to make the sum of the digits congruent to 0 mod 3) and this represents the number of twists each corner needs to be correctly oriented. > > -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- > Van: GameOfDeath2 [mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com] > Verzonden: zaterdag 14 mei 2005 1:08 > Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group] Re: Huge optimal solver > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > Here are some algorithms which I suspect might be optimal: > > > > > > L2 F2 R2 D2 B2 U2 L' B2 U B2 L R' D' F' R' U2 F' D' F' R2 (20f) //3;1346 > > > D2 L2 U2 B F' U2 F' L B2 D' F2 L2 F2 D F2 D2 U2 R' F' U2 (20f) // 3;1366 > > > U L2 B2 U' B2 D2 R2 F U2 L' D' R2 D' B U R2 D2 R' F2 R' (20f) //3;1445 > > > > > > F2 U2 R2 D2 L U2 L F2 U2 R' D' B R' F' R B L' F' R2 U (20f) //90;1187 > > > R2 B2 F' L2 B D2 L2 R' D2 B F' L2 U R2 B D2 U2 L2 F' R2 (20f) //90;1832 > > > > Actually 90;1832 above is not optimal (optimal is 19 moves). > > 3;1445 isn't optimal either - that one's optimal in 19 moves too. > > > > > _____ > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > * To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > <http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/> > > > * To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > <mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscri > be> > > > * Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service > <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/> . > > > ================================================ > De informatie opgenomen in dit bericht kan vertrouwelijk zijn en > is uitsluitend bestemd voor de geadresseerde. Indien u dit bericht > onterecht ontvangt, wordt u verzocht de inhoud niet te gebruiken en > de afzender direct te informeren door het bericht te retourneren. > ================================================ > The information contained in this message may be confidential > and is intended to be exclusively for the addressee. Should you > receive this message unintentionally, please do not use the contents > herein and notify the sender immediately by return e-mail. > ================================================ > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

minimum of 100 piece order to even consider bulk pricing.

Quite a lot of my orders are to overseas, and I can't put a $1 stamp
on a Supercube. :)

week including Alexandars star and Megaminx sets.

anyone hase suggestions for items or sticker sets they'd like to see
please let me know.

672. [Speed cubing group] Re: Huge optimal solver
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 May 2005 19:11:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" > <bbeer@g...> wrote: > > Can anyone tell me what 3;1346 (and all the others like that) mean? > > A good question. It might be the number of a particular case in one of > his blindfold-solving systems, see > http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/9589 > > On the other hand, it might be something else. ;) > > I really wish that in these irregular posts Richard would link to a web > page (or even an earlier posting here) informing us (or reminding us) > of what he is doing. No doubt it is very interesting -- a single case > he mentioned a while back was intriguing because of its symmetry and > depth. > > Mike These refer back to posts somewhere around numbers 16040-16080. Since it's now ply possible to search a few messages at a time I don't want to look for earlier similar posts. The particular topic here (or rather subtopic) is optimising of the orientation subgroup (fix the positions of the pieces but orient them). There are 94,518 inequivalent such positions. They can all be done in 20 moves (half turn metric) or less. At least 11 of these require 20 moves. Initially I'm trying to cut down the number of 20s. In those posts I listed some candidate positions (that CubeExplorer was taking a long time over. Two or 3 of those I subsequently found were optimal in 19 - hence the follow-ups. Still lots more candidates. In those earlier messages I think I had just uner 2400 to go. Now that figure is well under 1500.
673. Re: [Speed cubing group] Is 100% silicone spray flammable?
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 May 2005 19:13:29 -0000

Hi Per, Thanks for telling us about you cans being confiscated. I don't want to lose my lubricant if I fly to the Worlds in November. Perhaps the sponsors could have a "Cube Service Station" where people could clean and lube their cubes, sand their springs, swap springs and washers, etc. Have you looked into ordering the black 3M non-oil-based, non-toxic spray online, and having it shipped to you? I use it, having found it at an auto parts store. In the 80's I never used lube. I once tried graphite, which works very well except that it doesn't stay in the cube! :P Thanks, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hi! > > I was stupid enough to bring 2 cans of silicone spray to the 2nd GCD > in Gütersloh. The stupid thing is that i brought it in my rucksack > thinking it was much safer there than in my suitcase. Had it been > there it would have been fine. But after a security scan of my > rucksack they confiscated both cans (this was on my way out), and > there was no way i could get them back later. One can did indeed say > flammable on it, and the other even said _highly flammable_. So even > if it should not really be flammable it will say so on the can, and > may cause u trouble trying to transport in onboard aircrafts, at > least as part of ur hand luggage ... *ugh* > > Luckily silicone spray is cheap ;-) There are actually some types of > silicone sprays that are no legal here in Norway anymore, due to > toxicity probably. Amongst others the black 3M spray is impossible > to get hold of here. Same with Chestertone. And since it seems kinda > impossible to get spray from one country to another in any legal way > it's tough luck if u live in a restrictive country. Cubing was > easier back in early 80's ;-) > > Slick cubing! > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus > <lars@n...> wrote: > > It's been 8 hours. > > > > I guess if we never hear from Tyson again, the answer is "yes". > > > > /Lars > > > > On May 16, 2005, at 0:32, Tyson Mao wrote: > > > > > I'll get back to you on the subject of your post after I find a > > > lighter. > > > > > > Tyson Mao > > > MSC #631 > > > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > On May 16, 2005, at 12:29 AM, Mark Longridge wrote: > > > > > >> It seems there is no way to order silicone spray > > >> through the mail in Canada. I'm wondering if it's > > >> on the restricted items list for Canada Post. > > >> No Canadian sellers of silicone spray on ebay either. > > >> > > >> I tried to order the Castle brand of spray and they > > >> only ship within the Continental United States. > > >> > > >> What brands of silicone spray are Canadians using > > >> and where can I buy it? Thanks a bunch. > > >> > > >> Mark > > > > - - - - - - - - - - - - > > "The mind is like a parachute. It doesn't work unless it's open." > > --- Frank Zappa > > > > Lars Petrus - lars@l... http://lar5.com
674. Re: My Method
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 May 2005 19:44:04 -0000

Greeting Pentium, There are a few people who post here who do use there own methods and algorithms. Welcome. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pentium6700" <pentium6700@y...> wrote: > I'm guessing that if I count the double moves as one the total will go > down to about 80 because I use A LOT of doubles at the end. My method > goes in layers, and I hear many of them do but have yet to research > that. I may not at all. I like making my own, and call those who > used the booklet that comes with the cube to solve it cheaters. I think that by not solving it for themselves the first time they they miss out on a major opportunity to prove something to themselves. > Anyway, I do the top edges, then corners, then middle edges. All of > those are just kind of... done. I don't have "steps" in my mind, I > just see and do what is necessary. I place two middle edges, four bottom corners, the other two middle edges then the four bottom edges. I average between 36 and 54 moves to solve the cube, using about 30 moves to solve the first 2 levels. > Then I have a move that switches > two adjacent bottom corners and a move that switches both pairs of > adjacent bottom corners. I work on the top level next. I call those switching "two corners adjacent" and switching "two corners across." > Next, I have a single move that re-orients > three corners, but not necessarily correctly the first time I use it. > I may have to re-orient the cube itself, then do the sequence two or > three more times. There are no orientations which require the famous seven move sequence applied more than twice. > Then, I have a move that shuffles three bottom > edges around. Finally, I finish up with any of three sequences that > solve the three possible situations at that point. If I break the last level into four pieces I move the corners into place, reorient them, then reorient the edges and move the edges into place. I only use my own algorithms. Since I started cubing I try to do as much as possible at one go. I often solve the corners and flip over two edges at the same time. It does take time to find all 1211 last level algs, but I'm slowly getting there. I almost have a complete set of CLL and ELL. Congratulations on solving it on your own. David J
675. Re: Huge optimal solver
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 May 2005 19:53:34 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > These refer back to posts somewhere around numbers 16040-16080. Thanks! E.g. post 16069. I guess you don't have a progress page... I do understand the problem of searching back through the earlier posts; the thing is, though, that if /you/ don't do it, every potentially interested reader will have to do this painful searching himself. Or, more likely, will give up after five minutes. Much better if you just kept a record of the key post numbers yourself (for terminology, notation, last report, etc.) and included the most relevant post numbers when you next report on the project. All the best, Mike

677. Slice Moves?
From: "uberstuberizzle" <jestuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 May 2005 20:39:39 -0000

How do people who use corners first methods perform slice moves? I use

r R' and r' R, but I don't think thats the fastest way.




678. Yet another Beginner method
From: "uberstuberizzle" <jestuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 May 2005 20:48:01 -0000

http://www.stubers.org/jamesstuff/begmethod.htm

testing it on some victims...I mean friends... soon.




679. Re: Slice Moves?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 May 2005 22:54:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "uberstuberizzle" <jestuber@v...> wrote: > How do people who use corners first methods perform slice moves? I use > > r R' and r' R, but I don't think thats the fastest way. For me it depends on the environment, particularly of course the move right before and the move right after the slice turn. For example, I'd do (r (R' U))*4. It's two movements, but the R' combines nicely with the U. On the other hand, I pull the middle slice with my left ring finger when I do this OLL (yes I know that's actually more like an antislice): (M' R') U' R U' R' U2 R U' R r'. Ha! I do the slice move at the end as two moves :-) Cheers! Stefan

For DIY kits, that would be only about $650, and you'd make the money right back after a couple months of sales. Perhaps this way you make a slight profit and we buy for the same price but have an added convenicne of ordering cheaper and (IMHO) better stickers, thus driving down shipping time and costs. Offering washers too would be nice... a perfect addition to DIY kits... as would Rubik's Magic wires. 683. WARNING: careful with lube injectors
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 May 2005 23:59:28 -0000

OMG, it seems the slightest amount of force in the wrong direction and
the end of the lube injector can be pulled out even with the cap still
on.

I'm trying to clean up the mess right now and it seem the wax is quite
easily absorbed onto clothes...

Some of it I was able to salvage for my 5x5 though.

CubeSmith: consider bulk ordering Rubik's brand cube lube, it's great
stuff...

-Doug (making a mess as usual)

686. Re: Is 100% silicone spray flammable?
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 18 May 2005 03:24:19 -0000

I must concur with Rob. I get my silicone lubricant from Canadian Tire. It carries various types in its automotive section, all across the country. I use Jig-A-Loo, personally: http://jigaloo.nulko.com/en/silicone.html It is less than $10 there, plus you get the handy Canadian Tire money in return. Now who doesn't want Canadian Tire money? -Dave --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Rob Butler" <futuese@y...> wrote: > > Hi Mark, > > I just take the easy way out and use "Motomaster Silicone Spray". > It is easy to find in the automotive section of any Canadian Tire > I've been to in either Ontario or Manitoba - presumably available > from coast to coast. It comes in an aerosol can with an > orange/reddish lid (they have several different types of lubes in > the same section so do be careful which one you pick up). It is > cheap and easy to find. It seems to work quite well on my cubes but > since it is the only brand I have ever used I cannot rate its > performance against other brands. I usually take my cubes apart, > spray the silicone on all the cubies, and wait for the pieces to dry > before reassembling. If I do this the cube is ready to go as soon > as it is reassembled. > > Rob >
687. Question about algoritms
From: "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@...>
To: "'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com'" <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 18 May 2005 08:37:28 +0200

Hi all,

Today I started studying the algoritms on
http://cubefreak.hp.infoseek.co.jp/, but I did not understand all of them.
What do x, y, w and - mean in these algoritms? Are they layers? I currently
only use the following layer names: R (Right), L (Left), U (Up/Top), D
(Down/Bottom), F(Front) and B (Back). Notice that there is no definition for
the middle layers in each orientation.
================================================
De informatie opgenomen in dit bericht kan vertrouwelijk zijn en
is uitsluitend bestemd voor de geadresseerde. Indien u dit bericht
onterecht ontvangt, wordt u verzocht de inhoud niet te gebruiken en
de afzender direct te informeren door het bericht te retourneren.
================================================
The information contained in this message may be confidential
and is intended to be exclusively for the addressee. Should you
receive this message unintentionally, please do not use the contents
herein and notify the sender immediately by return e-mail.
================================================


688. Re: Question about algoritms
From: "Mikael" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 18 May 2005 12:07:17 -0000


Hello!

x,y,z refers to rotating the whole cube. Whereas x points to the
right, y towards you and z up. If you look at the java cubes you can
surely understand how it works. But note that the java-cubes use a
different notation than Macky does (the axis are not the same and
double layer turns are also noted differently).

Hope that helps,
Mikael

PS. Check speedcubing.com (-> Algorithms -> Notation) for a visual
explanation of the x,y,z notation.




689. Re: Cube Smith
From: "Koen Heltzel" <allyourbase@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 18 May 2005 13:21:24 -0000

Hey,

I just dropped by to say I'm very pleased with CubeSmith's stickers! I
ordered a shitload and received them very fast (considering I live in
Holland :P ).

Only 1 suggestion: I once got stickers from Ton Dennenbroek which came
with a little sticky layer on top of them which enabled you to put all
the stickers of a cube face on the cube at once.. Don't know how to
explain it.. my vocabulary sucks. Anyway... stickering a 5x5 for
example became very easy that way.

Thx Jello!!!

- Koen




690. Re: Cube Smith
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 18 May 2005 13:39:13 -0000

Hey Koen ! My opinion is that it's easier without the _applicator sheet_ which probably is the word u are looking for :-) If u are unlucky with the sheet u end up with the stickers not being straight on the cubies and it can be hard to reposition the whole sheet :-o. Not being straight u wera out the stickers with ur fingers much much faster. So i find i have more control doing one sticker at a time. But it sure takes a while on the 5x5x5 :-( In the end it's worth it. Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Koen Heltzel" <allyourbase@h...> wrote: > Hey, > > I just dropped by to say I'm very pleased with CubeSmith's stickers! I > ordered a shitload and received them very fast (considering I live in > Holland :P ). > > Only 1 suggestion: I once got stickers from Ton Dennenbroek which came > with a little sticky layer on top of them which enabled you to put all > the stickers of a cube face on the cube at once.. Don't know how to > explain it.. my vocabulary sucks. Anyway... stickering a 5x5 for > example became very easy that way. > > Thx Jello!!! > > - Koen

696. Re: WARNING: careful with lube injectors
From: nascarjon2001 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 18 May 2005 14:49:11 -0000


> I think that the Rubiks lube is some type of floor wax. I doubt
they manufacture it specificly for cubes.

It is actually called Shine Up and is manufactured by SC Johnson and
Son.


> Do most of you prefer Rubiks lube or silicone spray?

I truly hate the "Rubik's Cube Lube" and don't like any of the
silicone sprays that I have tried. Instead I use an old bottle of
Westley's Black Magic leather and vinyl restorer. It is a thick
liquid silicone that I apply to my cubes with a cotton swab. The
bottle is probably 15 years old and I haven't found anything
comparable on the shelves of the stores today.

Jon
http://www.geocities.com/nascarjon2001

699. Re: Question about algoritms
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 18 May 2005 16:51:59 -0000

Hi All, I just thought that I'd mention that this confusion happens, and will keep happening until the community unifies notation. :P Hi Bram, I use Q followed by F, L, U, B, R, or D to indicate rotating the whole cube. Q stands for "cube" so QR means that you rotate the whole cube clockwise like you would rotate the Right side clockwise When the 3x3x3 appeared David Singmaster used F, L, U, B, R, or D to indicate sides of the cube. I think he use ME and S to mean slices. When the 4x4x4 appeared he used the lower case letters f, l, u, b, r, d to mean slices. Some immediately extended this to the 3x3x3, since the meaning of M E and S: Middle, Equator, and Slice do not just fall into place and have to be memorized. Unfortunately most of the first people online did not use a lot of slices. They have since coopted the lower case to mean a slice and a side on the 3x3x3 for "finger tricks," and screwed up very clean notation. They also refuse to go back to the original usage. Oh well. Then there are the map maker's coordinates x, y, and z. I've yet to see a math class that didn't have someone get confused about axes. Because of that confusion, and since people use x, y, and z differently, Chris Hardwick recently suggested replacing them. I suggested Q for cube, but while people were interested, they didn't have websites. I guess a single set of letters for turns, slices, and cube rotations is too simple for people addicted to memorization. (That's a joke, people!) Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > Hi all, > > Today I started studying the algoritms on > http://cubefreak.hp.infoseek.co.jp/, but I did not understand all of them. > What do x, y, w and - mean in these algoritms? Are they layers? I currently > only use the following layer names: R (Right), L (Left), U (Up/Top), D > (Down/Bottom), F(Front) and B (Back). Notice that there is no definition for > the middle layers in each orientation. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr <david20708@g...> wrote: > Actually, z is towards you and y is up. > > On 5/18/05, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mikael" <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > > > Hello! > > > > x,y,z refers to rotating the whole cube. Whereas x points to the > > right, y towards you and z up. If you look at the java cubes you can > > surely understand how it works. But note that the java-cubes use a > > different notation than Macky does (the axis are not the same and > > double layer turns are also noted differently). > > > > Hope that helps, > > Mikael > > > > PS. Check speedcubing.com (-> Algorithms -> Notation) for a visual > > explanation of the x,y,z notation.
700. Re: Question about algoritms
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 18 May 2005 16:45:55 -0000

Classically, z would be upwards - but I guess that doesn't seem to be the case in cubing... In any case, if z is upwards, y should be away from you but if y is upward z should be towards you (in both cases assuming x is to the right) - at least assuming you want a right-handed orthonormal triad of unit vectors. : ) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mikael" <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > > Ooops! My bad, but if you look at the java-cube z is up ;). But you > are absolutely right. Y is up Z is towards you. > > Mikael > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Evan Gates <evan. > gates@g...> wrote: > > doesn't y point up and z points out towards you? > > > > -E > > > > On 5/18/05, Mikael <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > > > > > > Hello! > > > > > > x,y,z refers to rotating the whole cube. Whereas x points to the > > > right, y towards you and z up. If you look at the java cubes you > can > > > surely understand how it works. But note that the java-cubes use a > > > different notation than Macky does (the axis are not the same and > > > double layer turns are also noted differently). > > > > > > Hope that helps, > > > Mikael > > > > > > PS. Check speedcubing.com (-> Algorithms -> Notation) for a visual > > > explanation of the x,y,z notation. > > > > > > > > > > > > ________________________________ > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > To visit your group on the web, go to: > > > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > > > > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > > > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > > > > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of > Service.
701. Re: Question about algoritms
From: "Mikael" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 18 May 2005 21:32:56 -0000

Well, well... I hate cube rotation noted with x,y,z because I can't keep track of where which axis is pointing. I tried to be helpful but now I think I caused more confusion that anything else =D Until cube rotation notation is standardized I will just keep my cube orientated the same throughout my solve! Happy rotationless cubing everyone ;) Mikael --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Classically, z would be upwards - but I guess that doesn't seem to > be the case in cubing... > > In any case, if z is upwards, y should be away from you but if y is > upward z should be towards you (in both cases assuming x is to the > right) - at least assuming you want a right-handed orthonormal triad > of unit vectors. : ) > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mikael" > <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > > > > Ooops! My bad, but if you look at the java-cube z is up ;). But > you > > are absolutely right. Y is up Z is towards you. > > > > Mikael

Are there any cubers here from Iowa? I got an e-mail from someone who
works for a television station in Eastern Iowa asking for info about
Iowans that go to competitions. Her name is Danielle Wagner and you
can contact her directly at danielle.wagner@... since she doesn't
check this group.

Ian Winokur




703. Re: F2L help! :) + cross trainer
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 18 May 2005 23:25:09 -0000

I just checked back, and looks like this guy has added a cross trainer! I think you can get it here: www.cubestation.co.uk/cross/crosstraining.html Or go to www.cubestation.co.uk click on Solve the Cross, and then go to the bottom of that page and click the link there. I think he will add printable pages and finish it all off tomorrow. Dan :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n.. > .> wrote: > > > > On the cross... I heard some guy has a fantastic cross page on his > > website, with examples and rules and everything. Maybe you could try > > that out :) > > > > Dan :) > > Yeah, I think I've seen it and I like it a lot. If that guy could just > add a cross trainer it would be perfect. With this I mean a webpage > that lists scrambles with (let's say) 10-15 moves and also lists how > many moves are necessary to solve the cross. So I can print them and > then practice solving cross in shortest ways. I'll suggest it to him > next time we talk... > > Cheers! > Stefan

I will have a look at the algoritms again to see if I understand them now and get back to you if I don't. - Bram -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- Van: d_j_salvia [mailto:d_j_salvia@...] Verzonden: woensdag 18 mei 2005 18:52 Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group] Re: Question about algoritms Hi All, I just thought that I'd mention that this confusion happens, and will keep happening until the community unifies notation. :P Hi Bram, I use Q followed by F, L, U, B, R, or D to indicate rotating the whole cube. 707. [Speed cubing group] Re: Question about algoritms
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 19 May 2005 09:36:17 -0000

Hey! This discussion will keep recurring cause it's extremely bad notation. Easy as that. There is no consensus on what x,y,z is. Whether z is upwards or facing towards u and so on. The only thing that is clear is that when using x,y,z in algorithmic notation it means rotation about those respective axes. Again in which direction could cause confusion. So why not replace those with notation based on FRBLUD which we all agree on and doesn't cause any confusion? Let Rc = x, R'c = x' R2c= x2 and so on. This also extends to other puzzles where each face has well defined names, like the megaminx. Most common way is to use A,B,C,D,E,F,a,b,c,d,e,f i guess. Physical movement of the megaminx can easily be defined from those facenames. Adding brackets to avoid confusion. So we could have c(c)3 etc etc ... How could x,y,z ever extend to megaminx? :-P Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Evan Gates <evan.gates@g...> wrote: > didn't we get into this debate just a few weeks ago? > lol > > -E > > On 5/18/05, Mikael <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > > > > Well, well... > > I hate cube rotation noted with x,y,z because I can't keep track of > > where which axis is pointing. I tried to be helpful but now I think I > > caused more confusion that anything else =D > > > > Until cube rotation notation is standardized I will just keep my cube > > orientated the same throughout my solve! > > > > Happy rotationless cubing everyone ;) > > Mikael > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Classically, z would be upwards - but I guess that doesn't seem to > > > be the case in cubing... > > > > > > In any case, if z is upwards, y should be away from you but if y is > > > upward z should be towards you (in both cases assuming x is to the > > > right) - at least assuming you want a right-handed orthonormal triad > > > of unit vectors. : ) > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mikael" > > > <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Ooops! My bad, but if you look at the java-cube z is up ;). But > > > you > > > > are absolutely right. Y is up Z is towards you. > > > > > > > > Mikael > > > > > > > > > > ________________________________ > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > To visit your group on the web, go to: > > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.
708. Re: Question about algoritms
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 19 May 2005 10:42:46 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > This discussion will keep recurring cause it's extremely bad > notation. Easy as that. I agree wholeheartedly. But, sadly, this battle has been lost... we cannot expect so many people to change their notation now. :( And, in the end, it /is/ just notation. Mike
709. [Speed cubing group] Re: Question about algoritms
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 19 May 2005 12:43:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > How could x,y,z ever extend to megaminx? :-P Well, you could add the degrees, e.g. y72 for a fifth turn of the top face and everything below. Rotations for other faces could be written as a combination of x, y and z, for example z57 x313. Not sure these numbers would work. I think it would be easiest to have a sequence of rotations for each face that make this face the top face. Then to rotate the puzzle around any face, bring that face to top, rotate it with a clean multiple of y72, then bring it back where it came from. That all said, who cares about megaminx anyway? Cheers! Stefan
710. Re: F2L help! :) + cross trainer
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 19 May 2005 14:36:42 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n.. .> wrote: > I just checked back, and looks like this guy has added a cross > trainer! I think you can get it here: > www.cubestation.co.uk/cross/crosstraining.html Hi Dan, that's really cool, thanks a lot! (Too tired to continue the game after training the cross so much ;-) I guess you found the optimal lengths and number of solutions with computer help (which program?), so maybe most of the other solutions are somewhat more "magical". Below I list solutions and comments found by another human (me). Can you give numbers to the cases so it's easier to talk about them? I've simply numbered them from 1-15. On the webpage, it would be good to hide the optimal lengths. When I practice this, I'd like to know afterwards whether there's something better, not necessarily beforehand. Thanks for all the work. So far it's different than what I had in mind, but I like it a lot as well. What I had in mind is a program that generates random scrambles, maybe by solving two random cubes and concatenating their solutions to build the scramble. That would result in good scrambles with about 13 moves. I wouldn't have (your) human solutions so I wouldn't expect to learn as easily from it, but it would give me the opportunity to practice as often as I want to with new scrambles all the time. I must admit sometimes I exceeded the 15 seconds a bit and often I didn't have a clear vision of the solution, so I had to follow the pieces closely, think and turn slowly. That's part of why I'm not yet able to look ahead for the first F2L pair. I'd like to practice cross more often and then execute with closed eyes to force myself to see the solution clearly. Since you never have cube rotations I guess that can't be the way you execute your solutions. Can you show us how you execute them? 1) R D' B D' L F D Yippie, I beat you in QTM ;-) 2) D' F2 D2 R D F' Darn... 3) Same as yours. 4) Same as yours, though I rotated the cube with y first. 5) Same as yours. 6) x U L U' l U y' L2 D' Slightly different in the end. I save a quarter turn but pay with a cube rotation (or alternatively a B turn). Here's one I like, too, it's a bit longer but easier to execute (it's more similar to yours): x U L U' l D' U2 R2 7) L' F D B' L R' D I like yours a lot, too. Your B' start is a bit counter-intuitive since you turn the "correctly flipped" white/green edge into an incorrect one. I need to learn not to always see that as something bad. 8) F' B2 U R2 D' L I think I actually did (y' R' L2 D L2 D2 F) which is slightly different, not only because of the cube rotation. 9) Same as yours, though I started with y. 10) y' D2 L' D' L' R' D' +1 in HTM but same in QTM, and only <L,D,R> after initial rotation, so I'm not too unhappy ;-) 11) R B E' L F' Ha! Shorter than optimal ;-) 12) y2 D' R2 U F' D L2 Another one, quite similar to yours but with an inserted U to save the white/green early on: D' L2 U B' D R2. One less B' turn. 13) y' U2 L' D' R' F' L' B' Yeah yeah, I beat you in QTM ;-) But it took me a long time to actually execute it because my vision of the alg was all but clear, probably not only because of the overall length but because I turn all six sides :-) 14) I screwed this one and in the second attempt did 8 moves but had to do it slowly. Sigh... This is a hard one. Though your solution makes it look so easy, especially after your first three moves. I think my problem was that the white/orange edge was almost solved and I didn't think about moving it away. I had tried U B L' U' F2 R2. Unfortunately the white/green wasn't at UR before the R2. Something like this still happens to me too often. 15) Same as yours, but with a different order in the middle where we solve each piece individually: F' R' L B L2. You seem to switch between right and left areas of action. That's all for now... thanks again! Cheers! Stefan
711. New file uploaded to speedsolvingrubikscube
From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: 19 May 2005 16:04:07 -0000

Hello, This email message is a notification to let you know that a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the speedsolvingrubikscube group. File : /Notation Notebook/Notation for 3x3x3 and 4x4x4 Uploaded by : d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...> Description : The simplest notation You can access this file at the URL: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/files/Notation%20Notebook/Notation%20for%203x3x3%20and%204x4x4 To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit: http://help.yahoo.com/help/us/groups/files Regards, d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...>
712. Notation folder
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 19 May 2005 16:07:59 -0000

Hi Everybody,

I have created a folder in "Files" for notation schemes. Everyone
is invited to add their notation scheme to the file. This way in the
future when notation questions are asked by new members all the
notation can be found in one place.

Thanks,

David J




713. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: F2L help! :) + cross trainer
From: Rune Wesström <rune.wesstrom@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 20 May 2005 16:01:19 +0200

Hi Dan, Suppose, there exists an optimal five mover for the cross. During the inspection time you get sight of a six mover, which you can execute more or less blindly. Would you still, whith a reasonable probability, find that five mover? (That is, in practical game). R ----- Original Message ----- From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Thursday, May 19, 2005 4:36 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: F2L help! :) + cross trainer > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n.. > .> wrote: > > I just checked back, and looks like this guy has added a cross > > trainer! I think you can get it here: > > www.cubestation.co.uk/cross/crosstraining.html > > Hi Dan, > > that's really cool, thanks a lot! (Too tired to continue the game > after training the cross so much ;-) > > I guess you found the optimal lengths and number of solutions with > computer help (which program?), so maybe most of the other solutions > are somewhat more "magical". Below I list solutions and comments found > by another human (me). > > Can you give numbers to the cases so it's easier to talk about them? > I've simply numbered them from 1-15. On the webpage, it would be good > to hide the optimal lengths. When I practice this, I'd like to know > afterwards whether there's something better, not necessarily > beforehand. > > Thanks for all the work. So far it's different than what I had in > mind, but I like it a lot as well. What I had in mind is a program > that generates random scrambles, maybe by solving two random cubes and > concatenating their solutions to build the scramble. That would result > in good scrambles with about 13 moves. I wouldn't have (your) human > solutions so I wouldn't expect to learn as easily from it, but it > would give me the opportunity to practice as often as I want to with > new scrambles all the time. > > I must admit sometimes I exceeded the 15 seconds a bit and often I > didn't have a clear vision of the solution, so I had to follow the > pieces closely, think and turn slowly. That's part of why I'm not yet > able to look ahead for the first F2L pair. I'd like to practice cross > more often and then execute with closed eyes to force myself to see > the solution clearly. Since you never have cube rotations I guess that > can't be the way you execute your solutions. Can you show us how you > execute them? > > 1) R D' B D' L F D > Yippie, I beat you in QTM ;-) > > 2) D' F2 D2 R D F' > Darn... > > 3) Same as yours. > > 4) Same as yours, though I rotated the cube with y first. > > 5) Same as yours. > > 6) x U L U' l U y' L2 D' > Slightly different in the end. I save a quarter turn but pay with a > cube rotation (or alternatively a B turn). Here's one I like, too, > it's a bit longer but easier to execute (it's more similar to yours): > x U L U' l D' U2 R2 > > 7) L' F D B' L R' D > I like yours a lot, too. Your B' start is a bit counter-intuitive > since you turn the "correctly flipped" white/green edge into an > incorrect one. I need to learn not to always see that as something > bad. > > 8) F' B2 U R2 D' L > I think I actually did (y' R' L2 D L2 D2 F) which is slightly > different, not only because of the cube rotation. > > 9) Same as yours, though I started with y. > > 10) y' D2 L' D' L' R' D' > +1 in HTM but same in QTM, and only <L,D,R> after initial rotation, so > I'm not too unhappy ;-) > > 11) R B E' L F' > > Ha! Shorter than optimal ;-) > > 12) y2 D' R2 U F' D L2 > Another one, quite similar to yours but with an inserted U to save the > white/green early on: D' L2 U B' D R2. One less B' turn. > > 13) y' U2 L' D' R' F' L' B' > Yeah yeah, I beat you in QTM ;-) But it took me a long time to > actually execute it because my vision of the alg was all but clear, > probably not only because of the overall length but because I turn all > six sides :-) > > 14) I screwed this one and in the second attempt did 8 moves but had > to do it slowly. Sigh... This is a hard one. Though your solution > makes it look so easy, especially after your first three moves. I > think my problem was that the white/orange edge was almost solved and > I didn't think about moving it away. I had tried U B L' U' F2 R2. > Unfortunately the white/green wasn't at UR before the R2. Something > like this still happens to me too often. > > 15) Same as yours, but with a different order in the middle where we > solve each piece individually: F' R' L B L2. You seem to switch > between right and left areas of action. > > That's all for now... thanks again! > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > >
714. Re: F2L help! :) + cross trainer
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 20 May 2005 17:53:08 -0000

Wow.. Thanks a lot Dan.. I have been searching for something like this for ages! - Joël. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > I just checked back, and looks like this guy has added a cross > trainer! I think you can get it here: > www.cubestation.co.uk/cross/crosstraining.html > > Or go to www.cubestation.co.uk click on Solve the Cross, and then go > to the bottom of that page and click the link there. I think he will > add printable pages and finish it all off tomorrow. > > Dan :) > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" > <dan_j_harris@n.. > > .> wrote: > > > > > > On the cross... I heard some guy has a fantastic cross page on > his > > > website, with examples and rules and everything. Maybe you could > try > > > that out :) > > > > > > Dan :) > > > > Yeah, I think I've seen it and I like it a lot. If that guy could > just > > add a cross trainer it would be perfect. With this I mean a webpage > > that lists scrambles with (let's say) 10-15 moves and also lists > how > > many moves are necessary to solve the cross. So I can print them > and > > then practice solving cross in shortest ways. I'll suggest it to > him > > next time we talk... > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan
715. [Speed cubing group] Re: F2L help! :) + cross trainer
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 20 May 2005 22:04:03 -0000

Hey Rune, If in the inspection time, I would see a 6-move cross, which was easy to execute, I would definitely stick with it. I would then use the rest of the inspection time to try and imagine where my first F2L pair would be, that way right after the cross I could go seamlessly straight into the F2L. Of course, I wouldn't know that the 5-mover existed if I didn't search for it and see it, so I wouldn't really have to make a decision "between the two". Dan :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Rune Wesström <rune.wesstrom@h...> wrote: > Hi Dan, > Suppose, there exists an optimal five mover for the cross. During the inspection time you get sight of a six mover, which you can execute more or less blindly. Would you still, whith a reasonable probability, find that five mover? (That is, in practical game). > R > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Thursday, May 19, 2005 4:36 PM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: F2L help! :) + cross trainer > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n.. > > .> wrote: > > > I just checked back, and looks like this guy has added a cross > > > trainer! I think you can get it here: > > > www.cubestation.co.uk/cross/crosstraining.html > > > > Hi Dan, > > > > that's really cool, thanks a lot! (Too tired to continue the game > > after training the cross so much ;-) > > > > I guess you found the optimal lengths and number of solutions with > > computer help (which program?), so maybe most of the other solutions > > are somewhat more "magical". Below I list solutions and comments found > > by another human (me). > > > > Can you give numbers to the cases so it's easier to talk about them? > > I've simply numbered them from 1-15. On the webpage, it would be good > > to hide the optimal lengths. When I practice this, I'd like to know > > afterwards whether there's something better, not necessarily > > beforehand. > > > > Thanks for all the work. So far it's different than what I had in > > mind, but I like it a lot as well. What I had in mind is a program > > that generates random scrambles, maybe by solving two random cubes and > > concatenating their solutions to build the scramble. That would result > > in good scrambles with about 13 moves. I wouldn't have (your) human > > solutions so I wouldn't expect to learn as easily from it, but it > > would give me the opportunity to practice as often as I want to with > > new scrambles all the time. > > > > I must admit sometimes I exceeded the 15 seconds a bit and often I > > didn't have a clear vision of the solution, so I had to follow the > > pieces closely, think and turn slowly. That's part of why I'm not yet > > able to look ahead for the first F2L pair. I'd like to practice cross > > more often and then execute with closed eyes to force myself to see > > the solution clearly. Since you never have cube rotations I guess that > > can't be the way you execute your solutions. Can you show us how you > > execute them? > > > > 1) R D' B D' L F D > > Yippie, I beat you in QTM ;-) > > > > 2) D' F2 D2 R D F' > > Darn... > > > > 3) Same as yours. > > > > 4) Same as yours, though I rotated the cube with y first. > > > > 5) Same as yours. > > > > 6) x U L U' l U y' L2 D' > > Slightly different in the end. I save a quarter turn but pay with a > > cube rotation (or alternatively a B turn). Here's one I like, too, > > it's a bit longer but easier to execute (it's more similar to yours): > > x U L U' l D' U2 R2 > > > > 7) L' F D B' L R' D > > I like yours a lot, too. Your B' start is a bit counter-intuitive > > since you turn the "correctly flipped" white/green edge into an > > incorrect one. I need to learn not to always see that as something > > bad. > > > > 8) F' B2 U R2 D' L > > I think I actually did (y' R' L2 D L2 D2 F) which is slightly > > different, not only because of the cube rotation. > > > > 9) Same as yours, though I started with y. > > > > 10) y' D2 L' D' L' R' D' > > +1 in HTM but same in QTM, and only <L,D,R> after initial rotation, so > > I'm not too unhappy ;-) > > > > 11) R B E' L F' > > > > Ha! Shorter than optimal ;-) > > > > 12) y2 D' R2 U F' D L2 > > Another one, quite similar to yours but with an inserted U to save the > > white/green early on: D' L2 U B' D R2. One less B' turn. > > > > 13) y' U2 L' D' R' F' L' B' > > Yeah yeah, I beat you in QTM ;-) But it took me a long time to > > actually execute it because my vision of the alg was all but clear, > > probably not only because of the overall length but because I turn all > > six sides :-) > > > > 14) I screwed this one and in the second attempt did 8 moves but had > > to do it slowly. 718. Re: [Speed cubing group] what should i do after i am done with the F2L, OLL and
From: "Arjan Bosse" <arbo_67@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 21 May 2005 09:43:11 -0000

Going to buy myself some ice cream ;-) Just finished learning OLL. Being able to always solve the LL in two looks feels great :-) Never thought I would be able to learn this method after seeing it for the first time 23 years ago. It took me almost a year. F2L is done intuitively, started doing this at the European Championships afterparty. Now most of the times I solve the cube within 60 moves. Next step is to drop my average time under 30 seconds. -Arjan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > After you've done F2L, OLL, PLL, personally, I'd go for some ice cream. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On May 13, 2005, at 6:23 AM, thewetdog wrote: > > > I am in no position to be giving advice, which is not what I am here > > to do. But I wanted to offer some first hand experience. This idea > > that Joel suggested, about not timing yourself for a bit and just > > concentrating on going slowly and looking ahead during the F2L is > > sound. I had read people offer the advice before, but it is > > difficult to comprehend when you are first starting. You see other > > cubers flying through the F2L and feel you need to go as fast as you > > can to try and keep pace (which you won't anyway). > > > > Since Joel was nice enough to offer me some good tips, I took him > > seriously and did exactly that for most of this week  didn't time > > myself, and only concentrated on solving the F2L without stopping, > > no matter how slowly it felt I was going. After only 3 days of > > doing that, I could feel I was finding the pieces better. So I did > > an average last night, and I already dropped nearly 2 seconds from > > my average. Sub 30 here I come! > > > > So listen to these guys, they know their stuff. (And thanks again!!) > > > > -Dave > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > >> Hmm.. I am not really sure if 'practice will do'... :S > >> > >> I think for LL, yes, practice will do after you have found > >> algorithms that you like to execute... For F2L, I don't think > >> practicing with a timer and all will do. I think it's very > > important > >> to solve the cube without timing yourself, while actively thinking > >> about the steps that you make, and try to find all the F2L > > shortcuts > >> yourself. > >> > >> Joël. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

723. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: what should i do after i am done with the F2L, OLL and PLL algorithms????
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 21 May 2005 16:24:04 -0700 (PDT)

do this. do a F then a 3-cycle to see some COLL. or a B then a 3 cycle. also try doing a F, then do the T permutation, you will see a nice alg from the 1211 rose palmers. practice that way, you will be able to see certain situations were you can do either a F, B, B' or F' and a certain permutation to fix oritentation and permutation at once. good luck! --- arbo_67 <arbo_67@...> wrote: > Going to buy myself some ice cream ;-) > > Just finished learning OLL. Being able to always > solve the LL in two > looks feels great :-) Never thought I would be able > to learn this > method after seeing it for the first time 23 years > ago. It took me > almost a year. F2L is done intuitively, started > doing this at the > European Championships afterparty. Now most of the > times I solve the > cube within 60 moves. Next step is to drop my > average time under 30 > seconds. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson > Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > After you've done F2L, OLL, PLL, personally, I'd > go for some ice cream. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On May 13, 2005, at 6:23 AM, thewetdog wrote: > > > > > I am in no position to be giving advice, which > is not what I am here > > > to do. But I wanted to offer some first hand > experience. This idea > > > that Joel suggested, about not timing yourself > for a bit and just > > > concentrating on going slowly and looking ahead > during the F2L is > > > sound. I had read people offer the advice > before, but it is > > > difficult to comprehend when you are first > starting. You see other > > > cubers flying through the F2L and feel you need > to go as fast as you > > > can to try and keep pace (which you won't > anyway). > > > > > > Since Joel was nice enough to offer me some good > tips, I took him > > > seriously and did exactly that for most of this > week ï¿½ didn't time > > > myself, and only concentrated on solving the F2L > without stopping, > > > no matter how slowly it felt I was going. After > only 3 days of > > > doing that, I could feel I was finding the > pieces better. So I did > > > an average last night, and I already dropped > nearly 2 seconds from > > > my average. Sub 30 here I come! > > > > > > So listen to these guys, they know their stuff. > (And thanks again!!) > > > > > > -Dave > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > Joï¿½l van Noort > > > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > >> Hmm.. I am not really sure if 'practice will > do'... :S > > >> > > >> I think for LL, yes, practice will do after you > have found > > >> algorithms that you like to execute... For F2L, > I don't think > > >> practicing with a timer and all will do. I > think it's very > > > important > > >> to solve the cube without timing yourself, > while actively thinking > > >> about the steps that you make, and try to find > all the F2L > > > shortcuts > > >> yourself. > > >> > > >> Joï¿½l. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 724. standard deviations
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 21 May 2005 23:49:17 -0700

Leyan's too lazy to post this so I'm posting it for him:

----- JNetCube Best Average for Sat May 21 23:48:51 PDT 2005 -----

Average: 17.97

Fastest Time: 16.55
Slowest Time: 19.76
Standard Deviation: 00.60

Individual Times:
1) 19.06 F2 B' U B L2 B2 U2 D B2 U D2 B2 L' B2 U2 B2
F' D2 F2 D2 R' B' R' B2 U'
2) (16.55) D2 B2 R' L' F R2 D2 R B F2 L' U B D' U F B
U F' B D U' R' D' L'
3) 18.48 U F L2 D2 R2 B F' R' L' D2 U' R' D U L U R'
D R' F' L2 U2 R L' D2
4) 17.88 U L' F' U2 R' D' F' D' R B D2 U2 F2 R2 U B'
L' F2 B' R2 B2 R' U R2 B'
5) 16.78 R L' B' U B2 R' U L U' F L' D' R2 D' F' R2
U' B2 U2 L2 R' U' L' D R
6) 17.88 D2 F2 B' L2 U2 B' L' U' F L2 B' D2 U R' B U2
R2 L' F2 B2 R F' L2 D R2
7) 18.47 L2 F' B' D L' F L2 F L2 F2 L D2 L R F' L' F'
B D' L U2 B2 L2 B2 L
8) 17.78 R2 F L' F2 B' D' R' D2 L2 F2 B2 U F' R B F
D' U' R2 U' F B L2 D' B'
9) 17.72 F' D F2 R B2 U D2 B D R B F2 U' D' F2 R F2
B' D F2 L B' U2 F2 B'
10) (19.76) B2 L2 U' B F L2 F' B' D' B2 F2 R' L' B'
R' D2 F' B2 D R D' R B2 D' L2
11) 17.81 L2 F' R2 B2 F' R2 F2 D2 L2 U' B2 R2 U' F2 R
B' R L2 D2 R D' B2 L' U2 B
12) 17.88 U2 R' L' B' U L F B R2 L2 U2 R' B R' L D F
R2 L' U F' B R' F2 B

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

726. Writing Contributions
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 22 May 2005 08:39:13 -0000

I'm not sure how well I've publicized this section of my site, but this
is a good a time as any.

http://www.geocities.com/rubiks_galaxia/OnTheMark.html

This is where I will be posting my cube related articles. I will also
post the work of others also, so please, email me your articles!

Anything cubing related will do! New method ideas, math related
articles, cubing experiences, etc. Just send your work to me:

richy_jr_2000@...

Happy cubing!

-Richard
www.geocities.com/rubiks_galaxia

729. Re: [Speed cubing group] New Game
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 22 May 2005 15:08:54 -0400

730. Re: [Speed cubing group] Writing Contributions
From: "Mikael" <stobe_98@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 22 May 2005 21:01:32 -0000

Very nice Richard! I really liked your story, especially your false identity ;) It all very much brings back my thoughts when I started cubing. I think most speedcubers find similarities with their own experiences. I've come a little further in my journey than you Sachin. I'm sure you will hit sub-30 but, it can take time. I had already lost hope for keeping my average that low (my PB was 29.37 seconds done in February) but only a week ago I took a quantum leap forward, now my PB is 26.62 and I again dream of sub-20 averages :) Happy cubing, Mikael --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, sachin shirwalkar <sachin_civilian@y...> wrote: > Nice story richard. I am also at the start of ur > journey i think. I average around 90 seconds now but > after reading ur story i also think i can get atleast > sub 30! :) > > maybe someday i'll put my story for others to > see...but still its a long way to go:) > > --- richy_jr_2000 <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > --------------------------------- > I'm not sure how well I've publicized this section of > my site, but this > is a good a time as any. > > http://www.geocities.com/rubiks_galaxia/OnTheMark.html > > This is where I will be posting my cube related > articles. I will also > post the work of others also, so please, email me your > articles! > > Anything cubing related will do! New method ideas, > math related > articles, cubing experiences, etc. Just send your > work to me: > > richy_jr_2000@y... > > Happy cubing! > > -Richard > www.geocities.com/rubiks_galaxia > > > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! 731. 3-look LL site?
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 22 May 2005 22:43:56 -0000

I received an email from a cuber who'd used my beginner solution to learn the basics and who is now interested in learning a 3-look LL. I thought Dan Knights' advanced solution <http://benjerry.middlebury.edu/~knights/Cube/Advanced.html> was very good for learning the 3-look LL, but Dan K's site has been down for quite a while now. Can anyone recommend another good 3-look LL site? If I had more time then I'd create one myself, but unfortunately I don't have time at the moment. I'm hoping that someone can point me in the direction of an existing 3-look LL site. :) Thanks, Jasmine http://www.geocities.com/jasmine_ellen/RubiksCubeSolution.html
732. Re: [Speed cubing group] 3-look LL site?
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 22 May 2005 15:50:23 -0700

hey, For a three look last layer, you can use any set of LL algorythms. Just use only the ones you need for orientation, and all of them for permutation. So I would recomend looking around at alot of different algorithm sites to find which ones fit best, as opposed to just learning them from a single site (my mistake). Hope that helps -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On 5/22/05, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > I received an email from a cuber who'd used my beginner solution to > learn the basics and who is now interested in learning a 3-look LL. > > I thought Dan Knights' advanced solution > <http://benjerry.middlebury.edu/~knights/Cube/Advanced.html> > was very > good for learning the 3-look LL, but Dan K's site has been down for > quite a while now. Can anyone recommend another good 3-look LL site? > If I had more time then I'd create one myself, but unfortunately I > don't have time at the moment. I'm hoping that someone can point me in > the direction of an existing 3-look LL site. :) > > Thanks, > Jasmine > http://www.geocities.com/jasmine_ellen/RubiksCubeSolution.html > > > > > ________________________________ > Yahoo! Groups Links > > To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.
733. Re: [Speed cubing group] 3-look LL site?
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 22 May 2005 23:08:15 -0000

Yeah, this is true, I just thought that it would be easier to email him a 3-look LL site if one existed (like Dan K's old site), rather than a selection of different sites where the 3-look LL stuff could be sourced. Anyway, I ended up sending the guy a couple of sites and specifying which algs on each site would be needed for each of the 3 steps (orient edges, orient corners, permute all). 738. Dan´s Page
From: "alejandro_lamas" <alejandro_lamas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 23 May 2005 10:33:14 -0000

Good, there is a VERY powerful tool WayBackMachine in Internet that
allows visit old versions of the pages :) and, of course, dead pages:

http://web.archive.org/collections/web.html

For example, diferents versions of Dan´s page are in:

http://web.archive.org/web/*/http://benjerry.middlebury.edu/~knights

There are some videos missing :( but you can see all the text and the
images.

Jan




739. Starting...
From: "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@...>

Date: Mon, 23 May 2005 13:51:53 +0200

Hi all,

Where can I find details on how to start a cube, before applying the F2L
algoritms? I have visited several pages, but still haven't found a decent
explanation on how to start.

I assume you all know where I can find this info, so please help me find it
too.

- Bram
================================================
De informatie opgenomen in dit bericht kan vertrouwelijk zijn en
is uitsluitend bestemd voor de geadresseerde. Indien u dit bericht
onterecht ontvangt, wordt u verzocht de inhoud niet te gebruiken en
de afzender direct te informeren door het bericht te retourneren.
================================================
The information contained in this message may be confidential
and is intended to be exclusively for the addressee. Should you
receive this message unintentionally, please do not use the contents
herein and notify the sender immediately by return e-mail.

741. WayBackMachine - records page
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 23 May 2005 13:53:47 -0000

Here's the oldest version of the records page I could find. It's
crazy to see how quickly speedcubing has evolved.

I miss being in the top ten on the averages list :-P

October 20, 2001
http://web.archive.org/web/20011020200033/http://www.geocities.com/cmhardw

the averages list is on the main site, here's most of the rest of the
records page
http://web.archive.org/web/20010808075618/http://www.geocities.com/cmhardw/recordtimes.html

some other old versions:
http://web.archive.org/web/*/http://www.geocities.com/cmhardw

and of course lots of other versions after it moved to speedcubing.com
under Ron's updating:
http://web.archive.org/web/*/http://www.speedcubing.com

Chris

745. Re: Huge optimal solver
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 23 May 2005 21:39:35 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" > > <bbeer@g...> wrote: > > > Can anyone tell me what 3;1346 (and all the others like that) mean? > > > > A good question. It might be the number of a particular case in one of > > his blindfold-solving systems, see > > http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/9589 > > > > On the other hand, it might be something else. ;) > > > > I really wish that in these irregular posts Richard would link to a web > > page (or even an earlier posting here) informing us (or reminding us) > > of what he is doing. No doubt it is very interesting -- a single case > > he mentioned a while back was intriguing because of its symmetry and > > depth. > > > > Mike > > These refer back to posts somewhere around numbers 16040-16080. With respect to those posts F2 U2 R2 D2 L U2 L F2 U2 R' D' B R' F' R B L' F' R2 U (20f) //90;1187 is indeed optimal. (1 out of 4 so far - one still to go from that post - not great, but at least one of them was a 20.)
746. Re: PLL
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 23 May 2005 21:55:37 -0000

(R'U2) (RU2) (R'FRUR'U') (R'F'R2) U2 Should the last move be U? ;) Joël. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > I finally finished updating my PLL page. Please, have a look ;) > > http://www.geocities.com/rubiks_galaxia/PLL.html > > > Happy Cubing! > > -Richard
747. Re: PLL
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 23 May 2005 22:08:54 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > (R'U2) (RU2) (R'FRUR'U') (R'F'R2) U2 > > Should the last move be U? I think the last move should be R2. Don't you think so? Cheers! Stefan
748. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: PLL

754. Cube sale
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 23 May 2005 23:21:22 -0000

We'll be selling a bunch of Rubik's Cubes at the New York Tournament
this Saturday. Proceeds will go to my school's Rubik's Cube Club.
Here's our price list:

3x3: $10 each or 3 for $27
4x4: $18 each or 2 for $34
5x5: $25 each or 2 for $50 (this bulk rate is for non math-majors
only)

We can only take cash or check. Put your orders in if someone who
lives near you will be going to the tournament.

Ian




755. Endlich :)
From: "Rob Butler" <futuese@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 24 May 2005 05:08:20 -0000


Tchus Stefan!

Tonight I finally joined you in solving a 5x5x5 supercube
blindfolded!

It was not by any means my first attempt at this type of solve as I
have had a few really heartbreaking near misses in the past couple
of months.

I had my system figured out just before Christmas but have only just
now managed to execute the entire solution flawlessly. Memorization
is really quite easy. What tripped me up was the length of the
solution. One must be absolutely perfect and over the course of
such a long solution there are many opportunities for even just a
little slip up which will, of course, ruin the whole enterprise. It
is indeed an unforgiving style of cubing but its rewards are
correspondingly high when successful :)

I memorize and solve the beast in the same order as follows:

stage 1 - solve the orientations (centers, corners, middle edges)
stage 2 - solve the 3x3x3 pieces (corners and middle edges)
stage 3 - solve the x centers
stage 4 - solve the outer edges
stage 5 - solve the + centers.

The center / middle edge / corner parity is discovered immediately
by analyzing the centercaps. It is dealt with as I memorize the
information before step 1. The outedges / + center parity is only
identified when I memorize step 4. When present it influences how I
approach step 5 and is finally solved as the last task of the
solution.

One of the real regrets about blindsolving big cubes is not being
able to see the cube gradually approach completion from chaos. In
order to get even some small pleasure out of this I blindly point my
digital camera towards my cube at the end of each stage of the
solve. (This is also useful for trying to figure out where things
went wrong on unsuccessful solves). Some of the pictures are a
little blurry and they are all (except for the very beginning and
very end) off center as it was very much a matter of guessing what
angle to point the camera.

I always blindsolve with BLUE facing me and WHITE on top. I took
three photos for every stage of the solve - from straight on, from
the left side, from the right side. I have uploaded them to the
photos section under the folder "profblind" if anyone is interested
in seeing them. You will notice that my supercube is not anywhere
near as nice looking as Stefan's or Chris' new stickers. It is
basically just a regular 5x5x5 painted with nailpolish and with the
centers identified by dots indicting 1-9 like they appear on playing
cards or dice. Now that such beautiful supercube stickers are
available to us I will be getting in touch with Chris in the very
near future to purchase real supercube stickers.

I will be returning home to Toronto at the very start of June after
I finish my summer courses at the U of Manitoba. I intend to write
up a full and detailed account of my method including the algs used
for each step and much more accurate details on the parity solution
but this will need to wait 10 days until the start of my summer
vacation.

Happy cubing,

Rob

Check > out page 98 and the > article called "Speedcubing at Caltech". > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > > __________________________________ Do you Yahoo!? Yahoo! 757. Re: Endlich :)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 24 May 2005 08:43:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Rob Butler" <futuese@y...> wrote: > > Tchus Stefan! Mmh, you wanna say "good bye" to me? Why, because my time is over? Hehe ;-) > Tonight I finally joined you in solving a 5x5x5 supercube > blindfolded! Yeah, great! Congratulations! I do remember your almost-successes you've mentioned before, glad you finally made it! One thing I do to prevent mistakes is to never in setup moves do something like (Rr) when actually I want (r) only, just because (Rr) is faster to execute. I did it a while ago and when undoing the setup moves I often wondered whether I had to undo (Rr) or (r). Now I always know. Rules are good, thinking is bad ;-) I solve both parities this way: For each type of piece I have an "error pair" on the U-layer, e.g. Urf and Ufl for the X-centers. In case of a parity problem, I make sure that it's this pair (or in case of centers, the U center) is wrong. Usually it takes two 3-cycles to solve my last piece and break the error pair. Then at the very end, I apply up to two algs, one for each parity. I solve all centers first, then outer edges, then middle edges, then corners. I think this way the layer steps have a smaller chance of destroying the first (particularly solving the corners will never destroy the centers or the edge triples, since I only use outer-layer twists) and thus if I make a mistake there then at least I can see parts of my cube solved :-) Cheers! Stefan

760. Re: Stupid Orange Stickers
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 25 May 2005 17:49:01 -0000

Hi Jasmine (from Down Under?)! You (and others) might be interested in the "original Hungarian" or Ideal made cubes. Those have orange stickers with a good light reflective glue that lasts much longer than the glue of other stickers. Orange stickers practically never peel off. Does anybody has an experience with tiled cubes made few years ago? I only find Rubik's Cube Deluxe Edition made in 1980 for $76 at http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=1247 I thought that tiled cubes are in production and available for something like $15 but it seems not to be true any more. Mirek --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I restickered a cube recently and the orange stickers are > *significantly* more worn than the other colours!! Grr! > > Jasmine > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pentium6700" > <pentium6700@y...> wrote: > > I don't know if anybody else has this problem, but no matter which > way > > I solve a cube, the orange stickers always start to peel within a > > week. I HATE IT!!! They get really bad and need to be taped down > > after a week and a half... Any ideas about what to do? Theories > > about why it's ALWAYS THE STUPID ORANGE ONES?!??!??

Mirek On www.cubesmith.com you can order 'tiles' which are not tiles like on the deluxe cube, but thin adhesive pieces of vinyl - I have them and they are really amazing. 766. Re: [Speed cubing group] Starting...
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 May 2005 10:15:05 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > I have no idea. I looked up the F2L algoritms and don't understand how to > start with them. Do I just apply them to my scrambled cube, or do I first do > something else (before applying the F2L algoritms)?? Have a look at a "beginner" solution, such as http://www.geocities.com/jasmine_ellen/RubiksCubeSolution.html to see what is meant by "the cross". Once that is done, each of the first-2-layer algorithms places a missing corner into an angle of the cross, together with the middle-layer edge next to it. Note that Jasmine's diagrams are slightly misleading: most speedcubers using this method prefer to solve the bottom layer (or sometimes the left- hand layer, if right-handed) first. But, rather than blindly following any algorithms, it is much better to work out how to do this yourself. Most of the cases are quite simple to work out, and thinking about it yourself will help your Cube understanding... which is (almost!) necessary for you to make easy progress. Really that is just common sense, but it is emphasized especially in J Fridrich's description of her own method. Good luck. Mike
767. Re: [Speed cubing group] Starting...
From: "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 May 2005 11:25:31 -0000

If you want to begin and to have a good comprehension of the cube, You should start by trying to build seral patterns on your cube : 1. A cross (with edges) 2. A complete layer 3. A complete layer with all the pieces well placed (the collors on the side are well placed) 4. Place correctly all the edges on the first two layers (without the corners on the first layer) 5. Place correctly all the edges on the whole cube 6. Try to find a way to build completely the first two layers 7. Try to orientate the top edges when the F2L are complete 8. Try to orientate the top corners correctly with the F2L and the top cross correctly placed This will take you some time to figure out how to do that, but if you can do that : you'll only have to learn the PLL of the Fridrich method (you can try to find them too :p). But you should be able to do 1, 2 3 and 4 quite shortly. For the 5 and the 6 : it's possible too, but you have to have faith : it's possible. Then the 7 and the 8th are quite easy if you have a good vision of the cube. Good luck ! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" > <bbeer@g...> wrote: > > I have no idea. I looked up the F2L algoritms and don't understand > how to > > start with them. Do I just apply them to my scrambled cube, or do I > first do > > something else (before applying the F2L algoritms)?? > > Have a look at a "beginner" solution, such as > > http://www.geocities.com/jasmine_ellen/RubiksCubeSolution.html > > to see what is meant by "the cross". Once that is done, each of the > first-2-layer algorithms places a missing corner into an angle of the > cross, together with the middle-layer edge next to it. Note that > Jasmine's diagrams are slightly misleading: most speedcubers using > this method prefer to solve the bottom layer (or sometimes the left- > hand layer, if right-handed) first. > > But, rather than blindly following any algorithms, it is much better > to work out how to do this yourself. Most of the cases are quite > simple to work out, and thinking about it yourself will help your > Cube understanding... which is (almost!) necessary for you to make > easy progress. > > Really that is just common sense, but it is emphasized especially in > J Fridrich's description of her own method. > > Good luck. > Mike
768. Re: [Speed cubing group] Starting...
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 May 2005 15:45:59 -0000

Hi Bram, Why not decide what color you want for the First Layer and the Last Layer, so that you can easily recognize what pieces are where? The better you can see the location of the next pieces to place the faster you can be. Cheers, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > People, please help me find the information I need... > > -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- > Van: Beer, Bram de [mailto:bbeer@g...] > Verzonden: maandag 23 mei 2005 13:52 > Aan: 'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com' > Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group] Starting... > > > Hi all, > > Where can I find details on how to start a cube, before applying the F2L > algoritms? I have visited several pages, but still haven't found a decent > explanation on how to start. > > I assume you all know where I can find this info, so please help me find it > too. > > - Bram > > ================================================ > De informatie opgenomen in dit bericht kan vertrouwelijk zijn en > is uitsluitend bestemd voor de geadresseerde. Indien u dit bericht > onterecht ontvangt, wordt u verzocht de inhoud niet te gebruiken en > de afzender direct te informeren door het bericht te retourneren. > ================================================ > The information contained in this message may be confidential > and is intended to be exclusively for the addressee.
