769. Re: [Speed cubing group] Starting...
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 May 2005 17:07:34 -0000

I recommend picking one color and making that color always the first layer. Some people have that color on top, but most have it on bottom [or the side]. I used to have it on top, but switched to the bottom a few months ago. I always use White first, which means yellow is always my last layer [remember, the center pieces never move relative to each other, they just spin around]. I haven't taken a poll or anything, but I think white's a pretty common pick, probably the most common. Next step is just do the cross on the white side, then go into the F2L algs to complete the first 2 layers. If you're trying to decipher an alg and not sure if you are performing the moves correctly, one suggestion is to start with a solved cube [take yours apart and put it back together solved if you have to], and perform the alg from the solved state and then note what changed. sometimes that helps me understand the algs better. good luck. stick with it--it's worth the effort. --Kirk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > People, please help me find the information I need... > > -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- > Van: Beer, Bram de [mailto:bbeer@g...] > Verzonden: maandag 23 mei 2005 13:52 > Aan: 'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com' > Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group] Starting... > > > Hi all, > > Where can I find details on how to start a cube, before applying the F2L > algoritms? I have visited several pages, but still haven't found a decent > explanation on how to start. > > I assume you all know where I can find this info, so please help me find it > too. > > - Bram > > ================================================ > De informatie opgenomen in dit bericht kan vertrouwelijk zijn en > is uitsluitend bestemd voor de geadresseerde. Indien u dit bericht > onterecht ontvangt, wordt u verzocht de inhoud niet te gebruiken en > de afzender direct te informeren door het bericht te retourneren. > ================================================ > The information contained in this message may be confidential > and is intended to be exclusively for the addressee. Should you > receive this message unintentionally, please do not use the contents > herein and notify the sender immediately by return e-mail. > ================================================ > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

772. Re: [Speed cubing group] Starting...
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 May 2005 20:16:27 -0000

I used to solve with cross on top, and that's how I was solving when I initally wrote the beginner solution page (http://www.geocities.com/jasmine_ellen/RubiksCubeSolution.html) However, I agree that it's better to solve with cross on bottom rather than on top. I should update my beginner solution with some comments about this. I've been gradually moving away from cross on top. Now I generally solve like this: - cross: mostly on left (yes, I'm right-handed) - F2L pairs: mostly cross on left, some pairs with cross on bottom - LL: *almost* all LL algs with cross on bottom, ~2 PLL algs with cross on left Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" > <bbeer@g...> wrote: > > I have no idea. I looked up the F2L algoritms and don't understand > how to > > start with them. Do I just apply them to my scrambled cube, or do I > first do > > something else (before applying the F2L algoritms)?? > > Have a look at a "beginner" solution, such as > > http://www.geocities.com/jasmine_ellen/RubiksCubeSolution.html > > to see what is meant by "the cross". Once that is done, each of the > first-2-layer algorithms places a missing corner into an angle of the > cross, together with the middle-layer edge next to it. Note that > Jasmine's diagrams are slightly misleading: most speedcubers using > this method prefer to solve the bottom layer (or sometimes the left- > hand layer, if right-handed) first. > > But, rather than blindly following any algorithms, it is much better > to work out how to do this yourself. Most of the cases are quite > simple to work out, and thinking about it yourself will help your > Cube understanding... which is (almost!) necessary for you to make > easy progress. > > Really that is just common sense, but it is emphasized especially in > J Fridrich's description of her own method. > > Good luck. > Mike
773. Re: [Speed cubing group] Starting...
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 May 2005 20:18:02 -0000

Hi! I would actually like to expand a bit on ur point 6 in the list. Otherwise i think the list is quite ok. It will take a while to figure out all of that but it's really worth it. It surely will enhance the understanding of "how the cube works" :-) I'd suggest to break up 6 like this: 6a) Figure out how to make complete first 2 layers except that 1 corner is missing (working corner) 6b) Figure out how to make complete first 2 layers except that 1 edge of the middle layer is missing (working edge) 6c) Now figure out from either a) or b) how the heck to do the last corner or edge. This will make up a complete first 2 layers, leaving only the last layer (the remaining points on the list). Mastering 6a and/or 6b should make the step from 5 to 6 (6c) a bit easier :-) Have fun cubing! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@y...> wrote: > If you want to begin and to have a good comprehension of the cube, > You should start by trying to build seral patterns on your cube : > > 1. A cross (with edges) > 2. A complete layer > 3. A complete layer with all the pieces well placed (the collors on > the side are well placed) > 4. Place correctly all the edges on the first two layers (without > the corners on the first layer) > 5. Place correctly all the edges on the whole cube > 6. Try to find a way to build completely the first two layers > 7. Try to orientate the top edges when the F2L are complete > 8. Try to orientate the top corners correctly with the F2L and the > top cross correctly placed > > This will take you some time to figure out how to do that, but if > you can do that : you'll only have to learn the PLL of the Fridrich > method (you can try to find them too :p). > > But you should be able to do 1, 2 3 and 4 quite shortly. For the 5 > and the 6 : it's possible too, but you have to have faith : it's > possible. Then the 7 and the 8th are quite easy if you have a good > vision of the cube. > > Good luck ! > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" > > <bbeer@g...> wrote: > > > I have no idea. I looked up the F2L algoritms and don't > understand > > how to > > > start with them. Do I just apply them to my scrambled cube, or > do I > > first do > > > something else (before applying the F2L algoritms)?? > > > > Have a look at a "beginner" solution, such as > > > > http://www.geocities.com/jasmine_ellen/RubiksCubeSolution.html > > > > to see what is meant by "the cross". Once that is done, each of the > > first-2-layer algorithms places a missing corner into an angle of > the > > cross, together with the middle-layer edge next to it. Note that > > Jasmine's diagrams are slightly misleading: most speedcubers using > > this method prefer to solve the bottom layer (or sometimes the > left- > > hand layer, if right-handed) first. > > > > But, rather than blindly following any algorithms, it is much > better > > to work out how to do this yourself. Most of the cases are quite > > simple to work out, and thinking about it yourself will help your > > Cube understanding... which is (almost!) necessary for you to make > > easy progress. > > > > Really that is just common sense, but it is emphasized especially > in > > J Fridrich's description of her own method. > > > > Good luck. > > Mike

Greetins Mirek, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" <goljan@s...> wrote: > Hi Jasmine (from Down Under?)! > You (and others) might be interested in the "original Hungarian" or > Ideal made cubes. Those have orange stickers with a good light > reflective glue that lasts much longer than the glue of other > stickers. Orange stickers practically never peel off. I agree. I've had no troulble at all with the stickers on the Ideal cubes. > Does anybody has an experience with tiled cubes made few years ago? I've seen about six different ones. The Gyro Cube is the only high quality clone I've seen. It's like the Deluxe Edition but the underside of the centers are flat. There are several which are OK in terms of being light, but avoid the ones with flash still on the tiles. "Old Brand Magic Square" cube is terrible. Though Stefan P likes their springs. > I only find Rubik's Cube Deluxe Edition made in 1980 for $76 at > http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=1247 These are the best cubes. > I thought that tiled cubes are in production and available for > something like $15 but it seems not to be true any more. Seven Towns has refused to produce it again. You can get tiles from Mefferts, Chris Licciardi and Mark Longidge. > Mirek Cheers, David J
777. Fridrich vs. Corners First
From: "Bruce Wayne" <drteeth@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 27 May 2005 01:12:33 -0000

I've only been cubing for two months and have learned the Fridrich f2l
and am working on the last layer. I was looking at the method that
puts the corners in first and then solves the top, bottom, then
middle. That method seems to be much faster (if the slice moves are
done quickly enough) and there appears to be much less to memorize. I
was wondering which one is actually faster and which i should put more
time into learning.




778. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich vs. Corners First
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 May 2005 18:21:26 -0700

A better question is... what's are the fastest times achieved with
corner's first? We've all seen what's possible with Fridrich.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

> and am working on the last layer. I was looking at the method that
> puts the corners in first and then solves the top, bottom, then
> middle. That method seems to be much faster (if the slice moves are
> done quickly enough) and there appears to be much less to memorize. I
> was wondering which one is actually faster and which i should put more
> time into learning.

779. RE: [Speed cubing group] Starting...
From: "Arturo N. Diocton, Jr." <lebart@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 27 May 2005 09:54:07 +0800

Hi Bram,

Art here. Like you I had this problem on how to start. First off as others
might have told you already, you might want to choose whether you want to
start solving the cube from the top to bottom (or vise versa) or left to
right (or vise versa) or from front to back (or vise versa). When you have
done this, to use the F2L you must make a cross or a plus pattern using the
edges of the whatever side you want to solve using F2L.

Then when you have done the F2L next is the Last Layer which are the
Orientation of the Last Layer (OLL) and Permutation of the Last Layer (PLL)

I use the cross at the bottom the doing the F2L then OLL then PLL or if I am
lucky and know the PLL of the top pattern I can just skip OLL.

I hope this helps you in making your current time faster or solving the
cube. Please try looking at other sites or other styles of solving the cube.

-----Original Message-----
From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
[mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]On Behalf Of Beer, Bram de
Sent: Monday, May 23, 2005 19:52
To: 'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: [Speed cubing group] Starting...


Hi all,

Where can I find details on how to start a cube, before applying the F2L
algoritms? I have visited several pages, but still haven't found a decent
explanation on how to start.

I assume you all know where I can find this info, so please help me find it
too.

- Bram

781. Re: Stupid Orange Stickers
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 27 May 2005 12:14:41 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > "Old Brand Magic Square" cube is terrible. Though Stefan P likes > their springs. It's *not* terrible. I just did three solves with mine: 19.91 (PLL=U), 25.66, 24.92. My average with my best speedcube is 22 seconds. Plus my OBMS is painted with a glow-in-the-dark pen. Yes, I took springs from these cubes to put them into my megaminx which had horrible springs. They're too long for 3x3s, though. Also, I do like the thin plastic for modding, i.e. building new puzzles from existing ones. I'm actually building a puzzle from an even cheaper clone that doesn't have springs and is probably really crap to play with (though I won't know for sure because I haven't even sanded/lubed it). It does have a great property, though, but I'll keep it secret for now. Maybe one day I'll add a "puzzle building for wimps" section on my website, describing how to build puzzles the easy way. Cheers! Stefan

Date: Fri, 27 May 2005 17:57:36 -0000

Being able to always solve the LL in two > looks feels great :-) Never thought I would be able to learn this > method after seeing it for the first time 23 years ago. It took me > almost a year. F2L is done intuitively, started doing this at the > European Championships afterparty. Now most of the times I solve the > cube within 60 moves. Next step is to drop my average time under 30 > seconds. > > -Arjan > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > After you've done F2L, OLL, PLL, personally, I'd go for some ice cream. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On May 13, 2005, at 6:23 AM, thewetdog wrote: > > > > > I am in no position to be giving advice, which is not what I am here > > > to do. But I wanted to offer some first hand experience. This idea > > > that Joel suggested, about not timing yourself for a bit and just > > > concentrating on going slowly and looking ahead during the F2L is > > > sound. I had read people offer the advice before, but it is > > > difficult to comprehend when you are first starting. You see other > > > cubers flying through the F2L and feel you need to go as fast as you > > > can to try and keep pace (which you won't anyway). > > > > > > Since Joel was nice enough to offer me some good tips, I took him > > > seriously and did exactly that for most of this week  didn't time > > > myself, and only concentrated on solving the F2L without stopping, > > > no matter how slowly it felt I was going. After only 3 days of > > > doing that, I could feel I was finding the pieces better. So I did > > > an average last night, and I already dropped nearly 2 seconds from > > > my average. Sub 30 here I come! > > > > > > So listen to these guys, they know their stuff. (And thanks again!!) > > > > > > -Dave > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > > > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > >> Hmm.. I am not really sure if 'practice will do'... :S > > >> > > >> I think for LL, yes, practice will do after you have found > > >> algorithms that you like to execute... For F2L, I don't think > > >> practicing with a timer and all will do. I think it's very > > > important > > >> to solve the cube without timing yourself, while actively thinking > > >> about the steps that you make, and try to find all the F2L > > > shortcuts > > >> yourself. > > >> > > >> Joël. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 783. Re: Fridrich vs. Corners First
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 27 May 2005 18:37:50 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > A better question is... what's are the fastest times achieved with > corner's first? We've all seen what's possible with Fridrich. But that's not a very fair question: compared with corners-first, there are so many followers of Fridrich nowadays that the record book is bound to be dominated by users of that system. Marc Waterman is known to have achieved very good times in the 1980s with a (rather complex) corners-first system, so it is not necessarily slow. Mike
784. Cube problem (a bit mathematical)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 27 May 2005 18:49:48 -0000


If x and y are elements of the cube group (moves), define the sequence C_n(x,y) for
n=0,1,2,3,... by

C_0(x,y)=e (the identity element)
C_{n+1}(x,y)=C_n(x,y)x^{-n}y^{-n}x^ny^n

in other words C_n(x,y) times the commutator x^{-n}y^{-n}x^ny^n.

Then for some n>0, C_n(x,y)=e. Let the minimal such n be c(x,y).

Here's the problem: what's c, the largest c(x,y) can be (by choosing x,y appropriately).
It's easy to get an upper bound for this problem.
Maybe it's quite easy - I've just come up with it so I've not given it any thought.

(More generally, for any group with finite exponent c will be finite.)




785. Re: Cube problem (a bit mathematical)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 27 May 2005 20:07:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > It's easy to get an upper bound for this problem. > Maybe it's quite easy - I've just come up with it so I've not given it any thought. OK, if I'm understanding this problem right, we can be sure that the commutators will start repeating themselves after n = N(x,y) = LCM(ord x, ord y) where ord x is the order of element x. So C_{mN} = (C_N)^m However, C_N cannot have an order exceeding 1260. From this, an easy upper bound for a particular x and y is 1260*N(x,y). You could check out the table of the possible values for the orders of elements, and so find the maximum possible N(x,y) pretty quickly, but I'm not so keen to do that myself, as this may be a wildly pessimistic bound anyway. However, is that roughly what you had in mind? And how did the problem arise in the first place? Mike
786. Re: Cube problem (a bit mathematical)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 27 May 2005 20:50:45 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > It's easy to get an upper bound for this problem. > > Maybe it's quite easy - I've just come up with it so I've not given > it any thought. > > OK, if I'm understanding this problem right, we can be sure that the > commutators will start repeating themselves after > > n = N(x,y) = LCM(ord x, ord y) > > where ord x is the order of element x. So > > C_{mN} = (C_N)^m > > However, C_N cannot have an order exceeding 1260. From this, an easy > upper bound for a particular x and y is 1260*N(x,y). > That's pretty much what I was thinking, except that since C_N=C_{N-1} we get 0 1 2 ... N-1 N 2N-1 2N 3N-1 and so 1260N-1 would work as well. > You could check out the table of the possible values for the orders > of elements, and so find the maximum possible N(x,y) pretty quickly, > but I'm not so keen to do that myself, as this may be a wildly > pessimistic bound anyway. That's true! > > However, is that roughly what you had in mind? And how did the > problem arise in the first place? > > Mike That's exactly what I had in mind. I just thought of it - no particular reason for it - just some kind of problem to think about. Then I basically used the same logic as above. I thought it might be an interesting sort of thing - especially since it is bounded (for groups of finite exponent at least - i.e. where every element has finite order).
787. Re: Cube problem (correction)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 27 May 2005 20:52:36 -0000

Sorry, I should have looked more closely at your recurrence relation,
as with your definition, C_1 = C_0. I'd looked instead at

C_0 = e
C_n = C_{n-1} x^{-n} y^{-n} x^n y^n

The offset of 1 is probably the least of one's troubles. ;)

Mike




788. Re: Cube problem (a bit mathematical)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 27 May 2005 21:09:53 -0000

Oops, looks as if those posts crossed. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I just thought of it - no particular reason for it - just > some kind of problem to think about. Hmmm... well, I wonder if you've thought about this one: Can you represent every element of the commutator subgroup [half the cube group, in other words] by a single commutator? And, if so: How? Jaap posted a partial answer on Cube Lovers 2, but I haven't managed to complete the argument... though I'll confess to not having spent many hours on it. > it is bounded (for groups > of finite exponent at least - i.e. where every element has finite order). Ah, thanks! I'd wondered what "finite exponent" meant.
789. Re: Cube problem (correction)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 27 May 2005 21:14:07 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Sorry, I should have looked more closely at your recurrence relation, > as with your definition, C_1 = C_0. Actually, with my definition C_1=x^{-1}y^{-1}xy isn't e (unless x and y commute). > I'd looked instead at > C_0 = e > C_n = C_{n-1} x^{-n} y^{-n} x^n y^n > That's what I'm using, but note that with n=N(x,y) you get C_{kn}=C_{kn-1} as x^{-kn}y^{-kn}x^{kn}y^{kn}=e. In particular since 1260*N(x,y)-1 will be an upper bound for x,y. > The offset of 1 is probably the least of one's troubles. ;) That's true. > > Mike
790. Re: Cube problem (a bit mathematical)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 27 May 2005 21:22:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Oops, looks as if those posts crossed. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I just thought of it - no particular reason for it - just > > some kind of problem to think about. > > Hmmm... well, I wonder if you've thought about this one: > > Can you represent every element of the commutator subgroup [half the > cube group, in other words] by a single commutator? And, if so: How? I haven't thought about it actually. It's a good question though. > > Jaap posted a partial answer on Cube Lovers 2, but I haven't managed > to > complete the argument... though I'll confess to not having spent many > hours on it. > > > it is bounded (for groups > > of finite exponent at least - i.e. where every element has finite > order). > > Ah, thanks! I'd wondered what "finite exponent" meant. Actually "i.e." was wrong there - finite exponent is a stronger condition than this but it does imply that every element has finite order. (If every element has finite order then each N(x,y) would be finite, but to get that the set of N(x,y)s is bounded wouldn't necessarily follow without finite exponent). The exponent of a group is the LCM of the orders of all the elements (in particular it implies that every element has finite order, but every element having finite order does not imply the exponent is finite). The exponent is always finite for finite groups though - the order of the group would work.
791. Re: Cube problem (correction)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 27 May 2005 21:29:09 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Actually, with my definition C_1=x^{-1}y^{-1}xy isn't e (unless x and y commute). Er... not the way you originally wrote it, but don't worry, since... > That's what I'm using, but note that with n=N(x,y) you get C_{kn}=C_ {kn-1} as > x^{-kn}y^{-kn}x^{kn}y^{kn}=e. > In particular since 1260*N(x,y)-1 will be an upper bound for x,y. ...I'd missed that point anyway. Must go and eat, though. Goodnight. Mike
792. Re: Cube problem (correction)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 27 May 2005 21:40:18 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Actually, with my definition C_1=x^{-1}y^{-1}xy isn't e (unless x and > y commute). > > Er... not the way you originally wrote it, but don't worry, since... Yes, you're right. I should have written C_{n+1}(x,y)=C_n(x,y)x^{-(n+1)}y^{- (n+1)}x^{n+1}y^{n+1}. I had intended C_1(x,y) to be the commutator of x and y but I messed up my indices. Hope you have a good dinner and good night also. > > > That's what I'm using, but note that with n=N(x,y) you get C_{kn}=C_ > {kn-1} as > > x^{-kn}y^{-kn}x^{kn}y^{kn}=e. > > In particular since 1260*N(x,y)-1 will be an upper bound for x,y. > > ...I'd missed that point anyway. > > Must go and eat, though. 794. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Fridrich vs. Corners First

A more likely explanation for the domination of the Fridrich system is that it is a faster system than corner's first. 797. Re: Fridrich vs. Corners First
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 28 May 2005 22:36:47 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr <david20708@g...> wrote: > > But that's not a very fair question: compared with corners-first, there > > are so many followers of Fridrich nowadays that the record book is > > bound to be dominated by users of that system. > > A more likely explanation for the domination of the Fridrich system is > that it is a faster system than corner's first. Timing the fastest speedcubers cannot prove it, unfortunately. I've no strong views either way, btw -- but I object to the assumptions... a bit like saying that the fastest running shoes are those worn by the fastest runners. > If the question isn't fair, can you come up with another practical way > of judging which system is faster? Fridrich's system was "first on the market" for the new generations of speedcubers. These users have had the benefit of many websites telling them how to do it, right down to collections of finger tricks. Sadly, we can't reproduce those conditions for corners- first, so an experiment with controls is an unlikely prospect! Mike
798. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Fridrich vs. Corners First
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 28 May 2005 16:33:01 -0700


On May 28, 2005, at 10:16, David Barr wrote:
>
> A more likely explanation for the domination of the Fridrich system is
> that it is a faster system than corner's first.

I'd like to point out that while Fridrich is a complete system with
several well defined steps covering the entire solution, Corners First
is just a general approach. There can be many different Corners First
systems, of very different quality.

So I say the two aren't even comparable entities.

- -- - - - - - - - - - - -
"He who refuses to do arithmetic is doomed to talk nonsense."
--- John McCarthy

Lars Petrus - lars@... http://lar5.com



799. Re: Fridrich vs. Corners First
From: "Jessica Fridrich" <Jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 29 May 2005 01:57:54 -0000

I strongly believe that there are numerous systems that can be as
fast and maybe faster than the Fridrich system. Gilles and his
innovative approaches are a good example.

I also believe that the average times will "asymptotically" converge
to the same number for a variety of systems once they are perfected
to a certain level. This is because

1. there is a limit on how many algorithms an ordinary human mind
can keep in memory and actively use (i.e., sufficiently fast recall
from memory),

2. with a growing number of algorithms, recognition time naturally
grows, and thus more and more algorithms will not necessarily mean
faster times,

3. most importantly, if you watch the fastest cubers, their mind and
fingers work "in parallel". Fingers push the faces while mind is
occupied with recognizing the next position. They seem to be in a
balanced state of continuous twisting, when increasing the twisting
speed will not lead to faster times unless the recognition improves
too (this is, of course not true for the LLP).

Jessica




800. Re: Black and White cubes mixed
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 29 May 2005 05:26:02 -0000

The black centers don't hold the white pieces far enough apart to work without some serious jerry rigging or bodging. David J

802. Finally cracked sub-40s as a *real* average (and sub-35s as a best average)!
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 29 May 2005 13:20:21 -0000

Just wanted to share...

Yesterday I got a new best average of 10 time: 34.22s
40.62s, 30.17s, 34.97s, 31.48s, (27.95s), 42.44s, 30.96s, 30.11s,
(42.53s), 34.17s, 30.94s, 36.32s

And this morning I did my first average with all 12 solves sub-40s.
39.05, 32.99, 38.42, 31.54, 36.20, 36.55, 35.06, (39.93), 38.66,
(30.02), 35.43, 39.93

Also, I reckon I can now comfortably say that my _real_ average is now
sub-40s. I've done 64 solves this weekend with an overall average of
36.95s. And the last few cubing sessions I've done (totally hundreds
of solves) have all had averages sub-40s. :)

BTW, timing and scrambles were done with JNetCube.

Happy day! :)

Jasmine
http://speedcuber.blogspot.com

804. Re: Cube problem (a bit mathematical)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 29 May 2005 13:54:36 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > > From this, an easy > upper bound for a particular x and y is 1260*N(x,y). 805. Re: Old Brand Magic Square WAS Stupid Orange Stickers
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 29 May 2005 14:04:11 -0000

Hi David, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > Hi Stefan, > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > > "Old Brand Magic Square" cube is terrible. Though Stefan P likes > > > their springs. > > > > It's *not* terrible. > > The first one I got would not turn at all. The second one would > turn all but one side, the third one broke apart *across" two cubies. > I threw the fourth one away without opening it. Yeah ok if you do it that way, I'm not surprised ;-) Here's what to do with them: 1) Buy it. 2) Do *NOT* play with it. 3) Disassemble by removing a center cap, then the screw and center piece. Do *NOT* disassemble the normal way (popping an edge out). 4) (optional, I don't think I did) cut imperfections and sand pieces 5) Lube. 6) Adjust tensions in all six centers (probably loosening the screws). 7) Assemble normally. 8) Play. I.e. don't treat it like a normal cube before you've prepared it. > Why not call it "building puzzles with crap!" You could include all > kinds of [censored]. That wouldn't cover all cases. I do have at least one idea that would make both building a certain puzzle easier and the puzzle itself better. And without crap ingredients. I don't want to use crap, I want to make building easier. Sometimes they coincide. Cheers! Stefan
806. Re: Black and White cubes mixed
From: "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 29 May 2005 16:00:34 -0000


> The corner and edge pieces of the white cubes are larger than
the
> corner and edge pieces of the black DIY cubes. The black centers
don't
> hold the white pieces far enough apart to work without some serious
> jerry rigging or bodging.
>
> David J


Three weeks ago I put together a white DIY with the centers of a
black DIY and I've been using it exclusively ever since. I used the
white center caps and had to use superglue for them since they don't
have any other way of fitting to the black center, but that's the
only rigging it's had. I initially lubed it and found it to be much
too slick for me to control, so i washed it off and it's still
slicker than I was ever able to make my black DIY. I'm also
thinking the white doesn't break itself in as fast as the black does
in that the dirty looking dust isn't showing up as much as my black
ones. For me, I like this because my cube came out great from the
start (after removing the lube), so I'm hoping it will have a
longer life before the corners become too loose and jiggly.

Was there ever a definitive answer to this being a legal cube?
It is somewhat canabalized from two Rubik's products and there is no
way of seeing a difference without taking it apart. I do like this
cube.




807. Re: Cube problem (a bit mathematical)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 29 May 2005 16:02:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. > ..> wrote: > > > > From this, an easy > > upper bound for a particular x and y is 1260*N(x,y). > > Mmh, maybe I misunderstand, but aren't we just asking how often I have > to apply a specific commutator until we reach identity? Shouldn't then > the general upper limit of simply 1260 also apply here? > > Cheers! > Stefan Not exactly: if [x,y] denotes the commutator of x and y then we're looking at the sequence: C_0=e C_1=e[x,y] C_2=e[x,y][x^2,y^2] C_3=e[x,y][x^2,y^2][x^3,y^3] ... C_{n+1}=C_n[x^{n+1},y^{n+1}] [x^n,y^n] is the identity (when n is the least common multiple of the orders of x and y, for example). Then [x^{n+1},y^{n+1}]=[x,y] and so C_{n+1}=C-nC_1 in this situtation. Similarly, C_{n+k}=C_nC_k and so C_{nm}=(C_n)^m. Also, C_{nm-1}=C_{nm} so C_{nm-1}=(C_n)^m. (C_n)^m=e for some m<=1260, but that doesn't the least k>0 with C_k=e will be <=1260. We just know it is <=1260*n-1. It's possible to compute an upper bound for n that is independent of x,y and hence one for the group. The exponent of the group would do (it's the least n>0 such that for every x in the group x^n=e i.e. the LCM of the orders of the elements of the group).
808. Re: Cube problem (a bit mathematical)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 29 May 2005 16:16:47 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Not exactly: if [x,y] denotes the commutator of x and y then we're > looking at the sequence: > C_0=e > C_1=e[x,y] > C_2=e[x,y][x^2,y^2] > C_3=e[x,y][x^2,y^2][x^3,y^3] > ... Ah, ok, so I did misunderstand, sorry... Makes it suddenly a lot more difficult ;-) > C_{n+1}=C_n[x^{n+1},y^{n+1}] > > in other words C_n(x,y) times the commutator x^{-n}y^{-n}x^ny^n. I think these two statements confused me. I don't think they correctly describe what you mean. For example they seem to say: C_3=[x^3,y^3][x^3,y^3][x^3,y^3] Cheers! Stefan
809. Adhesive sheets (was: Stupid Orange Stickers)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 29 May 2005 17:48:15 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > If you want thick tiles like the Deluxe cube then have a look at the > Mefferts website. I'm waiting for mine and I hope the "adhesive > sheets" I have will work great for applying the tiles to puzzles. I > hate super glue for that. It's just ugly and I can't take them off > again if I want or need to and it's just ugly. Mmh, gotta ask them > about my tiles, they're kinda very late... Will let you know about my > experiences when I get them. Works great: http://www.twistypuzzles.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=3765 Cheers! Stefan
810. Re: [Speed cubing group] Finally cracked sub-40s as a *real* average (and sub-35s as a best average)!
From: "Peter Douthwright" <pdouthwright0513@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 29 May 2005 13:51:52 -0400

What method are you using. The best I have done is a 44.22 average and a 33.81 single solve.
----- Original Message -----
From: jasmine_ellen
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, May 29, 2005 9:20 AM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] Finally cracked sub-40s as a *real* average (and sub-35s as a best average)!


Just wanted to share...

Yesterday I got a new best average of 10 time: 34.22s
40.62s, 30.17s, 34.97s, 31.48s, (27.95s), 42.44s, 30.96s, 30.11s,
(42.53s), 34.17s, 30.94s, 36.32s

And this morning I did my first average with all 12 solves sub-40s.
39.05, 32.99, 38.42, 31.54, 36.20, 36.55, 35.06, (39.93), 38.66,
(30.02), 35.43, 39.93

Also, I reckon I can now comfortably say that my _real_ average is now
sub-40s. I've done 64 solves this weekend with an overall average of
36.95s. And the last few cubing sessions I've done (totally hundreds
of solves) have all had averages sub-40s. :)

BTW, timing and scrambles were done with JNetCube.

Happy day! :)

Jasmine
http://speedcuber.blogspot.com

812. Re: Cube problem (a bit mathematical)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 29 May 2005 19:43:24 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Not exactly: if [x,y] denotes the commutator of x and y then we're > > looking at the sequence: > > C_0=e > > C_1=e[x,y] > > C_2=e[x,y][x^2,y^2] > > C_3=e[x,y][x^2,y^2][x^3,y^3] > > ... > > Ah, ok, so I did misunderstand, sorry... Makes it suddenly a lot more > difficult ;-) > > > C_{n+1}=C_n[x^{n+1},y^{n+1}] > > > > in other words C_n(x,y) times the commutator x^{-n}y^{-n}x^ny^n. > > I think these two statements confused me. I don't think they correctly > describe what you mean. For example they seem to say: > > C_3=[x^3,y^3][x^3,y^3][x^3,y^3] C_3=C_2[x^3,y^3]=(C_1[x^2,y^2])[x^3,y^3]=e[x,y][x^2,y^2][x^3,y^3]. Maybe I didn't put it clearly, Why does it look like C_3=[x^3,y^3][x^3,y^3][x^3,y^3]? I don't see how you can get that. > > Cheers! > Stefan
813. Re: Cube problem (a bit mathematical)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 29 May 2005 20:36:36 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > C_3=C_2[x^3,y^3]=(C_1[x^2,y^2])[x^3,y^3]=e[x,y][x^2,y^2][x^3,y^3]. Oh, ok, for some reason I thought C_n is a _number_ which is then _multiplied_ with the commutator. Sorry again, not my day ;-) Cheers! Stefan

815. Re: [Speed cubing group] Finally cracked sub-40s as a *real* average (and sub-35s as a best average)!
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 29 May 2005 23:53:35 -0000

Hi Peter, I use a pretty standard 3-look LL method... cross (always white), F2L pairs, orient edges, orient corners, permute all. My best single solve is 23.12s. I can get sub-30s times, but not very often. Of the 64 cubes I did this weekend, only 2 were sub-30s. Although 6 were *almost* sub-30s (i.e. 6 solves were 30.xx) so I'm definitely improving! :) On the downside, 16 of the solves were over 40s though. :( What method do you use? Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Peter Douthwright" <pdouthwright0513@r...> wrote: > What method are you using. 818. Re: Black and White cubes mixed
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 30 May 2005 01:48:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@m...> wrote: > > > The corner and edge pieces of the white cubes are larger than > the > > corner and edge pieces of the black DIY cubes. The black centers > don't > > hold the white pieces far enough apart to work without some serious > > jerry rigging or bodging. > > > > David J > > > Three weeks ago I put together a white DIY with the centers of a > black DIY and I've been using it exclusively ever since. I used the > white center caps and had to use superglue for them since they don't > have any other way of fitting to the black center, but that's the > only rigging it's had. I initially lubed it and found it to be much > too slick for me to control, so i washed it off and it's still > slicker than I was ever able to make my black DIY. I'm also > thinking the white doesn't break itself in as fast as the black does > in that the dirty looking dust isn't showing up as much as my black > ones. For me, I like this because my cube came out great from the > start (after removing the lube), so I'm hoping it will have a > longer life before the corners become too loose and jiggly. > > Was there ever a definitive answer to this being a legal cube? > It is somewhat canabalized from two Rubik's products and there is no > way of seeing a difference without taking it apart. I do like this > cube. The white caps are making up for the center cubies being smaller? How did you tune the cube with the centers off? Would you check and see if your black DIY parts are smaller than the white DIY parts? TIA, David J
819. Re: Black and White cubes mixed
From: "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 30 May 2005 02:17:15 -0000

> The white caps are making up for the center cubies being smaller? How
> did you tune the cube with the centers off?
>
Not at all, the two centers are the same size. The white cap's
edges are flush with the black center. The only way of seeing they
weren't made for each other, other than the obvious color
difference, is that the ridge on the back of the white cap is farther
inboard than the black's inside is thick. Maybe that's a bad
explanation, I'm saying the white cap can't be put onto the black
center and remain on it's own by simply pressing it on, it must be
glued. Conversely, the black cap's ridge would have be cut or shaved
off to fit onto the white center, then of course glued to remain.

> Would you check and see if your black DIY parts are smaller than the
> white DIY parts?
>
The cubies are all the same size. They are obviously made from
different molds, but I've mixed them together on both black rounded
centers and the white flat centers and the cubies all interact fine.
Turning the mixed cubes, I can feel a difference in that not all
turns feel as smooth, but I think it's attributed to the difference
in the white and black plastics, not the fitting of the pieces.


Matt

you! It gave me much needed motivation to start working on F2L. Hope
to see you guys at WC2005, and hopefully by then I'll actually be as
fast as some of you. =P

827. Re: [Speed cubing group] Horace Mann Report
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 30 May 2005 08:29:52 -0000

If the cube is off by one turn as defined by the WCA rules. Basically, the cube wasn't lined up properly. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o...> wrote: > In your report, you said > > My first solve was 25.18 seconds, but I got a 2-second penalty. > > I've never competed in a real tournament, and I'm curious what you > get penalties for? > > > > Bryan Mytko > bryanosaurus@b... > > > On May 29, 2005, at 6:16 PM, Bob Burton wrote: > > > Hey, > > > > If anybody is interested, I posted my report on the Horace Mann > > tournament held yesterday. 833. Horace Mann
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 30 May 2005 16:21:33 -0000

Hi all,

I'm really enjoying reading about the tournament since I didn't get
to see much of it myself so keep those reports and pictures coming!
I've got 4 hours of video to sift through and I'm looking for people
to host some clips from the tournament. If you've got some space on
your website, please e-mail me privately and let me know how much
space you have. I'll post to the group once videos are up.


I really enjoyed the weekend (despite some serious sleep
deprivation) and it was great seeing some old friends and making
some new ones. The competition was even better than I expected with
numerous world and American records set. Six of the eight finalists
averaged sub-20 in the finals!

This event wouldn't have happened without the efforts of a bunch of
people so a great big thank you to:

All the competitors for making the trip to New York (in particular
to Tyson, Ryan, Macky, Chris H., and Rich for traveling so far).
The Horace Mann School for the use of their facilities.
Winning-Moves for donating prizes.
cubesmith.com for donating stickers for all the competitors.
Tyson for scrambling, judging, organizing, and a million other
things.
Jason for doing all things excel and for entering the 4x4
competition moments after learning the parity algs.
HM volunteers (Marco, Aram - did anyone recognize him as the young
Ben Stiller from the Royal Tannenbaums?, Fran, Eleanor, Johnny,
Amanda and a few others whose names I've forgotten (sorry!)) for
judging and other important stuff.
Jeremy for filming.
Maria, Laura, and Alison for running the concession stand.
Peter for technical support.
My wife Theresa for single-handedly running the BBQube.
Everyone else who scrambled, judged, or helped out in any way.

All in all, I was very pleased with the event. Now it's time to get
back to reality and start grading 102 final exams. :)

Ian Winokur

842. 1 handed cubing

Date: Wed, 01 Jun 2005 00:56:38 -0000

I recently started 1 handed cubing. Well to get to my point, I'm
right handed and I feal more conferadable solving 1 handed with my
left hand. I was just wondering if this is the same for other 1
handed cubers out there?




843. Re: [Speed cubing group] 1 handed cubing
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 31 May 2005 18:07:26 -0700

Most of us are like that. I'm not a very good one-handed cuber, but
I'm right handed and I cube one-handed with my left hand. Other
notable cubers that do the same are Chris Hardwick, Macky, and Ryan
Patricio, and they're really fast.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

846. F2L algorithm help
From: "Jason Baum" <speedrunningcuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 01 Jun 2005 05:57:57 -0000

Hey,

I'm looking for an algorithm that switches two middle layer edge
pieces while flipping both of them at the same time. To see what I'm
talking about if that doesn't make sense, do R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 y2 z M U M
U M U2 M' U M' U M' U2 on a solved cube. Can someone help me out
here? Thanks,

-Jason





847. Multisolves
From: keggerius <keggerius@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 31 May 2005 23:23:46 -0700 (PDT)

Hey everybody! For a while now I've been working on
improving my methods for solving the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5
two different ways, or what I like to call a
"multisolve".

For those who aren't familiar with this, I'll explain:
the 4x4x4 can be scrambled as a 2x2x2 or a 3x3x3, and
the 5x5x5 can be scrambled as a 3x3x3 in two different
ways. By scrambling the puzzle first one way and then
the other, and then solving in reverse order, the
puzzle becomes a "custom" 2x2x2 or 3x3x3 that has
different "pieces" every time. Especially challenging
are the two cases that require orienting the centers
in the first stage of the solve. I will refer to these
as the "hard" cases, and the other two as the "easy"
cases.

I find multisolves to be very fun, and also quite
addictive to try to improve on, because of the greater
challenges they provide in piece recognition. Because
speedcubing.com has records from only 3 or 4 other
people in these categories, I must assume that few
people have ever tried multisolves, probably because
they never even considered them. It would be great to
get some more people interested, and compare times and
methods.

Anyway, here are my best times for all four types:

4x4x4 easy case
(scramble as 3x3x3, then as 2x2x2)
1:15.84

4x4x4 hard case
(scramble as 2x2x2, then as 3x3x3)
2:24.77

5x5x5 easy case
(scramble using only outer layers, then both layers)
1:45.95

5x5x5 hard case
(scramble using both layers, then only outer layers)
2:45.06

Except for the 4x4x4 easy case, these times are by far
the fastest I know of. While that's great, it simply
doesn't seem right when you consider that multisolves
are basically 2x2x2 and 3x3x3 solves, and there are
dozens of active members in this group alone who can
beat me in those categories by a wide margin. So, in
order to rectify this: I DARE anyone to beat my times!
That should do it. Now to sit back and await my
comeuppance, which will no doubt be arriving shortly.

-Ben B.



__________________________________
Discover Yahoo!
Find restaurants, movies, travel and more fun for the weekend. Check it out!
http://discover.yahoo.com/weekend.html



848. blindfold attempt

Date: Tue, 31 May 2005 23:29:59 -0700

For your entertainment, I think the picture explains itself.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology




849. Re: [Speed cubing group] blindfold attempt
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 31 May 2005 23:42:56 -0700

:-D Success! 6 minutes 14.97 seconds

F B' U F2 R2 D' R2 L2 D' B' R2 F2 D' B2 L F2 U' R2 F2 L2 U F' R' D' L

Well, I solved it blindfolded at JFK but I put it a U-turn off... so
this is kind of my first one. It's my first timed blindfold solve.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On May 31, 2005, at 11:29 PM, Tyson Mao wrote:

Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, June 01, 2005 5:40 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: 1 handed cubing > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, metgorubiks > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I recently started 1 handed cubing. 851. [Speed cubing group] Re: Multisolves
From: keggerius <keggerius@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 1 Jun 2005 00:31:58 -0700 (PDT)

P.S. Since the 6x6x6 has been discussed recently, I thought it would also be worth noting that while the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 have just two multisolves each, the 6x6x6 would have 18 possible multisolves. Now I REALLY can't wait to get one! --- keggerius <keggerius@...> wrote: > Hey everybody! For a while now I've been working on > improving my methods for solving the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 > two different ways, or what I like to call a > "multisolve". > > For those who aren't familiar with this, I'll > explain: > the 4x4x4 can be scrambled as a 2x2x2 or a 3x3x3, > and > the 5x5x5 can be scrambled as a 3x3x3 in two > different > ways. By scrambling the puzzle first one way and > then > the other, and then solving in reverse order, the > puzzle becomes a "custom" 2x2x2 or 3x3x3 that has > different "pieces" every time. Especially > challenging > are the two cases that require orienting the centers > in the first stage of the solve. I will refer to > these > as the "hard" cases, and the other two as the "easy" > cases. > > I find multisolves to be very fun, and also quite > addictive to try to improve on, because of the > greater > challenges they provide in piece recognition. > Because > speedcubing.com has records from only 3 or 4 other > people in these categories, I must assume that few > people have ever tried multisolves, probably because > they never even considered them. It would be great > to > get some more people interested, and compare times > and > methods. > > Anyway, here are my best times for all four types: > > 4x4x4 easy case > (scramble as 3x3x3, then as 2x2x2) > 1:15.84 > > 4x4x4 hard case > (scramble as 2x2x2, then as 3x3x3) > 2:24.77 > > 5x5x5 easy case > (scramble using only outer layers, then both layers) > 1:45.95 > > 5x5x5 hard case > (scramble using both layers, then only outer layers) > 2:45.06 > > Except for the 4x4x4 easy case, these times are by > far > the fastest I know of. While that's great, it simply > doesn't seem right when you consider that > multisolves > are basically 2x2x2 and 3x3x3 solves, and there are > dozens of active members in this group alone who can > beat me in those categories by a wide margin. So, in > order to rectify this: I DARE anyone to beat my > times! > That should do it. Now to sit back and await my > comeuppance, which will no doubt be arriving > shortly. > > -Ben B. > > > > __________________________________ > Discover Yahoo! > Find restaurants, movies, travel and more fun for > the weekend. Check it out! > http://discover.yahoo.com/weekend.html > > __________________________________ Discover Yahoo! Have fun online with music videos, cool games, IM and more. Check it out! http://discover.yahoo.com/online.html
852. Re: F2L algorithm help
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 01 Jun 2005 12:22:11 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jason Baum" <speedrunningcuber@y...> wrote: > Hey, > > I'm looking for an algorithm that switches two middle layer edge > pieces while flipping both of them at the same time. To see what I'm > talking about if that doesn't make sense, do R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 y2 z M U M > U M U2 M' U M' U M' U2 on a solved cube. Can someone help me out > here? Thanks, > > -Jason Only found this naive one: (R U R') d' (L U' L') d (R U' R) y (L U L') Cheers! Stefan
853. Re: Multisolves
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 01 Jun 2005 13:04:37 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, keggerius <keggerius@y. ..> wrote: I just gave it a try and it's indeed fun. I used two scrambles from the Sunday contest for each case and I write them in the order I did them (and the my number of attempts). > 5x5x5 easy case > (scramble using only outer layers, then both layers) > 1:45.95 2:11.55 (2) > 4x4x4 easy case > (scramble as 3x3x3, then as 2x2x2) > 1:15.84 1:05.49 (1) > 4x4x4 hard case > (scramble as 2x2x2, then as 3x3x3) > 2:24.77 8:22.43 (1) The first 1.5 minutes or so I had no idea what to do ;-) > 5x5x5 hard case > (scramble using both layers, then only outer layers) > 2:45.06 7:26.68 (1) This is truly fun :-) Once you get to the second phase it's such a relief... I know I've seen them on SCC but I can't find them anymore. Where are they? Cheers! Stefan

Damn... tried another hard multi-5x5 and was much faster but screwed
up permuting the LL edges of the first phase...

ago in the 100th edition of the weekly online Japanese Speedcubing
Contest:

855. Re: F2L algorithm help
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 01 Jun 2005 13:34:10 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jason Baum" > <speedrunningcuber@y...> wrote: > > Hey, > > > > I'm looking for an algorithm that switches two middle layer edge > > pieces while flipping both of them at the same time. To see what > I'm > > talking about if that doesn't make sense, do R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 y2 z M U > M > > U M U2 M' U M' U M' U2 on a solved cube. Can someone help me out > > here? Thanks, > > > > -Jason > > Only found this naive one: > (R U R') d' (L U' L') d (R U' R) y (L U L') > > Cheers! > Stefan Or with a commutator based on E-slice, since it's a matter of edges: [BR'UB'R, E]. BR'UB'R E R'BU'RB' D is 13 QTM moves too, but 12 SQTM ;-) ACube found this one: R'BU2S'U'SRUR'B' (11 HTM, 10 STM). Probably not faster than yours. Gilles.
856. Re: F2L algorithm help
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>

That's not exactly what he wants, you forgot to switch them ;-) Cheers! Stefan

859. Re: F2L algorithm help
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 01 Jun 2005 14:20:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > Or with a commutator based on E-slice, since it's a matter of edges: > > [BR'UB'R, E]. > > BR'UB'R E R'BU'RB' D is 13 QTM moves too, but 12 SQTM ;-) > > > > ACube found this one: R'BU2S'U'SRUR'B' (11 HTM, 10 STM). > > Probably not faster than yours. > > That's not exactly what he wants, you forgot to switch them ;-) But you made me think about something again. How about this: L' u' B2 M' B' M E' B' U L But I modified it even further: R' S R S' E R E' R' *You* (Gilles) should've found something like this and you know why ; -) Actually I think you might like this execution even better: l' E' R E x' E R E' R' What do you say? Cheers! Stefan

862. Re: F2L algorithm help
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 01 Jun 2005 19:59:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jason Baum" <speedrunningcuber@y...> wrote: > Hey, > > I'm looking for an algorithm that switches two middle layer edge > pieces while flipping both of them at the same time. To see what I'm > talking about if that doesn't make sense, do R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 y2 z M U M > U M U2 M' U M' U M' U2 on a solved cube. Can someone help me out > here? Thanks, > > -Jason Hi Jason, I've an alg for you. For me it's the simplest and quickest. To watch it work put the First Level on the left and the Last Level on the right (or vice-versa) and the middle pair to be flipped and swapped on the bottom. I use r to mean the slice next to R. Turn r the same direction that you would turn R. r U r U' r' U r' U' Cheers, David J
863. Re: F2L algorithm help
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 01 Jun 2005 20:55:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jason Baum" > <speedrunningcuber@y...> wrote: > > Hey, > > > > I'm looking for an algorithm that switches two middle layer edge > > pieces while flipping both of them at the same time. To see what I'm > > talking about if that doesn't make sense, do R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 y2 z M U M > > U M U2 M' U M' U M' U2 on a solved cube. Can someone help me out > > here? Thanks, > > > > -Jason > > Hi Jason, > > I've an alg for you. For me it's the simplest and quickest. > > To watch it work put the First Level on the left and the Last Level on > the right (or vice-versa) and the middle pair to be flipped and > swapped on the bottom. > > I use r to mean the slice next to R. Turn r the same direction that > you would turn R. > > r U r U' r' U r' U' > > Cheers, > > David J Nice David, that's really the simplest. This reminds me an idea I had a few years ago (and I'm certainly not the only one), you could solve the F2L following this algorithm: 1) Solve the first layer. 2) Solve 2 middle edges (neighbours). If you assume that at least a middle edge already lies in the last layer, and considering symetries, the number of sequences needed is really small. Some would look like Waterman's, others can be enhanced for speed. 3) Solve the last 2 middle edges. I don't think this strategy can be better than the standard approach, only in special cases when the first layer looks easy. But you certainly can solve the F2L in less than 10s and I'd be curious to see someone optimize it for speed... Gilles.
864. Re: F2L algorithm help
From: Gaétan Guimond <rubiks99ca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 02 Jun 2005 02:27:48 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jason Baum" > <speedrunningcuber@y...> wrote: > > Hey, > > > > I'm looking for an algorithm that switches two middle layer edge > > pieces while flipping both of them at the same time. To see what I'm > > talking about if that doesn't make sense, do R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 y2 z M U M > > U M U2 M' U M' U M' U2 on a solved cube. Can someone help me out > > here? Thanks, > > > > -Jason > > Hi Jason, > > I've an alg for you. For me it's the simplest and quickest. > > To watch it work put the First Level on the left and the Last Level on > the right (or vice-versa) and the middle pair to be flipped and > swapped on the bottom. > > I use r to mean the slice next to R. Turn r the same direction that > you would turn R. > > r U r U' r' U r' U' > > Cheers, > > David J I use the same algorythm a long time ago :)) My notation Turn r (M) is the same direction that Kik methode (french notation) on http://www.rubikscuberecord.com/ M'H M H' M' H M' H' (H=U) Look my triangle in Function corner, French explanation message 3609, may 30 on http://fr.groups.yahoo.com/group/rubiklub/ Gaétan

874. Re: F2L algorithm help
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>

Looks good, but is 90% mystery to me ;-) Can you explain how/why it works? 875. 5x5 Lube
From: "Wayne" <mylib_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 02 Jun 2005 17:19:43 -0000

Does anyone here know how to lube a 5x5. I was able to pop a piece out
for my 4x4 but the 5x5 is really tight and I'm afraid of breaking it.

Wayne




876. Re: F2L algorithm help
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 02 Jun 2005 19:04:38 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > I've an alg for you. For me it's the simplest and quickest. > > > > r U r U' r' U r' U' > > Cheater, cheater! > > I can do it even shorter. Hold the two edges at FL and FR and do: > L R U D F' > > Cheers! > Stefan You are right. I moved *fewer* pieces (other than the pair specified) than in his example. Cheers, DJ
877. Re: 5x5 Lube
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 02 Jun 2005 19:21:24 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Wayne" <mylib_2000@y...> wrote: > Does anyone here know how to lube a 5x5. I was able to pop a piece out > for my 4x4 but the 5x5 is really tight and I'm afraid of breaking it. > > Wayne My cube isn't particularly loose but it is much better than it once was. I suggest you turn a slice through 45 degrees and spray the exposed innards. You'll be able to hit either one side of 2 slices or 1 side of 2 slices and 2 sides of a third, depending which slice (outer or inner) you rotate. Do this for several slices and slice them back in. This will get the spray inside. I used this technique on my 4x4x4 and my 5x5x5.
878. Re: F2L algorithm help
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 02 Jun 2005 22:05:15 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jason Baum" > > <speedrunningcuber@y...> wrote: > > > Thanks Gilles and Stefan. Those algorithms were very helpful! > > > > > > -Jason > > > > > > Another very fast one that does the job (I hope): > > (r'Ur)u(R'U'R)y(Ru'R') (r=R+inner slice) > > > > Gilles. > > Looks good, but is 90% mystery to me ;-) Can you explain how/why it > works? It reminds me of another special F2L alg I recently found on > SCC: > R U2 R2 u' R' u R > I don't understand that one, either... :-( > > Stefan Think with blocks instead of sides. It looked like a case where you have to break things already built to create a free space, and reinsert them the same way, or in another way. (r'Uru) takes the B-BR-BRD-BD 1x2x2 block out of the F2L and moves it to a safe place. (Bu'B') puts it back in another way, changing unsafe middle edges. It works like (R'URU)(BU'B), but with a block. I found that (R'U'R) between the two (change a few things in the free space) answers the problem. Based on this, you can build similar sequences: - (r'Uru)(BUB'U')(Bu'B') - (r'Uru)(R'U2R)(Bu'B') - (BuB')(BUB'U')(Bu'B') = BuUB'U'Bu'B' changes only 1 edge, but I like it more than other shorter sequences. - etc. When dealing with partial F2L, I mean 2*1x2x3, more optimizations can be found. I admit that's not very scientifical :-) Gilles.
879. Cubing while juggling (3 of them)
From: "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 03 Jun 2005 00:57:17 -0000

solving a cube one-handed while solving two other cubes in the other
hand and cycling them through until having all three solved:
3:09.00

I'm done with finals and have a lot of time on hand...when Richard
Patterson IMed me with the idea, I just had to try it. ;)

Just had to share.

Macky

Date: Fri, 03 Jun 2005 06:58:58 -0000

> Just had to share.

Unbelievable.

-Chris

883. Re: SV: [Speed cubing group] Cubing while juggling (3 of them)
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 3 Jun 2005 00:13:23 -0700

You juggle two cubes in one hand, then solve the third cube in the other hand. Then you just switch off the cubes with some type of cross throw and you repeat until all cubes are solved. Then you proceed to get another four cubes, so you juggle all 7 cubes, you do a db97531, and then you're done. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Jun 3, 2005, at 12:07 AM, Terje Kristensen wrote: > Just wondered if you really meant “while JUGGLING the two other cubes” > ... the main text didnt quite match the subject :) > > Terje > > -----Opprinnelig melding----- > Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av > mackymakisumi > Sendt: 3. juni 2005 02:57 > Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Emne: [Speed cubing group] Cubing while juggling (3 of them) > > solving a cube one-handed while solving two other cubes in the other > hand and cycling them through until having all three solved: > 3:09.00 > > I'm done with finals and have a lot of time on hand...when Richard > Patterson IMed me with the idea, I just had to try it. ;) > > Just had to share. > > Macky > > > > > _____ > > Yahoo! Groups Links > * To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > * To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > <mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com? > subject=Unsub > scribe> > > * Your use of Yahoo! 884. Re: F2L algorithm help
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 03 Jun 2005 08:35:15 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > You are right. I moved *fewer* pieces (other than the pair > specified) than in his example. As can be seen in the subject, his question was about F2L. So you change *more* pieces: One more 2nd layer edge and if you hold the cube like you suggested then also a 1st layer edge :-) Cheers! Stefan
885. blindfold for normal solving
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 3 Jun 2005 01:58:34 -0700

I just had an idea. What would happen if I taught someone how to solve
a cube with their eyes open but with the blindfold method? In fact, I
was even thinking about teaching them how to permute first and orient
later, because with your eyes open, orientations are easy to spot once
the pieces are in place. I've got someone who wants to learn... I'm
thinking about using her as a guinea pig.

Just think about it. And then like, after they've learned, you just
say... oh btw... just limit yourself to these set up moves, change the
order in which you do things and... uh, yeah, you can blindfold.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology




886. Re: F2L algorithm help
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 03 Jun 2005 09:24:58 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > Think with blocks instead of sides. > It looked like a case where you have to break things already built to > create a free space, and reinsert them the same way, or in another way. Thanks, your explanation and the other examples helped a lot. > - (BuB')(BUB'U')(Bu'B') = BuUB'U'Bu'B' changes only 1 edge, but I like > it more than other shorter sequences. How about this one? R U' M' U R' U' M It's basically (R U' R') (r U R' U' M), I found that second part recently when I tried to get rid of cube rotations and F turns for that case. Actually I'd execute the combination as (R U' r R' U R' U' R r'). If you start with left thumb on F and right thumb on D then it's quite fast. Mmh, actually then (R U' l' U R' U' l) feels nice, too... But I'd certainly prefer my new one if the LL corners look good, since they're not changed. Hmm, another thought. Inverses. Try (r R' U R U' R r' U R') and (l' U R U' l U R'). Strange, why did I never before think about using inverses of F2L algs? Cheers! Stefan

889. New 3x3x3 single solve record by Macky!!
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 03 Jun 2005 14:40:25 -0000

Wooow !!!

9.89 secs by Macky on the 3x3x3 cube. Where will this end? well
obviously it will end. Can't do zero/negative time hehe ...

http://www.speedcubing.com/records/recs_cube_333.html

Awesome Macky !! I did set up the scramble for that solve. Doesn't
seem to be too easy in any way. Didn't try to solve it though, cause
i'm not a top 3x3x3 speedcuber ;-)

Cheers!

-Per

893. Re: F2L algorithm help
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 03 Jun 2005 18:46:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > You are right. I moved *fewer* pieces (other than the pair > > specified) than in his example. > > As can be seen in the subject, his question was about F2L. So you > change *more* pieces: One more 2nd layer edge and if you hold the cube > like you suggested then also a 1st layer edge :-) > > Cheers! > Stefan Hi Stefan, I wrote, > To watch it work put the First Level on the left and the Last Level on the right (or vice-versa) and the middle pair to be flipped and swapped on the bottom. < "Vice versa" means you can have the FL on the right, and therefore it doesn't have to change any edge on the First Level. Besides, I do the F2L differently from you. To swap two edges you must swap either two other edges or two corners minimum. My "flip two edges and swap them," only swapped two other edges - that is minimum. r U r U' r' U r' U' makes fewer changes than his > R2 U2 R2 U2 R2 y2 z M U M U M U2 M' U M' U M' U2 < which additionally changes the position of four corners and two edges. My statement is accurate. :) Cheers, David J
894. Re: 5x5 Lube

To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

I was able to pop a piece out > for my 4x4 but the 5x5 is really tight and I'm afraid of breaking it. > > Wayne
895. Re: F2L algorithm help
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 04 Jun 2005 10:41:51 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > "Vice versa" means you can have the FL on the right, and therefore it > doesn't have to change any edge on the First Level. I know what it means. But it was written in parentheses which makes it look like an alternative only, the main option being putting it on the left. > Besides, I do the F2L differently from you. Still, as long as with "F2L" you don't mean two adjacent outer layers (which would be kinda strange (though maybe I just invented a new method)), I think you change a third F2L edge (which we don't). > My statement is accurate. :) Well, obviously depends on how one counts ;-) Cheers! Stefan

897. Last Layer Corner Piece Position
From: "advil2night" <asacrewmember@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 05 Jun 2005 20:18:58 -0000

I'd like to get on to speedcubing, but I gotta be able to solve it
first. Down the road maybe.

In any case, I can complete the first 2 layers and make the cross on
the final layer with no problems. I position the cube with the cross
up.

I've got the final layer edges positioned as well.

This leaves 4 corners on the final layer.

1 of the 4 is in the correct position (but not oriented correctly).

Using any number of sites (4 to be exact), I am left with the same
results each time. When I try to position the 3 remaining LL corners
into their respective corners, I get an out of place corner on the
bottom layer. If I position the cross up and the correct position
corner piece in the Upper Right Corner, and then apply U R U' L' U R'
U' L, I get the back bottom corner out of color. If I repeat the same
move 2 more times, I'll be back where I started. Any ideas




898. fastest time to mix up a cube
From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 06 Jun 2005 00:54:37 -0000

hey all, haven't posted here in a while. still cubing though!
so today, I decided to try something. in Jess Bonde's Timer, it shows
a scrambling algorithm while the timer is going. soo.... I decided to
see how fast I could mix up a cube. my first time was 11.67 I think,
and I reduced it so far to 8.69 seconds. I'm sure that with practice I
could get under 8 seconds at least.... maybe faster. I think that this
would be good for practice because you have to figure out how to do
random moves really fast and make them flow together really well
without locking up and all that.... yes. so that's my story. has
anyone else tried this? or will anyone else try it and totally
demolish my record?




899. Re: [Speed cubing group] fastest time to mix up a cube
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 5 Jun 2005 18:00:38 -0700

Hahaha! This is great! Ian, Chris, and I were 'scramble racing' at
Ian's house at about 3 AM in New York during the weekend of the
tournament. Yeah, Chris beat us pretty hard. He was hitting sub-8's
pretty regularly. Macky came into my room the other day and wanted to
try it. Using my cube, he hit 8.68 on the first try. My times are
between 10 and 11 right now.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

900. Re: [Speed cubing group] Last Layer Corner Piece Position
From: Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 5 Jun 2005 18:24:59 -0700 (PDT)

Hey, Try this out: www.geocities.com/rubiks_galaxia/4lookLL.html Try this approach for the LL... 1. flip up edges you already know how to do this. 2. flip up corners Using the sequences on the page I provided, you should be able to complete this step. 3. position corners sequences are on the page I provided 4. position edges again, sequences are on the page I provided Hope this helps! -Richard --- advil2night <asacrewmember@...> wrote: > I'd like to get on to speedcubing, but I gotta be > able to solve it > first. Down the road maybe. > > In any case, I can complete the first 2 layers and > make the cross on > the final layer with no problems. I position the > cube with the cross > up. > > I've got the final layer edges positioned as well. > > This leaves 4 corners on the final layer. > > 1 of the 4 is in the correct position (but not > oriented correctly). > > Using any number of sites (4 to be exact), I am left > with the same > results each time. When I try to position the 3 > remaining LL corners > into their respective corners, I get an out of place > corner on the > bottom layer. If I position the cross up and the > correct position > corner piece in the Upper Right Corner, and then > apply U R U' L' U R' > U' L, I get the back bottom corner out of color. If > I repeat the same > move 2 more times, I'll be back where I started. Any > ideas > > > __________________________________ Discover Yahoo! Date: Sun, 5 Jun 2005 23:29:09 -0400
