Steve On 6/5/05, Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...> wrote: > Hey, > > Try this out: > > www.geocities.com/rubiks_galaxia/4lookLL.html > > Try this approach for the LL... > > 1. flip up edges > you already know how to do this. > > 2. flip up corners > Using the sequences on the page I provided, you should > be able to complete this step. > > 3. position corners > sequences are on the page I provided > > 4. position edges > again, sequences are on the page I provided > > Hope this helps! > > -Richard > > --- advil2night <asacrewmember@...> wrote: > > > I'd like to get on to speedcubing, but I gotta be > > able to solve it > > first. Down the road maybe. > > > > In any case, I can complete the first 2 layers and > > make the cross on > > the final layer with no problems. I position the > > cube with the cross > > up. > > > > I've got the final layer edges positioned as well. > > > > This leaves 4 corners on the final layer. > > > > 1 of the 4 is in the correct position (but not > > oriented correctly). > > > > Using any number of sites (4 to be exact), I am left > > with the same > > results each time. When I try to position the 3 > > remaining LL corners > > into their respective corners, I get an out of place > > corner on the > > bottom layer. If I position the cross up and the > > correct position > > corner piece in the Upper Right Corner, and then > > apply U R U' L' U R' > > U' L, I get the back bottom corner out of color. If > > I repeat the same > > move 2 more times, I'll be back where I started. Any > > ideas > > > > > > > > > > > __________________________________ > Discover Yahoo! > Find restaurants, movies, travel and more fun for the weekend. Check it out! > http://discover.yahoo.com/weekend.html > > > ________________________________ > Yahoo! Groups Links > > To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.
903. An awful idea...
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 06 Jun 2005 05:46:35 -0000

I just found out how bad of an idea it was to completely disassemble
and reassemble a Rubik's Magic. Total time: ~ 2 hours, end result:
unfavorable wire positions and improper tile placement so that I'll
have to take it apart AGAIN to fix it. My opinion: this was a
terrible idea!

~ Bob




904. RE: [Speed cubing group] Last Layer Corner Piece Position
From: "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@...>
To: "'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com'" <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 6 Jun 2005 08:38:55 +0200

I can't make out exactly where you are in the solve, but the last layer algoritms you can use would be: Positioning corners: Put good corner in UFR position and apply R2 D' L R' F2 R L' U2 D R2 You might have to do this twice. If you dont have any good corners, just apply the algoritm and you will get one. Rotating corners: Put wrong corner in UFR position To rotate clockwise, apply F D F' D' F D F' D' To rotate counterclockwise, apply D F D' F' D F D' F' Turn U until you have another wrong corner in UFR position (Keep the rest of the cube in the same position!!!!!!!) and apply algoritm. Repeat until all corners are correct. I am not a speedcuber myself, but this works for me. Good luck solving the cube. - Bram -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- Van: advil2night [mailto:asacrewmember@...] Verzonden: zondag 5 juni 2005 22:19 Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group] Last Layer Corner Piece Position I'd like to get on to speedcubing, but I gotta be able to solve it first. Down the road maybe. In any case, I can complete the first 2 layers and make the cross on the final layer with no problems. I position the cube with the cross up. I've got the final layer edges positioned as well. This leaves 4 corners on the final layer. 1 of the 4 is in the correct position (but not oriented correctly). Using any number of sites (4 to be exact), I am left with the same results each time. When I try to position the 3 remaining LL corners into their respective corners, I get an out of place corner on the bottom layer. If I position the cross up and the correct position corner piece in the Upper Right Corner, and then apply U R U' L' U R' U' L, I get the back bottom corner out of color. If I repeat the same move 2 more times, I'll be back where I started. Any ideas _____ Yahoo! 905. Spring breakages
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 06 Jun 2005 12:53:28 -0000

Sorry if this is a regular topic here, but don't remember seeing any
discussion -

I have trouble with springs breaking (studio cube): 4 in the past 6
months. That may not sound too bad, but I doubt that the cube has
averaged much more than 1 hour's use per day.

What's considered "normal" for spring breakages?

Also, is it possible to reduce the risk of it happening? The cube is
well lubricated and the ends of the springs are smooth, but I haven't
bothered to file the screw-thread flat underneath the spring. I keep
the centres screwed well down to reduce the risk of pops -- maybe
that's the problem (if these spring breakages are unusual).

Ideas, please!

Mike




906. Re: An awful idea...
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 06 Jun 2005 12:55:18 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > I just found out how bad of an idea it was to completely disassemble > and reassemble a Rubik's Magic. Total time: ~ 2 hours, end result: > unfavorable wire positions and improper tile placement so that I'll > have to take it apart AGAIN to fix it. My opinion: this was a > terrible idea! 2 hours seems excessive. Have you used Jaap's instructions? I found them very helpful! Mike
907. Re: Spring breakages
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 06 Jun 2005 13:40:58 -0000

The only springs I have *ever* broken were when I tried to grind their ends flat with a dremel clone and did too much. I have *never* broken a spring inside a puzzle (and I do have numerous puzzles of different types including studio cubes). I'd assume it's because you tightened the springs too much. The studio cubes have way too strong springs and a much much better way to reduce pops is to use weaker springs (which will also reduce the general tension/friction). I have a mint one which I haven't lubed or sanded yet, which doesn't pop (well, unless I really purposely try to, actually it's not even easy to disassemble) and which already allows me to do the T-perm four times in 10 seconds (i.e. 5.6 moves/second) fairly easily (with a good cube I need about 8.5 seconds unless I lock up). All I did was replace the springs and add some washers. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > Sorry if this is a regular topic here, but don't remember seeing any > discussion - > > I have trouble with springs breaking (studio cube): 4 in the past 6 > months. That may not sound too bad, but I doubt that the cube has > averaged much more than 1 hour's use per day. > > What's considered "normal" for spring breakages? > > Also, is it possible to reduce the risk of it happening? The cube is > well lubricated and the ends of the springs are smooth, but I haven't > bothered to file the screw-thread flat underneath the spring. I keep > the centres screwed well down to reduce the risk of pops -- maybe > that's the problem (if these spring breakages are unusual). > > Ideas, please! > > Mike

Why not go to a hardware store and by a few sets of springs with
different tensions and test which works best ;)

913. Re: F2L algorithm help
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 06 Jun 2005 20:16:11 -0000

Hi Stefan, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > "Vice versa" means you can have the FL on the right, and therefore > it > > doesn't have to change any edge on the First Level. > > I know what it means. But it was written in parentheses which makes it > look like an alternative only, the main option being putting it on the > left. The parentheses indicate a legitimate alternative, not some inferior alternative. If it is allowed it is allowed, period. The primary elements, the flip and swap, are accomplished both ways. I do middle edges before First Level edges, with the option of doing two middle edges both before or after the four First Level corners. > > Besides, I do the F2L differently from you. > > Still, as long as with "F2L" you don't mean two adjacent outer layers > My solution changes three middle layer edges and one edge on either the First Level or the Last Level. At no time does it effect both First Level and Last level. > (which would be kinda strange (though maybe I just invented a new > method)), I think you change a third F2L edge (which we don't). I do change a third middle edge, but that is fine in my F2L method. > > My statement is accurate. :) > > Well, obviously depends on how one counts ;-) No, it doesn't. :P His original two algs have an unecessary U2, leaving two edges and all four LL corners out of place. Cheers, David J > > Cheers! > Stefan

But it was written in parentheses which makes it > look like an alternative only, the main option being putting it on the > left. > > > Besides, I do the F2L differently from you. > > Still, as long as with "F2L" you don't mean two adjacent outer layers > (which would be kinda strange (though maybe I just invented a new > method)), I think you change a third F2L edge (which we don't). > > > My statement is accurate. :) > > Well, obviously depends on how one counts ;-) > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > > > > Yahoo! 916. US Nationals 2006
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, caltechrubiks@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 6 Jun 2005 14:07:00 -0700

Hi Everyone,

There's no harm in thinking about US Nationals 2006. In terms of a
venue selection, I would like to hold this tournament in some place
that we've actually had experience with. I know a lot of the mid-west
cubers were talking about the Great Mall but unless we've held a
tournament there, I don't want to take the risk with a new environment.
With that said, I have only a handful of venue locations right now.
In order to save space on discussion, I would recommend that discussion
for US Nationals takes place in the Caltech group so we don't flood all
the non-US readers with countless e-mails.

My first choice right now, and this is very early in the process, would
be the Exploratorium Museum in San Francisco, CA. We held our Winter
Tournament 2005 there and it was a lot of fun. Also, we had hundreds
of spectators because it was an open event and it was just another day
in the museum. We met after the tournament and discussed the problems
we had and they can all be fixed. The Exploratorium will probably be
our choice for the Caltech Winter Tournament 2006 so we would have
another chance to be there before a US National tournament, which would
take place in the summer of 2006. And another thing... at the
Exploratorium, we would have enough judges... and this is guaranteed.
They have high school students who work/volunteer etc. and they loved
seeing the cube last time...

Another idea is to hold it at Caltech again. I am slightly reluctant
because of the inaccessibility to food at Caltech. However, we all
know this venue very well and so it would be very easy to run a smooth
tournament here.

A third idea is Horace Mann, in New York. However, like Caltech, these
are private places. The media coverage for a tournament in a museum
would easily be 100 times more than the media attention at a private
institution.

Of course, there is a bit more hassle with competing in a museum but I
must say, I had a great time in San Francisco last January and I think
it's a lot of fun. I realize that two of these choices are again on
the west coast. For a US National tournament though, I don't want to
be playing around with a venue we haven't been at. We had a few issues
at the Exploratorium and we know what these issues are now and we can
avoid them.

One more thing is that I would probably be in favor of a two day event.
A one day event is extremely exhausting for the tournament organizers.
Furthermore, with the growing numbers of participants in Rubik's Cube
competitions these days, a two day event may be the only feasible idea.

So feel free to suggest places. I would recommend, again, that
discussion takes place in the Caltech group. I can try talking to a
few major amusement parks around, and I'm sure that would be fun, but I
would be hesitant to hold a national tournament in an unfamiliar venue.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

918. Re: Spring breakages
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 06 Jun 2005 22:32:59 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > > Will any nasty cube do as a source? I don't remember ever seeing your > favourite OBMS... does it have any aliases? I only used springs from those cheap clone cubes for my megaminx. Its springs were *way* too strong, even much stronger than those of the studio cubes. So the springs of the clones were much better. But they're much too long (and probably too strong) for 3x3s (actually for most puzzles except the current megaminx, not even the older megaminx because it had much shorter screws). Now I used springs that I've bought from an industrial spring manufacturer. I had to buy lots of them to get good prices. The manufacturer I chose is relatively cheap I think but if you only buy a single spring you pay 2-3 Euros, not even including shipping. The price drops rapidly with higher quantities but unfortunately you can't mix different springs. If you want 100 of type X and 100 of type Y then no matter how similar they are, you have to pay them separately. You can *not* pay the cheaper per-spring-price for 200 pieces. I ended up with four orders so far, almost 1000 springs altogether, spending a little more than 100 Euros. Yep, just for springs. Cheers! Stefan
919. [Speed cubing group] Re: Spring breakages
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 06 Jun 2005 22:35:11 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o.. .> wrote: > I recently got a studio cube, and I don't even use it because if I > loosen the screws to just the right place so that it spins easy, the > thing pops all the time. It's not that I lack the control of the flat > centers - my other main cube has flat centers and I never pop with > it. Do you think that replacing the springs would help make the cube > usable? Definitely yes! I know exactly what you mean. My studio cubes (also from Hungary) were exactly like you described. Either way too stiff (even after lubing) or popping horribly all the time. Now thanks to better springs they're great. Cheers! Stefan
920. Re: Spring breakages
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I only used springs from those cheap clone cubes for my megaminx. The world record one, that is. I have used other new springs for my other megaminxs and I think they'll be even better. A few days ago I got a non-lucky 1:38 as the fourth solve of a mint megaminx, which was *not* lubed, I had only used some better springs and washers. Cheers! Stefan

From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>

Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... On Jun 6, 2005, at 6:35 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o.. > .> wrote: > > I recently got a studio cube, and I don't even use it because if I > > loosen the screws to just the right place so that it spins easy, the > > > thing pops all the time. It's not that I lack the control of the > flat > > centers - my other main cube has flat centers and I never pop with > > it. Do you think that replacing the springs would help make the cube > > > usable? > > Definitely yes! > > I know exactly what you mean. My studio cubes (also from Hungary) were > exactly like you described. Either way too stiff (even after lubing) > or popping horribly all the time. Now thanks to better springs they're > great. > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
922. [Speed cubing group] Re: Spring breakages
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 06 Jun 2005 23:22:42 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o.. .> wrote: > You seem to be the guy to talk to on this subject :) > > So, what kind of springs do i want? Ones with less or more tension, > longer or shorter than the ones currently in my studio cube? The length (about 10 mm) is ok. But the wire should be thinner. Completely compress a spring, measure its compressed height and divide by the number of coils to get the wire diameter. Will probably be somewhere around 0.6 to 0.7 mm, right? I have 0.5 and 0.32, both with middle coil diameter 4 mm and length 10 and 12.7 mm, respectively. The 0.5 might still be too strong but it's certainly better already and it's the thinnest I can order with ends ground flat already (though they don't do the best job and I often sand them even further, but they're much better than not ground at all and if you use washers it gets even less important). The 0.32 are maybe a bit too weak but it depends on your cubing style. Diameter 0.4 is also available, maybe that's perfect. But I like the two strengths I have very much. Depends on the cube which is better. If you have screws with large heads or if you use large washers to reach the same effect, then 0.5 is excellent because you don't even get close to full compression. For example I use the 0. 5 ones in my newest megaminx, together with 1 nylon washer and 5 metal washers (in each center) and it feels perfect. Don't know whether you'll find cheap suppliers, maybe I could sell some of those that I have (and get back some of that 100+ Euros ;-). Cheers! Stefan
923. [Speed cubing group] Re: Spring breakages
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 06 Jun 2005 23:23:42 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I have 0.5 and 0.32, both with middle coil diameter 4 mm and length 10 > and 12.7 mm, respectively. Uncompressed, I mean.
924. Canadian National Championship 2005????
From: "Peter Douthwright" <pdouthwright0513@...>

Date: Mon, 6 Jun 2005 20:40:40 -0400

Let me know.

925. Special Team FMC #100
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>, <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 7 Jun 2005 02:11:45 +0100

Hi everyone!

The FMC has a new, fresh look, and registration has opened for the special Team Fewest Moves Event which will be held to celebrate FMC #100!

Registered competitors will be put into teams of 3, and will be given 5 weeks to solve the special scramble as a team.You can communicate as much as possible via email, phone, or whatever, and if it is possible, you will be teamed with people who live near you so you could even arrange a face to face meeting!

You are guaranteed to learn lots from the experience, and you will also have a lot of fun!

Absolutely anyone is welcome to take part, and if you are a beginner, you are sure to be teamed up with a more knowledgeable FMC'er so you can get the most out of the competition!

All you have to do to take part in this "historic" event is to register your details using the Team FMC registration form. The form is on this page http://www.cubestation.co.uk/fmcresults/teamfmc100.php - or alternatively you can visit www.cubestation.co.uk, click on the Fewest Moves Challenge link in the Red menu panel, and then click the yellow box to get to the Team FMC page. And why not browse around the new look FMC pages while you are there :)

Full details of the competition will be emailed to all registered competitors, and registration closes at around FMC week 95, and the scramble will be released at FMC #96.

Hope you can take part!

Dan Harris :)

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



926. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Spring breakages

Date: Mon, 06 Jun 2005 21:22:32 -0400

On Jun 6, 2005, at 7:22 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o.. > .> wrote: > > You seem to be the guy to talk to on this subject :) > > > > So, what kind of springs do i want? Ones with less or more tension, > > longer or shorter than the ones currently in my studio cube? > > The length (about 10 mm) is ok. But the wire should be thinner. > Completely compress a spring, measure its compressed height and divide > by the number of coils to get the wire diameter. Will probably be > somewhere around 0.6 to 0.7 mm, right? > > I have 0.5 and 0.32, both with middle coil diameter 4 mm and length 10 > and 12.7 mm, respectively. > > The 0.5 might still be too strong but it's certainly better already > and it's the thinnest I can order with ends ground flat already > (though they don't do the best job and I often sand them even further, > but they're much better than not ground at all and if you use washers > it gets even less important). > > The 0.32 are maybe a bit too weak but it depends on your cubing style. > Diameter 0.4 is also available, maybe that's perfect. > > But I like the two strengths I have very much. Depends on the cube > which is better. If you have screws with large heads or if you use > large washers to reach the same effect, then 0.5 is excellent because > you don't even get close to full compression. For example I use the 0. > 5 ones in my newest megaminx, together with 1 nylon washer and 5 metal > washers (in each center) and it feels perfect. > > Don't know whether you'll find cheap suppliers, maybe I could sell > some of those that I have (and get back some of that 100+ Euros ;-). > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! 927. Sub-20!!
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 07 Jun 2005 03:47:45 -0000

Last night I set a pb average of 20.02. Should have been happy to
improve on my old record by half a second but I was disappointed to
have just missed a sub-20 average. It took three hours of cubing
tonight but it was totally worth it:

(17.96), 19.98, 23.10, 18.23, 21.12, 19.66, 20.73, 19.96, 18.79,
18.49, (23.58), 18.77

average = 19.88

Took almost 2 and a half years but I did it! WOOHOO!!!

Ian "sub-20" Winokur

931. Re: Spring breakages
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 07 Jun 2005 10:19:21 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > I only used springs from those cheap clone cubes for my megaminx. Its > springs were *way* too strong, even much stronger than those of the > studio cubes. Oh, shoot. I spotted an OBMS yesterday and - not believing my good luck - bid on it... never mind. > Now I used springs that I've bought from an industrial spring > manufacturer. I had to buy lots of them to get good prices. When you reckon you've found "the perfect spring", please let us all know - we could help you recoup your investment :) Mike
932. Re: Spring breakages
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 07 Jun 2005 13:28:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I only used springs from those cheap clone cubes for my megaminx. Its > > springs were *way* too strong, even much stronger than those of the > > studio cubes. > > Oh, shoot. I spotted an OBMS yesterday and - not believing my good > luck - bid on it... never mind. Just to clarify my quote above: The original megaminx springs were the ones that were way too strong. The clone cube springs were much better inside the megaminx. They're just not good for cubes I think (except maybe the clone cubes themselves, maybe they have more room inside the centers). > When you reckon you've found "the perfect spring", please let us all > know - we could help you recoup your investment :) There's no such thing as *the* perfect spring. It always depends on what you want it for and what you'd like it to be. I'm still experimenting a lot, actually I enjoy buying old cubes (not necessarily only original Rubik, the "wonderful puzzler" is very very good, too, for example) from flea markets, clean them, replace springs and add washers, adjust tension, sand and lube the cubies. Most of these cubes can be easily turned into great speedcubes I think. So I see a lot of different cubes (or also octagons for example), with different wear and different screw heads and different plastic and I'm trying to find out what's good for what. I think I'd like the 0.32 springs for mods like the half-truncated cube because I'd like them to turn very easily. I think my 0.5 springs in combination with my washers are pretty perfect for the current Megaminx. They seem to work well with the older Megaminx, too, but with fewer washers since it had much shorter screws. The Megaminx only has one source (Meffert) and it doesn't wear as much as cubes (partly because most people play less with it) so I think most current Megaminxs are almost the same, thus "the" perfect spring for it makes much more sense than for 3x3. Would anyone want new springs+washers for Megaminx (I know there aren't many Megaminx fans out there)? Cheers! Stefan

Date: Tue, 07 Jun 2005 14:51:55 -0000

It always depends on > what you want it for and what you'd like it to be. Personally, I just need something to use in a studio cube, so that I can tighten it enough to prevent popping, without making it difficult to turn. It sounds as if Bryan needs the same. Would anyone want > new springs+washers for Megaminx (I know there aren't many Megaminx > fans out there)? Not for me -- at the moment. But how about the Dogic? Mike

936. Mefferts Puzzles Homepage
From: Andreas Renberg <rubikssites@...>
To: midwestcubeclub@..., blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, petrusmethod@yahoogroups.com, speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Cubing@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 7 Jun 2005 14:00:43 -0700 (PDT)

I got this mail from 'Meffert's Puzzles' mailing list. Im forwarding it to the group in case someone did not get it because they do not subscribe to the mailing list.

----------------------------Original Letter From Mefferts------------------------------------------------------

Hi, all, I need your help. I am creating a new supporting website for
www.mefferts.com that will
feature daily online puzzles with weekly, monthly and annual
competitions featuring great prizes.
The new site will be translated into more than 100 different
languages(!), so I need to keep the
amount of text to an absolute minimum. This is where I need your help.

Do you have a clever idea for pictures, picture Icons and symbols that
could substitute for text?
Something like the great FWD and PLAY symbols now used on all VCRs and
DVD players? I will also need
ideas for Menu items, such as Hints, Contact Us, Media, Make Home Page,
Add to Favorites, Link to Us
and Shop. I wantt to use as few words as possible: just pictures,
symbols and a little bit of
English.

Also needed:
[bullet] An icon for "New Free Game of the Day" -- any smart ideas for
that?

[bullet] A "people" icon showing how many people are online playing at
any one time

[bullet]The online Puzzle Competitions

[bullet] For "About Uwe Meffert & Puzzles and Education." These two
items could be combined into one,
just requiring one click on my "mug shot" (head photo). Any better
ideas?

Please, I welcome your suggestions. I know this newsletter reaches one
of the most creative groups
of people on the Internet -- Puzzlers -- and I'm sure you have some
innovative ideas just waiting to
be expressed. So let me have them! Suggestions that are used in
creating our new website will receive
a FREE puzzle of their choice from our online shop. Put your brains to
work, Puzzlers!
Uwe

Should you wish to be removed from this mailing list; just click
"Reply" and type "Remove" in the
subject line.

Uwe Meffert
Meffert's Puzzles & Games
2008, Remex Centre,
42 Wong Chuk Hang Rd.
Aberdeen, Hong Kong
Tel. (852) 2580-8044
Fax.(852) 2580-5525
Email:- mpg@...
URL's www.mefferts.com www.puzzles.ws



---------------------------------
Do you Yahoo!?
Read only the mail you want - Yahoo! Mail SpamGuard.

937. Re: Spring breakages
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 07 Jun 2005 21:01:55 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > > Personally, I just need something to use in a studio cube, so that I > can tighten it enough to prevent popping, without making it difficult > to turn. It sounds as if Bryan needs the same. There must be > others, too. Surely 6 good springs would be worth at least $6 from > each of us. Just think about all... I'd probably sell that but do you think anyone would pay that much? Maybe for 12 springs + 60 washers (that's what I've put in my megaminx) with its almost guaranteed big improvement... > > I enjoy buying old cubes (not > > necessarily only original Rubik, > > ...the really /nasty/ cubes you could buy for $6! ;) I usually buy old original Rubik or good clones (Wonderful Puzzler maybe?) for 1 Euro, sometimes 2. Recently I paid 5 for a clone (I think) but it has arched centers and it'll probably become one of my very best cubes (I haven't sanded/lubed it yet and can only average about 30 seconds, but I feel lubrication will work extremely well on this one). > > most current Megaminxs are almost the same, thus "the" perfect > > spring for it makes much more sense than for 3x3. Would anyone want > > new springs+washers for Megaminx (I know there aren't many Megaminx > > fans out there)? > > Not for me -- at the moment. But how about the Dogic? Yep, I've done that, too. With still different springs, though, 0.5mm wire diameter and uncompressed length 7mm only. Can you do this without much force? http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/foo/dogic_spider.wmv Also have a look at a TP thread about this kind of stuff: http://www.twistypuzzles.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=3488 Cheers! Stefan

944. Re: Spring breakages ($$$ & Dogic)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 08 Jun 2005 13:06:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Surely 6 good springs would be worth at least $6 from > > each of us. Just think about all... > > I'd probably sell that but do you think anyone would pay that much? Like Bryan, I would pay that much. It would be well worth it, given the amount of time one spends on the Cube. > > Not for me -- at the moment. But how about the Dogic? > > Yep, I've done that, too. With still different springs, though, 0.5mm > wire diameter and uncompressed length 7mm only. Can you do this > without much force? > http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/foo/dogic_spider.wmv No, I can't do that. (I had seen the TP thread, btw.) Despite the larger number of springs needed compared with the Cube, I wouldn't want to spend very much more than $6 per set. The Dogics look good on the shelf, but don't seem much fun to play with (solving is too repetitive). On the other hand, it would be good to have them turning well. Mike

946. 2x2 solution
From: "Bruce Wayne" <drteeth@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 08 Jun 2005 21:03:30 -0000

knows of that can explain a fast solution to the mini cube.
-Justin




947. Re: 2x2 solution
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 08 Jun 2005 21:32:57 -0000

Gaetan Guimond's method is very, very fast for the 2x2x2, http://www.rubikscuberecord.com/methode_en.html I would also recommend looking into either CLL or COLL. If you solve OLL/PLL style then COLL would be useful for the 3x3 for you as well. I know people still do CLL/ELL as well. CLL is better for the 2x2x2 but not useful for the 3x3x3 unless you either do CLL/ELL or other cool tricks for the LL. COLL is slower for the 2x2x2 than CLL, but also useful for 3x3. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bruce Wayne" <drteeth@o...> wrote: > Its not that i can't solve it but is there any website that anyone > knows of that can explain a fast solution to the mini cube. > -Justin

950. Re: [Speed cubing group] School Cup
From: "Bill MCGAUGH" <bmcgaugh49@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 08 Jun 2005 17:36:43 -0700

Among the students that I know at Temecula Valley High, there is one 16 second average (Ryan Patricio), 2 other guys that can probably average under 30, one guy at 35, maybe 3 in the 40's, and possibly another 5 people under 60...and those are people I know... the students and I estimate that about 200 students out of about 3000 can do the cube... it's like a virus ;-)...I am guessing there are probably a number of sub-60's that I don't know...at least there are rumors ;-) There are a couple of girls in my classes that have gone under a minute (47 sec and 57 sec)... the 57 second girl learned how to cube 2 or 3 weeks ago...a guy that learned last week did a 1:12 on the stackmat today... Many of the fast cube people at the school are sophomores and juniors, so we would definitely be competitive next year in a School Cup contest.... >From: Leyan Lo <leyanlo@...> >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] School Cup >Date: Wed, 08 Jun 2005 14:34:36 -0700 > >That's silly. doesn't work on the newer one. I tried downloading it from the net and

957. Re: [Speed cubing group] Help with JNetCube
From: sachin shirwalkar <sachin_civilian@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 9 Jun 2005 07:18:32 +0100 (BST)

I am not a whiz too but i'll try to help. :) Seems like your Java is not installed properply. Goto http://www.java.com/en/download/help/testvm.jsp to check your java version. Upgrade it to the latest. This usually happens when if a application is written for java 1.4 for example and you use java 1.3 to run it and 1.3 dosent understand some features of 1.4 so it gets confused:) And about the main class error i think you have to give a path to your java installation files- its called the classpath. Check the documentation. Do tell us when you solve your problem so that we all can learn. Bye. 959. Various questions
From: "sinac_be" <sinac_be@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 09 Jun 2005 08:20:17 -0000

Hello,
I have a few questions:

1) when solving 4x4x4 (centers first), while finishing LL I often have
2 edges-pairs permuted diagonally, I use U-permutation then r2U2r2(Uu)
2r2u2. Is there a faster way to fix?

2) for 3x3x3, I'm starting to use finger tricks/shortcuts but I have
problem to do RUR'U and R'U'RU' in one motion. Is there anyone which
can explain me how to do or send me a link to a video of this finger
trick?

3) when trying to solve 3x3x3 fast, I have precision problems: I always
go to far (1/8 or 1/16 of turn) when triggering U/U' in shortcuts. Do
you have any exercices/tips to become more precise?

Thanks,

Joël




960. Re: Various questions
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 09 Jun 2005 13:23:13 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "sinac_be" <sinac_be@y. ..> wrote: > Hello, > I have a few questions: > > 1) when solving 4x4x4 (centers first), while finishing LL I often have > 2 edges-pairs permuted diagonally, I use U-permutation then r2U2r2(Uu) > 2r2u2. Is there a faster way to fix? Yes, r2U2r2(Uu)2r2u2 alone. Just do it before the PLL. Or use (Uu)2 (Rr)2 U2 r2 U2 (Rr)2 (Uu)2. If you really end up with it last, try to use one of these embedded in setup-moves (only 2 are needed). Cheers! Stefan
961. Re: Various questions
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 09 Jun 2005 13:25:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "sinac_be" <sinac_be@y...> wrote: > Hello, > I have a few questions: > > 1) when solving 4x4x4 (centers first), while finishing LL I often have > 2 edges-pairs permuted diagonally, I use U-permutation then r2U2r2(Uu) > 2r2u2. Is there a faster way to fix? If you do this before you permute the LL, there is no harm doing (Uu)2 instead of u2 to finish. > 2) for 3x3x3, I'm starting to use finger tricks/shortcuts but I have > problem to do RUR'U and R'U'RU' in one motion. Is there anyone which > can explain me how to do or send me a link to a video of this finger > trick? I made quick videos that hopefully show how I would perform each of these sequences of moves: http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/fsc/FSC-RUR'U.avi For R U R' U', I hold the cube with my thumb on bottom and my first three fingers on the top of the cube. I use my wrist to turn the . As the cube begins to become lined up, I use my pointer to push the U, and continue to turn my wrist in the opposite direction for the R'. Meanwhile, my right middle finger heads to the back of the cube to prepare for the last turn. As that R' is finishing, I use my right middle finger for the final U. http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/fsc/FSC-R'U'RU'.avi This is done similarly, except I use my thumb to push the second U', and I grip the cube differently. I would start with my right index on the top of the cube, my middle and ring fingers on the back, and my pinky just below the cube. My thumb would be covering the top right square of the front face. (DivX is required to view both videos). I didn't have a cameraman to help me out, so you have to translate the angle to first person on your own. > 3) when trying to solve 3x3x3 fast, I have precision problems: I always > go to far (1/8 or 1/16 of turn) when triggering U/U' in shortcuts. Do > you have any exercices/tips to become more precise? I would just practice those shortcuts over and over so that they become more natural. Try to really concentrate on letting your fingers do exactly what they have to. First go slowly, then gradually pick up some speed. I'm sure others could offer better advice for this, though.
962. Re: Various questions
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 09 Jun 2005 13:25:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "sinac_be" <sinac_be@y. ..> wrote: > > 3) when trying to solve 3x3x3 fast, I have precision problems: I always > go to far (1/8 or 1/16 of turn) when triggering U/U' in shortcuts. Do > you have any exercices/tips to become more precise? Use a stiffer cube ;-). Or a well-lubed Meffert assembly cube, that one will teach you to become precise (either that or it'll make you mad). Cheers! Stefan
963. Re: Various questions
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 09 Jun 2005 13:31:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/fsc/FSC-RUR'U.avi > > For R U R' U, I hold the cube with my thumb on bottom and my first > three fingers on the top of the cube. I use my wrist to turn the . > As the cube begins to become lined up, I use my pointer to push the U, > and continue to turn my wrist in the opposite direction for the R'. > Meanwhile, my right middle finger heads to the back of the cube to > prepare for the last turn. As that R' is finishing, I use my right > middle finger for the final U. Sorry, this is actually not completely correct. At first, I was thinking of the wrong FSC. I hold the cube with index and middle fingers on the top and ring finger in the back. I made the first U turn with my ring finger, not the middle finger.

967. Re: 2X2 Lubing
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 09 Jun 2005 19:07:31 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bruce Wayne" <drteeth@o...> wrote: > i bought a mefferts 2x2 i finall got all of the cubies off of it but > the device inside is what actually needs to be lubed. do i need to > take the device apart? please someone help me lol > -Justin Hi Justin You need to take the core apart, IMO. The core is a modified 3x3x3, but DON'T try to disassemble by levering out an "edge" piece. The edges are shaved right down, and are so thin that they get chewed up badly if you try to lever them out. In the middle of the "3x3x3" centres you'll see the flat heads of 3 pins. Gently lever these up, but DON'T remove any other pieces until all 3 pins are removed. (If you DO remove the edges surrounding a centre, it may crack when you lever out the pin -- the centres are also thin and fragile.) Once you've removed the 3 pins, disassembly is easy. Reasssembly is much easier than disassembly -- you won't need instructions. :) Hope this helps. Mike
968. Re: Help with JNetCube
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 09 Jun 2005 19:42:32 -0000

You need to download the latest JRE (java runtime environment) for
your operating system. You can get that here:

http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/download.jsp

The browser java plugin cannot be used to run a .jar file. That is why
you must download and install the JRE from the link above.

After you have installed the latest JRE from the link above, then you
can run the .jar file by opening a command prompt and typing:

"java -jar JNetCube.jar"

If you are using Windows, then you should be able to just double-click
the JNetCube.jar file after installing the latest JRE.

Please let me know if you still cannot run the timer after following
the steps above and I will be more than happy to get it working for you.

-Chris




969. Re: [Speed cubing group] Help with JNetCube
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 09 Jun 2005 19:43:25 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o...> wrote: > I'm curious, what operating system are you running? I recently > switched to mac os x (running 10.4.1) and I can't get jnetcube to > open, which is a disaster. I have my java fully updated but there is > an error when i try to open the jar file. Tyson Mao says it works > fine on his mac. I have been trying to get mine to work for a few > weeks now to no avail. How are you running the .jar file and what error are you getting? -Chris
970. Re: Help with JNetCube
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 09 Jun 2005 19:45:10 -0000

You should also download the latest JNetCube.jar from:

http://www.plu.edu/~huntca/jnetcube.html

Make sure you 'save-target-as' so that you get the whole file. A lot
of people have WinRAR and other zip utilities that try to extract the
file.

-Chris




971. Re: World Cube Cup
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 09 Jun 2005 19:54:11 -0000

I enjoyed the last one a lot. I only wish my /team/ enjoyed it as much
as I did...

-Chris




972. Re: [Speed cubing group] Help with JNetCube
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 09 Jun 2005 17:54:31 -0400

You can run the jar file directly on mac osx, you don't need to do it from the terminal - My problem was that I didn't have the right JRE set as the default. All I had to do was go into java preferences and set JRE 5.0 to be first priority over JRE 1.4.2. After that just clicking the jar file opens up the program. I actually figured this out minutes after I responded to the previous post. Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... On Jun 9, 2005, at 3:43 PM, burntbizzkit wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko > <bmytko@o...> wrote: > > I'm curious, what operating system are you running? I recently > > switched to mac os x (running 10.4.1) and I can't get jnetcube to > > open, which is a disaster. I have my java fully updated but there is > > an error when i try to open the jar file. Tyson Mao says it works > > fine on his mac. I have been trying to get mine to work for a few > > weeks now to no avail. > > > How are you running the .jar file and what error are you getting? > > -Chris > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
973. Re: Spring breakages ($$$ & Dogic)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>

974. The best thing since sliced bread
From: Yasmara Pourrier <blonkm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 9 Jun 2005 17:04:31 -0700 (PDT)

Well, maybe not. Sliced bread is pretty cool. What I
made is called a favelet, it's a program so small it
fits in your browsers address bar. I created one that
shows a rubikplayer applet for any selected algorithm
on the page. So for all the guys who created pages
with tons of applets, no need for that anymore. Now
anyone can create the applets on the fly while
browsing.

You can read more and 'download' it at
http://www.vanderblonk.com/cube/favelet/index.htm

If you cannot wait and know how this works, here is
the code. Remember it must remain one line.

javascript:d=document;if (d.getElementById('frubik'))
showRubikApplet(); else {
z=document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0].appendChild(document.createElement('script'));z.setAttribute('src','http://vanderblonk.com/cube/favelet/frubik.js');z.setAttribute('type','text/javascript');z.setAttribute('id','frubik')};
void(0);

And here is the code for a simpler version that can
also work offline, provided you have the applet

javascript:(function() { var
d=document;a=d.createElement('applet');a.code='ch.randelshofer.rubik.RubikPlayerApp.class';a.codebase='http://www.randelshofer.ch/rubikplayer/';a.archive='rubikplayer.jar';alg=d.createElement('param');alg.name='script';alg.value=d.selection.createRange().text;lang=d.createElement('param');lang.name='scriptLanguage';lang.value='HarrisENG';a.appendChild(alg);a.appendChild(lang);d.body.appendChild(a);
void(0); })()

If you experience any problems with it let me know.
If you want to thank me you can come over and clean my
house (I didn't get time for that while programming).

Michiel



__________________________________
Discover Yahoo!
Get on-the-go sports scores, stock quotes, news and more. Check it out!
http://discover.yahoo.com/mobile.html


975. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Various questions
From: Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 9 Jun 2005 21:42:48 -0700 (PDT)

I make the U turn with my pinky finger :P One of my favorite finger tricks actually. -Richard --- Bob Burton <bob@...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob > Burton" <bob@c...> > wrote: > > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/fsc/FSC-RUR'U.avi > > > > For R U R' U, I hold the cube with my thumb on > bottom and my first > > three fingers on the top of the cube. I use my > wrist to turn the . > > As the cube begins to become lined up, I use my > pointer to push the U, > > and continue to turn my wrist in the opposite > direction for the R'. > > Meanwhile, my right middle finger heads to the > back of the cube to > > prepare for the last turn. As that R' is > finishing, I use my right > > middle finger for the final U. > > Sorry, this is actually not completely correct. At > first, I was > thinking of the wrong FSC. I hold the cube with > index and middle > fingers on the top and ring finger in the back. I > made the first U > turn with my ring finger, not the middle finger. > > > __________________________________ Discover Yahoo! Use Yahoo! to plan a weekend, have fun online and more. Check it out! http://discover.yahoo.com/
976. Re: [Speed cubing group] The best thing since sliced bread
From: sachin shirwalkar <sachin_civilian@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 10 Jun 2005 06:42:21 +0100 (BST)

Great work! Thanks man, i've always wanted something like this. At first i didnt mean what u meant by "on the fly" but after going to ur site i fully understood its meaning. For the uninitiated, this applet (or favlet as u call it) will generate Java cubes for any algo--u just select the algo and then run the favlet -- then u get a nice cube which u can drag anywhere u like. Keep up the good work :) --- Yasmara Pourrier <blonkm@...> wrote: --------------------------------- Well, maybe not. Sliced bread is pretty cool. What I made is called a favelet, it's a program so small it fits in your browsers address bar. I created one that shows a rubikplayer applet for any selected algorithm on the page. So for all the guys who created pages with tons of applets, no need for that anymore. Now anyone can create the applets on the fly while browsing. You can read more and 'download' it at http://www.vanderblonk.com/cube/favelet/index.htm If you cannot wait and know how this works, here is the code. Remember it must remain one line. javascript:d=document;if (d.getElementById('frubik')) showRubikApplet(); else { z=document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0].appendChild(document.createElement('script'));z.setAttribute('src','http://vanderblonk.com/cube/favelet/frubik.js');z.setAttribute('type','text/javascript');z.setAttribute('id','frubik')}; void(0); And here is the code for a simpler version that can also work offline, provided you have the applet javascript:(function() { var d=document;a=d.createElement('applet');a.code='ch.randelshofer.rubik.RubikPlayerApp.class';a.codebase='http://www.randelshofer.ch/rubikplayer/';a.archive='rubikplayer.jar';alg=d.createElement('param');alg.name='script';alg.value=d.selection.createRange().text;lang=d.createElement('param');lang.name='scriptLanguage';lang.value='HarrisENG';a.appendChild(alg);a.appendChild(lang);d.body.appendChild(a); void(0); })() If you experience any problems with it let me know. 977. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re:Help with JNetCube
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 10 Jun 2005 01:04:28 -0500

Thanks to all for the advice. It turns out I was running a slightly older version of Java because my firewall had blocked my attempts to install the new one. Now that I've gotten it up and running, the timer is working perfectly again and I'm hoping to get some good practice in soon.

-Mike Bennett

978. Favelet
From: "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 10 Jun 2005 11:07:03 -0000

Hi all,

After demonstrating you my favelet
(http://vanderblonk.com/cube/favelet/index.htm) I realized it showed
the cube after a scramble. I think it's more interesting if it shows
by default how the algorithm solves the cube. That's in the case of
PLL/OLL pages etc. So I changed the favelet.

For something like the sunday/xday contest you still need the original
one. I am working on making multiple versions of the favelet available
and working out a way of making it configurable.

I have to remind you that the program is hosted. That means even
though it looks like it's on your PC it gets downloaded on every
invocation and I can change it anytime (scary huh?).

Michiel




979. Springs etc
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 10 Jun 2005 22:47:49 -0000

I just took some pictures I'd like to share:

http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/foo/paper_cap.jpg
Michel Bechtatou once suggested to use paper pieces to fix the 3x3
center caps. I *hate* glue. I have used the hammer method and can live
with it. But this paper method is now my favourite, it does the least
damage. The cross shape I use now is great, when you push down the cap
then the paper will slide inside perfectly. It does raise the cap
slightly but that might actually be good because if you've played with
a cube for a while you might notice that the centers move inside a bit
because both they and the edges polish each other at the connection.

http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/foo/scratch_identifiers.jpg
I scratch the color of the cubie into the center piece and I mark both
the piece and the cap with a line that must then matched. This way I
can always put everything back exactly the way it was (I consider this
to be important because no two parts are ever the same). Helps for
example if you want to keep all caps off and twist the and adjust the
tensions.

http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/foo/box.jpg
A box I made from polystyrol sheet. I need more for a semi-secret
project and I want to start giving ids to all my cubes because I'm
losing the overview, which cube is which, what have I done to it,
where are its original springs etc.

http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/foo/studio3x3_fix.jpg
What I now do to Studio 3x3s. Two washers at each end of the spring.
Each washer has one side with a more rounded rim and let all round
sides point into the cube. The innermost washer makes the center cubie
hole bottom flat. The next one reduces the friction. The outer two
also reduce friction, but mainly I need so many because the spring is
quite short if fully compressed.

http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/foo/studio3x3_springs.jpg
Spring from a Studio 3x3 and its replacement.

Cheers!
Stefan

The next one reduces the friction. The outer two also reduce friction, but mainly I need so many because the spring is quite short if fully compressed. http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/foo/studio3x3_springs.jpg Spring from a Studio 3x3 and its replacement. 981. New York tournament DVD available
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 11 Jun 2005 01:33:14 -0000

I have just finished compiling and editing footage from the Horace
Mann Tournament held on May 28, 2005 and I'm pleased with the
results. The finished product is over 3 hours long. We caught
virtually every solve of Macky, Chris Hardwick, and Ryan Patricio
(including Macky's insane 23 second one-handed solve) and we put
chapters into the DVD that allow you to skip to any scramble of any
solve. I'm selling the two DVD set for $15 including free shipping to
anywhere in the contiguous US. I can ship overseas as well. For
screenshots and lots more info, go to

http://home.manhattan.edu/~ian.winokur/DVD/dvd.html

Feel free to e-mail me with questions or comments.

Ian Winokur

983. Re: [Speed cubing group] Springs etc
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 11 Jun 2005 08:17:51 -0000

The inner diameter is supposed to be 3.2mm but I can't check it. I only say this because the outer diameter is supposed to be 6mm but actually it's about 5.75mm which I determined by lining up 10 in a row. With 6mm it would probably *not* fit into the 3x3, so I was lucky (I had bought them for Megaminx which has larger holes). They're 0.8mm thick but that doesn't really matter much, I just say it for completeness. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Chun Hei Uwe Wong <lilbeyond@y...> wrote: > http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/foo/studio3x3_fix.jpg i wanna get those washers taht are pressing hte spring. what size are they? like what do i ask for at a hardware store?? > > chun hei uwe > > Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@g...> wrote: > I just took some pictures I'd like to share: > > http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/foo/paper_cap.jpg > Michel Bechtatou once suggested to use paper pieces to fix the 3x3 > center caps. 985. Re: [Speed cubing group] Springs etc
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 11 Jun 2005 15:55:24 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Chun Hei Uwe Wong <lilbeyond@y...> wrote: > ic. i got some that are 6 mm outer. i find it too big, but i used a dremel and sand it down which will fit into a 3x3x3. wouldn't ur studio cube pop if you dont have a big washer at the head of the screw jus tlike the DIYs? Uh, too many negations for me... but what I think is: If you have large screw heads (or large washers right under them) and appropriate springs, or if you use very weak springs, then they don't pop (unless you really want to or are a really terrible cuber ;-) Cheers! Stefan

988. Re: Cubing while juggling (3 of them)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 11 Jun 2005 22:31:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > Thanks for sharing. From my point of view (I'm a beginner), that's > > really impressive! A video? > > > > Gilles. > > Here's a 20-second clip (working on the second cube), thanks to Tedrick > Leung. Unfortunately, the switching isn't on this video. > http://cubefreak.hp.infoseek.co.jp/videos/ARML_cube_juggle.avi > > > PS: I don't feel proud when I'm juggling, but well, I don't care, > > having fun :-) > > http://grrroux.free.fr/juggleking.avi > > =) Nice. > > Macky That's pretty crazy stuff - I thought maybe you were juggling all 3 at once and just solving them as they came round into one hand (I guess left judging by the video) though. Then you'd be solving all 3 at once, intertwined so to speak. Not sure how hard that would be... or if you could get many twists in at once.
989. Re: Cubing while juggling (3 of them)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 11 Jun 2005 22:43:33 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I thought maybe you were juggling all 3 at once and just solving > them as they came round into one hand (I guess left judging by the video) though. > Then you'd be solving all 3 at once, intertwined so to speak. > Not sure how hard that would be... or if you could get many twists in at once. I think I could do that. And to top it off, I'd do it underwater! Cheers! Stefan
990. Missing Link puzzle :-)
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 12 Jun 2005 00:30:04 -0000

Hi!

I just recently receive a missing link puzle that i bought off eBay.
After 2 days i have had some rather nice achievements.

I started off by working out a nice method, while having a look
around what methods exist out there. I found actually only one which
was writen down in some detail. This method i found on Jaap's site
and solves the puzzle column by column.

The method im currently using involves following steps

- trickle down all the tiles to go in first row and place them at
bottom ... this should be faitly intuitive i hope ... make sure u do
ALL 4 bottom tiles before proceed or u are in a bit of trouble

- now turn the middle 2 rows (they won't turn individually though)
so as to put as many tiles as possible into solved or good
positions ... a good position is typically in it's correct column

- now u actually have some freedom in how u proceed .. either
complete column by column (leave white for last) ... or u can do
sorta row by row ... basically u solve the tiles that u spot first
so as not to waste time ... when placing a tile into 2nd row from
bottom u can always lift a column (i leave it to urselves to work
out how) and then solve the tile and lower the column back

- after having finished all tiles in the 2nd row almost all activity
takes place in 2 top rows ... solving 3rd row is trivial ...

- so final step is dealing w the last row .. there are five cases
only u should know .. i have easy solutions for all of them ... only
one case involves dealing with lifting a column ... this case is
where if white column in front and the empty slot is also in front u
have to swap the left and right top tile only ... then u have to put
the tile in 3rd row from bottom in the column opposite to white into
the 2nd row in that column (u know how already) ... doing that
correctly and simply the puzzle is now solved

I will post all these 5 last layer algs once i have worked out a
good notation and made some diagrams :-)

For those who don't know the missing link puzzle looks like here is
a link :

http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/missing.htm

I'd like some feedback on this method. Any others here know how to
solve the missing link and use other methods? I would also like some
competion cause i have already posted good times for single solve
and average. Check of course at :

http://www.speedcubing.com/records/recs_other_puzzles.html

This turned out to be a rather long post. Thx for ur time :-)

Kind regards,

Per

997. Is Corner's First suboptimal?
From: "dmacauley" <dmacauley@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 Jun 2005 03:34:13 -0000

Hi:
I'm new to this forum so decided to break the ice with a question.
While many speed cubists will refer to corner's first in passing as
one of the speed cubing solutions, I have not seen solutions based on
it recently. I learned to put the cube together using a corner's first
framework years ago and I'm now trying to improve my time with this
methodology. I'm now averaging about 70sec, with personal best in the
50s.

So my question at this point is if it's worth pursuing faster times
using this methodology or has it been proven to be suboptimal, in
which case I should scrap it and try to relearn Fridrick or Peterus. I
have not yet learned any finger moves as of yet; I now put the corners
together using Petrus's Niklas/Sune combos; and my edge solutions are
similar to that in http://cube.misto.cz/_MAIL_/cfsm.html.

I think I can significantly increase my edge time (about 40 sec) with
more stronger algorithms but haven't seen much in this area lately.
Any thoughts or suggestions would be appreciated.

dmacauley@...







998. Locations
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 Jun 2005 06:30:45 -0000

We all know that cubers are from all around the world, and I was
curious where people are from, so I created a database in which people
could enter their city/state/country so that others could see where
somebody is from. Completely optional, of course :)

~ Bob





999. Re: Locations
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 Jun 2005 09:10:37 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > We all know that cubers are from all around the world, and I was > curious where people are from, so I created a database in which people > could enter their city/state/country so that others could see where > somebody is from. Completely optional, of course :) > > ~ Bob Will you then generate a picture of the world showing a little point for each cuber? Or better: An applet that shows you the name when you put the mouse cursor over a point and displays further info (like Dan's profiles) when you click on it. That'd be sweet... Cheers! Stefan
1000. Re: Is Corner's First suboptimal?
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 Jun 2005 13:11:07 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "dmacauley" <dmacauley@y...> wrote: > So my question at this point is if it's worth pursuing faster times > using this methodology or has it been proven to be suboptimal, in > which case I should scrap it and try to relearn Fridrick or Peterus. I'm doubtful that this has ever been proved, and /suspect/ that the current dominance of the layer-by-layer approach is largely a "social" phenomenon. You would not be in bad company in pursuing corners-first. It's known that Marc Waterman achieved very fast times with a (complex) corners- first system. For details (probably you've already looked), see http://rubikscube.info/ Note also that the majority of competitors in the 1982 world championship (including the Champion) used corners-first methods. See http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/cubic3.htm#p4 Perhaps the dominance of corners-first in those days was similarly due to a "social" phenomenon. The big "problem" with adopting a corners-first framework as a beginner nowadays is that you will have to think for yourself: with Fridrich, there are many websites from which you can select sequences/fingertricks; also, the majority of people who contribute on this forum will be familiar mainly with Fridrich, so a corner-starter won't have so many people to talk to. Fridrich herself seems very open minded about this question. She has stated that there may be many methods that could be as fast as hers when worked out to a sufficient level of "perfection" - see also her recent comments here http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/16756 So, good luck with the corners -- and sorry that I'm too inexpert to help with the specifics of any approach, let alone corners-first. Mike
1001. Rubiks Timer ad & photo
From: "rubikstimer" <rubikstimer@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 Jun 2005 13:15:05 -0000

Hi everyone,

The Rubik's timer is going into production (finally, gasp). There are
only a couple very minor issues left to work out.

On the timer's journal web page, I have posted a photo of the
production timer (in the black enclosure) and a rough draft of the
advertisement that will appear on www.rubiks.com during the pre-order
period.

If you haven't seen the website recently, check it out at
http://www.mission-designs.com/timer/journal.htm

Peace,
-Eric




1002. Competition tutorial
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 Jun 2005 13:16:40 -0000

Hey everyone,

I have a question about a section I'm adding to my webpage.

I've already taken all the videos, I just need to get them onto my
computer and edit them into separate clips, so almost all the work is
done so far.

Basically what this page will do is show you what a competition solve
for speed, and for blindfolded solving, looks like.

I did a complete mock-up of a competition solve, based on my
experiences with how they go, and I filmed them.

So there are 3 videos to watch:
1) mock competition 3x3 speed solve
- this includes a judge (many thanks to my girlfriend Becky for
helping me out here :-), everything the judge says to you that you
have to respond to, the timer, the 15 second inspection, everything.
Also includes the fact that you have up to about 2 seconds after the
judge removes the paper to re-focus on the cube before picking it up.
(I think the rules technically say 3, but I think it's not a good
idea to push this one).

2) mock competition 3x3 BLD solve
- I didn't do the whole solve of course, I put the cube about two
moves away from solved, but I show how the time starts, you picking up
your cube, memorizing, putting on the blindfold, solving and stopping
the timer.

3) putting down the cube without dropping.
- I heard people a lot of times at competitions talking about how they
don't know how to put their cube down at the end of the solve without
droppping it. Well I filmed this video from two different angles,
from my point of view, and from someone watching's point of view. It
shows how I bring the cube to the mat and let it go at the last
second, so not technically a drop. I have the approval of Tyson on
this one, so it's ok WCA wise.

I'm just curious if anyone here, who has not been to a competition but
is considering going, would be interested? I'm going to put it on my
site, and I was curious if I could get some reviews both by people who
have been, and haven't been to one before.

I will have the site done later today, but I just wanted to get an
idea of whether or not people would be interested in this.

Chris

1009. blindfold tutorial
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>

1010. Re: Is Corner's First suboptimal?
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 14 Jun 2005 00:28:55 -0000

Greetings dmacauley, Welcome to the list. Is "Corners First" suboptimal? I don't think so. I use a method which does 1. two edges 2. four corners 3. six edges (done in pairs) 4. four corners 5. four edges and on a good day I take around 30 seconds. If I try "corners first" it take about 35 seconds. So off hand I'd say that it looks like corners first is very good approach. I think that 2x2x2 practice can help a lot. Consider being able to "see" the corner's solution during the inspection time... I've played a little at "blindfold" 2x2x2 with a best at 7 seconds. Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "dmacauley" <dmacauley@y...> wrote: > Hi: > I'm new to this forum so decided to break the ice with a question. > While many speed cubists will refer to corner's first in passing as > one of the speed cubing solutions, I have not seen solutions based on > it recently. I learned to put the cube together using a corner's first > framework years ago and I'm now trying to improve my time with this > methodology. I'm now averaging about 70sec, with personal best in the > 50s. > > So my question at this point is if it's worth pursuing faster times > using this methodology or has it been proven to be suboptimal, in > which case I should scrap it and try to relearn Fridrick or Peterus. I > have not yet learned any finger moves as of yet; I now put the corners > together using Petrus's Niklas/Sune combos; and my edge solutions are > similar to that in http://cube.misto.cz/_MAIL_/cfsm.html. > > I think I can significantly increase my edge time (about 40 sec) with > more stronger algorithms but haven't seen much in this area lately. > Any thoughts or suggestions would be appreciated. > > dmacauley@y...
1011. blindfold tutorial
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 Jun 2005 19:29:57 -0600

http://www.astro.caltech.edu/~tmao/blindfold.doc

Ian pressured me to finish the file. As a result, I'm really hungry
because I've been postponing dinner. I'm sure my hunger will become
evident towards the end of the tutorial.

I guess I forgot to mention some permutaiton tricks, like if you're
cycling edges, you can do that on the U, F, D, or B faces, but I'll add
that in later after I get some dinner.

And I forgot some other stuff... that'll all get added in. I think at
this point, it should be possible to blindfold a cube by using the
file. Read it, let me know, suggestions if you've got them, and yeah,
I'm hungry.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology



1012. competition tutorial (link provided)

never been to a competition before, this tutorial is meant for you. I
have lots of videos showing procedure's as well as descriptions of
that to do and all that.

Even if you have never used a stackmat, this tutorial is meant for you
to get a lot of use out of.

Please let me know what you all think.

http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/competitiontutorial.html

Chris





1013. Re: Is Corner's First suboptimal?
From: "dmacauley" <dmacauley@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 14 Jun 2005 01:37:08 -0000

This is very good information Mike, thanks; I'm going to give corner's first some more try cause I think I may be able to improve my time faster over learning a new method all over. good luck in your cubing as well, dmac --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "dmacauley" > <dmacauley@y...> wrote: > > So my question at this point is if it's worth pursuing faster times > > using this methodology or has it been proven to be suboptimal, in > > which case I should scrap it and try to relearn Fridrick or Peterus. > > I'm doubtful that this has ever been proved, and /suspect/ that the > current dominance of the layer-by-layer approach is largely a "social" > phenomenon. > > You would not be in bad company in pursuing corners-first. It's known > that Marc Waterman achieved very fast times with a (complex) corners- > first system. For details (probably you've already looked), see > > http://rubikscube.info/ > > Note also that the majority of competitors in the 1982 world > championship (including the Champion) used corners-first methods. See > > http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/cubic3.htm#p4 > > Perhaps the dominance of corners-first in those days was similarly due > to a "social" phenomenon. > > The big "problem" with adopting a corners-first framework as a beginner > nowadays is that you will have to think for yourself: with Fridrich, > there are many websites from which you can select > sequences/fingertricks; also, the majority of people who contribute on > this forum will be familiar mainly with Fridrich, so a corner- starter > won't have so many people to talk to. > > Fridrich herself seems very open minded about this question. She has > stated that there may be many methods that could be as fast as hers > when worked out to a sufficient level of "perfection" - see also her > recent comments here > > http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/16 756 > > So, good luck with the corners -- and sorry that I'm too inexpert to > help with the specifics of any approach, let alone corners-first. > > Mike
1014. Re: [Speed cubing group] competition tutorial (link provided)
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 Jun 2005 19:40:40 -0600

Hey Chris,

After you inspect, the judge needs to ask you if you're ready to solve
and you need to acknowledge it. That way, the competitor can't claim
"oh, I wasn't ready."

Also, the "3, 2, 1" countdown after the inspection isn't necessary.
I've been meaning to amend to rules so that the judge just has to say
"ready? go." And remember, after the judge says go, you have a second
or two to refocus.

And if there is any obvious delay, the judge kicks you in the bottom.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Jun 13, 2005, at 7:29 PM, cmhardw wrote:

> Hey everyone,
>
> I just finished it, so please let me know what you think. If you have
> never been to a competition before, this tutorial is meant for you. I
> have lots of videos showing procedure's as well as descriptions of
> that to do and all that.
>
> Even if you have never used a stackmat, this tutorial is meant for you
> to get a lot of use out of.
>
> Please let me know what you all think.
>
> http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/competitiontutorial.html
>
> Chris
