1023. FMC prizes
From: <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>,<speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 14 Jun 2005 10:14:36 +0100

Hi everyone!

In association with www.cubesmith.com, www.cubestation.co.uk is proud to annouce that from next week we will be offering small prizes to the winners of each metric each week in the FMC!

www.cubesmith.com is a small yet rapidly growing enterprise manufacturing custom cube stickers for the various shapes and sizes of rubik's puzzles.

Each week we will offer small prizes such as set of stickers or tiles, for the various cubes. Let's face it, everyone will need some replacerment stickers sometime!

So why not have a practice at this week's FMC scramble (week #88) which is listed on the FMC page at www.cubestation.co.uk , in preparation for the following prize FMC's to come! Check the FMC newswire for more details as I get a chance to post them :)

Good Luck!
Dan Harris - www.cubestation.co.uk :)

-----------------------------------------
Email provided by http://www.ntlhome.com/



1024. Re: blindfold tutorial
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 14 Jun 2005 09:16:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > So would you guys check this out and let me know how it's going so far? > > http://www.astro.caltech.edu/~tmao/blindfold.doc Hi Tyson, you asked for it... ;-) General: I'd appreciate it if you could at least mention that you describe only one method and that there are others as well. You say one solves two or three pieces at a time, I do one at a time. Not everybody does orientation and permutation separately. I never memorize with numbers, I'm convinced it's very very unnatural and bad, maybe unless you're Japanese and memorizing the sound of a number sequence is easy for you. There's good reason the real memorizers memorize numbers not as numbers but as images. Numbers are so abstract. Finally, as some people have demonstrated, it's indeed possible and not even hard (just takes long to plan the solution) to solve the cube blindfolded using your regular speedsolving method. Wrong effects for your corner orientation algs. Particularly you always say top/bottom when you really mean front/back (Or back/front? I'm completely confused). Also it could be better to name all three faces to describe a corner, not just two, but it coul be clear from context once you fix the other issue. About the powerful corner orientation method: I think the R' is not outstanding, it's part of the single-corner-orientation. Do the other six moves alone on a solve cube and it will just look confusing. Also, I highly recommend (you write this for beginners, right?) to *always* add the D-turn, this way you never have to think whether to do it or not, you just always do it. Examples of what I'd do: (R' D R D' R' D R D') U' (D R' D' R D R' D' R) U (R' D R D' R' D R D') U' (R' D R D' R' D R D') U' (R' D R D' R' D R D') U2 You could also mention that one can orient all four corners as well. And that the overall orientation must be a multiple of three (in clockwise rotations). I get the feeling you describe algorithms derived with the method but not the method itself clearly, which is a pity. It could also make the text quite a bit shorter. Maybe simply show that (R' D R D' R' D R D') and (D R' D' R D R' D' R) rotate the URF corner that you do them several times, to different corners, which you select by U-turns between the single-corner-rotations. Then show some instantiations (algorithms) of the general method. And how about orienting corners in the D layer instead of U? Do Macky/Leyan really do it the way you described? Try this, it's much faster (and also easier because one makes fewer mistakes when using fingertricks): (R U R' U' R U R' U') D (U R U' R' U R U' R') D' (R U R' U' R U R' U') D (R U R' U' R U R' U') D (R U R' U' R U R' U') D2 You say "always remember that I'm not right". Don't be so mean to yourself ;-) An easier way to find out whether an edge is badly oriented: I say white/yellow are brightest, green/blue are darkest and orange/red are medium. This way each edge has a brighter and a darker sticker. An edge is correctly oriented iff its brighter sticker is on the brighter face (defined by the centers). Just this single rule. I think "flip" is better than "switch" to describe the effect of edge orientation algs. Corner permutation: Same top/bottom vs front/back confusion again. Typo in (L F' L B2 L' F' L B2 L2). "This is very similar to Stefan Pochmann's blindfold method". Hmm... as much as I like my solution being referenced, I'd say this is not correct. I do use the T-perm, yes, but that's all the similarity. We use it for quite different purposes. So I'd like to ask you to remove the reference, please. Btw, you got the T-perm wrong ;-) And the edge crosser, too... Oh, and if you know the F-perm or N-perm you can use those, too. Any perm that swaps two opposite edges. Or two adjacent but you need to do it for both perms of course. But since it's a beginner tutorial I'd not demonstrate this in detail, just (if at all) mention it. It could improve the understanding and if someone knows the other perms already it might help to make blindsolving even easier. Some suggestions you maybe already have in mind for the rest of the document: - Suggest to solve using the blindfold method but without wearing a blindfold. At least until they get it right. - Suggest to scramble two cubes the same way. Then do one step to the first cube and make sure you got it right by comparing it to the other, which still shows the cube state right before the step. Then do the step to the other cube and make sure both cubes look the same again. - Link to the other solutions on the web and to the blindsolving yahoo group. Cheers! Stefan
1025. Re: competition tutorial (link provided)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 14 Jun 2005 10:27:52 -0000

Hi Chris,

thanks a lot (though I personally don't need it anymore unless I'm a
judge for a newbie ;-), that's a very good idea. Some comments and
corrections, though:

The Timer
---------

Hmm, I've seen Katsu place the hands on the timer this way, but I
myself don't, I put my fingers on the contacts. Otherwise you could
cheat (even unintentionally) when picking up the cube, especially with
the Stackmat 2. Also, maybe describe the procedure, particularly what
the lights mean.


Putting the cube down
---------------------

I think if you show it that slowly only, that's no use. With that
speed, any method of holding the cube will work. A suggestion would be
to lower your hands (probably better the whole body) close to the
surface during the last solution step. And you could link to Macky's
12.11 solve, it looks very good how he puts down the cube and I doubt
he grips the bottom of the cube like you describe. Btw, besides the
risk of penalty, you should mention how mean it is to the poor cube if
you throw it down, it might even break (and not only out in tears).


The solve and competition procedure
-----------------------------------

1+2) This is only correct for the first attempt in a round. Well,
unless Americans do it differently. At the competitions I've been to
we were usually packed into groups of 4 or 8 people and we didn't get
our cubes back between the solves of a round.

8) I'd recommend not getting too close to the limit here, either,
because you might get interrupted during analysis and lose track.
Also, I always count in my head (starting at 0, not at 10) so I have a
better feeling how much time is left.

10) Not getting too close might also be important if as judge you get
one of those people who start counting at 1 instead of 0. You know,
some people count "1..2..3" and thus actually only measure 2 seconds.
Maybe cubers are more intelligent, but I've seen it in real life.
Also, like Tyson already mentioned, the judge should again ask you
whether you're ready before he starts the countdown. That is, unless
you've clearly instructed him otherwise beforehand, e.g. that you will
be ready and that he shouldn't ask whether you are and maybe not even
count down again but just cover the cube and take it away after the
timer is ready (i.e. second light is on). Not sure whether this is in
the rules but as a judge I was requested to do it this way once and I
don't see a problem with it.

12) The cube must be flat on the table? I think it would be ok if it
stays on a corner. Or if it drops to the floor of the podium and then
to the floor below the podium (as happened with some 5x5s at the
German Open... ouch ;-).

12.5) This step is missing (also in the video). The judge inspects
your cube, looks whether it's correctly solved and whether a penalty
is needed. Btw, with Rubik's Clock it's particularly irritating to
hear the crowd cheer before anybody has checked the back side (which
has really caused many disqualifications).

14) Unless the judge takes your cube with him/her for your next
scramble. And you can also switch to a different cube if you want to.

The video: I believe you only hold the cube with your left hand when
putting it down. Baaad example ;-)


Blindfolded solving procedure
-----------------------------

2) I wouldn't be so strict about wearing it from the start unless
you're solving only a 3x3 or so ;-)

5) When you put the cube down for putting on the blindfold, be sure
you don't accidentally stop the timer! I've almost done this myself
once or twice, because the procedure is so similar to speedsolving.
You inspect/memorize, then put the cube down, then (*), then pick up
the cube and solve it. In speedsolving you touch the timer at (*) and
in blindsolving you must not! It's also important during the solve, e.
g. if you put the cube down for a moment to relax or whatever, and
when you try to pick it up again you could accidentally stop the
timer. Remember it's very sensitive.

7) It's the job of the judge, *not* the solver, to check whether the
solve was successful. Do *not* touch the cube before the judge did it.

The video: You put your hands down on the mat before and after putting
on the blindfold. Not a good example I think, even though you don't
get near the timer contacts.

Cheers!
Stefan





1026. Re: competition tutorial (link provided)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 14 Jun 2005 10:44:35 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > 5) When you put the cube down for putting on the blindfold, be sure > you don't accidentally stop the timer! I've almost done this myself > once or twice, because the procedure is so similar to speedsolving. > You inspect/memorize, then put the cube down, then (*), then pick up > the cube and solve it. In speedsolving you touch the timer at (*) and > in blindsolving you must not! It's also important during the solve, e. > g. if you put the cube down for a moment to relax or whatever, and > when you try to pick it up again you could accidentally stop the > timer. Remember it's very sensitive. Ok, if you do accidentally stop the timer, that's still not the end of the world, since that's one reason why the judges always stop the time with an additional stopwatch. (uh, even though I seem to say these things to you (Chris) I guess you know I know you know them, they just could be said in your tutorial) Cheers! Stefan

1029. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: competition tutorial (link provided)
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 14 Jun 2005 09:34:01 -0600

That's not true... it actually is the end of the world.

In all seriousness, if you stop the timer by accident, that's your
fault, and we won't award you the time or another solve. In actuality,
the stopwatch is only used for the 15 seconds inspection. Maybe it
would be better if the judge doesn't time the actual solve because it
gives the misconception that the judge's timing is a backup. The
judge's timing of the solve is not a backup; simply said, usually the
judge has the stopwatch in their fingers, so they feel compelled to
time the solve.

If the timer fails on its own, then you get another solve. Otherwise,
you do not.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Jun 14, 2005, at 4:44 AM, Stefan Pochmann wrote:

> Ok, if you do accidentally stop the timer, that's still not the end of
> the world, since that's one reason why the judges always stop the time
> with an additional stopwatch.
>
> (uh, even though I seem to say these things to you (Chris) I guess you
> know I know you know them, they just could be said in your tutorial)
>
> Cheers!
> Stefan

Date: Tue, 14 Jun 2005 16:03:23 -0000

Oh, ok, didn't realize it's so strict. What if the timer fails on its own and I get a superb solve? Can't we then take the time from the judge? I thought that's also a reason why judges take the time... if that time doesn't count at all then I agree the judge really shouldn't take the time, it has indeed always given me the backup feeling and I've also been a judge sometimes :-( Cheers! 1031. [Speed cubing group] Re: competition tutorial (link provided)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 14 Jun 2005 16:12:02 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > That's not true... it actually is the end of the world. > > In all seriousness, if you stop the timer by accident, that's your > fault, and we won't award you the time or another solve. Actually, have a look at the official WCA world rankings for 3x3 blindfold or for 5x5. You can see times exceeding 10 minutes. Since the stackmats (at least generation 1) stop counting after 10 minutes, these are probably from the judges and their stopwatches... are they all invalid now? Cheers! Stefan
1032. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: competition tutorial (link provided)
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 14 Jun 2005 10:14:59 -0600

Yeah, unfortunately we can't. Especially if your time is superb and
even more especially if your solve is a world record. We can't have
the world record time with inaccurate means. Fortunately, in the
thousands of solves that I've watched over, I've only seen the timer
fail once.

These things happen, and there's nothing we can really do about it.
Any other timing method would not be in accordance of the regulation
and really wouldn't be fair. Also, how do we decide what's a "superb"
solve and an absolute junk solve?

Chris, when you refilm this video, maybe you could have Becky not time
you during the actual solve. It's how things should be done.

Exceptions for stopwatch timing occur for events that are expected to
last over 10 minutes. At those time scales, the error in human judging
is smaller. .2 is a big deal at the 15 second level but not that big
of a deal at the 15 minute level, and for most of our events, if you're
solving it in 15 minutes, it's not going to be a world record.

I will work on asking StackMat to adjust their timers so that they do
not shut off after 10 minutes. In the mean time, did you know that the
timing of solar system object observations with the Very Large Array
need to be timed so that you have the array in the right configuration?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Jun 14, 2005, at 10:03 AM, Stefan Pochmann wrote:

> Oh, ok, didn't realize it's so strict. What if the timer fails on its
> own and I get a superb solve? Can't we then take the time from the
> judge? I thought that's also a reason why judges take the time... if
> that time doesn't count at all then I agree the judge really shouldn't
> take the time, it has indeed always given me the backup feeling and
> I've also been a judge sometimes :-(
>
> Cheers!
> Stefan

Ok, what I meant was mainly a personal great achievement, also like when you solve blindfolded successfully for the very first time. We just need to enforce it, all judges need to know it (I think right now almost none do). Cheers! Hey Chris,

I bet Mr. Rubik would be offended for you not capitalizing his name!

Putting the cube down:

I also agree you should include a fast video demonstrating how to do
this. It sometimes helps to see something done at actual
speed...though I guess you already have this included in the mock-solve.

Competition procedure:
14) Don't actually take your cube, but wait for the judge to return
it to you. Otherwise, you can get yelled at. :)

~ Bob

1046. [Speed cubing group] Re: competition tutorial (link provided)
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 15 Jun 2005 06:08:15 -0000

Hey everyone,

Ok I fixed the main videos, the mockup 3x3 solves. I ran them by
Tyson and I have the WCA stamp of approval for correctness of the
procedure, what the judge says, when the competitor speaks, etc..

I also fixed the description of the procedure on my page.

Also, thanks all for the detailed responses.

In particular Stefan, I didn't realize that I never actually use both
hands to bring the cube to the mat, but I thought I did! That's
really weird, I always though I used both hands but after doing some
speedsolves and really paying attention to that step I always do it
with one hand!

I've already refilmed all the videos for putting the cube down, but I
have to go through and edit them into small downloadable clips.

It's really late, so I'll do that tomorrow.

But, the main 3x3 mock solves are corrected and can be used safely for
preparing yourself for a competition solve.

http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/competitiontutorial.html

Chris

P.S. I'll also add some stuff about how the stackmats work in a text
description, but right now I need sleep. Ok, enjoy the page, and keep
checking back for more updates/fixes




1047. Re: [Speed cubing group] another blindfold tutorial

Date: Wed, 15 Jun 2005 17:35:22 -0000

I like the timing on all the blindsolving tutorials. I just did my
first bld solve on the 2x2x2 last week and was going to start on the
3x3x3 this week.

One question I have though is how much writing you guys actually do.
When I was doing the 2x2x2 it ended up taking quite a bit of writing,
corner cycles etc... I know a lot of you can bld solve the 2x2x2 in
under a minute, so I assume there's not a whole lot of writing.

Understanding exactly what to do is necessary in order to solve it
quickly, so I guess the writing must convey the thought process which
can take a bit.

Tyson Mao

1050. Re: blindfold tutorial
From: "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 15 Jun 2005 20:20:50 -0000


> And how about orienting corners in the D layer instead of U? Do
> Macky/Leyan really do it the way you described? Try this, it's much
> faster (and also easier because one makes fewer mistakes when using
> fingertricks):
>
> (R U R' U' R U R' U') D (U R U' R' U R U' R') D'
>
> (R U R' U' R U R' U') D (R U R' U' R U R' U') D (R U R' U' R U R'
U')
> D2

I turn the cube with z'. So now the corner twister is R and U, and
the layer move is L.

> An easier way to find out whether an edge is badly oriented: I say
> white/yellow are brightest, green/blue are darkest and orange/red
are
> medium. This way each edge has a brighter and a darker sticker. An
> edge is correctly oriented iff its brighter sticker is on the
brighter
> face (defined by the centers). Just this single rule.

Not if you're using blue-opposite-white!

Macky





1051. Re: blindfold tutorial
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 15 Jun 2005 20:48:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > I turn the cube with z'. So now the corner twister is R and U, and > the layer move is L. Ok, that's even better :-) But why the cube rotation? And why not say so in your tutorial? I'm convinced using finger tricks also makes it easier, not only faster. > Not if you're using blue-opposite-white! Only sickos use that. Cheers! Stefan
1052. 4*4*4 : 9 pairs of edge at once
From: Frédérick BADIE <f_badie@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 15 Jun 2005 22:06:52 -0000

Hi,

I use this alg to solve 9 pairs of edge at once :

L' F' U (Rr)' (Dd)' D' U' R U D R' (Dd) (Rr)

9 pairs is a max, 8 more often.
The first 3 moves don't touch the edge-pair, but it's an help to
preposition them.

Frédérick.




1053. TournamentSheet.xls
From: makimoto2000us <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 15 Jun 2005 22:27:01 -0000

Hi everybody,

We are working on Kyoto contest to make it successful event.
I made a excel sheet for tournament with macro program
in order to organize competition effortless.

I know there are many great cubers and computer programers here.
When I made a stupid cube timer, great timers took over it.

I wish you would like it.
I wish someone could develop it and make it much nicer program.

Happpy cubing

Masayuki Akimoto

P.S. The file is in th files section.

don't know while you're doing this?

1063. 4x4x4 speedsolving vid !!!
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 16 Jun 2005 19:47:04 -0000

Hi!

I have been trying to shoot a good 4x4x4 speedsolving video today.
It's not easy to find a good angle for the webcam. And it's a bit
awkward to have to think of showing the cube for the cam while i
solve. So i didn't manage my topspeed. But at least i did manage a
1:13.97 solve while shooting.

As you can see im not using the usual pairing-up. My method is ...
umm .... arguably more intuitive. Sort of layer by layer if u like.
I call theis the "cage" method since the cube looks indeed like a
cage before i do the final centers :-)

Ok, here is the link : (no guarantee how long it remains there)

http://vakt.idi.ntnu.no/Per_4x4x4_1_13_97.wmv

Please enjoy it ;-)

-Per

PS! I'll procedd tomorrow to shoot a vid of me solving the missing
link puzzle ...

1071. Re: 4x4x4 speedsolving vid !!!
From: "Chris Parlette" <cparlett@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 16 Jun 2005 22:57:15 -0000

Actually, I've thought about this before, but do not have the necessary equipment to go through with the idea. I was thinking that if you could get multiple cameras set up at different angles, then you could put them together on the computer in 4 different quadrants. For instance, you have one from the cubers perspective, one below pointing up, one from the right side, and one from the upper-back-left (if that makes sense). If the cameras were positioned properly, then you wouldnt be able to see the other cameras in the shot. I think it would be great for analyzing someone's technique, but like I said, it requires a bit more resources than most people have. It would be fun to watch though! -Chris Parlette --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > Hi Per, > > Very nice solve. I could see the cube well - good distance. > > If you do another one, I would like to see all six sides of the cube > both before and after it is solved. > > The only "better angle" that I can think of right of is if you shot it > with a mirror placed strategically. 1075. Re: would it be cool if macky has a video solving the cube for 9 seconds?????
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 17 Jun 2005 12:28:47 -0000

Hi! Yes that would be really cool. However Yuki Hayashi has a really fast 3x3x3 solve recorded on his site : http://www.geocities.jp/n_wota/cube/video/fastest01.mpg This seems to me to be a practiced solve ;-) But still it's really really impressive. As far as i can see he solves the cube in something like 9.5 - 10.0 secs. Even for a practised solve this is really good. This is equivalent to about 4 moves/sec or more. It's really lucky fridrich solve if it's less than 40 moves required ;-) Cheers! -Per >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, James Benedict Caares <ben41sbr2@y...> wrote: > Ei everybody!!!!! > > Would it be cool if macky has a video solving the cube for 9 seconds????? using this scramble B2D'RU2BU2DF'B'U'F'R2L'D'U2R2F'DU2L2R2F2U2F2R2, i was really hoping that macky would post a cool video like this in his site............. > > J.B. > > __________________________________________________ > Do You Yahoo!? > Tired of spam? 1076. Re: would it be cool if macky has a video solving the cube for 9 seconds?????
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 17 Jun 2005 12:37:42 -0000

Umm ... That direct link won't work. So u have to go first here : http://www.geocities.jp/n_wota/cube/ Then it's the Katsu Method video. Check out his other cool videos. There are some awesome 4x4x4 vids too (pairing-up method). Some vids are on his temp page : http://www.geocities.jp/n_wota/temp/ Enjoy !! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hi! > > Yes that would be really cool. However Yuki Hayashi has a really > fast 3x3x3 solve recorded on his site : > > http://www.geocities.jp/n_wota/cube/video/fastest01.mpg > > This seems to me to be a practiced solve ;-) But still it's really > really impressive. As far as i can see he solves the cube in > something like 9.5 - 10.0 secs. Even for a practised solve this is > really good. This is equivalent to about 4 moves/sec or more. It's > really lucky fridrich solve if it's less than 40 moves required ;-) > > Cheers! > > -Per > > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, James Benedict > Caares <ben41sbr2@y...> wrote: > > Ei everybody!!!!! > > > > Would it be cool if macky has a video solving the cube for 9 > seconds????? using this scramble > B2D'RU2BU2DF'B'U'F'R2L'D'U2R2F'DU2L2R2F2U2F2R2, i was really hoping > that macky would post a cool video like this in his site............. > > > > J.B. > > > > __________________________________________________ > > Do You Yahoo!? > > Tired of spam? 1078. Re: blindfold question
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 17 Jun 2005 20:08:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ben King" <grsbmd@y...> wrote: > When you do a bld solve I know you're allowed to put it behind your > back to solve it, but are you allowed to read algorithms that you > don't know while you're doing this? I'd say not. You're not supposed to make notes so equally you shouldn't be able to read anything. If you read something then you're not really solving without sight, plus that totally differentiates it from blindfold solving where you wouldn't be able to read anything.
1079. Prize FMC #89 this week
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>, <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 17 Jun 2005 21:01:19 +0100

Hi everyone!

Just to remind you, that thanks to our friend at www.cubesmith.com from this week onwards there will be a small prize up for grabs for the winners of each of the FMC Turn Metric competitions.

This week, you have the chance to net yourself a lovely brand new set of 3x3x3 stickers!
The scramble will appear on the website - www.cubestation.co.uk -> Fewest Moves Challenge very soon, happy FMC'ing, and Good Luck!

Dan Harris :)

1082. San Clemente High School's Cuber's Club
From: Jeremy Fleischman <jeremyfleischman@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 18 Jun 2005 01:40:11 -0700 (PDT)


San Clemente High School's Cuber's Club just held a competition! We currently have 12 people at our school who I know can solve the cube, and 6 of the fastest competed. We even got to eat a Rubik's cake! Understand that most of the competitors have only been cubing for a month, so hopefully the times will be lower by the next competition. Since I was the host and judge of the competition, I did not participate. Obviously, this wasn't an official WCA competition, but I hope to bring a few friends to a Caltech competition soon (I'd love to go to the Dallas tourney, but I don't think I can go.) I've attached the results, and wanted to know if there is a simple way for me to post all of the results on speedcubing.com, rather than one at a time (though it wouldn't be that difficult.) People just love to see their names online.

This was the first meeting for San Clemente High School's Cuber's Club, I hope to get a website running soon, and I'll post some pictures. I'd also love any advice you would give to someone starting a Rubik's cube club.

Jeremy Fleischman



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1083. Re: Need another clock Stefan?
From: "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@...>

Date: Sat, 18 Jun 2005 10:20:38 -0000

LOLL!!! I was actually looking for one so I bought it. Thanks :-) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > I found this amusing... > > http://cgi.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll? > ViewItem&category=19187&item=5980645719&rd=1
1084. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4*4*4 : 9 pairs of edge at once
From: Frédérick BADIE <f_badie@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 18 Jun 2005 18:13:06 -0000

By following the 9-cycle, you have the first 4 pairs in the same layer. Consider it like the D layer ( made as a cross) . The 4 next pairs are in the middle layer ( by analogy the F2L step). And the last pair is in the U layer. This alg leaves the last 3 pairs in U layer unsolved. If you have 5-cycle by example, nevermind. Continue the preposition with an other cycle. Just you loose one pair. Most of the time, my alg leaves 4 pairs unsolved. If I loose one pair (it's an unlucky case), you have 5 pairs unsolved. But 4 or 5 pairs unsolved is the same (about). I try to calculate the probabilities : having a cycle of minumum 9 pairs is possible most of the time, and it is not very important if you loose one pair. Have fun, Frederick --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > Frédérick, > > Cool algorithm! > But how do you easily set up this 9 cycle? And what if there is a 5 cycle > instead of a 9 cycle? > > Have fun, > > Ron > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Frédérick BADIE" <f_badie@y...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Thursday, June 16, 2005 12:06 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] 4*4*4 : 9 pairs of edge at once > > > > Hi, > > > > I use this alg to solve 9 pairs of edge at once : > > > > L' F' U (Rr)' (Dd)' D' U' R U D R' (Dd) (Rr) > > > > 9 pairs is a max, 8 more often. > > The first 3 moves don't touch the edge-pair, but it's an help to > > preposition them. > > > > Frédérick. > >

if you had to choose between the two.

Tyson Mao

1086. Re: Need another clock Stefan?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 18 Jun 2005 22:10:46 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > I found this amusing... > > http://cgi.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll? > ViewItem&category=19187&item=5980645719&rd=1 Haha, reminds me of something... I once taught a friend of mine how to solve it (with a 14-move solution) and he was able to solve it in about 25 seconds on average. One day I "scrambled" it for him just by changing a center clock by a single hour. He was so afraid to destroy anything that after two minutes of basically doing nothing he gave up I think (maybe he proceeded to solve it from scratch, but I don't remember anymore). Cheers! Stefan

1090. Fast {R,U,L} version of a COLL alg
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 19 Jun 2005 07:09:49 -0000

Hey everyone,

First off let me say that the COLL case I am mentioning has a fast alg
to it already. However, personally for my hands I don't like that alg
and it is very slow for me.

Well I used Acube and came up with an {R,U,L} alg that I really,
really like for it.

All the COLL sites seem to list the same alg, which is (in some form
or another):
y (R F') U' (R2 F) U' F' U R2 U (F R') (Lars' site)
RF'U'R2FU'F'UR2UFR' (Ron's algs list)

The alg I found with Acube is:
L U L' U R' U L U R U R' U R L'
which I do as

(L U L') (U) (R' U) L (U) [(R U R' U) R] L'

Again, personally for my hands this RUL alg is MUCH better than the
other one, but I know that the "regular" alg is also fast. Just not
for my hands :-D

Chris





1091. Re: [Speed cubing group] San Clemente High School's Cuber's Club
From: Jeremy Fleischman <jeremyfleischman@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 19 Jun 2005 02:10:51 -0700 (PDT)

It's really too bad I wasn't able to pull off the competition before the school year ended, it would be a lot easier to gauge the school's interest in cubing. I know that there are at least three dedicated cubers who plan on learning more algorithms; while others may not be interested in knowing more than how to solve the cube. By October, if everything goes to plan, everyone at San Clemente will want to go to an official competition! Seriously though, I hope to bring four people (myself included) to a Caltech competition in Pasadena. And hopefully, the same group will go to the 2006 Nationals. I believe there is some real untapped talent at my high school, and I hope to have some very fast cubers for the coming school year.

Oh, and thaiguy20fromLA, don't "wish that my middle school had a competition," instead, hold your own to kick off a new club! I'm amazed at how interested people are in learning how to solve a Rubik's cube. Just today, when I took a cube out of my pocket and did a 51 second solve, two people came up and asked me to teach them how to solve it this summer (and of course, I will.) As I've seen many people say, cubing is going through a revival of sorts, and we can help spread it like a virus!

Jeremy Fleischman

1093. [Speed cubing group] Re: Minh Thai interview?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 19 Jun 2005 12:03:37 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Rune Wesström <rune. wesstrom@h...> wrote: > > Don´t you mean the interwiew, mentioned down? I think it was more like a normal interview (not an email interview in which Minh repeats all questions before answering, and it had a picture I believe). > Having *your* brain, I could probably quote the whole article, but alas, I havn´t! If you say that because of blindsolving: I can only remember things that well if I actively store them in memory, but my normal memory isn't different from yours. Anyone could do these blindsolve things. Actually I'm for example very bad at remembering quotes from movies (I'm always amazed how well others can do this, right when we come out of the cinema and they talk about quotes and things and I don't remember them anymore) and often I forget the ending of a movie, which isn't that bad because then I can be somewhat surprised again when I watch it again :-). Cheers! Stefan

1096. Re: Fast {R,U,L} version of a COLL alg
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 20 Jun 2005 16:28:51 -0000

Hi Chris, If I don't want to change where the corners are and just reorient them I use 11 moves: R U2 R2 U' R2 U' R2 U2 R which is probably well known. Your COLL reverses the LL corner positions. For that CLL I do 10 moves: R' F' U' F U' R U R' U R I call that corner permutation "barrow" because it reminds me a wheel barrow. Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > First off let me say that the COLL case I am mentioning has a fast alg > to it already. However, personally for my hands I don't like that alg > and it is very slow for me. > > Well I used Acube and came up with an {R,U,L} alg that I really, > really like for it. > > All the COLL sites seem to list the same alg, which is (in some form > or another): > y (R F') U' (R2 F) U' F' U R2 U (F R') (Lars' site) > RF'U'R2FU'F'UR2UFR' (Ron's algs list) > > The alg I found with Acube is: > L U L' U R' U L U R U R' U R L' > which I do as > > (L U L') (U) (R' U) L (U) [(R U R' U) R] L' > > Again, personally for my hands this RUL alg is MUCH better than the > other one, but I know that the "regular" alg is also fast. Just not > for my hands :-D > > Chris
1097. Re: another blindfold tutorial
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 20 Jun 2005 17:30:06 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > http://cubefreak.hp.infoseek.co.jp/blindfoldcubing_guide.html > > Sunil pressured me to finish it. I would greatly appreciate some > feedbacks or suggestions. > > Much thanks, > Macky Hi Macky, You wrote: "Solving a Rubik's Cube blindfolded is not difficult. At all! All we need is a fairly good short-term memory and the persistence to learn the method." Maybe you should add the parenthetical remark: "Solving a Rubik's Cube blindfolded is not difficult. At all! (If you take the time to memorize it properly!) All we ..." because if you try to go really fast it is quite possible to start the resolution before you've actually properly committed the starting position to memory. That's especially true if you're racing other people. But it's certainly true that if you just want to be able to solve a cube blindfolded then it isn't at all difficult. I'll agree with you 100% on that. Your link near the bottom (http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/% 20Richard/BlindfoldRevenge.pdf) doesn't seem to work. Looks like it is because of the extra space: %20. http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Richard/BlindfoldRevenge.pdf would be the correct link. That's an old document, a beginner method - I guess you could use this intermediate method one instead: http://www.math.columbia.edu/~carr/BCFTSS.pdf This is also not a great document but it is a little better - in particular, I never really wrote a good section on memorization and it's not as in-depth as it might be. If I ever finish the advanced method it will be much better (and take far fewer moves on average). As far as I know, BCFTSS is the only method that gives an exact expected number of moves for solution (assuming non-cancellation between stages which I really didn't want to go into).
1098. Re: another blindfold tutorial
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 20 Jun 2005 17:51:33 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > http://cubefreak.hp.infoseek.co.jp/blindfoldcubing_guide.html > > Sunil pressured me to finish it. I would greatly appreciate some > feedbacks or suggestions. > > Much thanks, > Macky Some observations - I'll admit that I haven't read it all, so maybe these are uninformed! i) Cycle Decomposition Algorithm 1. Locate the smallest number that has not been written (the first time this number is 1). a. If such number exists, write down "(" and then that number. b. If all numbers have been written, stop. 2. Find the last number that was written. Determine to which spot this corner needs to be moved. a. If the number of this spot has not been written, write it down and repeat step 2. b. If the number of this spot has been written, write ")" to end the cycle. Go to step 1. Just a small point: this seems to indicate that you are allowed to write stuff down. Surely that's against the rules. "iii. Edge Permutation Edge orientation is the hardest part of blindfold cubing" ^^^^^^^^^^^ Actually, having written the below I realize you have discussed exactly what I am saying. "iv) ..." Just as a note - you could reduce to 4 corners and 4 edges to be cycled (and then solve with "U" for instance). In the cycle set up that would be easier perhaps. It's immediately obvious whether you will need to do this stage if you are memorizing cycles and you could adjust the cycles mentally at the start to solve to the stage where you just need to do "U" at the end. This would result in a much faster resolution at the end. (Those skills are necessary anyway, if you want to be able to learn to blindfold solve from one given scrambled position to another.)
1099. Re: Fast {R,U,L} version of a COLL alg
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 20 Jun 2005 17:57:30 -0000

For the past few years I've been using a different one than any of those. (RB'R'F)(R2'B)(RF')LF2'(RF2')L' I forget how I came up with it, it was a long time ago, before Lars or Ron posted those algs. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > First off let me say that the COLL case I am mentioning has a fast alg > to it already. However, personally for my hands I don't like that alg > and it is very slow for me. > > Well I used Acube and came up with an {R,U,L} alg that I really, > really like for it. > > All the COLL sites seem to list the same alg, which is (in some form > or another): > y (R F') U' (R2 F) U' F' U R2 U (F R') (Lars' site) > RF'U'R2FU'F'UR2UFR' (Ron's algs list) > > The alg I found with Acube is: > L U L' U R' U L U R U R' U R L' > which I do as > > (L U L') (U) (R' U) L (U) [(R U R' U) R] L' > > Again, personally for my hands this RUL alg is MUCH better than the > other one, but I know that the "regular" alg is also fast. Just not > for my hands :-D > > Chris
1100. Re: another blindfold tutorial
From: "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 20 Jun 2005 18:03:00 -0000

Since I'm in vacation (since today), I'll finally be able to concentrate on Blindfold cubing. I'll write a report of my progress with your guide. How long do you think is necessary to learn to solve a cube blindfolded ? > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mackymakisumi" > <mackymakisumi@y...> wrote: > > http://cubefreak.hp.infoseek.co.jp/blindfoldcubing_guide.html > > > > Sunil pressured me to finish it. I would greatly appreciate some > > feedbacks or suggestions. > > > > Much thanks, > > Macky
1101. Re: another blindfold tutorial
From: "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 20 Jun 2005 20:36:27 -0000

Hi Richard, Thank you for the comments. > Maybe you should add the parenthetical remark: > > "Solving a Rubik's Cube blindfolded is not difficult. At all! (If > you take the time to memorize it properly!) All we ..." > > because if you try to go really fast it is quite possible to start > the resolution before you've actually properly committed the > starting position to memory. That's especially true if you're racing > other people. But it's certainly true that if you just want to be > able to solve a cube blindfolded then it isn't at all difficult. > I'll agree with you 100% on that. Haha, you're quite right. I'll add that with "(Richard Carr adds, 'If you take....')" > Your link near the bottom (http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/% > 20Richard/BlindfoldRevenge.pdf) doesn't seem to work. Looks like it > is because of the extra space: %20. > http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Richard/BlindfoldRevenge.pdf > would be the correct link. > That's an old document, a beginner method - I guess you could use > this intermediate method one instead: > > http://www.math.columbia.edu/~carr/BCFTSS.pdf My apologies for the mistake. I'll fix the first and add this new link as well. This is quite an impressive collection of algorithms, plus theory for Megaminx! Cool stuff. I also rewrote the cubie names according to your "U<D<F<B<R<L." > i) Cycle Decomposition Algorithm > 1. Locate the smallest number that has not been written (the first > time this number is 1). > a. If such number exists, write down "(" and then that number. > b. If all numbers have been written, stop. > 2. Find the last number that was written. Determine to which spot > this corner needs to be moved. > a. If the number of this spot has not been written, write it > down and repeat step 2. > b. If the number of this spot has been written, write ")" to > end the cycle. Go to step 1. > > Just a small point: this seems to indicate that you are allowed to > write stuff down. Surely that's against the rules. Right. I added, "In official attempts, writing down or reading anything is not permitted. However, using a piece of paper to write down the needed information for each step is a good practice when first working with cycles." > "iii. Edge Permutation > > Edge orientation is the hardest part of blindfold cubing" > ^^^^^^^^^^^ Fixed. > Actually, having written the below I realize you have discussed > exactly what I am saying. > > "iv) ..." > > Just as a note - you could reduce to 4 corners and 4 edges to be > cycled (and then solve with "U" for instance). In the cycle set up > that would be easier perhaps. It's immediately obvious whether you > will need to do this stage if you are memorizing cycles and you > could adjust the cycles mentally at the start to solve to the stage > where you just need to do "U" at the end. This would result in a > much faster resolution at the end. (Those skills are necessary > anyway, if you want to be able to learn to blindfold solve from one > given scrambled position to another.) I was writing about doing U at the beginning of the solve, but you're right, you could modify the cycles just as easily to do U at the end. I'll also add a sentence about that. Much thanks, Macky
1102. Re: Fast {R,U,L} version of a COLL alg
From: makimoto2000us <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 20 Jun 2005 23:25:56 -0000

Hi Chris,

The alg I found with Acube is:
L U L' U R' U L U R U R' U R L'
Thank you for your new algorithm.
It seems great.

I normally flip edges in this CLL case.
RUR'U-D'w-RU'R'F'

I will add your alg on my list.
But I like reverve and mirror, then the first move becomes same as my
old one.

RL'U'R'U'RU'-L-U'R'-f-RU'RU

Masayuki Akimoto




1103. Re: Fast {R,U,L} version of a COLL alg

Sorry, I made a lot of mistakes
> I normally flip edges in this CLL case.
> RUR'U-D'w-RU'R'F'
RUR'UR-D'w-RU'R'F'

>
> I will add your alg on my list.
> But I like reverve and mirror, then the first move becomes same as my
> old one.
>
> RL'U'R'U'RU'-L-U'R'-f-RU'RU
RL'UR'URU-L-UR'-f-RU'RU


> Masayuki Akimoto

1116. [Speed cubing group] Re: re-stickering a 3x3
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 21 Jun 2005 09:51:06 -0000

Yes, but I figured he wanted to know the absolute minimum. And it's usually not too hard to remove the center caps, is it? I'd rather switch the stickers, though ;-). Not because it might be easier (depends on the cube) but because the caps are a semi-functional part and I always try to put everything back where it came from (that's for example the reason I usually only remove one center at a time). Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o.. .> wrote: > Doesn't that depend on if he can remove his center caps or not? > > > Bryan Mytko > bryanosaurus@b... > > > On Jun 21, 2005, at 5:03 AM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, tlceer <no_reply@y. ..> > > wrote: > > > hi, just wondering, how many stickers will i need to change, in > > order > > > to conver the color scheme of a 3x3 cube from Japanese to standard? > > > > 8 > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 1122. Re: [Speed cubing group] rubik's cd cover
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 21 Jun 2005 13:36:39 -0400

1132. 4x4x4 method :-)
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 22 Jun 2005 12:20:37 -0000

Hi James :-)

For the 4x4x4 revenge/master cube i use the same system as i do for
the 5x5x5 wahn/professor cube.

The basic steps are as follows:

(I call this the "Cage" method. )

1. Do first layer completely. This is intuitive. If some centers
are "tricky" to solve they can be left for later if so desired.
basically i solve the cubies in the order i see them. Cubies that make
up blocks are inserted into first layer as a block also, when possible.

2. (First twist the middle layers into favorable positions. U can get
quite a few edges and/or centers for free by doing this.) Now do
middle layers edges. This is done by and large with commutator 3-
cycles. Also here one can cycle blocks of cubies when solving them.
Either to solve several edges at the same time or remove badly placed
edges (move to final layer where i do most of the "fishing") or move
bad edges to a better position within the middle layers.

3. Final layer corners. First position them (only 2 algs needed) then
orient them (there are 6 easy cases for this).

4. Now solve all last layer edges with 3-cycles. This is perhaps the
most tricky step. I use easy commutator 3-cycles with very few setup
moves. In fact the setup is never more than 1 single move. The most
difficult thing about this is to recognize which 3-cycle to do next. I
normally look for 3-cycles that will solve 2 edges with same 3-cycle.
So i do a quick "scan" tracking the edges and see if that is possible.
If not i just settle for a 3-cycle solving 1 edge only. There is of
coz the parity which means im left with only 2 edges to swap. This is
fairly easy also. This is fixed with an inner slice turn and a edge 3-
cycle on this layer. In most cases some setup moves are needed (at
most 2 moves). Remember that it doesn't matter that my parity fix will
mess w the centers. With some luck block 3-cycles can also be used
efficiently.

5. Do all the remaining centers with yet more 3-cycles. Block cycles
where possible. With practice u can achieve good cancellations btw 2
succesive 3-cycles : (simple example) r'urUr'u'd'rU'r'dr - 4 moves are
cancelled. There are also some other center-algs that works on oppsite
faces. One example : (r2b2)*2

Benefits of this method are:

- U solve the cubies into their home position all the time. There is
no tricky parts where u just solve cubies relative to eachother like
when pairing up edgesw Chris' method.

- Doing lots of 3-cycle it's easy to foresee where all pieces are
going so u get excellent lookahead and very good flow in ur solves
most of the time.

- Mistakes u do early are not so fatal. There is usually easy fix for
simple mistakes.

- U don't rely on a fast 3x3x3 method to do the last stage for u. My
method has no "3x3x3-stage" at all.

- Only one parity, not two.

One disadvantage is that i probably need about 25% more moves as
compared w Chris' method. So u really have to be a grandmaster of
commutator 3-cycles and utilise block cycling as much as u can. And u
need to make sure u get a good flow.

A typical solve for me goes like this :

- (15 secs) First layer done
- (30 secs) Middle layer edges done
- (50-55 secs) Last layer done
- (70-75 secs) All centers are done. Cube is SOLVED!!

That's it for the 4x4x4 method. The 5x5x5 method has a few more
special cases. A list of these:

- Make sure while orienting the middle layers after solving first
layer that the extreme middle layer is twisted such that the middle
centers end up in correct location. So u are can actually only twist 2
of the 3 middle layers freely. Umm u can choose to willingly set up
the 4-spot pattern. But i never do that.

- For last layer edges i would do the middle edges first. This is
actually a separate step since u can't mix middle edges and outer
edges. Doing the middle ones first gives easier recognition for
solving the outer edges.

- There are more special algs for exchanging centers between opposite
faces. Example : (r2 E2)*2 or (Ff) r'u'r U r'u r U' (Ff)'

Writing down these details make it cound more complicated then it
really is ;-)

Cheers!

-Per

1136. Re: New York tournament DVD available
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 22 Jun 2005 23:29:40 -0000

I got mine today and they're great! Really good job! I've watched them on my notebook running Windows XP without problems, both video and sound work alright (I only say so because Ian mentioned problems with PCs on his webpage). Btw, I know why Lars Vandenbergh and Macky can stay so cool in competitions. I had the theory about Lars last year already and now I have it about Macky, too, after seeing him on the DVDs. Notice that Lars has a lot of long hair which covers his neck. It's a primary instinct of humans to feel vulnerable if the neck is open for attacks. So that's why we're nervous but not Lars, he's protected by his hair. Macky is somewhat similar. Not with hair, but with his long-sleeved shirt. And with the jacket he wears *additionally*! While everybody else is wearing T-shirts!!! Alright, now I'll let you praise me for exposing the coolness mystery... Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ian" <iwinoky@y...> wrote: > I have just finished compiling and editing footage from the Horace > Mann Tournament held on May 28, 2005 and I'm pleased with the > results. The finished product is over 3 hours long. We caught > virtually every solve of Macky, Chris Hardwick, and Ryan Patricio > (including Macky's insane 23 second one-handed solve) and we put > chapters into the DVD that allow you to skip to any scramble of any > solve. I'm selling the two DVD set for $15 including free shipping to > anywhere in the contiguous US. I can ship overseas as well. For > screenshots and lots more info, go to > > http://home.manhattan.edu/~ian.winokur/DVD/dvd.html > > Feel free to e-mail me with questions or comments. > > Ian Winokur

> the next business day.

I have tried to let them know I am still WAITING for a response, but
they just give me the same message above. (Anyone from rubiks.com
reading this?)

Anyway, my question was about the DIY kits. Both black and white seem
not to have arched centres according to the photos:

https://secure.rubiks.com/lvl3/index_lvl3.cfm?lan=eng&lvl1=produc&lvl2=rubbrn&lvl3=diykit&lvl4=cubkit
https://secure.rubiks.com/lvl3/index_lvl3.cfm?lan=eng&lvl1=produc&lvl2=rubbrn&lvl3=diykit&lvl4=cubwkt

Is that right? Or is one or both of these supposed to have arched
centres?

Thanks,

Ryan

1145. Re: New York tournament DVD available
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Jun 2005 11:39:34 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hmmm. Interesting theory, Stefan. But my hair is even longer than Lars > V's hair and I get quite nervous in competition. Then again, I usually > tie my hair back for competition so it doesn't fall over my face and > annoy or distract me. Maybe if I left my hair out I'd do better?? > > Jasmine Yeah, you should try that. Of course another reason for you to get nervous might be all the good-looking guys around you so you should bring lots of female cubers with you next time ;-) Cheers! Stefan

1153. How to assemble Eastsheen 4x4x4 (tutorial)
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Jun 2005 21:10:36 -0000

Hi guys !

I made finally a tutorial for how to assemble the Eastsheen 4x4x4
cube. I have seen many (mostly bad) descriptions how to do this.
Most of them have seemed too complicated using various tricks such
as loosen all the screws. It's surprisingly easy to put it back
together. But yes u need to screw off one of the inner centers in
order to do it my way.

Here is the link :
http://vakt.idi.ntnu.no/apartment/Eastsheen_4x4x4.htm

Hope that some will find it useful. I must admit that first time
ever i assembled that cube it took me ages. It wasn't until a little
later i found an easy way to put it back together. Actually it's no
wonder why this puzzle locks so badly when there are so many
pieces :-o

Cheers!

-Per

PS! I hate the eastsheen 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 for speeding. 4x4x4 version
locks horribly and 5x5x5 version pops horribly as well as locks too
much for my liking :-(

1159. New LL strategy proposal
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 26 Jun 2005 01:18:07 -0500

I've been doing a lot of serious pondering concerning last layer methods recently, since my job now affords me the time. I have a couple of observations and would like to pose a few questions, as well as a strategy I feel might be worth consideration. Apologies if anyone has come up with this before, but I've not heard of this, so I'm currently assuming I'm the only one. Yay me. =D

First off, I know that Macky uses partial edge control during the F2L. I also know that Chris Hardwick and others are using ZBF2L. I understand this is a good way to cut down on your LL and recognization times, while only increasing your F2L times by a smaller amount. I also know most of the people doing this are using either a 2 or 3 look approach to follow it, with either OLL+PLL, COLL+PLL, or what have you. I don't think ZB is a realistic approach for most of us (sane cubers ;D). This can make for fast times in either case, but I think it can be improved upon, without resorting to ZBLL (for those of us who are far too lazy, such as myself).

I started learning the Roux method a while back, and managed some relative success with it, despite doing corners in two looks, and not learning the 26 special optimization cases or any of the fun tricks. I managed times in the low 20's, and was slightly faster than my 3 and 4 look LBL method at the time. This is where I began to consider CLL and COLL based strategies as competitive. I've since learned most of the PLL and some more tricks, and have been neglecting my Roux practicing lately. I decided to learn the CLL+ELL, both to help prevent me from being a basic Fridrich clone, and to help me with my occasional Roux solving. It also helps for 2x2x2, apparently, because I took my first averages for it yesterday, and managed a couple of 5.xx and few 6.xx solves.

What if someone were to comprise a method using basic F2L with partial edge control only when the case is easy? This would cut down on how much your F2L would be slowed down, at least on average. You would of course need ELL algorithms to be able to finish in most cases, then. Next, if the method included both COLL algs and CLL algs that flip edges, you would have much better odds of obtaining a lucky case for your ELL step, often rendering it a simple edge only PLL. In the worst cases, you'd still wind up with only slightly longer LL times because of the comparison of ELL against pure edge PLL, but I think you'd make that up in time saved on the F2L and through lucky cases.

As near as I can tell on my extremely quick number crunching, here are the approximate algorithm requirements for various last layer strategies:
OLL+PLL: 57+21=78
Partial Edge Control+OLL+PLL: 8+7 to 57+21=36 to 86
CLL+ELL: 40+29=69
EOLL+COLL+PLL: 2+40+4=46
Partial Edge Control+COLL+PLL: 8+40+4=52
ZBF2L+COLL+PLL: 306+40+4=350 (or fewer; I'm not certain)
ZBF2L+ZBLL: 306+493=799
Proposed method: 8+40+40+29=117
(partial edge control+C/COLL+ELL/PLL)

If you discount reflections, most of these numbers will be less. The total number of algs for the proposed method would be cut down to something like 8+24+24+19=75, giving it an small fraction of the algorithms necessary for anything ZB, but with the added advantage of more lucky scenarios and easy recognition on the each of the cases for corners. All you would have to distinguish above and beyond either the CLL or COLL case to perform would be which of those to use, depending on the number of correctly oriented edges, and whether or not you want to flip any. It seems at first glance, that if you double the number of algorithms in your repertoire like this, you can effectively double the number of lucky situations you can achieve.

I'm interested to hear what everyone thinks, and definitely what anyone who already uses a CLL or COLL approach thinks, especially as a viable alternative to ZBLL for most of us (I'm looking at you, Chris Hardwick), so if you have any thoughts or suggestions, fire away.

-Mike 'putting way too much effort into this post' Bennett

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1160. Re: voice conversation?
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 26 Jun 2005 13:36:05 -0000

That's a great idea. My nick is: jnoort. If any cuber wants to add me, go ahead ;). --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Let's all talk on the phone! > > http://www.skype.com/ > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology
1161. Re: New LL strategy proposal
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 26 Jun 2005 15:28:32 -0000

Hey Mike, Thanks for your LL post, it was really interesting reading it, and my comments are below. First off, I would like to add one more option to your LL approach list. I seriously doubt I will be ready to use much ZB tricks by WC2005, but there is one idea that I think I may be ready for, and would like to practice to see if it has any merit. ZBF2L+OLL+PLL: 306+7+21=334 This idea has the advantage of using Fridrich PLL (very fast) and also only the 7 OLL algs that flip corners (all VERY fast). The F2L would of course be longer, but a lot of COLL algs are very fast and very easy to recognize, so on the easiest cases I would still do COLL. And of course the easiest to execute and recognize ZBLL algs as well. I'm still doubtful of this variation, but I think it might be a better option than COLL/PLL for me at least for WC2005. So add that the to your list too. This can also have the variation: Partial edge control+OLL+PLL which you already mentioned, so of course ZBF2L is not required. About your proposed method, I think it is a good idea. The only hard part I see is to know , for each CLL case, which edges are flipped. Of course just because something is hard doesn't mean you shouldn't do it too :-D The way I see it CLL has a 1/8 chance of not only solving corners, but flipping all edges correctly, leaving a fast edge PLL (or a 1/12 skip). Also I'm really starting to like COLL/PLL as well as a LL ending. The 1/12 chance of a PLL skip comes in handy, as well as the always very fast PLL alg. So I also agree that this is a good strategy. Personally I think this strategy is a good idea. It doesn't require a huge number of algs, or decisions while finishing the F2L or for the CLL/COLL step. I think delaying won't be a problem once mastered, and the ending would be very fast too. You may want to keep the fast OLL algs too, since Fridrich PLL is very fast. Say if you get the oriention that looks like the T (B U L U' L' B' to setup) then just do the OLL. Also, one thing you may want to think about for the 4th pair are ZBF2L algs where all edges are correctly, or incorrectly flipped. These cases are all very easy to notice, and the algs are all very fast to execute. It would require you to learn roughly 25 more algs, since most standard F2L algs are the ones that preserve edge orientation. In general flipping all edges while doing the 4th pair takes very slightly longer than the algs for preserving edge orientation, but not very much. So that might be something you could look into if you want to expand that step, but otherwise I think partial edge control is enough. I think this would be a good option for a LL technque, I mean the more algs you know towards achieving a lucky case, the more likely you are to get lucky. And your method has the option of CLL also orienting all edges (and also the 1/8 * 1/12 = 1/96 chance of a 1 look LL, but only for algs that flip edges), and COLL skipping PLL step 1/12. If you're interested I can give you what I consider the easiest ZBF2L cases (only about 5 or 6 or so) that are all easy to recognize and really really short. You could add that to partial edge control and have a better chance of ending up with oriented edges. I say go for it, the method sounds good to me :-D Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > I've been doing a lot of serious pondering concerning last layer methods recently, since my job now affords me the time. I have a couple of observations and would like to pose a few questions, as well as a strategy I feel might be worth consideration. Apologies if anyone has come up with this before, but I've not heard of this, so I'm currently assuming I'm the only one. Yay me. =D > > First off, I know that Macky uses partial edge control during the F2L. I also know that Chris Hardwick and others are using ZBF2L. I understand this is a good way to cut down on your LL and recognization times, while only increasing your F2L times by a smaller amount. I also know most of the people doing this are using either a 2 or 3 look approach to follow it, with either OLL+PLL, COLL+PLL, or what have you. I don't think ZB is a realistic approach for most of us (sane cubers ;D). This can make for fast times in either case, but I think it can be improved upon, without resorting to ZBLL (for those of us who are far too lazy, such as myself). > > I started learning the Roux method a while back, and managed some relative success with it, despite doing corners in two looks, and not learning the 26 special optimization cases or any of the fun tricks. I managed times in the low 20's, and was slightly faster than my 3 and 4 look LBL method at the time. This is where I began to consider CLL and COLL based strategies as competitive. I've since learned most of the PLL and some more tricks, and have been neglecting my Roux practicing lately. I decided to learn the CLL+ELL, both to help prevent me from being a basic Fridrich clone, and to help me with my occasional Roux solving. It also helps for 2x2x2, apparently, because I took my first averages for it yesterday, and managed a couple of 5.xx and few 6.xx solves. > > What if someone were to comprise a method using basic F2L with partial edge control only when the case is easy? This would cut down on how much your F2L would be slowed down, at least on average. You would of course need ELL algorithms to be able to finish in most cases, then. Next, if the method included both COLL algs and CLL algs that flip edges, you would have much better odds of obtaining a lucky case for your ELL step, often rendering it a simple edge only PLL. In the worst cases, you'd still wind up with only slightly longer LL times because of the comparison of ELL against pure edge PLL, but I think you'd make that up in time saved on the F2L and through lucky cases. > > As near as I can tell on my extremely quick number crunching, here are the approximate algorithm requirements for various last layer strategies: > OLL+PLL: 57+21=78 > Partial Edge Control+OLL+PLL: 8+7 to 57+21=36 to 86 > CLL+ELL: 40+29=69 > EOLL+COLL+PLL: 2+40+4=46 > Partial Edge Control+COLL+PLL: 8+40+4=52 > ZBF2L+COLL+PLL: 306+40+4=350 (or fewer; I'm not certain) > ZBF2L+ZBLL: 306+493=799 > Proposed method: 8+40+40+29=117 > (partial edge control+C/COLL+ELL/PLL) > > If you discount reflections, most of these numbers will be less. The total number of algs for the proposed method would be cut down to something like 8+24+24+19=75, giving it an small fraction of the algorithms necessary for anything ZB, but with the added advantage of more lucky scenarios and easy recognition on the each of the cases for corners. All you would have to distinguish above and beyond either the CLL or COLL case to perform would be which of those to use, depending on the number of correctly oriented edges, and whether or not you want to flip any. It seems at first glance, that if you double the number of algorithms in your repertoire like this, you can effectively double the number of lucky situations you can achieve. > > I'm interested to hear what everyone thinks, and definitely what anyone who already uses a CLL or COLL approach thinks, especially as a viable alternative to ZBLL for most of us (I'm looking at you, Chris Hardwick), so if you have any thoughts or suggestions, fire away. > > -Mike 'putting way too much effort into this post' Bennett > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1162. Re: [Speed cubing group] voice conversation?
From: nascarjon2001 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

1163. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New LL strategy proposal
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 26 Jun 2005 12:12:49 -0500

Thanks for reading the post. It took me entirely too long to write, seeing as it was 1 in the morning here.

I definitely thought about that one, but forgot to add it. 306+57+21=384 cases. (The last pair could be solved for you, leaving you with any OLL case)

I only know a small portion of the CLL and a slightly larger chunk of the COLL. Still, even using the basic approach of a 3 look LL (2 look OLL+1 look PLL), it's easy to recognize the cases I know. When I look at the corner orientation, I really don't pay much attention to edges, only noticing if all are correct or some. Because I try to follow them during the end of my F2L, this is usually not a problem. When all are correct, obviously I use the COLL case. And when either some or none are, I use the CLL algorithm. Easy cases for the ELL include most of the cases where no edges are correct, the cases where all of the edges are correct, and several cases where either two adjacent or two opposing edges are correct. This leaves something like 1/3 of the ELL cases as very easy or lucky, with the others only lagging behind a bit. If 1/3 of cases wind up as either lucky or very easy, I think this gives the method a definite shot at being competitive with other methods.

In general, I think this method also has an advantage due to incremental upgradability. For the time being, I'm using normal F2L with some partial edge control, then flipping any remaining edges, then using COLL+PLL. I think I'm going to finish learning the COLL first, followed the ELL. This will help out on solves where I still have a pair of edges to flip after the F2L. I'll learn CLL last, since it requires ELL in some cases. First, though, I'm interested in the ZBF2L cases you mentioneed. For only 25 or so more algs, most of which I would imagine to be rather short, I think that sounds like a fantastic idea. Adding those cases to the repertoire for the F2L would provide additional easy or lucky cases, and I hope it would help cancel some of the worst ELL cases, but that's only a hope. If you give me a list of the algs you think would be most useful for this, I can do some testing and see which would cancel. For the easier cases, I know a few of the OLL's, including the one you mentioned, and I use them when possible.

Thanks for the input. Now all we need is a snappy name for it...
=D

-Mike Bennett

----- Original Message -----
From: cmhardw
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, June 26, 2005 10:28 AM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: New LL strategy proposal


Hey Mike,

Thanks for your LL post, it was really interesting reading it, and my
comments are below.

First off, I would like to add one more option to your LL approach
list. I seriously doubt I will be ready to use much ZB tricks by
WC2005, but there is one idea that I think I may be ready for, and
would like to practice to see if it has any merit.

ZBF2L+OLL+PLL: 306+7+21=334

This idea has the advantage of using Fridrich PLL (very fast) and also
only the 7 OLL algs that flip corners (all VERY fast). The F2L would
of course be longer, but a lot of COLL algs are very fast and very
easy to recognize, so on the easiest cases I would still do COLL. And
of course the easiest to execute and recognize ZBLL algs as well.

I'm still doubtful of this variation, but I think it might be a better
option than COLL/PLL for me at least for WC2005. So add that the to
your list too. This can also have the variation:

Partial edge control+OLL+PLL which you already mentioned, so of course
ZBF2L is not required.

About your proposed method, I think it is a good idea. The only hard
part I see is to know , for each CLL case, which edges are flipped.
Of course just because something is hard doesn't mean you shouldn't do
it too :-D The way I see it CLL has a 1/8 chance of not only solving
corners, but flipping all edges correctly, leaving a fast edge PLL (or
a 1/12 skip).

Also I'm really starting to like COLL/PLL as well as a LL ending. The
1/12 chance of a PLL skip comes in handy, as well as the always very
fast PLL alg. So I also agree that this is a good strategy.

Personally I think this strategy is a good idea. It doesn't require a
huge number of algs, or decisions while finishing the F2L or for the
CLL/COLL step. I think delaying won't be a problem once mastered, and
the ending would be very fast too.

You may want to keep the fast OLL algs too, since Fridrich PLL is very
fast. Say if you get the oriention that looks like the T (B U L U' L'
B' to setup) then just do the OLL.

Also, one thing you may want to think about for the 4th pair are ZBF2L
algs where all edges are correctly, or incorrectly flipped. These
cases are all very easy to notice, and the algs are all very fast to
execute. It would require you to learn roughly 25 more algs, since
most standard F2L algs are the ones that preserve edge orientation.

In general flipping all edges while doing the 4th pair takes very
slightly longer than the algs for preserving edge orientation, but not
very much. So that might be something you could look into if you want
to expand that step, but otherwise I think partial edge control is enough.

I think this would be a good option for a LL technque, I mean the more
algs you know towards achieving a lucky case, the more likely you are
to get lucky. And your method has the option of CLL also orienting
all edges (and also the 1/8 * 1/12 = 1/96 chance of a 1 look LL, but
only for algs that flip edges), and COLL skipping PLL step 1/12.

If you're interested I can give you what I consider the easiest ZBF2L
cases (only about 5 or 6 or so) that are all easy to recognize and
really really short. You could add that to partial edge control and
have a better chance of ending up with oriented edges.

I say go for it, the method sounds good to me :-D

Chris

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
