1166. Re: New LL strategy proposal (fastest of the ZBF2L algs)
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 26 Jun 2005 20:53:02 -0000

Hey Mike, Here are the fastest ZBF2L algs in my opinion. This list should also include all the "standard" F2L algs, which are very fast compared to most ZBF2L algs. I inlcuded the "standard" alg with all the cases I put down here, but you really should include all of them. http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/zbf2l1.html All of these algs are fast and easy to recognize, and I think knowing all of these is a very powerful, useful tool to have in your belt so to speak. For all the algs listed below, do the inverse to set up the case: The groups are done by F2L case, so when the numbering goes back to 1, that's a new F2L case. 1) R U' R' F' U2 F 2) R U2 R' U F' U2 F 1) F' U' F U' R U2 R' 2) F' U2 F R U2 R' 3) R U' R2 F R F' 4) R U' R' U R U' R' 1) F' U F R U R' 2) R U R' U' R U R' 1) R U2 R' U' R U2 R' 1) F' L' U L F R U R' 2) (U2) R' F R F' U' F' U' F 3) (U) F2 U2 F U F' U F2 1) (U') R U2 R' U F' U' F 2) F U2 F2 U' F2 U' F' 1) F' L' B' U B L F 2) R U' R' U2 F' U' F 1) R U R2 F R F2 U' F 2) (U) F' U F U' F' U' F 1) R U R' F' U' F 2) F' L F' L' F2 (THE fastest ZBF2L alg, other than RUR') 3) F' U' F U' F' U F 1) F' U2 F2 R' F' R 2) F' U2 F U' F' U F 1) (U) R U' R' U F' U' F 2) (U') F' U' F U' F' U' F 1) L F' R' F R F L' 2) (U2) F' U' F U F' U2 F http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/zbf2l13.html These are all fairly intuitive, and don't require memorizing for each alg, but rather just the patterns seen in each case. These are optional though. So total count is 23 if you learn all the ones from the zbf2l1.html page as well as the individual ones I listed. If you learn the optional ones on zbf2l13.html it's an additional 7 (you already know one of the 8 cases as the "standard" F2L case). So 23 algs that are all very fast, or if you want the additional 7 it is 30 overall. The cases on zbf2l13.html aren't really among the fastest cases, but they all follow a similar pattern, and you can quickly learn how to do all 8 cases once you find the pattern. Hope this helps, Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Thanks for reading the post. It took me entirely too long to write, seeing as it was 1 in the morning here. > > I definitely thought about that one, but forgot to add it. 306+57+21=384 cases. (The last pair could be solved for you, leaving you with any OLL case) > > I only know a small portion of the CLL and a slightly larger chunk of the COLL. Still, even using the basic approach of a 3 look LL (2 look OLL+1 look PLL), it's easy to recognize the cases I know. When I look at the corner orientation, I really don't pay much attention to edges, only noticing if all are correct or some. Because I try to follow them during the end of my F2L, this is usually not a problem. When all are correct, obviously I use the COLL case. And when either some or none are, I use the CLL algorithm. Easy cases for the ELL include most of the cases where no edges are correct, the cases where all of the edges are correct, and several cases where either two adjacent or two opposing edges are correct. This leaves something like 1/3 of the ELL cases as very easy or lucky, with the others only lagging behind a bit. If 1/3 of cases wind up as either lucky or very easy, I think this gives the method a definite shot at being competitive with other methods. > > In general, I think this method also has an advantage due to incremental upgradability. For the time being, I'm using normal F2L with some partial edge control, then flipping any remaining edges, then using COLL+PLL. I think I'm going to finish learning the COLL first, followed the ELL. This will help out on solves where I still have a pair of edges to flip after the F2L. I'll learn CLL last, since it requires ELL in some cases. First, though, I'm interested in the ZBF2L cases you mentioneed. For only 25 or so more algs, most of which I would imagine to be rather short, I think that sounds like a fantastic idea. Adding those cases to the repertoire for the F2L would provide additional easy or lucky cases, and I hope it would help cancel some of the worst ELL cases, but that's only a hope. If you give me a list of the algs you think would be most useful for this, I can do some testing and see which would cancel. For the easier cases, I know a few of the OLL's, including the one you mentioned, and I use them when possible. > > Thanks for the input. Now all we need is a snappy name for it... > =D > > -Mike Bennett > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: cmhardw > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Sunday, June 26, 2005 10:28 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: New LL strategy proposal > > > Hey Mike, > > Thanks for your LL post, it was really interesting reading it, and my > comments are below. > > First off, I would like to add one more option to your LL approach > list. I seriously doubt I will be ready to use much ZB tricks by > WC2005, but there is one idea that I think I may be ready for, and > would like to practice to see if it has any merit. > > ZBF2L+OLL+PLL: 306+7+21=334 > > This idea has the advantage of using Fridrich PLL (very fast) and also > only the 7 OLL algs that flip corners (all VERY fast). The F2L would > of course be longer, but a lot of COLL algs are very fast and very > easy to recognize, so on the easiest cases I would still do COLL. And > of course the easiest to execute and recognize ZBLL algs as well. > > I'm still doubtful of this variation, but I think it might be a better > option than COLL/PLL for me at least for WC2005. So add that the to > your list too. This can also have the variation: > > Partial edge control+OLL+PLL which you already mentioned, so of course > ZBF2L is not required. > > About your proposed method, I think it is a good idea. The only hard > part I see is to know , for each CLL case, which edges are flipped. > Of course just because something is hard doesn't mean you shouldn't do > it too :-D The way I see it CLL has a 1/8 chance of not only solving > corners, but flipping all edges correctly, leaving a fast edge PLL (or > a 1/12 skip). > > Also I'm really starting to like COLL/PLL as well as a LL ending. The > 1/12 chance of a PLL skip comes in handy, as well as the always very > fast PLL alg. So I also agree that this is a good strategy. > > Personally I think this strategy is a good idea. It doesn't require a > huge number of algs, or decisions while finishing the F2L or for the > CLL/COLL step. I think delaying won't be a problem once mastered, and > the ending would be very fast too. > > You may want to keep the fast OLL algs too, since Fridrich PLL is very > fast. Say if you get the oriention that looks like the T (B U L U' L' > B' to setup) then just do the OLL. > > Also, one thing you may want to think about for the 4th pair are ZBF2L > algs where all edges are correctly, or incorrectly flipped. These > cases are all very easy to notice, and the algs are all very fast to > execute. It would require you to learn roughly 25 more algs, since > most standard F2L algs are the ones that preserve edge orientation. > > In general flipping all edges while doing the 4th pair takes very > slightly longer than the algs for preserving edge orientation, but not > very much. So that might be something you could look into if you want > to expand that step, but otherwise I think partial edge control is enough. > > I think this would be a good option for a LL technque, I mean the more > algs you know towards achieving a lucky case, the more likely you are > to get lucky. And your method has the option of CLL also orienting > all edges (and also the 1/8 * 1/12 = 1/96 chance of a 1 look LL, but > only for algs that flip edges), and COLL skipping PLL step 1/12. > > If you're interested I can give you what I consider the easiest ZBF2L > cases (only about 5 or 6 or so) that are all easy to recognize and > really really short. You could add that to partial edge control and > have a better chance of ending up with oriented edges. > > I say go for it, the method sounds good to me :-D > > Chris > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

1169. website design
From: "Evan" <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 26 Jun 2005 22:20:03 -0000

Hey everyone,

I'm moving my website, so I figured I might as well redesign while I'm
at it. The main question I have is whether people prefer a frame for
navigation, the way that speedcubing.com is, and the way my site is
now, or just links on the top or side of each page for navigation,
that aren't a seperate frame. There are the pros and cons of both, so
I just wanted to know what people thought. And anything else you'd
like to say, tips, constructive criticism (about the site, not my
spelling ;-) ) would be greatly appreciated.

-Evan

Until next time, Happy Cubing
http://www.deepcube.tk

1173. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New LL strategy proposal
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 27 Jun 2005 08:13:05 +0100

Hi Chris/Mike I havent really been following this because I dont have experience on COLL and all those things. However your (Chris') point about Fridrich PLL and the 7 corner flips in OLL is exactly the LL situation I solve when I use my L2L1 strategy and I can vouch for how fast abnd easily recognisable it is. Im not sure how the other L2L strategies compare with what Mike is proposing. They use less algorithms but as they dont use CE pairs so much they are probably a little less efficient on the F2L. Nevertheless you might find something useful in there! Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "cmhardw" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Sunday, June 26, 2005 4:28 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: New LL strategy proposal > Hey Mike, > > Thanks for your LL post, it was really interesting reading it, and my > comments are below. > > First off, I would like to add one more option to your LL approach > list. I seriously doubt I will be ready to use much ZB tricks by > WC2005, but there is one idea that I think I may be ready for, and > would like to practice to see if it has any merit. > > ZBF2L+OLL+PLL: 306+7+21=334 > > This idea has the advantage of using Fridrich PLL (very fast) and also > only the 7 OLL algs that flip corners (all VERY fast). The F2L would > of course be longer, but a lot of COLL algs are very fast and very > easy to recognize, so on the easiest cases I would still do COLL. And > of course the easiest to execute and recognize ZBLL algs as well. > > I'm still doubtful of this variation, but I think it might be a better > option than COLL/PLL for me at least for WC2005. So add that the to > your list too. This can also have the variation: > > Partial edge control+OLL+PLL which you already mentioned, so of course > ZBF2L is not required. > > About your proposed method, I think it is a good idea. The only hard > part I see is to know , for each CLL case, which edges are flipped. > Of course just because something is hard doesn't mean you shouldn't do > it too :-D The way I see it CLL has a 1/8 chance of not only solving > corners, but flipping all edges correctly, leaving a fast edge PLL (or > a 1/12 skip). > > Also I'm really starting to like COLL/PLL as well as a LL ending. The > 1/12 chance of a PLL skip comes in handy, as well as the always very > fast PLL alg. So I also agree that this is a good strategy. > > Personally I think this strategy is a good idea. It doesn't require a > huge number of algs, or decisions while finishing the F2L or for the > CLL/COLL step. I think delaying won't be a problem once mastered, and > the ending would be very fast too. > > You may want to keep the fast OLL algs too, since Fridrich PLL is very > fast. Say if you get the oriention that looks like the T (B U L U' L' > B' to setup) then just do the OLL. > > Also, one thing you may want to think about for the 4th pair are ZBF2L > algs where all edges are correctly, or incorrectly flipped. These > cases are all very easy to notice, and the algs are all very fast to > execute. It would require you to learn roughly 25 more algs, since > most standard F2L algs are the ones that preserve edge orientation. > > In general flipping all edges while doing the 4th pair takes very > slightly longer than the algs for preserving edge orientation, but not > very much. So that might be something you could look into if you want > to expand that step, but otherwise I think partial edge control is enough. > > I think this would be a good option for a LL technque, I mean the more > algs you know towards achieving a lucky case, the more likely you are > to get lucky. And your method has the option of CLL also orienting > all edges (and also the 1/8 * 1/12 = 1/96 chance of a 1 look LL, but > only for algs that flip edges), and COLL skipping PLL step 1/12. > > If you're interested I can give you what I consider the easiest ZBF2L > cases (only about 5 or 6 or so) that are all easy to recognize and > really really short. You could add that to partial edge control and > have a better chance of ending up with oriented edges. > > I say go for it, the method sounds good to me :-D > > Chris > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" > <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > I've been doing a lot of serious pondering concerning last layer > methods recently, since my job now affords me the time. I have a > couple of observations and would like to pose a few questions, as well > as a strategy I feel might be worth consideration. Apologies if > anyone has come up with this before, but I've not heard of this, so > I'm currently assuming I'm the only one. Yay me. =D > > > > First off, I know that Macky uses partial edge control during the > F2L. I also know that Chris Hardwick and others are using ZBF2L. I > understand this is a good way to cut down on your LL and recognization > times, while only increasing your F2L times by a smaller amount. I > also know most of the people doing this are using either a 2 or 3 look > approach to follow it, with either OLL+PLL, COLL+PLL, or what have > you. I don't think ZB is a realistic approach for most of us (sane > cubers ;D). This can make for fast times in either case, but I think > it can be improved upon, without resorting to ZBLL (for those of us > who are far too lazy, such as myself). > > > > I started learning the Roux method a while back, and managed some > relative success with it, despite doing corners in two looks, and not > learning the 26 special optimization cases or any of the fun tricks. > I managed times in the low 20's, and was slightly faster than my 3 and > 4 look LBL method at the time. This is where I began to consider CLL > and COLL based strategies as competitive. I've since learned most of > the PLL and some more tricks, and have been neglecting my Roux > practicing lately. I decided to learn the CLL+ELL, both to help > prevent me from being a basic Fridrich clone, and to help me with my > occasional Roux solving. It also helps for 2x2x2, apparently, because > I took my first averages for it yesterday, and managed a couple of > 5.xx and few 6.xx solves. > > > > What if someone were to comprise a method using basic F2L with > partial edge control only when the case is easy? This would cut down > on how much your F2L would be slowed down, at least on average. You > would of course need ELL algorithms to be able to finish in most > cases, then. Next, if the method included both COLL algs and CLL algs > that flip edges, you would have much better odds of obtaining a lucky > case for your ELL step, often rendering it a simple edge only PLL. In > the worst cases, you'd still wind up with only slightly longer LL > times because of the comparison of ELL against pure edge PLL, but I > think you'd make that up in time saved on the F2L and through lucky cases. > > > > As near as I can tell on my extremely quick number crunching, here > are the approximate algorithm requirements for various last layer > strategies: > > OLL+PLL: 57+21=78 > > Partial Edge Control+OLL+PLL: 8+7 to 57+21=36 to 86 > > CLL+ELL: 40+29=69 > > EOLL+COLL+PLL: 2+40+4=46 > > Partial Edge Control+COLL+PLL: 8+40+4=52 > > ZBF2L+COLL+PLL: 306+40+4=350 (or fewer; I'm > not certain) > > ZBF2L+ZBLL: 306+493=799 > > Proposed method: 8+40+40+29=117 > > (partial edge control+C/COLL+ELL/PLL) > > > > If you discount reflections, most of these numbers will be less. > The total number of algs for the proposed method would be cut down to > something like 8+24+24+19=75, giving it an small fraction of the > algorithms necessary for anything ZB, but with the added advantage of > more lucky scenarios and easy recognition on the each of the cases for > corners. All you would have to distinguish above and beyond either > the CLL or COLL case to perform would be which of those to use, > depending on the number of correctly oriented edges, and whether or > not you want to flip any. It seems at first glance, that if you > double the number of algorithms in your repertoire like this, you can > effectively double the number of lucky situations you can achieve. > > > > I'm interested to hear what everyone thinks, and definitely what > anyone who already uses a CLL or COLL approach thinks, especially as a > viable alternative to ZBLL for most of us (I'm looking at you, Chris > Hardwick), so if you have any thoughts or suggestions, fire away. > > > > -Mike 'putting way too much effort into this post' Bennett > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >
1174. Re: center cap pop question
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 27 Jun 2005 08:06:26 -0000

Hmmm ... U had 2 replies already. Non of them answered ut question ;-) I would say that as long as u can see that the centers are correctly solved it should be counted as solved (if the rest is also solved). This will of coz be at the judge discretion. But shouldn't be any problem unless too many center caps pop at same time :-o And yes, glue them down. It's enough to use superglue along one edge only. U can also cut out the inner plastic support bridges. Well at least my diy cube centercaps had those. But they were obstructed by the screws so i had to remove them ... Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bruce Wayne" <drteeth@o...> wrote: > i just got the rubiks diy kit and my center caps pop off sometime > while solving...if this were to happen during a tournament would the > cube be counted as solved if a center cap pops? > -Justin Medoy
1175. Re: center cap pop question
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 27 Jun 2005 10:47:15 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > I would say that as long as u can see that the centers are correctly > solved it should be counted as solved (if the rest is also solved). Surely yes. Isn't that in the WCA rules? > And yes, glue them down. It's enough to use superglue along one edge > only. U can also cut out the inner plastic support bridges. Not keen on superglue myself. Even with a small amount on one ridge, the ridge can break when removing the cap. Currently I make one or two cuts across the ridge using a sharp knife. Like Ton's "hammer method", this deforms the ridge sufficiently to keep the cap in place. Or you could try Stefan's paper crosses to wedge the caps in place. Mike
1176. Re: center cap pop question
From: "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 27 Jun 2005 11:48:44 -0000

With my DIY cube, I didn't use any kind of glue and i didn't use the "hammer method" : i just pushed all the centers and i never had any problem. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > I would say that as long as u can see that the centers are correctly > > solved it should be counted as solved (if the rest is also solved). > > Surely yes. Isn't that in the WCA rules? > > > And yes, glue them down. It's enough to use superglue along one edge > > only. U can also cut out the inner plastic support bridges. > > Not keen on superglue myself. Even with a small amount on one ridge, > the ridge can break when removing the cap. Currently I make one or two > cuts across the ridge using a sharp knife. Like Ton's "hammer method", > this deforms the ridge sufficiently to keep the cap in place. > > Or you could try Stefan's paper crosses to wedge the caps in place. > > Mike
1177. Re: New LL strategy proposal
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 27 Jun 2005 12:09:43 -0000

If I understand correctly, what you propose is: (1) Take care of last-layer edges orientation while solving the last pair, only if it's very fast. (2) Solve last layer corners before edges, using sequences that do not flip edges only if they're already correctly oriented thanks to (1). (3) Solve last layer edges, using mostly PLL sequences. What I think about it: (1) I'm not a F2L/OLL solver, but it looks like a good idea. I think a lot of Fridrich users try to do this, at least to avoid OLL cases with 4 misoriented edges. (2) Why not! The CLL and COLL sets have a lot in common. And you can ask Masayuki Akimoto, I think one of his goals last year was to find CLL sequences that solve edges orientation too. (3) That's where I disagree. Unfortunately, permuting oriented edges is not always faster than some other ELL cases. Take M'UMU2M'UM for example, or R'U'RUMU'R'Ur. They are VERY fast and frequent. (plus I feel a bit stupid when I have to 3-cycle edges of a side, it's much faster to 3-cycle edges of an inner slice with U2M'U2 :-) ) In my opinion, the keys to faster solving are: 1) Learn a basic method perfectly. Train a lot, anticipate, practice fingers and mental dexterity, etc. 2) Multi-experts optimizations, or dynamic hybrid methods. Try to maximize lucky cases by choosing a technique or another. When the "method R3a-Z expert" in your head yells "Hey! This case is for me, I know that if you follow me, the chances for you to finish this cube fast are quite good!", listen to him. That's what you propose, and I totally agree with you. That's what I'm doing with the last 6 edges and 4 centers: Method 2 if I don't want to think at all, methods 1+3 tricks when there's an obvious shortcut that can be detected fast, and sometimes ELL when the F2L are already solved. If at a given point of a solve you're given to choose between 2 possibilities, choose the one that is statistically the most powerful. But mixing different methods in real time is not easy. The criteria that will tell you to choose one way or another have to be very simple, because every step must be anticipated while executing/finishing the previous step. If you can't anticipate enough, you can't ready your fingers, and since we're trying to optimize for a few 1/10s it's often much easier to loose time. *IDEA* We could draw a graph of all methods and variations, that would tell you, step by step, what your choices are and how to decide. 3) Learn a lot of magical sequences. I don't believe in learning hundreds of cases to solve LL corners + permute edges. Since Lars or others introduced this idea, I've never understood why it makes people so excited (but it's fine if other people like this idea and have fun looking for all these sequences, I hope they'll prove me wrong -- Chris ;-) ). Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > I've been doing a lot of serious pondering concerning last layer methods recently, since my job now affords me the time. I have a couple of observations and would like to pose a few questions, as well as a strategy I feel might be worth consideration. Apologies if anyone has come up with this before, but I've not heard of this, so I'm currently assuming I'm the only one. Yay me. =D > > First off, I know that Macky uses partial edge control during the F2L. I also know that Chris Hardwick and others are using ZBF2L. I understand this is a good way to cut down on your LL and recognization times, while only increasing your F2L times by a smaller amount. I also know most of the people doing this are using either a 2 or 3 look approach to follow it, with either OLL+PLL, COLL+PLL, or what have you. I don't think ZB is a realistic approach for most of us (sane cubers ;D). This can make for fast times in either case, but I think it can be improved upon, without resorting to ZBLL (for those of us who are far too lazy, such as myself). > > I started learning the Roux method a while back, and managed some relative success with it, despite doing corners in two looks, and not learning the 26 special optimization cases or any of the fun tricks. I managed times in the low 20's, and was slightly faster than my 3 and 4 look LBL method at the time. This is where I began to consider CLL and COLL based strategies as competitive. I've since learned most of the PLL and some more tricks, and have been neglecting my Roux practicing lately. I decided to learn the CLL+ELL, both to help prevent me from being a basic Fridrich clone, and to help me with my occasional Roux solving. It also helps for 2x2x2, apparently, because I took my first averages for it yesterday, and managed a couple of 5.xx and few 6.xx solves. > > What if someone were to comprise a method using basic F2L with partial edge control only when the case is easy? This would cut down on how much your F2L would be slowed down, at least on average. You would of course need ELL algorithms to be able to finish in most cases, then. Next, if the method included both COLL algs and CLL algs that flip edges, you would have much better odds of obtaining a lucky case for your ELL step, often rendering it a simple edge only PLL. In the worst cases, you'd still wind up with only slightly longer LL times because of the comparison of ELL against pure edge PLL, but I think you'd make that up in time saved on the F2L and through lucky cases. > > As near as I can tell on my extremely quick number crunching, here are the approximate algorithm requirements for various last layer strategies: > OLL+PLL: 57+21=78 > Partial Edge Control+OLL+PLL: 8+7 to 57+21=36 to 86 > CLL+ELL: 40+29=69 > EOLL+COLL+PLL: 2+40+4=46 > Partial Edge Control+COLL+PLL: 8+40+4=52 > ZBF2L+COLL+PLL: 306+40+4=350 (or fewer; I'm not certain) > ZBF2L+ZBLL: 306+493=799 > Proposed method: 8+40+40+29=117 > (partial edge control+C/COLL+ELL/PLL) > > If you discount reflections, most of these numbers will be less. The total number of algs for the proposed method would be cut down to something like 8+24+24+19=75, giving it an small fraction of the algorithms necessary for anything ZB, but with the added advantage of more lucky scenarios and easy recognition on the each of the cases for corners. All you would have to distinguish above and beyond either the CLL or COLL case to perform would be which of those to use, depending on the number of correctly oriented edges, and whether or not you want to flip any. It seems at first glance, that if you double the number of algorithms in your repertoire like this, you can effectively double the number of lucky situations you can achieve. > > I'm interested to hear what everyone thinks, and definitely what anyone who already uses a CLL or COLL approach thinks, especially as a viable alternative to ZBLL for most of us (I'm looking at you, Chris Hardwick), so if you have any thoughts or suggestions, fire away. > > -Mike 'putting way too much effort into this post' Bennett > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1178. Re: center cap pop question
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 27 Jun 2005 13:25:45 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > Not keen on superglue myself. Even with a small amount on one ridge, > the ridge can break when removing the cap. Currently I make one or two > cuts across the ridge using a sharp knife. Like Ton's "hammer method", > this deforms the ridge sufficiently to keep the cap in place. Thanks, after three superglue people I almost thought I'm the only one who doesn't like superglue ;-) In my two black DIYs so far I've made little "cuts", too. Next time I'll try paper, though I know it won't be as easy as with Studio cubes... Stefan

day to the man who has drained years from my life because of his
invention, while at the same time provided years of joy and mental
challenges. We should send him a gift... maybe some cubes? :)

1187. Swedish Championship 2005
From: "al_yyz" <anders.larsson@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 27 Jun 2005 19:00:20 -0000

Hi all! We have started the planning of the Swedish Championship 2005. The dates are 10-11 September. We intend to have "noncommon" events (pyraminx, magic, no preinspection....) during the first day and the main events (3x3x3, 4x4x4... speedsolving) during the second day. The exact events and division between the two days will be decided upon later. The venue is still to be decided, but it will be in the city of Stockholm. SveKub <www.svekub.se> is the organiser and I will be the main contact person at present. We will have an open championship, thus allowing non-Swedes to participate. /Anders

1193. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Sunday Contest prizes
From: "Peter Douthwright" <pdouthwright0513@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 27 Jun 2005 17:05:18 -0400

I am one of those who regularly participates in the Sunday Contest and probably will not get a prize ever. but with practices who knows.

My idea, to encourage participation, is three fold:

1) Make it a draw

2) Make the winner ineligible for N tries( 6 is a good as any). This means that the winner is ineligible to win for 6 attempts.

3)If possible for every week you try, you get an additional entry into the draw. If you try for 10 weeks in a row you would get 10 "tickets" in the draw.


How does this sound?

Peter Douthwright


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

1195. RE: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 method :-)
From: "James Stuber" <jestuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 27 Jun 2005 15:56:06 -0700

How about this: 1) 1x3x4 block 2)1x3x4 block on opposite side (like gilles roux's 3x3x3 method) 3)Pair up edges using r, l, and U until 3 edges are left 4)pair up last 3 edges with a 3 cycle 5) Orient edges and fix flip parity 6) last corners 7) solve edges and fix swap parity 8)solve last 4 centers. I'm not sure step 3-7 is the fastest way to go about with a start like this. Perhaps solving edges directly with 3 edge cycles might be faster. I can't tell whether or not it would be good for speedcubing simply because I take so long to do step 4 and 8 ( I only know a 2 center cycle and the two center algs Per gave below...). Any ideas? _____ From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Per Kristen Fredlund Sent: Wednesday, June 22, 2005 5:21 AM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 method :-) Hi James :-) For the 4x4x4 revenge/master cube i use the same system as i do for the 5x5x5 wahn/professor cube. The basic steps are as follows: (I call this the "Cage" method. ) 1. Do first layer completely. This is intuitive. If some centers are "tricky" to solve they can be left for later if so desired. basically i solve the cubies in the order i see them. Cubies that make up blocks are inserted into first layer as a block also, when possible. 2. (First twist the middle layers into favorable positions. U can get quite a few edges and/or centers for free by doing this.) Now do middle layers edges. This is done by and large with commutator 3- cycles. Also here one can cycle blocks of cubies when solving them. Either to solve several edges at the same time or remove badly placed edges (move to final layer where i do most of the "fishing") or move bad edges to a better position within the middle layers. 3. Final layer corners. First position them (only 2 algs needed) then orient them (there are 6 easy cases for this). 4. Now solve all last layer edges with 3-cycles. This is perhaps the most tricky step. I use easy commutator 3-cycles with very few setup moves. In fact the setup is never more than 1 single move. The most difficult thing about this is to recognize which 3-cycle to do next. I normally look for 3-cycles that will solve 2 edges with same 3-cycle. So i do a quick "scan" tracking the edges and see if that is possible. If not i just settle for a 3-cycle solving 1 edge only. There is of coz the parity which means im left with only 2 edges to swap. This is fairly easy also. This is fixed with an inner slice turn and a edge 3- cycle on this layer. In most cases some setup moves are needed (at most 2 moves). Remember that it doesn't matter that my parity fix will mess w the centers. With some luck block 3-cycles can also be used efficiently. 5. Do all the remaining centers with yet more 3-cycles. Block cycles where possible. With practice u can achieve good cancellations btw 2 succesive 3-cycles : (simple example) r'urUr'u'd'rU'r'dr - 4 moves are cancelled. There are also some other center-algs that works on oppsite faces. One example : (r2b2)*2 Benefits of this method are: - U solve the cubies into their home position all the time. There is no tricky parts where u just solve cubies relative to eachother like when pairing up edgesw Chris' method. - Doing lots of 3-cycle it's easy to foresee where all pieces are going so u get excellent lookahead and very good flow in ur solves most of the time. - Mistakes u do early are not so fatal. There is usually easy fix for simple mistakes. - U don't rely on a fast 3x3x3 method to do the last stage for u. My method has no "3x3x3-stage" at all. - Only one parity, not two. One disadvantage is that i probably need about 25% more moves as compared w Chris' method. So u really have to be a grandmaster of commutator 3-cycles and utilise block cycling as much as u can. And u need to make sure u get a good flow. A typical solve for me goes like this : - (15 secs) First layer done - (30 secs) Middle layer edges done - (50-55 secs) Last layer done - (70-75 secs) All centers are done. Cube is SOLVED!! That's it for the 4x4x4 method. The 5x5x5 method has a few more special cases. A list of these: - Make sure while orienting the middle layers after solving first layer that the extreme middle layer is twisted such that the middle centers end up in correct location. So u are can actually only twist 2 of the 3 middle layers freely. Umm u can choose to willingly set up the 4-spot pattern. But i never do that. - For last layer edges i would do the middle edges first. This is actually a separate step since u can't mix middle edges and outer edges. Doing the middle ones first gives easier recognition for solving the outer edges. - There are more special algs for exchanging centers between opposite faces. Example : (r2 E2)*2 or (Ff) r'u'r U r'u r U' (Ff)' Writing down these details make it cound more complicated then it really is ;-) Cheers! -Per _____ Yahoo! Groups Links * To visit your group on the web, go to: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ * To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com <mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscri be> * Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/> Terms of Service. [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1196. Re: [Speed cubing group] website design
From: Bryant Tran <bmtran@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 27 Jun 2005 19:00:06 -0500

I have to agree with James. Frames are also just not as aesthetically pleasing as a simple repetitive layout. I tend to favor websites that don't use frames. --Bryant On 6/27/05, James Stuber <jestuber@...> wrote: > > Don't use frames, they're annoying if you want to link to a specific > page. > > > > _____ > > From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Evan > Sent: Sunday, June 26, 2005 3:20 PM > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Subject: [Speed cubing group] website design > > > > Hey everyone, > > I'm moving my website, so I figured I might as well redesign while I'm > at it. The main question I have is whether people prefer a frame for > navigation, the way that speedcubing.com <http://speedcubing.com> is, and > the way my site is > now, or just links on the top or side of each page for navigation, > that aren't a seperate frame. There are the pros and cons of both, so > I just wanted to know what people thought. And anything else you'd > like to say, tips, constructive criticism (about the site, not my > spelling ;-) ) would be greatly appreciated. > > -Evan > > Until next time, Happy Cubing > http://www.deepcube.tk > > > > > > _____ > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > * To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > * To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > <mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > ?subject=Unsubscri > be> > > * Your use of Yahoo! 1197. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 method :-)
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 00:19:43 -0000

Hi James, I've got the same 1st, 2nd and 8th steps :-) The rest differs: a) Build two 1x3x4 L/R-blocks - 55 b) Finish L/R-sides (4 edge pieces) - 75 c) Solve M (L+r) edges (8 pieces) - 95 d) Solve M centers (16 pieces) - 130 No parity problems, that's the good point of "centers-last". It averages 130 moves, but my technique is rather basic. For example, I don't use complicated sequences in c), only a simple one: U2rU2. In d) I'm sure you can optimize much more than I do. I'm not a big 4^3 fan and my best average is 84 secs. But I think such a technique is slower than the "standard" way (pairing up edges). Because there are many slice moves. Did you try: 6) corners, and then 5+7) solve edges and fix parity problems Are parity fixing sequences much shorter when you don't have to preserve some centers? GIlles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "James Stuber" <jestuber@v...> wrote: > How about this: > > > > 1) 1x3x4 block > > 2)1x3x4 block on opposite side (like gilles roux's 3x3x3 method) > > 3)Pair up edges using r, l, and U until 3 edges are left > > 4)pair up last 3 edges with a 3 cycle > > 5) Orient edges and fix flip parity > > 6) last corners > > 7) solve edges and fix swap parity > > 8)solve last 4 centers. > > > > > > I'm not sure step 3-7 is the fastest way to go about with a start like this. > Perhaps solving edges directly with 3 edge cycles might be faster. I can't > tell whether or not it would be good for speedcubing simply because I take > so long to do step 4 and 8 ( I only know a 2 center cycle and the two center > algs Per gave below...). Any ideas? > > > > > > _____ > > From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Per Kristen > Fredlund > Sent: Wednesday, June 22, 2005 5:21 AM > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Subject: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 method :-) > > > > Hi James :-) > > For the 4x4x4 revenge/master cube i use the same system as i do for > the 5x5x5 wahn/professor cube. > > The basic steps are as follows: > > (I call this the "Cage" method. ) > > 1. Do first layer completely. This is intuitive. If some centers > are "tricky" to solve they can be left for later if so desired. > basically i solve the cubies in the order i see them. Cubies that make > up blocks are inserted into first layer as a block also, when possible. > > 2. (First twist the middle layers into favorable positions. U can get > quite a few edges and/or centers for free by doing this.) Now do > middle layers edges. This is done by and large with commutator 3- > cycles. Also here one can cycle blocks of cubies when solving them. > Either to solve several edges at the same time or remove badly placed > edges (move to final layer where i do most of the "fishing") or move > bad edges to a better position within the middle layers. > > 3. Final layer corners. First position them (only 2 algs needed) then > orient them (there are 6 easy cases for this). > > 4. Now solve all last layer edges with 3-cycles. This is perhaps the > most tricky step. I use easy commutator 3-cycles with very few setup > moves. In fact the setup is never more than 1 single move. The most > difficult thing about this is to recognize which 3-cycle to do next. I > normally look for 3-cycles that will solve 2 edges with same 3-cycle. > So i do a quick "scan" tracking the edges and see if that is possible. > If not i just settle for a 3-cycle solving 1 edge only. There is of > coz the parity which means im left with only 2 edges to swap. This is > fairly easy also. This is fixed with an inner slice turn and a edge 3- > cycle on this layer. In most cases some setup moves are needed (at > most 2 moves). Remember that it doesn't matter that my parity fix will > mess w the centers. With some luck block 3-cycles can also be used > efficiently. > > 5. Do all the remaining centers with yet more 3-cycles. Block cycles > where possible. With practice u can achieve good cancellations btw 2 > succesive 3-cycles : (simple example) r'urUr'u'd'rU'r'dr - 4 moves are > cancelled. There are also some other center-algs that works on oppsite > faces. One example : (r2b2)*2 > > Benefits of this method are: > > - U solve the cubies into their home position all the time. There is > no tricky parts where u just solve cubies relative to eachother like > when pairing up edgesw Chris' method. > > - Doing lots of 3-cycle it's easy to foresee where all pieces are > going so u get excellent lookahead and very good flow in ur solves > most of the time. > > - Mistakes u do early are not so fatal. There is usually easy fix for > simple mistakes. > > - U don't rely on a fast 3x3x3 method to do the last stage for u. My > method has no "3x3x3-stage" at all. > > - Only one parity, not two. > > One disadvantage is that i probably need about 25% more moves as > compared w Chris' method. So u really have to be a grandmaster of > commutator 3-cycles and utilise block cycling as much as u can. And u > need to make sure u get a good flow. > > A typical solve for me goes like this : > > - (15 secs) First layer done > - (30 secs) Middle layer edges done > - (50-55 secs) Last layer done > - (70-75 secs) All centers are done. Cube is SOLVED!! > > That's it for the 4x4x4 method. The 5x5x5 method has a few more > special cases. A list of these: > > - Make sure while orienting the middle layers after solving first > layer that the extreme middle layer is twisted such that the middle > centers end up in correct location. So u are can actually only twist 2 > of the 3 middle layers freely. Umm u can choose to willingly set up > the 4-spot pattern. But i never do that. > > - For last layer edges i would do the middle edges first. This is > actually a separate step since u can't mix middle edges and outer > edges. Doing the middle ones first gives easier recognition for > solving the outer edges. > > - There are more special algs for exchanging centers between opposite > faces. Example : (r2 E2)*2 or (Ff) r'u'r U r'u r U' (Ff)' > > Writing down these details make it cound more complicated then it > really is ;-) > > Cheers! > > -Per > > > > > > _____ > > Yahoo! 1198. I need help with a ZBLL case
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 02:12:28 -0000

Hey everyone,

I have a fun request for everyone here. I ran into what has so far
become my slowest ZBLL case, and I can't find a fast alg for it.

So everyone do this alg on your cube from solved:
U2 B U B' U2 F U' B U' B' U B U2 F' B'

Now solve your cube. In any way you please, I don't care. Just write
down your solution and either e-mail to me
chris[nospam]@... or post it on the group.

Here's your chance to prove your method against mine :-D My record
for solving that case is 2.63 seconds, but I average about 4.00
seconds. Can you beat 4.00 seconds on average for that finish?

If your method doesn't run into this type of case at any point, please
ignore this post altogether.

So you fast people out there, can you beat me for that case? If so,
let me know! I would really like to find a fast alg for that case.

Chris

P.S. If you haven't guessed, my alg to solve that case is the inverse
of the one above :-D
P.P.S I've already messed around a bit with Acube with no success,
but if you know cool, fast move groups to try please feel free!




1199. RE: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 method :-)
From: "James Stuber" <jestuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 27 Jun 2005 19:30:22 -0700

Did you try: 6) corners, and then 5+7) solve edges and fix parity problems Are parity fixing sequences much shorter when you don't have to preserve some centers? I just use the pure edge swap and the almost pure edge flip that messes up orientation of corners. _____ From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Gilles Roux Sent: Monday, June 27, 2005 5:20 PM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 method :-) Hi James, I've got the same 1st, 2nd and 8th steps :-) The rest differs: a) Build two 1x3x4 L/R-blocks - 55 b) Finish L/R-sides (4 edge pieces) - 75 c) Solve M (L+r) edges (8 pieces) - 95 d) Solve M centers (16 pieces) - 130 No parity problems, that's the good point of "centers-last". 1200. RE: [Speed cubing group] I need help with a ZBLL case
From: "James Stuber" <jestuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 27 Jun 2005 19:37:29 -0700

Hows this: B2 D' B2 U F' U2 F B U B2 R2 D B or y R2 D' R2 U L" U2 L R U R2 F2 D R would be faster. I found this with cube explorer. _____ From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of cmhardw Sent: Monday, June 27, 2005 7:12 PM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] I need help with a ZBLL case Hey everyone, I have a fun request for everyone here. I ran into what has so far become my slowest ZBLL case, and I can't find a fast alg for it. So everyone do this alg on your cube from solved: U2 B U B' U2 F U' B U' B' U B U2 F' B' Now solve your cube. In any way you please, I don't care. Just write down your solution and either e-mail to me chris[nospam]@... or post it on the group. 1201. RE: [Speed cubing group] I need help with a ZBLL case
From: "James Stuber" <jestuber@...>

Date: Mon, 27 Jun 2005 19:49:28 -0700

Some more F' R' U' F2 U F2 R U' F' U' F2 U F2 U' Y L' F' U' L2 U L2 F U' L' U' L2 U L2 U2 _____ From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of James Stuber Sent: Monday, June 27, 2005 7:37 PM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: RE: [Speed cubing group] I need help with a ZBLL case Hows this: B2 D' B2 U F' U2 F B U B2 R2 D B or y R2 D' R2 U L" U2 L R U R2 F2 D R would be faster. 1202. Re: I need help with a ZBLL case
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 02:48:07 -0000

Um... I just do the COLL followed by a three-cycle. It takes me about 4.25s. (4.23, 4.04, 4.54 4.43, 3.81, 4.54, ...) It's becuase this particular COLL is really short and fast for me. I do it this way: [u'] L'B'RBLB'R'B - [u] R'UR'U'R'U'R'URUR2', where the last turn of the first part cnacels out with the first turn of the second part and can thus be omitted. Hopefully people understand my notation ([u'] = y'). -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I have a fun request for everyone here. I ran into what has so far > become my slowest ZBLL case, and I can't find a fast alg for it. > > So everyone do this alg on your cube from solved: > U2 B U B' U2 F U' B U' B' U B U2 F' B' > > Now solve your cube. In any way you please, I don't care. Just write > down your solution and either e-mail to me > chris[nospam]@... or post it on the group. > > Here's your chance to prove your method against mine :-D My record > for solving that case is 2.63 seconds, but I average about 4.00 > seconds. Can you beat 4.00 seconds on average for that finish? > > If your method doesn't run into this type of case at any point, please > ignore this post altogether. > > So you fast people out there, can you beat me for that case? If so, > let me know! I would really like to find a fast alg for that case. > > Chris > > P.S. If you haven't guessed, my alg to solve that case is the inverse > of the one above :-D > P.P.S I've already messed around a bit with Acube with no success, > but if you know cool, fast move groups to try please feel free!
1203. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: I need help with a ZBLL case
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 00:21:17 -0500

Hi, Chris. In return for your advice on my developing method, here's a little feedback for you. =D I played around with a few things, and then settled on my approach, which is the COLL alg, followed by the edge 3 cycle. I do it like this: B' R'FR B R'F'R y2 M2U'M U2 MU' M2 But it might help to either look at it like this: x D'R'UR D R'U'l y2 M2U'M U2 MU' M2 Performing it like that, after ten or so practice tries, I took an average and wound up at 3.91 seconds. Since I'm too lazy, that's how I do it. To make it a single alg, however, I'd eliminate the y2 turn by just doing the 3 cycle from the other side. The biggest factor slowing down this alg the way I do it is the rotation. If you eliminate this, I'm sure you could do much better. Try B' R'FR B R'F'R M2U'M' U2 M'U' M2. Happy learning too many algorithms for a new method in hopes of becoming only a few seconds faster! ;D -Mike Bennett --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I have a fun request for everyone here. I ran into what has so far > become my slowest ZBLL case, and I can't find a fast alg for it. > > So everyone do this alg on your cube from solved: > U2 B U B' U2 F U' B U' B' U B U2 F' B' > > Now solve your cube. In any way you please, I don't care. Just write > down your solution and either e-mail to me > chris[nospam]@... or post it on the group. > > Here's your chance to prove your method against mine :-D My record > for solving that case is 2.63 seconds, but I average about 4.00 > seconds. Can you beat 4.00 seconds on average for that finish? > > If your method doesn't run into this type of case at any point, please > ignore this post altogether. > > So you fast people out there, can you beat me for that case? If so, > let me know! I would really like to find a fast alg for that case. > > Chris > > P.S. If you haven't guessed, my alg to solve that case is the inverse > of the one above :-D > P.P.S I've already messed around a bit with Acube with no success, > but if you know cool, fast move groups to try please feel free! -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- YAHOO! 1204. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New LL strategy proposal
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 01:04:30 -0500

Yep. You're correct. I'm nuts. ; )

But in regards to (3), I'm not sure you're correct. Like you mentioned down there, permuting edges within a slice may be ever so slightly faster, but I don't think the PLL's are all that slow. I just tried an average of a slice 3 cycle against a normal 3 cycle, and the slice 3 cycle was only .2 seconds faster. Also, The PLL's are slightly easier to recognize, because you only have to pay attention to placement, not placement and orientation. In regards to the ELL case you mentioned, that's almost exactly how I perform the 3 cycle. Just change the first and last M'/M to M2.

I agree with your position, as noted on your site, that algorithms involving M and U turns are very fast. All of the ELL's I use are of that variety for the same reason. My brain thinks in terms of slice moves well, and they just feel right.

I also disagree with your position that mixing methods in real time is very difficult or detrimental. It just takes practice. Especially at the start of my solves, I try to be ambigous about methods. The more methods you are familiar and comfortable with, the more chances you have for lucky cases. If I see an easy start with your method, I use it. I also employ lots of blocks and every once in a great while an extended cross. My times have only benefited from this, as near as I can tell.

As for last layer method ambiguity, it's also really not that hard. To distinguish between using the CLL and COLL case, you really only have to know whether or not you managed to solve all of the edges during the last F2L pair, which I try to keep track of anyhow. You don't necessarily need to know which specific edges or how many are flipped. You just need to know that some are or none are. My reaction times are already fairly low for the few cases I already know. I anticipate they will improve with practice.

And happily, the cases aren't really as numerous as they appear. There are 24 CLL+reflections (which I learn simultaneously, so they really seem like a single case to me). It's the same number for COLL. There are only 19 or 20 distinct cases for ELL, 3 of which are the PLL cases. That leaves 24+24+16=64 cases+whatever optional junk you feel like throwing in. It's not a beginner method, by any means, but it seems to me to be the logical next step from either COLL+PLL or CLL+ELL. Of course, I know of a certain 'simple' method that uses 24 corner cases+9 edge algs+26 special edge cases=59, so for the extra 6, I think I'll be in a similar boat. ;D

-Mike Bennett


----- Original Message -----
From: Gilles Roux
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, June 27, 2005 7:09 AM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: New LL strategy proposal


If I understand correctly, what you propose is:

(1) Take care of last-layer edges orientation while solving the last
pair, only if it's very fast.
(2) Solve last layer corners before edges, using sequences that do not
flip edges only if they're already correctly oriented thanks to (1).
(3) Solve last layer edges, using mostly PLL sequences.

What I think about it:

(1) I'm not a F2L/OLL solver, but it looks like a good idea. I think a
lot of Fridrich users try to do this, at least to avoid OLL cases with
4 misoriented edges.
(2) Why not! The CLL and COLL sets have a lot in common. And you can
ask Masayuki Akimoto, I think one of his goals last year was to find
CLL sequences that solve edges orientation too.
(3) That's where I disagree. Unfortunately, permuting oriented edges
is not always faster than some other ELL cases. Take M'UMU2M'UM for
example, or R'U'RUMU'R'Ur. They are VERY fast and frequent. (plus I
feel a bit stupid when I have to 3-cycle edges of a side, it's much
faster to 3-cycle edges of an inner slice with U2M'U2 :-) )


In my opinion, the keys to faster solving are:

1) Learn a basic method perfectly. Train a lot, anticipate, practice
fingers and mental dexterity, etc.

2) Multi-experts optimizations, or dynamic hybrid methods. Try to
maximize lucky cases by choosing a technique or another.
When the "method R3a-Z expert" in your head yells "Hey! This case is
for me, I know that if you follow me, the chances for you to finish
this cube fast are quite good!", listen to him.
That's what you propose, and I totally agree with you.
That's what I'm doing with the last 6 edges and 4 centers: Method 2 if
I don't want to think at all, methods 1+3 tricks when there's an
obvious shortcut that can be detected fast, and sometimes ELL when the
F2L are already solved.
If at a given point of a solve you're given to choose between 2
possibilities, choose the one that is statistically the most powerful.
But mixing different methods in real time is not easy. The criteria
that will tell you to choose one way or another have to be very
simple, because every step must be anticipated while
executing/finishing the previous step.
If you can't anticipate enough, you can't ready your fingers, and
since we're trying to optimize for a few 1/10s it's often much easier
to loose time.
*IDEA* We could draw a graph of all methods and variations, that would
tell you, step by step, what your choices are and how to decide.

3) Learn a lot of magical sequences.
I don't believe in learning hundreds of cases to solve LL corners +
permute edges. Since Lars or others introduced this idea, I've never
understood why it makes people so excited (but it's fine if other
people like this idea and have fun looking for all these sequences, I
hope they'll prove me wrong -- Chris ;-) ).


Gilles

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1205. [Speed cubing group] Re: Sunday Contest prizes
From: "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 06:05:25 -0000

The thing is that if the first one is the one whow wins, the winners will frequently be the same. I first thought that it could be a good thing to enable slower people to win the prize if they progressed well, if the participated frequently,... but then the fastest one won't have the prize and that's not fair. I think that the period is a good compromise. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Yeah, I would like to see this "prize" thing... well, the main purpose > of the prize that I see is to increase participation in the Sunday > contest, and that's not going to happen if the winner of the prize has > to be very fast, because honestly, yeah, I have no chance at taking a > prize like that. > > www.cubesmith.com also won't get much publicity if the participation > numbers aren't increased. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology
1206. [Speed cubing group] Re: Sunday Contest prizes
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 08:40:19 -0000

I have a possible idea. Last night I chatted with Tyson about a method which ranks people based on how much they bettered their average average, according to Normal Probability theory. This would require everyone taking part to have a regular statistic on their previous (at least 30, maybe 50) cubes, with Mean and S.d. A normal probability calculation could then be performed on their competition average, and the person who has beaten their average average with the lowest probability of occurrence should take the prize, since they have bettered themselves the most, no matter what their times are. This would reward constantly improving competitors more, than just the fastest guy each week. This is the method I shall be using in the friendly handicap competition we will have on July 16th in the first puzzle meeting of speedcubers in the UK. Dan :) - www.cubestation.co.uk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@y...> wrote: > The thing is that if the first one is the one whow wins, the winners > will frequently be the same. > I first thought that it could be a good thing to enable slower people > to win the prize if they progressed well, if the participated > frequently,... but then the fastest one won't have the prize and > that's not fair. > > I think that the period is a good compromise. > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > Yeah, I would like to see this "prize" thing... well, the main purpose > > of the prize that I see is to increase participation in the Sunday > > contest, and that's not going to happen if the winner of the prize has > > to be very fast, because honestly, yeah, I have no chance at taking a > > prize like that. > > > > www.cubesmith.com also won't get much publicity if the participation > > numbers aren't increased. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology

I do take your point of course. At first I didn't like the ineligibility idea, but I am warming to it now. Best newcomer is a very good idea, perhaps I would include this very soon. And also it might be possible to extend my normal calculation to FMC, but gleaning the Mean/SD statistic would be much harder, perhaps it would be more feasible to use a different distribution or so. Thanks for your ideas though! 1210. [Speed cubing group] Re: Sunday Contest prizes
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 10:50:36 -0000

Yes, almost right, but don't forget it also is dependent on the Standard Deviation. Two people who have the same average (say 30 seconds) but Person 1 has a long term (50 cubes or so) SD of 5 seconds, and Person 2 has an SD of 10 seconds. (Just example numbers) If they both then posted a 25 second average in a competition, Person 1 would be ranked higher than person 2, because they would have beaten their average by 1 SD, whereas Person 2 only beats his by 1/2 SD. This means that the probability that Person 1 would score 25s in the competition is lower than the probability of Person 2 posting the same. Dan :) - www.cubestation.co.uk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Peter Douthwright" <pdouthwright0513@r...> wrote: > I really like this idea in that it encourages people to get better and practice. Am I right in assuming that the person who betters their average the most over their previous 50 atempts ets the prize? > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Dan > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Tuesday, June 28, 2005 4:40 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Sunday Contest prizes > > > I have a possible idea. > > Last night I chatted with Tyson about a method which ranks people > based on how much they bettered their average average, according to > Normal Probability theory. > > This would require everyone taking part to have a regular statistic > on their previous (at least 30, maybe 50) cubes, with Mean and S.d. > > A normal probability calculation could then be performed on their > competition average, and the person who has beaten their average > average with the lowest probability of occurrence should take the > prize, since they have bettered themselves the most, no matter what > their times are. This would reward constantly improving competitors > more, than just the fastest guy each week. > > This is the method I shall be using in the friendly handicap > competition we will have on July 16th in the first puzzle meeting of > speedcubers in the UK. > > Dan :) - www.cubestation.co.uk > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "gillesvdp" > <gillesvdp@y...> wrote: > > The thing is that if the first one is the one whow wins, the > winners > > will frequently be the same. > > I first thought that it could be a good thing to enable slower > people > > to win the prize if they progressed well, if the participated > > frequently,... but then the fastest one won't have the prize and > > that's not fair. > > > > I think that the period is a good compromise. > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao > <tmao@i...> > > wrote: > > > Yeah, I would like to see this "prize" thing... well, the main > purpose > > > of the prize that I see is to increase participation in the > Sunday > > > contest, and that's not going to happen if the winner of the > prize has > > > to be very fast, because honestly, yeah, I have no chance at > taking a > > > prize like that. > > > > > > www.cubesmith.com also won't get much publicity if the > participation > > > numbers aren't increased. > > > > > > Tyson Mao > > > MSC #631 > > > California Institute of Technology > > > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------- > YAHOO! 1211. [Speed cubing group] Re: Sunday Contest prizes
From: nascarjon2001 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 13:28:57 -0000

Thanks for all of the great ideas. I like Dan's idea, but it would be very difficult to coordinate for the 70 - 80 different competitors. This is what I cam up with last night: Starting next Sunday. The winner of the contest will recieve a set of stickers for any six-color puzzle of his or her choice. In addition to that, a random drawing will be held for a set of 3x3x3 stickers. Winners will be ineligable for 4 participations in the contest. For every consecutive participation non-winners will get an additional entry into the drawing for the next week. So the more that you participate, the better the chances that you'll win the drawing. Thanks to http://www.cubesmith.com for supplying the prizes! Jon http://www.geocities.com/nascarjon2001 --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > Yes, almost right, > > but don't forget it also is dependent on the Standard Deviation. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > > > c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms > of Service. > > > > > > ----------------------------------------------------------------- -- > ----------- > > > > > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1212. Re: I need help with a ZBLL case
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 15:34:31 -0000

The two 14-move QTM solutions found by ACube can be quite fast: - (RUR'U'l'B'Ul)z'x'(U'R'FRE) You should naturally find the "right" left finger and the "right" right grip for the last E. - (RUR'uRU')x(U'r'U'rUR')y'(R'U) Sub-4s is easy. Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > Hey Chris, > > I just saw your post. > > I use this algorithm, which is the same as yours, but much much > easier to execute (IMHO) > > (U L)(R U2 R' U' R U R' U)(L' U2)(R U' R' U) > > Good Luck mate, > > Dan :) - www.cubestation.co.uk > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > > > I have a fun request for everyone here. I ran into what has so far > > become my slowest ZBLL case, and I can't find a fast alg for it. > > > > So everyone do this alg on your cube from solved: > > U2 B U B' U2 F U' B U' B' U B U2 F' B' > > > > Now solve your cube. In any way you please, I don't care. Just > write > > down your solution and either e-mail to me > > chris[nospam]@... or post it on the group. > > > > Here's your chance to prove your method against mine :-D My record > > for solving that case is 2.63 seconds, but I average about 4.00 > > seconds. Can you beat 4.00 seconds on average for that finish? > > > > If your method doesn't run into this type of case at any point, > please > > ignore this post altogether. > > > > So you fast people out there, can you beat me for that case? If > so, > > let me know! I would really like to find a fast alg for that case. > > > > Chris > > > > P.S. If you haven't guessed, my alg to solve that case is the > inverse > > of the one above :-D > > P.P.S I've already messed around a bit with Acube with no success, > > but if you know cool, fast move groups to try please feel free!
1213. Re: I need help with a ZBLL case
From: "rubiks1938" <rubiks1938@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 15:38:08 -0000

I saw all of the other solutions to the ZBLL case and I simply did this:

y(U2 R U R' U2)(L U')(R U' R' U R U2)(L' R')

The key to this sequence is in the y at the very beginning. The goal is to have as many
triggers involving (R,U) and (L,U) as possible. I hope this helps.

My slowest time for this was 4 seconds (which I got only twice) and my fastest was 2. I'm
guessing my average was about 2.6 - 2.9 seconds for this case.

Andy C.

http://andyscubepage.tk




1214. Re: I need help with a ZBLL case
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 16:44:37 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubiks1938" <rubiks1938@y...> wrote: > I saw all of the other solutions to the ZBLL case and I simply did this: > > y(U2 R U R' U2)(L U')(R U' R' U R U2)(L' R') > > The key to this sequence is in the y at the very beginning. Of course you could also do without that key feature if you replace the U2 at start with U' and add another U' at the end: (U' R U R' U2)(L U')(R U' R' U R U2)(L' R' U') Actually though you solve the inverse case since you probably used Dan's solution for scrambling: (U L)(R U2 R' U' R U R' U)(L' U2)(R U' R' U) And they're even inverse algorithms ;-) Ok, now what I'd really like to know is how you found these algorithms. Stefan
1215. Re: I need help with a ZBLL case
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 17:22:36 -0000

Ok, let me add some, too :-) U R' F' R F U' R' U2 R U' F' R' F U' R R' U R' U' R' U' F' R' U R U' F U2 R2 Found with ACube using <R,U,F>. I like the first one better and you could save its first U by adjusting the U layer differently. I think with practice it could become quite fast. Stefan
1216. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: I need help with a ZBLL case
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 12:55:31 -0500

If you're going to go that route, you may as well change the beginning to d' U'.

That saves you on a rotation, which is unproductive in terms of moves per second, since it's not really even a move.

-Mike Bennett

----- Original Message -----
From: rubiks1938
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, June 28, 2005 10:38 AM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: I need help with a ZBLL case


I saw all of the other solutions to the ZBLL case and I simply did this:

y(U2 R U R' U2)(L U')(R U' R' U R U2)(L' R')

The key to this sequence is in the y at the very beginning. The goal is to have as many
triggers involving (R,U) and (L,U) as possible. I hope this helps.

My slowest time for this was 4 seconds (which I got only twice) and my fastest was 2. I'm
guessing my average was about 2.6 - 2.9 seconds for this case.

Andy C.

http://andyscubepage.tk

We intend to have "noncommon" events > (pyraminx, magic, no preinspection....) during the first day and the > main events (3x3x3, 4x4x4... speedsolving) during the second day. The > exact events and division between the two days will be decided upon > later. The venue is still to be decided, but it will be in the city of > Stockholm. > > SveKub <www.svekub.se> is the organiser and I will be the main contact > person at present. > > We will have an open championship, thus allowing non-Swedes to > participate. > > /Anders I would really like to come and participate. I live in Tampere, Finland, and it's quite easy to come by train/ship to Stockholm. It's not that expensive and I don't mind about spending 10 hours on the sea, from Turku to Stockholm. But since hotels are much more expensive, I was thinking if it would be possible for one of you to let me stay at their place for preferably the three nights of the tournament (Friday to Monday). If it is possible, then I will surely come! Sebastian
1218. legal writing
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 15:34:31 -0600

Hi Guys,

Is there anyone who's familiar with legal documents in this group?
Most specifically, I'd like to know what it means when the Late Show
with David Letterman cannot accept any show ideas or anything, and that
anything we submit to them becomes their property.

Please contact me personally if you have a better idea of what this
means and I will let you know the specific situation.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

1222. Re: legal writing
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 29 Jun 2005 15:55:22 -0000

Tyson, Send me more details of your specific situation, but it is typical for shows to require you to relinquish rights to any materials [footage or ideas or suggestions] you submit for the show. That way, they don't have to pay you for the material and even if they use it, you are not entitled to royalties and cannot sue for copyright infringement, etc. And because they now own it, they can use it in any manner they please. If you want to email me more details, you can reach me at Kirk[at] EagleFinancialAdvisors.com best regards, Kirk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hi Guys, > > Is there anyone who's familiar with legal documents in this group? > Most specifically, I'd like to know what it means when the Late Show > with David Letterman cannot accept any show ideas or anything, and that > anything we submit to them becomes their property. > > Please contact me personally if you have a better idea of what this > means and I will let you know the specific situation. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology
1223. Re: I need help with a ZBLL case
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 29 Jun 2005 17:48:28 -0000

Hey everyone, Wow! Thanks so much for all the help! I really appreciate the time you guys took to do this. I went through and tested and worked on every alg, and finally came up with the two best options (for my hands of course). In fact, both of these algs are so fast that I am having a hard time deciding between the two. I think I may learn both of them, since they both end with effectively turning the LL a different direction. You all seriously turned my slowest case into one of my faster ones! Thanks so much!!! Here are my choices for the best two (again for my hands). The first one is slightly faster on average, but again #2 is so close I can't really ditch it for #1. 1) y L' F' U' L2 U L2 F U' L' U' L2 U L2 (posted by James Stuber) fastest exection: 2.26 seconds (5.75 t/sec including the cube rotation) fastest average: 2.82 seconds (4.61 t/sec) This includes the y rotation at the beginning, which actually makes the following L' F' much easier. I do the trigger as (y L' F') U' (L')2 U (L)2 (F) U' (L' U' (L)2) (U) (L')2 also ending with a U turn is fast because both hands end at a standard grip. 2) R' U R' U' R' U' F' R' U R U' F U2 R2 (posted by Stefan Pochmann) fastest execution: 2.30 seconds fastest average: 3.19 seconds (could be faster as I practiced #1 a bit more. I think this one can also go sub-3 on average.) I do the trigger as: [(R' U R') (U')] (R' U') (F') [(R' U) (R U')] (F U2) R2 Pros of #1: -the L2 U alternating moves are CRAZY fast, so the ending and the middle go by VERY quickly. - my common misalignment mistakes are easily corrected - grip never changes after y rotation Pros of #2: - Lots of RU moves - grip never changes - no rotation required Cons of #1: - The first trigger/rotation is hard to correct if I screw up - It requires a rotation from the angle I recognize the case at Cons of #2: - It has 3 non-productive hand movements (twisting my wrist around so that where I was grabbing the back of the face I now have to grab the front: the first move has none). - My common mistakes tend to be the move f' (F'S') instead of (F') which kills my time completely. So mistakes are not easily corrected. ---------------------- So far I like #1 just a tiiiiiiiny little bit better, but I think I'll end up keeping both. I'm so quoting help from the group on my ZBLL page for this case :-D Thanks so much to everyone, I spent a good bit of time figuring out finger tricks to each alg, so thanks to everyone who posted an alg. I really appreciate it. Thanks so much! Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I have a fun request for everyone here. I ran into what has so far > become my slowest ZBLL case, and I can't find a fast alg for it. > > So everyone do this alg on your cube from solved: > U2 B U B' U2 F U' B U' B' U B U2 F' B' > > Now solve your cube. In any way you please, I don't care. Just write > down your solution and either e-mail to me > chris[nospam]@... or post it on the group. > > Here's your chance to prove your method against mine :-D My record > for solving that case is 2.63 seconds, but I average about 4.00 > seconds. Can you beat 4.00 seconds on average for that finish? > > If your method doesn't run into this type of case at any point, please > ignore this post altogether. > > So you fast people out there, can you beat me for that case? If so, > let me know! I would really like to find a fast alg for that case. > > Chris > > P.S. If you haven't guessed, my alg to solve that case is the inverse > of the one above :-D > P.P.S I've already messed around a bit with Acube with no success, > but if you know cool, fast move groups to try please feel free!

1225. Re: I need help with a ZBLL case
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 29 Jun 2005 18:09:20 -0000

y L' F' U' L2 U L2 F U' L' U' L2 U L2

Actually after lots more practice I've decided to stick with this alg
only. I've found that with the other alg (my #2 from before) I can
only get sub-3 on a flawless execution, whereas I can still get sub-3
on #1 even with minor mistakes. Also even with more practice I can't
get #2 to average sub-3, but I can easily now with #1.

Thanks to all for the help. I really really really appreciate it! I
went from 4.00-4.25 on average to sub-3 for this case!

Can't say thanks enough :-)
Chris

> 1) y L' F' U' L2 U L2 F U' L' U' L2 U L2 (posted by James Stuber)
> fastest exection: 2.26 seconds (5.75 t/sec including the cube rotation)
> fastest average: 2.82 seconds (4.61 t/sec)
> This includes the y rotation at the beginning, which actually makes
> the following L' F' much easier.
> I do the trigger as
> (y L' F') U' (L')2 U (L)2 (F) U' (L' U' (L)2) (U) (L')2
> also ending with a U turn is fast because both hands end at a standard
> grip.
