1228. magic solution
From: "Bruce Wayne" <drteeth@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 29 Jun 2005 21:43:35 -0000

hey i just got a magic today and can solve the unlinked side no
problem and can get to the linked position is there a webpage or a
method that anyone knows of to help me solve the linked side. Also in
a competition is the back scrambled? and if so is there any inspection
time for the back? thanks a lot
-Justin Medoy




1229. Re: magic solution
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 29 Jun 2005 22:44:56 -0000

I made a video showing how I solve: http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/burtonmagicsolution.avi (DivX is required, www.divx.com). In a competition, the back is scrambled, and the front shows unlinked rings. It is always the same starting position and the object is to solve the unlinked rings. Note: when you watch the video, it shows how I solve and go back. Most people just go completely in reverse, but I like to be different, so when I go back, I go "the long way," but it is almost just as fast. ;-) As for inspection time, you are allowed infinite inspection time (unless the judge gets upset with you). It's recommended to take no more than 0 seconds to inspect the magic ;-) ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bruce Wayne" <drteeth@o...> wrote: > hey i just got a magic today and can solve the unlinked side no > problem and can get to the linked position is there a webpage or a > method that anyone knows of to help me solve the linked side. Also in > a competition is the back scrambled? and if so is there any inspection > time for the back? thanks a lot > -Justin Medoy
1230. Re: magic solution
From: "Bruce Wayne" <drteeth@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 29 Jun 2005 22:50:22 -0000

thanks a lot for the info...when u say its always in the same starting position and the back is scrambled do you mean that the rings are just constructed on the front or that they are constructed in a certain way...i noticed that u can build the unlinked rings in a couple of different ways --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > I made a video showing how I solve: > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/burtonmagicsolution.avi (DivX is > required, www.divx.com). > > In a competition, the back is scrambled, and the front shows unlinked > rings. It is always the same starting position and the object is to > solve the unlinked rings. Note: when you watch the video, it shows > how I solve and go back. Most people just go completely in reverse, > but I like to be different, so when I go back, I go "the long way," > but it is almost just as fast. ;-) As for inspection time, you are > allowed infinite inspection time (unless the judge gets upset with > you). It's recommended to take no more than 0 seconds to inspect the > magic ;-) > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bruce Wayne" > <drteeth@o...> wrote: > > hey i just got a magic today and can solve the unlinked side no > > problem and can get to the linked position is there a webpage or a > > method that anyone knows of to help me solve the linked side. Also in > > a competition is the back scrambled? and if so is there any inspection > > time for the back? thanks a lot > > -Justin Medoy
1231. Re: magic solution
From: "Bruce Wayne" <drteeth@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 29 Jun 2005 23:15:04 -0000

thanks a lot for the info...when u say its always in the same starting position and the back is scrambled do you mean that the rings are just constructed on the front or that they are constructed in a certain way...i noticed that u can build the unlinked rings in a couple of different ways --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > I made a video showing how I solve: > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/burtonmagicsolution.avi (DivX is > required, www.divx.com). > > In a competition, the back is scrambled, and the front shows unlinked > rings. It is always the same starting position and the object is to > solve the unlinked rings. Note: when you watch the video, it shows > how I solve and go back. Most people just go completely in reverse, > but I like to be different, so when I go back, I go "the long way," > but it is almost just as fast. ;-) As for inspection time, you are > allowed infinite inspection time (unless the judge gets upset with > you). It's recommended to take no more than 0 seconds to inspect the > magic ;-) > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bruce Wayne" > <drteeth@o...> wrote: > > hey i just got a magic today and can solve the unlinked side no > > problem and can get to the linked position is there a webpage or a > > method that anyone knows of to help me solve the linked side. Also in > > a competition is the back scrambled? and if so is there any inspection > > time for the back? thanks a lot > > -Justin Medoy
1232. Re: Standard Deviation
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 29 Jun 2005 23:20:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Anthony Hsu" <erwaman@m...> wrote: > Just curious, how is standard deviation calculated? > > ~Erwaman~ > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] It's the square root of the variation, which is the expected value of (X-mu)^2 where X is your random variable and mu is the mean. (Population standard deviation) The sample variance is 1/(n-1) * sum (x-m)^2 where m is the sample mean and n is the size of the sample. That's not quite the expected value (which would begin with 1/n rather than 1/(n-1). The sample standard deviation is the square root of the sample variance. It is an unbiased estimator of the population standard deviation (which might not be tractable). If you replace 1/(n-1) by 1/n you'll get a biased estimator, although I think you will then have the maximum likelihood estimator. It's been a long time so that part about the MLE might not be right.
1233. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Standard Deviation
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 29 Jun 2005 16:26:39 -0700

They way it was explained to me was the average distance from the average. Just easier way to think about it, IMHO. -E On 6/29/05, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Anthony > Hsu" <erwaman@m...> > wrote: > > Just curious, how is standard deviation calculated? > > > > ~Erwaman~ > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > It's the square root of the variation, which is the expected value of > (X-mu)^2 where X is > your random variable and mu is the mean. (Population standard deviation) > > The sample variance is 1/(n-1) * sum (x-m)^2 where m is the sample mean and > n is the > size of the sample. That's not quite the expected value (which would begin > with 1/n rather > than 1/(n-1). The sample standard deviation is the square root of the sample > variance. It > is an unbiased estimator of the population standard deviation (which might > not be > tractable). If you replace 1/(n-1) by 1/n you'll get a biased estimator, > although I think you > will then have the maximum likelihood estimator. It's been a long time so > that part about > the MLE might not be right. > > > > ________________________________ > YAHOO! 1234. Re: magic solution
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 29 Jun 2005 23:26:33 -0000

As long as the rings are unlinked on the front, the back will always look the same, regardless of how you got there. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bruce Wayne" <drteeth@o...> wrote: > thanks a lot for the info...when u say its always in the same starting > position and the back is scrambled do you mean that the rings are just > constructed on the front or that they are constructed in a certain > way...i noticed that u can build the unlinked rings in a couple of > different ways > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> > wrote: > > I made a video showing how I solve: > > > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/burtonmagicsolution.avi (DivX is > > required, www.divx.com). > > > > In a competition, the back is scrambled, and the front shows unlinked > > rings. It is always the same starting position and the object is to > > solve the unlinked rings. Note: when you watch the video, it shows > > how I solve and go back. Most people just go completely in reverse, > > but I like to be different, so when I go back, I go "the long way," > > but it is almost just as fast. ;-) As for inspection time, you are > > allowed infinite inspection time (unless the judge gets upset with > > you). It's recommended to take no more than 0 seconds to inspect the > > magic ;-) > > > > ~ Bob > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bruce Wayne" > > <drteeth@o...> wrote: > > > hey i just got a magic today and can solve the unlinked side no > > > problem and can get to the linked position is there a webpage or a > > > method that anyone knows of to help me solve the linked side. Also in > > > a competition is the back scrambled? and if so is there any inspection > > > time for the back? thanks a lot > > > -Justin Medoy

1236. Re: Magic question for bob
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 30 Jun 2005 04:32:49 -0000

Hey Batman, Heh, sorry, I let the camera just dangle from my neck when I filmed because nobody else was around to film. Yes, transform 5 on Jaap's page, except the way I hold it is slightly different than he suggests, I believe. I like the way I hold it because it feels very fast for me, but different people have different preferences on how to hold the puzzle for that transform. Side note--I made a new Magic video recently: http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/burtonmagic129.avi (1.29 seconds). Notice the pause in the solve? Should have been faster... :\ ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bruce Wayne" <drteeth@o...> wrote: > thanks for all the info bob, im finally able to solve it but i use the > three step method on this site > http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/magic.htm > theres an alg on this page that combines the first two steps of this i > was wondering if this is what you were doing in your video becuase its > kinda hard to pick up on what ur doing cuz the magic moves out of the > camera for a second...thanks alot for all your help. > -Justin Medoy

1241. Improved PLL Algs??
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 30 Jun 2005 08:48:32 -0000

Found this one today:
[x] B RB'R U2 [x'] URURU'R'U'F2R2
----------------------------------------


(RU')(R'l')(U2B')(RU2)(R'B)U2(lR)UR'U)
Found this one a while ago. Thanks to Francois for helping me adjust
the alg for double layer turns. Thanks to Francois again after giving
this alg to me again when I lost it...lol


===========================================
Let me know what you think!

-Richard

1244. Re: Improved PLL Algs??
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 30 Jun 2005 09:40:37 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > Found this one today: > [x] B RB'R U2 [x'] URURU'R'U'F2R2 For this one, I prefer (L U2') (L' U2) (L F' L' U' L U) (L F L2' U), which can somewhat easily be done in sub-2 seconds (easily average sub-2.5). This could be even faster if I cubed left-handed. ;-) How fast have you been able to perform this one? ~ Bob

1246. Method for Handicap Competitions
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 30 Jun 2005 10:46:26 -0000

Hi Everyone,

I would like some input on the following method for judging a
handicap competition, especially whether it is actually feasible to
use in a competition!

1. From each competitor, have a long term Mean and Standard
Deviation Statistic. From my Statistics course a long tim ago, the
number 30 seems to ring a bell in my head, ie you have to make 30+
solves before the statistics becomes valid.

2. After the competition, calculate each competitors average. Then
calculate a Normal Probability, with competition average as the "x"
statistic, and using the long term Mean and SD. This will calculate
the probability of the competitor achieving this competition
average, if they were to make many thousands of averages.

3. The competitor who has achieved the lowest average probability
would win, and competitors are ranked in order of ascending
probabilities.

So, all fine in theory?

I have tried plugging some numbers into a spreadsheet, and the
results are quite promising. But one observation I have made, is
that in real life, results don't seem to "quite fit" the normal
distribution. It is perfectly likely for someone who is quite
consistent in practice, to have a wildly varying average in
competition, and the probabilities end up being almost 0, or almost
1. Is there someway of "stretching" the margins of the normal
probability, so it can cover a wider range of results? One way would
be to multiply the competitors standard deviations by a factor, but
is this mathematically valid?

Any help is greatly needed :)

Dan Harris - www.cubestation.co.uk :)

P.S. I hated Statistics in college ;)




1247. Re: Method for Handicap Competitions
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 30 Jun 2005 11:07:25 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n.. .> wrote: > > 3. The competitor who has achieved the lowest average probability > would win, and competitors are ranked in order of ascending > probabilities. That way I'd win with a 60 second average because the probability for that is incredibly small ;-). Well, Macky might beat it with a 20 second average being similarly improbable. Cheers! Stefan
1248. WCA = ?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 30 Jun 2005 11:10:42 -0000

I think it stands for "World Clairvoyant Association" because on the
bottom of
http://www.speedcubing.com/rankings/worldrecords.html
there's a link to "Broken records in and *after* 2005." ;-)

Cheers!
Stefan





1249. Re: Method for Handicap Competitions
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 30 Jun 2005 11:16:46 -0000

No, thats not quite true. If your average was say 20 seconds (am I flattering or insulting you Stefan? ;) ) and you made a 60 second average in competition, then you would be at the high end of the scale, you probability would be 1, because the likelihood in the long term almost (if not all) your averages would be 60 seconds or under. So there is no way you would win like that. To win, you have to better your average by the most. Dan :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n.. > .> wrote: > > > > 3. The competitor who has achieved the lowest average probability > > would win, and competitors are ranked in order of ascending > > probabilities. > > That way I'd win with a 60 second average because the probability for > that is incredibly small ;-). Well, Macky might beat it with a 20 > second average being similarly improbable. > > Cheers! > Stefan

To win, you have to better your average by the most. > > Dan :) > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" > <dan_j_harris@n.. > > .> wrote: > > > > > > 3. 1255. Re: [Speed cubing group] Dallas Tournament this August

Date: Thu, 30 Jun 2005 09:51:20 -0600

Hey Chris,

That's great! It'll be great to see you again. I'm very curious at
how suddenly you acquired money to go to the tournament. If you've
found out how to make money from solving cubes, you gotta let me know.

As for all of you, if you feel you're 'noteworthy' or 'special' in any
way, the museum is looking for ways to promote the tournament. Part of
this includes making profiles of the competitors and talking about what
they've done. For example, there could be a huge poster of Chris that
lists all of his records and everything. You guys should let me know,
because these things might look cool, and I'm sure they'd let you take
it home afterwards.

Sorry I can't provide you with a place to stay. Unfortunately, I don't
live in Dallas (naturally) and I'm staying at a friend's place and
everything. Maybe they have like, youth hostels or something?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

I just talked to my parents, and if I do run a few bucks short they can spot me a little bit. So I'm definitely coming. Woohoo!!! :-D It's always cool to see other cubers, and it sadly happens too infrequently. Well, see you guys in August :-) Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hey Chris, > > That's great! It'll be great to see you again. If you've > found out how to make money from solving cubes, you gotta let me know. > > As for all of you, if you feel you're 'noteworthy' or 'special' in any > way, the museum is looking for ways to promote the tournament. Maybe they have like, youth hostels or something? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Jun 30, 2005, at 3:47 AM, cmhardw wrote: > > > Hey all, > > > > I recently worked out my financial situation and it turns out that I > > can afford to go the the Dallas tournament! ..... sorta :-) > > > > I can totally afford the flight and food and all that, but I would be > > hard pressed and probably have to borrow money from other people if I > > had to pay for hotel also. > > > > Are there any Dallas cubers, or other cubers nearby, that I could stay > > with just for the competition? 1258. Re: [Speed cubing group] website design
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 30 Jun 2005 15:27:36 -0500

use an all css-based design. see www.csszengarden for more info. it's a little hard at first, but after you get used to it, it makes much more sense. and it's also a nice challenge. On 6/27/05, Bryant Tran <bmtran@...> wrote: > I have to agree with James. Frames are also just not as aesthetically > pleasing as a simple repetitive layout. I tend to favor websites that don't > use frames. > > --Bryant > > On 6/27/05, James Stuber <jestuber@...> wrote: > > > > Don't use frames, they're annoying if you want to link to a specific > > page. > > > > > > > > _____ > > > > From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Evan > > Sent: Sunday, June 26, 2005 3:20 PM > > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] website design > > > > > > > > Hey everyone, > > > > I'm moving my website, so I figured I might as well redesign while I'm > > at it. The main question I have is whether people prefer a frame for > > navigation, the way that speedcubing.com <http://speedcubing.com> is, and > > the way my site is > > now, or just links on the top or side of each page for navigation, > > that aren't a seperate frame. There are the pros and cons of both, so > > I just wanted to know what people thought. And anything else you'd > > like to say, tips, constructive criticism (about the site, not my > > spelling ;-) ) would be greatly appreciated. > > > > -Evan > > > > Until next time, Happy Cubing > > http://www.deepcube.tk > > > > > > > > > > > > _____ > > > > Yahoo! 1259. Re: [Speed cubing group] Method for Handicap Competitions
From: Leyan Lo <leyanlo@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 30 Jun 2005 14:02:58 -0700

Where would you get the 30 solves?

If you're using solves that span a large time frame, this is not a good
idea because most people get faster the more they cube. It would
probably be more fair to fit their solve times to an exponential decay
curve up to a constant as a function of time, and then calculate their
expected average and standard deviation for the day of the tournament
from the fit.

Leyan

PS. From the statistics class I took, I remember the number 40 (Law of
large numbers).


Dan wrote:
> Hi Everyone,
>
> I would like some input on the following method for judging a
> handicap competition, especially whether it is actually feasible to
> use in a competition!
>
> 1. From each competitor, have a long term Mean and Standard
> Deviation Statistic. From my Statistics course a long tim ago, the
> number 30 seems to ring a bell in my head, ie you have to make 30+
> solves before the statistics becomes valid.
>
> 2. After the competition, calculate each competitors average. Then
> calculate a Normal Probability, with competition average as the "x"
> statistic, and using the long term Mean and SD. This will calculate
> the probability of the competitor achieving this competition
> average, if they were to make many thousands of averages.
>
> 3. The competitor who has achieved the lowest average probability
> would win, and competitors are ranked in order of ascending
> probabilities.
>
> So, all fine in theory?
>
> I have tried plugging some numbers into a spreadsheet, and the
> results are quite promising. But one observation I have made, is
> that in real life, results don't seem to "quite fit" the normal
> distribution. It is perfectly likely for someone who is quite
> consistent in practice, to have a wildly varying average in
> competition, and the probabilities end up being almost 0, or almost
> 1. Is there someway of "stretching" the margins of the normal
> probability, so it can cover a wider range of results? One way would
> be to multiply the competitors standard deviations by a factor, but
> is this mathematically valid?
>
> Any help is greatly needed :)
>
> Dan Harris - www.cubestation.co.uk :)
>
> P.S. I hated Statistics in college ;)
>
>
>
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>
>


1260. Re: [Speed cubing group] Method for Handicap Competitions
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 30 Jun 2005 15:05:00 -0600

Gary Lorden? Or, people could just "warm up" and then you could take
the 30 solves? Because exponential decay only works for small values
of t, and eventually the person gets tired and then their times start
going up.

I screwed up the final for that class, by the way.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

Pool is one of those things I've always thought about practicing and getting really good at. Unlike the cube, the average person out there plays pool. I don't have to get good, I just have to get slightly better than the average, and just get to a point where I really understand the game, and know what I'm doing, and then I can... go to bars and hustle people, get them drunk, and walk away with their girlfriends. Yeah, that was besides the point. Anyway, glad to hear you're coming to Dallas. Dallas isn't my city, so I don't know where the places to shoot pool are. You should have come to New York. Macky's mom was owning EVERYONE! 1264. Re: [Speed cubing group] Method for Handicap Competitions
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Jul 2005 09:02:14 -0000

Hi Leyan, Tyson, The 30 - 40 solves would have to be fairly near the time of the competition, yes. As you say, if you were using an out of date statistic, it wouldn't work, because people's long term averages would slowly increase as they improved. This, in my opinion, is the main stumbling block of this method, how would you get all the competitors to bother to time 30 or 40 solves, before the day of the tournament? Perhaps everyone should time as many cubes as they possibly can, in a practice session before the competition or so. Well, I guess we will just have to see what happens on July 16th! Dan :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Leyan Lo <leyanlo@g...> wrote: > Where would you get the 30 solves? > > If you're using solves that span a large time frame, this is not a good > idea because most people get faster the more they cube. It would > probably be more fair to fit their solve times to an exponential decay > curve up to a constant as a function of time, and then calculate their > expected average and standard deviation for the day of the tournament > from the fit. > > Leyan > > PS. From the statistics class I took, I remember the number 40 (Law of > large numbers). > > > Dan wrote: > > Hi Everyone, > > > > I would like some input on the following method for judging a > > handicap competition, especially whether it is actually feasible to > > use in a competition! > > > > 1. From each competitor, have a long term Mean and Standard > > Deviation Statistic. From my Statistics course a long tim ago, the > > number 30 seems to ring a bell in my head, ie you have to make 30+ > > solves before the statistics becomes valid. > > > > 2. After the competition, calculate each competitors average. Then > > calculate a Normal Probability, with competition average as the "x" > > statistic, and using the long term Mean and SD. This will calculate > > the probability of the competitor achieving this competition > > average, if they were to make many thousands of averages. > > > > 3. The competitor who has achieved the lowest average probability > > would win, and competitors are ranked in order of ascending > > probabilities. > > > > So, all fine in theory? > > > > I have tried plugging some numbers into a spreadsheet, and the > > results are quite promising. But one observation I have made, is > > that in real life, results don't seem to "quite fit" the normal > > distribution. It is perfectly likely for someone who is quite > > consistent in practice, to have a wildly varying average in > > competition, and the probabilities end up being almost 0, or almost > > 1. Is there someway of "stretching" the margins of the normal > > probability, so it can cover a wider range of results? One way would > > be to multiply the competitors standard deviations by a factor, but > > is this mathematically valid? > > > > Any help is greatly needed :) > > > > Dan Harris - www.cubestation.co.uk :) > > > > P.S. I hated Statistics in college ;) > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
1265. loose string on the magic (4x2)
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Jul 2005 09:34:31 -0000

Hey all you magic solvers,

I'm totally and completely new to all this. I learned how to solve
the magic just recently, and it turns out that I started timing myself
before I knew the solution very well and on one of my solves my hand
sort of spasmed or something and the magic went into a weird shape.

I was able to get it back to the reguloar one and realign all the
tiles, but now one of my strings is loose. I only notice it after I
have solved, then undo the solve back to the start.

The loose string, if I am looking at the unlinked side exactly as it
should look before I start the solution, is on the top row 2nd tile
from the right.

There are 4 diagonal rows of strings that go from the top left to the
bottom right, and it is the 2nd one from the bottom, there is a metal
connector thingy (go easy, I'm new to this :-) Near where this tile
touches the 3rd tile from the right is where the string gets loose.

If after every solve and undo I pop that string back in things seem to
go fine still, but that gets old after oh... 2 solves. :-D

Is there a way to fix this string without restringing completely? (I
have no idea how to do that). If that's necessary though, is there a
tutorial vid or site with pics that I can learn how to do that?

Thanks for the help, and please go easy on me if this explanation is
more than what is needed, or if I goofed on something. I'm a noob
magic solver :-D

Chris




1266. Re: loose string on the magic (4x2)
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Jul 2005 11:31:48 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey all you magic solvers, my hand > sort of spasmed or something LOL. Sorry, but it really made me laugh :P Dan :)
1267. Re: loose string on the magic (4x2)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Jul 2005 11:52:41 -0000

What exactly do you mean with "it's loose"? Is it like the string is too long? Or does it just slip out of the groove slightly? I have the latter problem with one of mine, but it's not annoying enough to make me take it all apart. Maybe one day it will break and I'm gonna replace it then. I have this Darwin-like theory, survival of the fittest, so if a string breaks it's actually good because this way you identify and remove the weak links. Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey all you magic solvers, > > I'm totally and completely new to all this. I learned how to solve > the magic just recently, and it turns out that I started timing myself > before I knew the solution very well and on one of my solves my hand > sort of spasmed or something and the magic went into a weird shape. > > I was able to get it back to the reguloar one and realign all the > tiles, but now one of my strings is loose. I only notice it after I > have solved, then undo the solve back to the start. > > The loose string, if I am looking at the unlinked side exactly as it > should look before I start the solution, is on the top row 2nd tile > from the right. > > There are 4 diagonal rows of strings that go from the top left to the > bottom right, and it is the 2nd one from the bottom, there is a metal > connector thingy (go easy, I'm new to this :-) Near where this tile > touches the 3rd tile from the right is where the string gets loose. > > If after every solve and undo I pop that string back in things seem to > go fine still, but that gets old after oh... 2 solves. :-D > > Is there a way to fix this string without restringing completely? (I > have no idea how to do that). If that's necessary though, is there a > tutorial vid or site with pics that I can learn how to do that? > > Thanks for the help, and please go easy on me if this explanation is > more than what is needed, or if I goofed on something. I'm a noob > magic solver :-D > > Chris
1268. Re: [Speed cubing group] Method for Handicap Competitions
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachin_civilian@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 1 Jul 2005 13:44:16 +0100 (BST)

No Dan but there is a way to beat this. If you are considering only the best improvement done by a person then I'll do my worst times in the first 30 solves and then in the real solves i'll solve normally. So my scores come out far better than the 30 previous ones. Though this looks like a good idea. Keep working on this. Sachin --- Dan <dan_j_harris@...> wrote: --------------------------------- Hi Leyan, Tyson, The 30 - 40 solves would have to be fairly near the time of the competition, yes. As you say, if you were using an out of date statistic, it wouldn't work, because people's long term averages would slowly increase as they improved. This, in my opinion, is the main stumbling block of this method, how would you get all the competitors to bother to time 30 or 40 solves, before the day of the tournament? Perhaps everyone should time as many cubes as they possibly can, in a practice session before the competition or so. Well, I guess we will just have to see what happens on July 16th! Dan :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Leyan Lo <leyanlo@g...> wrote: > Where would you get the 30 solves? > > If you're using solves that span a large time frame, this is not a good > idea because most people get faster the more they cube. It would > probably be more fair to fit their solve times to an exponential decay > curve up to a constant as a function of time, and then calculate their > expected average and standard deviation for the day of the tournament > from the fit. > > Leyan > > PS. From the statistics class I took, I remember the number 40 (Law of > large numbers). > > > Dan wrote: > > Hi Everyone, > > > > I would like some input on the following method for judging a > > handicap competition, especially whether it is actually feasible to > > use in a competition! > > > > 1. From each competitor, have a long term Mean and Standard > > Deviation Statistic. From my Statistics course a long tim ago, the > > number 30 seems to ring a bell in my head, ie you have to make 30+ > > solves before the statistics becomes valid. > > > > 2. After the competition, calculate each competitors average. Then > > calculate a Normal Probability, with competition average as the "x" > > statistic, and using the long term Mean and SD. This will calculate > > the probability of the competitor achieving this competition > > average, if they were to make many thousands of averages. > > > > 3. The competitor who has achieved the lowest average probability > > would win, and competitors are ranked in order of ascending > > probabilities. > > > > So, all fine in theory? > > > > I have tried plugging some numbers into a spreadsheet, and the > > results are quite promising. But one observation I have made, is > > that in real life, results don't seem to "quite fit" the normal > > distribution. It is perfectly likely for someone who is quite > > consistent in practice, to have a wildly varying average in > > competition, and the probabilities end up being almost 0, or almost > > 1. Is there someway of "stretching" the margins of the normal > > probability, so it can cover a wider range of results? One way would > > be to multiply the competitors standard deviations by a factor, but > > is this mathematically valid? > > > > Any help is greatly needed :) > > > > Dan Harris - www.cubestation.co.uk :) > > > > P.S. I hated Statistics in college ;) > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! 1273. Re: [Speed cubing group] Method for Handicap Competitions
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 1 Jul 2005 09:18:03 -0600

Hey... there are three Sundays between now and, the 16th are there? Fine, maybe two, but you can have people all do the Sunday contests? And just have them submit their results to both you and Jon, and for the last one, they just have to submit before the 16th. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Jul 1, 2005, at 3:02 AM, Dan wrote: > Hi Leyan, Tyson, > > The 30 - 40 solves would have to be fairly near the time of the > competition, yes. As you say, if you were using an out of date > statistic, it wouldn't work, because people's long term averages > would slowly increase as they improved. > > This, in my opinion, is the main stumbling block of this method, how > would you get all the competitors to bother to time 30 or 40 solves, > before the day of the tournament? Perhaps everyone should time as > many cubes as they possibly can, in a practice session before the > competition or so. > > Well, I guess we will just have to see what happens on July 16th! > > Dan :) > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Leyan Lo > <leyanlo@g...> wrote: >> Where would you get the 30 solves? >> >> If you're using solves that span a large time frame, this is not a > good >> idea because most people get faster the more they cube. It would >> probably be more fair to fit their solve times to an exponential > decay >> curve up to a constant as a function of time, and then calculate > their >> expected average and standard deviation for the day of the > tournament >> from the fit. >> >> Leyan >> >> PS. From the statistics class I took, I remember the number 40 > (Law of >> large numbers). >> >> >> Dan wrote: >>> Hi Everyone, >>> >>> I would like some input on the following method for judging a >>> handicap competition, especially whether it is actually feasible > to >>> use in a competition! >>> >>> 1. From each competitor, have a long term Mean and Standard >>> Deviation Statistic. From my Statistics course a long tim ago, > the >>> number 30 seems to ring a bell in my head, ie you have to make > 30+ >>> solves before the statistics becomes valid. >>> >>> 2. After the competition, calculate each competitors average. > Then >>> calculate a Normal Probability, with competition average as > the "x" >>> statistic, and using the long term Mean and SD. This will > calculate >>> the probability of the competitor achieving this competition >>> average, if they were to make many thousands of averages. >>> >>> 3. The competitor who has achieved the lowest average > probability >>> would win, and competitors are ranked in order of ascending >>> probabilities. >>> >>> So, all fine in theory? >>> >>> I have tried plugging some numbers into a spreadsheet, and the >>> results are quite promising. But one observation I have made, is >>> that in real life, results don't seem to "quite fit" the normal >>> distribution. It is perfectly likely for someone who is quite >>> consistent in practice, to have a wildly varying average in >>> competition, and the probabilities end up being almost 0, or > almost >>> 1. Is there someway of "stretching" the margins of the normal >>> probability, so it can cover a wider range of results? One way > would >>> be to multiply the competitors standard deviations by a factor, > but >>> is this mathematically valid? >>> >>> Any help is greatly needed :) >>> >>> Dan Harris - www.cubestation.co.uk :) >>> >>> P.S. I hated Statistics in college ;) >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> Yahoo! Groups Links >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1274. Re: [Speed cubing group] Method for Handicap Competitions
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Jul 2005 15:17:32 -0000

Yeah but that's the problem with anything involving people. What's to stop me from posting an average of 15.00 on UWR list, even thought I've never been under 16? And it's not that unbelievable really. But it might be a bit odd, statistically, I might post a fake average where all the hundredths of a second were under .50 for example, which is statistically very unlikely. It's also unlikely, given enough cubes, that you would beat your long term average by more than 3 SD's. But yeah, I agree with you, but if people want to cheat, then they're only really cheating themselves. Dan :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachin_civilian@y...> wrote: > No Dan but there is a way to beat this. If you are > considering only the best improvement done by a person > then I'll do my worst times in the first 30 solves and > then in the real solves i'll solve normally. So my > scores come out far better than the 30 previous ones. > > Though this looks like a good idea. Perhaps everyone > should time as > many cubes as they possibly can, in a practice session > before the > competition or so. > > Well, I guess we will just have to see what happens on > July 16th! > > Dan :) > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Leyan > Lo > <leyanlo@g...> wrote: > > Where would you get the 30 solves? > > > > If you're using solves that span a large time frame, > this is not a > good > > idea because most people get faster the more they > cube. From the statistics class I took, I remember > the number 40 > (Law of > > large numbers). > > > > > > Dan wrote: > > > Hi Everyone, > > > > > > I would like some input on the following method > for judging a > > > handicap competition, especially whether it is > actually feasible > to > > > use in a competition! > > > > > > 1. From my Statistics course a > long tim ago, > the > > > number 30 seems to ring a bell in my head, ie you > have to make > 30+ > > > solves before the statistics becomes valid. > > > > > > 2. It is perfectly likely for someone > who is quite > > > consistent in practice, to have a wildly varying > average in > > > competition, and the probabilities end up being > almost 0, or > almost > > > 1. Is there someway of "stretching" the margins of > the normal > > > probability, so it can cover a wider range of > results? One way > would > > > be to multiply the competitors standard deviations > by a factor, > but > > > is this mathematically valid? > > > > > > Any help is greatly needed :) > > > > > > Dan Harris - www.cubestation.co.uk :) > > > > > > P.S. 1276. Re: [Speed cubing group] Teamsolve video :)
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 1 Jul 2005 09:16:16 -0600

So, for "Team Cubing," I was under the impression that the cube didn't
have to be on the table, and that one person could hold the cube, and
the other person could make moves while it was still in the other
person's hand. The rules, in my mind, were such that one person would
make a move (I think HTM was the standard) and then the other person
would make a move, but there was no limitation on how you held the
cube.

Ian Winokur and I tried this and it was pretty ridiculous, we didn't
use the same algorithms at all. (R U R' U R U2 R') versus something
else... which can't remember.

I think it might be time for a team Caltech :-P

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Jul 1, 2005, at 8:32 AM, Joël van Noort wrote:

1277. Re: [Speed cubing group] Method for Handicap Competitions
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 1 Jul 2005 09:22:53 -0600

Is there some prize that's really worth it? That's why we can't do handicap competitions as an official event because there's no sure way to ensure honesty. For non-official events, and all that other sort, such as Sunday contests, or speedcubing.com averages, so far, we've been relying on the honesty of the cubers, and it's been working in my opinion. There really aren't that many doubtful records, and if someone lies, I personally don't care, because your sub-14 average on speedcubing.com means nothing to me if I beat you in a tournament. If you end up posting a fake average, then you waste the rest of your life trying to protect this lie, and trying to prevent people from finding out the truth. You're reduced to nothing more than a person who makes up excuses on why his times are so slow. It's just not worth it :-P Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Jul 1, 2005, at 9:17 AM, Dan wrote: > Yeah but that's the problem with anything involving people. > > What's to stop me from posting an average of 15.00 on UWR list, even > thought I've never been under 16? And it's not that unbelievable > really. But it might be a bit odd, statistically, I might post a > fake average where all the hundredths of a second were under .50 for > example, which is statistically very unlikely. It's also unlikely, > given enough cubes, that you would beat your long term average by > more than 3 SD's. > > But yeah, I agree with you, but if people want to cheat, then > they're only really cheating themselves. > > Dan :) > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar > <sachin_civilian@y...> wrote: >> No Dan but there is a way to beat this. If you are >> considering only the best improvement done by a person >> then I'll do my worst times in the first 30 solves and >> then in the real solves i'll solve normally. So my >> scores come out far better than the 30 previous ones. >> >> Though this looks like a good idea. Keep working on >> this. >> >> Sachin >> >> >> --- Dan <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: >> >> >> --------------------------------- >> Hi Leyan, Tyson, >> >> The 30 - 40 solves would have to be fairly near the >> time of the >> competition, yes. As you say, if you were using an out >> of date >> statistic, it wouldn't work, because people's long >> term averages >> would slowly increase as they improved. >> >> This, in my opinion, is the main stumbling block of >> this method, how >> would you get all the competitors to bother to time 30 >> or 40 solves, >> before the day of the tournament? 1278. Re: Method for Handicap Competitions
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Jul 2005 15:31:53 -0000

No, of course not. Maybe you're missing the point. There's no need for a handicap in speedcubing tournaments, because there are a lot of sub 20 cubers, and those cubers who aren't sub20 will have lots to aspire to, and to be honest, if they want to win, they'll have to improve. But for a small competition, where there maybe be on or two sub 20ers, a 30, 40, and a minuter, for example, and the averages are spread wide, then it makes it a lot more fun for everyone involved, rather than just going through the motions to make the eventual, predictable winner. Dan :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Is there some prize that's really worth it? That's why we can't do > handicap competitions as an official event because there's no sure way > to ensure honesty. For non-official events, and all that other sort, > such as Sunday contests, or speedcubing.com averages, so far, we've > been relying on the honesty of the cubers, and it's been working in my > opinion. There really aren't that many doubtful records, and if > someone lies, I personally don't care, because your sub-14 average on > speedcubing.com means nothing to me if I beat you in a tournament. > > If you end up posting a fake average, then you waste the rest of your > life trying to protect this lie, and trying to prevent people from > finding out the truth. You're reduced to nothing more than a person > who makes up excuses on why his times are so slow. It's just not worth > it :-P > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Jul 1, 2005, at 9:17 AM, Dan wrote: > > > Yeah but that's the problem with anything involving people. > > > > What's to stop me from posting an average of 15.00 on UWR list, even > > thought I've never been under 16? And it's not that unbelievable > > really. But it might be a bit odd, statistically, I might post a > > fake average where all the hundredths of a second were under .50 for > > example, which is statistically very unlikely. It's also unlikely, > > given enough cubes, that you would beat your long term average by > > more than 3 SD's. > > > > But yeah, I agree with you, but if people want to cheat, then > > they're only really cheating themselves. > > > > Dan :) > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar > > <sachin_civilian@y...> wrote: > >> No Dan but there is a way to beat this. If you are > >> considering only the best improvement done by a person > >> then I'll do my worst times in the first 30 solves and > >> then in the real solves i'll solve normally. So my > >> scores come out far better than the 30 previous ones. > >> > >> Though this looks like a good idea. Keep working on > >> this. > >> > >> Sachin > >> > >> > >> --- Dan <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > >> > >> > >> --------------------------------- > >> Hi Leyan, Tyson, > >> > >> The 30 - 40 solves would have to be fairly near the > >> time of the > >> competition, yes. Perhaps everyone > >> should time as > >> many cubes as they possibly can, in a practice session > >> before the > >> competition or so. > >> > >> Well, I guess we will just have to see what happens on > >> July 16th! > >> > >> Dan :) > >> > >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Leyan > >> Lo > >> <leyanlo@g...> wrote: > >>> Where would you get the 30 solves? > >>> > >>> If you're using solves that span a large time frame, > >> this is not a > >> good > >>> idea because most people get faster the more they > >> cube. It would > >>> probably be more fair to fit their solve times to an > >> exponential > >> decay > >>> curve up to a constant as a function of time, and > >> then calculate > >> their > >>> expected average and standard deviation for the day > >> of the > >> tournament > >>> from the fit. > >>> > >>> Leyan > >>> > >>> PS. From the statistics class I took, I remember > >> the number 40 > >> (Law of > >>> large numbers). > >>> > >>> > >>> Dan wrote: > >>>> Hi Everyone, > >>>> > >>>> I would like some input on the following method > >> for judging a > >>>> handicap competition, especially whether it is > >> actually feasible > >> to > >>>> use in a competition! > >>>> > >>>> 1. From each competitor, have a long term Mean and > >> Standard > >>>> Deviation Statistic. After the competition, calculate each > >> competitors average. > >> Then > >>>> calculate a Normal Probability, with competition > >> average as > >> the "x" > >>>> statistic, and using the long term Mean and SD. > >> This will > >> calculate > >>>> the probability of the competitor achieving this > >> competition > >>>> average, if they were to make many thousands of > >> averages. > >>>> > >>>> 3. The competitor who has achieved the lowest > >> average > >> probability > >>>> would win, and competitors are ranked in order of > >> ascending > >>>> probabilities. > >>>> > >>>> So, all fine in theory? > >>>> > >>>> I have tried plugging some numbers into a > >> spreadsheet, and the > >>>> results are quite promising. But one observation I > >> have made, is > >>>> that in real life, results don't seem to "quite > >> fit" the normal > >>>> distribution. It is perfectly likely for someone > >> who is quite > >>>> consistent in practice, to have a wildly varying > >> average in > >>>> competition, and the probabilities end up being > >> almost 0, or > >> almost > >>>> 1. Is there someway of "stretching" the margins of > >> the normal > >>>> probability, so it can cover a wider range of > >> results? One way > >> would > >>>> be to multiply the competitors standard deviations > >> by a factor, > >> but > >>>> is this mathematically valid? > >>>> > >>>> Any help is greatly needed :) > >>>> > >>>> Dan Harris - www.cubestation.co.uk :) > >>>> > >>>> P.S. I hated Statistics in college ;) > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> Yahoo! Groups Links > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> --------------------------------- > >> YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > >> > >> > >> Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the > >> web. > >> > >> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > >> speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > >> > >> Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! > >> Terms of Service. > >> > >> > >> --------------------------------- > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> _______________________________________________________ > >> Too much spam in your inbox? Yahoo! Mail gives you the best spam > > protection for FREE! http://in.mail.yahoo.com > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
1279. Re: [Speed cubing group] Teamsolve video :)
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Jul 2005 15:32:58 -0000

No, you should really have it resting on the table, or pass it from person to person, otherwise it's very easy to hold the cube in such a way that only the correct move is possible. That's cheating a bit, don't you think? Dan :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > So, for "Team Cubing," I was under the impression that the cube didn't > have to be on the table, and that one person could hold the cube, and > the other person could make moves while it was still in the other > person's hand. The rules, in my mind, were such that one person would > make a move (I think HTM was the standard) and then the other person > would make a move, but there was no limitation on how you held the > cube. > > Ian Winokur and I tried this and it was pretty ridiculous, we didn't > use the same algorithms at all. (R U R' U R U2 R') versus something > else... which can't remember. > > I think it might be time for a team Caltech :-P > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Jul 1, 2005, at 8:32 AM, Joël van Noort wrote: > > > Hey everybody, > > > > I just uploaded a new video to my website... 1283. Re: loose string on the magic (4x2)
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Jul 2005 18:48:39 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey all you magic solvers, > > I'm totally and completely new to all this. I learned how to solve > the magic just recently, and it turns out that I started timing myself > before I knew the solution very well and on one of my solves my hand > sort of spasmed or something and the magic went into a weird shape. > > I was able to get it back to the reguloar one and realign all the > tiles, but now one of my strings is loose. I only notice it after I > have solved, then undo the solve back to the start. Loose? If it just comes out of the groove and you have to put it back in from time to time, that's normal (I suppose). On my Magic, VERY often I have to re-align strings if I went full speed because something usually pops out of place (even more common on my Master Magic). If the string seems to long, I would recommend cutting it with a razor and replacing it (you can replace any string without removing any additional strings ;)) ...you do have extra strings don't you? :-P I found that the silliest thing somebody can do if they want to get fast at the Magic is to buy only one Magic because the strings break so easily (I discovered this when I got my first broken string on Day 2 or 3). I would definitely recommend a Harry Potter or Simpson magic for spare parts (I've actually used more than two full Magics full of strings to replace broken ones by now). > The loose string, if I am looking at the unlinked side exactly as it > should look before I start the solution, is on the top row 2nd tile > from the right. > > There are 4 diagonal rows of strings that go from the top left to the > bottom right, and it is the 2nd one from the bottom, there is a metal > connector thingy (go easy, I'm new to this :-) Near where this tile > touches the 3rd tile from the right is where the string gets loose. > > If after every solve and undo I pop that string back in things seem to > go fine still, but that gets old after oh... 2 solves. :-D At least it's not like a cube and doesn't have to be scrambled after EVERY solve ;) > Is there a way to fix this string without restringing completely? (I > have no idea how to do that). If that's necessary though, is there a > tutorial vid or site with pics that I can learn how to do that? Jaap's page has directions on how to replace a string or even string a Magic from scratch (which I found to be a total hassle and I don't plan on ever doing again ever in my life--I'd rather buy a new Magic than ever ever go through that again!) I actually plan on making a quick video showing how to replace a string (it takes about 15-30 seconds for me now) :) > Thanks for the help, and please go easy on me if this explanation is > more than what is needed, or if I goofed on something. I'm a noob > magic solver :-D I hope this helps. ~ Bob

1301. Re: Speedcubing.com design
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 02 Jul 2005 18:08:31 -0000

1309. Re: Your best times with 2-steg OLL!

Date: Sun, 03 Jul 2005 09:04:15 -0000

Yeah, your F2L most be extremly fluid. I average around 12 seconds for F2L, so I have to cut off 2 seconds or so to get really good times. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > With a 16.36 average and 3-look LL, you must have a very nice f2l average. > > -Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, François Sechet > <frsechet@y...> wrote: > > 16.36s average for me w/ 3-look LL, and getting better everyday... > > François > > > > gunkr520 a écrit : > > > > > Hi! > > > > > > I'm learning OLL right now and got 16 more to learn. 1315. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 method :-)
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 3 Jul 2005 05:32:57 -0500

I've been playing around with my 4x4 method the last couple of hours. I realized I'd better start practicing, seeing as 2005 is now more than half over. November soon approaches. After hearing about Per's method, I decided to give it a shot. Here are some things I've noticed. 1) I can finish the 1x3x4 blocks on both sides. If you start with two opposing centers, then add the L/D and R/D edge pairs, followed by the corner edge pairs, it's simple and quick. 2) I think it's easier to finish the second center group if the centers are done first. 3) This is fairly simple and intuitive. 4) I've found a simple commutator that does the job, but I suspect there are a couple of tricks that could come in useful. For instance, often, I am only left with two pairs to finish. This is easily solvable by the commutator I found, but three cycles are not. 5) Which parity do you mean? The whole point to 'edges first' solutions is to avoid the nasty parity problem, isn't it? In my practice, I only ran into the easy parity problem once, and never obtained the difficult case. 6) Yep. Hooray for C(O)LL! 7) I pretty much resort to Gille's method to orient and place edges. Easy step. 8) This part I'm having problems with. The only algorithm I have found for this step switches a pair of opposing center pieces. That makes solving the final step somewhat difficult, as you might imagine. If anyone out there has any better suggestions, please let me know. -Mike Bennett --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "James Stuber" <jestuber@v...> wrote: > How about this: > > > > 1) 1x3x4 block > > 2)1x3x4 block on opposite side (like gilles roux's 3x3x3 method) > > 3)Pair up edges using r, l, and U until 3 edges are left > > 4)pair up last 3 edges with a 3 cycle > > 5) Orient edges and fix flip parity > > 6) last corners > > 7) solve edges and fix swap parity > > 8)solve last 4 centers. > > > > > > I'm not sure step 3-7 is the fastest way to go about with a start like this. > Perhaps solving edges directly with 3 edge cycles might be faster. I can't > tell whether or not it would be good for speedcubing simply because I take > so long to do step 4 and 8 ( I only know a 2 center cycle and the two center > algs Per gave below...). Any ideas? > > > > > > _____ > > From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Per Kristen > Fredlund > Sent: Wednesday, June 22, 2005 5:21 AM > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Subject: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 method :-) > > > > Hi James :-) > > For the 4x4x4 revenge/master cube i use the same system as i do for > the 5x5x5 wahn/professor cube. > > The basic steps are as follows: > > (I call this the "Cage" method. ) > > 1. Do first layer completely. This is intuitive. If some centers > are "tricky" to solve they can be left for later if so desired. > basically i solve the cubies in the order i see them. Cubies that make > up blocks are inserted into first layer as a block also, when possible. > > 2. (First twist the middle layers into favorable positions. U can get > quite a few edges and/or centers for free by doing this.) Now do > middle layers edges. This is done by and large with commutator 3- > cycles. Also here one can cycle blocks of cubies when solving them. > Either to solve several edges at the same time or remove badly placed > edges (move to final layer where i do most of the "fishing") or move > bad edges to a better position within the middle layers. > > 3. Final layer corners. First position them (only 2 algs needed) then > orient them (there are 6 easy cases for this). > > 4. Now solve all last layer edges with 3-cycles. This is perhaps the > most tricky step. I use easy commutator 3-cycles with very few setup > moves. In fact the setup is never more than 1 single move. The most > difficult thing about this is to recognize which 3-cycle to do next. I > normally look for 3-cycles that will solve 2 edges with same 3-cycle. > So i do a quick "scan" tracking the edges and see if that is possible. > If not i just settle for a 3-cycle solving 1 edge only. There is of > coz the parity which means im left with only 2 edges to swap. This is > fairly easy also. This is fixed with an inner slice turn and a edge 3- > cycle on this layer. In most cases some setup moves are needed (at > most 2 moves). Remember that it doesn't matter that my parity fix will > mess w the centers. With some luck block 3-cycles can also be used > efficiently. > > 5. Do all the remaining centers with yet more 3-cycles. Block cycles > where possible. With practice u can achieve good cancellations btw 2 > succesive 3-cycles : (simple example) r'urUr'u'd'rU'r'dr - 4 moves are > cancelled. There are also some other center-algs that works on oppsite > faces. One example : (r2b2)*2 > > Benefits of this method are: > > - U solve the cubies into their home position all the time. There is > no tricky parts where u just solve cubies relative to eachother like > when pairing up edgesw Chris' method. > > - Doing lots of 3-cycle it's easy to foresee where all pieces are > going so u get excellent lookahead and very good flow in ur solves > most of the time. > > - Mistakes u do early are not so fatal. There is usually easy fix for > simple mistakes. > > - U don't rely on a fast 3x3x3 method to do the last stage for u. My > method has no "3x3x3-stage" at all. > > - Only one parity, not two. > > One disadvantage is that i probably need about 25% more moves as > compared w Chris' method. So u really have to be a grandmaster of > commutator 3-cycles and utilise block cycling as much as u can. And u > need to make sure u get a good flow. > > A typical solve for me goes like this : > > - (15 secs) First layer done > - (30 secs) Middle layer edges done > - (50-55 secs) Last layer done > - (70-75 secs) All centers are done. Cube is SOLVED!! > > That's it for the 4x4x4 method. The 5x5x5 method has a few more > special cases. A list of these: > > - Make sure while orienting the middle layers after solving first > layer that the extreme middle layer is twisted such that the middle > centers end up in correct location. So u are can actually only twist 2 > of the 3 middle layers freely. Umm u can choose to willingly set up > the 4-spot pattern. But i never do that. > > - For last layer edges i would do the middle edges first. This is > actually a separate step since u can't mix middle edges and outer > edges. Doing the middle ones first gives easier recognition for > solving the outer edges. > > - There are more special algs for exchanging centers between opposite > faces. Example : (r2 E2)*2 or (Ff) r'u'r U r'u r U' (Ff)' > > Writing down these details make it cound more complicated then it > really is ;-) > > Cheers! > > -Per > > > > > > _____ > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > * To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > * To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > <mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscri > be> > > * Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! > <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/> Terms of Service. > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1316. New Website
From: "cue_elf" <cue_elf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Jul 2005 13:48:50 -0000

Hi,

I have just uploaded some of my notes(speedcubing/regular cubing) onto:

http://www.umich.edu/~tanqf/cube/index.html

The page is 75% complete.

I look forward to comments. Thanks for your time!

-Tan

p.s.
Just sth about my cubing experience:-
I started speedcubing beginning of last year. I was using 4-look LL
for about a month b4 switching to Fridrich. It took me around 1 month
to learn Fridrich and after that my times dropped dramatically. 5
months after time zero I was averaging around 20 seconds. Then i
stopped taking averages, and only solved for fun. The cube i use has a
weird color scheme: white-yellow, pink-purple, green blue. Moreover,
it doesn't have springs in its axle. Probably i can get significantly
faster if i switch to cubes with springs.







1317. Program request.
From: nascarjon2001 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Jul 2005 16:17:11 -0000

I was wondering if somebody could make me a little program to make the
random drawing for the Sunday Contest easier on me. What I need is a
program that I can list a bunch of names and randomly draw one. But
here is the catch; Some names will have more than one entry in the
drawing and I need to be able to assign the number of entries to each
name. There may be a free set of stickers for whoever makes me the
nicest program, before next Sunday ;)

Thanks,

Jon
http://www.geocities.com/nascarjon2001




1318. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 method :-)
From: chris brownlee <heretogame@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 4 Jul 2005 09:23:50 -0700 (PDT)

per uses exact same method that i do... did you get your solution off of mcfarren's pages?? Mike Bennett <mikebennett_one@...> wrote: I've been playing around with my 4x4 method the last couple of hours. I realized I'd better start practicing, seeing as 2005 is now more than half over. November soon approaches. After hearing about Per's method, I decided to give it a shot. Here are some things I've noticed. 1) I can finish the 1x3x4 blocks on both sides. If you start with two opposing centers, then add the L/D and R/D edge pairs, followed by the corner edge pairs, it's simple and quick. 2) I think it's easier to finish the second center group if the centers are done first. 3) This is fairly simple and intuitive. 4) I've found a simple commutator that does the job, but I suspect there are a couple of tricks that could come in useful. For instance, often, I am only left with two pairs to finish. This is easily solvable by the commutator I found, but three cycles are not. 5) Which parity do you mean? The whole point to 'edges first' solutions is to avoid the nasty parity problem, isn't it? In my practice, I only ran into the easy parity problem once, and never obtained the difficult case. 6) Yep. Hooray for C(O)LL! 7) I pretty much resort to Gille's method to orient and place edges. Easy step. 8) This part I'm having problems with. The only algorithm I have found for this step switches a pair of opposing center pieces. That makes solving the final step somewhat difficult, as you might imagine. If anyone out there has any better suggestions, please let me know. -Mike Bennett --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "James Stuber" <jestuber@v...> wrote: > How about this: > > > > 1) 1x3x4 block > > 2)1x3x4 block on opposite side (like gilles roux's 3x3x3 method) > > 3)Pair up edges using r, l, and U until 3 edges are left > > 4)pair up last 3 edges with a 3 cycle > > 5) Orient edges and fix flip parity > > 6) last corners > > 7) solve edges and fix swap parity > > 8)solve last 4 centers. > > > > > > I'm not sure step 3-7 is the fastest way to go about with a start like this. > Perhaps solving edges directly with 3 edge cycles might be faster. I can't > tell whether or not it would be good for speedcubing simply because I take > so long to do step 4 and 8 ( I only know a 2 center cycle and the two center > algs Per gave below...). Any ideas? > > > > > > _____ > > From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Per Kristen > Fredlund > Sent: Wednesday, June 22, 2005 5:21 AM > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Subject: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 method :-) > > > > Hi James :-) > > For the 4x4x4 revenge/master cube i use the same system as i do for > the 5x5x5 wahn/professor cube. > > The basic steps are as follows: > > (I call this the "Cage" method. ) > > 1. Do first layer completely. This is intuitive. If some centers > are "tricky" to solve they can be left for later if so desired. > basically i solve the cubies in the order i see them. Cubies that make > up blocks are inserted into first layer as a block also, when possible. > > 2. (First twist the middle layers into favorable positions. U can get > quite a few edges and/or centers for free by doing this.) Now do > middle layers edges. This is done by and large with commutator 3- > cycles. Also here one can cycle blocks of cubies when solving them. > Either to solve several edges at the same time or remove badly placed > edges (move to final layer where i do most of the "fishing") or move > bad edges to a better position within the middle layers. > > 3. Final layer corners. First position them (only 2 algs needed) then > orient them (there are 6 easy cases for this). > > 4. Now solve all last layer edges with 3-cycles. This is perhaps the > most tricky step. I use easy commutator 3-cycles with very few setup > moves. In fact the setup is never more than 1 single move. The most > difficult thing about this is to recognize which 3-cycle to do next. I > normally look for 3-cycles that will solve 2 edges with same 3-cycle. > So i do a quick "scan" tracking the edges and see if that is possible. > If not i just settle for a 3-cycle solving 1 edge only. There is of > coz the parity which means im left with only 2 edges to swap. This is > fairly easy also. This is fixed with an inner slice turn and a edge 3- > cycle on this layer. In most cases some setup moves are needed (at > most 2 moves). Remember that it doesn't matter that my parity fix will > mess w the centers. With some luck block 3-cycles can also be used > efficiently. > > 5. Do all the remaining centers with yet more 3-cycles. Block cycles > where possible. With practice u can achieve good cancellations btw 2 > succesive 3-cycles : (simple example) r'urUr'u'd'rU'r'dr - 4 moves are > cancelled. There are also some other center-algs that works on oppsite > faces. One example : (r2b2)*2 > > Benefits of this method are: > > - U solve the cubies into their home position all the time. There is > no tricky parts where u just solve cubies relative to eachother like > when pairing up edgesw Chris' method. > > - Doing lots of 3-cycle it's easy to foresee where all pieces are > going so u get excellent lookahead and very good flow in ur solves > most of the time. > > - Mistakes u do early are not so fatal. There is usually easy fix for > simple mistakes. > > - U don't rely on a fast 3x3x3 method to do the last stage for u. My > method has no "3x3x3-stage" at all. > > - Only one parity, not two. > > One disadvantage is that i probably need about 25% more moves as > compared w Chris' method. So u really have to be a grandmaster of > commutator 3-cycles and utilise block cycling as much as u can. And u > need to make sure u get a good flow. > > A typical solve for me goes like this : > > - (15 secs) First layer done > - (30 secs) Middle layer edges done > - (50-55 secs) Last layer done > - (70-75 secs) All centers are done. Cube is SOLVED!! > > That's it for the 4x4x4 method. The 5x5x5 method has a few more > special cases. A list of these: > > - Make sure while orienting the middle layers after solving first > layer that the extreme middle layer is twisted such that the middle > centers end up in correct location. So u are can actually only twist 2 > of the 3 middle layers freely. Umm u can choose to willingly set up > the 4-spot pattern. But i never do that. > > - For last layer edges i would do the middle edges first. This is > actually a separate step since u can't mix middle edges and outer > edges. Doing the middle ones first gives easier recognition for > solving the outer edges. > > - There are more special algs for exchanging centers between opposite > faces. Example : (r2 E2)*2 or (Ff) r'u'r U r'u r U' (Ff)' > > Writing down these details make it cound more complicated then it > really is ;-) > > Cheers! > > -Per > > > > > > _____ > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > * To visit your group on the web, go to: > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/ > > * To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > <mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscri > be> > > * Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! > <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/> Terms of Service. > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle games Online puzzle games Computer puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! 1319. Cube meeting, two new fun records
From: "Ron" <ron@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Jul 2005 17:23:57 -0000

Hi friendz,

Yesterday we had a nice cube meeting at Jaap Scherphuis's place.
There were 11 cubers: Lars V, Ton D, Peter J, Ruben G, Joël v N,
Hans vd Z, Jaap S, Koen H, Michael F, Stefan B and me.

Before dinner we had a little handicap competition and Joël beat
us
all by far. Averaging under 15. I haven't practiced 3x3x3 very much
recently (focused on 4x4x4), but Joël in this shape is gonna be a
tough guy to beat!

We also set two new fun records. But I am not sure whether they are
records. Any group having done better maybe?

First record:
Joël and I were competing eachother on Stackmat, scrambling
eachother's cubes. There was only one cube for which we both had the
same time. And that time was 12.88 seconds!

Second record:
Later Joël, Lars, Ton and I were competing eachother on Stackmat.
For one cube the worst time of all 4 was 18.05 seconds (set by me).

Great to have so many cubers living so close!

Have fun,

Ron






1320. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 method :-)
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 3 Jul 2005 13:07:32 -0500

Nope. I came up with it on my own after Per mentioned doing edges first to avoid parity problems. I'm interested in learning where this page you mention is. I suspect I could be much faster with a method like this than a centers first method, because of the recognition time.

-Mike Bennett

From: chris brownlee

per uses exact same method that i do... did you get your solution off of mcfarren's pages??

1321. Re: 4x4x4 method :-)
From: "uberstuberizzle" <jestuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Jul 2005 18:59:42 -0000

One problem I found with this method is too many slice moves. I Can't do fast slice moves for my life, but if you can do 'em it could be fast. Which commuter do you use for two edges left? For centers, r2b2r2b2, ldl' U ld'l' U', and r'urUr'u'd'rU'r'dr are nice. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Nope. Thanks for your time! > > -Tan > > p.s. > Just sth about my cubing experience:- > I started speedcubing beginning of last year. I was using 4-look LL > for about a month b4 switching to Fridrich. It took me around 1 month > to learn Fridrich and after that my times dropped dramatically. 5 > months after time zero I was averaging around 20 seconds. Then i > stopped taking averages, and only solved for fun. The cube i use has a > weird color scheme: white-yellow, pink-purple, green blue. Moreover, > it doesn't have springs in its axle. Probably i can get significantly > faster if i switch to cubes with springs.

1330. Re: [Speed cubing group] forums / php
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachin_civilian@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 5 Jul 2005 07:43:15 +0100 (BST)

Hi Evan. Adding forum to your site is very easy. There is an open source php scripts called phpBB which do all the work for you. It uses MySql for storing the messages and has a lot of advanced features. Plus its free. And if you want to learn php itself then the best place would be www.php.net itself. Check the online documentation its totally exhaustive. And still if u face any problems feel free to ask me :) Sachin --- Evan <evan.gates@...> wrote: --------------------------------- So if I want to add forums to my site, or do other fancy stuff, which I beleive is php, does anyone know a good place to learn? -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk --------------------------------- YAHOO! 1333. Ap-3 lubricant?
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachin_civilian@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 5 Jul 2005 08:11:07 +0100 (BST)

Hello all. I just got my new cubes from a good friend
of mine in Amsterdam.:) Now after working them for a
couple of days i am thinking of applying some lube to
it. One lube i have with me is titled as white AP-3
grease. Is it safe to apply it to my cube? And please
could you tell me what the AP-3 signifies? Does it
mean its petroleum based?

I know u all must be thinking why not use silicon
based lubes but the thing is at the shops here noone
understands what is silicone ... and when asked for a
lubricant they give this AP-3 grease.

Please tell me. I am very afraid to damage these
cubes.

Sachin
