1334. RE: [Speed cubing group] Ap-3 lubricant?
From: "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@...>
To: "'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com'" <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 5 Jul 2005 09:21:18 +0200

Google says that AP3 is not silicone. It is oil, so probably not good for your cube... -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens Sachin Shirwalkar Verzonden: dinsdag 5 juli 2005 9:11 Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group] Ap-3 lubricant? Hello all. I just got my new cubes from a good friend of mine in Amsterdam.:) Now after working them for a couple of days i am thinking of applying some lube to it. One lube i have with me is titled as white AP-3 grease. Is it safe to apply it to my cube? And please could you tell me what the AP-3 signifies? Does it mean its petroleum based? I know u all must be thinking why not use silicon based lubes but the thing is at the shops here noone understands what is silicone ... and when asked for a lubricant they give this AP-3 grease. Please tell me. I am very afraid to damage these cubes. Sachin _______________________________________________________ Too much spam in your inbox? Yahoo! 1338. Re: [Speed cubing group] Ap-3 lubricant?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Jul 2005 10:07:28 -0000

Hi! I have actually heard about ppl using olive oil as lubricant. And it's supposedly quite alrite. My guess is that probably u would use an almost microscopic amount to make sure u don't get oil on ur hands while u cube. Also i don't know if they used the expensive extra virgin or plain cooking variety of the oil :-P Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > Well, I can surely say that I have never heard of aybody else using > cooking oil as lubricant. :-D > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "gillesvdp" > <gillesvdp@y...> wrote: > > Am I the only one to use cooking oil to lube cubes ? > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" > > <bbeer@g...> wrote: > > > Google says that AP3 is not silicone. 1339. cooking oil
From: "mahtianssi" <mahti-anssi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Jul 2005 12:37:01 -0000

I have always used cooking oil (Kultasula rypsiöljy) as a lube,
because my father's friend said that others could be dangerous.

1341. Re: [Speed cubing group] cooking oil
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 5 Jul 2005 09:46:19 -0400

Cooking oil will damage the plastic of the cube. I believe that this is true of all oil based products. You should avoid Vaseline for the same reason. Most people prefer a silicone based lubricant (either a spray or a gel). And you are putting this in the cube, not eating it or inhaling it, so it should be pretty safe. Short term contact with the skin while you are working with it is also harmless. On 7/5/05, mahtianssi <mahti-anssi@luukku.com> wrote: > I have always used cooking oil (Kultasula rypsiöljy) as a lube, > because my father's friend said that others could be dangerous.

1347. Standard grip notation
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Jul 2005 15:56:46 -0000

Hey everyone,

is there a standard practice used to denote your grip when doing a
trigger? If not can we try to think one up?

I'd like to be able to denote when I grab a standard grip, when you
allow for say U and R turns, or U and L turns.

Grips tend to hold the 2x2x3 that runs from F to B along the DL edge
or DR edge, but often you can do others too.

For example the Z perm holds the grip on just the FL and BL edges
allowing R U D turns freely.

Is there a way to denote this simply?

My idea would be to have an alg and denote the grip before the triggers.

such as ([grip notation here] R U R' U' R U R' U') all within the
parenthesis.

and if you change grips you could include that with cube rotations too:
(R U R' U') x' y2 [new grip notation] (some other trigger here)

What does everyone think? I'd like to use this idea to describe
notation on my site, but if one doesn't exist and there isn't much
interest I'll just make one up myself. However I would greatly prefer
this to be a community effort with lots of input all around.

Chris




1348. A New Alg Set
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Jul 2005 16:52:32 -0000

Here's a new alg set for some of the non-standard systems we use.

http://www-personal.umich.edu/~dlli/NewAlgSet.html

I just cooked it up last night after talking to RichardP.

It applies to my method, Richard's, and probably Gille's... and others
in this spirit.

I don't have a name for it yet. Maybe you guys might find some use for
it. Oh and tell me if there should be optimizations or sllightlier
lengthier but well-triggered algs instead.

-Doug

1350. Re: Standard grip notation
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Jul 2005 17:25:40 -0000

Hey Chris,

> is there a standard practice used to denote your grip when doing a
> trigger? If not can we try to think one up?

I don't think one exists...if one does, I've never heard of it.

> I'd like to be able to denote when I grab a standard grip, when you
> allow for say U and R turns, or U and L turns.
>
> Grips tend to hold the 2x2x3 that runs from F to B along the DL edge
> or DR edge, but often you can do others too.

And that's not a very uncommon thing to happen.

> For example the Z perm holds the grip on just the FL and BL edges
> allowing R U D turns freely.
>
> Is there a way to denote this simply?

I think the best way to denote it (to be space efficient and not
clutter algorithms up too much) would be to have some sort of
symbolism for each group. For example, if you are holding the 2x2x3
block you described, that would be for example, "A". It should be
something short and simple, but the tricky part would be to come up
with something that is also related to the grip so that these symbols
don't have to be learned by brute memorization.

> My idea would be to have an alg and denote the grip before the triggers.
>
> such as ([grip notation here] R U R' U' R U R' U') all within the
> parenthesis.
>
> and if you change grips you could include that with cube rotations too:
> (R U R' U') x' y2 [new grip notation] (some other trigger here)

That would be a good way to do it.

> What does everyone think? I'd like to use this idea to describe
> notation on my site, but if one doesn't exist and there isn't much
> interest I'll just make one up myself. However I would greatly prefer
> this to be a community effort with lots of input all around.

I think it would certainly make learning algorithms a bit easier
because it's much easier to remember them with your hands than your
brain (in my opinion, anyway). I use slow-motion videos to show grips
and triggers instead since no such notation exists.

~ Bob




1351. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Standard grip notation
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 5 Jul 2005 10:44:08 -0700

How about giving each finger a number, or something along those lines, then refer to the sticker that the specific finger is touching, somehow. Say your fingers are numbered 1 - 5 on the left and right hands, thumb being one. So your left thumb could be L1 or 1L and your right pinky would be R5, etc. Then naming the stickers. Perhaps you could use the conventional UFR, DBL, FR, etc. where the first letter, indicates the sticker you are touching. So UFR is the sticker on top of the UFR corner, but FRU is the sticker on the front of the up front right corner. Then combine the two, to tell where a finger goes. so L1F would be the left thumb on the front center, etc. So a fairly standard grip for a right handed cuber would be: (L1F L2BL L3B L4BD R1FR R2BUR R3BR R4BDR) Not as brief as what Bob mentioned, but less memorizing, and its simple to figure it out, without going to a lookup table. The formatting can of course be different, whether its separated by commas, or something else between finger, between hands, maybe a new line between hands. Just a rough idea up for criticism. -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.tk On 7/5/05, Bob Burton <bob@cubewhiz.com> wrote: > Hey Chris, > > > is there a standard practice used to denote your grip when doing a > > trigger? If not can we try to think one up? > > I don't think one exists...if one does, I've never heard of it. > > > I'd like to be able to denote when I grab a standard grip, when you > > allow for say U and R turns, or U and L turns. > > > > Grips tend to hold the 2x2x3 that runs from F to B along the DL edge > > or DR edge, but often you can do others too. > > And that's not a very uncommon thing to happen. > > > For example the Z perm holds the grip on just the FL and BL edges > > allowing R U D turns freely. > > > > Is there a way to denote this simply? > > I think the best way to denote it (to be space efficient and not > clutter algorithms up too much) would be to have some sort of > symbolism for each group. For example, if you are holding the 2x2x3 > block you described, that would be for example, "A". It should be > something short and simple, but the tricky part would be to come up > with something that is also related to the grip so that these symbols > don't have to be learned by brute memorization. > > > My idea would be to have an alg and denote the grip before the triggers. > > > > such as ([grip notation here] R U R' U' R U R' U') all within the > > parenthesis. > > > > and if you change grips you could include that with cube rotations too: > > (R U R' U') x' y2 [new grip notation] (some other trigger here) > > That would be a good way to do it. > > > What does everyone think? I'd like to use this idea to describe > > notation on my site, but if one doesn't exist and there isn't much > > interest I'll just make one up myself. However I would greatly prefer > > this to be a community effort with lots of input all around. > > I think it would certainly make learning algorithms a bit easier > because it's much easier to remember them with your hands than your > brain (in my opinion, anyway). I use slow-motion videos to show grips > and triggers instead since no such notation exists. > > ~ Bob > > > > ________________________________ > YAHOO! 1352. Re: Standard grip notation
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Jul 2005 18:17:21 -0000

Hey Chris, Never heard of grip notations, but I think the grip is something most cubers do automatically, depending on the algorithm. When I scramble, I can usually ajust my grip depending on the next three moves. And in your example, if I have an alg with R, U and D moves, if won't grab the cube at the D layer.. So I don't really think an extra notation for grips is necessary. Cya! Joël. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > is there a standard practice used to denote your grip when doing a > trigger? If not can we try to think one up? > > I'd like to be able to denote when I grab a standard grip, when you > allow for say U and R turns, or U and L turns. > > Grips tend to hold the 2x2x3 that runs from F to B along the DL edge > or DR edge, but often you can do others too. > > For example the Z perm holds the grip on just the FL and BL edges > allowing R U D turns freely. > > Is there a way to denote this simply? > > My idea would be to have an alg and denote the grip before the triggers. > > such as ([grip notation here] R U R' U' R U R' U') all within the > parenthesis. > > and if you change grips you could include that with cube rotations too: > (R U R' U') x' y2 [new grip notation] (some other trigger here) > > What does everyone think? I'd like to use this idea to describe > notation on my site, but if one doesn't exist and there isn't much > interest I'll just make one up myself. However I would greatly prefer > this to be a community effort with lots of input all around. > > Chris
1353. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Standard grip notation
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 4 Jul 2005 13:21:14 -0500

If you're going that route, you might as well try this for brevity's sake.

Instead of (L1F L2BL... Just make standard spots for each finger. The first sticker note would always be L1, etc.

A standard grip would look more like (FL * BL BLD BLD FR * BR BRD BRD) where * is a finger not touching the cube.

For the most common grips, I suggest a symbol or implication. G1 or whatever you choose could be standard, and more complicated grips could be noted. Or, you could leave it blank and make it assumed to be a standard grip.

-Mike Bennett


----- Original Message -----
From: Evan Gates
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, July 05, 2005 12:44 PM
Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Standard grip notation


How about giving each finger a number, or something along those lines,
then refer to the sticker that the specific finger is touching,
somehow. Say your fingers are numbered 1 - 5 on the left and right
hands, thumb being one. So your left thumb could be L1 or 1L and
your right pinky would be R5, etc. Then naming the stickers. Perhaps
you could use the conventional UFR, DBL, FR, etc. where the first
letter, indicates the sticker you are touching. So UFR is the sticker
on top of the UFR corner, but FRU is the sticker on the front of the
up front right corner. Then combine the two, to tell where a finger
goes. so L1F would be the left thumb on the front center, etc.

So a fairly standard grip for a right handed cuber would be:
(L1F L2BL L3B L4BD R1FR R2BUR R3BR R4BDR)

Not as brief as what Bob mentioned, but less memorizing, and its
simple to figure it out, without going to a lookup table.

The formatting can of course be different, whether its separated by
commas, or something else between finger, between hands, maybe a new
line between hands. Just a rough idea up for criticism.

-Evan

Until next time, Happy Cubing
http://www.deepcube.tk

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1354. Re: Standard grip notation
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Jul 2005 18:26:48 -0000

Hi Chris Good idea! For algs which use F R and B I use my leftt thumb on the Up Center and my middle finger on the Down Center. So using L for left and R for right and as an alternative to using numbers which Evan suggested, you could use letters for the names T for thumb, I for index, M for middle R for Ring and L for little (or P for pinky. But maybe it would be simpler to number the common grips: #1 LTF-LMB for Left Thumb Front (center) and Left Middle Back center. #2 LTU-LMD for Left Thumb Up (center) and Left Middle Down center. #3 LTL-LMR for Left Thumb Left (center) and Left Middle Right center. #4 RTF-RMB for Right Thumb Front (center) and Right Middle Back center. #5 RTU-RMD for Right Thumb Up (center) and Right Middle Down center. #6 RTL-RMR for Right Thumb Left (center) and Right Middle Right center. ([#2] R2 B2 R F2 R' B2R F2R ) ([#1] R U R' U R U2 R' U2) for sune Slight variations may be understood to be implied, like favoring the side that's turning: Her I'm actually holding the edges under the Thumb and Middle fingers not the centers, because I turn a side and that turning becomes a grip. ([#2,6] F' L' [#6] U' L [#3,6] U R) Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > is there a standard practice used to denote your grip when doing a > trigger? If not can we try to think one up? > > I'd like to be able to denote when I grab a standard grip, when you > allow for say U and R turns, or U and L turns. > > Grips tend to hold the 2x2x3 that runs from F to B along the DL edge > or DR edge, but often you can do others too. > > For example the Z perm holds the grip on just the FL and BL edges > allowing R U D turns freely. > > Is there a way to denote this simply? > > My idea would be to have an alg and denote the grip before the triggers. > > such as ([grip notation here] R U R' U' R U R' U') all within the > parenthesis. > > and if you change grips you could include that with cube rotations too: > (R U R' U') x' y2 [new grip notation] (some other trigger here) > > What does everyone think? I'd like to use this idea to describe > notation on my site, but if one doesn't exist and there isn't much > interest I'll just make one up myself. However I would greatly prefer > this to be a community effort with lots of input all around. > > Chris
1355. Re: Standard grip notation
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Jul 2005 18:29:16 -0000

That is another good point. After one gets accustomed to learning algorithms, the grips become pretty natural when learning a new algorithm. Also, some people have different grip preferences for the same algorithms. (I'm playing both sides on this one ;-)) ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > Hey Chris, > > Never heard of grip notations, but I think the grip is something > most cubers do automatically, depending on the algorithm. When I > scramble, I can usually ajust my grip depending on the next three > moves. And in your example, if I have an alg with R, U and D moves, > if won't grab the cube at the D layer.. So I don't really think an > extra notation for grips is necessary. > > Cya! > > Joël. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > > > is there a standard practice used to denote your grip when doing a > > trigger? 1356. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method :-)
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 4 Jul 2005 13:39:05 -0500

The commutator I use is rU2r' It pairs up UBl edge with the FDl edge and the UBr edge with FDr. When the edges are in the wrong spots, just turn the top pair of to the side with U, do an M, another U turn, and do the algorithm from the opposite side of the cube. I use this to pair up the last 3 sets of edges. It usually only takes two, because I've you can often match up two pairs of edges at the same time, but two executions can solve 3 edge pairs. Also, I ran into the hard parity problem last night and had no recourse but to resort to the very difficult algorithm I used previously. That single algorithm takes me something along the lines of 25 seconds when executed well. I'm very bad at executing it well. I'm also very bad at remembering it. I know there must be a better way to fix it for this method, but I have yet to find it. Any suggestions? -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: uberstuberizzle To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Monday, July 04, 2005 1:59 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method :-) One problem I found with this method is too many slice moves. I Can't do fast slice moves for my life, but if you can do 'em it could be fast. Which commuter do you use for two edges left? For centers, r2b2r2b2, ldl' U ld'l' U', and r'urUr'u'd'rU'r'dr are nice. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Nope. I came up with it on my own after Per mentioned doing edges first to avoid parity problems. I'm interested in learning where this page you mention is. I suspect I could be much faster with a method like this than a centers first method, because of the recognition time. > > -Mike Bennett > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: chris brownlee > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Monday, July 04, 2005 11:23 AM > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 method :-) > > > per uses exact same method that i do... did you get your solution off of mcfarren's pages?? > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com c.. Your use of Yahoo! 1357. Re: A New Alg Set
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Jul 2005 19:26:21 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > ... > I don't have a name for it yet. > ... Maybe something like DLf2leOlle(*) ? More seriously, I guess you already thought about doing more than this with this step, for example not just orient LL-edges, but solve them in the same time and keep four LL-corners as a last step. Could it be an interesting option? Gilles. (*) Doug Li's algorithms for solving the last first-two-layers edge while orienting last-layer edges
1358. Re: Standard grip notation
From: "qwerty1110" <qwerty1110@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Jul 2005 19:49:14 -0000

For everybody who has been cubing a while, grips become natural. Unless there is some extremely strange grip, there is no need for a grip notation. And if there is, use a picture. For those who have just picked up cubing, learning a whole new notation would be annoying and (I think) counterproductive. Videos and pictures are a much better tool for conveying this type of information. Even in text, finger tricks lose their "punch" on the newbies because they're not used to what they feel or look like. This is a visual game, don't fight it. TBTTyler Fox --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > That is another good point. After one gets accustomed to learning > algorithms, the grips become pretty natural when learning a new > algorithm. Also, some people have different grip preferences for the > same algorithms. (I'm playing both sides on this one ;-)) > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > Hey Chris, > > > > Never heard of grip notations, but I think the grip is something > > most cubers do automatically, depending on the algorithm. So I don't really think an > > extra notation for grips is necessary. > > > > Cya! > > > > Joël. > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > Hey everyone, > > > > > > is there a standard practice used to denote your grip when doing a > > > trigger? If not can we try to think one up? > > > > > > I'd like to be able to denote when I grab a standard grip, when you > > > allow for say U and R turns, or U and L turns. > > > > > > Grips tend to hold the 2x2x3 that runs from F to B along the DL > > edge > > > or DR edge, but often you can do others too. > > > > > > For example the Z perm holds the grip on just the FL and BL edges > > > allowing R U D turns freely. > > > > > > Is there a way to denote this simply? > > > > > > My idea would be to have an alg and denote the grip before the > > triggers. > > > > > > such as ([grip notation here] R U R' U' R U R' U') all within the > > > parenthesis. > > > > > > and if you change grips you could include that with cube rotations > > too: > > > (R U R' U') x' y2 [new grip notation] (some other trigger here) > > > > > > What does everyone think? 1362. Re: Ap-3 lubricant?
From: "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Jul 2005 23:42:17 -0000

Hi I have used all kinds of lubricants. Olive oil works, but it depends on the cube. I have actually almost ruined my studio cube, where my regular rubiks.com cube had no problem with the oil. It came off nice and later I used silicon based spray. Now I haven't lubed my cube in about 5 months, and I have no trouble with it, it is still pretty smooth, so it's quite amazing. But don't use the stuff they put in cars... Oh yes, and I have also used body lotion, which makes your hands smell really nice. Michiel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachin_civilian@y...> wrote: > Hello all. I just got my new cubes from a good friend > of mine in Amsterdam.:) Now after working them for a > couple of days i am thinking of applying some lube to > it. One lube i have with me is titled as white AP-3 > grease. Is it safe to apply it to my cube? And please > could you tell me what the AP-3 signifies? Does it > mean its petroleum based? > > I know u all must be thinking why not use silicon > based lubes but the thing is at the shops here noone > understands what is silicone ... and when asked for a > lubricant they give this AP-3 grease. > > Please tell me. I am very afraid to damage these > cubes. > > Sachin > > > > _______________________________________________________ > Too much spam in your inbox? Yahoo! 1374. Fake Teamsolve
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 01:36:22 -0000

Since I have no other cuber nearby, I just invented "fake
teamsolving". Put the cube on a surface and then make turns
alternating between your hands. At no time can both hands touch the
cube. Just did it once so far, got a 1:37.49 which should be very easy
to beat. Try it :-)

Cheers!
Stefan





1375. Re: Standard grip notation
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 01:41:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@z...> wrote: > Hi Stefan, > > Ok, you got me. This is great. How do you compress them so well? I took Bob's slow PLL 11 video: http://www.cubewhiz.com/pll.html It's 1346 KB, though. Then I imported it into Windows Movie Maker and saved it again, choosing the file size. I chose it as small as possible, still keeping the original 320x240 size but reducing to 15 fps (it's a slow demo video anyway, no need for 30 fps). That's all. Cheers! Stefan
1376. Re: Maybe forums would be better...
From: "chris_almich" <chris_almich@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 01:46:01 -0000

1377. Re: Standard grip notation
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 02:04:35 -0000

Had I known I could reduce my videos by that much so easily, I would have done so already. Perhaps I will do that soon with my slow vids if I get a chance. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Michiel van der Blonk" > <blonkm@z...> wrote: > > Hi Stefan, > > > > Ok, you got me. This is great. How do you compress them so well? > > I took Bob's slow PLL 11 video: > http://www.cubewhiz.com/pll.html > > It's 1346 KB, though. Then I imported it into Windows Movie Maker and > saved it again, choosing the file size. I chose it as small as > possible, still keeping the original 320x240 size but reducing to 15 > fps (it's a slow demo video anyway, no need for 30 fps). That's all. > > Cheers! > Stefan

1379. Re: Maybe forums would be better...
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 04:30:38 -0000

> I dunno, it just seems like that would be way easier than this.

I agree with you 100%. I would even take the time to set it up. It's
just hard to move this group to a new forum because so many people
have been here for a long time and fear the change :). Even if we
tried to move the group to a new location, I think lots of people
would still continue to post here, it's just habit.

I don't post nearly as much as a lot of people here, but I have been
reading for about 2 years. A forum would be better because it keeps
all the topics in one group. I wouldn't need to shift through a big
long stream of messages to find the next/previous in a topic. It would
even make it easier to see what messages you havn't read yet. I
realize that many email programs can sort the messages in an appealing
way, but I happen to check the board from the internet and don't
really want all these messages coming to my inbox.

I think the only way we'll move to a new location is when Yahoo
explodes and we're all forced to move. I don't plan on that happening
any time soon, so until then, I think we're stuck with this.

-Chris




1380. Slow OLL Videos!! YAY! :-D
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 05:01:23 -0000

Finally, I have created and posted slow videos for all 57 orientation
cases.

http://www.cubewhiz.com/oll.html

Most videos are under 1MB each. I thought I had Windows Movie Maker
on my PC, but I guess it was uninstalled. I will get around to
reducing file sizes eventually, but these will do for now.

I hope they will be useful for anybody trying to learn the
orientations. I know I find videos helpful, especially for cases with
strange triggers and grips. :)

~ Bob

1382. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Maybe forums would be better...
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachin_civilian@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 6 Jul 2005 07:28:03 +0100 (BST)

Ya i totally agree. In my institute we have a common discussion forum based on phpBB containing about 2000 users. With about 1000 posts everyday. and everything is going very smoothly. with phpBB the advantage is that you can have plugins to it also like we just had a shoutbox added to our forum and its a craze now. Also the practice of administrating the forum is a piece of cake - everything is already providied by the developers. Also there are searching facilities, pm users and many more things... I would love to see a php forum for spedcubing but the webspace i get dosent allow php scripts to run .. :( So i would request others who have registered domains(Joel, Dan, etc) to try out this thing, its really easy to setup you just need a MySql database additionally. 1384. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method :-)
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 5 Jul 2005 01:57:02 -0500

Bwahahahahaha. Victory. After much playing around with my 4x4 (read: working), I found a simple move to swap two center pieces on adjacent sides. Using this move, coupled with r2u2r2u2, I've managed to solve my 4x4 with this new method. Also, I've found a way around the difficult parity, but it's intuitive and difficult. I still think someone out there has to know a simpler way to fix this. Anywho, November is creeping up quickly, and I'd like to be ready by then, so if Per could just share all his secrets right now, that would be great. =) -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: uberstuberizzle To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Monday, July 04, 2005 1:59 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method :-) One problem I found with this method is too many slice moves. I Can't do fast slice moves for my life, but if you can do 'em it could be fast. Which commuter do you use for two edges left? For centers, r2b2r2b2, ldl' U ld'l' U', and r'urUr'u'd'rU'r'dr are nice. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Nope. I came up with it on my own after Per mentioned doing edges first to avoid parity problems. I'm interested in learning where this page you mention is. I suspect I could be much faster with a method like this than a centers first method, because of the recognition time. > > -Mike Bennett > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: chris brownlee > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Monday, July 04, 2005 11:23 AM > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 method :-) > > > per uses exact same method that i do... did you get your solution off of mcfarren's pages?? > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ YAHOO! 1392. Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 11:57:10 -0000

There are more techniques to memorize the cube than piece by piece : you can have a photographic memory which only requires to look once at each face to know it completely. And then with 6 images you can build a cube inside your head and then start to solve it. I believe he uses a memory technique of that kind. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > Yeah, he's just unbelievable. He has (I think at least) 20 pieces to > memorize and that makes 4 per second. It's amazing. He solves it very > quick to for blindfolded solving. He must know a lot of algorithms for > special cases. > > /Gunnar Krig

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachin_civilian@y...> wrote: > > PS: Stefan you dont have to type [quote] [/quote] > everytime. theres a buton below each reply that does > the job for you. Yes I know. But it's painful. Note I'm not talking about full quotes but selected quotes. Say I want to answer several parts of your post separately, i.e. alternating between your quote and my comments (which is not that unusual). I have to type [quote][/quote] a lot, that's what I meant. I know there are two buttons for these but they're useless since they add at the *end* of the text. Stefan

1395. Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 12:38:02 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > Yeah, he's just unbelievable. He has (I think at least) 20 pieces to > memorize and that makes 4 per second. Let's say you have a 12-cycle for edges and an 8-cycle for corners, then it's 18 pieces. And I could imagine for his record it was an easier (not necessarily lucky) case needing even fewer pieces. > He must know a lot of algorithms for special cases. As far as I know he uses four different algorithms. Stefan

1397. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Maybe forums would be better...
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 6 Jul 2005 10:13:29 -0400

On 7/6/05, burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > I don't post nearly as much as a lot of people here, but I have been > reading for about 2 years. A forum would be better because it keeps > all the topics in one group. I wouldn't need to shift through a big > long stream of messages to find the next/previous in a topic. It would > even make it easier to see what messages you havn't read yet. I > realize that many email programs can sort the messages in an appealing > way, but I happen to check the board from the internet and don't > really want all these messages coming to my inbox. Set up a Gmail account. It is an excellent way to read the messages in this group. You can set up a filter to keep the group messages in a separate category so they don't clutter your inbox. Your view of the messages has one line per topic, and topics with unread messages are clearly marked.
1398. Re: Maybe forums would be better...
From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 14:43:38 -0000

I TOTALLY agree and have tried to tell everyone we should use forums many a time. but everyone is too comfortable here....forums have sooo many uses, if there's one thread that has a ton of great information, you'd better bookmark it before it gets too far back in the archive, because without a forum search, you'll never ever see it again. and forums are much easier to read, easier to stay up on, there can easily be a ton of different threads going on for a long time, they don't all get backed up until we don't remember if something has been said before etc. yes, I agree, but alas, I'm afraid it will never happen. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "chris_almich" <chris_almich@y...> wrote: > Well, I am new to this site and after coming here a few times, I am > quite annoyed by the layout, (all the Re:s that take up pages and > pages). Well, I just think it would be better if we found a website > with forums. I just think that would be better than this. > Perhaps the world cubing association forums you can find a link to on > speedcubing.com. > > I dunno, it just seems like that would be way easier than this.

1402. Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 15:10:22 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@y...> wrote: > > There are more techniques to memorize the cube than piece by piece : > you can have a photographic memory which only requires to look once at > each face to know it completely. I don't really believe in that kind of thing. Just recently I read in a psychology book about an experiment where kids were shown an Alice in Wonderland picture and afterwards they were asked how many stripes the tail of the cat in the tree has. Surprise, surprise, there was a boy who got the right answer 13 and he explained that he saw the picture in his mind and counted. Big deal. Give me enough kids and I'll certainly find one who gets it right and they probably all try to see it in their mind and count so when someone gets it right then that will be his explanation. Stupid experiment! Tell me: With all those people who can memorize a page of a phone book completely and exactly in just one short look, why did none of them ever break a single world record for memorizing? All the records you can see here must make them laugh: http://www.recordholders.org/en/records/quick-memory/quick-memory.html I think what created this myth of photographic memory are stupid people misinterpreting things. Take cubing for example, very similar story: How often do I hear people around me whisper to each other "wow he doesn't even look"? It mostly happens when I scramble or they even say it because they don't realize I *do* look between the steps of the method, e.g. between OLL and PLL. They just misinterpret things and of course they tell others and the story begins... And consider the "Rubik's Cubic Compendium" book in which Mr Rubik himself was involved so it's kinda official. Chapter 6 is about photographic memory and stuff and the author ends by saying "And he did not even look at it" after describing how he saw a guy twist a cube in a train without looking at the cube. The chapter though makes it so obvious that the author is a non-cuber and probably has no clue about it so I claim he was probably wrong (yes I know blindsolving is possible but I hear the "he doesn't even look" much more often when I scramble than when I actually blindsolve). Another myth is extreme speedreading. Tony Buzan, a guy well-known for memorizing/speedreading/mindmapping books (though I don't like him very much because I'm convinced he makes up lots of the "facts" he claims in his books) writes in his speedreading book about a girl who could read 416,250 words per minute if she could only flip the pages fast enough. Assuming average word length of 5 letters and 60*60 letters fitting on one page that's 9.6 pages per second! And she's supposed to know everything perfectly then. Apart from the speed itself, I'd like to ask again why she doesn't simply shatter the speedreading world records (yes there are even world championships). And why 416,250? How can they find out so exactly? Why did Tony not mention any details about how it was measured? > I believe he uses a memory technique of that kind. As far as I know he doesn't. Stefan

And if you click on "Polls Help" on the upper right and then "How do I restrict access to this feature?" on the lower right, the description makes it sound like this feature is just turned off for us non-moderators. So I'd say you blame the wrong people ;-) Stefan

1405. [Speed cubing group] Re: Maybe forums would be better...
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 15:30:14 -0000

> How can you make that sound like an advantage? Do we need more here?
> I'd rather claim the opposite.
>
> Stefan

I wasn't saying it was an advantage, because we all know that this
group needs no maintanence whatsoever. Yahoo pretty much takes care of
that. I was simply saying how easy it is to get a phpBB server up and
running. I just don't think that moving to a php forum would require
that much more work for whoever decided the host the thing (which I
would be glad to do).

I must admire your dedication to this group. It's incredible. Can you
see no benefits in moving to a phpbb forum? If quoting someone is your
main beef, then let me see if there is a way around type [quote][/quote].

This group does function fine without being on a forum, but I think
the added features of a forum as well as the organization of a forum
would only improve the experience. I doubt we'll ever make the move,
but I sure would be happy if we did.

-Chris




1406. [Speed cubing group] Re: Maybe forums would be better...
From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 15:38:10 -0000

> I must admire your dedication to this group. It's incredible. Can you
> see no benefits in moving to a phpbb forum? If quoting someone is your
> main beef, then let me see if there is a way around type
[quote][/quote].

there is a way around it....on most forums, there's a button you click
above the reply that says QUOTE, you click it then type your quote in
a little box, then click okay and it puts the QUOTE tags around it for
you.


> This group does function fine without being on a forum, but I think
> the added features of a forum as well as the organization of a forum
> would only improve the experience. I doubt we'll ever make the move,
> but I sure would be happy if we did.

me too....one thing I hate about this type of group is that you can't
easily search through the archives. I remember a lot of threads I'd
love to go back and reread, that have great information, but I simply
can't find them because the only search on this goes through only like
50 posts at a time or so. and out of the, what, 15 thousand+ that are
already here, that will take a while.




1407. [Speed cubing group] Re: Maybe forums would be better...
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 15:46:02 -0000

Just a couple features that we add to this group by moving to a phpbb
based forum:

-> Seperate forums for different catagories like theory, blindfold,
fridrich, general, etc...

-> MUCH more powerful search that returns full threads rather than
individual posts.

-> Message formatting with various font styles and sizes as well as
allowing quoting, code display, image posting and automatic URL linking

-> Support of standard and extended BBCode tags and controlled HTML tags

-> Polls! (for whatever reason we don't have them now)

-> Email-like private messaging system

-> Supports local, remote and uploadable avatars

-> You can EDIT your post (I'm pretty sure you can't do this now)

..

I know we may not /need/ any of these features, but they would be nice
to have.

-Chris

1410. Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 16:16:12 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > And why 416,250? How can they find out so exactly? Why did Tony not > mention any details about how it was measured? Ok, gotta admit I found the explanation. They made a test and she read 1390 words in a fifth of a second. Somehow I wonder though how they measured so exactly, but it explains the huge number since 1390*5*60=417000. Of course it's slightly off so they must've actually measured 0.20036 seconds. Btw, she's Russian and the scientists testing her are Russian, too. Not that I have anything against them, but I don't necessarily trust everything that comes from Russia, especially if it's something spectacular. And unfortunately Tony didn't bother to mention when this happened (the text makes it sound like it wasn't too long ago, though). And he only provides her first name Eugenia. I tried to find out any more details about her on the web but I've been unsuccessful. Summary: This kind of stuff are myths, stories that people just made up to impress other people or they misinterpreted things they don't understand. And then they tell someone who tells someone else and so on and on and numbers get bigger and bigger and more and more specatular. Stefan
1411. Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 16:22:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > And why 416,250? How can they find out so exactly? Why did Tony not > > mention any details about how it was measured? > > Ok, gotta admit I found the explanation. They made a test and she read > 1390 words in a fifth of a second. Somehow I wonder though how they > measured so exactly, but it explains the huge number since > 1390*5*60=417000. Ok, one more thing about this. Even though it's technically correct to say her reading speed is 417000 words per minute when she can read 1390 words in a fifth of a second, it's completely misleading. The duration must be mentioned, too, otherwise someone who reads it will tell someone else that the girl read 417000 words in one minute which she didn't. That's exactly one of the ways these myths are created. Stefan P.S. I wish I could solve the 5x5 in 92 seconds just because I can solve the 3x3 in 20 seconds...
1412. Re: Maybe forums would be better...
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

> http://www.twistypuzzles.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=3720

Fair enough. We could set the message limit to 15 or so per page. That
sounds reasonable. I believe there are phpbb mods available that allow
a user to select if he/she wants to view avatars, but if not we could
just take vote to see how many people really want avatars and possibly
disable them globally.

As for the reverse thread option, phpbb has sorting options at the
bottom of each thread.

I'm just trying to make this sound appealing to everyone ;)

-Chris




1413. Re: Maybe forums... (why we don't have polls on this group)
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 16:27:36 -0000

Hey everyone,

When I started this group it was a yahoo club, before there were even
groups. That gave you the option to hide your e-mail address, and
when things converted over to groups a couple years later that option
was kept. Only groups where you are NOT allowed to hide your e-mail
address can have polls.

The fault is in this group having been successful for too long :-D

Chris

> I claim that's not the fault of the system but the choice of our
> moderators. Go here:
>
> http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/polls

> "Polls Help" on the upper right and then "How do I restrict access to
> this feature?" on the lower right, the description makes it sound like
> this feature is just turned off for us non-moderators.

1414. Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 17:02:42 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > they probably all try to > see it in their mind and count so when someone gets it right then that > will be his explanation. Stupid experiment! This kind of thing becomes more credible when the person has a high level of knowledge/skill (genius even) in the relevant area. E.g. Mozart writing down the score of a piece (how long?) after a single hearing: presumably the "patterns" he knew made this easy for him. Similarly with chess players doing simultaneous blindfold displays: I doubt that they need to make artificial associations like "black queen on a4" = "Donald Duck eating ketchup and fries" to keep the various games in mind. I also doubt that J.B.O. makes up a lengthy story in 5sec, even if he is still associating artificial images with the cube pieces. Perhaps we'll find out someday what he really does. > All the records you > can see here must make them laugh: > http://www.recordholders.org/en/records/quick-memory/quick- memory.html And so they should. Don't they make you laugh? Cubing is funny, too, of course. > I think what created this myth of photographic memory are stupid > people misinterpreting things. Vaguely recall that Marvin Minsky claimed to have investigated a number of these cases. He decided they were all untrue, but he was probably trying to "prove" some equally dubious point. (Where did he write about it, though?) > a girl who > could read 416,250 words per minute if she could only flip the pages > fast enough. It does indeed sound like something from the old Soviet school. Old joke: "I took a speed reading course and read 'War and Peace' in twenty minutes. It involves Russia." (W. Allen) Mike
1415. Re: [Speed cubing group] musical talent (was: Re: J Bernett Orlando)
From: François Sechet <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 19:30:43 +0200

nothing to do with the initial topic though, if you feel like reading my babbling on music, just scroll down :-D mike_go_uk a ï¿½crit : > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > they probably all try to > > see it in their mind and count so when someone gets it right then > that > > will be his explanation. Stupid experiment! > > This kind of thing becomes more credible when the person has a high > level of knowledge/skill (genius even) in the relevant area. E.g. > Mozart writing down the score of a piece (how long?) after a single > hearing: presumably the "patterns" he knew made this easy for him. > Yeah, just... don't bring up the music topic with me... Supposedly, Berlioz wrote the whole Symphonie Fantastique in one night, which gives a rate of something in the order of 10 notes/sec if you consider he started writing at, say, 6PM and stopped at 9AM. Which is, not possible... That's one of these myths... Also, I became quite expert in the field of Russian composers and more specifically Shostakovitch. Anyway, it is said (and I have reasons to believe it is true, actually no musician I know ever doubted that) that he was sitting in a pub one day with his friend and conductor and composer Nikolai Malko. Back then, there was one very popular song all over the world called "Tea for Two" (excerpt from "No, No, Nanette" by Vincent Youman). I know everyone here knows that song even if the title doesn't ring a bell, especially the French members of that group (vous vous souvenez, "la Grande Vadrouille", avec de Funï¿½s et Bourvil et bien d'autres encore? le truc qu'il siffle dans les bains turcs, et bah c'est ï¿½a...) Anyway, Shosta said to Malko, "come on, that thing sucks I bet I can orchestrate it in less than one hour" (well I guess that's not the way he said it,especially cuz both of them didn't speak one word of English back then) so they sat down in the pub, ordered a vodka and started to write it. 40 minutes later Shosta was done, with a brilliant orchestration I still can't believe someone wrote anything so cool. I think Malko was done about 30 minutes later, I've never heard his version of it anyway, but a while later, Shosta took that music again, thought it would be cool to insert it after the 3rd act of his ballett "the golden Age". Too bad for him, the only piece of that ballet that was "encored" every evening was that one piece, which doesn't have anything to do with the rest of the ballet anyway. that was just my last ï¿½0.02 before taking the plane tomorrow and switching to plain US$... Oh, and yeah, that post was totally inadequate, yeah... just felt like spending 10 mins on it instead of packing my stuff d'oh. Oh and if anyone wants to do something, I'll be in the Detroit, MI, area between tomorrow evening and next Wednesday. Won't have a chance to drive very far from home though. Drop me a line (Jon I don't forget you maybe planned something, just tell me before next wednesday if you can) Franï¿½ois ___________________________________________________________________________ Appel audio GRATUIT partout dans le monde avec le nouveau Yahoo! Messenger Tï¿½lï¿½chargez cette version sur http://fr.messenger.yahoo.com

Which is, not > possible... That's one of these myths... That's a good one. 1419. Re: [Speed cubing group] musical talent
From: François Sechet <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 20:06:39 +0200

to both of you... a friend of mine, Dorel Fodoreanu (member of the Enescu quartet) intended to record Brahms double concerto alone playing the cello part and then recording the violin part note by note and adding everything together... Also, I bought a CD recently, Fazil Say playing the Rite of Spring (Stravinsky) alone. Yeah, except that's supposedly for 2 pianos (4 hands? not sure). Poor sound engineer... especially in the very last movement... Oh, and speaking of Ysaï¿½e, I had the pleasure to play on his personal piano 2 months ago... The thing seriously needs a huge tuning, other than that it was fun to play on his piano. (It's been donated to a school not far from where I live). That was just a side note, nothing to do with talent... Franï¿½ois - sorry for the posts... Tyson Mao a ï¿½crit : > Leyan Lo also learned the Brahms Violin Concerto in a week. How you do > that, is beyond me too. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Jul 6, 2005, at 11:46 AM, Leyan Lo wrote: > > > Ysaye is said to have outlined all six of his violin sonatas in one > > night. How you outline music that sounds like the way his sonatas > > sound > > is beyond me. > > > > Leyan > > > > > > mike_go_uk wrote: > >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Franï¿½ois Sechet > >> <frsechet@y...> wrote: > >> > >>> Yeah, just... don't bring up the music topic with me... Supposedly, > >>> Berlioz wrote the whole Symphonie Fantastique in one night, which > >> > >> gives > >> > >>> a rate of something in the order of 10 notes/sec if you consider he > >>> started writing at, say, 6PM and stopped at 9AM. Which is, not > >>> possible... That's one of these myths... > >> > >> > >> That's a good one. But perhaps he /composed/ it in his head one night > >> in all its detail and spent the next month /writing down/ the notes. > >> ;) > >> > >> Mike > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> Yahoo! Groups Links > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------------ > YAHOO! 1420. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method :-) parity
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 18:52:40 -0000

Hi Mike, There was a long thread on this a while ago. I'm not about to try to search for it, but Chris mentioned that mathematically parity boils down to 1 quarter turn. I demonstrated that it was true, but I took 64 moves. Chris takes 15. Anyway, if you solve the Right and Left sides, with or without bothering with any of the Up edges, you can check for parity. If you have a parity problem you make one vertical slice quarter turn, then solve the rest with even-numbered moves. Cheers, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Bwahahahahaha. Victory. > > After much playing around with my 4x4 (read: working), I found a simple move to swap two center pieces on adjacent sides. Using this move, coupled with r2u2r2u2, I've managed to solve my 4x4 with this new method. Also, I've found a way around the difficult parity, but it's intuitive and difficult. I still think someone out there has to know a simpler way to fix this. Anywho, November is creeping up quickly, and I'd like to be ready by then, so if Per could just share all his secrets right now, that would be great. =) > > -Mike Bennett > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: uberstuberizzle > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Monday, July 04, 2005 1:59 PM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method :-) > > > > One problem I found with this method is too many slice moves. I Can't > do fast slice moves for my life, but if you can do 'em it could be > fast. Which commuter do you use for two edges left? > > For centers, r2b2r2b2, ldl' U ld'l' U', and r'urUr'u'd'rU'r'dr are nice. > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" > <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > Nope. I came up with it on my own after Per mentioned doing edges > first to avoid parity problems. I'm interested in learning where this > page you mention is. I suspect I could be much faster with a method > like this than a centers first method, because of the recognition time. > > > > -Mike Bennett > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: chris brownlee > > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > Sent: Monday, July 04, 2005 11:23 AM > > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 method :-) > > > > > > per uses exact same method that i do... did you get your solution > off of mcfarren's pages??
1421. Re: Maybe forums would be better...
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 18:59:10 -0000

Hi Stefan, Try typing [quote] [/quote], select them, hit control c, and then inset them at the beginning of the part you want to quote. Then select [/quote] and drag it to the end of what you are quoting. It's a lot faster than typing. YOu can insert and drag many times. Cheers, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "chris_almich" > > > <chris_almich@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Well, I am new to this site and after coming here a few times, I > > am > > > > quite annoyed by the layout, (all the Re:s that take up pages > and > > > > pages). > > > > > > That's not the fault of the system, that's the fault of the people > > > misusing it. > > > > > > Stefan > > > > Yes, but with a nice PHP forum, it wouldnt happen at all. > > You can full-quote in those forums as well. And neither here nor there > is it necessary. Quote the parts you're answering and leave the rest > out. Very simple. Actually it's simpler here than in phpBB, since I > have to type extra [quote] and [/quote] a lot, which is very annoying. > > Stefan > > P.S. What happened to your forum? I must admit I didn't bookmark it... > :-(

1428. Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 13:05:30 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@y...> wrote: > There are more techniques to memorize the cube than piece by piece : > you can have a photographic memory which only requires to look once at > each face to know it completely. I don't really believe in that kind of thing. Just recently I read in a psychology book about an experiment where kids were shown an Alice in Wonderland picture and afterwards they were asked how many stripes the tail of the cat in the tree has. Surprise, surprise, there was a boy who got the right answer 13 and he explained that he saw the picture in his mind and counter. Big deal. Give me enough kids and I'll certainly find one who gets it right and they probably all try to see it in their mind and count so when someone gets it right then that will be his explanation. Stupid experiment! Tell me: With all those people who can memorize a page of a phone book completely and exactly in just one short look, why did none of them ever break a single world record for memorizing? All the records you can see here must make them laugh: http://www.recordholders.org/en/records/quick-memory/quick-memory.html I think what created this myth of photographic memory are stupid people misinterpreting things. Take cubing for example, very similar story: How often do I hear people around me whisper to each other "wow he doesn't even look"? It mostly happens when I scramble or they even say it because they don't realize I *do* look between the steps of the method, e.g. between OLL and PLL. They just misinterpret things and of course they tell others and the story begins... And consider the "Rubik's Cubic Compendium" book in which Mr Rubik himself was involved so it's kinda official. Chapter 6 is about photographic memory and stuff and the author ends by saying "And he did not even look at it" after describing how he saw a guy twist a cube in a train without looking at the cube. The chapter though makes it so obvious that the author is a non-cuber and probably has no clue about it so I claim he was probably wrong (yes I know blindsolving is possible but I hear the "he doesn't even look" much more often when I scramble than when I actually blindsolve). Another myth is extreme speedreading. Tony Buzan, a guy well-known for memorizing/speedreading/mindmapping books (though I don't like him very much because I'm convinced he makes up lots of the "facts" he claims in his books) writes in his speedreading book about a girl who could read 416,250 words per minute if she could only flip the pages fast enough. Assuming average word length of 5 letters and 60*60 letters fitting on one page that's 9.6 pages per second! And she's supposed to know everything perfectly then. Apart from the speed itself, I'd like to ask again why she doesn't simply shatter the speedreading world records (yes there are even world championships). And why 416,250? How can they find out so exactly? Why did Tony not mention any details about how it was measured? > I believe he uses a memory technique of that kind. As far as I know he doesn't. Stefan

1432. [Speed cubing group] Re: Maybe forums would be better...

Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 00:30:33 -0000

Not discrediting the php forums, but...

I think Google groups is a viable option. Last time I looked, it was
still in beta, but I haven't noticed any problems.

When this topic last came up, some people opposed switching because
they used this group via email. I'm pretty sure that Google groups
works that way too.

BUT... On the site, it keeps topics in context just like gmail or a
forum.

I'm not sure it has features like polls, etc... but if it's anything
like gmail, load times should at least be a little better than yahoo.

1436. Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 15:28:30 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > And why 416,250? How can they find out so exactly? Why did Tony not > mention any details about how it was measured? Ok, gotta admit I found the explanation. They made a test and she read 1390 words in a fifth of a second. Somehow I wonder though how they measured so exactly, but it explains the huge number since 1390*5*60=417000. Of course it's slightly off so they must've actually measured 0.20036 seconds. Btw, she's Russian and the scientists testing her are Russian, too. Not that I have anything against them, but I don't necessarily trust everything that comes from Russia, especially if it's something spectacular. And unfortunately Tony didn't bother to mention when this happened (the text makes it sound like it wasn't too long ago, though). And he only provides her first name Eugenia. I tried to find out any more details about her on the web but I've been unsuccessful. Summary: This kind of stuff are myths, stories that people just made up to impress other people or they misinterpreted things they don't understand. And then they tell someone who tells someone else and so on and on and numbers get bigger and bigger and more and more specatular. Stefan
1437. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 6 Jul 2005 09:24:22 -0600

Memory is a muscle and it is trained. The reason why we find this so incredible is because we are cubers and for blindfold solving, it hasn't come to the point where memory has become an issue. Now, I don't really think that Bernett is special. We, as speed cubers, just simply haven't trained our memories. I don't know if 8 second memorization is possible for us, as my father isn't an international grand master, but I do believe with practice and dedication, 15 to 20 second memorization should be possible. After that, I'll just have to rely on my speed cubing speed for my competitive edge. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Jul 6, 2005, at 9:10 AM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "gillesvdp" > <gillesvdp@y...> wrote: >> >> There are more techniques to memorize the cube than piece by piece : >> you can have a photographic memory which only requires to look once > at >> each face to know it completely. > > I don't really believe in that kind of thing. Just recently I read in > a psychology book about an experiment where kids were shown an Alice > in Wonderland picture and afterwards they were asked how many stripes > the tail of the cat in the tree has. Surprise, surprise, there was a > boy who got the right answer 13 and he explained that he saw the > picture in his mind and counted. Big deal. Give me enough kids and > I'll certainly find one who gets it right and they probably all try to > see it in their mind and count so when someone gets it right then that > will be his explanation. Stupid experiment! > > Tell me: With all those people who can memorize a page of a phone book > completely and exactly in just one short look, why did none of them > ever break a single world record for memorizing? All the records you > can see here must make them laugh: > http://www.recordholders.org/en/records/quick-memory/quick-memory.html > > I think what created this myth of photographic memory are stupid > people misinterpreting things. Take cubing for example, very similar > story: How often do I hear people around me whisper to each other "wow > he doesn't even look"? It mostly happens when I scramble or they even > say it because they don't realize I *do* look between the steps of the > method, e.g. between OLL and PLL. They just misinterpret things and of > course they tell others and the story begins... And consider the > "Rubik's Cubic Compendium" book in which Mr Rubik himself was involved > so it's kinda official. Chapter 6 is about photographic memory and > stuff and the author ends by saying "And he did not even look at it" > after describing how he saw a guy twist a cube in a train without > looking at the cube. The chapter though makes it so obvious that the > author is a non-cuber and probably has no clue about it so I claim he > was probably wrong (yes I know blindsolving is possible but I hear the > "he doesn't even look" much more often when I scramble than when I > actually blindsolve). > > Another myth is extreme speedreading. Tony Buzan, a guy well-known for > memorizing/speedreading/mindmapping books (though I don't like him > very much because I'm convinced he makes up lots of the "facts" he > claims in his books) writes in his speedreading book about a girl who > could read 416,250 words per minute if she could only flip the pages > fast enough. Assuming average word length of 5 letters and 60*60 > letters fitting on one page that's 9.6 pages per second! And she's > supposed to know everything perfectly then. Apart from the speed > itself, I'd like to ask again why she doesn't simply shatter the > speedreading world records (yes there are even world championships). > And why 416,250? How can they find out so exactly? Why did Tony not > mention any details about how it was measured? > >> I believe he uses a memory technique of that kind. > > As far as I know he doesn't. > > Stefan > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1438. Re: forums
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 7 Jul 2005 14:00:56 +1000

Here's what I understand:

1. Some want email access to the forum
2. Others want web access to the forum, with fancy features
3. Many also want permanent archives (our history is important)

Let's make these the requirements for any plan of action. Also, let's
not make any immediate decision until we have (3) sorted out.

Justification of requirements:

1. Email is the most flexible solution for powerusers. With the right
tools and expertise, each individual to decide how they wish to
interface with the forum, and not be forced to use a particular
interface. If you wanted, you could make your inbox look just like a
fancy web-based forum, but better integrated with your personal
operating environment. This is important to me at least.

2. Non powerusers still need a ready made solution, and so a web
interface can do that job well.

3. If we are going to move to another host, let's make sure we can
transfer the whole message archive across because there are a great
number of interesting and significant posts in the archives that people
still refer to today.

Ryan


1439. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: forums
From: "Jeremy Fleischman" <jeremyfleischman@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 6 Jul 2005 22:37:16 -0700

I agree, we should find a solution that satisfies all of these
conditions. But I truly believe that the switch should be made, since it
seems that the majority want a forum setup. Correct me if I'm wrong.

-----Original Message-----
From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

1. Some want email access to the forum
2. Others want web access to the forum, with fancy features
3. Many also want permanent archives (our history is important)

Let's make these the requirements for any plan of action. Also, let's
not make any immediate decision until we have (3) sorted out.

Justification of requirements:

1. Email is the most flexible solution for powerusers. With the right
tools and expertise, each individual to decide how they wish to
interface with the forum, and not be forced to use a particular
interface. If you wanted, you could make your inbox look just like a
fancy web-based forum, but better integrated with your personal
operating environment. This is important to me at least.

2. Non powerusers still need a ready made solution, and so a web
interface can do that job well.

transfer the whole message archive across because there are a great
number of interesting and significant posts in the archives that people

Ryan



1440. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: forums
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 7 Jul 2005 00:52:26 -0500

This whole debate reminds me of the debate about stackmats and Rubik's timers. One is used because it has been, but the other is obviously more natural to the task at hand. Some wish to stay out of familiarity, others for lack of effort. I personally vote to switch, so long as there is still an option to receive the messages via email. I think one of the main benefits of php style forums, other than the fabulous organization, is the ability to watch various threads that interest you. I mean, sure, everyone loves hearing about cooking your cube with potatoes, but some of us have already had dinner for the night. ; )

-Mike Bennett

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

I'm certainly not gonna type the quote, it ought to > be copied from the original message. > > >> me too....one thing I hate about this type of group is that you > can't >> easily search through the archives. I remember a lot of threads I'd >> love to go back and reread, that have great information, but I > simply >> can't find them because the only search on this goes through only > like >> 50 posts at a time or so. and out of the, what, 15 thousand+ that > are >> already here, that will take a while. > > That bugs me, too. 1442. Re: [Speed cubing group] musical talent
From: François Sechet <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 19:58:54 +0200

Oh forgot that one too, how could I... Bach wrote the 6 suites for cello
solo in 2 or 3 days, and it was at first supposed to be some basic study
for one of his (numerous) sons who played the cello, in order to
strenghten his technic... Yep. Well done, Master Bach...
and, to Mike, what I heard is him physically writing the notes on paper.
And I thought I'm a fast composer... I don't believe that one, even if
he had the whole symphony in his head before writing it, I think some
stuff is just a *tiny* bit exaggerated... :-D
Franï¿½ois

Particularly I wouldn't want to switch to a website that has been created the day before, sorry... Stefan

1450. [Speed cubing group] Re: forums
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 10:08:35 -0000

To speak up for this side too, I consider myself a poweruser of this group (I check it several times a day) and I always use the website. I like the variety in that the messages are from all different categories when I click the next button. Plus I like the way the discussion flows since you forget what was going on a week before. You don't lose important messages if you bookmark, or just remember what month it was in. Of course I do admit a forum makes it easier to search, it is a pain to find a message where I can't remember when it was posted. Of course others don't like the group for the very same reasons that I like it, so these are just my two cents really. I am in favor of the yahoo layout, and I use solely the website to read this group. Plus I'm kind of biased towards the group for obvious reasons lol, so maybe my argument isn't the best one to listen to. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" > <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > This whole debate reminds me of the debate about stackmats and > Rubik's timers. On Thu, Jul 07, 2005 at 10:08:35AM -0000, cmhardw wrote:
> To speak up for this side too, I consider myself a poweruser of this
> group (I check it several times a day) and I always use the website.

Just to clarify my earlier post, "power user" means someone who takes
full advantage of a computer's advanced features (Webster's).

So what I was trying to say with respect to that was that email is an
attractive option to power users because it enables users to completely
control how emails are accessed, authored, rendered ...

As an example, I like to use an advanced writing tool called "vim" for
all of my writing needs (reports, emails, Yahoo! messages, etc.) that
doubles my efficiency. The sole reason I am able to use vim with Yahoo!
is that Yahoo! is using a standard protocol, called Email, with which
many power tools can interoperate.

Ryan


1459. Re: Algs for LL of 2x2x2
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 11:32:32 -0000

6 cases (including solved) for when no corners are to be swapped -well 9 including mirrors and inverses 12 cases for adjacent swaps/3-cycles -27 if you count inverses and mirrors 7 cases for when corners are to be swapped diagonally -10 if you count inverses and mirrors Thus I think 24 algs to memorize in total (if you are ok [experienced enough] with mirroring and inversing algs on the fly). 46 distinct cases in total.... -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Check out the CLL algs on speedcubing.com under algorithms. I believe there are 40, including reflections. > > -Mike Bennett > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Dwayne > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Thursday, July 07, 2005 4:22 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Algs for LL of 2x2x2 > > > Hey all, > > Does anyone know how many different algorithms it is to solve the last layer of a pocket cube in one algorithm? Also does anyone know where I can get a list of these to learn if the number is not that large (Can't memorize 1211 algs like the 3x3x3). > > Dwayne > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------- > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------- > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1460. Re: [Speed cubing group] musical talent
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 7 Jul 2005 22:21:42 +1000

On Wed, Jul 06, 2005 at 07:58:54PM +0200, Franï¿½ois Sechet wrote:
> and, to Mike, what I heard is him physically writing the notes on paper.
> And I thought I'm a fast composer... I don't believe that one, even if
> he had the whole symphony in his head before writing it, I think some
> stuff is just a *tiny* bit exaggerated... :-D

Well if you want to know this for sure instead of just guessing, you
could read his memoirs in which he writes:

"Immediately after this composition on the subject of Faust, and still
under the influence of Goeth's poem, I wrote the Fantastic Symphony;
some parts caused me great difficulty, but others came with incredible
ease. Thus the adagio (the Scene in the countryside), which always has
such an effect on the general public and on myself, exhausted me for
more than three weeks; I gave it up then started it again two or three
times. By contrast the March to the scaffold was written in one night.
Nevertheless I made many changes to both pieces and to all the other
movements of the work over a period of several years."

Ryan
