1462. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 7 Jul 2005 23:06:38 +1000

On Wed, Jul 06, 2005 at 04:16:12PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote:
> > And why 416,250? How can they find out so exactly? Why did Tony not
> > mention any details about how it was measured?
>
> Ok, gotta admit I found the explanation. They made a test and she read
> 1390 words in a fifth of a second.

This is not so unbelievable to me. I mean, I don't believe that she can
read 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, but I do think it is possible to
take a brain photograph of 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, then close
your eyes and read back what it says in the photograph. It seems to me
that the process of reading is computationally more expensive than the
process of merely taking a photograph. In a sense, the process of taking
a photograph uses a pre-computed image (thanks universe) which is simply
projected into your memory, while the process of reading involves a huge
amount of analysis to determine the meaning/sense. Many people do find
that they can stare at a picture, close their eyes and -- for a short
moment -- see an impression of the picture in their mind's eye, without
much computational effort at all.

Then how is it that some people can supposedly see the impression
clearer and for longer than others? It seems to me that this is because
those people use more computational effort looking for the key points
that would help to sustain the impression. This may be conscious or
subconscious.

I don't have well developed brain photo skills at all, but I do have a
similar ability to make brain recordings of sounds. This was developed
from a young age (at a subconscious level), and later, as I became more
analytical, I became aware of how my brain was actually doing it.

Relating back to photography vs. reading, I discovered I am much better
at hearing than listening. That is, I can hear and record a sound signal
instantly, and play it back in my head as many times as I wish, but some
times it takes me a while to analyse the sound and realise that someone
is trying to talk to me :-)

Ryan


1463. SV: [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: "Terje Kristensen" <terje.kristensen@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 7 Jul 2005 15:26:08 +0200

When speedreading in a way where you take in a whole page at the time,
you will not remember much instantly, but your brain will process what
you have "seen", so in a short time you will remember and comprehend
about as much as a person that read the text in "normal" speed.

So when someone "read" 1390 words in 1/5 of a second, they do in fact
take a brain photagraph, but the brain process the info as well, so a
person with very good skills will remember the info "scanned", not
reading back from the "scanned" image.

But as Stefan said, the fact that she can read 1390 words in a fifth of
a second, does not mean that she can read or comprehend 416,250 words a
minute. Even if Afasa Powell ran 100 meter in 9.77 seconds, he can not
run 10000 meter in 977 seconds. Even the brain gets tired, right ? :)

Terje

-----Opprinnelig melding-----
Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
[mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Ryan Heise
Sendt: 7. juli 2005 15:07
Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

1465. Re: Algs for LL of 2x2x2
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 11:51:57 -0000


43 distinct cases. Even if you don't want to deal with reversed
sequences, symetries are easy, and you'll see that you have to learn
about 30 or less.

Gilles.


> > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Algs for LL of 2x2x2
> >
> >
> > Hey all,
> >
> > Does anyone know how many different algorithms it is to solve
> the last layer of a pocket cube in one algorithm? Also does anyone
> know where I can get a list of these to learn if the number is not
> that large (Can't memorize 1211 algs like the 3x3x3).
> >
> > Dwayne
> >

1467. Re: Algs for LL of 2x2x2
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 14:36:55 -0000

Well these COLL algs are great to learn for other reasons but when it comes to the 2x2, lowing the restriction to preserve edge orientation does lower the average number of moves. Thus CLL would be faster. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@y...> wrote: > You can use COLL > (http://www.geocities.com/sinac_be/new_3x3x3/coll.html) if you want. > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > > From: Dwayne > > > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > > Sent: Thursday, July 07, 2005 4:22 AM > > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Algs for LL of 2x2x2 > > > > > > > > > Hey all, > > > > > > Does anyone know how many different algorithms it is to solve > > the last layer of a pocket cube in one algorithm? 1468. Re: forums
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 14:36:19 -0000

Well summarised, Ryan. I use both email and the web interface to access this group. For reading messages, I prefer email. I synchronise email to my iPAQ every day and catch up on messages from this group on the train to/from work (although not doing such things on the train this morning for obvious reasons - if you don't know what I'm talking about, check out any major news site and you'll see what happened in London this morning). For posting messages I generally use the web interface. I could do this from email, but I like to log on to the site every now and then. Re clogging up your email inbox - just set up another email address for messages from this group (this is what I have done), or use a filter - very easy options. Also, I have zillions of spare Gmail invitations and I'm happy to send them to anyone who wants one. Re moving, I would be very happy to move to any forum that satisfied Ryan's three criteria. Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Ryan Heise <rheise@p...> wrote: > Here's what I understand: > > 1. Some want email access to the forum > 2. Others want web access to the forum, with fancy features > 3. Many also want permanent archives (our history is important) > > Let's make these the requirements for any plan of action. Also, let's > not make any immediate decision until we have (3) sorted out. > > Justification of requirements: > > 1. Email is the most flexible solution for powerusers. With the right > tools and expertise, each individual to decide how they wish to > interface with the forum, and not be forced to use a particular > interface. If you wanted, you could make your inbox look just like a > fancy web-based forum, but better integrated with your personal > operating environment. This is important to me at least. > > 2. Non powerusers still need a ready made solution, and so a web > interface can do that job well. > > 3. If we are going to move to another host, let's make sure we can > transfer the whole message archive across because there are a great > number of interesting and significant posts in the archives that people > still refer to today. > > Ryan

Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Jul 7, 2005, at 4:08 AM, cmhardw wrote: > To speak up for this side too, I consider myself a poweruser of this > group (I check it several times a day) and I always use the website. > > I like the variety in that the messages are from all different > categories when I click the next button. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Jul 7, 2005, at 4:08 AM, cmhardw wrote: > To speak up for this side too, I consider myself a poweruser of this > group (I check it several times a day) and I always use the website. > > I like the variety in that the messages are from all different > categories when I click the next button. Plus I'm kind of biased towards the group for > obvious reasons lol, so maybe my argument isn't the best one to listen > to. > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" >> <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: >>> This whole debate reminds me of the debate about stackmats and >> Rubik's timers. One is used because it has been, but the other is >> obviously more natural to the task at hand. Some wish to stay out of >> familiarity, others for lack of effort. >> >> Not sure I like that comparison ;-) My reason I prefer stackmat is >> that I think it's better. If you want it more natural, please don't >> preinspect. >> >> One more reason that kept me here in this forum: fear. I do trust Joel >> or Chris as persons of course but not necessarily their abilities to >> run a server (since I just don't know much about you in that area), so >> I'd rather switch to a host that has already proven safety. >> Particularly I wouldn't want to switch to a website that has been >> created the day before, sorry... >> >> Stefan > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. b.. I don't think we're trying to fragment the groups up. I have a few I would love to go back and reread, they were very helpful and informative, but they're lost in the archives somewhere and the search takes forever to find anything about it. a forum you can search through the entire archive of threads, or even just all the threads in a single topic, such as blindfold cubing or one handed or something. makes it much, much easier to find things. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Gah... why are we fragmenting the groups like these? 1479. forums and moving
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 15:56:54 -0000

Hey everyone,

Reading over my last post I don't want it to seem like I'm
completely against forums, though I really don't get excited at the
idea of having this group on a forum over the current setup.

I've heard some suggestions to shut down this group in order to
facilitate this. Only Ron and I can do that, and speaking for
myself I would only do that if:

1) We were able to archive all the messages that haven't been lost
(we did lose about a year's worth of message when clubs converted to
forums) and make them very easily viewable and searchable for anyone
who wants to.

2) We make sure that everyone on this group has lots of ways of
finding out that the forum is moving. And even then I think this
forum should stay open long enough to let stragglers know (a year,
or at least several months). We can make it so that joining the
group requires moderator approval, and Ron and I could simply not
approve anyone who applies, but rather send them to the other forum.

3) e-mail access to post and read messages is maintained on the new
forum for all users who prefer this.

4) Any other criteria that I have left out in this post but that
most people would not agree to losing. I'm not flexible on the
first 3, but am willing to add more criteria.

----------------------------------

To be very clear, I absolutely do not want to move this group to a
forum. I really like the current setup, and from experience it has
taken a VERY long time to build up the number of members we have
right now. However, having said that if enough people do want to
move I am willing to consider helping provided the above criteria
are completely satisfied. I say "consider" because Ron and I are
the main co-moderators (with Doug Li helping with messages and other
moderator things of course :-D ), and I can't and won't act without
consulting him first.

Chris

forum.
You need an invitation to get a gmail account.
Send me an email at gillesvdp@gmail.com, i'll send you an invitation.


1481. Re: [Speed cubing group] Google Speed Solving Group
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 7 Jul 2005 10:22:58 -0700

Yeah, Gmail is great. It archives all your mail for you, so you can search through previous posts, and it groups messages together with the same subject line, so all messages from one discussion are in one place and you can easily look at any one you want. And, I've heard, that if you somehow actualy reach the limit for space they offer, instead of not letting you get more emails, it just says something along the lines of "your inbox is 104% full". So if anyone is interested just ask someone with a Gmail account, we have 50 invites each. -Evan On 7/7/05, Gillesvdp <gillesvdp@...> wrote: > Like someone said before: you should use e Gmail account to read the > messages, you would receive all the messages and it would look like a > forum. > You need an invitation to get a gmail account. > Send me an email at gillesvdp@..., i'll send you an invitation. > > ________________________________ > YAHOO! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Gah... why are we fragmenting the groups like these? I'm not signing > up for another one right now. I can't possibly check yahoo, google, > Chris' forum, and the WCA forum without getting FIRED from my job! Amen! I created a forum because I didn't know the wca had one. I wanted to let people see what a phpbb forum looks like for those of you who haven't used one in the past. I was simply providing an example of something we *could* use. An alternate plan. If people here don't want to move to a php forum, then we won't. I find this Yahoo group perfectly usable and it obviously suits everyone's needs. A forum would be better organized for those of us that access the group from the web. that's a fact. if the convience of email delivery is more important to most users then organzation, then we must stay here! I would rather not move to another email-based group because it offers very little over what we have now. I can always make the phpbb forum available if the desire is there. I'm just offering my webspace and bandwidth. I'm not trying to convince anyone to move. -Chris
1485. Re: forums and moving
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 18:27:12 -0000

I have been keeping up with this topic. I highly agree with Chris on how it takes a lot of time to earn as many members as we have. I also use many of the more advanced forums out there. I don't find the benefits of those to outweight the effort needed to convert. And I'm sure that would end up forcing people to learn a bunch of phpBB stuff that they might not otherwise need. Though I'm not a member I regularly check the twisty forum for example. I found that using gmail was a great way of viewing this group's posts as several people have mentioned. Frankly, I think that direct suggustions to shut down this fourm is sort of heresy. That reminds me, it really sucks that we lost like a years worth of posts... Anyhow, those three criteria are pretty reasonable I think. And for the record, I'm only a moderator officially, all I do is delete spam every now and then and am not around during the academic year. So Chris and Ron really don't need to consult me for anything. Though when I am around, I tend to be pretty active, when it comes to actual cubing methodology, I am very opinionated (sometimes too much) due to my experience. I'm getting way past my prime when it comes to speedcubing. I think after the next WC, I'll retire and start being a tournament runner like Tyson (but for the Midwest) and try for a position on WCA. Cubing is starting to drive me insane, and I fear I'm getting about a second slower after every passing year... today my JNet average was 24.09s. *sigh* (and it's so hopeless too, oh dear god I suck) OK, let's take a moment to consider the LOGISTICS of it!!! Trying to get hundreds of members to switch? Any guesses as to how long that would take? I know our setup is far from being the best, I hate the ads, the loading times aren't spectacular, the lack of editing, the plain- ness of it all, the inability to control spam (if you have it sent to your e-mail instead of just reading it here), ..., but it feels like home :). I say keep it simple, don't split the posts into all these new forums. Besides for more specilized things, there are already other groups/fourms for, I check the Petrus group, the Caltech group, and a few others too. I know some of you (especially those CS inclined) are ambitious enough to take on building a fourm (already see a few nice ones popping up). But take these 3 criteria as added challenges, mainly transfering the old posts. Realize that you need Chris's support, not many cubers out there command as much respect as he does, and if he says no, your definately out of luck. It better be a damn good phpBB forum for us to gamble all our chips on... if we do end up seriously considering (I'd need to see all the old posts populated in first of course). -Doug (member for 2 years) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > Reading over my last post I don't want it to seem like I'm > completely against forums, though I really don't get excited at the > idea of having this group on a forum over the current setup. > > I've heard some suggestions to shut down this group in order to > facilitate this. And even then I think this > forum should stay open long enough to let stragglers know (a year, > or at least several months). We can make it so that joining the > group requires moderator approval, and Ron and I could simply not > approve anyone who applies, but rather send them to the other forum. > > 3) e-mail access to post and read messages is maintained on the new > forum for all users who prefer this. > > 4) Any other criteria that I have left out in this post but that > most people would not agree to losing. 1488. speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 19:03:24 -0000

You guys make it sound like it's the most normal thing in the world. Can you do it? Has someone demonstrated it to you? If so, please share some details. I just found another article: http://www.execuread.com/press_media.htm Quote: "[...] read a 30 000 word book about Albert Einstein in 12s. Following that, she wrote a comprehension test and scored 95%." Depending on the book layout, that might be about 10 pages per second. Yeah ok I admit even I can flip the pages of a book that fast. My main argument is still this one: Of all those people (you'll easily find lots of reports of many people achieving things like that), why does not a single one of them ever go to a competition? They would completely SHATTER the existing world records. It'd be like a 10 meters tall basketball player in the NBA. Ok I don't have current world records but here's a report from 2001: http://www.msoworld.com/Press/Releases/MSO5day3.html It says "46012 words in a under 21 minutes". And I do believe that. Why? Not because I can get even close to that myself or have seen someone else doing it, but simply because it was an official and well-known competition. Why does this other woman not just go there and beat 21 minutes with 19 seconds? I mean, hello-o! Why don't *any* of those numerous geniuses go there? Don't tell me they're too shy or too decent or whatever. I'll tell you why: cause they're too lying. Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Terje Kristensen" <terje.kristensen@w...> wrote: > When speedreading in a way where you take in a whole page at the time, > you will not remember much instantly, but your brain will process what > you have "seen", so in a short time you will remember and comprehend > about as much as a person that read the text in "normal" speed. > > So when someone "read" 1390 words in 1/5 of a second, they do in fact > take a brain photagraph, but the brain process the info as well, so a > person with very good skills will remember the info "scanned", not > reading back from the "scanned" image. > > But as Stefan said, the fact that she can read 1390 words in a fifth of > a second, does not mean that she can read or comprehend 416,250 words a > minute. Even if Afasa Powell ran 100 meter in 9.77 seconds, he can not > run 10000 meter in 977 seconds. Even the brain gets tired, right ? : ) > > Terje > > -----Opprinnelig melding----- > Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Ryan Heise > Sendt: 7. juli 2005 15:07 > Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Emne: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando > > On Wed, Jul 06, 2005 at 04:16:12PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > > And why 416,250? How can they find out so exactly? Why did Tony not > > > mention any details about how it was measured? > > > > Ok, gotta admit I found the explanation. They made a test and she read > > > 1390 words in a fifth of a second. > > This is not so unbelievable to me. I mean, I don't believe that she can > read 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, but I do think it is possible to > take a brain photograph of 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, then close > your eyes and read back what it says in the photograph. It seems to me > that the process of reading is computationally more expensive than the > process of merely taking a photograph. In a sense, the process of taking > a photograph uses a pre-computed image (thanks universe) which is simply > projected into your memory, while the process of reading involves a huge > amount of analysis to determine the meaning/sense. Many people do find > that they can stare at a picture, close their eyes and -- for a short > moment -- see an impression of the picture in their mind's eye, without > much computational effort at all. > > Then how is it that some people can supposedly see the impression > clearer and for longer than others? It seems to me that this is because > those people use more computational effort looking for the key points > that would help to sustain the impression. This may be conscious or > subconscious. > > I don't have well developed brain photo skills at all, but I do have a > similar ability to make brain recordings of sounds. This was developed > from a young age (at a subconscious level), and later, as I became more > analytical, I became aware of how my brain was actually doing it. > > Relating back to photography vs. reading, I discovered I am much better > at hearing than listening. That is, I can hear and record a sound signal > instantly, and play it back in my head as many times as I wish, but some > times it takes me a while to analyse the sound and realise that someone > is trying to talk to me :-) > > Ryan > > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > >   Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. >   >   To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: >  speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com >   >   Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.
1489. Re: [Speed cubing group] Google Speed Solving Group
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 19:14:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Thomas Le Roux" <tomjackson@f...> wrote: > Hi everybody, > > Just a question to the french cubers which are there ; Where is the > Rubiklub ? Yeah, I just wanted to ask the same question. That's cause I wanted to point out last week they had 991 members (we have 1174) and I'm sure they started much later. Also, if we "move" somewhere else then I'd say we'll build up hundreds of members almost instantly. Well, at least I'd guess all the active members would go there quite soon. Stefan
1490. Re: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 7 Jul 2005 13:27:22 -0600

Oh man... I knew this guy once who could solve a cube in TWO seconds! Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Jul 7, 2005, at 1:03 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > You guys make it sound like it's the most normal thing in the world. > Can you do it? Has someone demonstrated it to you? If so, please share > some details. > > I just found another article: > http://www.execuread.com/press_media.htm > > Quote: > "[...] read a 30 000 word book about Albert Einstein in 12s. Following > that, she wrote a comprehension test and scored 95%." > > Depending on the book layout, that might be about 10 pages per second. > Yeah ok I admit even I can flip the pages of a book that fast. > > My main argument is still this one: Of all those people (you'll easily > find lots of reports of many people achieving things like that), why > does not a single one of them ever go to a competition? They would > completely SHATTER the existing world records. It'd be like a 10 > meters tall basketball player in the NBA. > > Ok I don't have current world records but here's a report from 2001: > http://www.msoworld.com/Press/Releases/MSO5day3.html > > It says "46012 words in a under 21 minutes". And I do believe that. > Why? Not because I can get even close to that myself or have seen > someone else doing it, but simply because it was an official and > well-known competition. Why does this other woman not just go there > and beat 21 minutes with 19 seconds? I mean, hello-o! Why don't *any* > of those numerous geniuses go there? Don't tell me they're too shy or > too decent or whatever. I'll tell you why: cause they're too lying. > > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Terje Kristensen" > <terje.kristensen@w...> wrote: >> When speedreading in a way where you take in a whole page at the > time, >> you will not remember much instantly, but your brain will process > what >> you have "seen", so in a short time you will remember and comprehend >> about as much as a person that read the text in "normal" speed. >> >> So when someone "read" 1390 words in 1/5 of a second, they do in > fact >> take a brain photagraph, but the brain process the info as well, so > a >> person with very good skills will remember the info "scanned", not >> reading back from the "scanned" image. >> >> But as Stefan said, the fact that she can read 1390 words in a fifth > of >> a second, does not mean that she can read or comprehend 416,250 > words a >> minute. Even if Afasa Powell ran 100 meter in 9.77 seconds, he can > not >> run 10000 meter in 977 seconds. Even the brain gets tired, right ? : > ) >> >> Terje >> >> -----Opprinnelig melding----- >> Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >> [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Ryan > Heise >> Sendt: 7. juli 2005 15:07 >> Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >> Emne: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando >> >> On Wed, Jul 06, 2005 at 04:16:12PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote: >>>> And why 416,250? How can they find out so exactly? Why did Tony > not >>>> mention any details about how it was measured? >>> >>> Ok, gotta admit I found the explanation. They made a test and she > read >> >>> 1390 words in a fifth of a second. >> >> This is not so unbelievable to me. I mean, I don't believe that she > can >> read 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, but I do think it is possible > to >> take a brain photograph of 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, then > close >> your eyes and read back what it says in the photograph. It seems to > me >> that the process of reading is computationally more expensive than > the >> process of merely taking a photograph. In a sense, the process of > taking >> a photograph uses a pre-computed image (thanks universe) which is > simply >> projected into your memory, while the process of reading involves a > huge >> amount of analysis to determine the meaning/sense. Many people do > find >> that they can stare at a picture, close their eyes and -- for a > short >> moment -- see an impression of the picture in their mind's eye, > without >> much computational effort at all. >> >> Then how is it that some people can supposedly see the impression >> clearer and for longer than others? It seems to me that this is > because >> those people use more computational effort looking for the key > points >> that would help to sustain the impression. This may be conscious or >> subconscious. >> >> I don't have well developed brain photo skills at all, but I do have > a >> similar ability to make brain recordings of sounds. This was > developed >> from a young age (at a subconscious level), and later, as I became > more >> analytical, I became aware of how my brain was actually doing it. >> >> Relating back to photography vs. reading, I discovered I am much > better >> at hearing than listening. That is, I can hear and record a sound > signal >> instantly, and play it back in my head as many times as I wish, but > some >> times it takes me a while to analyse the sound and realise that > someone >> is trying to talk to me :-) >> >> Ryan >> >> >> YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS >> >> •  Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. >>   >> •  To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: >>  speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com >>   >> •  Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of > Service. > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1491. Re: Springs etc
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 19:34:53 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/foo/paper_cap.jpg > Michel Bechtatou once suggested to use paper pieces to fix the 3x3 > center caps. I *hate* glue. I have used the hammer method and can live > with it. But this paper method is now my favourite, it does the least > damage. The cross shape I use now is great, when you push down the cap > then the paper will slide inside perfectly. It does raise the cap > slightly but that might actually be good because if you've played with > a cube for a while you might notice that the centers move inside a bit > because both they and the edges polish each other at the connection. Haha, I just realized that it won't raise the cap if you make the paper smaller. Stupid me ;-) And of course you don't need a cross, a rectangle that fixes two opposite sides does a good job, too. I wouldn't recommend a square to fix all four sides, cause its corners will not nicely fold and might clutter up, but maybe that'd actually be a good thing. Yeah, whatever... Stefan

1497. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method :-)
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 20:02:41 -0000

Hmm ... Which 2 edges are u swapping and calling "parity" ? And for the centers have u considered this one : (lr')d2(l'r)U'(lr')d2(l'r)U It looks longish but it's actually ony 8 moves counted with the Hardwick metric ;-) And besides u can sorta fingertrick at least the (l'r) "slice move" :-) Alrite my idea for swapping 2 edges easily is as follows. Turn an inner slice layer a quarter turn. Then cycle 3 edges on this layer so that u get 2 swapped edges. It messes with edges for sure. U might want to use Chris algorithm : R2 (u'R2)*5 instead of a simple u turn. Now u for sure know how to swap any 2 edges easily. U can use this idea only if u do centers last, or else somehow "absorb" the side effect on the centers. Cheers! -Per PS! Also have a look at : (lr')d2(l'r)U'D'(lr')d2(l'r)UD And alrite also this : r'(ud')rU2r'(u'd)rU2 U want more rabbits? There are quite a few edge-rabbits too. Most simply involve cycling blocks around :-) They are easily performed but require some experience to see when to utilise them. > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Bwahahahahaha. Victory. > > After much playing around with my 4x4 (read: working), I found a simple move to swap two center pieces on adjacent sides. Using this move, coupled with r2u2r2u2, I've managed to solve my 4x4 with this new method. Also, I've found a way around the difficult parity, but it's intuitive and difficult. I still think someone out there has to know a simpler way to fix this. Anywho, November is creeping up quickly, and I'd like to be ready by then, so if Per could just share all his secrets right now, that would be great. =) > > -Mike Bennett > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: uberstuberizzle > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Monday, July 04, 2005 1:59 PM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method :-) > > > > One problem I found with this method is too many slice moves. I Can't > do fast slice moves for my life, but if you can do 'em it could be > fast. Which commuter do you use for two edges left? > > For centers, r2b2r2b2, ldl' U ld'l' U', and r'urUr'u'd'rU'r'dr are nice. > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" > <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > Nope. I came up with it on my own after Per mentioned doing edges > first to avoid parity problems. I'm interested in learning where this > page you mention is. I suspect I could be much faster with a method > like this than a centers first method, because of the recognition time. > > > > -Mike Bennett > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: chris brownlee > > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > Sent: Monday, July 04, 2005 11:23 AM > > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 method :-) > > > > > > per uses exact same method that i do... did you get your solution > off of mcfarren's pages?? > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------- > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------- > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1498. Speedcubing coach needed for a film
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 20:32:21 -0000

Hey everyone,

I recently received an e-mail from a guy Patrick Ludden who needs a
speedcubing coach for an actor in a movie being filmed in San Francisco.

>From what he was saying the actor is fairly poplar and would want to
"talk tech" with a speedcuber to get a feel for it and also for how to
solve the cube quickly.

The solve will be prepared of course and needs to be done in
"something like ten quick moves". The scene involves an actor in a
cab egged on by a friend to solve the cube, which he "does quickly".

There is also the possibility of using a hands double, but it seems
more likely that the actor will do the solve.

I don't want to post this guy's e-mail address publicly, but e-mail me
(chris@[nospam]speedcubing.com) if you are available and I will put
you in contact with him. Remember to delete the [nospam] when you
type that address in.

Chris

P.S. Below is the original e-mail he sent to me

-------------------------------------------------------

> hey,
>
> my name is patrick ludden. i am a property master [i do props] for the
> film
> industry.
> i am currently working on a film where, in the script, the main
character
> solves a rubik's cube very quickly.
> i am looking for someone who could give pointers/advice/technical
help to
> our
> actor.
> we are shooting the film in the San Francisco Bay Area. do you or one of
> your
> friends live in this area and would be interested in doing this?
> thank you very much for your time.

1500. Re: [Speed cubing group] Google Speed Solving Group
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 20:19:09 -0000

To be clear on my purpose for creating a Google speedsolving group:

It wasn't created to fragment what we already have. Just like the
strangepuzzle and the other user-created forums, it's just another
option if we decide to move.

It doesn't live up to Chris's third standard and it's obviously not
catching on, so I'm probably going to delete it before the end of the
week.

1503. 2+ user JNetCube (JNetCube2?)
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 23:08:52 -0000

I keep getting asked to make a JNetCube that supports more then 2
users for online racing, so I think I'm going to start working on it.
I'm not sure of the programming language I'm going to use, but I will
promise to use another multiplatform language whether that may be
java, perl, or even web-based like html or php.

I have a little free time now after work so I'm going to investigate
the best plan of action and get started!

My question to you guys is: What features do you want?

I'm going to incorperate the standard things like average, fastest
time, slowest time, scramble, countdown, .... I just want to make sure
there's nothing huge that people want because that would require an
overhaul :) I want to get things right the first time.

I hope to support an unlimited amount of users (the max amount to be
set by the server) and to make the project dedicated server based. I
can have a dedicated server constantly running at a specified URL
(probably strangpuzzle.com) and have everyone just connect to the
server and start a 'race room'. People could just connect to the room
and race away with X amount of people. Does this sound like something
people would use? I going to make it even if people don't want it :)
but I figured I'd ask first too.

Maybe this could also start a new weekly contest where people log on
and race each other live. We'll see what happens. Let me know.

-Chris




1504. Re: [Speed cubing group] Google Speed Solving Group
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 16:20:10 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gillesvdp <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > I'm not sure it's a very good idea to split everything up. > The current version of this group using yahoo group works well I think. > Now if the GoogleGroup has something very useful the the YahooGroups > don't have, why not. But basically I don't see any differences... > Keeps messages in context like a forum, but also delivers messages via email.
1505. New updates to my site
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 23:18:22 -0000

Hey everybody,

I just added two new parts to my site. One of them is just a tips
page. The other is an OLL page. No, not 'Yet Another OLL page'. I
tried to organise the OLL algs in a new way (read more about that on
my site).

If you have any comments or see any typos, I want to know.

See you guys ;),

Joël.

www.solvethecube.co.uk

> can have a dedicated server constantly running at a specified URL
> (probably strangpuzzle.com) and have everyone just connect to the
> server and start a 'race room'. People could just connect to the room
> and race away with X amount of people. Does this sound like something
> people would use? I going to make it even if people don't want it :)
> but I figured I'd ask first too.
>
> Maybe this could also start a new weekly contest where people log on
> and race each other live. We'll see what happens. Let me know.

1509. Re: Speedcubing coach needed for a film
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 22:24:08 -0000

I'm not exactly close to San Francisco... :-( Suggestion for the future "coach": Find a fingertrickable algorithm that changes the whole cube and has order 2, i.e. if you apply it twice to a solved cube you'll have the solved cube again. That will make it easier to learn/practice. It should be fingertrickable not only in order to execute it fast but also it will help the actor to learn/remember it. Optimally no cube rotations. So actually I'd suggest to have the DBL 2x2 solved already and only show the U, R and F faces (should be possible) so it can be an algorithm in the <U,R,F> group. To find such an algorithm simply choose an effect with order 2 and let ACube solve it in <U,R,F>. Oh, and do you know why they need a coach? Cause you'll be the one who has to solve the cube all the time cause the actor will screw up the algorithm. Please keep us updated, it's quite interesting they actually ask us. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I recently received an e-mail from a guy Patrick Ludden who needs a > speedcubing coach for an actor in a movie being filmed in San Francisco.
1510. Re: Speedcubing coach needed for a film
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 00:51:42 -0000

Again I won't give away Patrick's e-mail, but here's the message he sent to me after that first one. ------------- chris, thanks for the email. the film is a studio film, and the actor is quite popular. one scene involves him riding in the back of a taxi with another actor. the other actor 'eggs' him on to try to solve the cube. so, our main actor does it quickly. so, we might need a cube set up for something like ten quick moves. i would get multiple cubes for extra takes. the actor might request to meet a speedcubing person to 'talk tech' with them. we might need a hand double, but it is too early in our prep to know that answer. basically i need a friendly person who would be OK talking to our actor, and then to be with me on set one day when we film the scene. this person would have to live in the Bay Area i suppose. what do you think? i would appreciate any help you could give me. cheers, patrick --------------- Really cool stuff! Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > I'm not exactly close to San Francisco... :-( > > Suggestion for the future "coach": Find a fingertrickable algorithm > that changes the whole cube and has order 2, i.e. if you apply it > twice to a solved cube you'll have the solved cube again. 1512. New updates to my website
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 22:55:13 -0000

Hey everybody,

I just uploaded two new tutorials to my site. One of them is just a
tips page with general tips for cubers. The other one is an OLL-page.
No, it's not 'Yet Another OLL-page', IMHO. I tried to organise all the
cases by their algorithm structure. A lot of algs are mirrors,
variations or combinations of each other. Knowing this can make
memorisation a bit easier.

If you guys have any comments, or if you see any typos or whatever,
please tell me.

See you guys ;),

Joël.

1515. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 8 Jul 2005 12:02:32 +1000

On Thu, Jul 07, 2005 at 07:39:47PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote:
> Sorry, but I don't think that's similar. Unless you mean you can
> record the sound of 1000 words in a second.

Not at all. If you take a page of 1000 words and reduce its size by 200
times, the naked human eye cannot physically sense all of the light
information required to actually see words.

The resolution of sound, on the other hand, is in time, not space. After
compressing 200 seconds worth of sound down to just 1 second, you are
unreasonably expecting that I be able to hear everything as if it were
at normal resolution.

No, what I'm saying is that if a normal person is able to hear 100
details about a fragment of sound after 50 hearings, I can hear those
same 100 details about a fragment of sound after only 1 hearing. I'm
sure that after 50 hearings of a 1 second recording of 1000 spoken
words, you would not pick up one single word. Do you understand?

Give me 1 second of natural spoken English, and I can remember every
inflection, tone, overtone, rhythm that I can reasonably hear at that
resolution, as if I am making an audio recording. Give me, say, 15
seconds of some music, and I will hear and remember not only the
"simple" information like the melody and rhythm, but all the layers of
intrumentation and their precise(*) expression in terms of their tone,
texture, and delayed timing.

So, it is quite reasonable to me that if I can hear+record in one
hearing what others can hear+record in 50 hearings, then some people can
quite likely see+record in one look what others can see+record in 50
looks.

I'm exiting this conversation now. Please Google eidetic memory if you
want to find evidence more to your liking.

(*) Regarding the word "precise", this does not mean "exact", of course.
I can hear/record to a high level of precision, but not a perfect one.
Memory, and even sensory input, is always an approximation of the real
world.

Ryan

Stefan Schönwälder

1519. Re: [Speed cubing group] 2+ user JNetCube (JNetCube2?)
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 8 Jul 2005 00:53:37 -0500

I would very much enjoy a slowest average statistic.

I would also very much like a 'handicap' function, where you can automatically add a prespecified number of seconds to your time, so that cubers of different abilities could compete more evenly. Perhaps there could be a table or some function to compute the handicap based on average averages? This may help to make racing via the program more popular, as well as give us a chance to compete with people of different skill levels.

It would also be nice to be able to do stop/starts in the middle of a time. When timing one step solves, you have to start and stop, then add the times up, then enter them separately.

Another request would be to be able to crop solves out for compiling averages and getting different stats. With a function like this, you could make an average of your solves with different methods, for those of us using more than one. It would also allow us to make a 'best 12 solves' or similar save file, without forcing us to save and pare or individually enter anew.

Other than that, an undo function seems almost necessary, if you don't include a separate 'Accept' button. I cannot count the number of times I have accidentally double clicked when I've had to stop a solve to go answer the telephone.

I think that about wraps up my list of demands/requests. I can't wait for the new version. =)

-Mike Bennett


----- Original Message -----
From: burntbizzkit
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, July 07, 2005 6:08 PM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] 2+ user JNetCube (JNetCube2?)


I keep getting asked to make a JNetCube that supports more then 2
users for online racing, so I think I'm going to start working on it.
I'm not sure of the programming language I'm going to use, but I will
promise to use another multiplatform language whether that may be
java, perl, or even web-based like html or php.

I have a little free time now after work so I'm going to investigate
the best plan of action and get started!

My question to you guys is: What features do you want?

I'm going to incorperate the standard things like average, fastest
time, slowest time, scramble, countdown, .... I just want to make sure
there's nothing huge that people want because that would require an
overhaul :) I want to get things right the first time.

I hope to support an unlimited amount of users (the max amount to be
set by the server) and to make the project dedicated server based. I
can have a dedicated server constantly running at a specified URL
(probably strangpuzzle.com) and have everyone just connect to the
server and start a 'race room'. People could just connect to the room
and race away with X amount of people. Does this sound like something
people would use? I going to make it even if people don't want it :)
but I figured I'd ask first too.

Maybe this could also start a new weekly contest where people log on
and race each other live. We'll see what happens. Let me know.

-Chris

1523. SV: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando
From: "Terje Kristensen" <terje.kristensen@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 8 Jul 2005 09:31:55 +0200

I dont see why not competing in a championship, proves that you are a fraud. I guess there are many ppl around that could potentially do very well in mind olympics contests, but are not interrested or not aware of the fact that they exist. It's a bit too easy to just discredit them because they have not competed. The persons them self are probably not all that interrested in the media focus, but the "inventors" of the speed reading systems want media focus to attract more ppl and make more money. And the extreme results shown are, if they in fact are true, probably not something they could easily repeat, but I agree that they should shatter the world records on even a bad day. 46012 words in 21 minutes are just over 2000 words a minute, and I myself can read over 800 words a minute without any speedreading training, so that does not seem impossible. Terje -----Opprinnelig melding----- Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Stefan Pochmann Sendt: 7. juli 2005 21:03 Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Emne: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando You guys make it sound like it's the most normal thing in the world. Can you do it? Has someone demonstrated it to you? If so, please share some details. I just found another article: http://www.execuread.com/press_media.htm Quote: "[...] read a 30 000 word book about Albert Einstein in 12s. Following that, she wrote a comprehension test and scored 95%." Depending on the book layout, that might be about 10 pages per second. Yeah ok I admit even I can flip the pages of a book that fast. My main argument is still this one: Of all those people (you'll easily find lots of reports of many people achieving things like that), why does not a single one of them ever go to a competition? They would completely SHATTER the existing world records. It'd be like a 10 meters tall basketball player in the NBA. Ok I don't have current world records but here's a report from 2001: http://www.msoworld.com/Press/Releases/MSO5day3.html It says "46012 words in a under 21 minutes". And I do believe that. Why? Not because I can get even close to that myself or have seen someone else doing it, but simply because it was an official and well-known competition. Why does this other woman not just go there and beat 21 minutes with 19 seconds? I mean, hello-o! Why don't *any* of those numerous geniuses go there? Don't tell me they're too shy or too decent or whatever. I'll tell you why: cause they're too lying. Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Terje Kristensen" <terje.kristensen@w...> wrote: > When speedreading in a way where you take in a whole page at the time, > you will not remember much instantly, but your brain will process what > you have "seen", so in a short time you will remember and comprehend > about as much as a person that read the text in "normal" speed. > > So when someone "read" 1390 words in 1/5 of a second, they do in fact > take a brain photagraph, but the brain process the info as well, so a > person with very good skills will remember the info "scanned", not > reading back from the "scanned" image. > > But as Stefan said, the fact that she can read 1390 words in a fifth of > a second, does not mean that she can read or comprehend 416,250 words a > minute. Even if Afasa Powell ran 100 meter in 9.77 seconds, he can not > run 10000 meter in 977 seconds. Even the brain gets tired, right ? : ) > > Terje > > -----Opprinnelig melding----- > Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Ryan Heise > Sendt: 7. juli 2005 15:07 > Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Emne: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando > > On Wed, Jul 06, 2005 at 04:16:12PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > > And why 416,250? How can they find out so exactly? Why did Tony not > > > mention any details about how it was measured? > > > > Ok, gotta admit I found the explanation. They made a test and she read > > > 1390 words in a fifth of a second. > > This is not so unbelievable to me. I mean, I don't believe that she can > read 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, but I do think it is possible to > take a brain photograph of 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, then close > your eyes and read back what it says in the photograph. It seems to me > that the process of reading is computationally more expensive than the > process of merely taking a photograph. In a sense, the process of taking > a photograph uses a pre-computed image (thanks universe) which is simply > projected into your memory, while the process of reading involves a huge > amount of analysis to determine the meaning/sense. Many people do find > that they can stare at a picture, close their eyes and -- for a short > moment -- see an impression of the picture in their mind's eye, without > much computational effort at all. > > Then how is it that some people can supposedly see the impression > clearer and for longer than others? It seems to me that this is because > those people use more computational effort looking for the key points > that would help to sustain the impression. This may be conscious or > subconscious. > > I don't have well developed brain photo skills at all, but I do have a > similar ability to make brain recordings of sounds. This was developed > from a young age (at a subconscious level), and later, as I became more > analytical, I became aware of how my brain was actually doing it. > > Relating back to photography vs. reading, I discovered I am much better > at hearing than listening. That is, I can hear and record a sound signal > instantly, and play it back in my head as many times as I wish, but some > times it takes me a while to analyse the sound and realise that someone > is trying to talk to me :-) > > Ryan > > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > >   Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. >   >   To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: >  speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com >   >   Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS   Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web.     To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:  speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com     Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.
1524. Re: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 8 Jul 2005 03:07:01 -0500

The difference is that these people are making outrageous claims. They are claiming something like 10 times the world record. To boot, the are offering little, if any evidence. Also, they are generally attempting to sell a product.

I don't know of anyone who can solve a randomly scrambled cube in under 1.2 seconds. I don't know of anyone who can run a mile in under 20 seconds. I certainly don't know of someone who can read 416,00 words per minute. I'm not saying it's impossible for any of these to happen (with the exception of the running bit. I'm fairly certain that works out to about 180 miles an hour, which is faster than human legs could conceivably carry someone.) I'm saying that we should be wary until some evidence is offered because the claims are so grand. Grand facts require grand scrutiny.

Not everyone who challenges the normally accepted 'records' for something should be regarded as a fraud. However, certain people, the ones attempting to sell a product, for instance, as well as those claiming several times a record and offering no proof, at least, should be considered with skepticism, if not immediately regarded with disbelief. The point was not so much that we should not trust people with claims of records. We should just not be very immediately trusting of non-recorded times with delusions of grandeur.

-Mike Bennett

----- Original Message -----
From: Terje Kristensen
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, July 08, 2005 2:31 AM
Subject: SV: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando


I don't see why not competing in a championship, proves that you are a
fraud. I guess there are many ppl around that could potentially do very
well in mind olympics contests, but are not interrested or not aware of
the fact that they exist.

It's a bit too easy to just discredit them because they have not
competed. The persons them self are probably not all that interrested in
the media focus, but the "inventors" of the speed reading systems want
media focus to attract more ppl and make more money.

And the extreme results shown are, if they in fact are true, probably
not something they could easily repeat, but I agree that they should
shatter the world records on even a bad day.

46012 words in 21 minutes are just over 2000 words a minute, and I
myself can read over 800 words a minute without any speedreading
training, so that does not seem impossible.

Terje

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

1528. SV: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando
From: "Terje Kristensen" <terje.kristensen@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 8 Jul 2005 11:34:38 +0200

This is quite off topic for this group, but anyway :)

I dont think you can compare the brain with the physical world. We know
of ppl that can do huge calculations in their head in just seconds, and
memorize huge wolumes of information that for a normal person seems
about as impossible as running a 20 second mile.

Another point that makes it hard for the "photo readers" to compete in a
contest is that even tho they can "read" the text really fast, they can
not recall it instantly, but it takes a while for them to process the
info. In a contest I guess they would be asked questions to check their
comprehension of the text right after they are done reading.

But I have never seen anyone perform these tasks, and have never tried
to do them myself, so I can't say that they are not frauds. I just
choose to believe that the human mind in capable of much more than we
can even imagine, so why should we not be able to read that fast ?

Terje

The difference is that these people are making outrageous claims.  They
are claiming something like 10 times the world record.  To boot, the are
offering little, if any evidence.  Also, they are generally attempting
to sell a product.

I don't know of anyone who can solve a randomly scrambled cube in under
1.2 seconds.  I don't know of anyone who can run a mile in under 20
seconds.  I certainly don't know of someone who can read 416,00 words
per minute.  I'm not saying it's impossible for any of these to happen
(with the exception of the running bit.  I'm fairly certain that works
out to about 180 miles an hour, which is faster than human legs could
conceivably carry someone.)  I'm saying that we should be wary until
some evidence is offered because the claims are so grand.  Grand facts
require grand scrutiny.

something should be regarded as a fraud.  However, certain people, the
ones attempting to sell a product, for instance, as well as those
claiming several times a record and offering no proof, at least, should
be considered with skepticism, if not immediately regarded with
disbelief.  The point was not so much that we should not trust people
with claims of records.  We should just not be very immediately trusting
of non-recorded times with delusions of grandeur.

-Mike Bennett

1530. [Speed cubing group] Re: Speedcubing coach needed for a film
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 13:28:10 -0000

The first thing that came to my mind after reading about this was that
something seems strange. How much does a "popular" actor pull in
these days, anywhere between 1  30 million dollars? And how much do
these movie companies sink into special effects and special training
for the actors? I find it odd that with all those large dollar bills
being thrown around that they couldn't just fly Chris (or someone of
equal proficiency) out to San Fran. How much does a plane ticket
cost, less than $1000?

Don't get me wrong, I am not saying it is a sham, I am found it to be
odd. If they really wanted to make the scene entertaining, get Macky
to do his 23 second one-handed solve.

-Dave





1531. Re: [Speed cubing group] 2+ user JNetCube (JNetCube2?)
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 8 Jul 2005 10:12:14 -0400

On 7/7/05, burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > My question to you guys is: What features do you want? There are a few of us that chat on cubestation.co.uk on weekends. This chat is actually on the #Rubik channel on the irc.irchat.tv irc server. Alexander (I don't know his e-mail address, just his nick on IRC), has written a script that responds when you issue scramble requests in the chat session, and when you announce your result, the times are stored in a database that can be queried with other chat commands. My suggestion would be to write a program that is a combination JNetCube/IRC client that lets people chat on this channel, has buttons to issue scramble requests to Alexander's program, and automatically announces the time results to the channel when the user accepts the results. This method would have the advantage that it also allows interaction with other cubers who can chat, but can't run the JNetCube timer (maybe because they are using Stackmat timers instead).

1533. proof of pairity
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 17:30:51 -0000

Hey guys,
I was wondering if anyone had something along the lines of a
mathematical proof that it is impossible to swap only 2 edge pieces on
the rubik's cube. Similarly, that you can only flip edges in pairs,
and the similar things with corners.
From experience, I know this to be true, but I'd like to see it
worked proofed somehow.

Thanks!
Daniel

1535. jNetCube at the NRAO
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 8 Jul 2005 11:51:28 -0600

Hi Everyone,

You might find this amusing. I'm using jNetCube to help with this
project I'm doing at the National Radio Astronomy Observatory. It's
pretty trivial, but the jNetCube RGB color palette is useful for
comparing colors. Just thought you might find this curious.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology



1536. [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 17:51:22 -0000

Thanks, you exactly described what I meant and why it can't be compared. You just draw a different conclusion. The point is that those people claim to record a huge amount of data in extremely short time. You do something different, you don't record a huge amount, you record very precisely. I might be able to read a full page of text in 50 short looks, but I need to look at different points, like one line each look. I don't think I can "read" a full page by shortly staring at the whole page 50 times. But in your sound example you surely meant hearing the *same* sound 50 times, not 50 different sounds, right? The resolution difference, time vs space, is exactly what I meant. What makes your ability not similar. Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Ryan Heise <rheise@p... > wrote: > On Thu, Jul 07, 2005 at 07:39:47PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > Sorry, but I don't think that's similar. Unless you mean you can > > record the sound of 1000 words in a second. > > Not at all. If you take a page of 1000 words and reduce its size by 200 > times, the naked human eye cannot physically sense all of the light > information required to actually see words. > > The resolution of sound, on the other hand, is in time, not space. After > compressing 200 seconds worth of sound down to just 1 second, you are > unreasonably expecting that I be able to hear everything as if it were > at normal resolution. > > No, what I'm saying is that if a normal person is able to hear 100 > details about a fragment of sound after 50 hearings, I can hear those > same 100 details about a fragment of sound after only 1 hearing. I'm > sure that after 50 hearings of a 1 second recording of 1000 spoken > words, you would not pick up one single word. Do you understand? > > Give me 1 second of natural spoken English, and I can remember every > inflection, tone, overtone, rhythm that I can reasonably hear at that > resolution, as if I am making an audio recording. Give me, say, 15 > seconds of some music, and I will hear and remember not only the > "simple" information like the melody and rhythm, but all the layers of > intrumentation and their precise(*) expression in terms of their tone, > texture, and delayed timing. > > So, it is quite reasonable to me that if I can hear+record in one > hearing what others can hear+record in 50 hearings, then some people can > quite likely see+record in one look what others can see+record in 50 > looks. > > I'm exiting this conversation now. Please Google eidetic memory if you > want to find evidence more to your liking. > > (*) Regarding the word "precise", this does not mean "exact", of course. > I can hear/record to a high level of precision, but not a perfect one. > Memory, and even sensory input, is always an approximation of the real > world. > > Ryan
1537. Re: SV: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 18:11:25 -0000

Out of the many many people with claimed outstanding abilities, there should be at least one who wants to prove it. And the mind olympics are well-known. Guiness World Records are even more well-known. And the people often write how they broke a world record. But ok, maybe they're really all shy and just the inventors want media focus. Then why on earth don't these inventors prove it in official competitions? They surely know about them and they surely would benefit, no? And usually the inventors claim huge achievements for themselves, too. So why don't at least those guys prove it? Wikipedia has a short article on eidetic memory: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eidetic_memory I guess I like Marvin Minsky now :-). The Guiness world records mentioned are something completely different, they're much less extreme and they can be explained. There are systems that anyone can learn and train to do similar things with enough time and mor importantly motivation. Stefan P.S. Too bad news24.com must have deleted the article I mentioned (http://www.execuread.com/press_media.htm), I would've liked to see it there. They do have older articles in their archives. I wonder why they deleted that one. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Terje Kristensen" <terje.kristensen@w...> wrote: > I don't see why not competing in a championship, proves that you are a > fraud. I guess there are many ppl around that could potentially do very > well in mind olympics contests, but are not interrested or not aware of > the fact that they exist. > > It's a bit too easy to just discredit them because they have not > competed. The persons them self are probably not all that interrested in > the media focus, but the "inventors" of the speed reading systems want > media focus to attract more ppl and make more money. > > And the extreme results shown are, if they in fact are true, probably > not something they could easily repeat, but I agree that they should > shatter the world records on even a bad day. > > 46012 words in 21 minutes are just over 2000 words a minute, and I > myself can read over 800 words a minute without any speedreading > training, so that does not seem impossible. > > Terje > > -----Opprinnelig melding----- > Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Stefan > Pochmann > Sendt: 7. juli 2005 21:03 > Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Emne: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando > > You guys make it sound like it's the most normal thing in the world. > Can you do it? Has someone demonstrated it to you? If so, please share > some details. > > I just found another article: > http://www.execuread.com/press_media.htm > > Quote: > "[...] read a 30 000 word book about Albert Einstein in 12s. Following > that, she wrote a comprehension test and scored 95%." > > Depending on the book layout, that might be about 10 pages per second. > Yeah ok I admit even I can flip the pages of a book that fast. > > My main argument is still this one: Of all those people (you'll easily > find lots of reports of many people achieving things like that), why > does not a single one of them ever go to a competition? They would > completely SHATTER the existing world records. It'd be like a 10 > meters tall basketball player in the NBA. > > Ok I don't have current world records but here's a report from 2001: > http://www.msoworld.com/Press/Releases/MSO5day3.html > > It says "46012 words in a under 21 minutes". And I do believe that. > Why? Not because I can get even close to that myself or have seen > someone else doing it, but simply because it was an official and > well-known competition. Why does this other woman not just go there > and beat 21 minutes with 19 seconds? I mean, hello-o! Why don't *any* > of those numerous geniuses go there? Don't tell me they're too shy or > too decent or whatever. I'll tell you why: cause they're too lying. > > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Terje Kristensen" > <terje.kristensen@w...> wrote: > > When speedreading in a way where you take in a whole page at the > time, > > you will not remember much instantly, but your brain will process > what > > you have "seen", so in a short time you will remember and comprehend > > about as much as a person that read the text in "normal" speed. > > > > So when someone "read" 1390 words in 1/5 of a second, they do in > fact > > take a brain photagraph, but the brain process the info as well, so > a > > person with very good skills will remember the info "scanned", not > > reading back from the "scanned" image. > > > > But as Stefan said, the fact that she can read 1390 words in a fifth > of > > a second, does not mean that she can read or comprehend 416,250 > words a > > minute. Even if Afasa Powell ran 100 meter in 9.77 seconds, he can > not > > run 10000 meter in 977 seconds. Even the brain gets tired, right ? : > ) > > > > Terje > > > > -----Opprinnelig melding----- > > Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Ryan > Heise > > Sendt: 7. juli 2005 15:07 > > Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > Emne: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando > > > > On Wed, Jul 06, 2005 at 04:16:12PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > > > And why 416,250? How can they find out so exactly? Why did Tony > not > > > > mention any details about how it was measured? > > > > > > Ok, gotta admit I found the explanation. They made a test and she > read > > > > > 1390 words in a fifth of a second. > > > > This is not so unbelievable to me. I mean, I don't believe that she > can > > read 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, but I do think it is possible > to > > take a brain photograph of 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, then > close > > your eyes and read back what it says in the photograph. It seems to > me > > that the process of reading is computationally more expensive than > the > > process of merely taking a photograph. In a sense, the process of > taking > > a photograph uses a pre-computed image (thanks universe) which is > simply > > projected into your memory, while the process of reading involves a > huge > > amount of analysis to determine the meaning/sense. Many people do > find > > that they can stare at a picture, close their eyes and -- for a > short > > moment -- see an impression of the picture in their mind's eye, > without > > much computational effort at all. > > > > Then how is it that some people can supposedly see the impression > > clearer and for longer than others? It seems to me that this is > because > > those people use more computational effort looking for the key > points > > that would help to sustain the impression. This may be conscious or > > subconscious. > > > > I don't have well developed brain photo skills at all, but I do have > a > > similar ability to make brain recordings of sounds. This was > developed > > from a young age (at a subconscious level), and later, as I became > more > > analytical, I became aware of how my brain was actually doing it. > > > > Relating back to photography vs. reading, I discovered I am much > better > > at hearing than listening. That is, I can hear and record a sound > signal > > instantly, and play it back in my head as many times as I wish, but > some > > times it takes me a while to analyse the sound and realise that > someone > > is trying to talk to me :-) > > > > Ryan > > > > > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > >   Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > >   > >   To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > >  speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > >   > >   Your use of Yahoo! 1538. Re: proof of pairity
From: portoseb <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 18:21:22 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > Hey guys, > I was wondering if anyone had something along the lines of a > mathematical proof that it is impossible to swap only 2 edge pieces on > the rubik's cube. Similarly, that you can only flip edges in pairs, > and the similar things with corners. > From experience, I know this to be true, but I'd like to see it > worked proofed somehow. > > Thanks! > Daniel The idea is that you look what the effect of a single move is. On the 3x3x3 cube there is one move (a face turned clockwise by 90 degrees) which we can say all moves consist of. Now, the effect of this move is to do an edge 4-cycle and a corner 4-cycle. Let the edges be 1, 2, 3, 4 and the corners be 1', 2', 3', 4'. If we start from the position (1, 2, 3, 4) and similarly for the corners, we get (4, 1, 2, 3) which is an odd permutation (i.e. we get to the solved position by doing an odd number of two pieces swaps). The corners will be in an odd permutation too. Now, since the starting position is obviously an even permutation, we see that performing one move will change the parity of the permutation of the edges. So it will also change the parity of the permutation of the corners. Overall, the permutation will be even. So the permutation of any position on the cube will be even. Since the position which we want to get to, that with two edges swapped, has an odd permutation, it is impossible to get to it. Same thing with the orientation. It's easy to define the orientation of pieces, and then we will just notice that no move changes the parity of the orientation. And since one switched piece means there is an odd orientation, than we see that this is impossible too. Sorry for the length. Sebastian
1539. Re: proof of pairity
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 18:27:51 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, portoseb <no_reply@y... > wrote: > > we see that performing one move > will change the parity of the permutation of the edges. So it will > also change the parity of the permutation of the corners. Overall, > the permutation will be even. Actually no need to separate edges and corners. Just say any quarter turn is two 4-cycles which is an even permutation :-) > Same thing with the orientation. It's easy to define the orientation > of pieces, and then we will just notice that no move changes the > parity of the orientation. And since one switched piece means there > is an odd orientation, than we see that this is impossible too. I asked myself the same yesterday. Someone asked me about a flipped edge on the Megaminx. I told him it's impossible and I know it's correct and I've proven it to myself, but it's harder for me to write a nice short proof. Proving the permutation parity is much easier for me. Stefan
1540. Re: proof of pairity
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 19:16:41 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > Hey guys, > I was wondering if anyone had something along the lines of a > mathematical proof that it is impossible to swap only 2 edge pieces on > the rubik's cube. Similarly, that you can only flip edges in pairs, > and the similar things with corners. > From experience, I know this to be true, but I'd like to see it > worked proofed somehow. > > Thanks! > Daniel Hi Daniel, The parity problem is caused by the centers only rotating in place, and never switching. The cube only allows 4 centers or 6 centers to move evenly (that is, in multiples of two turns) in relation to an otherwise solved cube. This even numbered limitation is shown, for example, by the cube not allowing only the centers of the slice between the Up and Down sides to move one turn to the right, in an otherwise solved cube. Regards, David J
1541. Re: SV: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando

There are systems that anyone can > learn and train to do similar things with enough time and mor > importantly motivation. > > Stefan > > P.S. I guess there are many ppl around that could potentially do > very >> well in mind olympics contests, but are not interrested or not aware > of >> the fact that they exist. >> >> It's a bit too easy to just discredit them because they have not >> competed.
