Has someone demonstrated it to you? If so, please > share >> some details. >> >> I just found another article: >> http://www.execuread.com/press_media.htm >> >> Quote: >> "[...] read a 30 000 word book about Albert Einstein in 12s. > Following >> that, she wrote a comprehension test and scored 95%." >> >> Depending on the book layout, that might be about 10 pages per > second. >> Yeah ok I admit even I can flip the pages of a book that fast. >> >> My main argument is still this one: Of all those people (you'll > easily >> find lots of reports of many people achieving things like that), why >> does not a single one of them ever go to a competition? They would >> completely SHATTER the existing world records. It'd be like a 10 >> meters tall basketball player in the NBA. >> >> Ok I don't have current world records but here's a report from 2001: >> http://www.msoworld.com/Press/Releases/MSO5day3.html >> >> It says "46012 words in a under 21 minutes". And I do believe that. >> Why? Not because I can get even close to that myself or have seen >> someone else doing it, but simply because it was an official and >> well-known competition. Why does this other woman not just go there >> and beat 21 minutes with 19 seconds? I mean, hello-o! Why don't > *any* >> of those numerous geniuses go there? Don't tell me they're too shy > or >> too decent or whatever. I'll tell you why: cause they're too lying. >> >> Stefan >> >> >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Terje Kristensen" >> <terje.kristensen@w...> wrote: >>> When speedreading in a way where you take in a whole page at the >> time, >>> you will not remember much instantly, but your brain will process >> what >>> you have "seen", so in a short time you will remember and > comprehend >>> about as much as a person that read the text in "normal" speed. >>> >>> So when someone "read" 1390 words in 1/5 of a second, they do in >> fact >>> take a brain photagraph, but the brain process the info as well, > so >> a >>> person with very good skills will remember the info "scanned", not >>> reading back from the "scanned" image. >>> >>> But as Stefan said, the fact that she can read 1390 words in a > fifth >> of >>> a second, does not mean that she can read or comprehend 416,250 >> words a >>> minute. Even if Afasa Powell ran 100 meter in 9.77 seconds, he can >> not >>> run 10000 meter in 977 seconds. Even the brain gets tired, right ? > : >> ) >>> >>> Terje >>> >>> -----Opprinnelig melding----- >>> Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >>> [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Ryan >> Heise >>> Sendt: 7. juli 2005 15:07 >>> Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >>> Emne: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando >>> >>> On Wed, Jul 06, 2005 at 04:16:12PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote: >>>>> And why 416,250? How can they find out so exactly? Why did > Tony >> not >>>>> mention any details about how it was measured? >>>> >>>> Ok, gotta admit I found the explanation. They made a test and > she >> read >>> >>>> 1390 words in a fifth of a second. >>> >>> This is not so unbelievable to me. I mean, I don't believe that > she >> can >>> read 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, but I do think it is > possible >> to >>> take a brain photograph of 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, then >> close >>> your eyes and read back what it says in the photograph. It seems > to >> me >>> that the process of reading is computationally more expensive than >> the >>> process of merely taking a photograph. In a sense, the process of >> taking >>> a photograph uses a pre-computed image (thanks universe) which is >> simply >>> projected into your memory, while the process of reading involves > a >> huge >>> amount of analysis to determine the meaning/sense. Many people do >> find >>> that they can stare at a picture, close their eyes and -- for a >> short >>> moment -- see an impression of the picture in their mind's eye, >> without >>> much computational effort at all. >>> >>> Then how is it that some people can supposedly see the impression >>> clearer and for longer than others? It seems to me that this is >> because >>> those people use more computational effort looking for the key >> points >>> that would help to sustain the impression. This may be conscious > or >>> subconscious. >>> >>> I don't have well developed brain photo skills at all, but I do > have >> a >>> similar ability to make brain recordings of sounds. This was >> developed >>> from a young age (at a subconscious level), and later, as I became >> more >>> analytical, I became aware of how my brain was actually doing it. >>> >>> Relating back to photography vs. reading, I discovered I am much >> better >>> at hearing than listening. That is, I can hear and record a sound >> signal >>> instantly, and play it back in my head as many times as I wish, > but >> some >>> times it takes me a while to analyse the sound and realise that >> someone >>> is trying to talk to me :-) >>> >>> Ryan >>> >>> >>> YAHOO! 1543. Re: Speedcubing coach needed for a film
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 20:33:02 -0000

Well, first off, there are many "equally proficient" cubers out in the SF area... say LarsP or Tyson (DanK used to live there). I don't think the point is to do something as entertaining/extravegant as possible, they probably just want to follow the script as close as possible. Also, who says they wouldn't be willing to fly someone in from afar. The letter was from Patrick, and it sounded to me like they just wanted SF area for convience of all parties. Plane ticket like that would cost less then $500 round trip actually so that was a gross over-estimate. I don't find anything odd about the whole deal. Unless the actor has small slender (and perhaps Asian) hands, I don't think they would want Macky. If I was directing, I would want a hand-double reasonably close to the actor's as my top priority, not looking for speed. I'm sure any cuber under 35s can show off mad deterity/speed if they really wanted to and a scene/cube was setup for it. Don't assume they are looking for that much authenticity... -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog <no_reply@y...> wrote: > The first thing that came to my mind after reading about this was that > something seems strange. If they really wanted to make the scene entertaining, get Macky > to do his 23 second one-handed solve. > > -Dave

1547. Re: SV: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 8 Jul 2005 16:26:39 -0500

heh, funny thing (although possibly off-topic) last year, i had brought my cube to school and solved it in 35 or so seconds. some girl told me that she knew some kid who could solve it in 17 seconds. at first i disregarded it, thinking they didn't know anything. but it happened again, at least 2 more times. well one day i finally met up with this guy. turns out the fastest he'd ever solved it in was 50-something seconds. people often will exaggerate. 'nuff said. On 7/8/05, Tyson Mao <tmao@its.caltech.edu> wrote: > Guiness World Records are meaningless to us speed cubers though, > agreed? Even if Afasa Powell ran 100 meter in 9.77 seconds, he can > >> not > >>> run 10000 meter in 977 seconds. Even the brain gets tired, right ? > > : > >> ) > >>> > >>> Terje > >>> > >>> -----Opprinnelig melding----- > >>> Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > >>> [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Ryan > >> Heise > >>> Sendt: 7. juli 2005 15:07 > >>> Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > >>> Emne: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando > >>> > >>> On Wed, Jul 06, 2005 at 04:16:12PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > >>>>> And why 416,250? How can they find out so exactly? Why did > > Tony > >> not > >>>>> mention any details about how it was measured? > >>>> > >>>> Ok, gotta admit I found the explanation. They made a test and > > she > >> read > >>> > >>>> 1390 words in a fifth of a second. > >>> > >>> This is not so unbelievable to me. I mean, I don't believe that > > she > >> can > >>> read 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, but I do think it is > > possible > >> to > >>> take a brain photograph of 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, then > >> close > >>> your eyes and read back what it says in the photograph. It seems > > to > >> me > >>> that the process of reading is computationally more expensive than > >> the > >>> process of merely taking a photograph. In a sense, the process of > >> taking > >>> a photograph uses a pre-computed image (thanks universe) which is > >> simply > >>> projected into your memory, while the process of reading involves > > a > >> huge > >>> amount of analysis to determine the meaning/sense. Many people do > >> find > >>> that they can stare at a picture, close their eyes and -- for a > >> short > >>> moment -- see an impression of the picture in their mind's eye, > >> without > >>> much computational effort at all. > >>> > >>> Then how is it that some people can supposedly see the impression > >>> clearer and for longer than others? It seems to me that this is > >> because > >>> those people use more computational effort looking for the key > >> points > >>> that would help to sustain the impression. This may be conscious > > or > >>> subconscious. > >>> > >>> I don't have well developed brain photo skills at all, but I do > > have > >> a > >>> similar ability to make brain recordings of sounds. This was > >> developed > >>> from a young age (at a subconscious level), and later, as I became > >> more > >>> analytical, I became aware of how my brain was actually doing it. > >>> > >>> Relating back to photography vs. reading, I discovered I am much > >> better > >>> at hearing than listening. That is, I can hear and record a sound > >> signal > >>> instantly, and play it back in my head as many times as I wish, > > but > >> some > >>> times it takes me a while to analyse the sound and realise that > >> someone > >>> is trying to talk to me :-) > >>> > >>> Ryan > >>> > >>> > >>> YAHOO! 1548. Re: [Speed cubing group] Speedcubing coach needed for a film
From: ssrc@...
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 8 Jul 2005 21:29:51 +0000 (GMT)

I work in Berkeley across the bay from San Francisco, so I'd be interested in finding out more about it too.
Larry


PS regarding joining a list and sending out spam right away: regardless of free enterprise and whether you're breaking laws, etc. etc., I would like to say I frown on the practice, since in this case it appears that PK joined the list expressly for the purpose of furthering his personal gain, and although he's invited others to do the same, that's actually a minus, not a plus, for me, because it encourages further such behavior. The reason all these 50 million usenet, yahoo, & other groups exist is because people want to discuss specific topics. Going OT now and then (e.g. with speedreading) isn't so bad, because it relates to the matter at hand, but PK, please don't keep doing what you did here. If I see you on any other Yahoo groups that I'm on, suddenly joining and sending notes like that, I'll keep recommending to people not to participate in the game in the way that you want them to.

SPAM is now more than half of the mail in the world. That sucks. Help stop the problem.

Thanks,
L

1550. Re: SV: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 17:44:27 -0400

I get that all the time. It's funny that I've never met another speedcuber, but everyone I solve it for happens to know someone who can do it faster. And their times always happen to be a few seconds faster than mine. It gets annoying, but not as annoying as "I solved that once when I was a kid... yeah I peeled off the stickers and put them back in the right places LOL ROFLMAO" Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... On Jul 8, 2005, at 5:26 PM, Sapan Upadhyay wrote: > heh, funny thing (although possibly off-topic) > > last year, i had brought my cube to school and solved it in 35 or so > seconds. some girl told me that she knew some kid who could solve it > in 17 seconds. at first i disregarded it, thinking they didn't know > anything. but it happened again, at least 2 more times. well one day i > finally met up with this guy. > > turns out the fastest he'd ever solved it in was 50-something seconds. > > people often will exaggerate. 'nuff said. > > > > On 7/8/05, Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote: > >> Guiness World Records are meaningless to us speed cubers though, >> agreed? Their 'requirements' for setting records illustrate complete >> lack of understanding of our sport. Furthermore, they do not >> recognize >> our organization's records. >> >> Tyson Mao >> MSC #631 >> California Institute of Technology >> >> On Jul 8, 2005, at 12:11 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: >> >> >>> Out of the many many people with claimed outstanding abilities, >>> there >>> should be at least one who wants to prove it. And the mind olympics >>> are well-known. Guiness World Records are even more well-known. And >>> the people often write how they broke a world record. >>> >>> But ok, maybe they're really all shy and just the inventors want >>> media >>> focus. Then why on earth don't these inventors prove it in official >>> competitions? They surely know about them and they surely would >>> benefit, no? And usually the inventors claim huge achievements for >>> themselves, too. So why don't at least those guys prove it? >>> >>> Wikipedia has a short article on eidetic memory: >>> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eidetic_memory >>> I guess I like Marvin Minsky now :-). The Guiness world records >>> mentioned are something completely different, they're much less >>> extreme and they can be explained. There are systems that anyone can >>> learn and train to do similar things with enough time and mor >>> importantly motivation. >>> >>> Stefan >>> >>> P.S. Too bad news24.com must have deleted the article I mentioned >>> (http://www.execuread.com/press_media.htm), I would've liked to >>> see it >>> there. They do have older articles in their archives. I guess there are many ppl around that could potentially do >>>> >>> very >>> >>>> well in mind olympics contests, but are not interrested or not >>>> aware >>>> >>> of >>> >>>> the fact that they exist. >>>> >>>> It's a bit too easy to just discredit them because they have not >>>> competed. The persons them self are probably not all that >>>> >>> interrested in >>> >>>> the media focus, but the "inventors" of the speed reading systems >>>> >>> want >>> >>>> media focus to attract more ppl and make more money. >>>> >>>> And the extreme results shown are, if they in fact are true, >>>> >>> probably >>> >>>> not something they could easily repeat, but I agree that they >>>> should >>>> shatter the world records on even a bad day. >>>> >>>> 46012 words in 21 minutes are just over 2000 words a minute, and I >>>> myself can read over 800 words a minute without any speedreading >>>> training, so that does not seem impossible. >>>> >>>> Terje >>>> >>>> -----Opprinnelig melding----- >>>> Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >>>> [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Stefan >>>> Pochmann >>>> Sendt: 7. juli 2005 21:03 >>>> Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >>>> Emne: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando >>>> >>>> You guys make it sound like it's the most normal thing in the >>>> world. >>>> Can you do it? Has someone demonstrated it to you? If so, please >>>> >>> share >>> >>>> some details. >>>> >>>> I just found another article: >>>> http://www.execuread.com/press_media.htm >>>> >>>> Quote: >>>> "[...] read a 30 000 word book about Albert Einstein in 12s. >>>> >>> Following >>> >>>> that, she wrote a comprehension test and scored 95%." >>>> >>>> Depending on the book layout, that might be about 10 pages per >>>> >>> second. >>> >>>> Yeah ok I admit even I can flip the pages of a book that fast. >>>> >>>> My main argument is still this one: Of all those people (you'll >>>> >>> easily >>> >>>> find lots of reports of many people achieving things like that), >>>> why >>>> does not a single one of them ever go to a competition? They would >>>> completely SHATTER the existing world records. It'd be like a 10 >>>> meters tall basketball player in the NBA. >>>> >>>> Ok I don't have current world records but here's a report from >>>> 2001: >>>> http://www.msoworld.com/Press/Releases/MSO5day3.html >>>> >>>> It says "46012 words in a under 21 minutes". And I do believe that. >>>> Why? Not because I can get even close to that myself or have seen >>>> someone else doing it, but simply because it was an official and >>>> well-known competition. Why does this other woman not just go there >>>> and beat 21 minutes with 19 seconds? I mean, hello-o! Why don't >>>> >>> *any* >>> >>>> of those numerous geniuses go there? Don't tell me they're too shy >>>> >>> or >>> >>>> too decent or whatever. I'll tell you why: cause they're too lying. >>>> >>>> Stefan >>>> >>>> >>>> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Terje Kristensen" >>>> <terje.kristensen@w...> wrote: >>>> >>>>> When speedreading in a way where you take in a whole page at the >>>>> >>>> time, >>>> >>>>> you will not remember much instantly, but your brain will process >>>>> >>>> what >>>> >>>>> you have "seen", so in a short time you will remember and >>>>> >>> comprehend >>> >>>>> about as much as a person that read the text in "normal" speed. >>>>> >>>>> So when someone "read" 1390 words in 1/5 of a second, they do in >>>>> >>>> fact >>>> >>>>> take a brain photagraph, but the brain process the info as well, >>>>> >>> so >>> >>>> a >>>> >>>>> person with very good skills will remember the info "scanned", not >>>>> reading back from the "scanned" image. >>>>> >>>>> But as Stefan said, the fact that she can read 1390 words in a >>>>> >>> fifth >>> >>>> of >>>> >>>>> a second, does not mean that she can read or comprehend 416,250 >>>>> >>>> words a >>>> >>>>> minute. Even if Afasa Powell ran 100 meter in 9.77 seconds, he can >>>>> >>>> not >>>> >>>>> run 10000 meter in 977 seconds. Even the brain gets tired, right ? >>>>> >>> : >>> >>>> ) >>>> >>>>> >>>>> Terje >>>>> >>>>> -----Opprinnelig melding----- >>>>> Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >>>>> [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Ryan >>>>> >>>> Heise >>>> >>>>> Sendt: 7. juli 2005 15:07 >>>>> Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >>>>> Emne: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando >>>>> >>>>> On Wed, Jul 06, 2005 at 04:16:12PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote: >>>>> >>>>>>> And why 416,250? How can they find out so exactly? Why did >>>>>>> >>> Tony >>> >>>> not >>>> >>>>>>> mention any details about how it was measured? >>>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> Ok, gotta admit I found the explanation. They made a test and >>>>>> >>> she >>> >>>> read >>>> >>>>> >>>>> >>>>>> 1390 words in a fifth of a second. >>>>>> >>>>> >>>>> This is not so unbelievable to me. I mean, I don't believe that >>>>> >>> she >>> >>>> can >>>> >>>>> read 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, but I do think it is >>>>> >>> possible >>> >>>> to >>>> >>>>> take a brain photograph of 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, then >>>>> >>>> close >>>> >>>>> your eyes and read back what it says in the photograph. It seems >>>>> >>> to >>> >>>> me >>>> >>>>> that the process of reading is computationally more expensive than >>>>> >>>> the >>>> >>>>> process of merely taking a photograph. In a sense, the process of >>>>> >>>> taking >>>> >>>>> a photograph uses a pre-computed image (thanks universe) which is >>>>> >>>> simply >>>> >>>>> projected into your memory, while the process of reading involves >>>>> >>> a >>> >>>> huge >>>> >>>>> amount of analysis to determine the meaning/sense. Many people do >>>>> >>>> find >>>> >>>>> that they can stare at a picture, close their eyes and -- for a >>>>> >>>> short >>>> >>>>> moment -- see an impression of the picture in their mind's eye, >>>>> >>>> without >>>> >>>>> much computational effort at all. >>>>> >>>>> Then how is it that some people can supposedly see the impression >>>>> clearer and for longer than others? It seems to me that this is >>>>> >>>> because >>>> >>>>> those people use more computational effort looking for the key >>>>> >>>> points >>>> >>>>> that would help to sustain the impression. This may be conscious >>>>> >>> or >>> >>>>> subconscious. >>>>> >>>>> I don't have well developed brain photo skills at all, but I do >>>>> >>> have >>> >>>> a >>>> >>>>> similar ability to make brain recordings of sounds. This was >>>>> >>>> developed >>>> >>>>> from a young age (at a subconscious level), and later, as I became >>>>> >>>> more >>>> >>>>> analytical, I became aware of how my brain was actually doing it. >>>>> >>>>> Relating back to photography vs. reading, I discovered I am much >>>>> >>>> better >>>> >>>>> at hearing than listening. That is, I can hear and record a sound >>>>> >>>> signal >>>> >>>>> instantly, and play it back in my head as many times as I wish, >>>>> >>> but >>> >>>> some >>>> >>>>> times it takes me a while to analyse the sound and realise that >>>>> >>>> someone >>>> >>>>> is trying to talk to me :-) >>>>> >>>>> Ryan >>>>> >>>>> >>>>> YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS >>>>> >>>>> • Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. >>>>> >>>>> • To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: >>>>> speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com >>>>> >>>>> • Your use of Yahoo! 1551. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: François Sechet <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 8 Jul 2005 23:55:37 +0200 (CEST)

Hey all, This reminds me of a documentary i saw recently, about people that could read a bit faster than the average people. I don't know why i didn't think of it at first, anyway, it's known to be a very interesting and serious show, and they had different guys talking about techniques to read faster and still get the meaning of what you read. They didn't speak of record-breaking ppl, however, they interviewed an eye scientist who showed a very simple trick: knowing that the eye is "slow" (well not really slow, but it's not freaking fast either, how long does it take you to move the eye, find the word, refocus, move, find, focus, move, find, focus etc.)she had a computer in front of her where she displayed a single sentence word by word, the words being quite big (something like Times New Roman size 40). then you can set about any speed on the comp, your eye, even if not reading every word, will record the image of the whole thing and you'll understand what you read. this process not being so tiring as reading the same amount of words in the same amount of time and still being able to undferstand what you read, or if you prefer, this is 10 times faster than normal reading when you're fully focused on what you read, mostly because the eyes don't move. Of course looking at a screen for a long time is tiring... I'm not saying I believe these records, I just say that using this technique, there's a way to read a lot faster and you can even count the number of words. Being focused on a computer for 10s isn't that hard, then you multiply by 6 and you get your "number of words/minute average"... If anyone has already said something in that direction and I'm only resaying what's already been said, please forgive me, I haven't been following the discussion very actively... Francois Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> a écrit : Thanks, you exactly described what I meant and why it can't be compared. You just draw a different conclusion. The point is that those people claim to record a huge amount of data in extremely short time. You do something different, you don't record a huge amount, you record very precisely. I might be able to read a full page of text in 50 short looks, but I need to look at different points, like one line each look. I don't think I can "read" a full page by shortly staring at the whole page 50 times. But in your sound example you surely meant hearing the *same* sound 50 times, not 50 different sounds, right? The resolution difference, time vs space, is exactly what I meant. What makes your ability not similar. Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Ryan Heise <rheise@p... > wrote: > On Thu, Jul 07, 2005 at 07:39:47PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > Sorry, but I don't think that's similar. Unless you mean you can > > record the sound of 1000 words in a second. > > Not at all. If you take a page of 1000 words and reduce its size by 200 > times, the naked human eye cannot physically sense all of the light > information required to actually see words. > > The resolution of sound, on the other hand, is in time, not space. After > compressing 200 seconds worth of sound down to just 1 second, you are > unreasonably expecting that I be able to hear everything as if it were > at normal resolution. > > No, what I'm saying is that if a normal person is able to hear 100 > details about a fragment of sound after 50 hearings, I can hear those > same 100 details about a fragment of sound after only 1 hearing. I'm > sure that after 50 hearings of a 1 second recording of 1000 spoken > words, you would not pick up one single word. Do you understand? > > Give me 1 second of natural spoken English, and I can remember every > inflection, tone, overtone, rhythm that I can reasonably hear at that > resolution, as if I am making an audio recording. Give me, say, 15 > seconds of some music, and I will hear and remember not only the > "simple" information like the melody and rhythm, but all the layers of > intrumentation and their precise(*) expression in terms of their tone, > texture, and delayed timing. > > So, it is quite reasonable to me that if I can hear+record in one > hearing what others can hear+record in 50 hearings, then some people can > quite likely see+record in one look what others can see+record in 50 > looks. > > I'm exiting this conversation now. Please Google eidetic memory if you > want to find evidence more to your liking. > > (*) Regarding the word "precise", this does not mean "exact", of course. > I can hear/record to a high level of precision, but not a perfect one. > Memory, and even sensory input, is always an approximation of the real > world. > > Ryan --------------------------------- YAHOO! 1553. Re: [Speed cubing group] 2+ user JNetCube (JNetCube2?)
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 22:34:09 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@g...> wrote: > haha far from it (still in high school). just in my opinion (and > apparently many others) java is rather slow, and takes a while to > load. though i very well could be wrong. :-/ Yes, true. Because Java is an interpreted language and not a compiled one it tends to run slower then other compiled languages. I'm not a big fan of Java myself, but decided to use it for that project because it's pretty powerful and most of all, multi-platform. I'm a huge linux user and coding it in C or C++ wasn't a good idea because then I would have to write a different version for each operating system. The 'new' version I'm going to write is most likely going to be webbased...html or php. I'm not going to recreate a standalone timer. I'm just working on network timer that allows more users. -Chris

1557. Re: proof of pairity
From: "al_yyz" <anders.larsson@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 23:04:41 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, portoseb <no_reply@y...> wrote: >> > Same thing with the orientation. It's easy to define the orientation > of pieces, [...] Is it? Do a U-turn on a solved cube. Have you twisted any corner in the upper layer? If the answer is 'no', then it seems that it would be impossible to twists any corner. If the answer is 'yes', then the problem is to determine which corners that are twisted clockwise and which corners that are twisted anti- clockwise. The central issue is how to determine if a corner is twisted or not when the corner piece is not in its correct place. It seems impossible to define the twist in absolute terms, but that you need to have some kind of reference frame. The edges pose not the same problem since we can define that each single move flips four edges. Thus, the U-turn of a solved cube results in four flipped edges... /Anders
1558. Re: proof of pairity
From: "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 23:11:15 -0000

> Sorry for the length.
>
> Sebastian
Sorry? This is the shortest most elegant explanation I've ever read. I
never knew why this was and couldn't explain it. Now I can. Thanks.

Michiel




1559. [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 23:13:07 -0000

This program does just that: http://tinyurl.com/b4rt5 . I used to use it all the time when profs had me download something off the internet to read. It's much faster and easier on the eyes than scrolling through page after page online. -Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, François Sechet <frsechet@y...> wrote: > Hey all, > This reminds me of a documentary i saw recently, about people that could read a bit faster than the average people. I don't know why i didn't think of it at first, anyway, it's known to be a very interesting and serious show, and they had different guys talking about techniques to read faster and still get the meaning of what you read. They didn't speak of record-breaking ppl, however, they interviewed an eye scientist who showed a very simple trick: knowing that the eye is "slow" (well not really slow, but it's not freaking fast either, how long does it take you to move the eye, find the word, refocus, move, find, focus, move, find, focus etc.)she had a computer in front of her where she displayed a single sentence word by word, the words being quite big (something like Times New Roman size 40). then you can set about any speed on the comp, your eye, even if not reading every word, will record the image of the whole thing and you'll understand what you read. this process not being > so tiring as reading the same amount of words in the same amount of time and still being able to undferstand what you read, or if you prefer, this is 10 times faster than normal reading when you're fully focused on what you read, mostly because the eyes don't move. Of course looking at a screen for a long time is tiring... > I'm not saying I believe these records, I just say that using this technique, there's a way to read a lot faster and you can even count the number of words. Being focused on a computer for 10s isn't that hard, then you multiply by 6 and you get your "number of words/minute average"... > If anyone has already said something in that direction and I'm only resaying what's already been said, please forgive me, I haven't been following the discussion very actively... > Francois >
1560. LL Methods
From: "darereck" <darereck@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 23:15:39 -0000

just wondering... which method is faster for the Fridrich method after
you finish F2L and how many moves takes for each step?:

OLL then PLL average of 9 moves for OLL and 12 for PLL

ELL then CLL ????

CLL then ELL ????




1561. Re: [Speed cubing group] 2+ user JNetCube (JNetCube2?)
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 8 Jul 2005 19:16:17 -0400

The problem is that the !alg and !time commands are handled by Alexander's IRC client, so he has to be logged in in order for it to work. So, if you were to use this approach in your program, that's an additional problem you'd have to deal with. You could probably handle this by writing your own bot that is always logged in. On 7/8/05, burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > That's actually an interesting idea, and I like it. I have tried a > couple times today to logon to the channel, and I have been > successful, however, I can't issue the !alg command. Can you please > give me a list of commands to experiment with as well as how I'm > suppose to use them. > > It could just be my IRC client (trillian), but it may also be > something else.
1562. Re: 2+ user JNetCube (JNetCube2?)
From: "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 23:26:52 -0000

Hi Chris, I'd like it to talk, of course, like my timer :) Some might think this is just for fun, but it started out because I want to know how far I am in my solution without having to look at the clock/timer. And it works. You could also implement the metronome as a simpler feature, and make it configurable, so 'beep every x seconds'. I am working for Dan Harris on an automated version of his profiles section. It's almost ready. If you like to connect your program to the profiles I am willing to cooperate. E.g. automatically show profile information downloaded from my database. Otherwise you'll end up storing all that information twice. It would be nice to see a picture of the one(s) you are racing against. If you want details of how to connect to my database, let me know in private email (blonkm[at]gmail[dot]com) Michiel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I keep getting asked to make a JNetCube that supports more then 2 > users for online racing, so I think I'm going to start working on it. > I'm not sure of the programming language I'm going to use, but I will > promise to use another multiplatform language whether that may be > java, perl, or even web-based like html or php. > > I have a little free time now after work so I'm going to investigate > the best plan of action and get started! > > My question to you guys is: What features do you want? > > I'm going to incorperate the standard things like average, fastest > time, slowest time, scramble, countdown, .... I just want to make sure > there's nothing huge that people want because that would require an > overhaul :) I want to get things right the first time. > > I hope to support an unlimited amount of users (the max amount to be > set by the server) and to make the project dedicated server based. I > can have a dedicated server constantly running at a specified URL > (probably strangpuzzle.com) and have everyone just connect to the > server and start a 'race room'. People could just connect to the room > and race away with X amount of people. Does this sound like something > people would use? I going to make it even if people don't want it :) > but I figured I'd ask first too. > > Maybe this could also start a new weekly contest where people log on > and race each other live. We'll see what happens. Let me know. > > -Chris
1563. Re: LL Methods
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 00:02:24 -0000

Well it wouldn't be the Fridrich method if you don't OLL then PLL... OLL first (41): 9.22 turn average PLL second (14): 11.21 turn average CLL first (25): 9.18 ELL second (19): 11.27 ELL first (13): 7.87 CLL second (42): 11.73 Of course these are in face turn metric. I counted the solved case for each case count in parentheses. Also you should account for an extra .75 turns based on the 75% chance of having to do an little post-adjust of the LL in the end. Now I've been a CLL/ELL user for a long time. Not sure if anyone in the world would do ELL/CLL, at least I've never heard of it. -Doug Li --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "darereck" <darereck@g...> wrote: > just wondering... which method is faster for the Fridrich method after > you finish F2L and how many moves takes for each step?: > > OLL then PLL average of 9 moves for OLL and 12 for PLL > > ELL then CLL ???? > > CLL then ELL ????
1564. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: LL Methods
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 8 Jul 2005 19:42:55 -0500

Ell+CLL seems like a viable solution, because the second step can be completed using simple corner commutators that are generally very fast. Ryan Heise's method includes this, I believe. It's just done intuitively, instead of as a defined set of algorithms. -Mike Bennett P.S. I'm curious what the approximate move count would be for a method described in my 'New LL strategy proposal' topic. I have a feeling it would be low, but I don't know how to find the number of moves. ----- Original Message ----- From: d_funny007 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Friday, July 08, 2005 7:02 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: LL Methods Well it wouldn't be the Fridrich method if you don't OLL then PLL... OLL first (41): 9.22 turn average PLL second (14): 11.21 turn average CLL first (25): 9.18 ELL second (19): 11.27 ELL first (13): 7.87 CLL second (42): 11.73 Of course these are in face turn metric. I counted the solved case for each case count in parentheses. Also you should account for an extra .75 turns based on the 75% chance of having to do an little post-adjust of the LL in the end. Now I've been a CLL/ELL user for a long time. Not sure if anyone in the world would do ELL/CLL, at least I've never heard of it. -Doug Li --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "darereck" <darereck@g...> wrote: > just wondering... which method is faster for the Fridrich method after > you finish F2L and how many moves takes for each step?: > > OLL then PLL average of 9 moves for OLL and 12 for PLL > > ELL then CLL ???? > > CLL then ELL ???? ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ YAHOO! 1565. Re: SV: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 01:22:20 -0000

Ya, I hate it when that happens. What I do is ask for a name, and since I know most of the cubers names on top 200 lists, I can verify or deny it pretty quickly. Sure lots of times it's fake or an exaggeration. But (as I have recently found out) there is truth to some of these claims. I mean, just think, I've been seen in public cubing at this university by lots of people. Now when they see some newbie sub-1min cuber, they are going to mention me (or some faint memory of a guy cubing on campus). Similarly, I've heard stories about a cuber here, and had been denying it, but it seems like there are other cubers at my school. Who's to say DanK or JonM, didn't walk through the Detroit airport one day and one of the people watching me cube didn't see such a feat already. So now I'm pretty open to the idea that news of cubing travels fast; that it's more likely than I had originally expected for an individual too run into another cuber. You say you've never meant another speedcuber in real life, right? Well maybe you should try to seek some out in your area. Open your eyes, there are speedcubers lurking in every corner of the world and in basically every (technical) profession. Heck, just give your location. Might get some hits on this fourm... I'm from Ann Arbor, MI... I occasioanlly stop by places kinda far off from home and cube there. Such as Saginaw and Kalamazoo... so some poor cuber out in those places are going to deny sightings of me undoubtedly, lol. There are at least 7 cubers I've meant in/from MI, 4 or 5 faster than me in fact. Three national or international record holders are from MI. This doesn't even cout the ones I've heard about but haven't meant in person. Look around, you'll be suprised to actually see cubers faster than you around. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o...> wrote: > I get that all the time. It's funny that I've never met another > speedcuber, but everyone I solve it for happens to know someone who > can do it faster. And their times always happen to be a few seconds > faster than mine. > > It gets annoying, but not as annoying as "I solved that once when I > was a kid... yeah I peeled off the stickers and put them back in the > right places LOL ROFLMAO" > > > > Bryan Mytko > bryanosaurus@b... > > > On Jul 8, 2005, at 5:26 PM, Sapan Upadhyay wrote: > > > heh, funny thing (although possibly off-topic) > > > > last year, i had brought my cube to school and solved it in 35 or so > > seconds. some girl told me that she knew some kid who could solve it > > in 17 seconds. at first i disregarded it, thinking they didn't know > > anything. but it happened again, at least 2 more times. well one day i > > finally met up with this guy. > > > > turns out the fastest he'd ever solved it in was 50-something seconds. > > > > people often will exaggerate. 'nuff said. > > > > > > > > On 7/8/05, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > > >> Guiness World Records are meaningless to us speed cubers though, > >> agreed? The persons them self are probably not all that > >>>> > >>> interrested in > >>> > >>>> the media focus, but the "inventors" of the speed reading systems > >>>> > >>> want > >>> > >>>> media focus to attract more ppl and make more money. > >>>> > >>>> And the extreme results shown are, if they in fact are true, > >>>> > >>> probably > >>> > >>>> not something they could easily repeat, but I agree that they > >>>> should > >>>> shatter the world records on even a bad day. > >>>> > >>>> 46012 words in 21 minutes are just over 2000 words a minute, and I > >>>> myself can read over 800 words a minute without any speedreading > >>>> training, so that does not seem impossible. > >>>> > >>>> Terje > >>>> > >>>> -----Opprinnelig melding----- > >>>> Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > >>>> [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Stefan > >>>> Pochmann > >>>> Sendt: 7. juli 2005 21:03 > >>>> Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > >>>> Emne: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando > >>>> > >>>> You guys make it sound like it's the most normal thing in the > >>>> world. > >>>> Can you do it? Has someone demonstrated it to you? If so, please > >>>> > >>> share > >>> > >>>> some details. > >>>> > >>>> I just found another article: > >>>> http://www.execuread.com/press_media.htm > >>>> > >>>> Quote: > >>>> "[...] read a 30 000 word book about Albert Einstein in 12s. > >>>> > >>> Following > >>> > >>>> that, she wrote a comprehension test and scored 95%." > >>>> > >>>> Depending on the book layout, that might be about 10 pages per > >>>> > >>> second. > >>> > >>>> Yeah ok I admit even I can flip the pages of a book that fast. > >>>> > >>>> My main argument is still this one: Of all those people (you'll > >>>> > >>> easily > >>> > >>>> find lots of reports of many people achieving things like that), > >>>> why > >>>> does not a single one of them ever go to a competition? I'll tell you why: cause they're too lying. > >>>> > >>>> Stefan > >>>> > >>>> > >>>> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Terje Kristensen" > >>>> <terje.kristensen@w...> wrote: > >>>> > >>>>> When speedreading in a way where you take in a whole page at the > >>>>> > >>>> time, > >>>> > >>>>> you will not remember much instantly, but your brain will process > >>>>> > >>>> what > >>>> > >>>>> you have "seen", so in a short time you will remember and > >>>>> > >>> comprehend > >>> > >>>>> about as much as a person that read the text in "normal" speed. > >>>>> > >>>>> So when someone "read" 1390 words in 1/5 of a second, they do in > >>>>> > >>>> fact > >>>> > >>>>> take a brain photagraph, but the brain process the info as well, > >>>>> > >>> so > >>> > >>>> a > >>>> > >>>>> person with very good skills will remember the info "scanned", not > >>>>> reading back from the "scanned" image. > >>>>> > >>>>> But as Stefan said, the fact that she can read 1390 words in a > >>>>> > >>> fifth > >>> > >>>> of > >>>> > >>>>> a second, does not mean that she can read or comprehend 416,250 > >>>>> > >>>> words a > >>>> > >>>>> minute. Even if Afasa Powell ran 100 meter in 9.77 seconds, he can > >>>>> > >>>> not > >>>> > >>>>> run 10000 meter in 977 seconds. Even the brain gets tired, right ? > >>>>> > >>> : > >>> > >>>> ) > >>>> > >>>>> > >>>>> Terje > >>>>> > >>>>> -----Opprinnelig melding----- > >>>>> Fra: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > >>>>> [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] På vegne av Ryan > >>>>> > >>>> Heise > >>>> > >>>>> Sendt: 7. juli 2005 15:07 > >>>>> Til: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > >>>>> Emne: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando > >>>>> > >>>>> On Wed, Jul 06, 2005 at 04:16:12PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > >>>>> > >>>>>>> And why 416,250? How can they find out so exactly? Why did > >>>>>>> > >>> Tony > >>> > >>>> not > >>>> > >>>>>>> mention any details about how it was measured? > >>>>>>> > >>>>>> > >>>>>> Ok, gotta admit I found the explanation. They made a test and > >>>>>> > >>> she > >>> > >>>> read > >>>> > >>>>> > >>>>> > >>>>>> 1390 words in a fifth of a second. > >>>>>> > >>>>> > >>>>> This is not so unbelievable to me. I mean, I don't believe that > >>>>> > >>> she > >>> > >>>> can > >>>> > >>>>> read 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, but I do think it is > >>>>> > >>> possible > >>> > >>>> to > >>>> > >>>>> take a brain photograph of 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, then > >>>>> > >>>> close > >>>> > >>>>> your eyes and read back what it says in the photograph. It seems > >>>>> > >>> to > >>> > >>>> me > >>>> > >>>>> that the process of reading is computationally more expensive than > >>>>> > >>>> the > >>>> > >>>>> process of merely taking a photograph. In a sense, the process of > >>>>> > >>>> taking > >>>> > >>>>> a photograph uses a pre-computed image (thanks universe) which is > >>>>> > >>>> simply > >>>> > >>>>> projected into your memory, while the process of reading involves > >>>>> > >>> a > >>> > >>>> huge > >>>> > >>>>> amount of analysis to determine the meaning/sense. Many people do > >>>>> > >>>> find > >>>> > >>>>> that they can stare at a picture, close their eyes and -- for a > >>>>> > >>>> short > >>>> > >>>>> moment -- see an impression of the picture in their mind's eye, > >>>>> > >>>> without > >>>> > >>>>> much computational effort at all. > >>>>> > >>>>> Then how is it that some people can supposedly see the impression > >>>>> clearer and for longer than others? It seems to me that this is > >>>>> > >>>> because > >>>> > >>>>> those people use more computational effort looking for the key > >>>>> > >>>> points > >>>> > >>>>> that would help to sustain the impression. This may be conscious > >>>>> > >>> or > >>> > >>>>> subconscious. > >>>>> > >>>>> I don't have well developed brain photo skills at all, but I do > >>>>> > >>> have > >>> > >>>> a > >>>> > >>>>> similar ability to make brain recordings of sounds. This was > >>>>> > >>>> developed > >>>> > >>>>> from a young age (at a subconscious level), and later, as I became > >>>>> > >>>> more > >>>> > >>>>> analytical, I became aware of how my brain was actually doing it. > >>>>> > >>>>> Relating back to photography vs. reading, I discovered I am much > >>>>> > >>>> better > >>>> > >>>>> at hearing than listening. That is, I can hear and record a sound > >>>>> > >>>> signal > >>>> > >>>>> instantly, and play it back in my head as many times as I wish, > >>>>> > >>> but > >>> > >>>> some > >>>> > >>>>> times it takes me a while to analyse the sound and realise that > >>>>> > >>>> someone > >>>> > >>>>> is trying to talk to me :-) > >>>>> > >>>>> Ryan > >>>>> > >>>>> > >>>>> YAHOO! looking at the weekend of September 17 and 18. Discussion for this
tournament, so as not to destroy the international forum, will continue
in the Caltech Rubik's Cube group.

1569. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 8 Jul 2005 20:20:33 -0600

Haha... given that the human pupil is .5 cm, the angular resolving power means you can read resolve how many words per line. I could totally figure this out, as it's my life as an astronomer, but I don't feel like it. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Jul 8, 2005, at 11:51 AM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > Thanks, you exactly described what I meant and why it can't be > compared. You just draw a different conclusion. > > The point is that those people claim to record a huge amount of data > in extremely short time. You do something different, you don't record > a huge amount, you record very precisely. I might be able to read a > full page of text in 50 short looks, but I need to look at different > points, like one line each look. I don't think I can "read" a full > page by shortly staring at the whole page 50 times. But in your sound > example you surely meant hearing the *same* sound 50 times, not 50 > different sounds, right? > > The resolution difference, time vs space, is exactly what I meant. > What makes your ability not similar. > > Stefan > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Ryan Heise <rheise@p... >> wrote: >> On Thu, Jul 07, 2005 at 07:39:47PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote: >>> Sorry, but I don't think that's similar. Unless you mean you can >>> record the sound of 1000 words in a second. >> >> Not at all. If you take a page of 1000 words and reduce its size by > 200 >> times, the naked human eye cannot physically sense all of the light >> information required to actually see words. >> >> The resolution of sound, on the other hand, is in time, not space. > After >> compressing 200 seconds worth of sound down to just 1 second, you > are >> unreasonably expecting that I be able to hear everything as if it > were >> at normal resolution. >> >> No, what I'm saying is that if a normal person is able to hear 100 >> details about a fragment of sound after 50 hearings, I can hear > those >> same 100 details about a fragment of sound after only 1 hearing. I'm >> sure that after 50 hearings of a 1 second recording of 1000 spoken >> words, you would not pick up one single word. Do you understand? >> >> Give me 1 second of natural spoken English, and I can remember every >> inflection, tone, overtone, rhythm that I can reasonably hear at > that >> resolution, as if I am making an audio recording. Give me, say, 15 >> seconds of some music, and I will hear and remember not only the >> "simple" information like the melody and rhythm, but all the layers > of >> intrumentation and their precise(*) expression in terms of their > tone, >> texture, and delayed timing. >> >> So, it is quite reasonable to me that if I can hear+record in one >> hearing what others can hear+record in 50 hearings, then some people > can >> quite likely see+record in one look what others can see+record in 50 >> looks. >> >> I'm exiting this conversation now. Please Google eidetic memory if > you >> want to find evidence more to your liking. >> >> (*) Regarding the word "precise", this does not mean "exact", of > course. >> I can hear/record to a high level of precision, but not a perfect > one. >> Memory, and even sensory input, is always an approximation of the > real >> world. >> >> Ryan > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >
1570. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: J Bernett Orlando
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 9 Jul 2005 12:25:23 +1000

On Fri, Jul 08, 2005 at 05:51:22PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote:
> Thanks, you exactly described what I meant and why it can't be
> compared.

You have kind of twisted my words, there.

> The point is that those people claim to record a huge amount of data
> in extremely short time. You do something different, you don't record
> a huge amount, you record very precisely.

My comparison is this:

- In "N" seconds of hearing I can record 50x more data than the average
person.
- In "N" seconds of looking this other person can record 50x more data
than the average person.

You claim it is not "data" that I am recording in great numbers but
something else??? What is it? On a computer, an audio file contains
audio data, and a graphic file contains visual data. Audio and visual
data are different in nature, of course, but I am instead comparing the
ratio of 50x relative to an average person's abilities for recording
whatever kind of data. The ratios are comparable.

Your claim that taking a visual recording of a page of 1000 written
words in 1 second is comparable to taking a sound recording of 1 second
of 1000 spoken words in 1 second is totally unfounded due to the matter
of normal resolution which you have completely misunderstood. You left
the size of the page at its normal size/resolution, while on the other
hand, you shrunk the size of the recording of 1000 spoken words from its
normal resolution of 200 seconds down to 1 second. This resolution is
too compacted for any human to perceive. To make a fair comparison, you
should also shrink the size of the page of written text by 200 times as
well. Then we are both handicapped in the same way.

Relative to their respective normals, I have compared two people as
being 50x better than average.

I have tried to offer you an insight into how in my case I am able to
achieve this feat. Take it or leave it, but please don't tell me I am
achieving a different feat from what I think I am, when you yourself
seem to have little understanding of it whatsoever.

If you would rather argue with me about that, I don't think that's what
everyone else who's participating in this thread wants to read about.
They want to know how such a feat is possible, perhaps to see how it
applies to memorising a cube configuration in blindfolded cubing. If you
would rather diminish my abilities, please take it to private email.

Thanks,

Ryan

1572. Re: SV: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando

> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eidetic_memory
> I guess I like Marvin Minsky now :-).

Some interesting evidence is mentioned in that article. It is a wonder
how you are less interested in it:

| There have been some cases where young children have demonstrated the
| ability to focus on a picture and then recall it with perfect clarity
| minutes later. However, these skills are usually lost as they grow
| older.

Ryan

Well, if it helps, the Dawes limit for a 5mm pupil would be about 23 arc seconds, and the Airy disc of a point source would be 28 arcseconds-ish. -Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Haha... given that the human pupil is .5 cm, the angular resolving > power means you can read resolve how many words per line. I could > totally figure this out, as it's my life as an astronomer, but I don't > feel like it. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology

1576. Re: seeing/hearing vs remembering
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 9 Jul 2005 16:10:28 +1000

On Fri, Jul 08, 2005 at 05:51:22PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote:
> I might be able to read a full page of text in 50 short looks, but I
> need to look at different points, like one line each look. I don't
> think I can "read" a full page by shortly staring at the whole page 50
> times.

Without being aware of it, your mind has been trained to focus on a
small part of the page and ignore the rest of it. This is the way you
learn to read. First of all, they teach you to focus on one letter at a
time. After your brain learns how to automatically translate the image
of that letter into the letter itself, you learn how to focus on a whole
word and recognise the image of the whole word as the word itself. After
that, most people learn on their own how to recognise two or three words
in one go, and by necessity, only learn to expand their focus
horizontally (for horizontally flowing languages), or vertically (for
vertically flowing languages).

This process happens automatically whenever you see something that can
be interpreted as written words, and it is quite difficult to override
this training. However, it is easy to rediscover how broadly your eyes
can really focus when you stare at a block of text written in a
different language. For example, please take a look at the table of
Korean symbols on the following page:

http://www.wam.umd.edu/~stwright/korean/korean-linguistics-origins.html

Since the meaning of these symbols is not registering with you as
written English, your mind is allowing you to focus normally and you can
take in the whole image quite easily. However, if you try to learn how
to read the Korean language, you will again train your mind to focus on
each individual character, and you will ignore the rest of what's on the
page. When I began learning the Korean language, I experienced exactly
that: although I knew my eye could easily capture an entire Korean word
with clarity, I could not stare at a whole Korean word and recognise it.
Instead, I had to stare at each character individually until I had read
through the whole word.

Apart from this, there is a limit to how much you can focus on with
clarity, but I am not about to guess at what the limit is. The more
peripheral your vision, the less clear it is. When you look at
something, your eyes automatically wander around to grab the full
picture. Do you know if she is not allowed to move her eyes within that
one second? One second seems like ample time to easily see the whole
page.

To me, "seeing" the whole page in 1 second is not the real feat. The
real feat is being able to sustain the impression of that image in your
mind for a long period of time.

Please refer to my original email for an idea of how I do this for
sound.

> But in your sound example you surely meant hearing the *same* sound 50
> times, not 50 different sounds, right?

Well, if you were to listen to a length of sound with the aim of
memorising it, you would listen to it several times, focussing on a
different portion each time and ignoring the rest. Possibly you would
take in relatively small portions at a time, whereas I would take in
relatively large chunks of sound as one unit. By portion, I do not mean
just timewise, but also depthwise. For example, if you were able to
demonstrate to me that you could listen to a whole 10 second fragment of
music in one hearing and remember the entire melody, I would point out
that you have only remembered one portion of the sound; There are also
the drums, the guitar, bass guitar, keyboard (which is very dense in
that it can involve chords with 6 or 7 parts played simultaneously),
vocal parts and more, as well as the finer subtle points such as "how"
the vocalists expressed each word (e.g. there are an infinite many ways
to say a particular word), how the bass player attacked the 29th note in
the bassline, etc. There is a lot of data in here, which I can pick up
in one hearing, like an audio recording, but not quite that precise.

I don't really know how to convince you that it is a huge amount of data
that I am hearing, since fewer people really care about hearing than
they do about looking. I mean, it seems most would prefer to have visual
rather than audio eidetic memory, and thus it is easy to diminish the
latter ability relative to the former. After all, it is fair enough to
say that more of the brain is devoted to vision than hearing, and that
people depend more on vision than hearing.

Ryan


1577. Re: SV: [Speed cubing group] speed reading (was: J Bernett Orlando
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>

I was talking more about random occurrences, and how someone always has a friend who can solve it in 15 seconds, yet that friend is always somehow unreachable, and the fact that I never bump into one of those people's friends. I'm in New York by the way... anyone else on here from NY? Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... How can they find out so exactly? Why did > > >>>>>>> > > >>> Tony > > >>> > > >>>> not > > >>>> > > >>>>>>> mention any details about how it was measured? > > >>>>>>> > > >>>>>> > > >>>>>> Ok, gotta admit I found the explanation. They made a test > and > > >>>>>> > > >>> she > > >>> > > >>>> read > > >>>> > > >>>>> > > >>>>> > > >>>>>> 1390 words in a fifth of a second. > > >>>>>> > > >>>>> > > >>>>> This is not so unbelievable to me. I mean, I don't believe > that > > >>>>> > > >>> she > > >>> > > >>>> can > > >>>> > > >>>>> read 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, but I do think it is > > >>>>> > > >>> possible > > >>> > > >>>> to > > >>>> > > >>>>> take a brain photograph of 1390 words in 1/5th of a second, > then > > >>>>> > > >>>> close > > >>>> > > >>>>> your eyes and read back what it says in the photograph. It > seems > > >>>>> > > >>> to > > >>> > > >>>> me > > >>>> > > >>>>> that the process of reading is computationally more > expensive than > > >>>>> > > >>>> the > > >>>> > > >>>>> process of merely taking a photograph. In a sense, the > process of > > >>>>> > > >>>> taking > > >>>> > > >>>>> a photograph uses a pre-computed image (thanks universe) > which is > > >>>>> > > >>>> simply > > >>>> > > >>>>> projected into your memory, while the process of reading > involves > > >>>>> > > >>> a > > >>> > > >>>> huge > > >>>> > > >>>>> amount of analysis to determine the meaning/sense. Many > people do > > >>>>> > > >>>> find > > >>>> > > >>>>> that they can stare at a picture, close their eyes and -- > for a > > >>>>> > > >>>> short > > >>>> > > >>>>> moment -- see an impression of the picture in their mind's > eye, > > >>>>> > > >>>> without > > >>>> > > >>>>> much computational effort at all. > > >>>>> > > >>>>> Then how is it that some people can supposedly see the > impression > > >>>>> clearer and for longer than others? It seems to me that this > is > > >>>>> > > >>>> because > > >>>> > > >>>>> those people use more computational effort looking for the > key > > >>>>> > > >>>> points > > >>>> > > >>>>> that would help to sustain the impression. This may be > conscious > > >>>>> > > >>> or > > >>> > > >>>>> subconscious. > > >>>>> > > >>>>> I don't have well developed brain photo skills at all, but I > do > > >>>>> > > >>> have > > >>> > > >>>> a > > >>>> > > >>>>> similar ability to make brain recordings of sounds. This was > > >>>>> > > >>>> developed > > >>>> > > >>>>> from a young age (at a subconscious level), and later, as I > became > > >>>>> > > >>>> more > > >>>> > > >>>>> analytical, I became aware of how my brain was actually > doing it. > > >>>>> > > >>>>> Relating back to photography vs. reading, I discovered I am > much > > >>>>> > > >>>> better > > >>>> > > >>>>> at hearing than listening. That is, I can hear and record a > sound > > >>>>> > > >>>> signal > > >>>> > > >>>>> instantly, and play it back in my head as many times as I > wish, > > >>>>> > > >>> but > > >>> > > >>>> some > > >>>> > > >>>>> times it takes me a while to analyse the sound and realise > that > > >>>>> > > >>>> someone > > >>>> > > >>>>> is trying to talk to me :-) > > >>>>> > > >>>>> Ryan > > >>>>> > > >>>>> > > >>>>> YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > >>>>> > > >>>>> � Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > >>>>> > > >>>>> � To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > > >>>>> speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > >>>>> > > >>>>> � Your use of Yahoo! 1580. A Quiet Cube?, 25th Anniversary cubes rock!, What's ur cube?
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 08:26:14 -0000

So I'm sitting here at 4am, with nearly all my cubes out. Sadly only
5 fully operational 3x3 cubes, and that includes my chrome one.

I'm trying to re-build a fleet here. Two more cubes to prep and 2
and a half to re-sticker. And omg, re-stickering takes so much time
and effort! Prepping used to take about a month per cube for me, so
this is all looking pretty daunting. And once I'm done with that
time to order more cubes...

A while ago, I bashed the 25th aniversary cubes a bit. I thought
they were too much like the Meffert's assembly in feel. That is it
didn't take mis-alignment very well or have enough springy-ness.

Right now I have two speedcubes: a White DIY, and one that is 25th
anniversary pieces on a regular mechanism that I have worn in for
about a year. But in genreal pretty crappy for my standards.

Lately I've heard that a lot of very fast cubers use the 25th
anniversary cubes. So I thought I'd give it a try.

I took the pieces off a new 25th anniversary cube (hard to do btw),
and put the ones from my black speedcube on it. And OH boy was it
super smooth! And super quite too, oddly enough.

Right now I'm doing a full cleaning and re-lubing just to make sure
that phenomenon wasn't just a by-product of having lots and lots of
dryed lube gunk in there. But so far I'm very impressed, and have
changed my mind, I like these cubes now. Initially they are pretty
bad and don't have that desired tightness I was used to finding on
new cubes (in the past it used to be that tightness initially
translated to smoothness a year later).

I recommend the 25th anniversary cubes now. The one I just put
together seems to be better then any cube I've used lately. Well
except when one of my friends (35s cuber) came to visit 6 weeks ago
with a cube I prepared for him 2 years ago, that one rocks hardcore
and I'm convinced is one of the best speedcubes in the world.

But back to this... Any one ever find a speedcube that doesn't do
the usual clicking sounds but is very quite?

Well back to pulling an all-nighter preping cubes and listening to a
playlist entitiled "cubing" that I made years ago. See?, I'm such a
hardcore cuber :). Speaking of which we should come up with jokes
starting with "You know you've been cubing too much when..."

Oh ya and it's that time of year again... I want people to start a
thread, posting/listing the primary and perhaps secondary speedcube
they use. Like how old it is, what make/model, and the type of
stickers. Oh and don't forget to mention what class of speedcuber
you are (i.e. sub-20 class, sub-25, sub-30, sub-35, ...).



-Doug

1582. You know you've been cubing too much when...
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 09:18:24 -0000

Ok fine, so I'm bored. In keeping with my last post, let me be the
first to try some of these jokes. Though I suck at this.


=====================================================================
You know you've been cubing too much when the first thing you do
every morning is wake up and check speedcubing.com.

You know you've been cubing too much when the edges of your computer
monitor(s) are filled with old cube stickers.

You know you've been cubing *WAY* too much when all these stickers
are LOGO stickers.

You know you've been cubing too much when you regularly use the
word "F2L" in conversation with non-cubers.

You know you've been cubing too much when your fingers twitch while
sleeping as if your doing a trigger.

You know you've been cubing too much when it's 4:38am and you
realized you hadn't left your room since you woke up and have been
cubing continuously.

You know you've been cubing too much when you have two Acube windows
up, Ron's OnlineTimer, JNetCube, several IM windows to various
cubers around the world, a recently finished MagicCube 4D window
that you can't bare to close due to the 3.5 hrs you spent on it last
night, browsers to several cubing sites (including your own!),
shopping cart on rubik.com, a few record pages, CubeExplorer, and
JNet's "Scramble View" window. (Oh wait, that's just me.)

Your roommates know you've been cubing too much when you whip
out "the mat".

Your friends know you've been cubing too much when you always bring
a cube to the restroom.

You know you've been cubing too much when you have a special
waterproof cube that you use while in the shower (and stays in the
soap holder).

You know you've been cubing too much when you walk around campus
with a cell phone in one hand against your ear and doing one-handed
in the other (...talking about the bld solve you did last night,
lol).

You know you've been cubing too much when the new roommate that just
moved in last week finds you up at 6:45am out in the living room
solving a cube with a blindfold on and does a double-take as she's
trying to reach the bathroom.

You know you've been cubing too much when you have an iTunes
playlist entitled "Cubing" that is full of techno.

You know you've been cubing too much that when shopping for a new
cell phone you must have one that times to the hundredths of a
second.

Your classmates know you've been cubing too much when your palms are
full of ink showing F's, prime's, L's, U's, etc... and your teacher
know's your not cheating.

You know you've been cubing too much when you carry around a piece
of paper listing the latest Sunday contest scrambles.

You know you've been cubing too much when your wardrobe has a
disproportionate amount of utilites pants with extra large pockets.

You know you've been cubing too much when you have a suitcase with
foam lining with places for cubes and can lube.

You know you've been cubing too much when for the past 5 years your
computer's "busy-cursor" depicts a solving rubik's cube.

You know you've been cubing too loudly when your neighbors pound the
walls :(.

You know you've been cubing too much when all your
excercise/sleeping T-shirts are full of black grease marks.

You know you've been cubing too much when you bring a cube to the
beach or swimming pool and are anxious to do an underwater solve.

You know you've been cubing too much when you've solved the cube on
every rollercoster ride at your local theme park.

You know you've been cubing too much when instead of fuzzy dice
hanging in your car, you have fuzzy Rubik's cubes.

You know you've been cubing too much when you take skydiving (or
bungy jumpping) lessons for the expressed purpose of doing
an "extreme-solve".

You know you've been cubing too much when you have the utmost
confidence that you can solve every mechanical permutation puzzle
out there, even those not yet invented.... well except the accursed
Astrolabacus, doh!

You know you've been cubing too much when you keep a cube under your
pillow...

You know you've been cubing too much when you have a draw full of
2500 old cube stickers neatly packed in zip-lock bags with permenent
marker
labeling "Amsterdam", "Petrus", "HongKong", "Bombay", "CalTech
04", "Toronto 03", "Berkely 05", etc...

You know you've been cubing too much when poeple ask you to write a
book on the subject.

You know you've been cubing too much when the school regularly asks
you to give cubing/group theory lectures.

You know you've been cubing too much when people forget your name
and just call you "the cube guy".

You know you've been cubing too much when you give mean and standard
deviation when asked about your times.

You know you've been cubing too much when you twist your watch
around to the inside, reset it and then proclaim that "I am now in
cubing-mode" like the nerd you are.

You know you've been cubing too much when whenever people ask you
for the time, you have to switch modes momentarily away from timer
mode to respond.

You know you've been cubing too much when you honestly think CalTech
is the cubing capital of the world.

You know you've been cubing too much when you have nightmeres about
giant alien cubes invading and devouring your speedcubes.
=====================================================================


Ok, well now you get the picture...; I'm starting to get silly. Come
up with some of these jokes on your own and post them here!


-Doug




1583. Tips on Training for Competition
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 09:53:21 -0000

I'm doing a bit of cubing right now, and noticed I've been doing a
couple of interesting things.

You see, competitive speedcubing*, or at least the physical aspect
can be broken up into three parts: Dexterity, Strength, and Accuracy.

I think deterity comes from practice and is even something inherent
of a person. So not much special can be done about that.

For strength what I have been doing is practicing on an extra-tight
and weighter cube. I have been using an over-tightened white DIY. To
weigh it down, I put in about 18 zinc washers and stuff the edge
pieces with playdoh.

For accuracy, I now practice on an over lubed 25th anniversary cube,
they are quite sensitive to lock-ups if your not careful enough, and
the over-slickness will force you to build up accuracy and control.

Ah yes, "accuracy" in this new age of cubing, that is now the new
catch-phrase. I hear this term a lot from people like Macky and
Tyson.

So I leave you with the reminder:
"It's not that your cube sucks, it's that you SUCK! So quick blaming
your cubes and start working on your accuracy."


-Doug


*I say "competitive speedcubing" since there are actually many types
of cubers out there, some that don't do it for speed, and even some
that do it for speed but are not competitive on it. In fact, I don't
fully fit into this category; I opted to be more of an "algorithm
monopolizer".




1584. Re: Tips on Training for Competition
From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 14:18:22 -0000

> So I leave you with the reminder:
> "It's not that your cube sucks, it's that you SUCK! So quick blaming
> your cubes and start working on your accuracy."


truly words of wisdom (:
I often use another cube than my main speedcube to practice
with....sort of like training cubes. one is too loose, one is too
tight, and one is just right.

1587. Re: One Handed PLL
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 15:38:23 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bruce Wayne" <drteeth@o...> wrote: > Does anyone know if there are better algorithms than the standard ones > for pll which are specifically tailored for one handed cubing.... just > curious > -Justin Medoy > waysted and solving the cube since 2005 I use this one for one-handed but not normal speedcubing: (U' U' L' U' L U L') y' (L' U' R U' R' U' L U) That's for left-handed, mirror it for right-handed. Stefan
1588. Re: 2+ user JNetCube (JNetCube2?)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 15:59:57 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sapan Upadhyay > <cubekid@g...> wrote: > > haha far from it (still in high school). just in my opinion (and > > apparently many others) java is rather slow, and takes a while to > > load. though i very well could be wrong. :-/ > > Yes, true. Because Java is an interpreted language and not a compiled > one it tends to run slower then other compiled languages. I what millenium are you guys living? ;-) Read a bit about JIT (just in time) compilers or Java HotSpot. And here's a little demo program: -------------------------------------------------- class Speed { public static void main ( String[] args ) { int a = 2, b = 3, c = 5, d = 7; for( int i=0; i<1000000000; i++ ){ a += i; b += a; c += b; d += c; } System.out.println( d ); } } -------------------------------------------------- I also translated the program to C and C++, here are the timing results: Java: 0m21.740s C: 0m34.830s C++: 0m34.850s Notice the program purposely has only very simple and fast operations (no divisions etc, just additions) so that most of the time is spent running the code, not waiting for computation results. I also ran the Java program on my PC (I only have Java 1.4.1 where I did the first tests and that one doesn't have nice profiler output) and got the following profiler output. Notice how much is interpreted and how much is *compiled*: -------------------------------------------------- Flat profile of 5.68 secs (468 total ticks): main Interpreted + native Method 0.2% 1 + 0 sun.net.www.protocol.file.FileURLConnection. getPermission 0.2% 1 + 0 sun.misc.URLClassPath$JarLoader.<init> 0.2% 0 + 1 java.io.WinNTFileSystem.getBooleanAttributes 0.6% 2 + 1 Total interpreted Compiled + native Method 99.4% 465 + 0 Speed.main 99.4% 465 + 0 Total compiled Flat profile of 0.01 secs (2 total ticks): DestroyJavaVM Interpreted + native Method 100.0% 1 + 0 java.lang.Shutdown.<clinit> 100.0% 1 + 0 Total interpreted Thread-local ticks: 50.0% 1 Blocked (of total) Global summary of 5.69 seconds: 100.0% 470 Received ticks -------------------------------------------------- Are you still convinced Java is slow? Stefan

1590. Re: proof of pairity
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 16:58:45 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "al_yyz" <anders. larsson@i...> wrote: > > The edges pose not the same problem since we > can define that each single move flips four edges. Thus, the U-turn of > a solved cube results in four flipped edges... Hmm... how do you "define" that each move flips four edges? Also, it might be better to define how to count the edge flips and then "observe" that each move flips four edges (if that's true, and I actually doubt it). Here's my attempt for 3x3 corners: For each corner and each corner position choose a standard orientation (for corners choose a real sticker and for positions choose an imaginary sticker). Now the "twist" of a corner is how far it must be rotated clockwise (0,1 or 2) to match the standard orientation of the position it's in. The "total twist" is the sum of all corner twists, modulo 3. Now let's prove that a move doesn't change the total twist. The trick is to temporarily adjust the standard orientations of the corner positions involved in the move. Adjust them so that they match the face being turned. Since they're our reference, this will of course change our total twist. Call that change the "face twist". Now we do the move which (thanks to the adjusted standard orientations) doesn't change the total twist further. Afterwards we undo the adjustments, which will again change our total twist, but this time the opposite way. So we're back at the original standard orientations and the overall effect of the move on our total twist is: (face twist) + 0 - (face twist) = 0. Since any move doesn't change the total twist but rotating a single corner does, this can't be done with moves. What do you think? The proof (with different numbers/names) also works for edges and also other puzzles, e.g. Megaminx. Stefan
1591. Re: [Speed cubing group] Speedcubing coach needed for a film
From: Mailer_Daemon <perscription_death@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 9 Jul 2005 10:04:21 -0700 (PDT)

i haven't checked this in a while but i'm from the bay
area and would also be happy to help in anyway.
