1592. Re: 2+ user JNetCube (JNetCube2?)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 17:09:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Are you still convinced Java is slow? > > > > Stefan > > Ha. nice. It might just be swing that appears to run slow. I haven't > had an trouble with the speed of console programming. I'm no expert in Java graphics (I've done a bit with it but not too much) but if this is really a problem then you might want to try AWT instead of Swing. AWT is heavyweight (let the operating system draw stuff like buttons etc) and Swing is lightweight (drawing everyhing itself), which is why AWT can be faster. Here's a very nice page discussing both, including a discussion about the pros and cons of each: http://bdn.borland.com/article/0,1410,26970,00.html So if you have problems with speed and don't really depend on Swing, try AWT instead. Though I'd be a bit surprised if you have speed problems unless you have a fancy graphical application, which I don't imagine a cube timer to be... Cheers! Stefan

i'm from the bay area and would also be happy to help in anyway, if it
promotes cubing i'm all over it.

clancy




1594. Re: [Speed cubing group] A Quiet Cube?, 25th Anniversary cubes rock!, What's ur cube?
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 9 Jul 2005 12:31:30 -0500

> Well back to pulling an all-nighter preping cubes and listening to a > playlist entitiled "cubing" that I made years ago. sounds very interesting :). you think you could upload the names of the songs? > Speaking of which we should come up with jokes starting with "You know you've been > cubing too much when..." yea we should do that again... we had that a while ago, but i kinda lost the link to it :-/ On 7/9/05, d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > So I'm sitting here at 4am, with nearly all my cubes out. Sadly only > 5 fully operational 3x3 cubes, and that includes my chrome one. > > I'm trying to re-build a fleet here. Two more cubes to prep and 2 > and a half to re-sticker. And omg, re-stickering takes so much time > and effort! Prepping used to take about a month per cube for me, so > this is all looking pretty daunting. And once I'm done with that > time to order more cubes... > > A while ago, I bashed the 25th aniversary cubes a bit. I thought > they were too much like the Meffert's assembly in feel. That is it > didn't take mis-alignment very well or have enough springy-ness. > > Right now I have two speedcubes: a White DIY, and one that is 25th > anniversary pieces on a regular mechanism that I have worn in for > about a year. But in genreal pretty crappy for my standards. > > Lately I've heard that a lot of very fast cubers use the 25th > anniversary cubes. So I thought I'd give it a try. > > I took the pieces off a new 25th anniversary cube (hard to do btw), > and put the ones from my black speedcube on it. And OH boy was it > super smooth! And super quite too, oddly enough. > > Right now I'm doing a full cleaning and re-lubing just to make sure > that phenomenon wasn't just a by-product of having lots and lots of > dryed lube gunk in there. But so far I'm very impressed, and have > changed my mind, I like these cubes now. Initially they are pretty > bad and don't have that desired tightness I was used to finding on > new cubes (in the past it used to be that tightness initially > translated to smoothness a year later). > > I recommend the 25th anniversary cubes now. The one I just put > together seems to be better then any cube I've used lately. Well > except when one of my friends (35s cuber) came to visit 6 weeks ago > with a cube I prepared for him 2 years ago, that one rocks hardcore > and I'm convinced is one of the best speedcubes in the world. > > But back to this... Any one ever find a speedcube that doesn't do > the usual clicking sounds but is very quite? > > Well back to pulling an all-nighter preping cubes and listening to a > playlist entitiled "cubing" that I made years ago. See?, I'm such a > hardcore cuber :). Speaking of which we should come up with jokes > starting with "You know you've been cubing too much when..." > > Oh ya and it's that time of year again... I want people to start a > thread, posting/listing the primary and perhaps secondary speedcube > they use. Like how old it is, what make/model, and the type of > stickers. Oh and don't forget to mention what class of speedcuber > you are (i.e. sub-20 class, sub-25, sub-30, sub-35, ...). > > > > -Doug > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > -- -cubekid
1595. Re: seeing/hearing vs remembering
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 18:05:10 -0000

Sorry for still answering in the group, but I'll keep it short. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Ryan Heise <rheise@p... > wrote: > > Your claim that taking a visual recording of a page of 1000 written > words in 1 second is comparable to taking a sound recording of 1 second > of 1000 spoken words in 1 second is totally unfounded due to the matter > of normal resolution which you have completely misunderstood. You left > the size of the page at its normal size/resolution, while on the other > hand, you shrunk the size of the recording of 1000 spoken words from its > normal resolution of 200 seconds down to 1 second. This resolution is > too compacted for any human to perceive. To make a fair comparison, you > should also shrink the size of the page of written text by 200 times as > well. Then we are both handicapped in the same way. I should've been more clear. I don't want to play the 1000 words at high speed, I want to play them at *normal* speed. Just all at the same time. Just like the photoreaders when they see 1000 normal size words at the same time. > Well, if you were to listen to a length of sound with the aim of > memorising it, you would listen to it several times, focussing on a > different portion each time and ignoring the rest. Possibly you would > take in relatively small portions at a time, whereas I would take in > relatively large chunks of sound as one unit. By portion, I do not mean > just timewise, but also depthwise. For example, if you were able to > demonstrate to me that you could listen to a whole 10 second fragment of > music in one hearing and remember the entire melody, I would point out > that you have only remembered one portion of the sound; There are also > the drums, the guitar, bass guitar, keyboard (which is very dense in > that it can involve chords with 6 or 7 parts played simultaneously), > vocal parts and more, as well as the finer subtle points such as "how" > the vocalists expressed each word (e.g. there are an infinite many ways > to say a particular word), how the bass player attacked the 29th note in > the bassline, etc. There is a lot of data in here, which I can pick up > in one hearing, like an audio recording, but not quite that precise. I do believe you that. Reminds me a bit of the chess masters that can easily remember whole chess boards (that is, if they display a normal game, not if they're random). The first problem of most people remembering much of a music fragment is probably that they aren't even able to pay attention to everything because they're not used to it (missing attention when being introduced to people is also the #1 reason why I often can't remember their names ;-) And yes, it's of course data, but a different kind of data. How are you going to play/record 1000 words in a second using sound? Hmm, just a thought... there's a memorization discipline called "spoken numbers" where you're just listening to someone telling a sequence of digits, one digit each second. How many do you think you could remember? And would it help if they spoke faster? Stefan
1596. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 2+ user JNetCube (JNetCube2?)

It might just be swing that appears to run slow. I haven't > > had an trouble with the speed of console programming. > > I'm no expert in Java graphics (I've done a bit with it but not too > much) but if this is really a problem then you might want to try AWT > instead of Swing. AWT is heavyweight (let the operating system draw > stuff like buttons etc) and Swing is lightweight (drawing everyhing > itself), which is why AWT can be faster. Here's a very nice page > discussing both, including a discussion about the pros and cons of > each: > http://bdn.borland.com/article/0,1410,26970,00.html > > So if you have problems with speed and don't really depend on Swing, > try AWT instead. Though I'd be a bit surprised if you have speed > problems unless you have a fancy graphical application, which I don't > imagine a cube timer to be... > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > -- -cubekid
1597. Re: proof of pairity
From: _jaap <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 19:34:19 -0000

> --- "al_yyz" <anders.larsson@i...> wrote: > > The edges pose not the same problem since we > > can define that each single move flips four edges. Thus, the > > U-turn of > > a solved cube results in four flipped edges... --- Stefan Pochmann wrote: > Hmm... how do you "define" that each move flips four edges? Indeed. It just happens to be the case that you can choose a reference facelet for each edge such that no two are a quarter turn apart. If you do this 6H pattern, you will see which facelets I mean: U2 B2 R2 U2D2 R2 F2 U2 > Here's my attempt for 3x3 corners: ... > What do you think? That is the standard proof. You can find it in the Cubic Circular: http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/cubic3.htm#p21 There you will also see the one-line proof for edge flip parity: A single edge-flip is a swap of two facelets, and hence is an odd permutation of the facelets, but every move is an even permutation of facelets and so no single edge flip is possible. Unfortunately this does not work on corners because a corner twist is a 3-cycle of facelets, not directly ruled out by the parity. Jaap http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/
1598. Re: proof of pairity
From: portoseb <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 19:42:23 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "al_yyz" <anders.larsson@i...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, portoseb > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > >> > > Same thing with the orientation. It's easy to define the orientation > > of pieces, [...] > > Is it? Do a U-turn on a solved cube. Have you twisted any corner in > the upper layer? > > If the answer is 'no', then it seems that it would be impossible to > twists any corner. > > If the answer is 'yes', then the problem is to determine which corners > that are twisted clockwise and which corners that are twisted anti- > clockwise. The answer can be both "yes" and "no". The idea is that the cube is no longer considered symmetrical. That is, different face turns are different. Namely, U and D turns are different from the other face turns. We'll consider the reference frame as being the U and D faces. The twist of a corner is how many times it has to be twisted clockwise so that it's U/D face is in the U/D face (this can always be done, since every corner belongs to either of these two faces). In the starting position, the total twist is 0. Now let's see what different face turns do. U and D don't change the total twist. It is then easy to see that F, B, R and L are symmetrical to each other, so we'll consider doing the move F. We will have 4 twisted corners. The ones in the UFL and DFR positions have twist 1, and the ones in the UFR and DFL positions have twist 2. The total is 0. So no move changes the total twist. > The edges pose not the same problem since we > can define that each single move flips four edges. Thus, the U- turn of > a solved cube results in four flipped edges... > > /Anders I think that's not possible if we define the orietation with regards to a frame, but I just found another definition: We define the twist of an edge as 0 if by bringing it to its correct position (and orientation) we use an even number of quarter outer face turns, and 1 if we need an odd number of quarter turns. One move changes the orientation of 4 edges, because they are one quarter turn more (or less) away from their solved position - it is exactly that quarter turn which we performed. Since 4 is an even number, the parity of the total twist doesn't change when we perform a quarter turn. Again we see that there is an invariant: the parity of the total twist. One twisted edge means the total twist is odd, which is a contradiction. Sebastian
1599. Re: proof of pairity
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 19:55:03 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > Thanks to everyone who answered, that's pretty much exactly what I > wanted to know! And it's good to have a few different approaches of it. > > Thanks again, > Daniel I'm not sure if this was mentioned but there's a technical aspect to this also - which is that the oddness/evenness of a permutation is well-defined. Essentially, that's to say that the identity ican't be realized as an odd permutation. If you are willing to accept that then the proof is fairly straightforward but that detail does require some proof. (One way to do this is using determiants of permutation matrices - then it essentially boils down to (-1)^n can't be 1 if n is odd.)

1601. Re: proof of pairity
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 20:46:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, portoseb <no_reply@y... > wrote: > > We define the twist of an edge as 0 if by bringing it to its correct > position (and orientation) we use an even number of quarter outer > face turns, and 1 if we need an odd number of quarter turns. That's an interesting idea. But it's not too obvious that this is well-defined, at least not to me... :-( Yeah ok, now (after thinking a bit) I see it, we can use Jaap's 6H-pattern... Stefan
1602. Re: proof of pairity
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 20:58:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, _jaap <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > Hmm... how do you "define" that each move flips four edges? > > Indeed. It just happens to be the case that you can choose a reference > facelet for each edge such that no two are a quarter turn apart. If > you do this 6H pattern, you will see which facelets I mean: > U2 B2 R2 U2D2 R2 F2 U2 Nice, that indeed makes it obvious :-) > > Here's my attempt for 3x3 corners: > ... > > What do you think? > > That is the standard proof. You can find it in the Cubic Circular: > http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/cubic3.htm#p21 Yeah yeah, once again I reinvented the wheel... I even used the same term and definition for "twist" ;-). Well, at least I didn't define the "principal direction" (my "standard orientation") of the pieces and positions to match when the puzzle is solved... which is completely unnecessary :-) > A single edge-flip is a swap of two facelets, and hence is an odd > permutation of the facelets, but every move is an even permutation of > facelets and so no single edge flip is possible. Too bad I was thinking about corners only, I did think about facelet permutations but quickly abandoned it ;-) Stefan
1603. Re: proof of pairity
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 21:59:14 -0000

Here is my two cents on all of this.

This is an incomplete project of mine, though I don't have much
farther to go. It's from a page of mine to prove that the general
formula for the number of combinations to an nxnxn cube.

That page is incomplete, but these sections are:

Proof that the number of clockwise twists on a corner is congruent to
0 (mod3) http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/lemma1.html

Proof that the number of flipped edges must be even:
http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/lemma4.html

Proof that the corner and edges must always have the same parity:
http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/lemma5.html

Chris

1605. Java is slow (was: Re: 2+ user JNetCube (JNetCube2?))
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 22:57:43 -0000

> So if you have problems with speed and don't really depend on Swing,
> try AWT instead. Though I'd be a bit surprised if you have speed
> problems unless you have a fancy graphical application, which I don't
> imagine a cube timer to be...

>From experience, I can say that swing is slower then awt. The reason
why I preffer swing, however, is because of its main flaw: it's drawn
by Java. With awt, it's almost impossible to tell what the final
product will look like on another OS/X combination. As a *nix user I
know that there are almost an unlimited amount of window managers out
there and you never know what to expect! I just like playing on the
safe side and let java(swing) control the graphics. That way I don't
have to worry about spacing issues when it comes to button/font sizes
on different OSs.

Java is nice. Not a bad language. Many prebuilt supplied libraries,
but the graphics engine is nothing compared to a good GTK+ setup! Only
problem with GTK+ is that I have to compile the GUI for every Os.
pfft. I'll never win.

-Chris






1606. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: seeing/hearing vs remembering
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 10:47:11 +1000

On Sat, Jul 09, 2005 at 06:05:10PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote:
> I should've been more clear. I don't want to play the 1000 words at
> high speed, I want to play them at *normal* speed. Just all at the
> same time. Just like the photoreaders when they see 1000 normal size
> words at the same time.

??!

Ok, here is my serious answer, and you can laugh if you weren't being
serious.

A sound is temporal and a page is spatial. That is, you discern the
contents of a sound by time, and you discern the contents of a page by
space. If you want to overlay all of the spoken words over each other at
one point in time and play them back, it is only fair to overlay all of
the written words at point in space and then try to look at them. It can
be done to a certain number of layers, but not 1000 words overlaid over
each other! However, I would say that the number of layers one can
discern in audio data is far greater than that in visual data, and that
is one of the differences between audio and visual data.

> And yes, it's of course data, but a different kind of data. How are
> you going to play/record 1000 words in a second using sound?

Yes, it's a different kind of data: it's audio, not visual. And this
answers your next question: there is no natural way to express 1000
spoken words in 1 second, because a spoken word takes up too much time.

No comparison can be made that way. It's not easy to express a sound on
a piece of paper either. It's much more efficient to hear it.

> Hmm, just a thought... there's a memorization discipline called
> "spoken numbers" where you're just listening to someone telling a
> sequence of digits, one digit each second. How many do you think you
> could remember? And would it help if they spoke faster?

There's a limit to how much data I can capture in one go. So, for
example, give me 10 seconds of complex data such as this, and I will
remember quite precisely the original audio track. I do not think about
or even recognise the actual numbers and try to filter out the rest, I
just hear and remember the whole sound. I can then play back the sound
later in my head and try to figure out what numbers you actually spoke.
People will often perceive me as a slow thinker because of that.

The amount of sound I can capture in one go depends on its complexity.
If it is less complex, I can capture maybe a whole minute in one go.

I'm sure that if all you were interested in were the actual numbers
themselves, you should ask someone who is good at filtering. I don't do
any filtering - I try to capture every detail I hear.

Ryan


1607. Need F2L Help...
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 02:15:03 -0000

Hey all,

I did a breakdown average, timing the F2L and LL separately on the
Stackmat, and (for the curious) here were my results:

F2L = cross (bottom face) + 4 C/E pairs
LL = OLL (+ AUF) + PLL

# F2L LL
1 16.61 9.61
2 15.61 6.54
3 15.53 8.40
4 18.39 7.99
5 (14.15) (9.61)
6 19.43 7.44
7 17.04 8.66
8 18.39 6.87
9 18.61 8.70
10 17.92 7.02
11 (20.69) 8.11
12 19.91 (6.00)
Av 17.74 7.93 (Total avg: 25.67)

Since my best average is 24.78, I think this average accurately
demonstrates what my typical solves look like (except OLL recognition
is instead replaced with starting the Stackmat timer and grabbing the
cube. There were no lucky cases. Based on these averages, it's clear
that my biggest problem is the F2L (only one sub-15 F2L time!). I
know it's been asked plenty of times before, but maybe I missed
something important, so here's my question:

Does anybody have any advice for improving the F2L?

~ Bob

1609. Java is slow (was: Re: 2+ user JNetCube (JNetCube2?))
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 02:46:21 -0000

Hmm ... Java does indeed have quite powerful graphics. Apart from using Java3D which at least on windows u can run in either the DirectX or the OpenGL flavour. U need a separate JDK and runtime environment for coding and running respectively. Apart from this, the Java2D is also quite powerful. At least for Java2D u won't need other than the normal Sun java virtual machine, preferably JRE 1.5 (5.0). For a demo of it's powerful features check out ur JDK folder which should reside somewhere similar to this : C:\Programfiler\Java\jdk1.5.0_03\demo\jfc\Java2D\Java2Demo.html At least im quite impressed with all of it's features. Remember that this is platform independent graphics :-) Besides the java collection classes this is the java stuff im most impressed by. The downside of Java is the relatively slow text- and numbercrunching. And also it can be somewhat of a pain to make attractive GUI's with java using it's layout managers. Using for instance Eclipse and a plugin like JIgloo it's at least a little more attractive. But it requires lots or RAM to run smoothly. Oh and don't try to run Eclipse and ACube at the same time :-P Yes u guessed it, Eclipse is a java application. It will be very slow. Effective threading within the JVM is also not it's strong side :-( Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > So if you have problems with speed and don't really depend on Swing, > > try AWT instead. Though I'd be a bit surprised if you have speed > > problems unless you have a fancy graphical application, which I don't > > imagine a cube timer to be... > > From experience, I can say that swing is slower then awt. The reason > why I preffer swing, however, is because of its main flaw: it's drawn > by Java. With awt, it's almost impossible to tell what the final > product will look like on another OS/X combination. As a *nix user I > know that there are almost an unlimited amount of window managers out > there and you never know what to expect! I just like playing on the > safe side and let java(swing) control the graphics. That way I don't > have to worry about spacing issues when it comes to button/font sizes > on different OSs. > > Java is nice. Not a bad language. Many prebuilt supplied libraries, > but the graphics engine is nothing compared to a good GTK+ setup! Only > problem with GTK+ is that I have to compile the GUI for every Os. > pfft. I'll never win. > > -Chris

1611. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Improved PLL Algs??
From: Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 9 Jul 2005 19:57:59 -0700 (PDT)

I was sorting through my email and noticed I left no reply for this...strange. >But how do you do the B' and B moves > fast? (U2B') right thumb on the R sticker of the URF corner, turn with your wrist for the U2, then pull the (B') with your thumb. (R'B) you do this the same way you would do R'U, by tilting the cube toward you a bit. Hope this helps! -Richard --- Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > "richy_jr_2000" > <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > > > > (RU')(R'l')(U2B')(RU2)(R'B)U2(lR)UR'U) > > That one might replace my slowest alg of all. And > the U at the end > could be left out or changed to U2 or U' so all > angles could be > completed fast. But how do you do the B' and B moves > fast? > > Stefan > > > > ____________________________________________________ Sell on Yahoo! Auctions ï¿½ no fees. Bid on great items. http://auctions.yahoo.com/
1612. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: seeing/hearing vs remembering
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 13:09:01 +1000

On Sun, Jul 10, 2005 at 10:47:11AM +1000, Ryan Heise wrote:
> However, I would say that the number of layers one can discern in
> audio data is far greater than that in visual data, and that is one of
> the differences between audio and visual data.

Sorry, it is one of the difference between the way we "perceive" audio
and visual data.

Ryan

1614. Re: [Speed cubing group] Need F2L Help...
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 07:58:46 +0200

Hi,

My averages are like you : around 25 (best : 23.77)

But I average 13~14 seconds for the F2L and 11 seconds (!!!) for the LL.

To improve my F2L times, I used Macky's Tips
(http://cubefreak.hp.infoseek.co.jp/speedcubing_tips.html) + I had a
F2L cube which is very useful to improve your F2L.
Another important thing is to be able to use FreeSlots when you do the
3 first F2L when it's necessary.
You should also try to see what you can do when you have 2 F2L done
but not correctly placed in order to save them.

For me, I have to work on the LL :p.


1615. Re: [Speed cubing group] Need F2L Help...
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 01:17:24 -0500

I'm in the same boat. I average under 15 on my F2L. My last layer is 10 or 11+ seconds most of the time. The key to slower times is to force yourself to go slower than the frantic pace you feel like you need. Just try to be constantly turning. Also, easy optimizations are very helpful. Play around with block style F2L shortcuts. Use tips from Gilles Roux's and Lars Petrus' sites. Also, try to use corners or edges already correctly placed to your advantage. Andy Camann's site has a great working corner method description you can use for this. -Mike Bennett >From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...> >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Need F2L Help... >Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 07:58:46 +0200 > >Hi, > >My averages are like you : around 25 (best : 23.77) > >But I average 13~14 seconds for the F2L and 11 seconds (!!!) for the LL. > >To improve my F2L times, I used Macky's Tips >(http://cubefreak.hp.infoseek.co.jp/speedcubing_tips.html) + I had a >F2L cube which is very useful to improve your F2L. >Another important thing is to be able to use FreeSlots when you do the >3 first F2L when it's necessary. >You should also try to see what you can do when you have 2 F2L done >but not correctly placed in order to save them. > >For me, I have to work on the LL :p.
1616. blindfold average
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 00:22:14 -0600

I submit this as an open challenge to all the blindfolders out there:

----- JNetCube Best Average for Sun Jul 10 00:08:36 MDT 2005 -----

Average: 4:02.62

Fastest Time: 2:56.39
Slowest Time: 5:06.97
Standard Deviation: 29.12

Individual Times:
1) 3:52.53 L' D2 U' L2 U' R' D U' R2 B2 F D2 L' D2 B2 U2 B2 F2 L2 B' D
F' R F2 L
2) (2:56.39) L2 D' L' R' D F2 R' D' F2 U' D' R2 L D2 L2 R U D' R B2 D2
L B2 L2 U
3) 4:20.73 U' F2 R2 D L D2 B' R2 D2 R' L U D' L F U2 R' B F U' L B' R'
L' F
4) 3:34.25 F B2 L B F U' F' L' F2 B U' B' L2 U' R' D R' D2 U B L U2 F
B2 L2
5) 3:29.78 R' F' B2 L' F2 U R2 D' R2 B2 D2 L2 R B2 F R2 L F2 R F2 U D
F2 B D2
6) 3:15.89 F2 U2 F2 B2 D2 L2 U' F' B L F' D B F' U' B' L R' F B U2 B' L
R' D
7) 3:58.78 L' F' R L2 B' D2 R F' U B2 F2 L' R D L2 U' F' R' U' R U2 L F
B D'
8) 4:43.80 B2 U2 L2 R B2 L B2 U' R2 D2 F2 B R' F' B L2 F' U' D2 R D' F
D2 L' R'
9) 4:31.32 L U' L2 U2 F L' R' D U2 R2 F2 U' B F2 L D2 F2 D F' D' U2 F D
B2 R'
10) 4:15.93 F R2 U D B D2 F' B' L' R B' D2 B' U D L' F' R U2 L U2 B' L'
U R'
11) (DNF) R F' D U' B2 R' D' B R2 F R' F2 B' U L2 R F' D' F R' L' F' U2
F L'
12) 4:23.15 B U2 B' R2 L B2 R' U' F D' U R D' L R2 U' L B2 D2 B' L' D2
R U2 R'
13) (5:06.97) L2 D' U F L2 F R' B F' U2 B U F U L' D2 F2 L2 B' D' L' F'
R U2 B

J. Bernett Orlando should promptly beat me. Though, please... let me
stay in first place for just a couple of days.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631

1617. Re: [Speed cubing group] Need F2L Help...
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 05:46:30 -0400

I have a question regarding the F2L - I have been cubing for a few
months and I average around 32s - my 3-look LL is very fast (haven't
yet learned OLL) but my F2L is horrible.
I use an intuitive method, cross on bottom, and many of the moves I
can "see" are not optimal at all - it should be around 6-7 moves per
pair and many cases for me are much more than that.

My question is, what is the general way of doing F2L, intuitively or
by memorization (or a mixture of both?).


Bryan Mytko
bryanosaurus@...


On Jul 10, 2005, at 1:58 AM, Gilles van den Peereboom wrote:

> Hi,
>
> My averages are like you : around 25 (best : 23.77)
>
> But I average 13~14 seconds for the F2L and 11 seconds (!!!) for
> the LL.
>
> To improve my F2L times, I used Macky's Tips
> (http://cubefreak.hp.infoseek.co.jp/speedcubing_tips.html) + I had a
> F2L cube which is very useful to improve your F2L.
> Another important thing is to be able to use FreeSlots when you do the
> 3 first F2L when it's necessary.
> You should also try to see what you can do when you have 2 F2L done
> but not correctly placed in order to save them.
>
> For me, I have to work on the LL :p.

1621. [Speed cubing group] Re: Improved PLL Algs??
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 13:41:16 -0000

Thanks for explaining these. Though it makes these parts easier I must admit I still have trouble with the alg as a whole and I'm not sure it'll be faster for me than the old one I used ;-) Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Richard Patterson <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > I was sorting through my email and noticed I left no > reply for this...strange. > > >But how do you do the B' and B moves > > fast? > > (U2B') > > right thumb on the R sticker of the URF corner, turn > with your wrist for the U2, then pull the (B') with > your thumb. > > (R'B) > > you do this the same way you would do R'U, by tilting > the cube toward you a bit. > > Hope this helps! > > -Richard > --- Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > > "richy_jr_2000" > > <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > > > > > > (RU')(R'l')(U2B')(RU2)(R'B)U2(lR)UR'U)

1623. Re: proof of pairity
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 13:58:55 -0000

Is there a reason I can't reply to just you? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Proof that the number of clockwise twists on a corner is congruent to > 0 (mod3) http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/lemma1.html I think it would be better to put the first paragraph of the proof before your claim, otherwise the claim talks about things that haven't been defined yet. > We can see that rotating the entire cube preserves the orientation > of the corners based on our definition above, since the reference > colors will change with all the pieces given any x or z rotation. What do you mean the reference colors will change? This sentence is a bit unclear to me. You could also say that F2 is just FF and F' is just FFF and R is just yFy' etc without proving them all separately. Stefan
1624. Results of Kyoto Contest
From: makimoto2000us <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 14:02:02 -0000

Hi everbody,

We would like to let you know about Kyoto Contest today.

It is the first successful event under the regulation of WCA.
Yuki Hayashi, unofficial record holder of 4x4x4, hit the new world
records.
The times were 01:00.38, 01:04.10, 01:10.44 (average = 01:04.97).

It may take some time to edit the videotape but we will put his all
three solves on some web site.

You can see the results on my web site temporally.

We really had great time.
Thanks everybody.


http://rokumentai.akimoto3.com/kyoto20050710.htm

1626. Re: [Speed cubing group] Need F2L Help...
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 16:55:44 +0200

> My question is, what is the general way of doing F2L, intuitively or
> by memorization (or a mixture of both?).

I think both.
You should first try to do most of them by yourself.
Then if you want, you can check with F2L algorithm list.
But the problem with that list is that it's for the last F2L.
So it works for all of them, but in some cases they are not optimal
because of free slots you could use to do F2L.

So:
1. Search yourself (not only when timing, for exemple take a
situation, then search what you can do. )
2. With time and practice, you'll find other ways (better ?) to do some F2L.
3. If you want to have some idea, check the F2L algorithms list but
don't study it stupidly.
"Make sense of what you're doing."

;-)

1631. Re: [Speed cubing group] Northern California Tournament
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 16:33:34 -0000

The more I think about it, the less fair your suggestions seems! Perhaps you are forgetting how big the United States is? This year, there are a total of 3 planned tournaments in California. The next closest tournament is OVER 1700 miles away. Almost every tournament in Europe is within about 1000 miles from the furthest one, which gives you (I am assuming you're from Europe?) a total of 7 competitions. Just look at the SCC Events page! The New York competition is just about as far from the California competitions as it is from the Dutch Open! I'm having trouble seeing what's so unfair and who it is unfair to. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Crispy <redivre@y...> wrote: > What if you aren't lucky enough to host your own > tournament - what is the suggestion then? > > --- Evan Gates <evan.gates@g...> wrote: > > > And if you feel like there aren't enough tournaments > > in your area, do > > as Tyson does and host your own... > > > > -E > > > > On 7/10/05, Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > (Warning: 1st paragraph is not serious) > > > > > > Please don't use the internet. 1632. Java is slow (was: Re: 2+ user JNetCube (JNetCube2?))
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 16:52:06 -0000

> Ok, looking at a screenshot it's pretty obvious you do make good use
> of layout managers. But I'd be surprised if there were big problems in
> different OSs/WindowManagers. Have you seen problems in the past or
> even have screenshots of them?
>
> Stefan

AWT is not so much a 'problem' as it is an annoyance. The programs
function fine and are still usable, they just have totally different
appearances on each OS I use it on. I like swing because it promises
that the GUI will look fine on any OS that supports a full JRE. I have
a few minimal-type window managers I use in Linux that don't have
native buttons (or even decent fonts), so AWT wouldn't work in that
case. I just like making stuff that I will be able to use on any
computer in my house (or any computer in anyone else's house I guess) :)

Applet programming is a little different because you have to use awt
(at least you did the last time I made an applet). That's why some
java applets don't work on some of my computers. I have an X Server
running, but not a powerful window manager. Only swing works for me in
that case.

-Chris




1633. [Speed cubing group] Mat vs Minimat
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 19:00:55 +0200

Hello,

I'm planning on buying a StackmatTimer.
But I'm hesitating between the regular large Mat or the MiniMat.

I'm only planning to use it to solve cubes, magic and small puzzles.

There is no price difference.
Is it really useful to have the large Mat to solve cubes ?
Or is it mostly a problem because of the size ?

Or is the best solution to have both ? :p
(+10$ is not that much, and it could be useful on travel, etc)

What do you think ?
Thx, Gilles.


1634. Rubiks Cube replacement stickers
From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 17:51:56 -0000

I have a Rubiks brand cube, the kind with the plastic film over the
stickers so it peels off after a while revealing the color which
scrape off very quickly. so I replaced all the stickers with a
replacement set I bought off rubiksdotcom. last time I did this, they
were GOOD stickers without plastic film and they lasted for AGES. but
now, the ones I used to replace them, the plastic film is peeling off
again. that makes me very, very mad....why in the world would
rubiksdotcom change the replacement stickers to a worse quality? are
they just trying to make me buy more of them, more often?

and most importantly, is there anywhere where I can get high quality
replacement 3x3x3 stickers?

I apologize....? I really didn't mean to make you mad. I'm sorry. I just don't think that Caltech should be allowed to hold as many OFFICIAL tournaments as they do. that's because official tournaments are where official world records can be set, so if they're always attended by the same people, being the people at Caltech, will most likely always have the official world records. making it a little bit unfair. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > All right, > > In my very humble opinion, you're all jerks. 1649. Re: [Speed cubing group] Java is slow (was: Re: 2+ user JNetCube (JNetCube2?))
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 15:05:56 -0400

On 7/10/05, burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > AWT is not so much a 'problem' as it is an annoyance. The programs > function fine and are still usable, they just have totally different > appearances on each OS I use it on. I like swing because it promises > that the GUI will look fine on any OS that supports a full JRE. I have > a few minimal-type window managers I use in Linux that don't have > native buttons (or even decent fonts), so AWT wouldn't work in that > case. I just like making stuff that I will be able to use on any > computer in my house (or any computer in anyone else's house I guess) :) I'm not sure what you're talking about. I've done some Java programming, and I've never heard of the window manager affecting whether or not you can run AWT or Swing. The only thing that I could think of that would affect this is whether or not the classes are present in your JRE (Java runtime environment). Or maybe this is a Kaffe vs. Sun JVM problem that you are talking about. > Applet programming is a little different because you have to use awt > (at least you did the last time I made an applet). That's why some > java applets don't work on some of my computers. I have an X Server > running, but not a powerful window manager. Only swing works for me in > that case. You can make applets that use Swing. Swing wasn't included in the Microsoft JVM, but there were still ways to make it work (see http://www.jguru.com/faq/view.jsp?EID=135132).
1650. Re: [Speed cubing group] non-California tournaments

He/she can be the WCA delegate, and will make sure that the full WCA regulations are followed. The problem is that there are only a few of us willing to offer time (and money) to organize events. There are some people out there who did this, some did it a few times. But it was ALWAYS to help other people, instead of for their own benefit. Cube tournaments have always been great, kind of like big reunions. It is absolutely unfair to complain if there is no tournament in your neighborhood. What prevents you from organizing one? And if you REALLY want to attend a tournament, then what prevents you from going to one? This is to ALL of you. If you are thinking of organizing a tournament, then just do it! If you contact Tyson, Gilles or me, then maybe we can help. Have fun, Ron No complaining please! ----- Original Message ----- From: Crispy To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Sunday, July 10, 2005 8:53 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] non-California tournaments --- Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote: > Here's an idea. I am just making sure that it would be totally feasible for myself to hold my own tournament if the requirements were met. True? 1651. Re: [Speed cubing group] Northern California Tournament
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 13:34:08 -0600

All right, my last post. I promise, and I'll be nicer in this one.

If you'll notice for the 2005 year, there has only been one tournament
held so far in Southern California. In October, we will hold the
Caltech Fall tournament so that will be two tournaments in Southern
California. In Northern California, there was the San Francisco
tournament—that makes one. If we hold another one, then it would be
two tournaments.

As you can clearly see, not one of these locations is have an
excessive number of tournaments. Furthermore, given the number of
cubers in Southern California, I would think that four tournaments each
year was a good number. That's one tournament every three months and
each one of these tournaments is bringing in over 40 people.

The Chevron gas station on Hill Ave. and Colorado Ave. in Pasadena to
the Chevron gas station in San Mateo, California on 4th Ave. is 370
miles. That's about 6 hours of driving. 5 and a half if I don't make
too many stops. For all purposes, Northern California and Southern
California are separate regions. With the exception of Texas, a six
hour drive easily puts you across state boarders. And on the east
cost, would put you across two or three.

I spend a lot of time and energy organizing these tournaments. It
should be conceivable to you that perhaps it is much more feasible for
you to come to Caltech or San Francisco than it is for me to go to your
home and hold a tournament there. I cannot do these tournaments
without my friends. The success in these tournaments lie in people
such as Mark Team or Sleeping Leyan and Blindfoldmasterwoman Shelley.
Without these people, the tournaments would not run smoothly. You
might be able to ask me to host a tournament near you, but I can't
possibly ask all of these people to come with me every where I go.

The origin of our tournament in Dallas was simple: I was thinking of
museums, Shelley suggest the Science Place, they liked the idea, and I
have been working with them since February to make this tournament
happen. If you want a tournament somewhere, how am I supposed to make
it happen if you go around complaining about tournaments in California?
That doesn't give me ANY information on where a tournament should be
held.

Take note of competitors like Bob and Macky. Bob has been to San
Francisco, Chicago, New York... you name, he's there. He'll be in
Dallas too. Macky has been to Pasadena, naturally, but he's also
traveled to San Francisco and New York, and he'll be off to Dallas as
well. Simply said, these are dedicated cubers willing to make the
effort of travel. There are opportunities here in the United States
for Rubik's Cube competitions, and they go ahead and take these
opportunities.

You complain about not having the resources. I am NOT a welfare
program. If you are really that great at the Rubik's Cube, then
someone would sponsor you. If not, all you need is the desire and
determination to make these things happen. If you wanted to come to
California to compete, and you wanted it bad enough, I'm sure you can
accomplish it. The fact of the matter is you have a computer and that
alone says that you have the resources and the intelligence to make
things happens. The motivation and determination, well, that you'll
have to dig up yourself.

You claim why should you have to invest money so that I can go to your
tournament? Well, you've treated me in such a manner that I don't
think I would be willing to spend my own money to help you set up your
own tournament, nor would I be willing to spend the time. Your
complaining shows a lack of understanding of the amount of work and
energy that goes in to these tournaments. You should notice that I
generally don't compete at the tournaments which I'm in charge in.
That should be an indication of the demands of running the tournament.

As a final note, I will take your complaining as a compliment because
you have noticed that a great deal of competitions are held under the
Caltech name and I thank you for recognizing my hard work.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology


1652. puzzle sharing
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 13:42:16 -0600

Oh, and by the way...

Buy your own 2x2x2! Puzzle sharing on a small scale is all right, but
you all need to make an effort to get your own puzzles. With a lot of
puzzle sharing, you start to hold back the tournament and it gets
really frustrating. I'm warning you ALL in advance for all future
tournaments... go buy your own 2x2x2, NOW!

World Championships will be very tight on time and if there's any
delay, such as something like (oh, he has my 2x2x2), we'll probably
have to skip you. We can't lose that much stage time because you
didn't bring your own puzzle.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

1655. California tournaments
From: "skeneegee" <skeneegee@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 20:53:06 -0000

Even though I live in California, Caltech is a 6 hour drive from my
house, it might as well be in another state as far as it is but I
still make the drive down there every chance I get to compete. Sure
I'm an adult so I am able to arrange it for myself a little easier
than a younger cuber might, but we can't put the world on hold until
they grow up;)

What you really need to think about is not that it's unfair that
California has 4 tournaments a year, but there's 4 chances per year
you may be able to come to one. Heck just a few years ago, there were
no tournaments at all to go to, and now that they are organized (very
well I must say) and more frequent, I find it hard to believe that any
speedcubers would complain about this. Just in the past year Tyson and
Caltech has done more to grow the sport especially in CALIFORNIA where
he LIVES than anyone else has done wherever they live.

Get off your butt, quit complaining, and do something about it. Do
some public cubing, try to get on TV somehow with your amazing talent
to get it some exposure in your area, just do something, be creative.
You have to generate some interest where you live if you ever hope to
get a tournament near you that you might have to organize yourself.
Band together with other speedcubers in your area and make it happen.

nobody likes whiners, let's try to keep it positive




1656. Re: proof of pairity
From: "al_yyz" <anders.larsson@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 21:17:31 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, _jaap <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- "al_yyz" <anders.larsson@i...> wrote: > > > The edges pose not the same problem since we > > > can define that each single move flips four edges. Thus, the > > > U-turn of > > > a solved cube results in four flipped edges... > > --- Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > Hmm... how do you "define" that each move flips four edges? If the cube is treated as symmetric, that is, all face turns are equivalent, and if we accept that such a thing as flipped edges exist, any quarter turn must flip at least one edge. Due to symmetry, four edges must be flipped in a quarter turn. The flip can be defined as follows: - An edge cubie is not flipped if it can be returned to its original position correctly oriented using an even number of quarter turns. (zero is also an even number!) - An edge cubie is flipped if it can be returned to its original position correctly oriented using an odd number of quarter turns. This definition is maybe not ideal when, for instance, solving LL, but it is a definition that treats all face turn equivalent. /Anders
1657. Re: proof of pairity
From: "al_yyz" <anders.larsson@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 21:19:14 -0000

That's my point. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, portoseb <no_reply@y...> wrote: [---] > The idea is that the cube is > no longer considered symmetrical. That is, different face turns are > different. Namely, U and D turns are different from the other face > turns. That's my point. For the edges, the cube can be considered as symmetrical and still the flip can be defined. See my other post. I have not found a way to do this for the twist of the corners. Something like your definition below is maybe the best we can achieve. /Anders > > We'll consider the reference frame as being the U and D faces. The > twist of a corner is how many times it has to be twisted clockwise > so that it's U/D face is in the U/D face (this can always be done, > since every corner belongs to either of these two faces). In the > starting position, the total twist is 0. Now let's see what > different face turns do. > > U and D don't change the total twist. It is then easy to see that F, > B, R and L are symmetrical to each other, so we'll consider doing > the move F. We will have 4 twisted corners. The ones in the UFL and > DFR positions have twist 1, and the ones in the UFR and DFL > positions have twist 2. The total is 0. > > So no move changes the total twist. >
1658. Re: [Speed cubing group] California tournaments
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 16:27:49 -0500

I wholeheartedly concur. Look at Bob Burton. He travelled to Caltech to cube from New Jersey. He went to Chicago to compete. I have the sneaking suspicion he'll crop up in Dallas, too. Why don't you try to do the same thing?

I realize you're only 16. Even so, if it bothered you so much, you could find a way to get there. This advice may seem harsh, but it's coming from someone working 7 day weeks in order to pay for a trip to Germany in a few weeks.

Caltech tournaments should not be limited in number simply because they're in the state of California. For one thing, it's a very large state. Even many California cubers have long commutes to get there. Also, I don't understand why you think the community as a whole shouldn't try for as many good tournaments as possible. This gives more people a chance to compete, more exposure for the community, and gives the individual competitors the most chances to improve.

I understand you're somewhat limited in your travel abilities, not only due to your age and financial situations, but also your location. You're 900 miles from Caltech. I'm twice as far. I've missed out on a lot of tournaments I'd liked to have attended because of this. It's still no grounds to be bitter. It only makes my resolve to get to future tournaments and compete well that much stronger.

-Mike Bennett

1659. blindfolds
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 16:25:15 -0600

Hi Everyone,

I just did a blindfold solve on a StackMat with a blindfold so I could
practice under tournament conditions. I discovered that the first time
I didn't quite pull the blindfold down very well and it was possible to
see a little. I was hoping for suggestions on how to improve our
blindfold technology. The googles they used in Sweden looked good, but
I think it would be nicer to have blindfolds that you could put on more
quickly. Anyway, ideas?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology



1660. Re: [Speed cubing group] blindfolds
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 16:30:41 -0600

Did I just say "googles"?

Actually, I think the problem isn't that much of a problem. The
elastic band on the blindfold I have is very loose. With the tighter
ones, the blindfolds hurt your eyes and face enough that there's no way
you could open them without dying. :-P

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 22:37:02 -0000

You know me all too well. I booked my flight yesterday... :P ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > I wholeheartedly concur. Look at Bob Burton. He travelled to Caltech to cube from New Jersey. He went to Chicago to compete. I have the sneaking suspicion he'll crop up in Dallas, too. Why don't you try to do the same thing? > > I realize you're only 16. Even so, if it bothered you so much, you could find a way to get there. This advice may seem harsh, but it's coming from someone working 7 day weeks in order to pay for a trip to Germany in a few weeks. > > Caltech tournaments should not be limited in number simply because they're in the state of California. For one thing, it's a very large state. Even many California cubers have long commutes to get there. Also, I don't understand why you think the community as a whole shouldn't try for as many good tournaments as possible. This gives more people a chance to compete, more exposure for the community, and gives the individual competitors the most chances to improve. > > I understand you're somewhat limited in your travel abilities, not only due to your age and financial situations, but also your location. You're 900 miles from Caltech. I'm twice as far. I've missed out on a lot of tournaments I'd liked to have attended because of this. It's still no grounds to be bitter. It only makes my resolve to get to future tournaments and compete well that much stronger. > > -Mike Bennett > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: skeneegee > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Sunday, July 10, 2005 3:53 PM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] California tournaments > > > Even though I live in California, Caltech is a 6 hour drive from my > house, it might as well be in another state as far as it is but I > still make the drive down there every chance I get to compete. Sure > I'm an adult so I am able to arrange it for myself a little easier > than a younger cuber might, but we can't put the world on hold until > they grow up;) > > What you really need to think about is not that it's unfair that > California has 4 tournaments a year, but there's 4 chances per year > you may be able to come to one. Heck just a few years ago, there were > no tournaments at all to go to, and now that they are organized (very > well I must say) and more frequent, I find it hard to believe that any > speedcubers would complain about this. Just in the past year Tyson and > Caltech has done more to grow the sport especially in CALIFORNIA where > he LIVES than anyone else has done wherever they live. > > Get off your butt, quit complaining, and do something about it. Do > some public cubing, try to get on TV somehow with your amazing talent > to get it some exposure in your area, just do something, be creative. > You have to generate some interest where you live if you ever hope to > get a tournament near you that you might have to organize yourself. > Band together with other speedcubers in your area and make it happen. > > nobody likes whiners, let's try to keep it positive > > > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ > YAHOO! 1663. [Speed cubing group] you have been cubing too much...
From: François Sechet <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 01:49:26 +0200 (CEST)

... if the code for your credit card is 2295
... if there is a cube (or something related) included in your signature
... if you have had one (or more) flirts because of your cubing skills
... if that same person left you because of your cubing skills
... if you have been at the 1981 champs and are still around
... if you have spent your whole sunday (today) doing nothing but being on the fmc chat and racing (e.g owning) everyone there
... if you have been asked by the airport ppl checking your hand luggage to solve it because they saw it on X-ray
... if you have been asked by that guy reading the Wall Street Journal in front of you in the bus/train to stop "the annoying noise" (and actually you left and waited for the next bus just in order to continue cubing...)
... if you have nothing better to do than read and reply to this post
... if you understand why it would be funny, for example, to have his credit card's code being 2295
... if you have to go eat and are actually hungry and your family has been calling you for 10 minutes but you've been staying here writing that and therefore you should leave before you get in real trouble.
Francois

1664. Re: [Speed cubing group] blindfolds
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 17:41:59 -0700

You could build a kind of screen that was placed between the solvers
head and cube. Sort of like the sneeze guard at buffet restaurants.

An other idea is a full hood covering the head. With breathing holes
only.

The other cheating avenue is if you let people use their own cubes.
It's not hard to put some distinctive feelable marks on some stickers.
It can easily happen to a worn cube even without you trying.

/Lars

On Jul 10, 2005, at 15:25, Tyson Mao wrote:

> Hi Everyone,
>
> I just did a blindfold solve on a StackMat with a blindfold so I could
> practice under tournament conditions. I discovered that the first time
> I didn't quite pull the blindfold down very well and it was possible to
> see a little. I was hoping for suggestions on how to improve our
> blindfold technology. The googles they used in Sweden looked good, but
> I think it would be nicer to have blindfolds that you could put on more
> quickly. Anyway, ideas?

- - - - - - - - - - - -
"The mind is like a parachute. It doesn't work unless it's open."
--- Frank Zappa

Lars Petrus - lars@... http://lar5.com



1665. Re: Speedcubing coach needed for a film
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 00:58:46 -0000

>d_funny007 wrote:
> Well, first off, there are many "equally proficient" cubers out in
> the SF area... say LarsP or Tyson (DanK used to live there).
>
> I don't think the point is to do something as
> entertaining/extravegant as possible, they probably just want to
> follow the script as close as possible.
>
> Also, who says they wouldn't be willing to fly someone in from
afar.
> The letter was from Patrick, and it sounded to me like they just
> wanted SF area for convience of all parties.
>
> Plane ticket like that would cost less then $500 round trip
actually
> so that was a gross over-estimate.
>
> I don't find anything odd about the whole deal.
>
> Unless the actor has small slender (and perhaps Asian) hands, I
> don't think they would want Macky. If I was directing, I would want
> a hand-double reasonably close to the actor's as my top priority,
> not looking for speed. I'm sure any cuber under 35s can show off
mad
> deterity/speed if they really wanted to and a scene/cube was setup
> for it.
>
> Don't assume they are looking for that much authenticity...
>
>
> -Doug

Doug

Well, you took that rather hard. Allow me to clarify, I was merely
kidding about getting Macky to do a one handed solve for the scene.
I think the concept of a script is pretty self explanatory, but your
dedication to the writer's guild was not lost. Do you have shares in
the industry?

I mentioned flying Chris, in particular, because it was he who they
contacted in regards to the opportunity, so obviously they were
interested in him. Especially since the email stated if HE, or one of
his friends, could do it. This led me to believe that they were
hoping for Chris first. My point was if that was the angle they had
hoped for, why not shell out a few bucks to get it? However, I am
sure you are more than capable of being the hand double and/or coach,
if reading that will make you feel better.

And I didn't do research for a plane ticket from Chris' home to San
Francisco, but know that when I looked for a ticket to Dallas from
Toronto, it was in the $700 range, so I was merely "ball parking"
it. I also offered it up as a question, not as a concrete statistic.
But I sure appreciate you clearing up such an important detail.

Were you having a bad day?

1669. Re: Midwest Tournament Anyone? (was non-California tournaments)
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 02:02:46 -0000

Well looking over his original post, I think he just feels it is unfair that a disproportionate number of tournemnts are held in CA. And from that alone, it does appear to be unfair for the rest of us. The obvious solution would be to limit the number of *offical* tournaments. (It's of course not possible to limit unoffical tournaments.) However, say there are 5 nearly identical tournaments at location X one year, and the limit is 3. Who gets to decide which of those 3 are offical... it's kind of a toss-up. World rankings will differ depending on that decision, and even if it is decided in advance, there is always the chance for bad-timing to happen... a very fast guy is out of town, or another very fast guy just happens to be visiting from out of town. So setting limits is not the best solution. It seems to me like anyone with enough experience can attempt to set up a tournament where they deem fit. I'd say it's fair to ask for 18 months experience in the cubing community. It's also a must to have someone trusted on site, and that person may or may not be the site coordinator. Most people that have been around for over 5 years or have ran previous tournements ought to be trustworthy enough, pending WCA decision.... Crispy, you failed to mention *WHERE* you would like a tournament to be held.... Instead of simply complaining, if you be more specific maybe somebody here is willing to help you out. I am at the initial planning stages of a tournament for the Midwest area, which seems to be lacking. Hopefully I can work something out with Tyson, Jon, and Jake on it. Though I do note that one was done in Chicago about 6 months ago already. I don't want to conflict with anyone else's tournament, or I'd like to get permission to work out a symmutaneous/distributed tournament like they do for ARML. That would mean starting everything on two (or more) sites at the same time, have the same events, and use identical scrambles. (This is regardless of time zones, but the scrambles would have to be held under the tightest security and be devolged at the latest possible moment.) So as for what Ron said about lack of time and money.... *I am willing to offer the time*. Now money.... that's another issue, but I'm sure I could get some help on that from some of you guys out there (or corporate sponsorship). Though typically entry fees oughta cover it in most cases. Note that it's still quite speculative and there's already lots of stuff already planned for the remainder of the year, so this is more for say January... and I'll be trying to get Tyson's help on it. Alright let's have a vote... maybe oughta do a poll here. Where should it be and when? I want a LOT of feed back. Location: Chicago metro Chicago suburbs Kalamazoo Ann Arbor (my town) Other Time: Same time as Dallas (means I won't have to go, but that requires quick action as it's coming soon and an OK from Tyson) September (not same weekend as the other tournament in Europe) October (our retaliation for not being able to go to Dutch cube day) November (no, it out to be a rule that no tournaments may be held on the same month as a WC) December? (maybe too soon after WC and who wants to travel around the holidays?) late-January (sounds evenly placed there) or some other time later? -Doug P.S. - Is it just me, or don't you all think that Erno Rubik is whealthy enough he could/should setup an endowment fund for cube- related travel expenses. (There could be a committee overseeing it...) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > Hi friendz, > > Everyone is free to organize a tournament. For official tournaments we do need someone attending, whom can fully trust. He/she can be the WCA delegate, and will make sure that the full WCA regulations are followed. > > The problem is that there are only a few of us willing to offer time (and money) to organize events. There are some people out there who did this, some did it a few times. But it was ALWAYS to help other people, instead of for their own benefit. Cube tournaments have always been great, kind of like big reunions. > > It is absolutely unfair to complain if there is no tournament in your neighborhood. What prevents you from organizing one? > And if you REALLY want to attend a tournament, then what prevents you from going to one? > > This is to ALL of you. If you are thinking of organizing a tournament, then just do it! > If you contact Tyson, Gilles or me, then maybe we can help. > > Have fun, > > Ron > > No complaining please! > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Crispy > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Sunday, July 10, 2005 8:53 PM > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] non-California tournaments > > > --- Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > > Here's an idea. You get me a planet ticket and a > > place to stay to where, and I'll hold a tournament > >there. > > Can't we hold our own tournament pending we meet > the prior requirements laid out by the WCA? I don't > believe that any of us were asking you to spend any of > your own out of pocket expenses for a tournament that > is outside of your area. I agree that you work hard > and put on good tournaments - I have seen them and > heard about them - that isn't an issue. If you > have/had the money to get to NY and to Dallas more > power to you, no one is disputing that - especially if > you volunteer to attend. > I am just making sure that it would be totally > feasible for myself to hold my own tournament if the > requirements were met. 1671. Re: you have been cubing too much...

get late-night cravings to solve a rubik's cube and don't have to turn on any lights to do it. ...if you ever considered Rubik's cubes as an interior design idea. ...if there is/was a giant rubik's cube dangling from your light fixtures, celling, or protruding out of a wall. ...if you fell like your sticking out in a crowd *without* a cube in hand. ...if you started becomming interested in dating a co-worker *after* she brought a square-1 to work one afternoon. ...if you you would consider marrying a girl that could solve the cube in under 30s. ...if you have a car painted in the form of a rubik's cube. ...if your licence plate is "SPD QBR". ...if you know the names of the two individuals whom the last two lines refer to. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, 1672. [Speed cubing group] Re: Rubiks Cube replacement stickers
From: "jello33" <chris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 02:20:31 -0000

Hey Everyone,

Thanks for all the kind words about my stickers. If you like the
Tiles, I'll have new ones next week with a rougher surface for better
grip.

Anyway here's the rules for winning the Sunday Contest Prize:

The winner of the contest will receive a set of stickers for any six-
color puzzle of his or her choice. The winner will then be
ineligible to win again for 4 weeks of participation, but will
continue earn "tokens" or random drawing entries for consecutive
participations in the Sunday Contest; See next paragraph.

In addition to having a winner for speed, a random drawing will
be held for a set of randomly chosen stickers. Winners will be
ineligible for 4 participations in the contest. For every
consecutive participation participants will get an additional "token"
or entry into the drawing for the next week. So the more that you
participate, the better the chances that you'll win the drawing.


As you can see it is well worth it to enter as any random entry can
win!!

Thanks
Chris
www.cubesmith.com




1673. Rules on BLD
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 03:30:50 -0000

LarsP brings up a good point...

I think it would be a good rule for sompetition that the tournament
officals provide decent (but new) cubes for bld events. THe only
problem is the color scheme might be differnt, fo this would have to
be requested b4 hand.

But I think that if we were to adapt such a rule, we could aboid any
possiblity of cheating in the event.

It shouldn't be too difficult...


-Doug




1674. Re: Rules on BLD
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 03:36:27 -0000

I am 100% against this. I think we should require the cuber to resticker their cube with provided sticker sheets, or if that is too expensive the cuber's own. This means that the cube will be stiff and hard to use triggers on. Also who's going to buy the cubes? The organizer him/herself? Stickers are cheaper anyway. Also you can't put your cube together such that if a piece pops you know how to put it back in. A new cube won't have your internal "system" for the pieces. So if you pop on a new cube you're screwed, rather than being able to continue on your own cube. I like the spirit of the idea, but lets just replace the stickers only. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > LarsP brings up a good point... > > I think it would be a good rule for sompetition that the tournament > officals provide decent (but new) cubes for bld events. THe only > problem is the color scheme might be differnt, fo this would have to > be requested b4 hand. > > But I think that if we were to adapt such a rule, we could aboid any > possiblity of cheating in the event. > > It shouldn't be too difficult... > > > -Doug
1675. Re: [Speed cubing group] blindfolds
From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 03:43:46 -0000

you can just buy like a bandana or something, can't you? and just tie it around your head.... I don't compete in blindfold solving, and so I just close my eyes while I'm doing it, or turn off the light, or both. usually both.... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Not all of use have blindfolds. But then again I've never shopped for > one. > > I am however starting to disturb my roommates by sitting around with > my shirt over my heaad all the time, lol. > > Links to ordering good quality blindfuolds would be appriciated; I > need a bunch for a tournament I might host (c.f. my last post). > > Do stores like Mijers carry them...? I never bothered to look... > > > -Doug > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Michael Atkinson" > <unipsycho6@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus > <lars@n...> > > wrote: > > > You could build a kind of screen that was placed between the > solvers > > > head and cube. Sort of like the sneeze guard at buffet restaurants. > > > > > > > I like this idea....just make a single plastic covering that's about > > 2-3 feet wide, and maybe a foot high on the table, so your hands can > > fit under it comfortably. > > > > wait....what's wrong with just wearing a blindfold?
1676. Re: Rules on BLD
From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 03:46:08 -0000

I'm with Chris....even if you do have a cube that's perfectly lubed and tensioned and everything, it still won't feel like your own, no matter what. makes it more comfortable using your own cube....and we all know that it would be hard if not impossible to customize a cube specially to be able to solve it faster, without anyone else noticing. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > LarsP brings up a good point... > > I think it would be a good rule for sompetition that the tournament > officals provide decent (but new) cubes for bld events. THe only > problem is the color scheme might be differnt, fo this would have to > be requested b4 hand. > > But I think that if we were to adapt such a rule, we could aboid any > possiblity of cheating in the event. > > It shouldn't be too difficult... > > > -Doug
1677. Re: Midwest Tournament Anyone? (was non-California tournaments)
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 03:49:13 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Well looking over his original post, I think he just feels it is > unfair that a disproportionate number of tournemnts are held in CA. > And from that alone, it does appear to be unfair for the rest of us. I agree. I don't see anything to be unfair about the CA tournaments. > So setting limits is not the best solution. I think limiting the tournaments is a terrible idea and am completely opposed. > It seems to me like anyone with enough experience can attempt to set > up a tournament where they deem fit. I'd say it's fair to ask for 18 > months experience in the cubing community. It's also a must to have > someone trusted on site, and that person may or may not be the site > coordinator. Most people that have been around for over 5 years or > have ran previous tournements ought to be trustworthy enough, > pending WCA decision.... Aren't there already rules about who can run a tournament? I could be wrong... > Crispy, you failed to mention *WHERE* you would like a tournament to > be held.... Instead of simply complaining, if you be more specific > maybe somebody here is willing to help you out. There is WAY too much complaining going on about things lately. > I am at the initial planning stages of a tournament for the Midwest > area, which seems to be lacking. Hopefully I can work something out > with Tyson, Jon, and Jake on it. Though I do note that one was done > in Chicago about 6 months ago already. I am also trying to plan a tournament for this Fall. Since I started the Rutgers Univ. Rubik's Cube Club, I can get funding from the school and the school can be used as a venue without having to worry about paying for equipment or whatever. Though not in the Midwest, there haven't been many east coast competitions here, either, so hopefully this would spark some more interest in the area. > Location: > Chicago metro > Chicago suburbs > Kalamazoo > Ann Arbor (my town) > Other Where is Kalamazoo? Ann Arbor? Sorry, I'm not actually from the Midwest. I would be interested in attending, though (I am taking too many days off from school as it is already, however...) > Time: > Same time as Dallas (means I won't have to go, but that requires > quick action as it's coming soon and an OK from Tyson) > September (not same weekend as the other tournament in Europe) > October (our retaliation for not being able to go to Dutch cube > day) > November (no, it out to be a rule that no tournaments may be held > on the same month as a WC) > December? (maybe too soon after WC and who wants to travel around > the holidays?) > late-January (sounds evenly placed there) > or some other time later? At the same time as Dallas seems a little soon since it's only a month away, and you really should advertise for it, hype it up, etc, ya know? I wouldn't really worry too much about conflicting with other tournaments since those who would attend this tournament would probably not already be attending a different one that is occuring simultaneously, right? > P.S. - Is it just me, or don't you all think that Erno Rubik is > whealthy enough he could/should setup an endowment fund for cube- > related travel expenses. (There could be a committee overseeing > it...) Is he really that wealthy? ~ Bob
