1679. Re: [Speed cubing group] blindfolds
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 22:18:36 -0600

Hi Lars,

Yeah, I've been wondering about that myself. As the tournament
director, I do my best ability to check a person's cube for the
blindfold solve. Usually though, Macky and Leyan use Chris Licarrdi's
or Adam Zamora's stickers so those don't really wear down too much.
It's something we watch for. We're not at the point where making
people use our own cubes is necessary yet.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Jul 10, 2005, at 6:41 PM, Lars Petrus wrote:

> You could build a kind of screen that was placed between the solvers
> head and cube. Sort of like the sneeze guard at buffet restaurants.
>
> An other idea is a full hood covering the head. With breathing holes
> only.
>
> The other cheating avenue is if you let people use their own cubes.
> It's not hard to put some distinctive feelable marks on some stickers.
> It can easily happen to a worn cube even without you trying.
>
> /Lars



1680. Re: Rules on BLD
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 04:21:07 -0000

I *kinda* see what you mean. I was watching Tyson's bld pop last night, and it was freakin' hilarious. So what you say is that if an edge pops out, it is possible that the cuber "knows" how to place it back properly. So that's good I suppose. Is that allowed though? I'm not sure what the WCA rules and regulations say about pops during bld events. This needs to be spelled out I think. Actually in addition to reschemeing my new cubes and putting on new stickers, I organize the pieces such that I could tell if any cubey is orientated or not. I'm sure it would be frowned upon however, if one does the bld solve by pulling al the pieces out and placing them back in all oriented... but in the same permutaions.... But from what LarsP was saying, I think it's more serious than stickers. Other cheating is possible... certain dents *under* the stickers for example. Heck any cube, if I look hard enough could find something distinctive. I am very (and I mean very, or used to be) observant about certain things. I recall once I was able to get a run of like 50 three-card monty games due to my observational skills, the back of cards have slight ink blots that most poeple might not see. (won losts of money too :) ) So all I was trying to do was expound on someone else's post about the possibilities. I was careful to say this, when I used the word "decent" I meant for the definition to be left open-ended. So in this case I would say that decent means not "stiff or hard to use triggers on." Which is something that WCA tournaments are supposed to provide anyways according to the rules and regulations that Tyson and Ron drafted. So it *shouldn't* be overly taxing for the organizers. I'd like to hear some more opinions! Other takers? -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I am 100% against this. I think we should require the cuber to > resticker their cube with provided sticker sheets, or if that is too > expensive the cuber's own. > > This means that the cube will be stiff and hard to use triggers on. > Also who's going to buy the cubes? The organizer him/herself? > Stickers are cheaper anyway. > > Also you can't put your cube together such that if a piece pops you > know how to put it back in. A new cube won't have your internal > "system" for the pieces. So if you pop on a new cube you're screwed, > rather than being able to continue on your own cube. > > I like the spirit of the idea, but lets just replace the stickers only. > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > LarsP brings up a good point... > > > > I think it would be a good rule for sompetition that the tournament > > officals provide decent (but new) cubes for bld events. THe only > > problem is the color scheme might be differnt, fo this would have to > > be requested b4 hand. > > > > But I think that if we were to adapt such a rule, we could aboid any > > possiblity of cheating in the event. > > > > It shouldn't be too difficult... > > > > > > -Doug

1682. Re: Rules on BLD
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 04:29:04 -0000

You can't expect any cuber to perform at his/her best without using one's own cube. The cube should be inspected before the solve for any distinctive markings, and the cuber should be watched for trying to determine pieces by the "feel" of the stickers. As long as the cube seems to be uniform, I don't see any problems. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I *kinda* see what you mean. I was watching Tyson's bld pop last > night, and it was freakin' hilarious. > > So what you say is that if an edge pops out, it is possible that the > cuber "knows" how to place it back properly. So that's good I > suppose. Is that allowed though? > > I'm not sure what the WCA rules and regulations say about pops > during bld events. This needs to be spelled out I think. > > Actually in addition to reschemeing my new cubes and putting on new > stickers, I organize the pieces such that I could tell if any cubey > is orientated or not. > > I'm sure it would be frowned upon however, if one does the bld solve > by pulling al the pieces out and placing them back in all > oriented... but in the same permutaions.... > > But from what LarsP was saying, I think it's more serious than > stickers. Other cheating is possible... certain dents *under* the > stickers for example. Heck any cube, if I look hard enough could > find something distinctive. > > I am very (and I mean very, or used to be) observant about certain > things. I recall once I was able to get a run of like 50 three-card > monty games due to my observational skills, the back of cards have > slight ink blots that most poeple might not see. (won losts of money > too :) ) > > So all I was trying to do was expound on someone else's post about > the possibilities. > > I was careful to say this, when I used the word "decent" I meant for > the definition to be left open-ended. So in this case I would say > that decent means not "stiff or hard to use triggers on." > > Which is something that WCA tournaments are supposed to provide > anyways according to the rules and regulations that Tyson and Ron > drafted. So it *shouldn't* be overly taxing for the organizers. > > I'd like to hear some more opinions! Other takers? > > > -Doug > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I am 100% against this. 1683. Re: [Speed cubing group] California tournaments
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Jul 2005 22:25:29 -0700

On Jul 10, 2005, at 13:53, skeneegee wrote:
>
> Get off your butt, quit complaining, and do something about it.

Seriously people, it is that simple.

I'm not surprised by the number of California tournaments, but by the
lack of them elsewhere. And it borders on the bizarre that Tyson not
only arranges all the California tournaments, but also most of the ones
in the rest of the country. Is there really no one out there with
enough initiative and energy to get something going??

Maybe it seems very hard and mysterious if you haven't been to a
competition yourself, but it really is not that hard. If you can speed
cube you are EASILY both smart enough and have enough free time to have
no excuse for not doing it yourself.

If you attempt to use the local science museum and attract media
attention it's a whole different level, but to do a small simple
"garage" tournament with a dozen or two people is so simple I really
don't understand what's stopping people. And don't worry about making
the first one "official" if that seems hard. Unless you plan to break
some world records it really doesn't matter.

Sure, your first attempt will not be perfect, but it will work, and the
next will be much better. You probably didn't solve the cube in 20
seconds the first day you tried either. If you first attend an other
tournament and see how they do it, you'll learn a lot, but if that's
impractical, don't let that stop you. You'll figure it out.

Finally, look at other sports. I can't think of one that limits the
number of competitions allowed in an area. And none that would consider
4 competitions in a state with 36 million people a lot.

- - - - - - - - - - - -
"The mind is like a parachute. It doesn't work unless it's open."
--- Frank Zappa

Lars Petrus - lars@... http://lar5.com

according to speedcubing.com. Though I see a +$15 for each person over
18 on the rubiks.com site. So I'm kinda confused.

Who wants to room with me?


-Doug

On Jul 10, 2005, at 10:20 PM, jello33 wrote:

> Hey Everyone,
>
> Thanks for all the kind words about my stickers. If you like the
> Tiles, I'll have new ones next week with a rougher surface for better
> grip.
>
> Anyway here's the rules for winning the Sunday Contest Prize:
>
> The winner of the contest will receive a set of stickers for any six-
> color puzzle of his or her choice. The winner will then be
> ineligible to win again for 4 weeks of participation, but will
> continue earn "tokens" or random drawing entries for consecutive
> participations in the Sunday Contest; See next paragraph.
>
> In addition to having a winner for speed, a random drawing will
> be held for a set of randomly chosen stickers. Winners will be
> ineligible for 4 participations in the contest. For every
> consecutive participation participants will get an additional "token"
> or entry into the drawing for the next week. So the more that you
> participate, the better the chances that you'll win the drawing.
>
>
> As you can see it is well worth it to enter as any random entry can
> win!!
>
> Thanks
> Chris
> www.cubesmith.com
>
>

Ok we need to collect these and put them on a site somewhere... I found yours rediculously funny. And I heard DanH did some a long time ago, should hunt those down as well. ...if you dated a girl primarily because you saw her with a cube. ...if every girl you ever dated now owns a cube. ...if you get late-night cravings to solve a rubik's cube and don't have to turn on any lights to do it. ...if you ever considered Rubik's cubes as an interior design idea. ...if there is/was a giant rubik's cube dangling from your light fixtures, celling, or protruding out of a wall. ...if you fell like your sticking out in a crowd *without* a cube in hand. ...if you started becomming interested in dating a co-worker *after* she brought a square-1 to work one afternoon. ...if you you would consider marrying a girl that could solve the cube in under 30s. ...if you have a car painted in the form of a rubik's cube. ...if your licence plate is "SPD QBR". ...if you know the names of the two individuals whom the last two lines refer to. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, sunday (today) doing nothing but being on the fmc chat and racing (e.g owning) everyone there > ... if you have been asked by the airport ppl checking your hand luggage to solve it because they saw it on X-ray > ... if you have been asked by that guy reading the Wall Street Journal in front of you in the bus/train to stop "the annoying noise" (and actually you left and waited for the next bus just Indien u dit bericht onterecht ontvangt, wordt u verzocht de inhoud niet te gebruiken en de afzender direct te informeren door het bericht te retourneren. ================================================ The information contained in this message may be confidential and is intended to be exclusively for the addressee. Should you receive this message unintentionally, please do not use the contents herein and notify the sender immediately by return e-mail. ================================================ [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

1692. [Speed cubing group] Re: you have been cubing too much...
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Everyone else can probably ignore this post. Durning most of the 80's 22.95s was the offical world record. It was held by Minh Thai and done at the 1982 world championships in Budapest, Hungery. And don't call yourself a noob..., that's our job :). -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > 1211 is the number of LL algoritms... knew that, but still don't know > 2295.... in case you hadn't noticed: me = N00b > > -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- > Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens Bob Burton > Verzonden: maandag 11 juli 2005 8:33 > Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group] Re: you have been cubing too much... > > > I suppose now I should change my credit card PIN to 1211. 1693. WCA Future
From: "Stefan" <sun_helos@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 07:05:01 -0000

Hi all,

Its seems like there are quite a few ppl who think about the actual
WCA rules: Timers, 45° rule, stickers, scrambles, number of official
competitions.... And this is good! Well but how can a cuber influence
these rules? If he only has the choice of talking over the topic in
this group he may feel his powerlessness and will get frustrated.
Obviously some ppl arent too happy with some decisions and the actual
power of some young and very engaged member of the WCA. At the same
time those engaged ppl did something for us all. So we gotta be
thankfull as well.
My opinion:
As quite all of us live in democratic systems i think it would be fair
to elect the ppl who make the rules for us!
It will be a lot of work and sure discussions will start too about who
and how can be elected. Its time to start that discussion i think.
So ..what do u guys think about that idea?
Didn't i read something like "after some time for installing WCA there
will be elections" a while ago... so ..lets do it before the rules get
too solid!

I d like to thank the WCA Members, but i also think its time to get
some more democracy into it.





1694. Re: WCA Future
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 08:11:09 -0000

GOOD CALL. No offense to anybody, but WCA oughta be bigger and more democratically elected... and personally there are a few rules I don't agree fully with. though after a vote the members may be exactly the same... :) -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan" <sun_helos@y...> wrote: > Hi all, > > Its seems like there are quite a few ppl who think about the actual > WCA rules: Timers, 45° rule, stickers, scrambles, number of official > competitions.... And this is good! Well but how can a cuber influence > these rules? If he only has the choice of talking over the topic in > this group he may feel his powerlessness and will get frustrated. > Obviously some ppl arent too happy with some decisions and the actual > power of some young and very engaged member of the WCA. At the same > time those engaged ppl did something for us all. So we gotta be > thankfull as well. > My opinion: > As quite all of us live in democratic systems i think it would be fair > to elect the ppl who make the rules for us! > It will be a lot of work and sure discussions will start too about who > and how can be elected. Its time to start that discussion i think. > So ..what do u guys think about that idea? > Didn't i read something like "after some time for installing WCA there > will be elections" a while ago... so ..lets do it before the rules get > too solid! > > I d like to thank the WCA Members, but i also think its time to get > some more democracy into it.
1695. [Speed cubing group] Re: seeing/hearing vs remembering
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 08:22:55 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Ryan Heise <rheise@p...> wrote: > On Sat, Jul 09, 2005 at 06:05:10PM -0000, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > I should've been more clear. I don't want to play the 1000 words at > > high speed, I want to play them at *normal* speed. Just all at the > > same time. Just like the photoreaders when they see 1000 normal size > > words at the same time. > > ??! > A sound is temporal and a page is spatial. That is, you discern the > contents of a sound by time, and you discern the contents of a page by > space. Sound is perceived spatially, too -- we have 2 ears! Everyone knows that it is easier to pick out individual instruments/voices from a stereo recording than a mono recording. Binaural is significantly better, as it puts the sound image outside your head: left/right, near/far, up/down are easy to distinguish; though, surprisingly, front/back isn't such an easy distinction to make (at least not for me). No, I'm not suggesting that anyone could pick out each of 1000 simultaneaously spoken words from a binaural recording. But the spatial information should help. Mike
1696. Let's Take It Easy (was Northern California Tournament)
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 08:34:14 -0000

Alright, slight misunderstanding I suppose. Seems to be lots of those around here. You know, we all (ESPECiALLY ME) need to try and sound more polite and nice around here, too many "flames" start up that make lots of people feel bad for no good reason. Take it easy everyone :)! And I do simply mean *sound* nicer, cuz I'm sure we are all nice people in real life, but shit happens. Misunderstandings, incorrectly read connotation/tone, differing styles of sarcasms, poor taste in humor, bad mood.... lead to making people feel *less then thrilled* about posting in the future. I'm sure we have driven away many members over the years because lots of people won't/can't put up with the un-intentional rudeness that occurs in fourms (not just ours, in fact the other fourms I'm on it's much worst). Lots of times a paritally formed idea or suggestion pops into our heads and before we have time to ponder it, we post it. Just expecting some "constructive feedback" and not to be attacked. Sometimes we just look the other way and think "oh he had it comming", but I have seen many threads run on and on... falling way off topic. Threads that go on forever is like X-Files running 2 seasons too much, nobody wants to see that happen right? Let's try to stay away from anything personal (i.e. personal attacks, lol). I leave myself wide open for personal attacks all the time in fact, :). And before you try to help, double check your not just fanning the flames... if in doubt don't post and leave room for material of substance. Over 17000 posts here, how many of them are worth keeping becuse they are actually useful? ==Benefit of the doubt, k?== Oh and to Crispy: "DUDE!, you still haven't told us where you'd like a tournament to be held. At least two of us asked, I guess you must have missed it... I want to help. I've been getting interested in the tournament running buisness lately." -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Crispy <redivre@y...> wrote: > Alright - let me rephrase my question. As I have > realized through some of the replies to it apparently > I didn't appropriately word it. > > Is there a MAX number of tourney's a "group" can hold > in a calendar year? Does the WCA have a set number of > Tournaments it is willing to approve for a year? > > I was pointed to the fact that I can view all the > tournaments on the SCC page (which I didn't know, and > I see that CA has only had 3 to date). So I apologize > for that - just seems like so many more :) > > --- Crispy <redivre@y...> wrote: > > > Since I am not on the Caltech groupI guess I can > > just > > post this here. > > Doesn't there seem to be an awful lot of CA > > Tournaments? Shouldn't there be a limit to how many > > official tournaments can be held per year? > > > > There should be some sort of limit because everytime > > I > > turn around there is yet another tournament in CA. > > > > To me it just seems like the people in the CA area > > are > > going to have quite an advantage against the people > > in > > other states. It just seems to me that we as a US > > should have a couple "opens" a year just like the > > rest > > of the nonUS countries do. Perhaps only have 1-3 a > > year instead of 5-7 > > > > --- Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > > > > Hi Everyone, > > > > > > A Northern California tournament is currently in > > the > > > works. We're > > > looking at the weekend of September 17 and 18. > > > Discussion for this > > > tournament, so as not to destroy the international > > > forum, will continue > > > in the Caltech Rubik's Cube group. > > > > > > Yeah, my brother wants revenge on his performance > > > from the Kennedy Cube > > > Club tournament. > > > > > > Tyson Mao > > > MSC #631 > > > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > > > > > > > Philia, > > Crispy > > > > > > > > __________________________________ > > Yahoo! Mail > > Stay connected, organized, and protected. Take the > > tour: > > http://tour.mail.yahoo.com/mailtour.html > > > > > > > > > __________________________________ > Discover Yahoo! > Use Yahoo! to plan a weekend, have fun online and more. Check it out! > http://discover.yahoo.com/
1697. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: seeing/hearing vs remembering
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 19:16:42 +1000

On Mon, Jul 11, 2005 at 08:22:55AM -0000, mike_go_uk wrote:
> Sound is perceived spatially, too -- we have 2 ears! Everyone knows
> that it is easier to pick out individual instruments/voices from a
> stereo recording than a mono recording. Binaural is significantly
> better, as it puts the sound image outside your head: left/right,
> near/far, up/down are easy to distinguish; though, surprisingly,
> front/back isn't such an easy distinction to make (at least not for me).
>
> No, I'm not suggesting that anyone could pick out each of 1000
> simultaneaously spoken words from a binaural recording. But the
> spatial information should help.

To try to compare chameleon eyes and chameleon ears sounds interesting,
but I think a simpler comparison can be made between feeding a test
subject the same image to both eyes, and the same sound to both ears.

Ryan


1698. Re: seeing/hearing vs remembering
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 10:39:45 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Ryan Heise <rheise@p...> wrote: > To try to compare chameleon eyes and chameleon ears sounds interesting, > but I think a simpler comparison can be made between feeding a test > subject the same image to both eyes, and the same sound to both ears. Er... I guess you mean that an image seen by one eye already has a lot of spatial information in it, whereas that heard by one ear has "none". It's hard to disagree with you there. :) [Nevertheless, I now remember reading that people with only one good ear can still locate sounds to a limited extent. Perhaps because the frequency-dependent filtering done by the outer ear and the rest of the head will "colour" a complex sound, depending on the source direction -- at least, I cannot imagine what else could be involved. Will have to dig around in psychoacoustics texts again sometime...] Mike

need something as big or as bulky, but they flip down in an instant.

Jon

1707. Re: [Speed cubing group] WCA Future
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 17:40:57 +0200

Hi Stefan and others,

Thanks for your feedback.

Recently we opened the WCA forum to discuss official regulations and other WCA subjects.
http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/forum
So this is the place to send your suggestions.

I think the main problem is that WCA is not a full time job for us, so establishing WCA has taken more time than expected.
I had a lot of offers for help from people, but in the end NOONE has done much. (Still thanks to all these nice people!)

Our schedule up to a full establishment is:
1) finalize the 2005 version of the regulations (not many changes, just improvements and clarifications)
2) finalize the website
3) legally establish WCA

For 1) we took ALL your comments on this group and from e-mails, and we are working on a new proposal.
For 2) I did have a little help, but noone has done what he has promised. It is probably too boring to do this. No problem, but it is taking more time. :-(
For 3) we are still in the process of defining what our goals exactly are. In the meantime we are investigating legal actions we need to take care of. This is international, so more complicated than I thought it was.

After that there can be elections. So before going democratic, first some people need to do the dirty work.

Although I agree on some of your points, I recall the saying "bachelor's wives and maiden's children are well trained".

I am very willing to retire. (4 tournaments I am working on, my own website that is taking me a lot of time, actually WCA costs me a lot of money, etcetera)
So anyone: discharge me if you can do better. But I will check whether you do better! :-) Do not underestimate this.

Anyway, we are always looking for help. So if you can do something: tell me!

Have fun,

Ron
----- Original Message -----
From: Stefan
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, July 11, 2005 9:05 AM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] WCA Future


Hi all,

Its seems like there are quite a few ppl who think about the actual
WCA rules: Timers, 45° rule, stickers, scrambles, number of official
competitions.... And this is good! Well but how can a cuber influence
these rules? If he only has the choice of talking over the topic in
this group he may feel his powerlessness and will get frustrated.
Obviously some ppl arent too happy with some decisions and the actual
power of some young and very engaged member of the WCA. At the same
time those engaged ppl did something for us all. So we gotta be
thankfull as well.
My opinion:
As quite all of us live in democratic systems i think it would be fair
to elect the ppl who make the rules for us!
It will be a lot of work and sure discussions will start too about who
and how can be elected. Its time to start that discussion i think.
So ..what do u guys think about that idea?
Didn't i read something like "after some time for installing WCA there
will be elections" a while ago... so ..lets do it before the rules get
too solid!

I d like to thank the WCA Members, but i also think its time to get
some more democracy into it.





SPONSORED LINKS Free puzzle games Computer puzzle game Jigsaw puzzle game
Online puzzle games Free puzzle inlay games

speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.

Hi Everyone,

It doesn't really matter what you do, never will everyone be happy.
But yes, this is all quite tiring and I look forward to a life of stars
rather than answering e-mails.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

1710. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Midwest Tournament Anyone? (was non-California tournaments)
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 13:28:34 -0500

Tyson and I talked a couple of times and thought a tournament in the middle of October was the most reasonably placed. I, too, would like to help out however possible.

We've already had one tournament in Chicago's suburbs, but it seemed to work well enough. I never heard of any travel complaints. I would also like to offer the possibility of a tournament in or around Minneapolis, Minnesota. It's comprable distance for me to Chicago, but I'm farmiliar with the area. There are lots of great possible venues.

Somebody shoot me an email and we can perhaps plan something.

-Mike Bennett

----- Original Message -----

1711. FL followed by CLL
From: "uweren2000" <rune.wesstrom@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 18:40:46 -0000

Hi Ron,
A year or so ago you wrote that beginning with FL followed by CLL you
could hardly count on an average under 26 secs.
Why?!
A man who does F2L in 9s, Must (with some practising) do FL in 6s. Then
CLL in 2s. Notice that the average lengths of the algs here are shorter
than e.g. with Friedrich, as you have the middle slice to your disposal.
Then 3 interchanges of edges between slice and LL (à 1.5s?) followed by
rotation in the slice.(1s) To that 2 or 3 inline moves.
Where am I that mistaken?
I agree that for me it seems incredible, but so does F2L in 9s as the
whole cube in 15s (but nevertheless it does exist).
R




1712. Re: Rules on BLD
From: "jello33" <chris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 19:36:15 -0000

So do you guys use the same cube for BLD as your normal speed cube?

I would gladly donate sticker or tile sets to anyone running a BLD
event. Although it might be a pain to have to resticker your cube on
the day of the event.

> > Actually in addition to reschemeing my new cubes and putting on new
> > stickers, I organize the pieces such that I could tell if any cubey
> > is orientated or not.

I don't understand this part, how is that possible. Do you mark the
pieces on the inside of the cube incase of a pop? I also watched
Tysons BLD pop from the Horrace Mann DVD and it was very funny. I
instantly thought of how frustrating that must have been.

So, do a lot of BLD solvers use a custom color scheme? I'm not opposed
to donating a few tiled DIY speedcubes to the WCA to send around to
tournys either. Although most people seem highly opposed to not using
they're own cube.

Anyway, let me know if I can help.

Chris
www.cubesmith.com

1714. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Rules on BLD
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 13:49:51 -0600

Gah... why is it that I'm always providing entertainment? On a side
note, as soon as I get a video camera, I will be sending an application
into that Beauty and the Geek. I'm at the freakin' Very Large Array...
that's gotta be geeky enough.

I actually don't use the same cube for BLD as my normal speed cube but
I could. My normal cube risks popping more and so that's why I go with
a different cube for BLD. I should make the note that at Horace Mann,
I hadn't really completed a BLD solve... ever, so I really wasn't sure
what I was doing. I had kind of done one at the JFK airport while
waiting for the shuttle that never came but that was about it.

Most, if not all, cubers use the same color scheme that they do for
speed solving. It's what we're used to.

What I've done with my stickers is that I have the edges all facing a
certain way so that when it pops out, I know which way to put it back
in. Now, I'll be honest... I popped, but I was in the middle of an
algorithm, and I thought about it, and decided heck, there's no way I
was going to be able to figure that out on stage so I gave up. I think
I might be able to do it today though, with more BLD experience under
my belt. If you still want more explanation, just wait for the Toy
Fair and Leyan will explain what I'm talking about in person. It's
much more easily understood that way.

I would consider taking pieces out and orienting them to be cheating.
However, I would also challenge anyone to beat me on a BLD solve by
doing that. Even J. Bernett Orlando. I'm convinced that taking out
the necessary pieces and feeling and then putting back in would be
disorienting, and time consuming enough that it would not provide any
type of advantage. Orienting pieces takes maybe... 10 seconds of
memorization at the most, and 25 seconds of execution on my part.

I don't think we need cubes yet. As Chris Hardwick said, perhaps
stickers are all that are necessary.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

I hate to point this out, but the world doesn't revolve around you.
Please consider only three things:

Quality of the venue
Convenience for the majority of cube participants
Convenience for the tournament organizer

Tyson Mao

1719. Re: [Speed cubing group] WCA Future
From: "Stefan" <sun_helos@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 20:31:40 -0000

Hi Ron, My post wasnt ment to critisize you, far away. I really enjoyed EM2004 for example. It must have been lots of work and yes indeed.. i didnt manage to thank u expressly. And what did in fact surprised me the most...It was free! (Or did i miss something?) I dont want to get u out of ur job u are obviusly doing like nobody else of us could. Respect and thanks! The idea of the democracy isn't just about elections its also about to approve ur work. U would then know that we are very proud of u! Another point is: If the rules are base on the majorities will by a transparent system nobody can really complain anymore. (Well we know there always will be a few). And btw i could imagine a WCA Fee. So donating WCA cubers will get registered and will have their voice in an election or something like that. U dont have to pay all the expenses from ur own pocket! I d like to spent some money into it! And to all the others... U heard it: Our man Ron would like us to help him more often! I m thinking about how i could help u...mhh. i am really not good at creating websites :( maybe i can do something .. i ll think about it.. ok Respect to Ron! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > Hi Stefan and others, > > Thanks for your feedback. > > Recently we opened the WCA forum to discuss official regulations and other WCA subjects. > http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/forum > So this is the place to send your suggestions. > > I think the main problem is that WCA is not a full time job for us, so establishing WCA has taken more time than expected. > I had a lot of offers for help from people, but in the end NOONE has done much. (Still thanks to all these nice people!) > > Our schedule up to a full establishment is: > 1) finalize the 2005 version of the regulations (not many changes, just improvements and clarifications) > 2) finalize the website > 3) legally establish WCA > > For 1) we took ALL your comments on this group and from e-mails, and we are working on a new proposal. > For 2) I did have a little help, but noone has done what he has promised. It is probably too boring to do this. No problem, but it is taking more time. :-( > For 3) we are still in the process of defining what our goals exactly are. In the meantime we are investigating legal actions we need to take care of. This is international, so more complicated than I thought it was. > > After that there can be elections. So before going democratic, first some people need to do the dirty work. > > Although I agree on some of your points, I recall the saying "bachelor's wives and maiden's children are well trained". > > I am very willing to retire. (4 tournaments I am working on, my own website that is taking me a lot of time, actually WCA costs me a lot of money, etcetera) > So anyone: discharge me if you can do better. But I will check whether you do better! :-) Do not underestimate this. > > Anyway, we are always looking for help. So if you can do something: tell me! > > Have fun, > > Ron

1721. Re: [Speed cubing group] FL followed by CLL
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 23:00:35 +0200

Hi Rune,

Please point me out in which message I wrote this. I don't understand. Which system do you refer to?

I can easily do F2L, then CLL, then ELL, probably under 18 seconds with some practice.
For CLL I would use COLL.
For ELL I would use a lot of ELL, but I forgot the hardest cases.

For F2L, ELL, CLL this would be harder.
I think there are 84 cases for CLL then! This is what Andy Camann had learned last year. He did this for the last step of the interesting system of Ryan Heise.

Or are you talking about first layer, then CLL, then last 8 edges? That would be like the Waterman system. Without practice it takes ages to solve the last 8 edges! The first two remaining edges are an easy step of the Waterman system, but the last two final layer edges are a lot of algorithms.

Have fun,

Ron

----- Original Message -----
From: uweren2000
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

Subject: [Speed cubing group] FL followed by CLL


Hi Ron,
A year or so ago you wrote that beginning with FL followed by CLL you
could hardly count on an average under 26 secs.
Why?!
A man who does F2L in 9s, Must (with some practising) do FL in 6s. Then
CLL in 2s. Notice that the average lengths of the algs here are shorter
than e.g. with Friedrich, as you have the middle slice to your disposal.
Then 3 interchanges of edges between slice and LL (à 1.5s?) followed by
rotation in the slice.(1s) To that 2 or 3 inline moves.
Where am I that mistaken?
I agree that for me it seems incredible, but so does F2L in 9s as the
whole cube in 15s (but nevertheless it does exist).

1723. Re: [Speed cubing group] WCA Future
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 23:12:03 +0200

Hi Stefan, That is too much honor! Luckily we have a lot of people in our community who either publicly or on the background help organizing events. But yeah, we need help. A few weeks ago I asked on this club if someone wanted to figure out all official records of the past. (1981/1982/2003/2004) Because now we only have the record history of 2005. Noone offered helped. It is not that much work! We are all too busy. The thing is that TALKING about regulations is a lot of fun. WRITING the regulations is the hardest and not much appreciated work. There are so many opinions that you need to take into account. And these opinions are often black/white (preinspection or not, pops allowed or not, how to deal with penalties). And you cannot change too much, there must be some basic stabile principles. Any help is still appreciated. You posting on this subject already helped, because today we found 1 more volunteer. :-) Have fun, Ron ----- Original Message ----- From: Stefan To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Monday, July 11, 2005 10:31 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] WCA Future Hi Ron, My post wasnt ment to critisize you, far away. I really enjoyed EM2004 for example. It must have been lots of work and yes indeed.. i didnt manage to thank u expressly. And what did in fact surprised me the most...It was free! (Or did i miss something?) I dont want to get u out of ur job u are obviusly doing like nobody else of us could. Respect and thanks! The idea of the democracy isn't just about elections its also about to approve ur work. U would then know that we are very proud of u! Another point is: If the rules are base on the majorities will by a transparent system nobody can really complain anymore. (Well we know there always will be a few). And btw i could imagine a WCA Fee. So donating WCA cubers will get registered and will have their voice in an election or something like that. U dont have to pay all the expenses from ur own pocket! I d like to spent some money into it! And to all the others... U heard it: Our man Ron would like us to help him more often! I m thinking about how i could help u...mhh. i am really not good at creating websites :( maybe i can do something .. i ll think about it.. ok Respect to Ron! R'D'L'F2U2FU2R'U2FR2U'LRF'R2F'D). Anyway, the machine can't have been working for
more than 3 days - rather less indeed as it hasn't been on that long, so 4320 minutes is
an upper bound. Is there any reason I'd get a figure back of over 94 days.




1725. tournament rules
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 16:21:10 -0600

Hi Everyone,

There are a few people out there who have accused me or suggested that
I write rules or influence regulations for the benefit of myself and my
friends. I would like to assure the speedcubing community that this is
not the case and that I write rules and regulations in an effort to
uphold the principles of speedcubing, ensure fairness throughout
Rubik's Cube competitions, and also provide a logical systematic
approach to tournaments.

For every regulation that a member of the community may disagree, there
is easily another person who agrees. It is simple; people have
different opinions and no one will ever fully agree. If there are
disagreements, I am always willing to listen to logical and well
supported evidence supporting the new suggestion. However, simply the
reason that a few people do not agree with something should not be
grounds for accusing or questioning my personal and moral integrity.

I particularly feel regret that some of you feel this way. However, I
also feel that one has little right to accuse me of such acts if they
have never been to any of the tournaments I have run. Of my friends at
Caltech, only one of them is really a speedcuber in contention of any
records or prizes. My other friends assist me with the tournament and
have little desire to compete and are, at no offense to them, way too
slow to even make it to the second round. I personally refrain from
competing in the 3x3x3 speed solve competition because I try to focus
my energy on running a fair tournament.

There are many things I could have done to influence the results of
this tournament; most notably, I could easily release tournament
scrambles to my friends before the tournament. I could have easily
looked and practiced scrambles for the Horace Mann tournament. I
assure you, if anyone approaches me and asks me to solve a Rubik's
Cube, I will be able to reproduce my tournament results. I am indeed a
sub-18 cuber, Macky can average sub-15, and Leyan did indeed perform a
2:41.54 blindfolded solve in adherence to the spirit of all aspects of
the sport of speedcubing and blindfold solving.

Anyway, I hope the community will reconsider their accusations and I
continue to work hard and provide the United States with quality events
and Rubik's Cube competitions that respect and hold dear the ultimate
ideals of fair play. If you have any doubts, I encourage you to
contact any member of the community who has attended any of my
tournaments. I have met many competitors just for a few moments and
have no ties or allegiance to most of them. I also encourage all to
attend the tournaments that I run and if any procedures or regulations
suggest any inkling of self-thought, I encourage you to raise the
concern with me and the public community.

I have done my best to present the world with an honest and open
competition front for the Rubik's Cube. After this year, I will
hopefully go off for further academic study in astrophysics and if is
the wishes of the Rubik's Cube community, I am more than willing to
leave this all behind.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology



1726. Re: tournament rules
From: "Stefan" <sun_helos@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 22:41:50 -0000

..
i dont want to quote everything from tyson just reply.

> Tyson Mao
> MSC #631
> California Institute of Technology

My aim wasnt to discredit Tyson. I m sad to see he takes this so
serious. But i can understand that when ppl work hard they are
sensitive to critics. Ppl who know me also know that i didnt want to
offend someone. English isnt my native language and im just triing to
express my thoughts as diplomatic as i can. Just be cool, and plz dont
try to interpret things like u want to...be some more forgiving :)

Another point is obvious: We cubers have nearly no clue what it means
to organize the Wca and tournaments and what u guys are working on
right now.
nuff said.
we are pulling the same string so why argue that hard?
thanks
Stefan





1727. Northern California Tournament
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, caltechrubiks@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 17:15:12 -0600

Hi Everyone,

I am only a couple of steps away from confirming this event. Once
everything is confirmed and reserved, we will make the proper
announcements on speedcubing.com and everything. Again, it would be
best if tournament discussion were in the Caltech groups so we don't
destroy the INBOXes of hundreds of people around the world. Honestly
though, I think it gives Leyan a break from looking at magnetic
influences on squids. Actually.... SQUID.

Date: Saturday, September 17, 2005
Time: 10:00 AM to 5:00 PM

Location: Crystal Springs Uplands School
400 Uplands Drive
Hillsborough, California 94010

http://www.csus.com/

We will do 3x3x3 speed sovling, of course, and any other events that
people would like to compete in. I would like to compete in the 3x3x3
blindfold solve. As a side event, it has been suggested that we do a
cube-athon. A cube-athon would entail solving a 2-cube, 3-cube,
4-cube, and 5-cube. Each time would then be compared to the world
record like they do in the decathlon and that's how we would decide the
winner. The event results would be listed in the results, but will not
appear in the WCA official records.

Also for this tournament, pre-registration will be required. The
school requests that I limit the number of competitors to 25. I doubt
that the tournament will get 25 people, but I really need to know in
case too many people decide to come—in which case, I would beg to the
facility officials for the allowance of more competitors.

So stay tuned to the Caltech yahoo groups as all future announcements
for this tournament will be in there.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology


1728. Re: Rules on BLD
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 11 Jul 2005 23:57:35 -0000

Hi Chris, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "jello33" <chris@c...> wrote: > So do you guys use the same cube for BLD as your normal speed cube? > > I would gladly donate sticker or tile sets to anyone running a BLD > event. Although it might be a pain to have to resticker your cube on > the day of the event. > > > > Actually in addition to reschemeing my new cubes and putting on new > > > stickers, I organize the pieces such that I could tell if any cubey > > > is orientated or not. > > I don't understand this part, how is that possible. Do you mark the > pieces on the inside of the cube incase of a pop? I also watched > Tysons BLD pop from the Horrace Mann DVD and it was very funny. I > instantly thought of how frustrating that must have been. In the case of a pop the blinfold cubist could be allowed one edge flipped, or two edges swapped, or two corners swapped. To allow for putting the cube back together wrong. > So, do a lot of BLD solvers use a custom color scheme? I'm not opposed > to donating a few tiled DIY speedcubes to the WCA to send around to > tournys either. Although most people seem highly opposed to not using > they're own cube. How about using both the old and the new "official" color schemes? > > Anyway, let me know if I can help. > > Chris > www.cubesmith.com Regards, David J
1729. Re: tournament rules
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 00:17:35 -0000

Hi Tyson, I want to thank you for your efforts. Im addition I appreciate that you went out of your way to allow me time for no inspection solves. Your tournaments have been fair and fun and you deserve a lot of credit. Forget the naysayers. I wasn't here for much of the weekend and was about to ask you how much of the sky is covered by a cube held at arm's length, and then I see that some people don't know that the way to balance a shortage is to increase in the shortfall areas... I am a little ticked off that some people are giving you a hard time. They need to sit down somewhere and listen to a few thousand words per second until what they use for thinking shuts down. Hopefully their systems will reset. :P Adjustable blindfolds are sold in travel stores for people who need dark for sleeping on planes. Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > [lots recently] > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology
1730. Re: tournament rules
From: "al_yyz" <anders.larsson@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 00:23:38 -0000

In Sweden, I have been involved in organising three tournaments, and
we have the upcoming Swedish Championships in September. Before each
of the tournaments, I have been in contact with both Ron and Tyson
and their support and help have been great. Thank you! We have also
shared views about rules and how to conduct tournaments.

I see no reason to limit the amount of tournaments at present. I
think that we should instead be inspired and encouraged by Tyson and
all his tournaments and start to arrange them at more places.
Certainly, I have been inspired.

One great thing of organising a tournament is that the organisers
can decide upon the rules themselves. Thus, at our first tournament,
the Swedish Cube Day 2004, we ranked people by the median value
instead of the average of five / mean of three. Furthermore, we
have, with great success, had a 3x3x3 speedcubing event without
preinspection. Such events will not at present be official, but I
find it proper to experiment with alternative events in tournaments
together with the official ones. Thus, I suggest that future
organisers experiment with the format (and in particular try the no-
preinspection event  my favourite!). BUT, please discuss it with
WCA in advance.

In addition to experiments, I also suggest that future organisers
try to make some events of tournaments official since one striving
force in cubing is to get into the official ranking lists. The issue
of ranking lists also makes me suggest that all rounds in
tournaments ought have the same format (for instance, "average of
five" in 3x3x3 speedcubing) so all competitors can be listed in all
ranking list regardless of their performance.

Organising tournaments are fun. Do as Ron uses to say "Have fun"!

/Anders

Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 01:08:35 -0000

I am a bit worried about that name: the pop resort. Maybe they could
change it to 'the eighties resort' or something. My cube is too loose
already.

Michiel




1732. Re: Worried...
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 02:42:48 -0000

LOL! Try the new 25th anniversary cube, it has arched centers. Or the black DIY kits from rubiks.com. That has gotten rid of all my popping issues. But just to shead some light on it, they call it the Pop Resort and not the Eighties Resort is because different parts of the building depict different decades, it's not just the 80's. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@z...> wrote: > I am a bit worried about that name: the pop resort. Maybe they could > change it to 'the eighties resort' or something. My cube is too loose > already. > > Michiel
1733. Re: Strange time (Cube Explorer)
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 02:53:44 -0000

I sugguest e-mailing the programmer, if you haven't already done so. Everytime I e-mailed him, he's been pretty quick with responding. Well there was that time he ignored my comment that it couldn't optimize the solved state properly and came up with some witty remark. (Yes, if you put in the solved state, it will return the sequence U U' of something like that... and they call it optimal.... so I nit-pick too much.) -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Cube solving time from Cube Explorer 135512.81 minutes (optimized > R'D'L'F2U2FU2R'U2FR2U'LRF'R2F'D). Anyway, the machine can't have been working for > more than 3 days - rather less indeed as it hasn't been on that long, so 4320 minutes is > an upper bound. Is there any reason I'd get a figure back of over 94 days.

1738. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: you have been cubing too much...
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 00:27:32 -0500

..when you would only consider dating a girl you can average faster than.

..when you consider breaking up with that same girl because she 4x4's better than you.

..by a minute.

..when you own several articles of clothing you have altered to become cube themed.

..when several of the articles are undergarments.

..when you have driven more than half an hour away on a special trip to purchase cube themed jewelry because nowhere else closer sells it.

..when you make these trips weekly until they're finally in stock.

..when you make a trip to an entirely different state for the express purpose of obtaining orange colored duct tape, because that way you can finally make that cube themed purse.

..when people offer you money to make them similar purses.

..when you seriously consider working a cube into a tattoo.

..when you can't sleep because you didn't have time to take an average.

..when you can't stop taking averages because you're 'so close to a record'.

..when 'so close to a record' is several seconds away and you're only rationalizing in order to cube more.

..if you've taken more than one average of 100 solves.

..in one day.

..if you've ever sincerely considered fashioning your own cube holster to hide under clothing.

..when planning a major overseas trip, the first thing you do is compile a list of algorithms to learn on the plane.

..when you ask to borrow someone's laptop just to be able to take JNetCube on the plane with you.

..when you have to be up in 5 hours for a 1 hour swim, a 4 mile run, a full day worth of errands, an 8+ hour work day, and then an all night cube marathon/movie party, before repeating with no sleep, and you still decide to create this list.

..and then take some averages.

..and then take some more.

..on your 4x4.

..and maybe some 2x2, if there's time.

..there's definitely time.

-Mike Bennett

----- Original Message -----
From: Gilles van den Peereboom
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, July 11, 2005 9:39 AM
Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: you have been cubing too much...


You know you have been cubing too much when :

...you are at the bank talking to the bank manager for a new credit
card and that you start talking about the Fridrich Method with him.

(happenned to me this morning lol)


------------------------------------------------------------------------------
YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS

a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web.

b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.

1740. Re: Rules on BLD (chris's question)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 07:07:29 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "jello33" <chris@c...> wrote: > > > I organize the pieces such that I could tell if any cubey > > > is orientated or not. > > I don't understand this part, how is that possible. Do you mark the > pieces on the inside of the cube incase of a pop? I don't think anyone's really answered your question... The cubies are unsymmetrical inside (have a look), so you can verify by touch the orientation of one that's popped out. ;) Mike
1741. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: you have been cubing too much...
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 03:31:39 -0400

> ...when you cube in front of a group of people who haven't seen it
> before, and know which guy is going to tell you he used to take the
> stickers off before he even says it

...when you've broken your spacebar from stopping JNetcube's timer

...when you've gotten free drinks at a bar for cubing for a stranger

...when you give your friend a scramble in which the notation of the
solution spells a word

...when you practice your one handed solve while driving

...when you own a bag in which you travel around with your cubes

...when you fall asleep with the cube in your hands

...and resume cubing when you wake up before you even brush your teeth

...when you know that Lars Petrus is hotter than 61% of the men on
amihotornot.com







[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1742. Re: Strange time (Cube Explorer bug?)
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 07:50:00 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > it couldn't optimize the solved state properly In fact, if you check the "Optimal" box and keep clicking the green arrow, Cube Explorer will calculate the shortest non-trivial identities (the "do-nothing" sequences). I rather like that feature and use it in my own puzzle-solving programs; i.e., the search always starts at depth 1 rather than at depth 0. On the (possible) real "bugs"... I have also noticed anomalies in the timings, but it doesn't bother me. However, when running under Windows XP I find that clearing the main window (even when there is only one cube) can sometimes be very slow -- from a few seconds to several minutes on a 1.7GHz machine with 512MB RAM. During all this time, C.E. is using 97-99% cpu whilst apparently doing nothing. The hard disk is not churning (there is plenty of memory free). Does anyone else have this problem with the program? If so, can you find any pattern in the behaviour? I can't. :( (H. Kociemba isn't using XP, so has not been able to investigate.) Mike
1743. [Speed cubing group] Re: Midwest Tournament Anyone? (was non-California tournaments)
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 07:58:22 -0000

Good idea if it's the right time of year for the weather, but if it's in a place like Ann Arbor (high pop-density) then it's just going to attract unwanted attention and possibly malicious interference. THough I don't know, cuz I've never done anything like that, but I'd imagine as much. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > Why not organize a tounament outside of a building ?
1744. Re: [Speed cubing group] WCA Future
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 08:14:08 -0000

> The thing is that TALKING about regulations is a lot of fun.
> WRITING the regulations is the hardest and not much appreciated
work. There are so many opinions that you need to take into account.


That's a beautiful point.

Even though I don't fully agree on some of the rules and regulations,
I don't whine about it. It just piles up work for one or two people.
People need to take action if you feel strongly enough, and if you
don't feel so strongly about it, then complaining doesn't help.

Democracy is going to take time; I'm satisified with what's been going
on so far. Rules and regulations will naturally evolve and adapt over
time. Take the time to be grateful for what others have done for the
cubing community these last 2 years alone.


-Doug

1748. [Speed cubing group] Re: you have been cubing too much...
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 09:05:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko > <bmytko@o...> wrote: > > > ...when you cube in front of a group of people who haven't seen > it before, and know which guy is going to tell you he used to take > the stickers off before he even says it > > ya, it's so obiovus though... I cube quite a lot on public transport but have had that comment only once. Luckily I remembered one of Macky's friendlier ripostes. Usually there's just a bit of eye-rolling, but once someone started throwing loose change at me. Not quite enough to make it worth putting up with, though. > > ...when you give your friend a scramble in which the notation of > the solution spells a word > > wtf? the only vowel (at least in the standard English singmaster) > would be a U... and how many words can that make with DLRFB??? BULL :) (or should that be BUL2?) It's not difficult if we allow M,S, and especially E. Mike

1750. Re: [Speed cubing group] Us daft boyz!
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 10:34:07 +0100

Thanks for sharing guys. I just know that anyone commenting on this is going to look bad to somebody but I can't help myself! I have the greatest respect for both of you. Someone wrote on here recently about how easy it is to misinterpret and take offence when none is intended. I don't think either of you have any reason to worry about this exchange being made public. Neither of you look bad in my eyes. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Stefan" <sun_helos@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Tuesday, July 12, 2005 10:10 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Us daft boyz! > Tyson suggested to publish the conversation we had. 1752. Re: [Speed cubing group] Us daft boyz!
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 11:46:57 +0200 (CEST)

Hi friends,

Thanks for sharing. :-) :-(

Now back to cubing! Let us not waste more energy on negative things!

If you have spare energy then use it in a positive way.
Some ideas:
= come with good suggestions for regulations. Preferrably in regulation
style. Try http://www.worldcubeassocation.org/forum

= help me with the WCA website

= help us with the legal stuff of establishing WCA

= create the history of world puzzle records before 2005

= help other cubers by making a great website with your ideas and systems

= create the best tournament Excel file that people can think of (generate
all sheets for all events with all information of all competitors, and
with all correct calculations)

= start organizing a local cube event

= write a good scientific article that will draw LOTS of attention to our
fun hobby

= et cetera, there is so much to do in Cubeland!

Have fun,

Ron

1753. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: tournament rules
From: "Peter Douthwright" <pdouthwright0513@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 05:48:47 -0400

I think anyone who is wiling to organize a tournament is to be given a lot of respect. If these people who are complaining were to try and organize a tourney themselves would see that it is not an easy task. I am still trying to get a tournament going for Canada and I know how hard it is. I am having trouble just getting a place to hold it. So well done Tyson, and anyone else who has managed to get a tournament going. ----- Original Message ----- From: "Sapan Upadhyay" <cubekid@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Tuesday, July 12, 2005 12:53 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: tournament rules > tyson, > > don't take crap from anyone. everyone knows how hard you work and none > of us want you to leave. we all appreciate your efforts to spread the > cube and no one can deny that you are one of the main reasons that > cubing is how it is today. keep up all the good work :) > > and btw, astrophysics is cool :) > > On 7/11/05, al_yyz <anders.larsson@...> wrote: > > In Sweden, I have been involved in organising three tournaments, and > > we have the upcoming Swedish Championships in September. Before each > > of the tournaments, I have been in contact with both Ron and Tyson > > and their support and help have been great. Thank you! We have also > > shared views about rules and how to conduct tournaments. > > > > I see no reason to limit the amount of tournaments at present. I > > think that we should instead be inspired and encouraged by Tyson and > > all his tournaments and start to arrange them at more places. > > Certainly, I have been inspired. > > > > One great thing of organising a tournament is that the organisers > > can decide upon the rules themselves. Thus, at our first tournament, > > the Swedish Cube Day 2004, we ranked people by the median value > > instead of the average of five / mean of three. Furthermore, we > > have, with great success, had a 3x3x3 speedcubing event without > > preinspection. Such events will not at present be official, but I > > find it proper to experiment with alternative events in tournaments > > together with the official ones. Thus, I suggest that future > > organisers experiment with the format (and in particular try the no- > > preinspection event ï¿½ my favourite!). BUT, please discuss it with > > WCA in advance. > > > > In addition to experiments, I also suggest that future organisers > > try to make some events of tournaments official since one striving > > force in cubing is to get into the official ranking lists. The issue > > of ranking lists also makes me suggest that all rounds in > > tournaments ought have the same format (for instance, "average of > > five" in 3x3x3 speedcubing) so all competitors can be listed in all > > ranking list regardless of their performance. > > > > Organising tournaments are fun. Do as Ron uses to say "Have fun"! > > > > /Anders > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -- > -cubekid > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > >
1754. Re: [Speed cubing group] Corners first is fun!
From: Rune Wesström <rune.wesstrom@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 14:07:40 +0200

Hi Ron,
That is, what I have found. (Maybe you wrote about 26s earlier).
OK, step 1 You should do in 6s. Step 2 (CLL?) You should do in 2s. Step 5 is skipped, as you flip the pieces in the middle slice in steps 3 and 4.
In short, I think You (with practising) could do the cube in 15s with this system.
R
Hi friendz,

Just to let you know that I started solving corners first a week
after the WC 2003.
My expectation is that I cannot beat my CFOP (cross/F2L/OLL/PLL)
record with it. I do think that it will give me more experience to
improve my times for more advanced CFOP systems.

The corners first system I currently use is:
1) first layer (systematically)
2) corners of last layer (algorithms)
3) two edges of last layer (algorithms)
4) last two edges of last layer (algorithms)
5) orient middle layer edges (algorithms)
6) permute middle layer edges (algorithms)

This is basically the Waterman system without combining step 4 and 5.
For combining these steps you need to learn table 3 and 4 of the
Waterman system. These are tough ones! Slowly I am working my way
through the tables, but it will take me some more time.

At the moment, exactly one month after starting corners first, my
normal averages are sub 24 seconds, with a best of 23.1 seconds:
20 (29) 25 24 22 20 20 26 23 23 23 (19).
I am finally getting used to keeping the last layer on the right and
finishing off the cube using only R, U and M moves.
I am surprised that using this system I only take on average 10
slice moves per cube.

Anyway: corners first is fun!

Have fun,

Ron
http://www.speedcubing.com

1755. University of Michigan Tournament
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 14:04:53 -0000

Just a quick reality check...

How many of you would come to a tournament (assuming it doesn't
conflict with another US tournamnet or Dutch Cube Day and is on a
weekend during the academic year), held in Ann Arbor Michigan?, which
is 40 minutes west of Detroit for those who don't know.

venue: The University of Michigan
room: decided soon, trying to reserve
funding: University of Michigan, possibly rubiks.com, possibly
cubesmith.com, entry fee

Thus instead of called "Midwest Tournament" it will be called
the "First [Annual] University of Michigan Cube Off."

And oh yes, there will be an entry fee attached. I can't be going
broke over this :). I need a least 20 entries, early registration
appriciated (once I properly arrange enough to publicize the date).

Macky, PLZ come! Pretty please?


-Doug




1756. Sudoku
From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 14:28:23 -0000

hey,

my dad was just on a business trip in Europe, and he knows how I like
puzzles, so he brought back a newspaper with a new puzzle in it called
Sudoku. apparently it's become really really popular in Japan, and
they publish it in the newspaper every week with the crossword. and
more recently they've started posting it in the Washington Post, USA
Today, etc....
anyway, it's a very interesting puzzle. it's a square that's divided
into 9 smaller squares, which are each divided into 9 more smaller
squares, so there's 81 smaller squares. some of them are already
filled with random numbers, and you have to fill in the rest of them
so that each row, column, and separate 3x3 square has the numbers 1-9
in it.
I knew some of you would be interested in it, so decided to share.
here's a wiki article on it:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudoku

1760. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: University of Michigan Tournament
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 09:34:09 -0600

The American Regions Mathematics Competitions a competition at three
simultaneous sites. One thought Doug and I were entertaining was to
hold the University of Michigan tournament at the same time as the
Caltech Fall. The tournaments would essentially be the same
tournament—same scrambles and everything. In which case, we would have
site winners, and also overall winners. Computers would be used to
compile scores.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

1763. Re: [Speed cubing group] Rubiks Tile Game?
From: "azinj05ieipih" <azinj05ieipih@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 17:24:31 -0000

I have two Rubik's Deluxe Game Cubes and one Deluxe Cube. They are both the same as far as I know, except for th e fact that one has peg holes in it to (so you can play a few games that they teach you to play). The peg holes are used to put pegs in them (duh -_-X). The feel of both cubes are the same (because everything but the tiles are different). As speedcubers, the pro and con of the Game Cube is that it is easier to grip (the holes catch onto your fingers), but all the holes takes a while to get used to. Oh yeah, and to answer Bryan's question, no it is not a piece of crap. It's hell good =], but heavier and feels bigger. Hope that helps~ ~Joseph http://jliao.tk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Evan Gates <evan.gates@g...> wrote: > As far as I know, it's the same as a Rubik's deluxe, but it has the > holes. I've even heard that the holes help because you can hold onto > it more easily. > > -E > > On 7/11/05, Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@g...> wrote: > > a friend of mine (doug reed) has that kind of cube. his is awesome. > > it's his primary speedcube and he gets sub 18 avgs with it all the > > time. > > > > as far as i know, its good. :) > > > > On 7/11/05, bryanosaurus <bmytko@o...> wrote: > > > What exactly is this rubik's tile game I've seen on ebay. Looks like it > > has holes in it. Can this > > > thing be made into a good speedcube, or is it a piece of junk? > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -- > > -cubekid > > > > ________________________________ > > YAHOO! 1773. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: you have been cubing too much...
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>

Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 15:08:27 -0400

> > > ...when you give your friend a scramble in which the notation of > the solution spells a word > > wtf? the only vowel (at least in the standard English singmaster) > would be a U... and how many words can that make with DLRFB??? They are usually just little riddles - with answers like SUM, BUD, F2L, DUMB, etc Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... On Jul 12, 2005, at 4:42 AM, d_funny007 wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko > <bmytko@o...> wrote: > > > ...when you cube in front of a group of people who haven't seen > it before, and know which guy is going to tell you he used to take > the stickers off before he even says it > > ya, it's so obiovus though... > >> >> > ...when you give your friend a scramble in which the notation of >> the solution spells a word >> >> wtf? the only vowel (at least in the standard English singmaster) >> would be a U... and how many words can that make with DLRFB??? > > > > > ...when you practice your one handed solve while driving > > Ok we as a community frown upon this, there were lots and lots of > posts about this a yr or two ago, furious people... though many of > us do this anyways, lets try to keep it at the stoplights, k? > > > > ...when you fall asleep with the cube in your hands > > daily. > > > > ...and resume cubing when you wake up before you even brush your > teeth > > daily. > > > > ...when you know that Lars Petrus is hotter than 61% of the men on > amihotornot.com > > agreed. > > > > -Doug > > > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Bryan Mytko

On Jul 12, 2005, at 10:28 AM, Michael Atkinson wrote:

> hey,
>
> my dad was just on a business trip in Europe, and he knows how I like
> puzzles, so he brought back a newspaper with a new puzzle in it called
> Sudoku. apparently it's become really really popular in Japan, and
> they publish it in the newspaper every week with the crossword. and
> more recently they've started posting it in the Washington Post, USA
> Today, etc....
> anyway, it's a very interesting puzzle. it's a square that's divided
> into 9 smaller squares, which are each divided into 9 more smaller
> squares, so there's 81 smaller squares. some of them are already
> filled with random numbers, and you have to fill in the rest of them
> so that each row, column, and separate 3x3 square has the numbers 1-9
> in it.
> I knew some of you would be interested in it, so decided to share.
> here's a wiki article on it:
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudoku
