1791. Pseudo-stackmat
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 02:08:13 -0000

Hey guys,
With the Dallas tourney approaching quickly and me with no
experience at a stackmat I decided to do something about it so I
wouldn't be caught totally unawares. A quick look at the bank account
said "You're buying a stackmat? Riiiiiiiiiiight." And a quick look
at the twistypuzzles forum gave me a kick in the rear to attempt to
make my own.

So after 1 night of slamming my head against a desk in desperation,
and one afternoon of much of the same I have my finished product. It
is ugly as all hell and doesn't function *exactly* like a stackmat,
but at least I'll have a bit of the feel down. The best part is it
only cost me $5 for a stopwatch and about $3 in parts I had lying
around the house.

The touch pads are sensitive enough to one person touch one, another
person touch the other and then any contact between the two people
will start the time (makes me think of the team solving vid I saw
earlier, very cool btw).

The only thing I'd like to do to it at this point is make it so that
the timer starts on release instead of on contact. As it is now, the
start and stop happen immediately upon touching the pads.

Without further ado, here is the vid of the ugly thing in action!

http://tinyurl.com/d89yt

Best,
Daniel




1792. Re: [Speed cubing group] California tournaments
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 02:07:46 -0000

Just catching up on the last few days of posts and wow there were a
lot!! (haven't finished reading them all yet!)

Anyway, I want to add a few of my own thoughts about the frequency of
California-based comps...

I think it's fantastic that Tyson and others have put in so much time
and effort to organise so many comps. I'm constantly impressed with
how Tyson manages to do so much for the speedcubing community and
still (I assume??) get through all his non-cubing stuff (astronomy,
violin and whatever else he does).

It doesn't bother me in the slightest that there are more official
competitions in and around California than in other places. I would be
sad to see this limited by anything other than Tyson's availability,
even if I can't ever compete at any Caltech comps. Personally, I think
it's great to see lots of official competitions happening and I don't
really care where they are or if I can attend. More competitions means
more publicity for speedcubing!

The fact that Tyson (and others) organise comps voluntarily means that
we should all be thankful for their hard work. I know I wouldn't be
able to commit the time and effort to organise a comp myself, and so
if not for the volunteers then I'd never have the opportunity to
compete in anything anywhere.

If organising competitions was *paid* work and the organisors chose to
always focus the comps in the same city/state, then yes, there
probably would be grounds for complaining, but as long as it's unpaid
voluntary work then I'm just happy that there are competitions
happening, wherever they might be!

BTW, if you think you have a long way to travel to competitions... I'm
Australian and I competed at the World Champs in Toronto. According to
an online distance tool I just googled, that's 15815kms (9828 miles)
away. I also went to the US Nationals (12334kms/7665 miles away). So
if you think the comps are too far away, think about all the people in
the southern hemisphere. I don't think there has ever been a single
official competition south of the equator!

Jasmine





1793. RE: [Speed cubing group] Pseudo-stackmat
From: François Sechet <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 04:19:55 +0200 (CEST)

the link doesn't seem to work, I get to a blank page with a whole lot of weird caracters that seem to say "you did something wrong" in a language I haven't learned yet. But I guess I got the rough meaning of it. Could you reupload that video or do something about it? ;-) Francois Daniel Hayes <swedishlf@...> a écrit : Hey guys, With the Dallas tourney approaching quickly and me with no experience at a stackmat I decided to do something about it so I wouldn't be caught totally unawares. A quick look at the bank account said "You're buying a stackmat? Riiiiiiiiiiight." And a quick look at the twistypuzzles forum gave me a kick in the rear to attempt to make my own. So after 1 night of slamming my head against a desk in desperation, and one afternoon of much of the same I have my finished product. It is ugly as all hell and doesn't function *exactly* like a stackmat, but at least I'll have a bit of the feel down. The best part is it only cost me $5 for a stopwatch and about $3 in parts I had lying around the house. The touch pads are sensitive enough to one person touch one, another person touch the other and then any contact between the two people will start the time (makes me think of the team solving vid I saw earlier, very cool btw). The only thing I'd like to do to it at this point is make it so that the timer starts on release instead of on contact. As it is now, the start and stop happen immediately upon touching the pads. Without further ado, here is the vid of the ugly thing in action! http://tinyurl.com/d89yt Best, Daniel --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. --------------------------------- --------------------------------- Appel audio GRATUIT partout dans le monde avec le nouveau Yahoo! Messenger Téléchargez le ici ! [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1794. Re: [Speed cubing group] Pseudo-stackmat
From: "Peter Douthwright" <pdouthwright0513@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 12 Jul 2005 22:34:21 -0400

I saw it and I sat if it works great. Nice job on it. Can you give us some details on the parts you used and how you did it?
----- Original Message -----
From: Daniel Hayes
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, July 12, 2005 10:08 PM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] Pseudo-stackmat


Hey guys,
With the Dallas tourney approaching quickly and me with no
experience at a stackmat I decided to do something about it so I
wouldn't be caught totally unawares. A quick look at the bank account
said "You're buying a stackmat? Riiiiiiiiiiight." And a quick look
at the twistypuzzles forum gave me a kick in the rear to attempt to
make my own.

So after 1 night of slamming my head against a desk in desperation,
and one afternoon of much of the same I have my finished product. It
is ugly as all hell and doesn't function *exactly* like a stackmat,
but at least I'll have a bit of the feel down. The best part is it
only cost me $5 for a stopwatch and about $3 in parts I had lying
around the house.

The touch pads are sensitive enough to one person touch one, another
person touch the other and then any contact between the two people
will start the time (makes me think of the team solving vid I saw
earlier, very cool btw).

The only thing I'd like to do to it at this point is make it so that
the timer starts on release instead of on contact. As it is now, the
start and stop happen immediately upon touching the pads.

Without further ado, here is the vid of the ugly thing in action!

http://tinyurl.com/d89yt

Best,
Daniel

c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service.

should get you there though).

Peter-

trying to make it clear enough to share :P.

-Daniel

1800. Standard deviation
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 03:43:44 -0000

I've noticed that my standard deviation is often ~10% of my average.
My average is around 38s and my SD is usually a little under 4 (duh,
obviously you could calculate that). Anyway, I was curious what sort
of SDs do other people get? And whether SDs for cubers tend to
increase/decrease the slower/faster they are, and also whether the SD
as a percentage of the average increases/decreases the slower/faster
the cuber.

Jasmine
http://speedcuber.blogspot.com





1801. [Speed cubing group] Re: you have been cubing too much...
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 03:54:52 -0000

You know you've been cubing too much when...

... you're at a restaurant and doing a speedcubing demo for a friend
and the waiter comes over and is so impressed that he offers you a
free drink and then at the end of the evening brings his own cube
(which he happened to have in his bag) to you and asks you to
autograph it and says that he recognises you from a news article in
the local paper!

... you're at a different restaurant with a different friend in a
different city and end up doing a speedcubing demo for all the staff,
and the waitress with the cube t-shirt is so impressed by the demo
that she gives you her t-shirt (no, this is not an x-rated story - she
had two tops on, the cube t-shirt was the outer layer)

... you're at an airport cafe drinking coffee and cubing and waiting
for a connecting flight and end up being asked to demo the cube to all
the staff at the cafe

(Yes, these all did happen to me - btw, the connecting flight I was
waiting for was on my way back from RWC2003!)

Jasmine
http://speedcuber.blogspot.com





1802. Re: Standard deviation
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 04:49:57 -0000

Just took an average: Average: 26.24 St dev: 2.38 = 9.07% of average. Now you've got me curious too! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I've noticed that my standard deviation is often ~10% of my average. > My average is around 38s and my SD is usually a little under 4 (duh, > obviously you could calculate that). Anyway, I was curious what sort > of SDs do other people get? And whether SDs for cubers tend to > increase/decrease the slower/faster they are, and also whether the SD > as a percentage of the average increases/decreases the slower/faster > the cuber. > > Jasmine > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com
1803. Re: Standard deviation
From: "tsbischof" <tom@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 05:02:08 -0000

Here's a couple of old averages from me: Average, standard deviation, percentage 23.26, 2.01, 8.64% 24.33, 1.55, 6.37% 23.64, 2.84, 12.01% 22.51, 1.30, 5.76% Just took out four averages from my JNetCube files. The first one is from a few days ago, and the others are a couple months old. -Thomas Bischof --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > Just took an average: > Average: 26.24 > St dev: 2.38 = 9.07% of average. > > Now you've got me curious too! > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I've noticed that my standard deviation is often ~10% of my average. > > My average is around 38s and my SD is usually a little under 4 (duh, > > obviously you could calculate that). 1806. Re: Standard deviation
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 05:47:11 -0000

Ya a couple nights ago, me and DanH was discussing this as well. I have a rediculous standard deviation I though... these days I get times over 30s occasioanlly and my fast times are even faster, I get 13s solves as well. So according to DanH (and i"m now inclined to agree), one *should* target a 10% SD. This is a "rule of thumb" similar to say... in tennis how your supposed to be at 80% on your first serve. (Just did 100 serves tonight btw, and then spent 20 minutes drenched in the rain, probably wake up with a cold....) Thus it comes to reason that if you are overly consistant, to risk more for the fast times, and to try to be more consistant (i.e. mistakes in terms of recognition, wrong alg execution, and lock-ups) by going a little be slower at first and then build up speed in a reasonable manner. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I've noticed that my standard deviation is often ~10% of my average. > My average is around 38s and my SD is usually a little under 4 (duh, > obviously you could calculate that). Anyway, I was curious what sort > of SDs do other people get? And whether SDs for cubers tend to > increase/decrease the slower/faster they are, and also whether the SD > as a percentage of the average increases/decreases the slower/faster > the cuber. > > Jasmine > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com

to
> always focus the comps in the same city/state, then yes, there
> probably would be grounds for complaining, but as long as it's unpaid
> voluntary work then I'm just happy that there are competitions
> happening, wherever they might be!


Excellent point!




So
> if you think the comps are too far away, think about all the people
in
> the southern hemisphere. I don't think there has ever been a single
> official competition south of the equator!


Wait..., I thought you were the only competitor from the southern
hemisphere :).


-Doug

1812. Re: [Speed cubing group] Sudoku
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 06:45:25 -0000

1813. Re: [Speed cubing group] California tournaments
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 07:58:49 -0000

I think I have been the only competitor from down south at comps in recent years, but only because the comps are so far away! :) There are definitely other cubers in Oz! If there was a comp in Sydney or Melbourne then I'm sure we'd discover other cubers. Maybe even some New Zealand cubers?? Never met or heard of any cubers from New Zealand. Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > So > > if you think the comps are too far away, think about all the people > in > > the southern hemisphere. 1816. Re: Sudoku
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 09:29:11 -0000

okidokie, I just beat it. However, my eyes no longer look healthy and it's 5:30am here. My thinks I have an addictive personality..., lol. After lvl-31 it started going fast again, but the very last one took a long time. Between this and working on sq-1 methodology tonight, I think I've been fairly productive, in the most unprodictuve sense of the word... -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > yep. very possible. several people seem to have done it just > today. if you keep at it long enough you'll get it and then you'll > wonder why it took you so long... > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Lvl 31. > > > > I can't seem to beat it either, been stuck for hrs. It's like I > need > > someone to assure me it's even possible. > > > > -Doug > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > I just got through level 30 and quit at 31 on gridlock. 27 was > > > actually harder for me than 24 or 25. so those are definitely > > > possible. i won't spoil it for you in case you want to figure > it > > > out on your own. give it another try and you'll get it. I may > > have > > > an advantage because like I said I've watched my kids [ages 6 > and > > 8] > > > doing rush hour, and I've bailed them out when they got stuck. > > But > > > let me know if you really want me to walk you through the > solution. > > > --Kirk > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, François Sechet > > > <frsechet@y...> wrote: > > > > That's cool because I noticed that puzzle in the newspaper > > > (Detroit News or whatever it's called) 2 days ago and wanted to > > post > > > about it, but Michael was faster... It's really fun to do. Also, > > > there's a cool puzzle I found the other day, it's called > gridlock, > > > it can be found there http://www.ebaumsworld.com/gridlock.shtml. > > > Richard and I are stuck at level 25, I haven't heard of ChrisH > > after > > > level 24 either, so if anyone figures that one out, please > contact > > > me... :-D > > > > The idea is to get the blue bar out of the box somehow, by > > pushing > > > the other bars out of it's way. > > > > have fun, > > > > Francois > > > > > > > > Duncan Dicks <duncan@d...> a écrit : > > > > Its a real craze in the Uk at the moment too! > > > > Not too hard but quite addictive! > > > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > > > From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@y...> > > > > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > > > > Sent: Tuesday, July 12, 2005 3:28 PM > > > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Sudoku > > > > > > > > > > > > > hey, > > > > > > > > > > my dad was just on a business trip in Europe, and he knows > how > > I > > > like > > > > > puzzles, so he brought back a newspaper with a new puzzle in > > it > > > called > > > > > Sudoku. apparently it's become really really popular in > > Japan, > > > and > > > > > they publish it in the newspaper every week with the > > crossword. > > > and > > > > > more recently they've started posting it in the Washington > > Post, > > > USA > > > > > Today, etc.... > > > > > anyway, it's a very interesting puzzle. it's a square > that's > > > divided > > > > > into 9 smaller squares, which are each divided into 9 more > > > smaller > > > > > squares, so there's 81 smaller squares. some of them are > > already > > > > > filled with random numbers, and you have to fill in the rest > > of > > > them > > > > > so that each row, column, and separate 3x3 square has the > > > numbers 1-9 > > > > > in it. > > > > > I knew some of you would be interested in it, so decided to > > > share. > > > > > here's a wiki article on it: > > > > > http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudoku > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > > > > YAHOO! 1819. Gridlock
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 11:02:03 -0000

Hey did anyone else find the bug in level 36?
http://www.ebaumsworld.com/gridlock.shtml

I beat it the normal way, but there's also a way to cheat and beat it
in 2 moves (slide one block out of the way, slide the blue block out).

Kinda weird, I wonder if the programmers know.

Chris

Indien u dit bericht onterecht ontvangt, wordt u verzocht de inhoud niet te gebruiken en de afzender direct te informeren door het bericht te retourneren. ================================================ The information contained in this message may be confidential and is intended to be exclusively for the addressee. Should you receive this message unintentionally, please do not use the contents herein and notify the sender immediately by return e-mail. ================================================ [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Yes i know there is sometimes a delay u can't control btw the levels ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey did anyone else find the bug in level 36? > http://www.ebaumsworld.com/gridlock.shtml > > I beat it the normal way, but there's also a way to cheat and beat it > in 2 moves (slide one block out of the way, slide the blue block out). > > Kinda weird, I wonder if the programmers know. > > Chris

1823. Re: [Speed cubing group] Standard deviation
From: nascarjon2001 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 14:48:15 -0000

I average 15 - 16 and my standard deviation is usually 0.5 to 1.5. Jon http://www.geocities.com/nascarjon2001 --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o...> wrote: > I average around 32s and my SD is around 2-3 > > > Bryan Mytko > bryanosaurus@b... > > > On Jul 12, 2005, at 11:43 PM, jasmine_ellen wrote: > > > I've noticed that my standard deviation is often ~10% of my average. > > My average is around 38s and my SD is usually a little under 4 (duh, > > obviously you could calculate that). Anyway, I was curious what sort > > of SDs do other people get? And whether SDs for cubers tend to > > increase/decrease the slower/faster they are, and also whether the SD > > as a percentage of the average increases/decreases the slower/faster > > the cuber. > > > > Jasmine > > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com > > > > > > > > > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > > > Your use of Yahoo! 1826. Re: [Speed cubing group] Skewb sighting
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 15:47:26 -0000

Don't forget the episode "Hurricain Neddy" in which the Simpsons are stuckin the basement and try to solve a cube they stumble across: Lisa: OK start with diagonal colors. Homer: Use your main finger on the yellow side, and your other finger on the other side, and turn it! Marge: My main finger? (inintelligable yammering) Bart: Spin the middle side topwise-topwise! One of my all time favorite Simpsons moments. -Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > And there are cubes in several Simpsons episodes. In the episode > where Homer removes a crayon out of his nose, he becomes very smart > and solves a lot of cubes. I'm quite impressed because he only needs > about five turns for each cube. > > /Gunnar >
1827. Re: Gridlock (****SPOLIER***** ****SPOLIER****)
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 15:59:06 -0000

This message is a spolier, don't read if you haven't solved level 36 already (or if you don't care to see the solution). Here are some screen shots for level 36. I found the cheat solution by accident (the block in question can actually be dragged completely off the board, so the first time I tried to move it, it went at an odd angle - so that's how I found out). I thought the puzzle was impossible and this was their clever trick to make you have to realize which block made it impossible, but there is a regular solution, I've included that screenshot too. How to cheat level 36 http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/36cheatsoln.jpg The regular solution to level 36 http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/36soln.jpg Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Umm ,,, > > I didn't get that far yet. Can u take a sreenshot and explain the bug? > Yes i know u have to replay the first 35 levels again ... hahaha ... u > might as well practice all the 40 levels for speed. Can u manage all > levels in say less than 20 minutes? Yes i know there is sometimes a > delay u can't control btw the levels ;-) > > Cheers! > > -Per

1843. Video database at strangepuzzle.com
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 21:50:30 -0000

I like videos!! That's why I decided to make a video database for all
speedsolving videos. It's fully searchable by first name, last name,
puzzle type, and the time of the solve (like less than 20 seconds or
something).

I went ahead and uploaded 68 3x3x3 speedsolving videos already (just
the ones I had in random places on my harddrive). Please check it out
and submit your videos! All you do is goto the videos section fill out
the form which includes your name, puzzle type, time of solve, and a
URL that I can download the video from. Once I download the video and
add it to the database, it's stored on my server. I have 3gig of
storage and I want to fill it up! Please make me have to buy more
webspace :P

I'm accepting videos for:

2x2x2
3x3x3
4x4x4
5x5x5
blindfold
clock
magic
megaminx
one-handed
pyraminx
siamese

Please send those videos in so I can watch them and share them with
every one else!

-Chris

California Institute of Technology

From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 22:37:42 -0000

I think the whole idea is excellent, but how many videos do you suppose you could post before you run out of space? :P ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > One thing you could do, and we could all help, is cut out videos from > > the Horace Mann DVD. That would provide you of a lot! Then you could > > also sort by "event" with "home video" being one of the options. > > Sweet! I don't have the DVD though :) > > If someone cuts the DVD up and submits each video seperatly then I > would gladly post them. > > Have a super day! > > -Chris

1850. Re: Video database at strangepuzzle.com
From: "Chris Parlette" <mdcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 23:11:29 -0000

Great job with the ability to search! I really like that database. A couple of things I was thinking about: 1) You might want to ask Ian Winokur before you start ripping videos from the DVD he made. He and Raul Garcia put a lot of time into making that look extraordinary, and I'd hate to see someone not buy the DVD since they could just download all the videos. However, he might say that its completely fine to do so, but I think you should get his permission. 2) I think it would be nice to have a naming convention for the videos. For instance, the names I use for the videos I download is "PuzzleType Time NameOfPerson.extension". So for instance, I have "3x3x3 12'11 Shotaro 'Macky' Makisumi.wmv". This way, when I have all the videos in my one folder, all the puzzles are grouped together, then listed in order of time. It's not a huge deal, but it would be nice. Thanks again for the site, I look forward to utilizing it! -Chris Parlette --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I like videos!! That's why I decided to make a video database for all > speedsolving videos. It's fully searchable by first name, last name, > puzzle type, and the time of the solve (like less than 20 seconds or > something).
1851. Re: Video database at strangepuzzle.com
From: burntbizzkit <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 23:19:10 -0000

> 1) You might want to ask Ian Winokur before you start ripping videos
> from the DVD he made. He and Raul Garcia put a lot of time into
> making that look extraordinary, and I'd hate to see someone not buy
> the DVD since they could just download all the videos. However, he
> might say that its completely fine to do so, but I think you should
> get his permission.

Absolutely. I would hate to undermine all their hard work. I also
encourage anyone who sees their videos on my site and doesn't want
them there, let me know!! I just uploaded all the videos that I had
laying around and don't want anyone to have videos up there that they
don't want me hosting.

> 2) I think it would be nice to have a naming convention for the
> videos. For instance, the names I use for the videos I download is
> "PuzzleType Time NameOfPerson.extension". So for instance, I have
> "3x3x3 12'11 Shotaro 'Macky' Makisumi.wmv". This way, when I have all
> the videos in my one folder, all the puzzles are grouped together,
> then listed in order of time. It's not a huge deal, but it would be
> nice.

Nice idea. I thought about that too, but I worry about file names
getting too large. I have a couple ghetto computers in my house that
don't like files with names larger than 8 (or so) characters. The
numbering system I use is also automated so it makes it a little
easier for me to add more videos to the database. I'm working on
trying to do something like that though.

-Chris




1852. Re: Video database at strangepuzzle.com
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 23:39:22 -0000

I actually prefer naming things as: namepuzzletime.avi (since all my videos are DivX). For 3x3x3, i just use nametime.avi so for example, my video names would be (are): burton2055.avi burtonpyraminx1501.avi burton2x2x21022.avi burtonmagic129.avi etc. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Chris Parlette" <mdcube@g...> wrote: > Great job with the ability to search! However, he > might say that its completely fine to do so, but I think you should > get his permission. > > 2) I think it would be nice to have a naming convention for the > videos. For instance, the names I use for the videos I download is > "PuzzleType Time NameOfPerson.extension". So for instance, I have > "3x3x3 12'11 Shotaro 'Macky' Makisumi.wmv". This way, when I have all > the videos in my one folder, all the puzzles are grouped together, > then listed in order of time. We should adopt the convention n-cube for nxnxn cube. I'm tired of saying three by three by three. Of course, this doesn't work for 2x2x3 but those aren't referenced enough yet. Two by two by three, two by two by two by three, un haiduk? NUMA NUMA! Anyway, I was curious what > sort > > > of SDs do other people get? 1857. Re: [Speed cubing group] Standard deviation
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Jul 2005 19:56:27 -0500

basically, standard deviation is how far one deviates on average from their average. so like nascarjon2001 averages 15-16 with a std dev of .5-1.5, which means that on average, he is .5-1.5 above or below 15-16. i hope that makes sense On 7/13/05, Pedro <pedrosino1@...> wrote: > I don't know what is this Standard Deviation... > > Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@gmail.com> escreveu:damn. thats good. > > On 7/13/05, nascarjon2001 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > I average 15 - 16 and my standard deviation is usually 0.5 to 1.5. > > > > Jon > > http://www.geocities.com/nascarjon2001 > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko > > <bmytko@o...> wrote: > > > I average around 32s and my SD is around 2-3 > > > > > > > > > Bryan Mytko > > > bryanosaurus@b... > > > > > > > > > On Jul 12, 2005, at 11:43 PM, jasmine_ellen wrote: > > > > > > > I've noticed that my standard deviation is often ~10% of my > > average. > > > > My average is around 38s and my SD is usually a little under 4 > > (duh, > > > > obviously you could calculate that). Anyway, I was curious what > > sort > > > > of SDs do other people get? And whether SDs for cubers tend to > > > > increase/decrease the slower/faster they are, and also whether > > the SD > > > > as a percentage of the average increases/decreases the > > slower/faster > > > > the cuber. > > > > > > > > Jasmine > > > > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > YAHOO! 1866. Re: 6x6x6 cube
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Jul 2005 07:41:34 -0000

Wow looks like it turns much better than my 5x5... I can't believe my eyes, how the heck is it even possible (from a mechanical pov)? Well I definately think that to be even more convincing the guy should of scrambled it up fully. Doing those turns and then undoing.... it doesn't have the same impact. For all I know, he's able to cheat the system, and have someting that looks like it works but doesn't really and is somehow (internally) "bandaged" if you know what I mean... Ummm, maybe the guy is rather slow at solving one and just didn't want to jumble it up beyond a couple simple turns. I would have at least liked to see him put a checkerboard pattern on it.... oh wait, that's right, even cubes don't admit good checkerboards. Ok, I want one. I want to take it apart and see how he does it... then again it might be too complicated and I wouldn't be able to put it back together. Though I'm sure Ton is doing everything in his power to get in on this amazing collector's item; and he's not the kinda guy that'll be too afraid to take it apart. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > The page says that they will be in production within the next few months. > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > My only questions are, 1) when do they go into production? ; 2) how > > much will they cost? ; and 3) when can we buy them? > > > > ;-) > > > > From speedcubing.com: > > Olympicube.com posted a video of a preproduction 6x6x6, invented by > > Panayotis Verdes from Greece (bottom of the page). > > > > Wow, awesome stuff! > > > > Chris

Date: Thu, 14 Jul 2005 04:03:26 -0400

where is this vid? Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... On Jul 14, 2005, at 3:41 AM, d_funny007 wrote: > Wow looks like it turns much better than my 5x5... > > I can't believe my eyes, how the heck is it even possible (from a > mechanical pov)? Well I definately think that to be even more > convincing the guy should of scrambled it up fully. Doing those > turns and then undoing.... it doesn't have the same impact. For all > I know, he's able to cheat the system, and have someting that looks > like it works but doesn't really and is somehow > (internally) "bandaged" if you know what I mean... > > Ummm, maybe the guy is rather slow at solving one and just didn't > want to jumble it up beyond a couple simple turns. I would have at > least liked to see him put a checkerboard pattern on it.... oh wait, > that's right, even cubes don't admit good checkerboards. > > Ok, I want one. I want to take it apart and see how he does it... > then again it might be too complicated and I wouldn't be able to put > it back together. Though I'm sure Ton is doing everything in his > power to get in on this amazing collector's item; and he's not the > kinda guy that'll be too afraid to take it apart. > > > -Doug > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > <bob@c...> wrote: > > The page says that they will be in production within the next few > months. > > > > ~ Bob > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > <no_reply@y...> > > wrote: > > > My only questions are, 1) when do they go into production? ; 2) > how > > > much will they cost? ; and 3) when can we buy them? > > > > > > ;-) > > > > > > From speedcubing.com: > > > Olympicube.com posted a video of a preproduction 6x6x6, invented > by > > > Panayotis Verdes from Greece (bottom of the page). > > > > > > Wow, awesome stuff! > > > > > > Chris > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle games Computer puzzle game > Online puzzle games Free puzzle inlay games > > YAHOO! 1868. Re: 6x6x6 cube
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Jul 2005 08:14:11 -0000

Wow :D It's not fair to publish a video like that when im trying to finish my master theses by sept 1st :-( Now i'm getting desperate to lay my hands on a beauty like that ;-) It seems to turn quite nicely indeed. My guess is that it's possible to solve it in less than 4 minutes at least. Maybe even sub 3 if turning is really smooth. Or would i not dare push it to it's limits? Hmmm ... I hope it's as light as it seems on the video. Also i hope it has no fragile pieces like the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 does. Oh well, we'll see ... :D :D Panayotis, are u reading this group? Will this beauty (or other even larger ones) go into mass production any time soon? And in that case would u have any idea what the price would be? Im willing to pay at least £50 for a puzzle like that. At least if the quality is good. Hmm okay Chris already asked those obvious questions :-P Awesome video !!! Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > My only questions are, 1) when do they go into production? ; 2) how > much will they cost? ; and 3) when can we buy them? > > ;-) > > From speedcubing.com: > Olympicube.com posted a video of a preproduction 6x6x6, invented by > Panayotis Verdes from Greece (bottom of the page). > > Wow, awesome stuff! > > Chris

1874. Re: University of Michigan Tournament
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Jul 2005 10:04:29 -0000

Due to the certainty of this tournament now that I have a few
cofirmations from people that will be comming a rather long way to
participate, I have decided that due this effort and financial
concerns I can no longer attend the Dallas tournament.

Sorry...

Also I was trying to reserve a couple dorm rooms for poeple that would
prefer that over hotel (better situated since there are no nearby
hotels, and much more affordable). But then I realized, ops it's not
going to be summer anymore. So it looks like I'll be looking around
for a centralized hotel/motel for you guys. It has to be cheap and
close by, though I can have my sister run a quick shuttle service
between the hotel and competition building... as well as Airport and
hotel.

Today I was able to recruit one more volenteer
(judges/scramblers/timers) for it (during an hr of intense soccer).
And then another on AIM (the guy that approched me about building a
cube robot a few months ago). The current progress on this is about 1
new person a day on average. Thus it's starting come together on the
informal side.... now for the legal side.

Going into student organizations office to discuss the feisibility of
it all is NOT something I loook forward to doing this week (was gonna
be today, but a friend dropped by and we walked the mall for hrs).



On a lighter note, I beat Gridlock (lvl 31 took 3-4hrs, lvls 36 and 40
long too, all the rest flew through), and so decided to try some
Sudoku, I htought it was rather hard and couldn't do it at first, but
then I red the rules :).

Besides columns and rows there's also the 3x3 regions... well I
rapidly did an easy one. And then did one on "insane/evil"
difficuilty, and am now temporarily severly addicted.

I was even working on a "speed-sudoku" method :).

One quote I find a bit disturbing though: "The immense popularity of
Sudoku in British newspapers and internationally has led to it being
dubbed in the world media in 2005 variously as "the Rubik's cube of
the 21st century" or the "fastest growing puzzle in the world"."
(source: wikipedia)


-Doug

p.s. Hope to see somebody in NY [c.f. my last post], and many thanks
to those that have already made plans to attend my event

1878. Caring for your cube
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Jul 2005 13:53:15 -0000

Hi everyone,

I have been cleaning my cubes today. I use silicone spray lube to make
the puzzles turn faster, and this is easy to clean off.

When I open up the cube, I have to clean this grey gunky stuff, looks
like a mix of dust and lube, with a texture slightly more viscous than
graphite.

Trouble is, some parts are very hard to reach. This happens in 2
places: 1) Inside the edge pieces. The gunk is quite thick here, and
on previous cleanings I think I've been a bit lazy and just rubbed the
pieces a bit with a kitchen towel. Is it important to also remove the
gunk inside the edge pieces? These areas, as far as I can see, don't
come into contact with anything else, but they might add extra weight
to each piece or something, I dunno hehe

2) Inbetween the centre piece of plastic, and the axles of each cube
"arm". I think it must be very important to remove this, because these
two areas are rotating against each other all the time during a solve.
It's extremely fiddly to get in there, I need about 4 hands. I was
just now going to take the whole centre-piece structure apart (a bit
reluctant because I was worried that I might not find the correct
spring tensions when I put it back together), and I found it was
riveted together, so I can't even de-construct it.

Do you have any tips for cleaning in these areas? And cleaning the
cube in general :)

Thanks,

Dan Harris :)




1879. Re: [Speed cubing group] Caring for your cube
From: "Alberto Cuesta" <arcdraven@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 14 Jul 2005 16:04:53 +0200

use a little toothbrush to reach and clean the 90 degree center part, wet with a little soap and water. then let it dry.

this way you do not need to screw off the skeleton...

i think the edge pieces do not need more exhaustive clean in that 'unreachabe' part...

Alberto

----- Original Message -----
From: Dan
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, July 14, 2005 3:53 PM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] Caring for your cube


Hi everyone,

I have been cleaning my cubes today. I use silicone spray lube to make
the puzzles turn faster, and this is easy to clean off.

When I open up the cube, I have to clean this grey gunky stuff, looks
like a mix of dust and lube, with a texture slightly more viscous than
graphite.

Trouble is, some parts are very hard to reach. This happens in 2
places: 1) Inside the edge pieces. The gunk is quite thick here, and
on previous cleanings I think I've been a bit lazy and just rubbed the
pieces a bit with a kitchen towel. Is it important to also remove the
gunk inside the edge pieces? These areas, as far as I can see, don't
come into contact with anything else, but they might add extra weight
to each piece or something, I dunno hehe

2) Inbetween the centre piece of plastic, and the axles of each cube
"arm". I think it must be very important to remove this, because these
two areas are rotating against each other all the time during a solve.
It's extremely fiddly to get in there, I need about 4 hands. I was
just now going to take the whole centre-piece structure apart (a bit
reluctant because I was worried that I might not find the correct
spring tensions when I put it back together), and I found it was
riveted together, so I can't even de-construct it.

Do you have any tips for cleaning in these areas? And cleaning the
cube in general :)

Thanks,

Dan Harris :)

1883. Re: [Speed cubing group] Caring for your cube
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Jul 2005 09:59:07 -0600

The toothbrush is a brilliant idea. Just make sure you know which
toothbrush is your cube brush and which one is for your teeth. I
always found the residue as a mild skin irritant and so the tooth brush
definitely helps protects my hands.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

but there is still sunny funny

and kick them to the wall

i am gonna be crazy
with my cat who is lazy

oh no you look cubic
your hands shake
please take a break

1887. [Speed cubing group] Re: Video database at strangepuzzle.com
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Jul 2005 17:45:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > WHAAAATTT!!! The ONE solve you have of me is a over 20 second solve of > me... WHILE SINGING BANANA PHONE!!!! > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology That video is actually pretty funny, thanks for bringing that to my attention. But it is in the "laughing with you not at you" kind of way. In regards to the strangepuzzle.com site, and the video section in particular, I wanted to throw out a suggestion or two. Of course I don't know what database you are using, but is it possible for you to change your query to use something like _select * from [table] where FirstName like `%@FName%'_ and the same for the last name as well? That way if you put in "Jeff" you would get results for "Jeffery" (if there is even such a cuber). Also, can you take off the restriction that you must put either a first or last name? It would be nice to just see every thing you have, as it is difficult to think of who you want to see, but if the list was just available it would be easier to decide. But aside from my requests, it is an excellent idea, and the site looks very nice. Great work and thank you for putting in the time, money and effort. -Dave

1889. Re: 6x6x6 cube
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Jul 2005 17:55:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Wow looks like it turns much better than my 5x5... > > -Doug A couple questions: 1. Do the 2 and 3 cubes have different mechanisms than other more "classic" implementations? 2. If so, does the smoothness on the 6-cube imply that the lower-order cubes could rival other cubes already in production in terms of speed and/or smoothness? 3. When it says on the 7-cube for example that it has "219 smaller pieces, of which 218 pieces are visible to the player", does that mean that it has a solid kernel? -Ben
1890. Re: 6x6x6 cube
From: "skeneegee" <skeneegee@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Jul 2005 20:25:33 -0000

About the 6x6x6 from Olympic Cubes, It's a completely different
approach to the building of the mechanism, each cubie reaches deep
into the center of the puzzle, not at all like the Professor cube.
There are a few lucky owners of this puzzle around and at least one
said they love it and it works.

Honestly, what would someone have to gain from a hoax of this nature,
including purchasing an expensive patent?

Believe it!

-mike grimsley

Date: Thu, 14 Jul 2005 21:38:14 -0000

> In regards to the strangepuzzle.com site, and the video section in
> particular, I wanted to throw out a suggestion or two. Of course I
> don't know what database you are using, but is it possible for you
> to change your query to use something like _select * from [table]
> where FirstName like `%@FName%'_ and the same for the last name as
> well? That way if you put in "Jeff" you would get results
> for "Jeffery" (if there is even such a cuber). Also, can you take
> off the restriction that you must put either a first or last name?

> difficult to think of who you want to see, but if the list was just
> available it would be easier to decide.

Great ideas. The latter I just finished this afternoon. You can now
browse all videos in a given puzzle catagory by selecting the puzzle
type and pressing 'search videos'. I'll implement the regular
expression evaluation later tonight, hopefully.

> But aside from my requests, it is an excellent idea, and the site
> looks very nice. Great work and thank you for putting in the time,
> money and effort.

Thanks a lot. I spent a while working on the page and I'm very very
happy that people are enjoying the service. You can thank me by
sending in videos :)

Have a nice day!

-Chris

1900. Re: Caring for your cube
From: "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 14 Jul 2005 21:52:25 -0000

I use Q-tips in all those places. I do clean the the inside of the edges and that little hole on the corners because I just have this feeling that once I lube the cube the gunk will drip out onto all the pieces I just cleaned. I don't know, sometimes I'm too compulsive. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > Hi everyone, > > I have been cleaning my cubes today. I use silicone spray lube to make > the puzzles turn faster, and this is easy to clean off. > > When I open up the cube, I have to clean this grey gunky stuff, looks > like a mix of dust and lube, with a texture slightly more viscous than > graphite. > > Trouble is, some parts are very hard to reach. This happens in 2 > places: 1) Inside the edge pieces. The gunk is quite thick here, and > on previous cleanings I think I've been a bit lazy and just rubbed the > pieces a bit with a kitchen towel. Is it important to also remove the > gunk inside the edge pieces? These areas, as far as I can see, don't > come into contact with anything else, but they might add extra weight > to each piece or something, I dunno hehe > > 2) Inbetween the centre piece of plastic, and the axles of each cube > "arm". I think it must be very important to remove this, because these > two areas are rotating against each other all the time during a solve. > It's extremely fiddly to get in there, I need about 4 hands. I was > just now going to take the whole centre-piece structure apart (a bit > reluctant because I was worried that I might not find the correct > spring tensions when I put it back together), and I found it was > riveted together, so I can't even de-construct it. > > Do you have any tips for cleaning in these areas? And cleaning the > cube in general :) > > Thanks, > > Dan Harris :)

(Hey Doug, I think I fixed the problem, but I am not 100% sure..) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, burntbizzkit <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I like videos!! That's why I decided to make a video database for all > speedsolving videos. It's fully searchable by first name, last name, > puzzle type, and the time of the solve (like less than 20 seconds or > something). > > I went ahead and uploaded 68 3x3x3 speedsolving videos already (just > the ones I had in random places on my harddrive). Please check it out > and submit your videos! All you do is goto the videos section fill out > the form which includes your name, puzzle type, time of solve, and a > URL that I can download the video from. Once I download the video and > add it to the database, it's stored on my server. I have 3gig of > storage and I want to fill it up! Please make me have to buy more > webspace :P > > I'm accepting videos for: > > 2x2x2 > 3x3x3 > 4x4x4 > 5x5x5 > blindfold > clock > magic > megaminx > one-handed > pyraminx > siamese > > Please send those videos in so I can watch them and share them with > every one else! > > -Chris

1907. [Speed cubing group] Re: Video database at strangepuzzle.com
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>

Date: Fri, 15 Jul 2005 03:39:05 -0000

I will send Chris a few vids from the Horace Mann tournament for him to post on his site. I'll be bringing copies of the DVD set to Dallas and to Disney. Since I don't have to pay for bubble envelopes or shipping, price will be $10 at either venue. Details are available at http://home.manhattan.edu/~ian.winokur/DVD/dvd.html Ian Winokur PS Chris Hardwick and I did over 100 team blindfold solves today. At what point do we seek help for this addiction? :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o...> wrote: > You should try and get permission for a few Horace Mann vids, and > provide a link to their site - it would work as an advertisement for > buying the whole DVD. > > > Bryan Mytko > bryanosaurus@b... > > > On Jul 13, 2005, at 7:19 PM, burntbizzkit wrote: > > > > 1) You might want to ask Ian Winokur before you start ripping videos > > > from the DVD he made. He and Raul Garcia put a lot of time into > > > making that look extraordinary, and I'd hate to see someone not buy > > > the DVD since they could just download all the videos. However, he > > > might say that its completely fine to do so, but I think you should > > > get his permission. > > > > Absolutely. I would hate to undermine all their hard work. I also > > encourage anyone who sees their videos on my site and doesn't want > > them there, let me know!! I just uploaded all the videos that I had > > laying around and don't want anyone to have videos up there that they > > don't want me hosting. > > > > > 2) I think it would be nice to have a naming convention for the > > > videos. For instance, the names I use for the videos I download is > > > "PuzzleType Time NameOfPerson.extension". So for instance, I have > > > "3x3x3 12'11 Shotaro 'Macky' Makisumi.wmv". This way, when I > > have all > > > the videos in my one folder, all the puzzles are grouped together, > > > then listed in order of time. It's not a huge deal, but it would be > > > nice. > > > > Nice idea. I thought about that too, but I worry about file names > > getting too large. I have a couple ghetto computers in my house that > > don't like files with names larger than 8 (or so) characters. The > > numbering system I use is also automated so it makes it a little > > easier for me to add more videos to the database. I'm working on > > trying to do something like that though. > > > > -Chris > > > > > > > > YAHOO! 1917. Re: [Speed cubing group] Skewb sighting
From: "Andreas Renberg" <rubikssites@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 15 Jul 2005 17:05:47 -0000

Actually, they draw it that way because years ago, animators had to draw everything by hand and draw several pages. This often took several hours. So sometimes animators took shortcuts by only drawing 4 fingers on characters, and drawing characters with less details. Now they often use computers for animation, but they still keep the "4 finger tradition". Andreas ;) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "uberstuberizzle" <jestuber@v...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" > <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > I wonder why cartoon characters always have only 4 fingers. Is it > > harder to draw five fingers? And which finger is missing. Probably > > the pinky. :-) > > > Having to draw the outlines of fingers makes 5 fingers look awkward > and as if there is too many. In anime they usually have five fingers > though.
1918. blindfold video
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 15 Jul 2005 12:42:58 -0600

B R' U' L' U' R' L2 U' B' U2 F2 B' U2 D' B' D' F2 B' D F' B U B' L D2

2 minutes 40.87 seconds

(by my numbering scheme of course)

Edge Permutation: (1 6 3 11 8 9 4 12 7)(2 5)
Corner Permutation: (1 8 2 5 6 3 4 7)
Edge Orientation: (L R2) + 4-flip, 2-flip straight on bottom
Corner Orientation: B' + RL Sunes, F' pairs to the right

http://www.its.caltech.edu/~tmao/Tyson.2-40.87.AVI

So the file is rather large... about 45 MB. If someone can compress it
for me, I'd really appreciate it.

For orientation, instead of listing out which pieces needed to be
corrected, I thought you'd be more interested in what I said to myself
in my head in the process of memorizing.

The glance up at 21 seconds was when I completed the memorization of
the edges.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology



1919. Re: [Speed cubing group] blindfold video
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 15 Jul 2005 13:07:38 -0600

Thanks to Frank Morris... compressed down here:

http://www.its.caltech.edu/~tmao/tysonbld24087.wmv

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

400 Uplands Drive
Hillsborough, CA 94010

1924. Re: LL Methods
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 15 Jul 2005 20:48:25 -0000

Hi Doug, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Well it wouldn't be the Fridrich method if you don't OLL then PLL... > > OLL first (41): 9.22 turn average > PLL second (14): 11.21 turn average > > CLL first (25): 9.18 This is incorrect. There are some corner positions missing. I wonder what other errors lurk unseen. I didn't bother to check the others. > ELL second (19): 11.27 > > ELL first (13): 7.87 > CLL second (42): 11.73 > > Of course these are in face turn metric. I counted the solved case > for each case count in parentheses. Also you should account for an > extra .75 turns based on the 75% chance of having to do an little > post-adjust of the LL in the end. > > Now I've been a CLL/ELL user for a long time. Not sure if anyone in > the world would do ELL/CLL, at least I've never heard of it. I do Corners then Edges. Regards, David J > > -Doug Li > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "darereck" > <darereck@g...> wrote: > > just wondering... which method is faster for the Fridrich method > after > > you finish F2L and how many moves takes for each step?: > > > > OLL then PLL average of 9 moves for OLL and 12 for PLL > > > > ELL then CLL ???? > > > > CLL then ELL ????
1925. [Speed cubing group] Re: Video database at strangepuzzle.com
From: "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 15 Jul 2005 23:05:06 -0000

What's up with that, Chris? You have 3 Gigabytes for video, but you can't spare more than 15 bytes on a name? Shame on you. Here's what I do in my professional databases: first name: 100 last name: 100 address: 255 telephone number: 50 Professor Dijkstra actually claimed once there were only three numbers to be used in computer science: 0, 1 and infinity. It's about time modern databases dumped the stupid maximum length. Michiel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > Hi, > > I have problems submitting a video : you have limited the "Name" > length to 15 letters... > I can't put my name in it ! 1927. [Speed cubing group] Re: Video database at strangepuzzle.com
From: "burntbizzkit" <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 00:26:58 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > Who has a 50 digit telephone number? > Or a 100 letter first name :). Why not set a maxlength? It's only one sql command to change a column to a new size. I think 30 for the first name and 30 for the last name is fine. If someone comes along with a longer name then that, then I'll knock it up again :). I only set limits because I like them. Why alot space when you don't need it. Seems like a waste to me :) -Chris

1929. Improved PLL? (again)
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 01:54:36 -0000

Many thanks to Per for generating a ton of sequences for me. (didn't
have access to aCube myself =/) I found a faster PLL for one of my
worst cases:

(R U')(R U R') D R D'R [y'](R2'U R2 U')B2

Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 04:53:37 -0000

That's a pretty nice alg, though I like the one I'm using now (sub-2 with perfect execution :)) ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@y...> wrote: > Many thanks to Per for generating a ton of sequences for me. (didn't > have access to aCube myself =/) I found a faster PLL for one of my > worst cases: > > (R U')(R U R') D R D'R [y'](R2'U R2 U')B2

1935. Re: [Speed cubing group] J Bernett Orlandos times
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 12:52:57 +0200

Hi Gunnar,

Yesterday I received a videocd of J. Bernett solving 3x3x3 and 5x5x5 blindfolded.
It appeared that he was sometimes peeking during the solve.

Therefore I removed his records. Now he needs to solve the cubes behind a barrier, so that he cannot peek. With his father watching carefully.
Under these strict conditions he already solved 3x3x3 and 4x4x4 blindfolded. But he was still feeling very insecure, that is why his times are much worse.
We are definitely sure that he can solve 3x3x3 blindfolded within 3 minutes.
Let us follow his progress back to the top.

Isn't it great that a 9 year old can solve 3x3x3 and 4x4x4 blindfolded?

Have fun,

Ron

1937. Re: Sudoku
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 11:59:35 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > Its a real craze in the Uk at the moment too! That's true. It seems to be in just about every newspaper here (Times (and Samurai), Independent (and 16x16), Guardian, Mail, Sun, TV guides, mobile phones (not that the latter is a newspaper) . Who knows, even the Sport - not a newspaper either, arguably - might have it (probably a 1x1 version, if they do)? > Not too hard but quite addictive! Some can be quite challenging: here's a good site: http://sudoku.sourceforge.net/ This one, from that page (Brain Of Britain section), is supposed to be quite hard (you can get a similar puzzle replacing the middle 4 with 7). It took longer than usual and I had to invent myself a new technique about halfway through: . 2 . * . . . * . . . . . . * 6 . . * . . 3 . 7 4 * . 8 . * . . . ********************** . . . * . . 3 * . . 2 . 8 . * . 4 . * . 1 . 6 . . * 5 . . * . . . ********************** . . . * . 1 . * 7 8 . 5 . . * . . 9 * . . . . . . * . . . * . 4 . It didn't paste well above, but it is worth a shot. It can all be done without trial-and-error, which is technically logical (being a finite puzzle) although the computer solver on the same site has to guess! - I guess it just doesn't have enough methods. Have a go at it - you definitely don't need anything extraordinary but it is tricky nonetheless. On a related topic with all the exposure it has over here I was naturally drawn to think up a related problem - it will need some terminology which is effectively just formalizing Sudoku terms to get everything on the same level of understanding. A clueset will be an assignment of clues to a subset of the squares (a function from some subset of n^2xn^2 to n, mathematically speaking). Given 2 clusets f and g, if f is a subset of g, f is a subclueset of g and g is a superclueset of f. f is row-feasible if it satisfies the row condition (the restriction of f to each row is 1 to 1 or injective). Similarly we define column feasibility and box-feasibility relating to the other conditions and feasibility regarding all 3 conditions holding at once. A clueset will be a solution if it is feasible and assigns clues to every square (has fulll domain n^2*n^2). A clueset is consistent if it admits a solution superclueset. (NB Feasibility does not imply consistency.) A clueset is inconsistent if it is not consistent. A Sudoku puzzle is then a clueset which admits a unique solution superclueset. A Sudoku puzzle such that no proper subclueset is a Sudoku puzzle would then be a good Sudoku puzzle (in the sense of not having superfluous clues). So we define (two defiinitions at once): a (good) Sudon'tku puzzle is an inconsistent clueset such that every proper clueset is consistent and such that every subclueset omitting just one clue is a (good) Sudoku puzzle. So the questions are: are there any Sudon'tku puzzles (and if so what are the restrictions on n - clearly n must be >1, but are there other restrictions). are there any good Sudon'tku puzzles (ditto)? Presumably it would be too hard to determine the answer for n=2 (by example if affirmative or an exhaustive search if negative, though a better argument would be preferable. Clearly we could start off by looking at all (good) Sudoku puzzles and then extending inconsistently by one clue and seeing if the result satisfied the conditions but perhaps there is a better way. > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@y...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Tuesday, July 12, 2005 3:28 PM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Sudoku > > > > hey, > > > > my dad was just on a business trip in Europe, and he knows how I like > > puzzles, so he brought back a newspaper with a new puzzle in it called > > Sudoku. apparently it's become really really popular in Japan, and > > they publish it in the newspaper every week with the crossword. and > > more recently they've started posting it in the Washington Post, USA > > Today, etc.... > > anyway, it's a very interesting puzzle. it's a square that's divided > > into 9 smaller squares, which are each divided into 9 more smaller > > squares, so there's 81 smaller squares. some of them are already > > filled with random numbers, and you have to fill in the rest of them > > so that each row, column, and separate 3x3 square has the numbers 1-9 > > in it. > > I knew some of you would be interested in it, so decided to share. > > here's a wiki article on it: > > http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudoku > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

1941. Re: Rules on BLD
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 14:19:45 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I am 100% against this. I think we should require the cuber to > resticker their cube with provided sticker sheets, or if that is too > expensive the cuber's own. It's not only about stickers. One face of each Studio Cube edge has a noticable dent. Some cubes have corners without caps and after a quarter turn you can easily feel the holes. The deluxe cube allows the same with edges. Different tensions can be used to determine cube orientation. New rubiks.com 3x3s have "Rubik's" indentation on one of the center caps which can be felt through the sticker (the 4x4 has it on a corner I believe). Stefan
1942. Re: Rules on BLD
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>

To allow for > putting the cube back together wrong. Could be exploited, e.g. if I know I need to flip UR and either FL or FR but don't remember which one, then I could simply flip all three (one by popping). Stefan

1945. [Speed cubing group] Re: Video database at strangepuzzle.com
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 14:41:38 -0000

I don't think it's a joke. I think the point is that any other numbers are artificial and there's no good reason why exactly that number should be used. For cube example, why do we have 15 seconds preinspection and not 30 or 7 or whatever? Well, 0 and 1 are a computer's blood, and if you really want to talk about larger things, why limit them? Had M$ listened to Mr Dijkstra, there wouldnt't be so many "buffer overflow" attacks by bastard crackers. Also, the "float" and "double" number types (at least the ones defined by IEEE) used in many programming languages do actually encode special values like infinity, -infinity or "not a number": http://stevehollasch.com/cgindex/coding/ieeefloat.html Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > Wow.. I didn't know infinity is actually a number in computer > sciences.. Or is that a joke? :) > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Michiel van der > Blonk" <blonkm@z...> wrote: > > > > Professor Dijkstra actually claimed once there were only three > > numbers to be used in computer science: 0, 1 and infinity.

Usually there's a little gap because the moving pieces push/pull the centers out. > It's extremely fiddly to get in there, I need about 4 hands. Isn't that exactly what you have a girlfriend for? 1956. Re: Anniversary cube for speedcubing?
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 18:40:34 -0000

Many of the fastest cubers in the world now use the anniversary cube it seems. Also, it is what I am using currently and I am preparing another one this week. For speedcubing I recommend either that or the Black DIY kits (I would go with no stickers and order stickers separately from cubesmith.com). Initally there is a bit of getting used to, but I think it takes less time for the anniversary cubes to become good than for the regular cubes. Since the anniversary cubes (and black DIY) have arched center pieces, they very rarely pop. In some styles of cubing, they simply do not pop unless forced. For me it has never popped. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" <goljan@s...> wrote: > Guys, > is the anniversary cube from rubiks.com good for speedcubing? > And which is best buy for speedcubing today? > https://secure.rubiks.com/lvl3/index_lvl3.cfm? > lan=eng&lvl1=produc&lvl2=rubbrn&lvl3=newrls&lvl4=cub25a > Mirek
1957. Blindfoldcubing with eyes wide open : 2 ideas
From: "golgobridge" <fdrubik@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 18:57:41 -0000

Hi Friends,


Following recent events about BLD, I could not resist the
temptation to introduce 2 ideas I had to perform BLD...
... with eyes opened.

IDEA 1 (can use it in comp.)
You need 2 cubes C1 and C2, and 2 scrambling algs S1 and S2.
The 2 cubes must have the same color schemes. Let's say that
C2 is the own cube of the competitor (lubed, etc.).
Protocol :
a. scramble C1 with S1
b. scramble C2 with S2 followed by S1.
c. give C1 to competitor for inspection and memorization
d. take+hide C1 from competitor once memorization is done.
e. give C2 to competitor.
f. competitor now "blindfoldsolves" C2 with eyes opened as
if it were C1.
g. take C2 from competitor
h. apply inverse(S2) [the reverse of the sramble S2] to C2
i. check if C2 is now solved.

IDEA 2 (new category for rubik's cube, another BLD with
eyes wide opened)
A few weeks ago, I was thinking about a new category for
solving rubiks's cube. And I came up with this idea :
a. Have the cube scrambled by a friend.
b. The scrambled cube is called SC.
c. try to :
- solve the cube first
- bring it back to the initial scrambled state SC
(you don't know what the scrambling alg was in 1st place,
so it's rather difficult ?).
Well, I don't know how topcubers would do this. Obviously, there
are two solutions at least :
Solution1 : speedsolve the cube remembering all moves, and apply
all those moves in reverse order to get back to initial state
Solution2 : memorize initial state, speedsolve cube, and "blindsolve"
the cube in reverse order (easy with Stefan P.'s method).

Well, I've tried this idea number 2 a couple of times ;-).

Hope you enjoyed this,
--
François, Paris












1958. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Anniversary cube for speedcubing?
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 19:22:19 +0000 (GMT)

And how about the White DIY kit? d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> escreveu:Many of the fastest cubers in the world now use the anniversary cube it seems. Also, it is what I am using currently and I am preparing another one this week. For speedcubing I recommend either that or the Black DIY kits (I would go with no stickers and order stickers separately from cubesmith.com). Initally there is a bit of getting used to, but I think it takes less time for the anniversary cubes to become good than for the regular cubes. Since the anniversary cubes (and black DIY) have arched center pieces, they very rarely pop. In some styles of cubing, they simply do not pop unless forced. For me it has never popped. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" <goljan@s...> wrote: > Guys, > is the anniversary cube from rubiks.com good for speedcubing? > And which is best buy for speedcubing today? > https://secure.rubiks.com/lvl3/index_lvl3.cfm? > lan=eng&lvl1=produc&lvl2=rubbrn&lvl3=newrls&lvl4=cub25a > Mirek --------------------------------- YAHOO! 1959. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Video database at strangepuzzle.com
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 16:23:53 -0300 (ART)

Chris, I have a video but it's not at a site. Can I send it to you by email? Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> escreveu:I don't think it's a joke. I think the point is that any other numbers are artificial and there's no good reason why exactly that number should be used. For cube example, why do we have 15 seconds preinspection and not 30 or 7 or whatever? Well, 0 and 1 are a computer's blood, and if you really want to talk about larger things, why limit them? Had M$ listened to Mr Dijkstra, there wouldnt't be so many "buffer overflow" attacks by bastard crackers. Also, the "float" and "double" number types (at least the ones defined by IEEE) used in many programming languages do actually encode special values like infinity, -infinity or "not a number": http://stevehollasch.com/cgindex/coding/ieeefloat.html Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > Wow.. I didn't know infinity is actually a number in computer > sciences.. Or is that a joke? :) > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Michiel van der > Blonk" <blonkm@z...> wrote: > > > > Professor Dijkstra actually claimed once there were only three > > numbers to be used in computer science: 0, 1 and infinity. --------------------------------- YAHOO! 1962. Re: Blindfoldcubing with eyes wide open : 2 ideas
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 19:43:29 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "golgobridge" <fdrubik@f...> wrote: Interesting idea. It is not very hard to solve to a known final state, so... > IDEA 1 (can use it in comp.) One way to do this would be to memorize the cycle structure of S1 (by inspecting C1, of course). Mentally apply inverse of this to your C2 to work out what the final state must be. Solve to that final state. It would still be a real challenge to do it that way -- maybe there's an easier approach. > IDEA 2 Might be too easy? -- no BLD techniques needed apart from memorization of the required final state. Mike
1963. Re: Blindfoldcubing with eyes wide open : 2 ideas
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 19:52:40 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > IDEA 1 (can use it in comp.) > > One way to do this would be to memorize the cycle structure of S1 (by > inspecting C1, of course). Mentally apply inverse of this to your C2 > to work out what the final state must be. Solve to that final state. Hmm... you could get away with memorizing the position C1, since you can work out from that "what must go to to where" on the fly. I still think it's tough, though. Mike
1964. Re: Blindfoldcubing with eyes wide open : 2 ideas
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 20:29:10 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "golgobridge" > <fdrubik@f...> wrote: > > Interesting idea. It is not very hard to solve to a known final > state, so... > > > IDEA 1 (can use it in comp.) > > One way to do this would be to memorize the cycle structure of S1 (by > inspecting C1, of course). Mentally apply inverse of this to your C2 > to work out what the final state must be. Solve to that final state. > > It would still be a real challenge to do it that way -- maybe there's > an easier approach. Hmm, you make it sound like it's something hard? As far as I understand it, for the competitor it's *exactly* the same as normal blindsolving, just that he/she switches to a different cube between memorizing and solving. The real difference is for the judge, he'll need to scramble and descramble more. And it must all be checked very thoroughly using printouts showing the scrambled cubes, created by the computer. We must make absolutely sure that the judge doesn't make a mistake, otherwise the competitor could do everything right and not get it accepted. The advantage of the normal way is of course that it's immediately obvious whether the competitor got it right, and it looks much more natural, especially to noncubers. But this new idea would make cheating much harder. I'd suggest though to not solve with eyes open but to still use blindfolds. I like the idea. Francois, are you into cryptography? ;-) Cheers! Stefan
1965. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Blindfoldcubing with eyes wide open : 2 ideas
From: "FD-Rubik" <fdrubik@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 23:13:13 +0200

----- Original Message ----- From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Saturday, July 16, 2005 10:29 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Blindfoldcubing with eyes wide open : 2 ideas > Hmm, you make it sound like it's something hard? > > As far as I understand it, for the competitor it's *exactly* the same > as normal blindsolving, just that he/she switches to a different cube > between memorizing and solving. Indeed. > The real difference is for the judge, he'll need to scramble and > descramble more. And it must all be checked very thoroughly using > printouts showing the scrambled cubes, created by the computer. We > must make absolutely sure that the judge doesn't make a mistake, > otherwise the competitor could do everything right and not get it > accepted. Yes. You could also decide that S1=S2. I mean, you scramble C1 w/ S1, and C2 with S1^2 (S1 applied twice). Then, when you "blindsolve" C2 after memorizing C1, you get... ... C1 :-). I guess it must be easy for the judge to check this ;), he has got two cubes to compare. > The advantage of the normal way is of course that it's immediately > obvious whether the competitor got it right, and it looks much more > natural, especially to noncubers. But this new idea would make > cheating much harder. I'd suggest though to not solve with eyes open > but to still use blindfolds. Yes using blindfolds should be mandatory. Cheating with that method would be... mmmm.... DIFFICULT ? :). The main problem is that it would probably be less spectacular. In order to make it spectacular, we could decide that S2 is a pretty pattern (In that case the final cube is not "random", but looks pretty). > I like the idea. Francois, are you into cryptography? ;-) Not really, but I agree we could nickname the cubes by Alice and Bob ;-). -- FD.
1966. Re: Blindfoldcubing with eyes wide open : 2 ideas
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 21:05:56 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "golgobridge" <fdrubik@f...> wrote: > > IDEA 1 (can use it in comp.) > You need 2 cubes C1 and C2, and 2 scrambling algs S1 and S2. > The 2 cubes must have the same color schemes. I think they could have different color schemes since the competitor doesn't need to see C2 at all! Only C1 must have the color scheme that the competitor wants, and probably he'll choose the same as C2... Ok... as much as I like the idea, I must admit that for the sake of "naturalness" I'd rather do it the normal way and use full-face blindfolds or boards between head and cube in order to fight cheating. I think the only way to cheat and gain speed is to peek (or if a partner gives you solving commands through a hidden headphone or telepathy so you don't need to memorize at all). Using little dirty tricks like feeling the orientations can make it easier, but I'm convinced not faster than someone who does it well without cheating. General question: Do we really need to do more than we currently do against cheating, i.e. using blindfolds? Well, we usually blindsolve with the cube not straight in front of our eyes but much lower in a more comfortable position, so peeking isn't all that impossible. Especially if someone raises the head, and I know I do that sometimes when I try hard to remember something. I don't want it, but I do it. And the noncubers out there, including the media, might see the possibility of cheating. I'd like to prove better that I don't cheat. Cheers! Stefan
